text: 02/03: Yes, I did it and survived. We drove my trusty Toyota Corolla down the ramp at Bayfield and out accross lake Superior toward Madeline Island.I learned it's best to drive something a little higher off the the road. Then, just head out and keep moving, fast. Timid me, scooting along slooowly got stuck and tried to turn around and got more stuck. But with some rocking and pushing we were back on our way, this time back toward the shoreline - fast.For $5.00 we could have taken the big air sled. But then we would have missed the excitement.Also walked along the frozen beach fron to the under water caves.

The Talimena Scenic Drive is a 50 mile drive along the ridge of the Winding Stair Mountains. In late October and early November the drive offers some of the best fall foliage in the south. Year round, the drive has RV and primitive camping, day use picnic areas, and a scenic turn-out almost every mile.For the more active, the Ouachita National Rereation Trail offers 225 miles of "easy to moderate" hiking between Talimena State Park in Oklahoma to Pinnacle Mountain State Park just west of Little Rock, Arkansas. Trailhead parking and primitive campsites are located about seven miles apart in the section of trail that follows the ridge of the Winding Stair Mountians. There is a $3 fee to camp, but you have free access to the showers in the adjoining RV parks. If you want to "loop" back to your car, you can take the equestrain trails down through the Holson Valley.Plan a stop at the Queen Wilhelmina State Park atop Rich Mountain in Arkansas. Just east of the Okla/Ark state line, this park has something for every member to your family or group. In addition to RV and tent camping, the lodge and restaurant offer food and accommodations, there are many children's activities, and several easy nature trails. Both the senic drive and the Ouachita Trail pass through this park. Reservations may be needed in the summer or fall. Call (800) 264-2477.Don't overlook this section of the country. You'll have to get off the d... interstate, and it may "cost" you a day, but it will be well worth it. After taking the drive, you may want to enjoy the local lakes, museums, and other attractions in the area.

Beautiful Park! They have just started an audio tour service that uses your cell phone! Very easy to use and tour fee helps the park. They have a very entertaining presentation of Paul Revere's midnight ride, the battle at North Bridge and other sites along the park - highly recommended. More info at (--)

In late August 2005, we drove the scenic route to Mt. Rushmore. The morning was spent driving thru the Spearfish Canyon Scenic Byway. Speed limit is 35 MPH so you can enjoy the scenery. If you are in a rush, don’t take this route. Just before Lead is a new attraction called Presidents’ Park. It is a self guided 6 block walking tour, or you can rent mountain bikes to go farther. Stone carvings of 43 Presidents, costs about $8 person. On to Deadwood. What a fun place to walk around on another self-guided tour! Allow at least 3 hours to see town [free], Mt Moriah Cemetary [$1 per person] and visit some casinos and have lunch. There are staged shoot-outs on the Main Street at 2pm. We ate lunch at the Iron Horse. My husband chose all day breakfast, I had grilled chicken salad [$15 USD with tax & tip] . Friendly staff, good food. At Mt Moriah we saw graves of Wild Bill Hickock, Calmity Jane, and Potato Johnny. 3 Eights and 2 Aces was the hand Wild Bill was holding when he was shot by the dirty scoundrel Jack McCall. On to Hill City to shop at the Quilt Corral of Mistletoe Ranch. Very friendly and helpful staff and wonderful selection of fabrics. We opted to stay on Hwy 16 [no park fee] rather than take the Needles Highway through Custer State Park [$5 person]. Hwy 16 has the pigtail bridges and the 3 tunnels, with Mt Rushmore framed in the exit of the last tunnel. Be aware that there is a lot of braking, tight, winding curves and narrow roads. Great scenery, saw buffalo, deer, mountain goats. Mt Rushmore [$8 parking fee] is very impressive. As you walk toward the mountain you pass thru the Avenue of Flags, every state and territory is represented. The town of Keystone is very, very commercialized. We opted to overnight in Rapid City.

It was a MUST STOP for us this past August, but I was surprised by the admission system. Coming from Washington, DC area (where the Washington Monument, Lincolm Memorial, Jefferson Memorial, and FDR Memorial can all be enjoyed for free) I was surprised to see that Mt. Rushmore is technically free, but there is an $8 parking fee...and no real way to visit without parking.

If you are visiting Boston, consider seeing the Adams Historical Site. You can take the Red Line T to Quincy Center and find the National Park Service visitor's center across the street from the T station. The National Park Service offers a trolley ride (for a fee) to the John Adams and John Quincy Adams birthplaces as well as Peacefield which was the residence for generations of John Adams children and grandchildren. Really interesting to view the homes and the artifacts within. National Park Service rangers at the sites are very knowledgeable and give detailed presentations.

Fort Matanzas is the best! You don't have to pay for anything (although a few bucks in the ferry bucket isn't a bad idea). There is a beautiful park and picnic area under sprawling oak limbs, a nature trail, and a guided ferry that takes you out to the Fort... (which you can climb in and play with cannons and see the ocean)- essentially a mini version of the Castillo with no admission or big crowds, much easier to get a feel and soak in the history.

I stopped at West Pinnacles (near Soledad CA) during a road trip down 101. There are 2 entrances to the park, but you can only hike between them - not drive. The rock formations are beautiful. There are also caves to explore, but I didn't have a flashlight. The sunset glows off of the pinnacles - take a camera! Park entrance is $5 and is good for 7 days.

Although Fort Matanzas is free most of the time. If you spring for an extra $5/person you can go on the night tour. You have to check at the visitor's center or the website for availability, they don't run all the time. On the night tour you get to watch a total of 4 cannon firings. 2 while you are on the ferry on the way over and 2 watching from behind the fort. Both are a unique and exciting experience. During the evening program the fort is fully staffed with living history interpreters, so you get to see what it really was like. The views of the river and the fort at sunset are the great. There is also a musket firing demonstration.

My feelings are a little mixed on Mammoth Cave. I have been twice and loved it both times. Going down in the caves is awesome and a good time. I like going on the guided tours because the guides give you good info and its fun being a big group as well. However, i wish there was some independent exploration avaiable. There is none. I know the reasons, liability for people getting hurt and money. The cave tours are not cheap, but worth it. This place is awesome and when you go, use the camp site, it is cheap and you can walk to the are where the tours begin.

It was easy to do this, once we found the visitor center in the red brick business building on Hancock St, near the United First Parish Church. Park in the garage, 3rd floor or above, attached to the building & have the vistor center stamp parking ticket & parking is free. Once you pay for the tour at the visitor center, $5/adult, under 16 yrs old - free, they provide the trolley to the sites of the three houses. Learned alot about the Adams family on this tour. The tour guides we had were very knowledgeable. As expected, they don't tell you much about the conflicts & problems the Adams' had in politics & other areas. but you do learn about many of the good things they accomplished. You spend about 1/2 hr each on the guided tour of the first 2 houses, see first floors only. & about 1 hr at the Old house, where you go thru 1st & 2nd floor of the 3 stories, plus the Library building. Take your pictures outside when you can, because they move you along rather quickly to the next tour or next trolley. The history alone in these houses, makes it worth while to vist all 3. We started at the visitor center about 9:15am & got back there at the end about 11:30am.

If you havn't yet seen Mt. Rushmore, then what are you waiting for? This is iconic piece of Americana ranks right up there with the Statue of Liberty, Liberty Bells, and the various memorials in our nations capital. The last time we were there (June 2006) I was shocked that there is now an entrance fee. That's not the only thing that's changed in the past 15 years. There are now extensive walking paths (not stroller friendly) a two level parking lot, and food and souvenier vendors (inside the monument entrance). You are likely to be joined by hundreds, if not thousands, of fellow visitors. So, you may want to plan a visit either at opening time, or closing time.
Mount Rushmore is worth the trip if you are in the area. The parking charge of $7 is a little steep, but that is the only fee to access the site.

My friends and I stayed in Gettysburg and decided to take a day trip to Sharpsburg to see Antietam Battlefield. We are all big Civil War buffs and were told it was a must see. We decided to hire a private guide for $50.00 which was definately worth it! He came with us in our car and basically went over the whole battle from beginning to end. This took about 2 1/2 hours. I have to say that was one of the most unbelievable tours I ever took. The tour guide was amazing! He went over everything with us and painted the most clearest pictures in our heads. He was patient and answered any questions we might have. He even took pictures of us at Burnside's Bridge. Even thought this battlefield is not as big as Gettysburg it is a must see. Standing on that battlefield especially near Bloody Lane just gives you chills. Its very quiet and peaceful here with no crowds and the views are magnificent! I definately recommend this battlefield to any one who enjoys Civil War history. Tip: Get the private tour guide! Its worth the time and money!!

My wife & I followed the Island Trail. As you follow the path you pass in front of lots of caves & there are frequent displays showing how life was for the Sinagua Indians living in this quite precarious location. We really enjoyed the peace & quiet that the place offers & saw some beautiful birds flying around the canyon. We took about 75 mins to complete the trail & we didn't rush.

We stopped here on our first RV trip, since it sounded interesting. It was kinda cool seeing the rock drawings, and the hikes were not bad at all, but people who have mobility problems might have difficulty. Our major gripe was that since we had an RV, we were not allowed to drive into the park, though we still had to pay the vehicle entrance fee ($1), and then walk to the trail entrances where everyone else was parked.

Petroglyph National Monument is just a few miles outside of Albuquerque, so it is an easy side trip as well as being interesting and educational. You can skip the Visitor Center if you are mainly interested in looking at the Petroglyphs (rock drawings made by Native Americans 400-700 years ago). You can continue on Unser Bl. and turn right at the sign for Boca Negra Canyon. There is a $2 parking fee and a few different trails that will lead you to numerous Petroglyphs. The images are cool and you may see some wild life too!

MCNP is a cave lover’s paradise. The park itself consists of trails, picnic facilities, cabins, campsites, inn, restaurant etc. You can purchase tickets for cave tours at the visitors center (plenty of parking), you’ll be transported on a bus to the cave. There are numerous tours you can go on within the park, there are also a number of privately owned cave attractions scattered on the perimeter of the park. While you are in the area, you could check out the Corvette museum and assembly plant in nearby Bowling Green. In terms of admission for the tours (government and private), you’re looking at anywhere from 7-16 dollars. Don’t forget your comfortable shoes.

Amazing beauty can be found in the canyons and mountains of Angeles National Forest, which can be reached in 30 minutes from Downtown LA. Angeles Crest Highway rises to 8000', with walks up to 10,000 foot mountains nearby. Mt. Wilson offers fantastic views of the LA Region, and on a clear day out to Catalina Island. Switzers, 20 minutes outside La Canada, provides a beautiful streamside walk, and a waterfall view, and stays cool even on hot summer days. The trail on the east side of JPL up the Arroyo is terrific. Be sure to purchase a Forest Adventure Pass for parking (available at Sport Chalet in La Canada and elsewhere). The park is laced with fire roads that are perfect for mountain biking, as well as hiking trails and backpacking camps. For overnight camping, drive an hour from La Canada out Angeles Crest. Don't miss it.

They have done a wonderful job preserving Andrew Johnson's homes. This site covers multiple buildings spread out over a small part of the town. There is his early home, tailor shop, final home, burial site, and a visitor’s center. There was no admission for any of the buildings and the tour guide at President Johnson's final home did a wonderful job explaining everything and answering the many questions that our group asked. The visitor’s center had many displays that were very easy to read and follow. We love visiting the homes of our presidents and this one was one of the best. A great history lesson for those who do not know much about this president.

This National Park showcases the historic Fort with its unusual moat, drawbridge, high stone walls, and cannons, built by the new American nation for protection against a British invasion and used intermittently by the military until World War II. The scenery of the Potomac River shoreline is beautiful, with views across the River to Mount Vernon, Va. and northward to downtown D.C. in the distance. The park has a circular, flat roadway excellent for hiking, skating, or bicycling. There are picnic areas, fishing, a lighthouse, a small playground and basketball court. Improvements were recently made to the shoreline hiking trail (which few people know about) which follows the River from the lighthouse southward. There is a tiny bookstore and museum open limited hours. Admission is free after 5:00 until sundown, and at most times in winter. Otherwise an admission fee.

You have to pay to park but then you can walk up to the obsevation deck and get some good shots. We were there in the off season, early May, so no crowds. It was a cloudy day. We also got good pics from Iron Mountain road with pigtail bridges and tunnels along the route. See my pics.
As many of you know, there is a fee to park at Mount Rushmore, but the parking pass is an annual pass, so you can use the pass for several visits in one year.

This was by far my favorite activity after a week in the Black Hills and we had to go three times to finally see it with a blue sky (or see it at all since the first time it was too foggy to see). This happened to be the cheapest thing we did while in South Dakota--everything else was much more expensive. And considering we went to the Lighting Ceremony another evening-we got our money's worth out of the $10 fee.

I visited WSNM in March of 2007 and I'm so glad I did!!! Approaching the dunes and catching that first glimpse of them, you're not at all prepared for the way that sight takes your breath away. The dunes and hills resemble humongous mounds of snow all over the place. I arrived a couple of hours before closing, so I wasn't able to body surf on the dunes, but I hear it's a must and loads of fun. There's a ranger guided tour that takes you out onto the dunes, and is loaded with lots of info, and does not have a separate fee. Take lots of pics b/c it's worth it!!!

I give this park 5 stars because the beauty just fully captured my attention while I was there, 100%. You cannot go to this park, drive over the hills, pay admission, and leave after seeing it from one overlook. It just would not be a sensible visit. You should go to each of the overlooks. The view of the deep gorge is almost different from every one. It's really amazing to see how a river could have forced a gorge that deep. I would make it a must-see stop if you're in the state of Colorado.

After paying $2.00 to park and watching the video at the visitor's center, we headed over to the "gray house with the red fire hydrant", which was the meeting spot for all tours. We waited 10 minutes or so and then our tour guide lead us into the house. We saw all the rooms, took pictures and basically squeezed into each hot spot in order to get a glimpse of everything. We must've had about 20 people on our tour, annoying kids included. The one kid tried to climb onto Mrs. Lincoln's bed! I couldn't believe how irresponsible the parents were the whole time. In fact, this family ruined my experience.

As you approach the park from either side-it's uphill. We went on July 3rd and had a terrible time with parking. The monument itself was awesome though. It's free to get in, we paid the $5 for the audio tour and really enjoyed that. The path and terrain to the monument is not difficult, but it's not short either. Be prepared to walk. There is a neat movie explaining the history (about 15 minutes) we also toured the studio. I'd say you could do it in half a day easily if you are an active person. We did not buy food in the park, although there is plenty of opportunity.

We just returned from a week in Kentucky and Mammoth Cave was certainly one of the highlights. We found the staff to be very helpful and the cave to absolutely amazing. We did two tours. One we booked several weeks in advance to insure we were on the trips that we wanted. Our daughters (9 and 11) went on the Trog Tour. They completely loved it. The rangers were great with the kids and the kids enjoyed being able to see things that weren't on any other tour. Here's a tip... don't be late for any of your booked tours. Literally, we were three minutes late for the Frozen Niagra tour and we missed the bus. We were not able to drive to entrance. The staff was very apologetic but there were no other tours available, the were very gracious to return our money (less a cancellation fee). We also went on the Self Guided Discovery tour. We really enjoyed having the time to ourselves and there were several rangers along the way to ask all of our questions.

Mount Rushmore was fabulous. We got there pretty early in the morning, so it wasn't crowded yet, which was nice. Make sure you bring cash, though, since parking is $10 and they only accept cash. The rest of the site is free. We were able to walk around a little of the Presidential Walk, which was well laid out. There were tee pees for the the kids to check out and a Ranger there talking about them. There are great signs to read about the presidents featured on the mountain. A great thing to see.

I couldn't believe that after 40 years of wanting to see this place, I finally took the time to visit. It was wonderful. It costs $10.00 to park but it's an annual pass so visit as often as you can. We got there fairly early (which I recommend during the summer rush) and found a parking place right away. We walked around and did the Presidential Walk, which gives you excellent views of the presidents. The lecture about buffalo skins and teepee making is the first top on the walk; it is also interesting. I was awestruck about the whole monument. To see it as you're walking up from the parking garage can only be described as breathtaking.

We took two tours on a Saturday in July. I booked them on-line two weeks in advance. We took the New Entrance tour in the morning and the Star Chamber tour in the evening. I am so glad I booked them in advance - the visitor center was a mad house. At 10 am most tours were sold out for the day. I had to stand in the same line as first time ticket purchasers to pick up my reserved tickets which was a little crazy.

A very well preserved NP. On the first day, we did the self drive tour and enjoyed it, but nothing like the second day. We got a battlefield guide who took us on an extended tour of the battlefield, three and a half hours. Found out interesting facts you would not know of without this type of tour. If the expense is not an issue, hire the guide. If you are a civil war buff or just a history fan, do hire a guide. Although not as fancy as Gettysburg NP, we actually enjoyed it as much if not more, much less crowded and much better preserved as it was the day of the battle.
My family and I traveled out west from Illinois...By Car, with gas prices over $4.00/gallon.

We are constantly in search of good camping spots in Colorado. This spot is about a 3.5 to 4 hour drive from Denver. If it's good weather, make sure to take Cottonwood Pass from Buena Vista instead of going all the way down through Gunnison. It saves about 45 minutes of driving, but the road is pretty rough.

We purchased the Annual Adams National Historical Park Pass that is good for one year from date of purchase for $10 which admits cardholder and three adults…..a good deal considering if the two of us purchased a day pass it would have been $10! We had toured the Park a few years ago, but wanted to return after seeing the HBO Miniseries. Since it was late in the season, there was not much of a line and we were able to get onto the 9:45am tour, only getting there at 9:35am. There is free parking (on weekends) behind the Visitors Center, which includes some video as well as some other interesting Adams facts and a small gift shop.

No exaggeration on the title… When I walked through this Revolutionary War Battlefield, I was constantly reminded of the game “king of the mountain”. A 1.5 mile paved interpretative trail meanders where local militias surrounded a crown loyalist army on top of a ridge. KMNMP had plenty of parking, plenty of trails, free admission, picnic areas, informative visitor’s center, and located next to Kings Mountain SP.. It’s not to far from I-85, Crowder’s Mountain SP, and Cowpens National Battlefield.

I've been on a LOT of cave tours. Here's why I rated this one as excellent... it is the perfect length and difficulty level for small children (and older people that can't get around so well). Adult tickets are $10. Kids under 6 are free.
Not as spectacular as Bryce, but you pass through it if you approach Bryce from the West. Very pretty formations.

The site is reached via a 8 mile dirt road. In dry weather it is a good surface. There are marker signs announcing the start and the end of the park. I found 1 sign in the park, but otherwise you are on your own. The site is unstaffed and there is no admission charge. What you get for your journey seems to be some atmosphere and a few prompts for what life may once have been like. A page from Wikipedia will tell you more about life in 19th Century forts.

Amazing jewel in the middle of the desert. We drove down from Rio Rancho, NM and arrived at the park w/in 5 hours (several stops, 3 kids....). Stopped at the visitor center, the used/rental sleds were sold out so we spent $15 EACH buying a new one (probably would fetch $7 at Wal-Mart, but hey you are in the middle of no-where). Drove into the park and found what we considered to be one of the last covered picnic tables left. Recommendation, get there early so you can secure a good, covered picnic area as you need it, the Sun is brutal. Set-up camp and attached the ceremonial kite to the car (flys all day by itself as there is a constant light wind....). Had lunch, kids sledded and over all, we just had a wonderful day at WSNP. We are looking forward to our next and next and next visit back to the NP. I wish that we lived close enough to warrant a seasonal pass as we would probably go there every weekend as the opportunities to connect with the family, explore nature and just have a wonderful time are endless.

Loved Walnut Canyon! It's a beautiful, historic site that can be experienced for $10 per car load. Hiking trails of various lengths for the experienced and inexperienced (we being inexperienced with two daughters, ages 6 and 9). If you can, take the 200+ stairs down into the canyon to get an up close look at old cliff dwellings - it's definitely worth the climb. We almost skipped this attraction because of cold and snow. I am very glad we braved the elements!

We have visited Mammoth Cave several times over the years, and the kids are finally old enough for one of the longer tours. The Grand Avenue Tour is a 4 1/2 hr tour that winds through a large section of the cave. It is rated as difficult, and if you have trouble walking up and down steep slopes, this may not be for you. The kids (8 and 13) had no trouble with the walking. There are frequent stops for narrative from the guide, so a reasonably fit person will have no trouble with the tour. The steps were easy compared to the occasionally steep and slippery slopes. 90% of the tour is through tubes formed by the river long ago. You will see large rooms, narrow canyons, wide tubes, and a few tight squeezes between rocks. It can get a bit monotonous since all the rocks look about the same. It is a dry cave, so other than the Frozen Niagra at the very end of the tour, you will not see the stalagtites and other formations that are plentiful in a wet cave (like Diamond Caverns). The guide was informative with a lot of talk about the geology and history of the cave. You eat lunch around 1 hour into the tour. The box lunch of a ham or turkey sandwhich, chips, apple, cup of vegetable soup, and drink is $7.50. They also have PB&J. The food was unremarkable, but hey, you're eating in a cave. Tour size was around 70 people, so don't expect any enroute commentary unless you are right behind the guide. This is a good tour for people who have an interest in cave geology and would like a nice walk, but you can see many of the more interesting features of the cave on shorter, less expensive tours.

The Quarry building closed some years ago because it began shifting on the land so the only thing open now is the Visitor Center. This was our 3rd trip to DNM and if your in Dinosaur Country, be sure to drop by. Even though it is a national monument, there is no entry fee.

This would be a great excursion for the budget minded traveler. The visitor center is free and has a few things to see. Park service staff recommended that we hike Boca Negra Canyon since it was our first visit and we had limited time Cost is a mere $2 per vehicle parking fee. It takes about 1-2 hours to hike all of the trails at Boca Negra Canyon, but you can pack a picnic lunch and enjoy a 1/2 day out with the family at minimal expense. Take some time to learn about petroglyphs before you go and challenge the kids to find as many different ones as they can.

We traveled to the Lincoln Boyhood National Monument in June 2008 while we were in the area visiting Holiday World and Splashin Safari. This National Park is very inexpensive as it was $5.00 for a family and that was good for 7 days if we wanted to go back. The main building was nicely done and had a good movie. We then toured the grounds which were well kept. It might be a tough walk in the heat and humidity of summer, but it wasn't too bad the morning we were there. The grounds contain a working farm with animals and actors who are dressed for the time period. One thing that was a little disappointing was the cabin that Lincoln built with his father is not there (anymore). However, there is an outline on the ground of where it stood. I know it has been a long time since Lincoln lived there, but it would have been neat to see the cabin. This, like many other attractions in the area, is isolated and is a little bit of a drive off the Interstate, but it is a good look at the early life of our 16th President.

Worth seeing if you are a huge Lincoln fan and are in the area for a couple of days. If you have to choose between this and the Lincoln Presidential Museum though, chose the Lincoln Presidential Museum instead. Onsight parking for $2.00. Tour will take about 45 minutes for everything.
$10 to get in with 4 in the van, can't beat that. And we all got a t-shirt for $5 each...not a bad shirt .

You have to see this place in person to be able to fully understand how amazing this place is. It's even free to enter, you only have to pay for a parking permit to allow you to visit as many times as you like. The light up of the faces is a must see, this takes place every summer at 9.30 pm, at 9 pm there is a movie showing the history of Mount Rushmore plus a great history lesson on the lives of the four presidents. For me this as to be one of the greatest places in America.

Mt Rushmore is somewhat interesting. That's all. The viewing area is well done, which reminded me of my favorite zoo, just without the animals. Amazing amounts of people there to look at the engineering accomplishment. Everything in the area surrounding Rushmore is a tourist trap extravanganza. Nothing worth the stop. Well, maybe something for the kids. Actually there were literally about 4 dozen signs littering the road to Rushmore with child friendly advertizements of Alligators and such for 'Reptile Gardens', which was a tiny little thing when we finally passed it. I felt bad for the parents whose kids would obviously want to stop at the trap. I almost regret taking the time to go to Mount Rushmore, which was extensive. The price for parking was extravagant. The winding roads to and from made me slightly ill, but I'm pretty sensitive about such things, and most will probably not be affected.

We stopped here on our way back from a rafting trip. The value for the money was great. In the visitor center you can watch a quick movie which has great production quality and provides the history of how the fossils came to be. Outside a ranger gives a talk about the park and has hands on demos of the fossils. It was a really nice experience and very affordable at only $3 per person (good for 1 week).

Even for visiting on a Wednesday in mid-June there were a lot of people. BUT, the number of people did not distract from the visit in any way. The monument is, of course, awe-inspiring for its scale and the era in which it was completed. The main viewing area is wide and accessible, providing plenty of vantage points for the classic straight-on views for all the people visiting. I walked on the path closer to the monument, which was worth my time, getting closer and different views of the monument. The sculpture's building and accompanying ranger talk provide interesting history. A cafeteria on site had reasonable park-priced fare (I liked my buffalo burger) and plenty of seating (when I was there). $10 to park. I spent about 2 hours at the Memorial.

Two hour tour through the man made entrance. Tour was wonderful and amazing! Tour guide had lots of stories and was funny. Took tons of pictures and well worth your time.This is my second visit in seventeen years and it's still amazing.I wish I had, had time to go on the other tours. I also found that it didn't cost a arm and leg.Adults 13 and up twelve dollars and 12 and under 8 dollars for the new entrance tour.

Is it me or is there a little bit of interstate rivalry between Kentucky and Indiana on the matter of which state contributed most to Lincoln’s character? Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial, located in Lincoln City, Indiana, focuses on his boyhood and young adult years-- The admission for the museum and film is like $3.00 individual / 5.00 for families-- While I always enjoy and recommend an NPS, overall this place is pretty standard in terms of content, historical collections, education media, etc.

Ft. Washington used to be overrun with partying people who were overly noisy and tossed a lot of trash. They started charging admission to cover the cost of maintaining the property, and today it's a wonderful mixture of dog-walkers, exercisers, and families. People fish near the lighthouse or explore the old fort.

The 1.5 hour scenic tour was only $8 per person, which is a bargain in my book. Although a lot of the cave looks very similar, there are plenty of unique items throughout the cave that make the tour worthwhile. Two things to remember: 1) Its only 50 degrees F in the cave all the time, so wear pants and a jacket. 2) Call ahead to book your tickets. Only 30 people can go down per tour, so they sell out quick. If you arrive on a busy day, expect to wait several hours. There also is not a place to eat anywhere around here, so you may want to factor that in as well. The entire tour is on a paved trail, or metal walkway with railings. Very safe, even for smaller children.

A very good bargain at $10 per car. Plenty of parking in a newer, well laid out parking structure. The hall of flags and viewing terrace were clean and well laid out. The presidential hiking trail allows an up-close view of the monument from the base of the rock pile. Take your time when hiking, as the return path can become strenuous. Definitely worth a look if you are in the area. Arrive in the morning to make sure the sun is directly on the faces. Excellent gift shop...don't forget to buy your 'four documents of freedom' reproductions.

Did this in mid-July in the morning hrs. I think it would be too hot to do any later in the day during the summer. We did Boca Negra trail. Kids had a blast climbing up a small mountain (hill) strewn with vesicular basalt (volcanic) rocks. We saw a lot of petroglyhs on the approx 30 min hike to the top and back down. The trail is paved and certain areas have steps and handrails to assist your climb. There were restrooms and a water fountain, but take water with you while on the trail. At $2 per vehicle, you can't beat the price and it provided a couple hours of fun and history for our family. We didn't see any snakes, but there were signs warning you to beware. We did see rock squirrels (which looked like chipmunks), lizards and rabbits. We took a picnic lunch and ate at a shaded table in Boca Negra Canyon.

What an incredible way to spend the afternoon... for $6, our family of six was able to watch the Antietam documentary, watch a group of 'soldiers' fire of a civil war era cannon, and get an in-depth ranger tour of the battlefield. An incredible value for something that is both very interesting and really educational.

The monument is very impressiv, the charge is very reasonable and the ticket lasts for many months, there are two different hikes you can take and plenty of parking available. We went there several times during our stay in Keystone and heard a lot of great things about the lightshow. So we went on one evening.

Sliding Rock in the Pisgah National Forest is the perfect natural water slide with a freezing cold pool at the bottom. We drove out of our way just to visit this again. This was my third time through here in the past 30 years and it has changed a lot. They now have lifeguards, a changing station and an admission fee (only $1.00/person though, so well worth it). You can get in line and go down as often as you wish. Also stopped at the nearby Looking Glass Falls which was beautiful.

Learn how the site was selected & why the four presidents' faces were chosen. Be sure to plan enough time to see everything. Take a guided tour, spend time in the Indian site, walk the Presidential Trail, visit the sculptor's studio & have lunch. Early and mid morning times the best. Gets crowded in the afternoon. Parking is $10 and convenient. A camera is a must--get someone to take your group's picture with the Presidents' faces in the background. Walking shoes will make the trail easier to maneuver.
There’s a lot of history here and admission is free.

We elected to drive down to Alamogordo the evening before and stay the the budget White Sands Motel. The $50 room was well worth the $$ just to get to the park before the crowds and the hot sun the next morning. We really enjoyed the 4.5 mile Alkali Flats hike. Bring a camelback and prepare to be all alone trekking up and down dunes for as far as the eyes can see! We got the most memorable pictures. Then we drove up to Cloudcroft in the mountains for a cool late lunch, and down into Carlsbad just in time to see the night flight of bats. What a perfect day!

The fee is annual, so you can visit multiple days. We visited Mt. Rushmore for the evening lighting ceremony and the next morning. It's absolutely amazing. There are trails you can hike, ranger talks and a film about Mt. Rushmore.

Your first stop will be the visitor center. After paying $6 for the carload to enter the parking area, me (25 yr old male), my older brother and my parents, decided to start things off with a little picnic. On the side of the parking area are a few picnic tables, just be warned, there are a lot of gnats! Otherwise it was peaceful. Then we went to the visitor center which is mainly just a small building with materials on the town itself and some items for sale. Then we all jumped on the shuttle bus (comfortable and air conditioned) where we headed to the town of Harpers Ferry.

The visitor center is nice to visit. Buy a disc to slide down the dunes. We visited Aug 25,2009 and got lucky with the heat. It was cloudy and a bit damp. You can stop in most wide places and climb around but follow the road deep into the dunes for the best dunes. It cost adults $3.00. Bring your own water,hat and sunshade. If you plan to hike deep bring a a GPS or a compass unless you incredibly lucky. This was a lot of fun and family oriented.

We've been in a lot of caves and this wasn't our favorite as it didn't really have anything special to it but it was nice and long and our guide made it worthwhile. He was excellent and definitely lively. we did the scenic tour in the morning (with reservations) at $8/ea.

i enjoyed this; everything is outdoors so go when weather is good else you will be disappointed; there is side trail which is handicapped acessible but does not go to the cliffside dwellings; you can step into some of the actual cliffside dwellings but it takes 185 steps but i did not find it difficult; young kids and older folks should be able to do it easily; visitor center has huge windows with fabulous views but the exhibits are below average; they show a video on various national monuments in the area upon request; entry fee is $5 per car; details on national park service website; you can spend between one to four hours visiting

The trolley and the three house tours only cost $5. I was visiting a friend that has lived near Quincy most of her life and had never before visited this treasure. Since I am a history buff it was definitely on my "want to do list" so my friend reluctantly tagged along with me. Both of us had a great time and were very impressed with how easy it was to get the trolley from the Visitor Center in town, and how knowledgeable the guides were at each location. The guides at both locations provided a lot of information, though the guide at Peacefield was outstanding and very personable. My friend is talking about going back again and taking more people there when they come to visit her. I recommend this tour to anyone visiting the greater Boston area.

You can see the complete carvings in all it's grandeur right from the side of the road. There is even a cut out for you to stop at and take pictures. So if the cost of going to see the monument may stop you. Still drive up and the whole family can view this amazing site for free. All the information is available on line about the monument. It's a shame the cost is so much to park your car and see the same site. I would not recommend paying to park and view the monument. But do think we should all see this amazing tribute to our fore fathers.

Now, I rarely give 5 stars to anything, but Valley Forge Park is absolutely my favorite park in the world. I come here for the acres and acres of green hills and wild forests and 200 year old buildings. I come here to escape the disturbing overdevelopment of the Philly suburbs and their artificially landscaped and costly manicured lawns. I come here to see the Inner and Outer Line Defenses and General Knox's artillery park, to hear a park ranger at the newly renovated General Washington's HQ and Valley Forge Station, to feed the omnipresent deer, to see reenactors fire off antiquated muskets, and to pay thanks to General Von Steuben for his masterly German training of the U.S. troops. I don't come here with a conceited attitude expecting Disneyland and fireworks every day or to be waited on hand and foot by a team of obsequient Park toadies. This park, like everything, is what YOU make of it. If you come expecting the Park to make it what you want it to be, you'll leave disappointed.

We began our late-September trip to Petroglyph National Monument at the Visitor’s Center. Our group spoke with a very friendly staff member who, after asking several questions regarding the goals of our visit, suggested we try the Boca Negra Canyon Trails. The Boca Negra Canyon Trails are three relatively short trails (5, 15 and 30 minutes) a quick drive away from the Visitor’s Center where you can quickly and easily see quite a few petroglyphs. We paid $1 to enter the Boca Negra Canyon Trails park and walked the 5-minute Macaw trail and the 15-minute Cliff Base trail. Due to very uneven terrain and the well-advertised possibility of snakes, it is recommended that visitors wear sturdy, closed-toe shoes.

When you least expect it, you can be most amazed. From Texas to New Mexico we had to take a different route itself in order to go to this place but in the end few extra hours were well worth it. People look for becahes with such white sands but I have never seen such pristine and clear white sand anywhere in my life. The reason is a lake nearby, however a 45 minute drive surrounded by large expanse of such pretty pious whiteness is a great and unique experience in itself. Definitely worth visiting with hardly 3$ cost per person. Maybe go early in the morning and you could feel it to be your own territory with no crowd and can get picturesque photos too.

As you drive along the highway, your first glimpse of this wonderful monument to 4 great leaders peeks thru the trees. I had the awesome opportunity to meet one of the people who actually worked on Mt. Rushmore. He wrote a book and was in the gift shop autographing it. The lighting ceremony at night is a treat that shouldn't be missed. Your entry pass is good for a few days so make sure you return at night when this wonder is fully lit.

I could say this, "...better then expected," about our whole 10 day trip to New Mexico. The variety of scenic panoramas was amazing. From the spectacular Carsbad Caverns to sophisticated Santa Fe; from the 9000 foot shops at Cloudcroft to the cliff dwellings at Bandiler Mponument, left us saying, "WOW!" But the biggest surprise had to be White Sands. I thought it might rate a mildly interesting day trip. The drive from Almagordo (about 10 miles) was mostly flat wasteland. An adobe Welcome Center is a few yards off of Rt 70. A brief stop for a for snacks and water (there's no restaurant) and you're on your way. A 16 mile paved loop road takes you into an unreal world that becomes more amazing the further you go. When you finally reach the apex of the loop you are in a white world of fine gypsum sand. You can climb the dunes and feel the amazingly cool sand on your bare feet. Youngsters have a ball sliding down the dunes on plastic saucers. We were there in early Sept. The temp was in the low 80s. It was a perfect day but temp can reach 100 in the summer and wind storms can close the road. There are plenty of trails for hikers but once you're away form the vegetated areas there is nothing but whiteness to the horizon. Hikers who want to challenge this envoirment are warned to thave a compass. White Sands National Monument...worth the trip?. New Mexico, worth the trip? Most definitely.

I haven't been to Mount Rushmore for the past 20 years and didn't know what to expect--I certainly didn't go with high expectations. From the minute we pulled into the park admissions area I was impressed. Only a $10 fee for parking, and that pass is valid the entire year! A great parking garage with ample parking left us knowing our belongings were safe--and we weren't hearded around. We got to the level of Mount Rushmore and saw that the entire obversatory area has been redone and it's magnificent. Very patriotic, very impressive. There is a new trail you can take and get really close to the mountain too! We did it all and it was one of our favorite parks of our South Dakota trip.

My wife and I recently traveled to Phiadelphia for an October weekend. We spent an enjoyable 5 - 6 hours at Valley Forge National Historical Park, which is only a 30- minute drive from the Philadelphia airport. It was a crisp fall day; the leaves were turning. The day began gray and rainy, but eventually the sun came out. We started at the Visitors Center which has a well-done museum containing artifacts from the site, and exhibits portraying the life of the soldiers during their encampent at Valley Forge during the winter of there. We also viewed a 15 minute video that was at best, average. There are lots of walking trails, and we took advantage of a loop trail that is actually paved and winds its way around the park. The loop trail is about 5 miles and winds its way through woods (we spotted a deer), across fields, and around the main parade grounds where the soldiers were trained by Von Steuben. There were no battles at the site, but it was an important staging ground for the Continental Army during the bitter winter of 1777-78. The Continental Army gave bonuses of $12 to the soldiers who could complete their log cabins in the shortest amount of time. At first we were disappointed because other than some log cabins -- most of which appeared to be reproductions of the originals -- there wasn't a lot to see. We were ready to leave but then decided to find the house at the park that was George Washington's headquarters. That was the highlight of the visit. The house was built sometime in the 18th century; much of it is restored, but there are some original parts of the house. Gen. Washington rented it from its owner. The park service guide did a wonderful job telling us about the house. If you go to Valley Forge, don't miss George Washington's headquarters. If you have young chidren, they will enjoy the "reenactors" who are dressed in 18th century military uniforms. Guided bus tours of the site are available for a fee. This is worth a visit if you have any interest in the Revolutionary War.

I envy people who got to see Mount Rushmore before the construction of the new visitor center. The memorial itself compliments the natural landscape surrounding it, as does the original Frank Lloyd Wright visitors' center. Now half the mountain is defaced by a gray granite monstrosity (gift shop, restaurant, ice cream shop, t-shirt shop, parking garage, etc.) and amphitheater that looks like an unholy combination of a suburban outlet mall and something out of a Nazi-propaganda film. If you want to see the faces of the presidents as they were probably intended to be seen, view them from one of the many overlooks in adjoining Custer State Park, where you can see them without Disneyland in the way. If you absolutely must go to the memorial itself, look in the other direction. The unobstructed view of the badlands and prairies stretching from the edge of the Black Hills, which is available from the top of the parking garage, is one of the best in the area. Oh, by the way, forget using your National Parks Pass, you're still going to get socked with a nice "parking fee."

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: If you like presidential history or anything related to LBJ, you'll enjoy this Historical Park. It's divided into two areas(so you'll need a car) with one part in Johnson City and the other 14 miles away in Stonewall. The visitor center is located in Johnson City. It features some nice displays on LBJ and the timeline of what was happening at the same time. It features two films, one on LBJ and the other on his wife Lady Bird. I thougth the one on Lady Bird was nice. LBJ's boyhood home is across the street. You can only view it during a tour which is free. I think it's worth a visit. The Johnson City area also features the Johnson Settlement. I frankly think you can skip this part especially if it's a hot day or it's hard for you to walk. It was a long walk for something that's not really that exciting to see. As for the Park in Stonewall, you stop at the state park and pick up a CD for your visit. The CD includes some information on what you'll see and stories from LBJ. It was very helpful and free. I liked hearing LBJ on part of the CD describe some of his events. You are also able to stop at the Texas White House and take a tour. It costs one dollar and at the moment only features 3 rooms. As the National Park refurbishes more rooms they will become open to the public. I thought it was very neat to see inside the house and on the front lawn. One note about this national park. You now drive through this area in your OWN car. You no longer take a tour bus. It took me about 4 hours to visit both parks, but I also watched both films at the visitor center. I think you could easily do the whole thing in 2 hours if you wanted without feeling cheated.

Lots of petroglyphs and a nice trail along the hills. Easy walk. Lots of parking but be sure to self pay as the rangers check often. Try to stay on the path though-there are snakes and other critters around that you may not notice.

Visisted July 20, 2009, with husband and kids (17 & 12). You just can't believe how large this is until you are actually there. The line to get in to park was a little ong but moved quickly. It is definately worth the $10 to park so that you can take the trail that leads right up under the monument. There are several picutre spots along the trail, but if your not up for hiking be sure to only take the easy part of the trail. We started on the easy side and then thought that the difficult side would be fine because it looked to be all downhill; however, it does climb again and can be difficult for some. We visisted the sculptures studio which was just OK. There is a rather large gift shop, but it looks to be crowded most of the time. We liked the trail the best and got some awesome pictures.

(Our visit—30 March, 2010) This was hands down my favorite site during our 9 day vacation in Arizona (and yes, we did visit the Grand Canyon). It was just so beautiful to walk the island trail, circling the canyon, passing the 700 year old homes of the Sinagua people, in ruins, but close enough to touch. The pine trees and brush throughout the canyon made for the most striking views. In total, there were 300 rooms built throughout the canyon (you will pass 25 dwellings along the trail), so everywhere you look, you see some evidence of another ‘home’ built into a nook of the canyon walls. This was in such stark contrast to other ancient dwellings I had visited which sat by themselves…this was nothing less than a thriving community. I like how a previous reviewer put it being like a ‘condominium settlement’. The island trail is a one mile loop that takes you 185 feet into the canyon (about half way into the canyon). There are a total of 480 steps on the whole loop (240 each way) with long stretches of pathways in between your decent and ascent. Because of the 7,000 feet altitude, it can seem like a harder climb; but no one is timing you, stop and rest along the way (there are benches). Have on good walking shoes. There was a drink vending machine at the top of the Island Trail for those that haven’t planned ahead. If you are unable to handle the sometimes steep areas of the island trail, there is a flatter Rim trail and an absolutely gorgeous view from the visitor center’s windows. Enjoy!!!

First a word of warning: flooding in January 2010 washed out the approach to the bridge that carries you between the visitors center and the trailhead. Thus, until the road is repaired, you must park next to the stables and walk the last mile along the road to the begining of the trail. That means a three mile walk instead of a one mile walk. The walk along the road is flat and easy and should not present too much difficulty to most people. Just thought you should know. (While the bridge is out of service, they are waiving the $3 entry fee.)

We thought the "park" was a little disorganized. There was no signage off the freeway leading to it. If we hadn't had a Garmin we would have had a hard time finding it. Once we got there, it was again not well marked. We weren't sure which parking garage to go into. Fortunately we found a parking on the street. The visitors' center itself doesn't have a lot to offer. There's a small gift shop, restrooms, some models of the outside of the houses, an open theatre area which was showing some strange musical production, and a counter with 2 rangers. We went the day were were leaving Boston and had to catch a flight, so our time was limited. In talking to the rangers we had the impression that the trolley was the only option for tours, but that you could drive to the different sites/ homes, and tour the grounds. We were disappointed but thought that was our only option. The next trolley tour was over an hour away in starting and "they were running a little late". We drove to the old house and were able to park right in front. We walked over to the carriage house and were surprised to find more rangers there. They told us we could take a tour of the Old House if we wanted. There was a tour scheduled in about 15 minutes, but "that they were running a little late". We waited on the front porch of the home as directed. When the trolley finally arrived, the group was large. They decided to split it into 2 groups - one to start in the home, the other to tour the grounds and the library. We went with the house group. It took an hour to go through the house and it was really interesting. The house was home to four generations of Adams. The fourth generation Adams was an historian and realized the historic value of the house. He got the family together and they agreed to donate it to the park service on the condition that nothing would be added or taken away from the property. As you walk through you see a clock that was made in the 1600s that was a wedding gift. You see the chair that John Adams died in. The whole place is REAL and the ranger gave us a lot of background information as we went from room to room. We loved it, but I don't know that children under the age of 12 would have the attention span or interest to spend the amount of time that it takes. I don't know what the cost is because it was par service week (or something) and everything was free. I hope we can make it back to see more of the site when we visit again.

This National Park is quite large with many different hiking paths and other places to picnic and such. I was particularly looking for the Visitor Center. (I collect National Park Pass Stamps). I was disappointed that I could not locate it! I didn't have much time to find it, but the signage was not evident. Pretty park, though!

We drove from Mesqite, NV, to Cedar City, Utah, near Bryce Canyon National Park. We chose to pass on the canyon and instead headed up Cedar Mountain on Rt 14. The landscape, scenery, terrain was like nothing we'd ever seen, and we've traveled 40 of the 50 states. The road is crooked, steep, but well maintained, with numerous areas to pull off and view or take pictures. The rock formations were spectacular, to say the least. We left the area and returned to the interstate at Long Junction, UT.

Other reviewers have covered the cave itself pretty well, so I just want to offer some logistical suggestions. We visited on the Tuesday right after Memorial Day and found no crowds at all. We took the New Entrance Tour, which has a ticket limit of 114 -- we had just 7 people in our group and it was fantastic! The ranger guiding the tour was able to get into a lot more explanation and interaction with such a small group. I strongly recommend you visit on an "off day," because this must be hard with a large group -- you have to walk single file, and there are only a few places on this tour where you can gather a group for a talk about what you're seeing. New Entrance is a good tour if you are concerned about strenuousness. You walk down 280 steps, straight down a shaft, at the very start. But you only have to come up 220 (to a different exit), and these steps are spaced out along the route, not all at once. $12 per person and well worth it.

We went to Mt. Rushmore with our daughter and her almost 3 year old son. We drove in from Colorado. The scenary was beautiful ! I fell in love with South Dakota. I was thrilled we stayed in Keystone. It was only one mile from Mt. Rushmore. Definitely be sure to see the mountain lighting ceremony and pre-lighting movie. I think it happens around 9 for the program and 9:30 for the lighting. Also be sure to see it in daylight too. A one time 10 dollar parking fee lets you in for the year.... I really was proud of our country and the great leadership it used to have being at that Monument.

We first stopped here in the evening and went to the lighting ceremony and watched the movie. Then went back in the morning and walked around more. It's good to go both times. If you're a veteran they recognize you at the night ceremony. The parking permit they give you ($10 at time we went) is good for the year.

Drove down from Cincinnati so I bought cave tour tickets online the day before to be sure we got on the tour.We arrived earlier than expected but they would not exchange our tickets for an earlier tour even though it was NOT sold out --they wanted to charge us a $9 fee--so we had to sit 2 hours and wait --visitor center museum was closed due to construction--nothing else to do on a rainy day. Some days the tours do sell out so either way you can lose--time or money.

Although it's only a 7 hour drive (on very good roads), I've waited a life time to see Mt. Rushmore. It was a unique experience, made so by the park rangers who tirelessly lead people from around the world on the cat walk around the base of the monument. Its great to be able to get so close to the Presidents. Also the local,, collared, wild mountain goats are quite an attraction; you can get within 4-5' of them for photo opps. Stay away from the cafeteria food, if possible. Though the huge room with a beautifully decorated, giant mantel piece, dedicated to the American Indians of the area, hold 300 plus people, the food is sketchy. The gift shop is enormous and contains everything from very high quality (and priced) hand crafted sterling and semi precious stone of amazing designs, to the salt and pepper/shot glass Presidents and everything inbetween. We went the week before Memorial weekend to beat the crowds and it was worth it. There are tons of touristy hotels close to the monument, but we stayed in Rapid City, about 30 minutes away, which for us, was a great choice. "Rapid" as the locals call it is friendly, clean and big enough to have some terrific restaurants (especially the Italian downtown...Bellisimo?) and 3 Starbucks! We are flat water kayakers, so there were lots of places for us to get our boats in the water, at no charge. Love to go back!

We took the Jewel Cave Discovery Tour and it was a perfect match for two small children and a senior with walking issues. Twenty minutes down in one large room that was elevator-accessible. Very difficult getting reservations by phone--kept getting cut off and no one answered. Senior Access Pass got us tours free. Bookstore small, movie not very interesting for little ones. Not much else to do while waiting for your tour except go a little ways on trailheads. Bathrooms in small, separate building. Cave is cool--recommend jacket and jeans. We had young seasonal ranger who was very good with children, knowledgeable, and humorous. So close to Mt. Rushmore that you really need to go.

What a dissapointment to see all the man-made stuff below a perfectly iconic American Monument. The awesome view was from the road, not the park. It cost $10 to park in a parking garage despite the fact that entrance to the park was free. This should be free to all visitors, but there is too much money invested in the avenue of flags, gift shops, and the multi-tiered garage to let you out of there for nothing. We went in June and it was quite hot, which also detracted from the enjoyment as all the rock pathways hold heat. Too many people. I suppose it would be nicer in the off season with fewer people. Still, the whole thing takes away from the majesty of the Monument itself. It was not the patriotic experience we had hoped for. We couldn't wait to leave!
Its what you expect full of people but worth the time.. Its 10 dollars a car for parking even if you have a senior citizen free park pass just an fyi

Our dream was to someday see Mt Rushmore. We were worried that we had such high expectations that we would be disappointed. We were awe struck. It was moving to see this piece of history. We were happy to pay the small parking fee of $10 to help with the cost. It was nice that you could walk the path and see it closer. I wished we stayed in Keystone because it looked so cute and closer so that we would have gone back to see the lighting ceremony. We stayed in Rapid City and it was about 25 minutes away so we didn't go back at night which I regret now.

Heading from Reno to Crater Lake, decided to pass on Mount Shasta and give Lava Beds N.M. a look-see. Glad we did. Much to enjoy. A camping headlamp is all one needs to take several mile-long (or longer) underground hikes in ancient lava tubes (or you can borrow a hand lamp from the park service for free). Hot outside in the summer but a balmy 58 degrees inside. Most trails can be hiked standing up with a few twists and bends along the way. If you take the few hikes that require some duck-walking, better wear a helmet and long pants (ouch!) The sights above-ground are interesting, and the walk through the historical battlefield is pleasant.

We loved our visit to Crater Lake National Park except for the mosquitoes. Be sure to bring bug spray because the mosquitoes wil cover you up. We stayed at Mazama Village, where the rooms are typical park style rooms. The rooms are plain, but clean with all the basic amenities. We were able to go on the boat cruise with a 3 hour stop at Wizard Island. The Cleetwood trail to the boat launch is very steep and strenuous on the way back up. The cruise was delightful though, with wonderful views. The park ranger, who was our guide, provided a very imformative presentation, which included the history of the park and various landmarks that he pointed out to us as we ventured out to Wizard Island. We also hiked up to the summit of Wizard Island. Again, this was very steep and included lots of switchbacks, but beautiful views of the lake. We also enjoyed eating at Annie's restaurant, located at Mazama village. It's a buffet restaurant, with pretty good food at a reasonable price.

This was our second trip to Mt. Rushmore. There have been major improvements to the site, including an amphitheater, paved trails, better entrance, better parking, etc. Very reasonably priced to enter ($10/car). On the drive up the mountain, a mountain goat jumped out into the road in front of us!

I called a week in advance to reserve time for my family’s tour. There were people waiting in line expecting to get a tour the same time I had reserved a week prior. I felt bad that they were unaware how fast these tours are scheduled. The fee was very reasonable. It was recommended to wear warmer clothes because the temperature remains 47 degrees. I considered the caves a bit damp, and at times the stairs were wet and one needs to be careful. The scenic tour started by going down an elevator in two separate groups and walking down stairs and looking at the caves on platforms to rest. If in this area, this attraction is worth the time to visit.

This place is now one of my new favorite National Parks!! There is so much to explore and see, and most of it is underground!! I HIGHLY recommend visiting the Golden Dome Cave because of the golden, glowing bacteria on the ceiling! Its absolutely gorgeous (but not contagious, so don't worry!) You can borrow huge flashlights from the rangers, and even buy a bump hat for $8 (which I would recommend if you plan on going into the more challenging caves) Also, if you decide to visit the Painted Caves, go to the one that is farther back on the trail because that one has more obvious paintings on the wall. HAVE FUN!! I will definitely be back soon!

I have been to Harper's Ferry many times. Its a terrific little town where the Potomac and Shenendoah Rivers connect with alot of history, ranging from John Brown's Raid to the Civil War to the floods that have frequently ravaged the town. There are wonderful videos to watch, great river views, hiking trails, a CSX rail bridge that you can stand next to and feel the power of a locomotive, ruins to explore. They charge $5 per car to park outside ot town and then the NPS shuttles you to the town. During the week, it is possible to park in the town but I don't think its encouraged.

This was awesome. We started our trip in Keystone and wound our way down route 16 into the Custer State Park (the $12 is totally worth it) and got a great view of Rushmore from afar. The journey through the park, along the Wilderness Loop and then on the Needles Highway is fantastic. We went to the Crazy Horse but for $20 admission did not go further than the end of the hill to turn around.
We drove through the park and stopped to hike at spots along the way. The most beautiful lake I have ever seen. Definitely worth the $10.00 park fee!

What a great cave to explore. Of everything we did in the custer area Jewel Cave was the most value for our money. It cost us just under 30.00 for 2 adults and 2 kids and lasted for almost 90 minutes. My kids loved the idea of being in a cave and the park ranger doing the tour was very knowledgeable. What a great tour i would recommend this tour.

I recently spent the better part of a day at Valley Forge on a trip to Philadelphia and it was the highlight of my trip. I am very interested in history and took this trip because I wanted to visit Valley Forge. I was not disappointed! The park is free, which should make it a place all travelers in the area should visit. The only thing you had to pay for was food, which I got from the Chapel Cabin Shop and it was delicious and very reasonably priced. The day I visited was very warm so I drove my car along the Encampment Tour route. The nice thing about the park is you can walk, bike or drive and you don't really miss out on anything anyway you choose to go. I started by viewing the introductory film and then headed out on the tour. Each stop is clearly marked on the map and along the road. There is a parking lot at all the stops and lots of informational signs. I found that I was pulling over at other points as well to take photos of markers or just the scenery in general. The highlight was probably seeing the headquarters of George Washington, but I enjoyed the whole park. Make sure to take the Inner Line drive. It is the road right after Washington's Headquarters that veers to the right. Not many cars went that way when I was there so I was able to drive slowly and enjoy the scenery. I would recommend this park to anyone with an interest in American History and really everyone in general. A wonderful, inexpensive way to experience how our country began.

I was in Harpers Ferry National Historical Park for four hours mid-August 2010. Getting to the park from the south was delayed because of construction. The entrance fee was $6. Parking was easy, and the ranger at the visitor center was very friendly and helpful, as this was my first visit. I took the shuttle to the Lower Town. It then started to rain and rained the rest of the day! I walked the quick Virginius Island trail. There are good restrooms in Lower Town next to the bookstore. The short 2:00 pm ranger talk was helpful in placing Harpers Ferry in history. I then walked around the historical buildings. It reminded me very much of Greenfield Village in Dearborn, Michigan! The walking bridge across the river was fun, and the walk up to the Jefferson Rock was easier than expected. The Bolivar Heights area was isolated. When I go again, I will walk the Maryland Heights and C&O Towpath trails and do a float trip!

We stopped at the visitors center first--#1 on the tour map. Small gift shop, very small snack shop (drinks and chips etc), and an area with informational signs and pictures. A fair amount of period pieces to check out, like the cooking gear, and the muskets they used. You can pick up a map of the area which indicates 10 different sites to check out. There is a short movie, but our timing was off so we skipped it. You can jump on the bus/trolley (I believe there was a fee), ride your own/rent a bike, walk, or drive your car. Walkers/bikers--lots of hills!! Only stops 2 and 5 were interesting to us--#2 a series of log cabins (reproductions) that you could look into, one you can enter. #5 Washington Headquarters and Train Depot. HQ was cool--no hands on stuff though. Train depot just had more info placards and pictures--still being developed I guess. Feel free to ask questions of the characters, they were very knowledgeable and good with the kids. The rest of the stops were just drive-bys of arches, cabins, and statues of famous people from the time. Expect to walk a fair amount regardless of what method you choose to tour the site--bring water and comfortable shoes!

This has to be one of our highlights of our visit to Boston and well worth the effort. We caught the "T" line out to Quincy Center and straight across the road was the Visitor Center and trolley stop. For just $5 an adult and children under 16 free we boarded the trolley and first stopped off at the Adams family birthplace and homes. The best was yet to come however when after an excellent short guide and talk we then reboarded the trolley for the main home. What a visit ! Our guide was very knowledgeable and to see so much under one roof, including the fantastic library built in the grounds was just simply fantastic. Every one visiting Boston should visit!!

Free attraction - you only have to pay to park (and I think that's on the honor system). A tour of Lincoln's house is given by park rangers, but there are exhibits in a couple of other homes in the neighborhood that are self-guided. Video in the (very nice) visitor center and nice gift shop also.
we were going to head out to meteor crater but i wanted to see Indian ruins, this place was only one mile out of Flagstaff and you pass it on the way out to the crater
1. Much smaller than Bryce but worthwhile; admission only $4 compared to $25 at bryce

While there is a concessionaire fee to park, the National Memorial is free. Informative exhibit and top-of-the-line videos within visitor center make the story behind the creation of Mt. Rushmore personal. Do the President's walk too....start on the left as you face Mt. Rushmore....and it's a easy loop. When you come to stairs down to artist's studio...you can back track to the visitor center if you do not want to do 'stairs. Evening lighting ceremony (seasonal) is moving....and free too! (Pay once for parking and can return at night for the illumination.)
Crater Lake is incredible beautiful!!! I would highly recommend a vistt. If you do plan to visit, be sure to stay in the lodge. It is worth the cost. You will need to book pretty far in advance.

My husband and I wanted to escape the 100 degrees of Vegas so we traveled 3 1/2 hours North to Cedar Breaks just East of Cedar City by 20 miles. We found an offer on-line for Cedar Breaks Lodge and Spa for under $100 a night. It included a small kitchen with microwave and refrigerator so you can fix a meal. We hiked in the Park the first afternoon and the next morning before heading South. We also went out after 10pm to see the stars, which were very bright at an elevation of 10,000 ft. The colors were bright yellow with some reds and lots of evergreens. Rock formations were also amazing . It was a perfect get away.

This site is awesome! The interpretor at the site was one of the best I have seen. Admission is free and includes a short boat ride. The nature trail us awesome too! Visit this site you won't be dissapointed!

Lowell National Historic Park encompasses multiple tours and exhibits from canal tours to how the mills got their power to the life of the mill workers. I have taken multiple tours here and learned something on all of them. Most recently we went on a canal tour and although the river was high and the boat couldn't go through the lock, the ranger gave us an outstanding tour of the lock by land which was excellent. Going on the boat tour is particularly appealing for families as those interested in the history get to hear a lot while those interested in sitting and looking around are equally entertained. Plus you get to ride BOTH a trolley and a boat. Plenty of low cost parking including a parking garage with $3 parking.

My husband wanted to go to see Mt Rushmore again, we went about 6-7 yrs ago, we had not been out that way for some time..He was shocked that they have a parking fee, and there is a parking garage, 10 bucks per car,RV,motorcycle, Van...wth ???

My husband and I loved Mt. Rushmore! The $10 price for parking almost seemed low for the sight, especially after just leaving Crazy Horse and feeling completely ripped off! Words just cannot describe how incredible it is to stand in front of this beautiful carving. The grounds were well taken care of and although it was fairly busy, we still had a great time! Everyone should see this site!
Beautiful. Put's a lump in your throat. Beware parking is $10.00 Cash only, no credit or debit allowed.

I had already hiked some of Zion's trails before I got to Bryce. However, in Bryce you start at the top. The scenery is some of the best I've seen in all of the parks.Research the hikes you want and charge. The first couple of stops are in the "Amphitheater". Enjoy!!!

We got up at about four in the morning, and started our journey from Las Vegas to Bryce Canyon National Park. Odds are, no matter where you are driving from, you will see your fair share of beautiful scenery along the way. The reason we chose this time of year to visit Bryce was so we could see the famous Utah snow draped atop the canyon. We made our way past Arizona, St. George (UT), and Zion National Park (visited Zion only two weeks ago) to one of the many entrances to the Dixie National Forest. The forest is home to some of the most beautiful scenery I have ever seen. Taking pictures a plenty, we would sooner or later get onto UT-89, and from there drive straight to Bryce Canyon. Because we were visited the park on Veteran's Day, the park was free of charge. It is usually $25.00, but it is most certainly worth it. The visitor's center holds an award-winning film that explains the history behind the canyon. Believe me when I say, that had my wife and myself not seen the film, we would have left the park later that day with more questions than answers. The film is free, so you might as well sit back and relax for twenty minutes, while you absorb the enigmatic background of Bryce Canyon. There are two different experiences you can take while driving through the park. A drive to Bryce Point and back is about four miles both ways. A drive to Rainbow Point and back (passing other major view points) is about seventeen miles both ways. When we got to Bryce Point, a Stellar's Jay (which we seen during the film) landed in a tree only about a couple of feet from where we were standing. We were able to get some really nice close-ups. We then walked the trail to one of the most scenic vistas anywhere, Bryce Point. I cannot even find words to explain it, other than unimaginable. At Bryce Point alone there are an incredible amount of different types of formations, but the biggest one is the amphitheater. Bryce Point is one of the highest points in the park at 8300 feet. Next, we continued to Paria View. Again, amazing formations mixed with a light snow made this the ultimate experience. We stopped by the Bryce Canyon Lodge which is currently packing everything up for the winter season. It will reopen in April. Not only was the scenery the most beautiful in our opinions, but the week before the lodge closes up is probably the most desolate time to visit the park. You pretty much have the park to yourselves. That doesn't happen during the Spring, Summer, and early Fall (especially May-August). We saw an abundance of Mule deer as well. Our last stop was Fairyland Canyon. This is where that famous scene of a balancing rock above all other formations can be seen in person. We liked everything about our trip to Bryce. I would recommend it to anyone and everyone. It doesn't matter whether you're an outdoor person or not, you absolutely have to see Bryce Canyon National Park!

Several nice hotels in the area, but parking can be difficult during the busy season. We had no choice but to visit on July 4th, so that had to be one of the worst weeks to go, but it was still worth the trip. Parking at the actual monument was so bad (about a 2 mile walk) that we decided to take the helicopter tour. If you don't mind the expense, it was a great way to see Mt Rushmore.

I think most people would consider this a must-see on the big Island, and I agree. Allow plenty of time for the two visitor centers / museums. The drive to the coast is pretty, but long, and no lava viewing from this side. If you want to get to the active lava flow, it is an hour+ drive toward Hilo and in from the other side. That was also worth the trip, especially after dark. Note a visitor may not see the actual lava flowing from this side either, unless a special tour is arranged ($55 per person, I think, from a vendor set up at the end of Route 130).

Our family of six (kids ages 8-13) enjoyed our visit here. If you've seen Carlsbad caverns be prepared for a different experience...starting with no elevators and no self-guided tour options. We took the 4.5 hr Grand avenue tour, with a 5mile underground hike through most of the highlights except for the historical Natural entrance. The frozen Niagara area is the most beautiful. There is a 30 minute lunch break, with cash only box lunches for $7.50,drinks and snacks or you can bring your own food unclear ziploc bags (no purses, camera cases or bags of any other kind are allowed due to homeland security concerns). The current visitor center only has tour ticket sales (there are many shorter options and rservations are recommended for popular ones), a restroom, and small gift shop,but ugrades are in process. There are some above ground hikes, and the mammoth cave hotel
