If you want a shorter tour through the caves, this is the tour for you. It only costs $10. and it's about an hour and 15 min. It isn't strenuous at all, the only exception to that is if you would like to take the steps down to view the under side of the falls, where there are 47 steps down and back up again. Great tour at a great price !

Although I was aware of it, I got annoyed when I was forced to purchase a $10 "annual" parking permit (that was good for 6 months). The concessionaire took only cash which was also annoying (they did make change for a $20 bill, however). I wonder why they don't sell $100 "century" parking permits (that are good for say 2 years).

This place is fantastic!! We ended up visiting the park on November 11th, which was Veterans Day…so there was no admission fee. We stopped at the Visitors Center, which is just inside the park gates. We looked around a bit and picked up a map. Then we hit the road. We headed down Crater Rim Drive first, toward the Jaggar Museum. On the way, we stopped to check out the Steam Vents (easy walk from the parking area). It was really odd to see steam coming from the earth like that. This is where we got our first look at the Kilauea Crater…you can see it in the distance from a little viewing area near the vents. After our first look at the crater, we were so excited to see it closer!! We headed to the Jaggar Museum (when we visited on 11/11/10, Crater Rim Drive was closed beyond the Jaggar Museum). We got out of the car and walked toward the museum. This is the only place during our entire trip where we detected a sulfur-like smell in the air. Certainly not overpowering in any way - and once you pass the National Park sign for the museum, the smell went away. We walked around the museum to check out the displays. They have a bunch of huge rolls of paper behind a glass wall which appear to be tracking seismic activity all over the area. They also have some samples of lava for you to check out. There is also a small Vistors Center where you can pick up some souvenirs. Don’t plan to eat here – there is no food or drink. Then, the big moment….we walked over to the viewing area and there it was….the Kilauea Crater!! There was a vent in the crater with steam pouring out constantly (thankfully the steam was heading away from the viewing area). As of our visit, there was no visible, flowing lava here….just steam. But it is an amazing view. According to one of the rangers that was walking around, the lava is about 150 feet below the surface. I could have just starred at it for days. But, we didn’t have days….so we left the Jaggar and came back down Crater Rim Drive, heading back towards the Visitors Center and the Park Entrance.

We drove from Zion Park to Bryce Canyon on December 28. It was a beautiful sunny day and the park was open. We walked the Queen/Navajo trail around the hoodoos. It was beautiful. One of the natural wonders..the formations are unreal and the canyon was well worth the visit. Initially we were worried as it has snowed a few days before but we lucked out with perfect weather to drive and walk around. I would positively recommend being well prepared for the cold weather in the season and we bought some snow grippers to put on our shoes from the Park store for $27 each. We didn't stop for lunch though some places were open. We preferred to drive back to Springdale and have lunch at Oscar's in Springdale.

This is a nice spot for those who love nature and a quite walk along some magnificent paths. Although you will not see any glowing or flowing lava at daytime, this might be a pretty memorable National Park for you. Entrance fee is totally OK with 10 bucks per car. If you want to get an idea of lava, stay until late since after sunset there is a crater where you will see some glowing points from quite a distance (Visitor Center).

Both the visitors center and the general store were first rate. The Park is busy in the summer, but manageable. We hiked the Navajo loop and Peekaboo loop together. Unfortunately we didn't get underway until 9:30am, by the end of our hike it was over 100F by 1pm. We went through about 2 litres per person of water. I'd call this hike strenuous, at least for us. Would not have been as bad if not for the heat, but that was our fault. The scenery was amazing, just really unique, with the colours and shapes of the hoodoos. Don't be put off by the crowds, after 1/2 mile it really thins out. Definitely a worth while hike.

this attraction is incredible. we learnt so much and saw so much. id suggest to do the hike, it took us an hour and 40 min. it was incredible. we got some beautiful pictures and video. They only charge 10 dollars and thats a 7day pass.

Operated by National Park Service. See at www.nps.gov . If you're taking the Apache Trail, this attraction is about 4 mile South on route 188. Overlooking Roosevelt Lake and about one mile off the highway, it's worth at least the drive to the parking lot to view the cliff dwellings even if you don't feel ready for the uphill hike.. Only one half mile, but gains 350 foot in elevation. Well paved trail and modern visitor center with facilities, only $3 admission. Two sets of ruins, the upper requires reservation for a ranger guided tour and only goes off twice a day. Visit in the morning for better view and photos as the site faces East. Set amongst the cactus and hills of the Tonto National Forest,

When my husband got his 4-day pass from Ft. Bliss before heading overseas, I wasn't sure if he would want to spend an afternoon frolicking in the sand...but even he agreed that White Sands is an absolute MUST when you are in the area. It is a $3.00/person entrance fee, which is good for 7 days and includes additional activities like the Sunset Stroll we took at 5 PM. When you first arrive, the visitor's center is across the breezeway from the bathrooms and they sell postcards, magnets, and offer literature about upcoming events at the park. There is also a knowledgeable ranger on staff who can answer questions about the park. There is a short film you can watch, which was not in operation when we were there. Behind the visitor's center is the gift store where you can buy more White Sands memorabilia and purchase a large disc sled for sledding down the dunes. To buy a sled is $14.95 and they will buy it back for $5.00. There is also sled wax for sale at the counter. It's 99 cents per block and is used to wax the bottom of the sled to keep the sand from sticking to it. We did not discover any of this until we were ready to leave the park so I'm sharing it with you now to keep you from making the same mistake. The Sunset Stroll, which starts 5 miles into the park from the visitor's center is also a must. The sun turns the San Andreas/Sacramento mountains an amazing color of orange when it sets and the sands are just brilliant. The stroll is led by a park volunteer and only ventures 100 yards or so into the dunes. I did it barefoot.

We much enjoyed our recent visit to the Ninety-Six National Historic Site, a National Park Service area that preserves a Revolutionary War site. Compared to other historic sites and battlefields, this park is accessible and well interpreted. A paved 1 mile trail winds its way through forest and field past an old colonial town site and star fort. The trail markers interpret the site very well. Also on site is an original colonial log building. Of associated sites, Cowpens National Battefield and Stone Mountain, we enjoyed visiting this site the most. There is no admission charge.
Entrance fee $3
About an hour drive from Monterey CA. (we went on a rainy day) $5 admission which is totally worth it and supports the park so just do it.

Not that I mind the cold. Not at all in fact - I'm from Buffalo originally. But be forewarned that the elevation change here is intense, especially as you venture further into the park. We read somewhere that it snows 280 days out of the year here. The park is amazing - we took a hike down through the hoodoos and went to lots of stops. When planning our trip I initially planned two days here, but after talking to people, they said you can easily spend one. I agree, this is a one day park. We stayed about 45 minutes away (although you could stay at Ruby's which is closer) but wanted to experience it at night, because it's one of the least light polluted areas in the country. That was a must see for anyone. Also, the park doesn't close at night, so we were alone, which was slightly terrifying considering all the wildlife warnings. We kept to the lookouts however. Great park. Also, potentially worth getting the national park pass if you're going to others.

We went to Mammoth Cave over spring break. We had 5 children ages 6-18 and an adult with a foot problem and we all easily did this tour. My sister said she had done the Lantern Tour the year before and liked this one better as far as beauty. This tour is a first come first serve so we could not reserve spots. We also went to Cub Run Cave just up the road and thought that was even better. This is a nice tour as far as beauty, cost, and ease.

We were looking for things to do around Las Cruces, and decided to pay a visit to White Sands. Good choice: This place is seriously cool. Only one significant hike (~4 miles roundtrip), but major opportunities for sliding down the dunes and collecting gypsum in your shoes (and everywhere else!).

Hawaii Volcanoes National Park should be at the top of your list of things to see on the Big Island. You can’t see this stuff anywhere else! It costs money to get in but your ticket is good for 7 days. This is a good thing if you can’t experience everything you want in one day or if you go on a cloudy day and want to return on a sunny day. Start at the Kilauea Visitor Center and ask one of the Rangers what is going on in the park the day you are there. They will give you a great map and bring the highlights to your attention. The Jaggar Museum has excellent displays with seimographs and other equipment used by scientists to monitor volcanoes. This is also the closest place to look into the caldera. Our other favorite spots were the Thurston Lava Tube, Kilauea Iki overlook and the Holei Sea Arch.

This park consists of two sites, several miles apart. You visit them on a single two-hour tour, traveling by trolley from the Visitors' Center to the birthplaces and then to the home where John and Abigail settled when they returned from Europe and where John Quincy, Charles Francis, Henry, Brooks, and other eminent Adamses and their families lived, right up to the mid-20th century. To me, the latter was most interesting, and stories about the people who lived and visited there are fascinating. (Our NPS Ranger guide was excellent). For bibliophiles the Stone Library, built in 1870 to accommodate the books accrued by the Adamses up to then, is a breathtaking venue. The birthplaces are classic New England saltboxes, very sparsely furnished; once you've been there you can check them off your life-list of Presidential Birthplaces (though not the actual rooms where John and John Quincy were born) and you probably won't be motivated to return; I'm not. (Our NPS Ranger there was not as good). But I am keenly looking forward to visiting the "Old House" again once I've learned more about all the Adamses. Caveat: the Visitors Center, where the bus tour begins, is on the ground floor of a nondescript modern office building in the center of Quincy. There's an identifying sign but no directions about where to park. You'll find an attached parking garage in the rear, which is free of charge on weekends. And when you travel on the bus you'll be subjected to the driver's taste in music....
we visited from Aiustralia and copped a foggy day. Waited 3 hours but fog never lifted. Pity, they could have a least refunded the car park fee.
The fort is not as big as the one in St Augustine but it is just as interesting. The tour guides are very knowledgable. It is free but I would have a little. It is worth a small fee.

We spent two full days in the area, devoting one day to Mount Rushmore, custer park and crazy horse and one day to the Badlands. Mount Rushmore, while one admires the original feat of carving it, is surprisingly dull. The area of shops at the entry are tacky, parking is expensive and there really is no payoff once you have walked out on to the viewing terrace. Photographs and postcards make it seem considerably more dramatic. Crazy Horse will, one day, have far more impact. It is far from completed however, and the $10 per person entry fee seemed more akin to a donation to the project. On the wildlife loop in Custer Park the few bison seemed bored and the miles and miles of road surrounded by empty grassland made us feel the same way.

On a recent trip to South Dakota to see Mt. Rushmore and the Crazy Horse Memorial, we discovered the Jewel Cave. It is the second longest cave in the world (second to Mammoth Cave in Kentucy) and if it is ever completely explored may well be the longest. The half-mile tour (which includes the over 750 steps) shows many different features of the cave and is interesting for both children and adults. The Park Ranger we had really loved his job and loved the cave. It is not expensive ($8 for adults, less for children) and was a great way to spend part of a rainy day.

Park just opened a new visitor's center and the facility and staff were great and very helpful in choosing the right tours for our group given the time allotted. Tour guides were friendly and knowledgeable and added to the experience. We stayed outside the park in a nearby town and accommodations were nothing to write home about. The best choice was a Sleep Inn because it was brand new, so the facility was nice with a decent breakfast bar in the morning. There did not appear to be any really good restaurants in the area but good enough to get by. Don't go for the food or lodging. Go for the amazing spectacle the cave is! You need a couple of days to take a couple of different tours to get a real feel for the cave. We did an afternoon 2 hour tour and a morning 4 - 5 hour tour. No entrance fee but you must pay for tours.

Mt. Rushmore is a majestic stop of many that are in the Black Hills. There are trails, a Sculptor's Lodge, gift shops, food, and more. You pay to park, and your pass can be used for more than one day should you choose to come back. There are many view points and photo ops, so take your time and wander the sights as there is much to see and experience.

We have a lifetime pass for the national parks that we bought this year. If you are 62 or older you can buy a lifetime pass for $10. There was still snow on the ground in May, but the roads were clear. No words can do justice to the beauty of the park. We entered through the south entrance of Kings Canyon and went to General Grant Tree which was a must see. We also saw the General Sherman. We exited the park to the city of Three Rivers. They are working on the road at this exit and it took us over an hour of stop and go trafffic to exit the park. May is a great time to go.

Had a wonderful time and especially enjoyed the informative talk by Park Ranger Charles Dumond; most interesting and I highly recommend it along with the Presidential Walk and the second lecture in Borglum's studio, No cost to enter but parking is $11 CASH, no CC accepted but worth the money. The winds were 60 mph the day we were there but we were told this was unusual - bring a jacket and if it's windy, hold on to your hat!

My wife and I visited Sequoia National Park for a couple days of hiking and viewing the sequoia trees. As usual, we were not disappointed by our experience in the national park. The forests are spectacular and the sequoia trees are truly a wonder of nature. We stayed at the Wuksachi Lodge in the park so that we would be close to the hiking trails and could get an earlier start each day. The Lodge was nice and a definite recommendation. You definitely want a camera and sturdy hiking shoes. Our favorite hike was up to Moro Rock, an enormous granite monolith that has spectacular views from its top. The hike up was a bit arduous so be prepared to walk up about 400 stairs and pass some spots where the guardrail is discontinuous. The climb is well worth the effort. We also spent half a day in the foothills, hiking along the river and that was fun. The foothills area was about 30 degrees warmer than up on the mountain and was much more humid. The one complaint we had about the park is that we didn't find out until we got there that there was still 4-6 ft of snow on many trails, making them rather inaccessible. It would be nice if the park rangers would post conditions on their website. Also, some services (e.g. museums, snack bars) were not operational during the first week in May although the website said that everything was officially open on May 1. Oh well, we made due with what they had and had a blast. We were there for one day and a half and we wished we would have spent another day there so that we could have driven up in the King's Canyon part of the park. If we go again, we will want to see that for sure. Have fun!

While visiting Tucson in April a friend took me to see this small -national- historic park. About 25 miles south of Tucson, its a lovely partly restored Jesuit Mission founded in about 1691. It was part of the wave of a century of expansion along New Spain's west coast corridor.The Mission is small in size and can easily seen in a few hours. The entrance fee is low.

We visited the White Sands park on a road trip as we made a way back from Roswell. On the approach to the park our first view was spectacular! Everything was so green and then we went over a hill and in front of us was this huge stretch of white. After making our way to the park we went into the visitors centre and paid the hire charge for the sledge and bought a cube of wax. The sledges can be hired or bought and on return of a hired sledge you get back about $5 of the $8 you originally pay.
Park is amazing. Pictures don't capture the views or drop to bottom of canyon. Take the road (right turn) at fee booth to bottom of canyon. Road is paved - however it is small and has many curves.

I had never heard of Theodore Roosevelt before and was expecting it to resemble the rest of the Midwest: flat, rolling plains and, at times, blustery winds. While the winds were still blustery, the terrain was far from flat; it was broken and colorful, with strange rock formations jutting up and massive buttes arrayed in splashes of yellow, orange, and red. In short, it was exactly what you would picture the Wild West looking like. There is a small fee to enter the park ($10 per vehicle per week, plus other rates depending on how long you wanted to stay), but the 24-mile loop was easily driven and quite scenic. The ranger at the gate told us that the South Unit (in Medora, ND) had around 350 head of bison. Still, I didn't really expect to see any. We drove for about 30 minutes before we encountered any wildlife (not counting prairie dogs - they're everywhere), but the experience was unforgettable! Feral horse herds walked right up to the car, and pretty soon we were surrounded by herds of bison, so close you could reach out and touch them! It was fabulous! There were a number of hiking trails that wound through the park, as well, that afford a more intimate view of the scenery and wildlife. I'm not sure when the best time of day is to experience the park, but we went close to evening, around 7pm MDT.

Our family finally got around to seeing this and I must say I wish more attractions were worth the money paid such as this one. We also got to listen to a patio talk about the jasper wild fire which was very insightful about the damage to the local area. With five of us the price was just right at $28.

If you don't want to wait a long time to get a tour, you need to call for tickets in advance. The problem with that is that I could never get an answer when I called the park. I kept getting a recording that all operators were busy and call back another time. We just ended up driving out there with our fingers crossed. At the ticket window, we were told in a snippy way that they only have 4 phone lines and two people anwering them. So, good look getting tickets ahead. I wish the Park Service would join the 21st century and have online ticket ordering.

Wow, not only is the monument impressive, the story behind it is even more so. Watch the video on how the monument was created - 90% via dynamite. The park is free, but there is an $11 parking fee for cars. The parking ramp is convenient and clean. We did not stay for the night lighting show. There are also hiking trails.

It is a sight that you have to stop by while you are in the area, but just be ready for lots of people. To miss the crowds go early in the morning. The lighting ceremony is ok, but I wouldn’t recommend waiting around for it, there are much better things in the area to see. We didn’t spend more than 1hr there in total taking pictures and looking at the gift shop. While there are no fees to enter the park, it costs $11 per car to park there… Make sure to look out for the mountain goats and other wildlife in the area.

While we only had a day to visit the park, it was well worth it. It costs $25 per car to enter the park for 7 days, or $30 for a yearlong pass. The crowds in the park when my wife and I went (June 2011) were very little, and it was so beautiful to see. Right after we entered we viewed the visitor center, which looked fairly new and had a wonderful exhibit as well.

We spent a couple of nights in Capitol Reef. This is a gorgeous park that seems to be little visited compared to many other parks and yet just as deserving of a visit. There are some absolutely fantastic hikes in the area, gorgeous vistas, and even an orchard and old schoolhouse. There was plenty of times we felt like we were the only ones in the park.. was very peaceful. While we were there we did the Goosenecks hike, Capitol Gorge ( must see!), Hickman Natural Bridge hike, and the scenic drive as well as picked fruit at the orchard ( yum!! they go by the honesty method, you pay for the number of fruit you pick and put it in the box, or at least when we were there ), and visited the schoolhouse. There were plenty of other hikes and such to do there, but we ran out of time. We did want to do the Grand Wash Hike when we were there but it was closed at the time.

My wife and I visited Mount Rushmore on a day when the weather was perfect.The views were spectacular! The grounds were very clean.We split a bowl of buffalo chili and a piece of cheese cake, both were excellent and reasonably priced.I felt the items we purchased from the gift shop were a good value for the money.The people who worked there were very kind and polite.My one gripe was that I couldn't use my Wells Fargo Debit Card to pay for admission.I put everything else (our full 7 day trip) on my card and this was the only place it was declined.

In the summer call ahead and reserve, I can't stress this enough! Jewel Cave is a great and cheap attraction in the Black Hills. The Scenic tour is only $8 for adults, a steal in the Black Hills as all the other attractions are a lot more. The cave tours regularly sell out so if you want to see the cave, call them before you head out to find out if there are tours still available and reserve a tour. It is so easy to do and you don't have sit around for hours waiting for your tour time, only 30 minutes. The cave is 53 miles from Rapid City but it takes a lot longer than you would think to get there. The tour itself is great, a lot of stairs but half of them are going down. And there flights are fairly spaced out so even if you can't do more than a 2 flights without getting wind you should be fine. They don't rush you through either. I've done many cave tours and this one is one of the best. The formations are interesting and you also get to see some box work which is what Wind Cave is mostly made of. If I had to pick between Jewel Cave and Wind Cave, I would pick Jewel.

What a great way to have fun with my family, all while sneaking in some knowledge! The monument itself is quite impressive, and we found some fun photo ops. The dining was mediocre at best, but it is nice to have the convenience. My kids loved it and learned alot about our contry's history! Plus, I loved that it is affordable. We just paid a small "parking fee" and that was it.

We took the self-guided driving tour of the battlefield site, which is well organised, with displays at the stopping points. The visitor centre provides a good background to the site and the battle with plenty to read and do as well as an introductory video. When leaving the battlefield site travel a few miles North to see the Schuyler country house (extra admission charge). A fascinating story to tell while visiting, all brought to life by an enthusiastic ranger. In all we spent about 1/2 a day here, but could have seen more, but needed to move on to our next destination.

We visited Volcanos National Park on the Big Island during our Honeymoon in June 2011. Entrance fee is $10 and is good for 7 days. The park is open 24/7. What can I say? It was absolutley amazing. Whether or not there is flowing lava, the sights are beautiful and aweinspiring. We just followed the road around the caldera, well as far we could anyways...the road was closed in sections because of high levels of noxious gases. This didn't matter however, as you could still access all the parks attractions. We walked around the Sulpher Banks which was interesting and stinky :) The view from the Jagger Museum is breathtaking, especially at night. We walked through the Thurston Lava Tube, down the Devastion Trail, and went to the many lookouts throughout the park...and I would recommend ALL of it, if you have the time. We also drove down Chain of Craters Road, which winds its way down from the Volcano Summit to the ocean. Truly amazing drive, it was one of the trips highlights.

This is one of those off the beaten path things. However, it still draws a fair crowd. It's free, but getting across the canal requires a boat ticket, and these are timed. So, get there early, get across on time. The boat doesn't always take a full load (why I don't know). The fort is interesting and unique in construction/design and living arrangements. You won't need a lot of time once over there, but there's a catwalk on the mainland and you can walk that a couple times. It's also a nice place for a family picnic (mainland) with tables and stuff. It does bring a lot of people though, so check on boat times and get tickets early (then take a walk to wait for your time).

This is one of those things that you must see if in the area. The park ranger discussion in the visitor center was interesting. And the walkway was neat to take to get an up close view of it. We unfortunately didn't get to see it at night. Although the park doesn't charge an admission fee, there is a one-time yearly parking fee.

It's one of those things that if you're going through here or near here and you haven't been to it yet...you have to check it out. It's a staple stop in any trip through here(especially for first timers), This is definitely not something I will go back to see again unless I'm with somebody who hasn't been there and wants to check it out. I paid the fee, went up there and googled for a couple minutes and took my pictures of it. that's about it. It's a pillar among national treasures and deserves the utmost respect but spend fifteen minutes there and you're ready to hit the road

If you plan on walking the trail then it might be a little more worth your time. We stopped by on our way home from vacation, paid the $10 fee, stayed for maybe an hour and left. The time that we were there was plenty to go up, admire the memorial and take some pictures, shop for a little souvenir and head on out. The flags lining the walkway are a nice addition, adds a lot of character.

We had planned this trip for a few months and found that it was well worth it. We drove from L A, CA and did the usual stops in Zion and Vegas. I have two friends that work inside Bryce so that made it even better since they know the place so well. My friend that works there came with me on the "trail ride" two hours of riding on the back of a mule or horse down to the bottom of the canyon and then back up! Some parts were kind of scary because the trail was so narrow but it was well worth it when you got to see the hoodoos up close and personal and did not have to do the hiking...the mules and horses did the work for you! The cost was not bad either at $50.00 a piece for the two hour ride. hint (go to the the restroom before going on the trail ride) no potty breaks on the ride!

We visited White Sands on the way home from our tour of the Southwest. Everyone was a little grumpy and on the sad side and didn't expect much when we pulled in. Boy, were we wrong! What a beautiful place! The dunes are made of white gypsum and some are over 60 feet high. We bought a sled in the gift shop for $15 and went sledding in the dune field with the kids (ages 3, 8, 10). Even our 65-year-old "granny" went sledding down the dunes and had a blast! The sand is a different consistency than beach sand so it wasn't "yucky" feeling when we had to get back into the car. Photo ops abound with this gorgeous scenery for your backdrop. This is definitely a must-see!
Entry fee seemed a little steep @$25 per vehicle as a solo traveler but the views were amazing. I would also recommend visiting Red Canyon which is nearby if you have an extra hour or two.

Visited Fort Clatsop last week with my wife while on vacation. Very informative, educational, but laid out nice that will intrest everyone. Cheap price to enter and very educational for both children and adults.
Had read poor reviews, but couldn't pass up seeing something in person that I've only seen pictures of all my life. Beautiful park and the magnitude of the carvings awesome to see. Worth the stop!
We visited this park early in the morning. The fee was very low, 8$ if I recall correctly.

This attraction does an excellent job of putting you back in Lincoln's time and place. Take the free Lincolns' neighborhood tour and learn about their neighbors. The home tour is free and the NPS visitor's center where you pick up the tickets has more information inside and a friendly staff. Ample $2. parking.

For $11 per car, you can come back as much as you like for a year. Its a quick visit, unless you go downstairs for the educational section. Go at night for the light show! Tip: when you leave the memorial, take a right. Just around the corner is a great profile shot of Washington! :)

I had a chance to visit Bryce Canyon National Park for only one day. I arrived around noon and left near sundown. It was an awesome experience. In spite of the short stay I had time to ride the shuttle bus to Bryce Point and then to Inspiration Point. From there I hiked the Rim Trail back to Sunrise and Sunset Point. Had lunch at the General Store, then hiked down the Navajo Loop through the Wall Street Slot Canyon. If you do not like heights then this trail can look intimidating but the reward at the bottom is worth it. Once you pass through the slot canyon keep going as the views are worth it. Just bring water and plan to stop and rest along the way. After hiking back out of the slot canyon I rode the shuttle back to Ruby's Inn and then drove my car all the way to Rainbow Point while it was still daylight. The view of the Grand Staircase is tremendous. On a clear day you can see all the way to the north rim of the Grand Canyon. By the time I was leaving the sun was going down and the wildlife was coming out to eat. Stopped several times to watch deer eat on the side of the road. I covered a lot of ground in only 8 hours. By the way, if you have Red Canyon on Hwy 12 going towards Panguich is worth a visit too.

We visited Harpers Ferry with a tour bus group of about 50 (mostly seniors) and began with a stop at the Visitors Center. There we paid a $150 fee and proceeded into town where we met up with Rick Garland's "O Be Joyefull" tour as we were instructed. It was an excellent and informative tour, but when our bus came to pick us up, an NPS ranger advised our driver he couldn't come up High Street as planned. The group had to walk back down the hill to the depot, catch a shuttle bus back to the Visitor Center, then meet our coach there. On the way, one of our guests was confronted by a NPS ranger and treated rather rudely...very disappointing and quite the opposite of my other experiences with these usually very friendly and informative folks. Bottom line is that we would have enjoyed our visit much more if folks had given us better information and if the rangers had not been so cold to their guests.

Awesome place to see. The most amazing sandpile you will ever see. Kids and adults both loved walking and sledding down the sand. It was about 105 out but the sand was cool to your barefeet. I wasn't really happy about how they sold/rented the sleds but it was worth it for the kids. I wanted you to "buy" a sled and then you could "return" it and get $5.00 back. Other than that, I would recommend seeing this at least twice in your life. Great photo ops everywhere.

I hadn't been to Mt. Rushmore since I was a kid & WOW they've done a lot with the place! It's great! Def. make the stop if you're in the area! And it's free! Besides parking which is $11. However, whatever you do, even if you're dying of hunger DO NOT, I repeat, DO NOT get the Chicken Sandwich at Mt. Rushmore, it's the worst salt bomb I've ever had. Not sure how you can screw up a chicken sandwich but they did. Def. the worste $20 I've ever spent (2 Chicken Sandwiches, 2 Bags of Chips & 2 Cokes)

The revolutionary war battle in Saratoga in 1777 is considered among the most significant battles in world history. If you are in the area, this site is educational as well as being inexpensive entertainment ($5 per car when we visited).

First I want to say that I come from and area of Illinois that has three beautiful state parks all within a few miles of each other. I like a well maintained park. Ft. Donelson is beautiful. This park is very well maintained and the driving tour is set up to provide a few hours of education about our civil war. The Rangers that we interacted with were very knowledgeable and accommodating. If you are anywhere close to Dover Tennessee make the trip and spend a half day touring the stops. It's worth your time and won't cost you a nickel.

Lincoln's home is beautifully restored along with the surrounding area. You may see costumed actors on the streets. The visitors' center on the same block provides visitors with maps of the area and locations various historic sites. There is no charge to tour Lincoln's home.

The visit to Walnut Canyon was teemendous. Kids couldn't imagine making their home on the edges of cliffs. Truly remarkable, park rangers were great and even stopped to give us a brief description of what the canyon looked like millions of years ago. Kids got quoted the educaiton and excercise. A wonderful time. There is a fee, but it's only $5 per car and its good for all the local national monument parks, excluding the grand canyon.

Visited here on my way home from the casino (not worth it), and am very glad I stopped. The view is gorgeous and the guides are very helpful. It only cost $6 for the entire car of people. There is a shuttle bus there that takes you into the small town for more sight seeing that is included with the price of admission to the park. Everything was clean, including the bus, and everyone in town was very nice and helpful.The history surrounding the park is also fascinating. I would go back again.

I always wanted to visit Mammoth Cave when I was a child and finally got the opportunity at 24 years of age! I was so glad I decided to go, as it proved worth the wait. We stayed a the campground in Mammoth Cave National Park, which was the best decision we could've made, as it made for a cheaper vacation and provided a great atmosphere. The campground was cheap, clean, secluded, and quiet, which is everything I ask for in a campground. The cave attraction itself was definitely worth the money. While the city itself on the outskirts of the national park has clearly declined in recent years with many businesses closed down, there was still plenty to keep us busy. We visited a Wildlife Museum that was actually a lot more fun than we thought it would be. The museum featured taxidermy animals and was definitely an old museum, but I ended up sharing a lot of laughs and taking a lot of photographs with my friend. The other cave attractions in the area are fun as well, and Bowling Green proved to be a lovely town to visit!

We have a 12 yr old son & a 9 yr old daughter that we took to Mammoth Caves in March. We thought it was just awesome! The kids really enjoyed it. There are several different entrances to the caves and we went to two of them. We spent about 6 hours at the park. They shuttle you to the entrance to the caves. There is a gift shop, good free parking close to ticket area but not much food/drink places on site. We brought our lunch and sat outside at a picnic table to eat. Even though it was March- we had a very nice day. Very interesting and educational for children and adults!

After seeing the Adams miniseries on HBO, we decided to pay a visit. We went on a very hot July day (midweek) and were able to get on the trolley right away. The birthplace and family homes are small and limited on what you can see, but portable A/C units made them bearable even on the very hot day. The guides are very knowledgeable and friendly. No internal photo's though. The tour of the library and of the Peacefield house are more comprehensive and again, knowledgeably led. Whole tour is about 2 hours, $5 (great deal), and very interesting for adults. I would leave kids at home though. Use bathrooms before leaving! They even validate parking for the lot behind the center.

After seeing crazy horse, we were shocked to see how small Mt. Rushmore really is! I always pictured it to be much bigger. Still worth visiting, nice facilities, we did the hike up the steps underneath the carving, over 200 steps! But worth doing. You have to visit if your in the area and its free, the parking is a big scam though! Way to much to charge but they have you trapped since there really is no good free place to park. It's a short stop you have to do if your in the Black Hills. And yes the food is way overpriced like the parking!

From where we were camping, we drove close to an hour to get to the Visitor Centre within the park, The drive from the North ($10 park fee) entrance was progressively getting more interesting. The rugged outcrops of black/brown lava were an incredible contrast to the surrounding landscape. Devil's Homestead was a fantastic sight -- a whole sea of lava that looks like it had bubbled to the surface.

Denali National Park is a "Must See" attraction. The views are absolutely unbelievable, and here you are treated to a new view at every turn. I continually told myself, I have enough pictures of the mountains, then took still more. The Park Staff are dedicated to helping you and answering all your questions. The Musium there is small, but highly informative. Be cautioned though, the roadways will not take you as close to Mt Mckinley as you would like. That's what keeps it a majestic wildernness and not an ammusement park. We were awed by this sight. Camping has a charge, visiting is free.

On a recent trip, I convinced my family to detour off of I-84 on a drive from Salt Lake to Boise to the visit the Golden Spike National Historic Site. I wanted to see the place where the first US transcontinental railway was completed in 1869, but I did not know what there was to see or do there. To our surprise, there was much to see if one has some interest in US history. The story of the building of the railroad is fairly well known, but we did not realize that Promontory Point, where the Golden Spike was driven in May 1869 was one of the most difficult parts of the railroad to build because it is so steep. We could see the old railroad grade climbing up the Promonory Mountains as we approached from the Salt Lake area so we started to realize this was a tough spot to build a railroad even before we reached the museum. We also did not know that Congress had allowed the two competing railroad companies to each build a right of way for the rails (at government expense) so there are actually two railroad grades visible at the Golden Spirke site though only one was ever used. Finally we were delighted to see that that the National Park Service conducts a daily recreation of the actual driving of the Golden Spike during the summer and they have two working steam engine locamotives that are close replicas of the ones that were actually used in 1869. That was the highlight of our visit. We also explored the small but nice museum and did a portion of the car tour that takes you along one of the old railroad grades to see how they built the railroad in the 1860s. The railroad now takes an easier route that bypasses the Golden Spike site so all the tracks have been removed except for the track used for the driving of the Golden Spike re-creation. Overall we felt our visit exceeded our expectations. If I went again I would check the Golden Spike's website to see the schedule for the driving of the Golden Spike re-creations which includes the two steam engines chugging up the tracks to meet. One from the west and the other from the east just like in 1869. Great sight to see if schedule allows

I am a huge history buff, so it is difficult for me to rate this site so low; however, the fact is we were very disappointed with the visit overall. It really just had the feel of a tourist trap. I was very much looking forward to visiting the Lewis and Clark museum but found it very lacking. The entire "museum" was located in one single small room. The reconstructed firehouse where John Brown and his party were captured was interesting and definitely the highlight. The majority of buildings were shops, bars, or eateries. If you are in the area it would be worth stopping by just to say you have been there. Otherwise, I am sad to say I could not recommend going far out of your way to visit the site as I feel its historical significance is not represented very well.

Denali State Park is the only national park in the USA that sold itself to a private company for profit, yet operates under the guise of a taxpayer sponsored national park. You are not allowed to enter the park with your own car. You can walk , but that would be impossible. You are required to use Aramark industries as a private consultant, and they will drive you in on a packed old school bus for $45-$120 per person per day. But, you must also pay the park entrance fee on top of this to the park service of $10 per person. A complete scam. No other park, specifically Yellowstone, the grand park, does such a terrible thing. You pay $25 at Yellowstone for a 3 day unlimited pass for one car to the entire park, as a taxpayer should. On top of all of this, the wildlife is very limited and is certainly not compared to Yellowstone. The people are scammer types that charge $30 for a baseball cap and $15 for a hot dog type, if you know what I mean. What a huge disappointment.

Take time to visit Jewel Cave, the 2nd longest cave in the world, if you are in the Black Hills area on vacation. Jewel Cave offers several different tours. The Scenic Tour (only $8 for adults) is one of the most popular and fills up quickly. You can call ahead to reserve/purchase tickets which I highly recommend. The scenic tour lasts about 1 1/2 hours and involves walking up and down 723 stair steps over a 1/2 mile loop, equal to about 40 flights of stairs. Some of the stairsteps are steep but overall it's very easy and not strenous. On this tour you'll see two types of calcite crystals, nailhead spar and dogtooth spar, which are the what Jewel Cave is known for. You'll also see formations of boxwork, flowstone, cave popcorn, draperies, stalactites, stalagmites and a long ribbon drapery that our guide referred to as cave bacon. Our guide was very knowledgeable so it made for an interesting tour. I would recommend this tour more for adults and older children. There were a few babies and young children on our tour and they became quite fussy and disturbed by the darkness shortly after the tour began.
Capitol Reef is by far one of the best parks in Utah. Very reasonable lodging. Camping as well in designated camp areas. I recommend paying for a cabin, prices run about $35 - $85 per night.

Heading North on Hwy 97 between Klamath Falls and Bend, detouring to Crater Lake (via Hwy 62) adds about 40 minutes of travel time. The drive was easy, even while hauling our travel trailer. There are several viewpoints to stop and overlook impressive deep canyons. We stopped at the Visitor Centre after paying the $10 park entrance fee, but didn’t find it was really necessary. Continuing to drive up to Rim Village was where everything convenes. (Café, gift shop, information, tours, etc.)

Awesome attraction. Much more to see and do that I anticipated. However, I would highly recommend to eat before or after you go as the food is mediocre at best and a bit pricey. There is quite a bit of selection but the burgers are premade and wrapped in foil on a warmer. I did notice that they were chargrilling burgers/hot dogs outside so that is the way to go. I got a garden burger and it was just barely edible. Bottled beer is $5 a pop. Otherwise, a fantastic experience and the only fee for the attraction is for parking which is $11 per car.

The Grand Tetons National Park and Jackson Hole make for a perfect family vacation. We flew into Jackson and spent two nights at the Rustic Inn in a lovely log cabin on a beautiful creek overlooking the mountains. The Inn was 10minutes from the airport and within walking distance to downtown Jackson. The rate includes an unbelievable huge breakfast with lots of choices.Dinner at the Blue Lion was fabulous with a wonderful guitarist serenading us softly during our meal.Cafe Genevieve was a perfect place for lunch with great reasonable comfort food. Mad River Rafting was excellent for white water rafting and they supply wet suits,booties and slickers which I highly recommend as you will get wet and have a blast! Take the tram up the mountain in Jackson Village for unbelievable views and the best waffles and hot cocoa when you get out at the top.After two nights in Jackson, we headed to the Grand Teton National Park to stay at Signal Mountain Lodge. This could be the best family vacation spot ever! It is set on Jackson Lake surrounded by the Tetons with wrap around views that go on forever. We had a wonderful upper lake view unit 160 with two double beds, a big comfy leather sofa, stove top, microwave and full size fridge and bath.I would highly recommend an upper unit unless you have small children or a dog, then I would suggest a ground floor unit or separate log cabin. Our unit was smoke and pet free. Everything is very clean, but not fancy. There is a convenience store, gas station, gift shop, and three restaurants. with organic and gluten free options.The Peaks , has unbelievable views in a beautiful fire placed dining room with great food and service. The staff are friendly and helpful and seem genuinely happy to be working there.Andy set us up with a motorboat at the marina steps from our room to zip around the lake and explore some of the hidden coves. You could also canoe , kayak or rent a larger pontoon boat. Johanna , at the front desk, set us up with horseback riding at a family ranch about 25 minutes away followed by lunch at an adorable place called the Buffalo Cafe with great burgers and huckleberry shakes on a screened porch.Yellow Stone National Park is just minutes from Signal Mountain. Pack a picnic,water,beach towels , sunscreen and lots of bug spray and plan on a full day of exploring. We spent time swimming in Moose Falls and found a perfect picnic spot, but did't have enough time for the hour and a half trip to Old Faithful. The next day we took a shuttle boat to Jenny's Lake for some great hiking to beautiful Cascade Falls and amazing views from Inspiration Point.We had the best pizza and homemade ice cream 20 minutes from Signal ,at Leeks. The line was out the door, but well worth the wait. Once inside the big retro styled dining room overlooking the lake, we joined families of many different nationalities sitting at picnic tables sharing pizza and bopping to the oldies ,piped in from the ipods of the fantastic group of young people working there. Watching the staff singing and dancing as they worked made us all smile and enjoy the fabulous pizza even more.

If you love history (especially Lewis & Clark) this is a great place to visit. The park is very clean & well maintained & has a wonderful visitor center with lots of helpful rangers & staff. They were awesome with our grandson who had completed is Jr Ranger booklet & with other kids who had earned their, too. They have a gift shop & a nice museum with some wonderful artifacts & of course the fort itself which is like stepping back in time. It's furnished as though the corps are living there & they have volunteers who are dressed in period clothes & will gladly answer all your questions & are very knowledgeable. They also have daily demonstrations on life in the L&C days at the fort. We watched the musket presentation & it was GREAT! Fun for old & young alike, especially kids learning about L&C or NW history. There are hiking trails & they even have free canoe trips each day during the summer. We had a very enjoyable time here. Fee is minimal & well worth it.

We stayed at the Cedar Grove Lodge. A little funky looking when you first arrive, but it's the only "lodging" option right in the heart of Kings Canyon, and it's like "The Little Engine That Could" of little National Park Lodges. Our room might have looked right out of the 70's, but it was VERY clean, the bed was VERY comfortable, great shower. Couldn't have asked for more for such a low price, and I really was happy not to be camping on the ground that night. The people who work there really seem to take a lot of pride in their little lodge, and they work hard running the market and snack bar that are the only services available to hundreds of campers coming through the area. Oh, and would you believe FREE Wi-Fi? Okay, that was unexpected. Kings Canyon has beautiful local hiking and also serves as the gateway to the backcountry. It's worth the drive, and even though Sequoia never really gets that crowded (any anything you think you might complain about a small crowd... remember how much worse it would be if you were in Yosemite...) and in Kings Canyon we hardly saw a soul once we were out on the trails.

It is a very lucky thing that people were so dedicated to keep this area of South Carolina from being torn down by loggers. The forest here is absolutely amazing and filled with tons of different species, vegetation, and other life. Admission was free (or we somehow accidentally missed where we were supposed to pay) and the visitors center is very informational and the park rangers are friendly and helpful. The park is a set of trails throughout the forest that have markers along the way to show you different types of growth, trees, and other things that stick out of the ordinary that you have not seen anywhere else. It’s a flood plain so it occasionally floods throughout the year and it’s a swamp most the rest of the time, but it was quite dry when we went. There were so many things to see, from the large looming trees that make up the canopy, the fallen trees various plants, and other things that make up the floor, the insects and animals that live all around, and so many unique things. We saw turtles and even got to hear a tree fall down somewhere! I would highly recommend stopping by this National Park and taking the 2-mile boardwalk trip to see all things it has to offer, with something to offer at every turn. Very very cool!!

We visited in June with 2 kids. We happened to visit on a day when it was free admission. Staff were wonderful--dressed in period dress. We had Sasparilla at the "bar". Very educational. We spent a lot of time here---we love history. Someone else probably wouldn't take as long as we did. Pony Express information here also.--Pies available at the bar.

We hurried to make it to the ticket office to buy boat tour tickets. We changed our minds when we arrived. It is about a mile and a half hike down which is easy. However, coming up it is like climbing a 75 story building straight up. We arrived at 10:00 and the next boat tour we could buy was for 3:00. No one in my family wanted to do the crazy hike so we just drove around the lake. You can also play in the snow. Where else can you were shorts and have a snowball fight. The lake is a beautiful blue and the weather is perfect!!!!!!

It is very frustrating to pay $$$ to our national parks, only to find out that there are strict regulations on where you can have a pet. For the most part it is within 6 ft off the roadway. There are no shady places to park where the pet would be cool. So you end up driving through the park and seeing only what you can from the car. I should have done more research on the regulations of our parks before driving over 2000 miles.

Fort Matanzas is a short drive out of St Augustine . You take a small ferry over to the island where the Fort is . The fort is very small and you have approx 45 minutes at the fort before the boat arrives to take you back . A Ranger stays at the fort with you and he is very knowledgable about the history of the place and tells very entertaining story's , he was good at engaging the children in the group telling them what their life would have been like at time . I was amazed that there was no fee for this attraction but you can leave tips in the box in the office where you get the tickets for the ferry . We spent a couple of hours here in total and would recommend it to others .

We took our family to Mt. Rushmore in July with a seven and three year old. The junior ranger program was great for our seven year old to get and stay interested in the park. The visitor center had some really neat information but it was not geared towards little kids at all. We watched the movie and found it to be interesting and information without being too long. I do highly recommend the ranger tour because they give a lot of little neat facts that aren't widely known. It was very neat to see this site but there wasn't a lot of activities to stay for a while. The entrance was free but parking cost $12 but the pass is good for the year.

Living close by in Southern New Mexico makes it convenient to visit this amazing place known as White Sands. It is right off of Interstate 70 between the White Sands Missile Range and Holloman AFB in Alamagordo. We have visited a few times in the past couple of years and they have quite a bit to offer for the whole family. You will first park at the visitor center where you will find a lovely adobe gift shop and media area where they show films about how nature has created the spectacular site. As this is part of the National Park Service, you will find a wealth of information about this natural wonder. The fee for entrance is $3 per person and you have the option of walking on trails or driving the 8 mile loop around the park. We chose to drive as it was hot most days when we visited. As you enter the park itself, you will be astounded by the abundance of pure white gypsum sand that surrounds you like sand dunes on a beach. You will see nothing but white, almost like you were in a winter wonderland. Along the road you will find areas where you can pull off and walk into the dunes. There are boardwalks along the way as well and roof covered picnic tables for the family. The park service offers many educational programs throughout the year and they even give tours of the lake that creates the sand several times a year. This is just a spectacular place that the whole family should visit when in New Mexico. You will feel like you are on another planet, as there is nothing like it on this Earth!

I've been here in the past and the memory I took away was the traffic and crowds. My visit this year (July 2011) was completely different: we visited on a Friday morning and drove right up to the area. There's now a large parking garage which I'm sure helped elivate the issues I remember in previous visits. (There's a fee to park but not to access the memorial.)

We ended up going to Mt. Rushmore three times during our one week visit in S.Dakota. (The parking pass is good for one year). It was our first stop on our first day in S. Dakota as it was on my "bucket list." The pictures in books, magazines, movies just can't give you the sense of how large this is, nor what an absolutely gorgeous setting it is.

Redwood National Park has so much to offer. In addition to some of the tallest trees in the world, the are also miles of beautiful coastline to explore. My favorites were Hidden Beach and the Cathedral Trail. The Tall Trees Trail is great also. If you want to visit it be sure to request a pass from the visitors center early in the day before they reach their 50 per day limit. Also, check out the Elk in the meadows. The rangers can tell you the best places to look.

Wonderful experience especially all those mountains! We did not see too many animals (1) but the scenery was worth going to & the Park Rangers were very helpful. We had to pay a small fee to go 15 miles in to the park as we did not have time to go on the tour bus but we could see a lot inspite of the low clouds & the threat of rain.

Our family with young children toured the Lincoln home in Springfield, Illinois recently. What a great experience to be able to walk in the same neighborhood as Mr. Lincoln! Stop in the Visitors' Center to pick up your FREE ticket for a guided tour of the Lincoln home.

If in the area or making a road trip, this must be visited. No entry fee as this is a National Memorial. The fee for parking was $11 for a car and was good for return visits at night or until the year's end. TIP: Renting the Audio Tour is worth the $5. Very easy to operate and gives information at numbered stops. .Wheelchairs cannot go on the walk around the Memorial due to the number of steps. We took the walk to get closer to the Memorial--long walk with many steps. But well worth the effort! At night they light the Momorial and worth the return tripENJOY!

We took the scenic tour which runs about an hour and a half. It was a great value for $20 for a family of 4. The tour was educational and fun for the whole family. Definitely call ahead to reserve tickets as the tours fill up quickly. I was worried about the 723 steps but it wasn't as bad as it sounds.

While on a road trip with friends I stopped by to see this monument. It is definitely something I recommend, especially for someone that appreciates history and culture. The monument is a bit underwhelming as it is very far away from the viewing platform and thus appears rather small off in the distance. Also, parking is for a fee (about $12), and was still difficult to find a parking space. My friends and I read all of the various plaques and information kiosks, took pictures of all of the state flags, and many pictures of the monument itself, and were still hard pressed to spend more than one hour here. There is a free show where a park guide describes the history of the monument, but this will be redundant to most people.

Really a national treasure. In the middle of the desert between Las Cruces, NM and Alamogordo, NM you will find White Sands National Monument. The visitors center has a great exhibit featuring the national monument along with a short video that educates visitors on the formation of the sand dunes. Once you enter the monument, you can choose many different routes to take and pick your dune. Never very busy when we go there are covered picnic tables available with grills. The kids and adults:) alike enjoy sliding down the sand dunes in waxed bottomed (candles work) saucer sleds (approximately $10-15 at visitors center so if you have one, bring it!) Watching the sunset from the top of the dunes is amazing. Dogs are allowed but must be leashed. Alcohol is prohibited during "spring break" times (call ahead if concerned, I think during March and April) and they will check your coolers. Be prepared to have a car full of sand, no matter how hard you try it sticks on your clothes. During the summers can be very hot so recommend going early in the morning or later in the evening. Certain days of the week/month the monument offers sunset tours, etc. Check the website for more info.

Our plan was to walk along the Fremont River trail. It was rather overgrown and buggy, but kids had fun petting the horses in the field and looking in the pioneer farmhouse. We stopped to pick apricots in the orchard - as many as you can eat for free and $1 per pound if you take them away. To the kids delight, the horses stuck their head over the fence and were loving to be fed the rotten apricots. I think we had more fun doing that than eating them ourselves!!

This park is amazing. I think it often plays second fiddle to Yellowstone, but it is very beautiful and the hiking and other activities are definitely not second rate. If you are coming to Jackson please don't just view this park as a gateway to Yellowstone - it is so much more. My family enjoyed biking on the relatively new bikepath - you have awesome views of the Tetons the entire time! There are some great family friendly hikes - an easy one is the shuttle across Jenny Lake then up to the falls. Too much to mention. We are going back next year and will spend a few days in Jackson Lake lodge so we can take advantage of even more the park has to offer. My kids loved it!

This is a site that is worth the drive. IT is funny that when we got our first look at the memorial there were four cars that had to pull off before they even got to the site. There is an $11 parking fee but the fee is good for a week.

This is a beautiful place. We did the boat tour in the lake. It takes about an hour to drive to the place once you get to the park, so allow plenty of time. We were rushed. Once you get there, you need to walk down a hugh hill. Going down isn't a problem. The boat tour is good, but not great. There is a ranger on the boat that tells you all about he lake. You could get the same thing from the tour up top, and it would take 2 hours. The hike up afterwards is very challenging. I think that it is worth doing if you are in shape and not in a rush. I think it was about $29 per person.

I had a free afternoon while visiting Salt Lake City, and decided to check this out. It was in the middle of nowhere, but relatively easy to get to. It costs $7 per car, but it's only collected when you enter the visitor's center so theoretically you can probably get on the driving trails for free as long as you know where you're going.

So glad we were able to see Mt. Rushmore. It was wonderful to see in person instead of in pictures. The price for parking is cheap enough compared to other things in the area. Would go back again if I was anywhere in the area. Was able to get some beautiful pics of my own.

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: Went to the LBJ Ranch, Western White House. The whole park takes about 3 hours to see, it is worth your time. You start off at the Visitors Center/ Gift Shop, there was no charge and we were given a CD to guide us over the Ranch. Numerous thing to see along the way. When you finally get the the Johnson Family home there is a $2 charge to go into the home. If you are a history buff you will enjoy.
It is neat to see, but as usual the federal government charges a fee to see it. I did not find that it was worth the $11.00 fee to enter the park.

Teen son was super impressed...first time seeing such a deep rocky canyon. Its a combination of black and grey rock with some warmer tones on one wall called the painted wall. Lots of stairs to climb to viewing platforms. Some pulloffs on roads for easier viewing too. Nice visitor center. Somewhat steep drive to the canyon itself....small fee to enter park.

We didn't know if we would visit Fort Clatsop when sightseeing down the Oregon Coast or not. My 12 year old and my 76 year old father love history along with myself, so we decided to stop for a little bit. We are so glad we did. We parked at the visitor's center, and my parents bought a Senior Citizen National Park card for $10 which got all of us in. (Which we later used it at the Grand Canyon, Montezuma's Castle and Yosemite! Definitely worth the cost) and we took a short walk to the fort. We arrived just in time for the 1:30 presentation on shooting the old musket. A nice presentation with a man in historical garb. My 8 year old enjoyed it along with us, but anyone much younger I noticed ended up leaving before it was over. Dad had to turn off his hearing aids for the shooting of the gun.
Well worth the trip. Great place to chill out and enjoy the view. The entire area around Keystone is just fantastic, lots to do and see. There is no fee to get in but there is a fee for parking.

We visited Mount Rushmore in late August and had a wonderful time. There was an extremely reasonable entrance fee plus your pass is good for the entire year! We walked the Presidents Trail and really enjoyed all of the different vantage points it provided to the monument. Later that night we returned for the lighting ceremony and this is another MUST SEE part of your trip. I found it to be a really moving and patriotic event. The park ranger brokedown the meaning of the Pledge of Allegiance, the National Anthem was sung, our military men and women were honored and there was a great video presented that detailed why each of the presidents was chosen to be memorialized on the mountain. This needs to be at the top of your list of things to do in the area!

I'm just going to point out some of the highlights of our trip in case it is helpful to anyone else. We stayed in the Ravenwood Motel in Klamath (& loved it but it is pretty isolated) then we spent a day travelling north & another day travelling south. Starting north on your park map & heading south: we would recommend the Howland Hill Rd. drive & the Stout Grove trail. You can walk over to the Battery Point Lighthouse but nearby is the Seal rescue center & you can walk around outside & see if they are re-habbing any animals & give them a donation for the awesome work they do. We liked the Yurok Loop trail and saw a bald eagle & we also did the Trees of Mystery. We drove the Newton Drury Pkwy & we did see some elk near the visitor center. We really liked the Fern Canyon trail (you can only hike it for a 1 mile loop if you want)--highly recommended but $8 per car load. We also liked the Trilium Falls Trail--we saw elk here too. These were our favorite things we did over 2 days. Good luck!

We took our family and our exchange student. We all loved it. The hike fun and the attraction as a site to see. Walnut canyon is something every small kid need to see. My boy is 4 and he did the hike all by his self. We packed a nice lunch and eat right at the park. The price is $5 a person in get in. Kid's under ( I think 15) where free.

We came to Springfield to see all the Lincoln attractions and were pleasantly surprised by the beautiful park-like atmosphere of this site. Instead of the 1/2 hour we expected, we spent over 2 hours and enjoyed every second. The tour of the home is led by a park ranger in small groups (you have to pickup a free ticket at the visitor center which tells you what time your tour starts) and is very interesting and well done. Afterwards (or before if you prefer) you are free to tour the two block neighborhood of restored homes. What a gem--don't miss this one.

Congaree is the nation's second newest national park, and to be honest I had not even heard of it until a couple of years ago. I can say without hesitation that it is one of the most spectacular places I have ever visited. It is almost a secret though. I visited mid-week and there were very few people there. I was told it is much busier in fall and spring when the water levels are higher and it is more conducive to canoeing. Park admission is free. There are 2 campgrounds; 1 is primitive with no facilities. The visitor center is small as national park visitor centers go but there is a good introductory film that I recommend before exploring. The park employees were all very friendly and informative; they enhance the experience. If you only have a few hours to spend at the park the Boardwalk Loop Trail is the way to go. It is 2.4 miles long and it must have been quite a project to build such an extensive structure. The next morning I was going to hike the 10 mile River Trail but a ranger recommended the 6.6 mile Oak Ridge Trail instead because of the spectacular oak trees along the way. She also said this time of year the River Trail gets overgrown with vegetation. I took her advice and am glad I did. Most of the trails start out on the Boardwalk Trail and branch off from it. The trails are well-blazed and there are well constructed footbridges over all water crossings. On the Oak Ridge Trail I did not encounter one other person, but I did see deer and I believe wild hogs, which I kept my distance from. As I was the first trailblazer of the day I did encounter countless spider webs spun across the trail so if you suffer from arachnophobia what are you doing in the deep woods to begin with lol. I cannot come up with appropriate words to describe the majesty of these soaring hardwoods (and loblolly pines for good measure). There are several champion trees here and I saw sycamores, oaks, beech and other trees that I never imagined could grow that tall. It is hard to imagine that just 35 years ago this area could have completely fallen victim to commercial interests. Thank God for the people who fought to preseve this most special place.

This was our second visit to Crater Lake. Before we did a quick rim drive and left. This time we stayed at the Whispering Pines Motel, a great value at $55, 25 minutes from the rim. We spent 2 days exploring Crater Lake more thoroughly, and still felt like we missed so much. Take the rim drive slowly, stop at all the pull-offs. Each angle is a different view and brings new surprises, even just 25 yards further along the rim. Get out of the car. Soak in the amazing geological history. We took the time to hike down Cleetwood trail and take the 2 hour boat trip around the lake. The climb is not easy, but we are middle aged and took our time. It is well worth it. The views from the lake level give a whole new view of the geology. The US National Park Service Guide was a fountain of knowledge and taught us fascinating things about the Crater and its history. She pointed out many formations and explained their meaning. Next time we will explore some of the trails to wonders surrounding the caldera. There are many short hikes to amazing places....next time.

While Sharpsburg, MD may not necessarily be on the top of everyone's wish list, it should be particularly if you have any interest in visiting & experiencing Civil War sites. We are so glad to have included Antietam as a stop this summer. The visitor center is staffed with very knowledgeable and friendly staff. The brief orientation film is a requirement as it provides a comprehensive overview of the hard fought battles fought on the surrounding fields. We opted to purchase the audio car tour; we're hooked on these since visiting Gettysburg and Valley Forge last year. They provide a lot of details and clearly direct you throughout the park. This is an important park to visit and pay respects to those who gave their lives fighting for what they believed in. Gettysburg and Valley Forge have more elaborate facilities and amenities but this park is a gem in a different way.

From downtown Astoria, it took just fifteen minutes to drive to Fort Clatsop. Because it was an uphill climb from the parking lot to the Visitor Center we got out the wheelchair for Louise, and upon reaching the entrance all three of us were allowed to enter the park free of charge based upon my National Park Senior Pass. I would heartily recommend obtaining this pass to anyone over the age of 62 who plans to travel even moderately. It cost a mere $10 and allows free entry into any National Park, Forest, Battlefield, etc., to the bearer and up to three other persons in his/her car. It is good for life.

While not overly convenient to the Interstate, Rushmore is well worth the visit. The monument itself is awesome, and the (relatively) new entrance adds to the splendor. We visited just before Labor Day and there were no crowds on a spectacular day. We had breakfast at the cafeteria on the site; food was surprisingly good for breakfast. When you go, notice the original viewing site adjacent to the current one. And go early or late in the day when the sun isn't directly overhead to get nice detail. The admission is $11 per car, there's a large parking structure, and the admission is much more reasonable than it is for Crazy Horse.

If you ever have the opportunity to travel to southern Utah, you must visit Bryce Canyon National Park. The cost is $25.00 per vehicle, and worth every dime. The formations are caused from sand and wind, primarily, and are utterly beautiful. Take advantage of the 22 minute video offered every half hour at the visitor center, and it will help you understand what you are seeing. Stop at all the observation points, and bring your camera. Bring your hiking shoes and plenty of water if you want to go on some of the trails. Be sure to follow the advice of all the rangers, and don't overextend yourself.

This was my third time to see this lake. It is the most beautiful lake I've ever seen, and I don't think I'd ever tire of seeing it. The views are spectacular. If you have time, (and Money) take the boat trip out to Wizard Island. We didn't this time, instead, just enjoyed the shoreline views of the blue blue water. If you are a senior (62 or over) be sure and buy a $10 lifetime pass for the National Parks in the United States. Hold on to it, because they don't keep records of your card...and if lost, you'll have to replace it. It's good for admittance to ANY national park....the daily entrance is usually $10/day, so once you've paid for it, you're in! This includes everyone in your vehicles as well!

There is a $2.00 parking fee, but tickets for the guided tour of the Lincoln's home is free. Suggest you allow 2 to 2 1/2 hours so you can walk the entire four block preserved area and read the historically information throughout the neighborhood. Also, don’t miss the short film in the visitor’s center.

This was our third trip to Mount Rush more and we are impressed every time. It was special this time as we met one of the original carvers that worked on the stones, Don "Nick" Clifford who is 90 years old and the only one surviving who worked on the monument. His wife, Carolyn, chatted with us for several minutes and her story was likewise as interesting.In the early morning hours there is a minimum group of people thus leaving a lot of the viewing space for just a few. Buses don't start arriving until mid morning. You will be charged $11.00 to park however the entrance to the monument is free. Fees of this type charged by concessionaires under contract with the National Park Service is slowing ruining the publics perception about the Park Service. The other concessions, such as the gift show , are also tun by large corporations determined to get your last dollar and many times providing a cheap , shoddy imported product as a souvenir. There is a gift shop and cafeteria on the grounds, plus a theater that will give you the story of the construction. The gift shop has numerous books about the monument and unless you just have to have the book at once, I find jotting down the name and ISNB number and waiting until I return home and make the purchase off of Amazon where I save 30 to 40 percent off the retail price. Plus I don't have to lug that book or books around for many more miles. The little town Keystone is located just down the road and there you can get a cup of coffee or maybe a sandwich. Fair warning---it is a tourist town with lots of cheap novelties. The traffic to and from the moment during the summer season can be a challenge, thus patience is a virtue.

The Mount Rushmore monument is beautiful and a value too! It was only $11 for a year long entrance pass. The outdoor areas are well thought-out. We took a walking tour with one of the park ranger, which was very fun and informative. We also returned for the night lighting ceremony, which was beautiful. It is well worth it!

This is a very nice National Parks with lots of water in several lakes. We loved the drive around the area. There are several places where on can get food, gas or lodging in the park. By the way there is a fee to enter. Maintain the proper speed limit as there are many park rangers that have nothing to do other that set up radar. When I first visited the area many years ago this was not the case. It’s apparently turning in to a revenue generating activity for the Nation Park Service If traveling north you will leave the Teton National park and enter Yellowstone. Be sure and allow plenty of time especially during the summer high season. The road will more than likely be closed in the winter according to one of the guides we listed to. If you have never been to this part of the United States you should certainly make it a point to add to your travel list. Last week it was cool and we were glad to be away from the Texas heat.

Just stayed here for the third time, and I absolutely love the place. I always stay at one of the campsites near trails end, a little rougher than most camp sites. It's cheap, easy, and a great getaway. For the backpacker, there are trails to hike in and camp, which I've also done and enjoyed very much. Any one who's looking for a little roughing it will have fun, and there is also a lodge with a store for those who don't.
