I had wanted to visit Mammoth Cave for many years and planned our vacation around it.The park and facilities around the cave were very nice.There were two places to eat while we waited for our timed cave tour.We opted for the smaller cafe and the food was excellent and I felt reasonably priced.There are also gift shops to look through while you wait.There are a variety of tours to choose from with different prices and levels of difficulty.We had our kids with us and opted for the Mammoth Passage Tour, it is considered EASY but does have 160 stairs round trip.The $5.00 per person (6-12yrs are $3.50) fee was reasonable for the 3/4 mile 1hour15min. guided tour,but we were very dissappointed with the cave.It is a dry cave (no stalagtites,no stalagmites,no beautiful formations of any kind).It was like walking through a mountain.Yes it was very big inside but nothing spectacular to look at in our opinion.It is chilly year round(50 degrees) in the cave so bring a lightweight jacket.It is also my opinion that if you have children under six who are easily bored or can't be quiet PLEASE do not bring them here.The tour guide does alot of talking and because there can be as many as 40 people on this tour it is difficult to hear,especially with small bored children in the group.We had a women that was alone with 3 kids under 5 that made it an unpleasant experience.It is not handicapped accessable.You can take still pictures,but no video taping.You are not allowed to bring in camera bags,diaper bags,purses,or bags of any kind.If you are going on a weekend it is recommended that you reserve and pay for your tour ahead of time as they do sell out quickly.Everyone has to walk on a disinfecting mat at the end of the tour because of White Nose Syndrome which is killing bats in Kentucky(I recommend you wear athletic shoes).Overall I would still recommend going if you are passing through the area or camping in the park and there are alot of other cave tours in the area.

It is something everyone should see. You hear about how big it is and what people had to do to create it, but seeing it all in person is a different story. They have tours there that I heard were good, but I injured my leg 2 days before the trip and couldn't do all the walking involved. We did look through all the museum-type attractions and it clearly details how the entire thing came about and all the people who endured very dangerous work conditions to get the job done. I would highly recommend this attraction. It's $10 or 11 to park and that is all you pay for.
So glad we worked this into our trip. We went in the afternoon and then back again for the lighting ceremony. The $11 parking fee is good for the entire year for the vehicle driven in.

This is a nice national park to visit to learn more about the Battles of Saratoga that took place in September and October of 1777. The park is run by the National Park Service.. The Visitors Center is free and has a wonderful exhibit and film. We went on the car tour which cost $5.00 per person. If you have the Golden Age pass it is free. There are a number of stops on the tour with explanations of the battle sites, including the home of the people who lived there at time. A re enactor was on site dressed in colonial clothes to answer our questions. We sort of rushed through it because we had to make a schedule but if I were to go again, I would be more leisurely. It is a good way to learn more about how our country was formed including the heroics of Benedict Arnold that most of us only think of as a traitor. You can also hike throughout the park.

We visited the redwood forest as part of our California road trip. We had been to the Muir Woods Sequoia forest the day before so it was interesting to compare this experience to that. The weather was gorgeous that day, warm and sunny with really bright blue skies, but the limited parking areas were full by the time we got there, well before noon. We had to park about a mile or so on the road and walk back, but it was free. The entrance fee to the forest is $5.00 per person. After paying that you can visit the gift shop, eat, drink, go to the restroom or just proceed into the redwood area. There is a whole different atmosphere upon entering the forest. It is a humbling, almost hushed attitude that the visitors have while in it. I looked around while walking the several miles that we did that day and there were people visiting from several nations. I could hear snippets of german, korean, italian, french and some indian and arabic dialects being spoken around us. After a mile or so inside the forest, there is a clearing where one can sit on a bench, reflect, take pics, etc., and where a park ranger gives a 15 minute talk on the history of the forest and how very difficult it is to grow a majestic redwood to maturity. A tiny redwood seed must go through a gauntlet of issues before it has a hope of becoming a fully mature tree. This was fascinating stuff to me. The natural beauty and history of this forest, on the day that we were there, was pretty much perfect.

I visited Mt Rushmore on 9/11/11, which seemed like a good day to celebrate America. There is really not much to say about the monument that you don't already know. Everyone has seen pictures and everyone knows what it is. But to finally see it in person was breathtaking. It almost brought tears to my eyes (seeing the monument combined with the fact that it was an infamous anniversary). The weather was gorgeous the day I was there (80s and sunny)--unseasonable for South Dakota in September. I do recommend you do some online research before going to Keystone so you know a little bit about prices and places to stay and best places to view. It is free to view the monument, but there is a fee to park in the best viewing area. The parking pass, though, is good for a calendar year.

After visiting the Eastern Sierra Mountains and Yosemite, I travelled to Kings Canyon/Sequoia National Park. The road in is a long, steep, and winding one. I arrived before noon, and had to wait in line to get my pass into the park. I proceeded on to Grant Grove Village, and found I was just in time to make a Rager led walk through the Grant Grove, so headed that way. The Ranger was an ex-teacher, who was very engaging with our group. In fact, he was so good that people along the way fell in with our group to find out the history and biology behind the Giant Sequoias. By the time I left Kings Canyon at about 2:00 p.m., there was a line of cars backed up down the hill about 3 miles, so I would suggest that you get there early to avoid long lines. Grants Village had a nice welcome center, gift shop and restaurant. There was a lot more of Kings Canyon/Sequoia that I did not see, as I did not have the time, but what I did see was worth the drive up the mountain.

My wife and I recently went on the tour of the Adams family historic sites conducted by the National Park Service. We highly recommend this tour to anyone who wants to see the origins and destinations of a family that contributed as much as any other to the history of our country. The tour starts from downtown Quincy where a trolley takes you to the houses where Adams family members were born, lived, worked and died. The tour guides from the National Park Service are extremely knowledgeable and pepper their historical narrative with interesting anecdotes. The whole tour takes two hours and time passes quickly. There is a nominal fee and photography is prohibited inside the buildings. The tour is family oriented but very small children might be restless by the end. Part of the tour requires going up and down stairs and the only bathrooms are at the Visitor Center where you begin and end. The tour is seasonal and closes down during the winter. Check the NPS web site for opening times.

The husband and I stopped here during a week-long road trip and were surprised by the splendor. The bridges are easily accessible from overlooks so one can just stop and view them, or you can go on several nice hikes to get closer to them. The scenery is beautiful and provides numerous stunning photography opportunities. There are some nice Native American ruins along one of the canyon walls to view (for this, I wish I had brought binoculars to get a better look). The landscape is pretty amazing and the park is peaceful as it does not get too crowded. The facilities are in excellent repair and the Park Ranger was very helpful and clearly enjoys his job. This park is definitely worth seeing and the entrance fee was cheap (about $7). We drove from the park toward Hite, UT, near Lake Powell, and the scenery was amazing.

This site is about four square blocks and is Illinois' only National Park! You can pick up a timed ticket (free) at the Visitors Center as only about 20 people are allowed in the Lincoln home at one time. A ranger will do introductions, and there will be rangers inside the home to tell you about the rooms. Note that the stairs to the second floor are steep.

It doesn't matter how many pictures you've seen of Mt. Rushmore. There is no way to describe how beautiful and special the National Park site is. Everyone ought to see it up close and personal at least once. Combined with a visit to Devil's Tower, Custer State Park, and Rapid City, and perhaps a drive through the Badlands National Park makes for a wonderful 5 to 7 day road trip. Taking this trip after Labor Day helps avoid the summer crowds and the weather was great. Be sure to return to Mt. Rushmore for the lighting ceremony at night.. Loved every minute of this trip.The National Park Golden Eagle pass does not work here.

I visited Lincoln's home for the first time in almost 30 years. The last time I was there was when I was 6-7 years old. It was very much the same as I remembered it. The house in the downtown area of Springfield and it is easy to get to. There is a small parking fee, but the tickets to visit the house are free. You just have to register at the visitors center to get your scheduled time. If you have to wait for a tour, there are a couple of other homes on the street that you may tour. This is a must see for anyone interested in history or Lincoln.

I loved my recent visit to this National Historical Park. The Visitor's center is right across the street from the Subway stop and a little trolley takes you around town to the different parts of the site. Very good value (5$ I think) and absolutely fascinating place to visit both for a taste of the period and to learn about the history of this remarkable family. This was a FAR more interesting site to visit than the JFK Library in my opinion.

jewel cave is great ,big wide open cavens cost to go on the tour is $8 each and well worth it the tour is about 1hour 30 minutes and your guide is very knowledgeable,well lit inside and there is a lot of stairs to climb but the pace is easy but note it is only for the able bodied,lots to see the flow stone is strange looks like caramel, please note you can not touch anything at all.

had great time at mount rushmore i am english but still thought mount rushmore was superb,do your walk around the base of rushmore its very nice things to read along the way they sell lovely icecream in the shop and its nice to just sit and watch people come and go up the avenue of flags dont miss it, it costs $11 dollars to park your car but entrance to the site is free , the parking ticket is valid for a week

This park has something for everyone. One day we visited the pools by the ocean, the next day we were at 10,000 feet high, watching the sun rise over a crater. If you do both things, save your receipt, because the admission fee is good for three days. Recommended.

2 stops here...wasn't visible for 2 days because of weather....but worth the wait. First seen at the night lighting ceremony....breathtaking.....park service does an excellent job of presentation....honoring Vietnam Veterans that evening. Following day can be done on same car ticket one time $11....park is well managed and operated. Park in lot #6, closest to the promenade for handicap access. Wheelchairs are available on sign out. Daytime overflight by jet fighters...awesome display. Lots to see, must take the Presidential Trail to the viewing platform....go to the left...easier walk going down the stair cases (250 steps). Gift shop was infuriating....only a few items Made in America, the rest made in China. So we only bought items MIA, their loss. Would have spent a lot more. Ice Cream cone was $4.75 for the smallest, more than a pint...seemed like a quart...way too much price and quantity...enough to freeze your brain. Mount Rushmore is a symbol of our great nation and the tone here is of a sacred nature....too bad the gift shop hasn't gotten the message....this is one place for America only. Better get here before Obama either grinds his face over Lincoln's or he sells it to the Chinese who will probably grind up the rock and put it in our food.
Beauty, great scenery, reasonable cost, you see wild life

Jewel Cave is a beautiful cave to visit. We had been to Carlsbad Cavern NP and Wind Cave NP and were wondering if "a cave is a cave". They are all different and beautiful in their own way. Jewel Cave seems to sparkle with it's formations. The park system has done a wonderful job with their tour. Bring a flashlight to better see the beauty of the many "jewel" like formations. Our ranger guide BethAnn was excellent, knowledgeable and seemed to love what she was doing. It is well worth the admission.

Our family was visiting Ruidoso, NM for an extended weekend. One morning we took the drive to White Sands to check it out. My wife and I and our two kids (3 & 5) and another family with same age children. It truly is a magnificent sight. I believe its 300 square miles of pure white sand dunes in the valley of some mountains. Definitely go to the visitor center and watch the short video. Even our young kids enjoyed it. It is also worth buying the saucers (sleds) in the gift shop and don't forget to buy the wax there too. You will want to keep the saucer good and waxed to enjoy a fast ride down the dunes. An unwaxed saucer won't go anywhere. There are two options. You can buy new or used saucers to start and you can turn them back in after you use them for a small refund. I think a new one was about $14, and they give you $5 back if you return it. I didn't know there were used ones or I would have pick that option. Anyway, the bottom line is that this is a worth while destination where you can easily burn up several hours. You can pack a cooler with food and beverages (take lots of water) and enjoy the day. Keep in mind my visit was in September... I have know idea what the heat would be like in mid summer. Probably not as nice of a visit I would imagine. If you don't enjoy and appreciate this sight, you simple don't have an appreciation for nature and the great outdoors. Enjoy.

Even in July, there was snow around, adding to the splendor of our nation's deepest lake. It's waters, viewed from the rim of the giant caldera--an island in the middle is actually a stillborn volcano--looks both Alaskan and Caribbean. As part of our cross country drive, it was the next stop (2 days later) after Yellowstone. Crater Lake is also a national park ($10 fee to enter, but we had the Nat'l park pass) that was like dessert compared to its far larger Wyoming neighbor, but it holds up to anything there in terms of its sheer beauty. At one point, jays, chipmunks and ground squirrels approached us as we looked out across the lake, and you couldn't help but look for a lost peanut on the floor of your minivan.
too few petroglyphs to see in the main hikes. cheap though

For some reason, I expected to Mount Rushmore to be enormous. In reality it is only 60 feet tall. Parking is $11, but you can get some descent views and pictures from the road. There are 4-5 different stops on the road as you go around the mountain. I'm glad I went, but once was enough.

We couldn't take the trail that goes straight down--and up again--because I have a leg injury, but we did take the Rim Trail, which was great. Got a nice view of some ruins. Take water--it gets hot!--and take your time. We'd like to go back, in cooler weather next time. There is a fee to get in, but if you have a National Parks pass, they will honor it for your admittance.
The Aerial Tramway Ride in Grand Teton Village was fantastic! The cost was $29.00 per person.
I rate it's beauty along with the Great Wall and Grand Canyon! A must visit.

Advertised as havin hundreds of petroglyphs. The sites are not protected so anyone could carve whatever they wanted on the rocks. No way to tell what's genuine and what isn't plus the trail is hot and dusty. Really difficult to identify any real petroglyphs and watch out for snakes at the same time. At least they don't charge to go there.

If you are thinking of going on to see the other monument Crazyhorse which is about 17 miles further on look at it from the road as they charge $29 to drive closer to it and considering its only partly finished is a rip off.
This was a nice short little stop, but if we didn't have the America the Beautiful pass I don't think I would have paid to go here. It's cool, but not much to see.

Decided to pay the $11 and go inside park. Well worth the money. The view is even more spectacular the closer you get. You can chat to the park rangers and find answers to your questions about the monuments. Went for a walk along the presidents trail and ended upat the base of the monuments. Amazing. The sculptors studio is worth a visit too. Gift shop is great. Don't even bother with the gift shops outside the Park. They sell cheap nasty alternatives. We had a snack in the cafe. The buffalo chili at $5 a bowl was very tasty. Free refills with the organic coffee was a bonus on a cold windy day.

We were on the south rim side. Worth our $15.00/carload I felt like. A beautiful and somewhat eerie place at same time. You can see why the old time travelers and Native Americans didn't hang around long-it is so deep they thought they might never get out of it, I suppose. Lots of places to stop and look over the canyon...we were here Sept 2011 and temps were little bit warm until you got the cool breezes. Ranger station was nice and the rangers were very friendly and informative. When you leave and are coming back down the hill there were spectacular views of the area. We enjoyed it!
Lovely place to visit and only had to pay to park. Well worth a visit. Could have spent a lot longer there.

Florissant gives you free entry if you have the national parks pass. There is a small visitor center, a tent with fossils plus a guide to explain them, some short hikes you can take (we did two of them), but the most exciting thing to see are the remnants of petrified stumps from redwoods that are gigantic and millions of years old. As we understood things, there were quite a few redwoods that were enormous but a volcanic eruption covered the bottom feet of the trees and eventually left them in a petrified state while the taller parts of the trees disappeared. The stumps are unbelievably huge. There were many more of these petrified stumps a century ago but visitors chipped them to pieces in attempts to take samples home. Those that are left are protected. Next to the site is an old farm that has been left as a museum piece but the house and barns were not open so you had to look in through the windows.

This area is awesome! I lived nearby for a summer and have returned at least every other year since. I start in Brevard and just drive. Stop at Raccoon Tree for a picnic and to wade in the river. Davison River Campground is a great place to stay. Looking Glass Falls is the most photographed east of the Mississippi, and for very good reason. I have to stop, wade in the river, wander down stream, swim a bit on a really hot day. Moores Cove Falls is next, about a mile hike but a great walk and really wonderful scenery. Be on the look-out for snakes and give them their space. Sliding Rock is awesome. It has become a fee area, but still worth the stop. Go on up to Mt. Pisgah - great views. Take the Blue Ridge Parkway and wander down to Graveyard Fields. It's just a wonderful spot for vacation, all around.

park: George Rogers Clark National Historical Park
text: I didn't know what to expect but was astounded by the size and beauty of this monument alongside the Wabash River. After climbing a slew of steps we found the doors locked but realized we hadn't been to the visitor's center. We were ushered into a theatre to watch an extremely informative and interesting video on the life of George Rogers Clark and the battles that took place in that area during the time of the Revolutionary War. After the video, the ranger in charge escorted us to the monument and inside, we were given audio sets to follow the diarama depicted on the walls. Turns out, that monument is the largest outside of Washington, D.C. We were all very impressed.

This is more of an informative review based on "what to do" before you get there. Number one and foremost is Do Your Homework! We took my 91 year old Dad to see the caves because it was his wish to do so. I looked over the website and found two tours offered that were considered "easy." At that point I should have purchased tickets (but did not) and I should have printed out the Fall Schedule (but did not). I suggest you do both! Also, before you go, I would check a milage guide (on the web, which I did) and calculate the approximate time it will take you to drive from your starting point to the caves. From there, add on at least 30-45 minutes (which I didn't) for parking, discussing tour options with a ranger, buying a ticket (if you do not have one), and a bathroom call. FYI: The caves sit back from the main highway about 7 miles. We traveled from Nashville and by the time (10:30-ish) we arrived the EASY Tour (only one offered) was at 9:45 AM and again at 4:30 PM. We were too late for the one and far, far too early for the other. Many of the other tour times were filled and were not really do-able for us with all of the stair climbing, etc. One male ranger felt sorry for us, I guess, and said that they MIGHT add on another tour at 12:45, but it was not announced so far and he could not guarentee that. Needless to say, we did not tour the caves and the opportunity to do so now is slim. So, I am giving the Mammouth Caves a 5 and for myself (a seasoned traveler who should have known better) a 1. Since school had started, I thought visitors would be at a minimum. That is not the case. Far too many people out there do not have school-age children or otherwise. A site does not become a National Park for nothing. So do your homework and plan well enough in advance, covering all angles and you should have a wonderful experience.

I read the reviews, still had a bit of a time finding the Park Office! The building where the National Historic Park office is not well marked at all. It shares space with an office building/ parking garage with a restaurant and shopping. Do not forget to get your parking ticket validated at the National Park desk when you buy your admission ticket! We were with the first group of 10 for the first tour of the day at 9:15. Some other members of this group told me that availability of the tours is limited and tour groups take availability first. The others in our group had called the day before to check for an open tour time. I just showed up at 8:30 and sat on the Park Service doorstep and got lucky. My daughter (age 11) and I enjoyed the tour very much. Staff very knowledgeable. Plan on two hours. If you want to stay and walk around the grounds at Peace Field, you can, but must wait about 30 minutes for the next trolley. Adult ticket was $3.50, my daughter was free. Exceptional value for the three houses plus library.

My husband and I decided to celebrate our wedding anniversary in West Virginia this year. One of the highlights this trip was to tour the park. We didn't do any pre-planning so everything about the park was a surprise. The park fee gave an option of returning the next day for free which we did take advantage of. The first day we walked a few trails,, visited the historic Murphy Farm and visited the Visitor's Center. We took quite a few beautiful pictures. We also got to go thru a bus that had several sections of artifacts that was very educational. The second day we took a park shuttle bus that had several stops. We spent most of our time in Lower Town and got to see the John Brown Wax Museum, the Black Voices exhibit and did some shopping at the Vintage Lady boutique. We were lucky to speak with a reenactor who was very happy to answer our questions.

We went in October and it was wonderful. No lines and smaller tour groups. We did the historic tour and enjoyed it. We also camped. With the National Park Senior Pass, it's only $8.50 for the night. No electricity or water, but quiet and relaxing. Hiked one of the trails and saw deer quiet close up. Excellent signs on the hiking trails so it is difficult to get lost.

I grew up in Utah and thought I knew all the parks -- state and national -- but this one was a map discovery. what a cool place! the gift shop has an excellent display and a fabulous selection of books -- a good place to buy the "old fart pass" to the parks for $10. The hike down to Owachomo arch was worth the effort -- word of warning -- you MUST have a wide angle or fisheye lens to do justice to the arch!

We travelled here on an impulsive weekend getaway during the off-peak tourist season. We didn't know if it would be very scenic being an autumn visitation and after the trees had lost their leaves. We were pleasantly surprised. This National Park is beautiful! The diverse colors in the badlands landscape, the juniper and cedar greens, the herd of buffalo that walked within feet of our car, the feral horses, pronghorn, and mule deer made it a superb place to visit. We drove the loop and walked three short trails all in 3.5-4 hours. I would love to come here again and hike one of the longer trails! It is not quite as moon-like as Badlands NP in South Dakota, but this park's version of badlands may have been taller and more diverse in coloration. A great place to visit! Also for a cheap, conveniently located stay, consider contacting Badlands Ministries, a local bible-camp with cabins for rent.

My boyfriend and I took the subway from Boston, walked about a block to the building where the NPS center is located. We paid $5 each for a 2 hour tour (including shuttle ride to/from the home sites). The tour guides were excellent, we really enjoyed the tours of the homes and library. One of the best deals on our trip!
Senior Pass, really not applicable here. $11 to park. The newer granite columns and entrance really was well thought out.

The Adams homestead and library are beautiful places to visit. The library next to the main house is unbelievable and very beautiful. The main house is decorated just the way it was originally. The tour is great and not to be missed. The Park Rangers do and excellent job of giving tours of the house and library. Since it is a National Park, seniors get free admission with the Park Pass.

park: Brown v. Board of Education National Historic Site
text: I found myself with my 12 year old son in Topeka for half a day. In search for something to do with him, I stumbled across Brown vs. Board on this site. All I can say is that the place lived up to the ratings and great comments given to it by the previous people who wrote reviews on it. This was a very educational trip and a must see for all. We are Black and I was very glad for my son to see and understand some of the challenges that faced his gradnparents in the not so distant pass. It helps us to be thankful for those who struggled before us and appreciate the opportunities awarded to us today.

I didn't expect this area to be as interesting as it was! Get your ticket to visit Constitution Hall first - it's free, but you need a ticket for an assigned time. Then use the tourist map to select the sites that interest you. Just make sure that you show up at least 15 minutes before your entry time at Constitution Hall. Our tour had a great docent, and the groups are small enough that you can see everything. Food and liquids are not allowed here, or in the Liberty Bell building, so plan ahead.

Be sure to get tickets first thing when you get to the plaza to tour independence hall. They are free but you have to have a ticket with a tour time to enter. The guides are interesting and informative and there is nothing like it to see in the midwest. The liberty bell line is long but moves quickly and is definitely worth seeing and listening to the short talk.
We as a couple really liked this half day trip due to the free cost and the views with a boat ride.

It's hard to believe such hardships took place here in what now appears to be a lovely park-like setting with picnickers playing Frisbee, joggers running past cannons, and children laughing among the somber monuments. The visitor center has a fascinating museum with artifacts and descriptions of what happened here so many years ago. There is a computer system that allows a guest to enter names of ancestors to find out if any old family members had been posted here. A very complete book store offers many items hard to pass up and the most amazing discovery is that it's all free! An 18 minute video provides background information that helps when later walking around the site. I was surprised how high up we were there and can understand a British reluctance to attack. I thought several hours would be enough to cover the grounds but was underestimating how spread out everything is. One could easily spend a day here and take advantage of the Trolley tour (fee) as well as biking and hiking.

We had a real nice time touring the Fort and many interesting facts. We got to watch the cannons go off on Friday. Boy what a bang it put out, a definate must see. The fee to get in is not to much and helps in the preservation of the fort.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: This park is like a preserved village from the Civil War. A very nice visitors center gives a good start to your visit there. A guide gives a brief introduction and then directs you to the Clover Hill Tavern where a Union Soldier "happens" to be available to talk about his assignment there! This fellow did an excellent job of living out the timeperiod, and was able to get interaction from the visitors present! This in itself was worth the time to visit. After this, we were on our own to explore the other buildings in this little community. The McLean House, were Generals Grant and Lee met to sign the documents, was well maintained in furnishings of the time. We were met on the porch by a friendly staff who was more than happy to take our photo there with our own camera (no charge). All staff were pleasant and helpful, making this a very fun and interesting place to visit-highly recommend!

The park is a beautiful place, especially when the autumn leaves are colorful. Lots of hiking and neat things to do. The best thing we found was a ranger-guided tour of the Hensley Settlement, located on a mountain top and occupied in the late 1800's through the early 1950's by several Hensley families. The tour location takes about an hour to reach by NPS van, and once there, it's about a two-hour walking tour through the Hensley farm lands, their service buildings, and one of their homes. The scenery is beautiful, and our ranger-guide, Sharon, did an exceptional job of keeping us informed about the Hensley family and how they survived in this remote location. It gives one great appreciation of the hardships some of the early pioneers endured just to survive. The tour costs $10 ($5 with a Golden Eagle pass), but it was well worth the time and effort. Check the web site for Cumberland Gap National Historic Park and make a reservation for this tour, as it fills up quickly and is very limited.
I though that going to Mt. Rushmore would be a so-so event. It was very inspiring. We also saw mountain goats along the path. The $11 parking is good for the entire calendar year.
Loved it, very interesting history. The cannons were cool and well worth the cost of a ticket.

Great for young and old alike! Well worth the $12 admission. Bring your AAA card for $1 off admission. Park on the street behind the museum for 50c per hour. Walk around the area to see the historic downtown and be sure to step inside the historic railroad depot which has been restored. Beautiful!

We planned a cheap get away and headed to South Dakota. I was actually very, very surprised! We drove from NE Oklahoma north and then crossed the stated headed west. There wasnt much to see until you got to the west side.

While in Philadelphia for a conference, I received the tip to go to Valley Forge from a television promotion of local attractions. I took the SEPTA Rt. 125 bus from 13th and Market St. to the visitor center of the park and the entire trip took only 1 hour with stops and cost $3.50 one way. Once at the park, I was amazed. There are many miles of trails, many, many interesting historical tidbits, and loads of wildlife. I was at the park on an unusually warm Autumn day. The leaves were blazing with color and there was a good number of birds, squirrels and even a small snake out and about. I cannot recommend visiting this park enough and I would say that one should plan on spending at least 4 hours there just to check out the visitor center, watch the short film on Washington's army, and drive around the park.
The CD audio guide, which you can purchase for about $15, is well worth it. It is available at the visitors' center where you purchase tickets and pick up a map.

Had a great and enjoyable visit to Harpers Ferry National Historical Park this past weekend. I was very confused by the previous post stating that it is "very expensive" to park at Harpers Ferry. The cost is only $6 per vehicle to park at the park entrance area and take a quick shuttle ride to the Lower Town. The entrance fee is good for three days and is a bargain for an entire family! This past weekend was a fee free weekend in honor of Veteran's Day so there was no charge at all!
History rocks and you should pay more attention to how it repeats itself.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: took us 3 hours to slowly walk around the compound. the costs is up in the air though- the couple in front of us paid 5, my hubby and I paid 6, the family of 3 behind us paid 25. dont know how they came up with that. My suggestion is take a pic of the price board before parking. there are only 3 places to go thru-the courthouse where you pay, mccleans house, the county jail. rest you walk around viewing them.when turning into this place, there are 2 places to stop along the road on the right. both have monuments to walk to along with placques to read.The second one is about the raine monument which you could take in after visiting the copound. its across from the confederate cementary. when leaving the compund, there is the confederate cementary where the last soldier that dies is located on the right. there are also placques to read. you may want to go accross the street to view the raine monument.

because it's free. The best deal in town, a boat ride, 20 minute tour of the fort, nature walk, beach, picnic area. This place is great. During the winter they have torchlight tours with reenactors dressed doing a 1st person interpretation (small cost, very limited space, tickets go fast!!) and nighttime cannon firings!

John Adams and his son John Quincy Adams were importan t figures in American history as a founder of the nation and as chief execkutives. It is the best deal in all of Boston at a minimum cost you get to tour the homes of these two important figures. Go to the nearby church where the two presidents and the wives rest in flag draped crypts side by side. It is in Quincy and if you are staying in town take the T to Quincy Center.

Been to Harpers Ferry on different occasions but this is first time in 10 years. First the parking, cannot remember where I parked in the past but this time I did not want to take the Shuttle from the external parking sites, so parked at the Amtrak train station which turns out to be the same price $6 as the external sites that require a shuttle. The Amtrak station is at the base of Harpers Ferry so no extra walking needed. My favorite spots are Jefferson Rock and then the walk over the Railroad bridge into Maryland Heights. If you enjoy hiking, hiking on the Maryland side is interesting.

This 3,500 acre park provides both the history buff and someone who simply enjoys walking plenty to see and do. Your first stop should be the Visitor's Center where you can obtain a map of the park. If you wish to hike the various trails, then you need to request a copy of their trail map. Although these trail maps are kept behind the counter due to the higher printing cost, the employees are more than happy to give you a map and share their enthusiasm for the park. The miles of trails within the park nice to walk, especially if you have already done the more touristy attractions.

We took a bus to Kantishna (end of the road) with a tour company - lunch included. At the end of the road, the cabin tour was interesting, but next time I will take the Denali bus (cheaper and really, the same type of bus), bring my own food (the lunch was basic), and go to Wonder Lake only. On our long and interesting ride, we did pass by Wonder Lake, but did not stop there. A bit disappointing. Also, in all the literature we've read about Denali, we never knew that actually seeing the mountain was a long shot. So we were there for 3 days, did not see the actual mountain, but the hikes with the rangers were fun, and hikes on our own were fun too. It did rain a little on one day, but that just brought more snow to the mountain tops.
We got in an hour early with the $50 photographers fee which was very worthwhile. Lots to see at the beginning and end of the day for photography.

We area glad we stopped at this area but it is probably only a place to stop once. The fort was interesting to see, probably more interesting during interactive summer times. The museum area was not one of my favorite NP area but was still interestings. Ranger programs were fun for our daughter. $3 per person to enter.

This experience offers an up close and personal view of pueblos that tribes lived in about 700 years ago. We missed the outside sign to the easy "rim trail" as it was not clearly marked. When we paid our admission we were told that "the trail" was right through the doors. Since we were in the area for a few days and I had been nursing a bad knee, we thought we would just do the easy trail to check out the place, knowing that we could return and do the "island trail" if it didn't look too daunting. So, we headed out the door and began a steep descent into this amazing canyon. There were pueblo homes all around. Unbelievable. When we got down we saw a sign that said island trail on the right. So we took the trail to the left only to find out from a friendly guide that we were halfway around the island trail going backwards! It was o.k. By them and the guide was happy to inform and answer any questions. This trail takes you past and even into these homes. Thankfully my knee held out pretty well, and I have to say that it was worth it! We did do the easy one while we were still there, but missed the ruins again due to lack of signage. They do have it all laid out on a map, which we will pay more attention to next time. I guess we were too excited to check it out.

After our disappointing visit to the Johnstown Flood Museum, we drove several miles to the National Memorial. I told my husband that I'd just sit in the car while he went inside....since we had already wasted $15 at the museum. Turned out that since it was Veteran's Day, admission was free, so we both went inside.

Amazing 8 mile loop road out to the middle of the whiteness - sand drifting across the road reminded me of snow drifts I am familiar with in the Midwest. I wanted to try the sledding, springing the $10 to rent a little saucer. I think it was a little overrated, although we saw lots of people doing it, since we were there on a Saturday. The sand was deep, and even on the steep hills, I just seemed to sink in instead of slide down! And then there was the walk up! It was a lot of work! Unfortunately, our stop was in the heat of the day, and finally it was just too hot to be enjoyable. Amazing place, though, never seen anything like it! Hope to go back when we come this way again, maybe in the cooler evenings!

Hawaii Volcanoes National Park is a great place to visit! It is the best time to visit however is when the volcanoe actually has lava flowing where you can see it. Currently the lava is flowing in a remote place in the park requiring a 20 mile hike in an "unsafe" area. We chose not to chance it. This is one of the best places in the world to see an active volcanoe. In addtion to the lava flowing, there are hiking trails, old lava tubes, and a road from the top of the mountain to the ocean through various old lava flows, some still smoldering. In all it is a good National Park to visit with very friendly staff. One last word of caution, take warm clothes. We forgot our sweatshirts and had to buy them in the park...which were not cheap...and we were not alone as MANY guests found themselves buying sweatshirts and windbreakers, as it was also raining the days we visited.
A bargain entry fee and dogs on leashes are allowed in this beautiful national monument. Our pup slept like an angel for the six-hour ride home after playing on the dunes here.

It is something you will not see anywhere else. The beauty and serenity of this place is beyond words. One must see it. There is a $25/car fee to enter the park. There are many hikes and many observation points. Most of the observation points are accessible to anyone.

We visited to fort as a part of our Trolley day pass (get the pass, its worth it!) The site is simple and informative and a definite place of interest for any history lover. No gimmicks or fluff. I am glad we stopped. The views were beautiful!

How incredibly disappointing to be held to ransom to see a National Monument. They have built an incredibly ugly edifice right in front of this monument which obstructs your view of the faces. To be able to see them without all the concrete in front you are forced to pay for an Annual membership to the carpark. It isn't a huge amount at $11 (at Dec 2011) however we didn't want to stay for hours - just for a few minutes to take photos. We were refused permssion to do that unless we paid.

Though you pay $10 per vehicle to enter that fee is good for 7 days so hang on to that receipt. We went back two more times. We arrived in the afternoon and went through the visitors center and then down to the Jaegger Museum which overlooks the caldera but going back that evening was the really spectacular night glow. WoW! Then we went back the next morning to go the other way down the Road of Craters and that was great because at that time of day there are very few people around, it takes all morning for the tours to come over from Kailua so we basically had the place to ourselves all the way to the ocean. Staying the night in Volcano was really worth it.

I took the train from Boston for the first morning tour. I had it all to myself - a private tour! It's now closed for winter. But go in the Spring! You first go to the Visitor's Center across from the train stop in Quincy and buy your $5 ticket (great value!) From there you take a trolley to the boyhood homes of John Adams and John Q. Adams. They stand next to one another, preserved for posterity in a busy residential area. They have been restored to appear as they did during Adams' occupancy. Some furnishings are original as the homes remained in the family until donated to the Park Service. You tour each home, which takes less than 30 min. total. You then get back on the trolley to drive 10 min. to tour the home John Adams bought later in life and lived in until he died. This home is exquisite and contains numerous family furnishings. You get a real sense of how they lived. I highly recommend that you read David McCullough's Pulitzer Prize winning book "John Adams" before you visit, as it will offer great insight into one of our greatest Founding Fathers and most under-appreciated Presidents. John Adams arguably did as much or more to secure America's freedom as any man, including Washington. Unlike Washington and Jefferson, Adams was not born rich, but he was determined to gain independence. A great American! John Quincy's youth in Paris with his father during the Revolution inspired him to become President, too. The first father-son Presidents. Go see where it all started.
I would definitely recommend this tour. It is free, just pay for parking. it doesn't take much time and good information.

We did both sides (Kipahulu and the Crater) and would highly recommend spending as much time as possible at this incredible park. The topography changes vastly depending on where you are in the park. The Kipahulu area is on the ocean and is lush and tropical. The other side of the park climbs to 10,000 feet above sea level and you can see the changes in plant life as you acend the mountain. It's approx 20 degrees cooler at the top - it was cold and foggy the day we went and too windy to hike. Our only disappointment was not being able to have a better view of the crater. The park pass if $10/car and is good for 3 consecutive days (not really feasible to do both sides of the park on the same day).

We stopped here on our way from front royal thinking it will be a quick stop, Wrong! Lots of history and historical monument. The wax museum was closed, but all that was open was way too interesting. Before we knew it 2.5hrs had passed! The John Brown place was great with the dramatical narrative of his failed 1859 raid that triggered the civil war. The storer college was awesome and so full of history. In short this place makes you take a flight in time back to the 1800s. The slave clothing, the shoes, the muskets, the buildings.....if you can, take your car and park it at the train station (with a ticket) also make sure you stop at Bolivar Heights. This is a place to dedicate a full day! Am coming back in the spring!

You can do this in a short amount of time or spend the day going to different sites, but it was something I had not seen before and was nice. It was a little more climbing than I expected, so if you have trouble climbing (sometimes on rocks) ask at the visitor center for the best place to find the Petroglyphs (there are several locations to view them). Small parking fee at one location only - others were free.

You need a full 1.5-2 days (not including drive time) to really explore the park. It is only $10 for a weeks admission. The junior ranger program is great, as are all the ranger-led programs. It can be mighty rainy and cold, so bring long pants and shirts and a rain jacket. Sturdy shoes are also a must. A first aid kit is a good idea too especially if you have kids. The lava rocks are sharp. Be sure to check out the view from Jaggar museum in both the daytime and nighttime. The glow after dark is super cool. We loved the steam vents, the petroglyph trail, and the Kilauea Iku trail. The Kilauea Iku trail is my favorite hike. It takes 2 hours, but is totally worth it. You hike down to the floor of the Caldera. Our 7 and 9 year old children had no problem with the hike. Bring plenty of water and snacks.

Fort Matanzas is located 14 miles south of St. Augustine, FL on highway A1A. There is no charge to take a passenger ferry over to Rattlesnake Island where the Fort is located and to tour it. There is a ranger at the fort who tells a fasinating story of what it was like to be a soldier stationed there and the history of the building and battles that took place. The fort is furnished as it would have been back then.
Short line and no cost made the visit to the Liberty Bell worthwhile.

The Andrew Johnson NHS is really very interesting, but somehow you get the feeling that the staff is just kind of walking through the motions of their presentations. Also, when money to run the place is so tight, you'd think the gift shop would carry a better selection of products. If I want to buy books I can get the same titles on Amazon for a fraction of what thy charge here.

Volcanoes National Park is a large park with a lot to see. The trick is to make certain that the sun is shining, or don't go at all. Our first day was typical of the area -- rain, rain, rain, nonstop rain. The locals told me it had been raining nonstop for 5 weeks. We finally got a break from the rain, though, on the second morning, but only for a few hours. If it's raining, go somewhere else. You can't see anything and it is very miserable since at 4000' it's cold, windy, and dreary in the rain (yes, even in Hawaii it can be cold). If the sun does shine, then you can see the caldera, take a few drives to the volcano tubes, or see the main steam vents near the observatory. I heard from others that they had enjoyed their helicopter flyover on a sunny day, and this was something I had wanted to do if we had had the time. The entrance fee is $12.00 per car, but for some reason there's always a wait to get into the park, longer than one might expect. Once you do get up to the gate, the entrance fee is good for about a week, so you keep your receipt. I wasn't all that impressed with the park and felt that the free Black Sand Beach just a little north of the park was a lot more interesting.

Arrived at the Park at 1:00 pm New Years Day to a nearly full parking lot. Set out to do the Oakridge Trail and, despite the parking lot, only saw 5 or 6 people once we left the boardwalk trail. The trails are well-marked and maintained. We saw amazing trees, feral hogs, birds and owls - heard lots of woodpeckers. Completed the trail around 5:30 pm which included time for lunch and one break to just enjoy the sounds of the swamp. Plan to return to hike the River Trail and Kingsnake Trail. Also planning on doing the canoe trail. Wonderful place to visit, no admission fee. HIghly recommend it!

Even though the fort is small, ranger Kevin is packed full of information about it. You can learn more in 30 minutes than you would reading a history book. We went in the slow season (early January) so we were the only ones on the tour! All the staff were very friendly and knowledgeable. Definitely worth a visit. And the price is right--- FREE!

My personal travel bucket list includes visiting every national park so this year we headed for Mount Rushmore in September. We had seen pictures and heard about the Mount Rushmore National Monument so we pretty knew what to expect..or so we thought.While doing my on line research I found out that the Chief Crazy Horse Monument was nearby and the annual fall buffalo round up would be held at Custer State Park while we were in the area. WOO HOO! We expected the buffalo round up to be the high light of our trip. After all, how many people can say they have been to a wild buffalo round up? I made arrangements to take a bus tour from Rapid City to Mount Rushmore, the Chief Crazy Horse Monument and the buffalo round up all on one day via Greyline Bus Tours.I read on line that while there is no entrance fee to MT . Rushmore, there is a steep fee to park, which can be scarce during peak tourst season. I figured since we didn't know our way around, the bus made the most sense for us. Be aware that this is a very long , all day bus trip and worth every dime. Actually, the bus ride between Mount Rushmore and the Crazy Horse Monument is what we remember most and tell our friends about. This twisting turning road , called Needles Highway, was designed to take advantage of every spectacular view on the Presidents carved into the mountain. Some places we felt as if we could almost reach out and touch them.We were very glad someone else was driving so we could spend every minute enjoying the views. Our driver kindly stopped multiple times along the way so we could get out and take lots of pictures....so be sure to bring a camera and extra batteries. I think my favorite part was squeezing through a one lane wide tunnel to see the face of George Washington framed in the light at the end of the tunnel. Breath taking really. There are probably quicker, easier routes to Mt. Rushmore from Rapid City but don't pass up driving the Needles Highway. Actually, I wish we had flown to Rapid City and saved our travel time for exploring Rapid City and that corner of South Dakota, rather than driving .There is so much to do and see in the area that we just didn't have the time for. Maybe that means we will go again.

Toured with Marylou on 12/28/2011. Excellent service. We emailed them ahead of time and got a confirmation number. She greeted us at the dock around 9:30 and we got to see so many places at our own pace - six of us with young children and seniors, and there was never a boring moment. She took us to many places for less than half of what the ship wou charge us and we got to see so much more! Ask her about the huge (for Hawaii) cactus, the garden at the back of the macadamia nut factory, and the rainbow trees. The big sea turtle was one of the highIights towards the end of the day. And we usually beat the croud. We paid at the end of day with a credit card and she took us to the ship at around 3:30. She used her own camera and took many pictures for us. When we got home, the photos were already in my email inbox. Couldn't have asked for more. Highly recommended!

Nowhere in the U.S. (or perhaps the world) one would see water bluer than at Crater Lake. That's because of its altitude and the way its water is kept. In most other lakes, we were told, you usually would see below water surface up to say 100 ft. But, at Crater Lake, you see much, much deeper below surface. The air is also so fresh. Add a sky as backdrop, with some white clouds, hmmmmm. For vacation purposes, there is no place better than some spot in the U.S., esp. the national parks. No place where it's so well-equipped, humanly and naturally, and bargain basement costs (a mere few dollars entrance fee). Come as one, as family, a grand time is guaranteed for all if the outdoors is your cup of tea.

How many of you have driven through an old industrial city, over the ripped up railroad tracks and dirty canals, and wondered what it was like in its heyday? Well a trip up to the Lowell National Park in Lowell, MA, will help answer this question. The National Park offers a combined canal, trolly and mill tour, which is informative, fun and a great value. I worked in Lowell for years before going on this tour and am now sorry I waited so long. The canal tour takes you in a boat, through manual 100+ year old locks to the Great Francis Gate. Park Rangers and historical actors drive home the importance of this canal system to the industrial growth of Lowell. The trolley tour is fun and relaxing and you can even see an actual mill turbine in operation. All this in one tour for less than $10! A fun and informative visit for the family.

After hiking to the Sand Cave and White Rocks in September I went back in October with my two hiking buddies and hiked up to Hensley Settlement. It was a great day for a hike and we chose to go up the Chadwell Gap Trail on the Virginia side of the Cumberland Mountain. There is another way up to the settlement via the Shillalah Trail which is on the Kentucky side of the mountain that is considered the easier of the trails to the top. You can also take the "bus" from the visitor center to the settlement for a fee.

It was fun to walk thru lava tubes and then at night when it got dark you could see the red lava from the McJagger Museum in the park. There was a $10 entrance fee per car. It is definitely cold here- you should bring warm clothes, jackets, gloves and a blanket to keep warm.

We camped up at the Namakani Paio campground (where camping is free for up to 7 days with your park entry fee). It was cool and damp, but also beautiful with good facilities and undercover cooking area (although the showers were closed for renovations when we were there - frustrating!) From this campground it was an easy, 30 minute walk to the lookout at the Jagger museum - where you can see the glow of the lava lake in the Kiluaea crater at night. During the time we spent in the park, there was a surface lava flow reported that was just inside the park boundary at sea level. We checked with the rangers and they explained that it was a arduous, exposed 4.5 mile hike to get from the end of the Chain of Craters road to where you could see lava. We decided to go for it. Since we were cycing around the island, we didn't have a car, so we hitched a ride with a very nice couple from the Visitors Center. The hike was INTENSE we brought tons of water and covered up with long sleeves, pants and hats but what we saw in the end was totally worth it. Molten lava flowing into the sea - we got within 30 feet. It was amazing!! And then, of course, the 4.5 mile hike back! The Visitor's Center is excellent - make sure you stop there and get the important information about how to view the lava safely, it's extremely hazardous - but SO AMAZING!

We loved this adventure! I was skeptical at how the kids would handle it and was the one attraction that I was aprehensive about but it was AMAZING!! You HAVE to call ahead for tickets, that was recommended by people on this site and I did do that and it was definitely needed. When I went up to the window to get my tickets most of the people there were realizing that most of the tours were already sold out:( We took the Historic Lantern Tour and it was a memory for a lifetime for those kids. We had four children with us; 7 y/o girl, 10 y/o boy, and two 12 y/o girls. I was worried about the difficulty for the 7 y/o and wether she would freak out or not but she did great and led the charge through the whole thing, we were amazed!. Once you get into the Cave for the Lantern Tour they will give you the option of an easier tour or a more difficult challenging one. Dont be scared the difficult tour is very easy and manageable. They take it slow and I had no claustrophobic breakdowns. The tour before us voted on the easy path and the adults said it was dissapointing so make sure you push for the "Purgatory Path" Like most have already said, not everyone needs to hold a Lantern, the young kids have battery operated ones but the younger kids can suffice with parents holding it, so they can use they're hands to help pull them around. Our tour guide was very funny and a great experience.

To make the most of your visit, you should visit the NPS website and read the descriptions of the available tours for your visiting day(s). We decided in advance to do the Frozen Niagara Tour. I called in advance to be sure that the tours would be operating on Thanksgiving Day, which they were. Since there were fewer tours that day, we knew we needed to be there when the visitor center opened. Some tours you could reserve in advance, but this tour they do not take reservations. As it turned out, there was plenty of room on our tour, but I did not want to take a chance. The tour was $10, and no park pass was needed to get into the park itself.

Harpers Ferry National Historical Park is uniquely situated at the tip of West Virginia. From Harpers Ferry, you can see and easily hike into Maryland (via the foot bridge) and Virginia (via the pedestrian path on Route 340). The park rangers are friendly and extremely helpful if you are not sure where you are trying to go. We parked at the Harpers Ferry historic train station, where you pay a $6 park entrance fee, which is good for 3 days from the date of purchase. My Dad was visiting and we enjoyed the park and area in general so much that we came back two days later to spend more time walking around the town of Harper's Ferry and Virginius Island. From my understanding, the town largely rolls up shop from Christmas to March, but you can still find places to eat and a few shops doing business. One of the main draws of the park and the town is the rich slice of American history, much of which is well preserved. This area is friendly to hikers, history buffs, families, and even dogs. If you plan to be in the vicinity or live within a 2-3 hour's drive, I highly recommend checking out this park and town.

If you are cruising and arriving at the Port of Hilo, the must see attraction is the wonderful Hawaii Volcanoes National Park. While there are many excursions offered to the National Park, you will be in a large group and on the tour provider’s schedule which we find usually includes too much time shopping at a location they have a relationship with and not enough time at the sights of interest to us. Instead of taking the excursion, it is easy to see the park at your own pace and save a lot of money by renting a car. I simply reserved a rental car from a Hilo airport rental car agency several months ahead of the cruise. When we arrived in Hilo we disembarked and the all the agencies had shuttles right from the cruise ship dock to their location at the nearby Hilo airport. The National Park is about 45 minutes away and easy to find with few turns but for assistance I had brought my GPS from home along. After we were done with our day at the park, we returned to the airport, dropped of the car off and took the shuttle back to the dock. The whole process was surprisingly smooth and simple and the cost of the rental and entrance to the National Park ($10 per car full) for the four of us was about the same as the price for one adult excursion!
I loved the hole thing. The free admission and the free boat ride to the fort. The guide at the fort was very informative. We highly recommend the experience.

Nothing else like it!! We could only spend two half days at the park, and this was a good amount of time to see the best parts of the park. We're not hikers, but you could easily spend more time exploring some of the longer trails. Our first half day we drove down chain of craters road, stopping at many of the craters along the way, walked the petroglyphs trail and continued down to the sea arch. That took us just over 3 hrs. At the top it was cold and rainy, but don't be discouraged because it was warm and sunny driving down the elevation. We came back after nightfall to see the glow of the caldera from the jagger museum, and even though it was raining and foggy it was still a sight to be seen! The next morning we returned early to see the lava tubes before a tour bus got there and hiked devestation trail. We were told to avoid the lava tubes if there was a tour bus parked outside and I would def pass that advice along because it is small in there and could take away from the experience if it's overcrowded.
The home is just the center of a whole street, making it better all the time,... and still free (although you may need to pay for parking).

My 7 yr old daughter really enjoyed this as did my husband and I. This is a National Park, and park rangers give a great tour. A lot to see here! I think we paid $3 to park and that was it. My daughter did a scavenger hunt they had to earn her Junior Park Ranger badge and really like that!

Walk in the footsteps of people who lived at Walnut Canyon more than 700 years ago. Peer into their homes, cliff dwellings built deep within canyon walls. The presence of water in a dry land made the canyon rare and valuable to its early human inhabitants. Good museum before you start on trail. No charge with a National Park Pass -- Golden Age.

I’m an amateur history buff and minored in history at PSU and I am critical on places that claim to be historical attractions. With that said I rate this place a complete homerun! The facility is AMAZING, historically accurate, beautiful, extremely visitor-friendly, extremely family-friendly…you can walk around, bike around…outstanding. My family and I have visited several times. The management knows what they are doing. I wish I lived in PA so I could visit more often.
What a nice Place. All Ranger's & Volunteers are very knowledgeable. The Fort is accessible only by guided boat tours. Hiking trails are available on the barrier island. No Fee

We visited Antietam with a group of Army officers for a staff ride of the battlefield. The National Park Service is exceptionally user-friendly for military groups for planning to conduct a historical study of the battle. We were able to get the cost of park entry deferred by submitting a memorandum to the park superintendent outlining our plan of study for the visit. We also arranged to have our visit led by the Antietam park historian, Mr Keith Snyder, a 20 year veteran of the park and a national guard senior officer. Mr Snyder's breadth of knowledge and experience at the park made for an incredible experience of professional development and helped the battle come alive for us. He covered the terrain and the strategic setting for the battle as well as discussing the decisions and some of the sub-plots of Antietam that occurred that fateful September day. The battlefield is well-preserved, and the park staff has it as their on-going mission to make and keep the park grounds in as close condition as possible to the way things were when the fighting occurred there. This is a great place to visit to better understand our nation's military history, military decision making, and leadership. Having such a knowledgeable guide was a key enhancement, though there is a self guided tour map available with informative signs along the way. Overall a highly recommended way to spend a day of historical study.

If you enjoyed the Castillo de San Marcos in St. Augustine, then you will probably like visiting its smaller brother. Fort Matanzas is located about thirty minutes north of the historic district on A1A. We enjoyed our visit but there is nothing here that can't be missed. We found it kind of surprising that it was free and there is no charge for the five minute pontoon boat ride across the river to the fort.

In this era where people wearing clothes made overseas and complain about having to work hard, a stop here might put things in perspective. The displays and museum offer a glimpse into the past where people worked long,hard hours for little pay. And when they moved on, immigrants who wanted a better life took their place at the mills. A must-stop-and-see place.

My husband and I visited Harpers Ferry National Park this weekend and we loved it. It's $6 to get into the park and a bus shuttles you from the visitors center down to the lower town so you don't have to walk. The park is set up like a little town and you can go into the different buildings and learn about life in Harpers Ferry before, during and after the civil war. There's also a lot of information about John Brown's raid. You can go into some of the homes and even visit the Catholic Church in the town that still holds mass every Sunday. Make sure to go up to Jefferson's Rock where the view from the top of the mountain is absolutely amazing. You can see where the Potamac and Shenandoah Rivers meet. When we were there, the Shenandoah was an emerald green...so beautiful! You should also walk across the footbridge over the Potomac (i think it's part of the C&O Trail) and get more scenic views looking back at Harpers Ferry. Make sure you also walk along the river and check out Virginius Island. You can walk right up the river and there are old ruins on the island.

Well worth a visit at a sensible entry price, this is one of the few forts that the British army failed to take by force so it must be seen by us as an objective for the future when we take back control of the the USA, however we need to regain control of many parts of England first.

I thoroughly enjoyed Ninety Six NHS. Like most other Battlefields, it is more of a park with hiking trails. However, that being said, the Park Service did a great job with signs, silhouettes, and recreated buildings. I believe that one of the buildings is actually original. The visitor center had lots of information and as usual, a great movie that introduced you to the setting. One should watch the movie to understand what happened here. The paved path is only one mile long. There are signs everywhere stating what happened where. It's a wonderful location for a picnic lunch. I would definitely recommend going to Cowpens and Kings Mountain in conjunction with Ninety Six. Those two National Sites are about two hours away. Admission was free.

First of all, go to the visitor's center first. You will receive a free ticket at the desk to have an incredibly knowledgeable and friendly park ranger guide you through the house. That said, the inside of the house is very well-explained, well preserved, and maintains many original artifacts from the LIncoln Family. Be sure to visit the two other exhibits housed in the Lincoln neighbors' houses, and walk the entire street.

It is so interesting to see the dormant volcano. The silver sword plant is wonderful to see; no where else in the world will you see it. Watch on the drive to the top; some motorcycle drivers think they have the right to drive fast and pass whenever and whereverr The rangers at the station are very interesting.

This is a great place to go and learn so much about Abraham Lincoln and his family. We got a personal tour, which with young children worked very nicely. We didnt stay long but was able to ask any questions and learned so much more about life back then. Beautiful! No fee to get in but you do need to pay for parking if you park in their lot. But even that is minimal. Only $2
You feel his presence on the grounds. What an unbelievable time in our history. We can't pay enough respect to the men who changed what our futures are now. Must see. Beautiful grounds.

We have been to Harpers Ferry several times. The shops are really pricy, the food there is ok. You get small portions and the food quality does not match the cost. In the summer time the river is plagued with trash,is over crowded and most of the folks there are drunk. Not family friendly overall in the summer time.

you can just pay for a spot and sit in the shade and picnic and read for the day....or you can camp overnight. We locals just like to go up there to relax on a hot day, especially if the stream is flowing.

Fort Matanzas is operated by the National Park Service as a National Monument. As a result, this site is NOT a tourist trap. Rather, it is a well preserved historical site. The fort may only be accessed by boat. However, all aspects of this attraction are free of cost! This includes the boat ride to and from the fort (which is brief ten minute trip each way), the tour and time exploring the fort. I enjoy photography--and was permitted to take all the photographs I wanted using my tripod! Also, there were some owls nesting in the trees just outside the visitor center. Highly recommend!

I am wishing that I had been on a tour here because there was lots to see and learn. The park has great displays that are loaded with info but I didn't feel like we had to enough time to take it all in. The crater was impressive at the Jagger center. We were told to go inside because of the toxic gases that were drifting our way. One could not drive completely around the crater because of the gases. We enjoyed the steam vents and I especially like the Thurston Lava tube. It was in the midst of a lush rainforest. It was so cool to walk through the tube. If you are going to the park, come prepared with water, good shoes and time to really explore. Since it is a National Park, we used our senior pass and it was free for our car!

I go every year for a day trip with my family. Nice, quiet, and relaxing. Also has a paved walkway and old houses and churches. There used to be an older man that made toys at one of the houses, but I haven't seen him in a couple of years. Also a building with a gift shop, canteen, and history about Pisgah before you get on the trail. There's a small admission fee to walk the trails, but it's worth it.

My family and I were split on this one. 2 of us really liked it and 2 of us thought it was okay. The two of us who liked it are history buffs and love to learn about each area we visit. I recommend listening to the curator, otherwise what you are looking at is just stone and has no meaning to you. They give you so much infomation and make the place come to life in your imagination. (it is free not extra charge to participate in the tour it is included in your addmission cost). I can't remember the exact cost of the admission but i do remember it was resonable. You can fully do the fort in about an hour and half. I recommend.

Cumberland Gap NHP was a very fun day trip. It was very accessible by interstate and highways. The park has had some major renovations within the past decade and it was very clean and well-kept. Definitely take the drive (or hike) to the Pinnacle Overlook at the top of the mountain. Here, you can see beautiful panoramas of the Tri-State area and see a ruins of a fort used during the Civil War. The highlight of the trip was taking the tour of Gap Cave. Make sure you arrive early enough to put your name on the list. Someone canceled last minute, so we were very lucky to get to go on it. We had to pay a small fee but it was definitely worth it. This cave required hardhats and lanterns to navigate. Also, be prepared for a lot of stooping and crawling around. The tour guides were phenomenal and very knowledgeable of the history of the cave and gap. You'll want to bring good shoes, a camera and remember, the cave stays around 60 degrees year round, so perhaps a light jacket. Overall a great and very fun trip!
Though it costed $25, it was worth it! The trails here are just fantastic! I stayed at Kodachrome State Park (which is great as well), and drove to Bryce three times.

Very nice park with many things to do! Take the time to visit all of the attractions within the park. The sea arch was really neat and the closest one we were able to get pictures of during our stay. Stay after sunset and see the glow of the lava by the Jaggar Museum. It is amazing! Well worth the $10 to visit the park, walk the trails, and see the sites.

After the White sands missle Range. There is the White sands national monument. Run by the US National Park Services. There is a really nice gift shop at the entrance and a great book store. After visiting the main building you get to drive into the park. It is $3 per adult and kids under the age of 16 are free. Bring water and suncreen. The park consist of a drive through monumental Sand dunes. They dont seem to finish. The beauty is that the sand is powder like (gypsum) and is white. It is one of the most beautiful sights I've ever seen. There are hiking trails and the kids bought a Sled at the Gift shop and spent the afternoon sliding on the white sand dunes. I highly recommend it.

Illinois' only national park, the Lincoln Home National Historic Site, is a must see for any fan of American history! With free admission to the house tour and approximately a 4-block area around the house that has been recreated to the period, a visitor can become uniquely familiar with Abraham Lincoln at a great value. My wife and I take visiting family members on a regular basis, and re-enjoy the multiple visits ourselves.

I know some people will say that you can see Mount Rushmore without paying for the parking or whatever, but there's nothing like walking the trail right under the faces. it's really an impressive place, and once you get through the crowds in the main entry area, really pleasant. The trail is not too strenuous, but there are a lot of stairs. Note that entry is free, but you have to pay for parking, which is managed by a private company.

We happened to visit Hawaii Volcanoes National Park on the 100th anniversary of the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory. This was fortunate as the $10 entry fee was being waved - and the observatory was open to the public. HVO scientists were out in force explaining anything and everything about the park and volcanoes.
It was interesting and you can't beat the price....free, but good luck finding a parking spot,I sugest getting there early.

Best value tour in St. Augustine. For some reason they do not charge to take you across the St. John's River by boat to the old fort on Rattlesnake Island. The fort is interesting in it own right and then the bird watching is fabulous.
We took the tour of the battlegrounds. That led us to Battle of the Cornfield, The Bloody Lane, and the Burnside Bridge. The tour guides make history come alive. Well worth the small fee.

This is for history bufffs who want to see the actual Adams houses and learn the history behind them and the famous Adamses from Quincy. It's a trek from Boston, but if you've got a car, you can see Wollaston Beach and eat at fancy Marina Bay, also in Quincy. Marina Bay has a range of restaurants from $$ to $$$$ and I think all of them have a waterfront view. There's a boardwalk and ice cream and a sense of being off the beaten path. If you don't have a car, Quincy is definitely on the T and Quincy Center has some nice eateries if you're on foot.

The bell is the real attraction here not the large modern non Interactive museum built around it. The bell is in the back and was surprisingly not behind glass. You can get good pictures. There are also rangers around to answer questions. There is no fee.

Whenever I visit these civil war battlefields, I question the reason for these wars and why humanity never learns its lessons. The cost to visit is reasonable at $6 per carload. There is a nice gift shop with some cool items. We watched the film in the visitor center which basically reviews the mechanics of the battle and you are given a map. The stops on the map take you step by step in order of the events as they took place. It is very hard to envision what it may have looked like as a battlefield from the serene cornfields now present. There is a observation tower. You will not find all the monuments and glamour present at Gettysburg, but instead a somber mood prevails. But I can't help but think..why? And I ponder of all the contributions that these individuals could have made for the benefit of society had their lives been not cut short and people had resolved their issues peacefully.

We were here two weeks ago. If you go in the off season, you may be able to find parking, but in the busy season, you can take a shuttle from the visitor's center which runs every 15 minutes. There is a place in the town where you can watch a movie of the history of the town. There is a church which was closed when we were there. You can hike to Jefferson Rock which gives a lookout of the valley below. There are also various shops and some restaurants. Very quaint. From what I recall, the fee was about $6 per family.

The Cave are fun for the whole family, and there are different one to choice from, there is different price so check out the web site to find how much it will cost you. Good place to visit for a day trip with family.
