We arrived around 3pm from Devils Tower (WY) via 85/385/16/16A from Spearfish and wish we'd spent more time stopping along the way but it's a good way to get there rather than just going straight from RAP. Amazing to see in person and well worth whatever the NPS entry fee was--$10/car I think which holds over all day [including return for night]. Definitely walk around the wooden walkway and most people should be able to do the loop--maybe a mile [guess] when it's all said and done and mostly level so not really physically demanding; some stairs here and there so I think handicapped folks would be somewhat limited in making the entire loop. Get some good vantage points from nooks and crannies of the fellas on the hill and the trail leads you over to the small museum where there is a video of the construction and a mock up of some equipment. All told two adults can swing the whole thing in 90 minutes including taking pictures but do that stuff during the day. Come back later at night using same parking pass, grab some ice cream and bring it out for a good seat for the evening lighting ceremony. There was an excellent movie that last 20-30 minutes around dusk followed by some narrative from a ranger [and a song actually], and at least on our night the ranger asked veterans to stand and be recognized then come down to the platform for retiring the Colors. So you'll spend maybe 3 hours all day split between two visits but not bad for parking fee..excellent value actually.

This is locaed in the wettest part of the USA and they charge you 10 bucks to drive in with not much guarantee of seeing anything. Buy a DVD of the lava on a good day filmed from a helicopter is my recommendation

This is a great stop if you are driving south in the spring through Kentucky whatever the weather. The cave is always 55 degrees. The Historic Tour is at 11, 1, or 3. This cave is unique for its size and the tour is a two mile walk. Most fun are the winding narrow passages of Fat Man 's Misery, followed by the low ceiling of Tall Man's Misery. I never knew they sourced saltpeter to spark gunpowder for the war of 1812 from this cave. This is a National Park so anyone over 62 can buy a pass for all members of their party.

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: While in Fredericksburg, my husband and I took a trip to the LBJ Ranch, which is now part of the National Park System. The ranch is behind the Lyndon Johnson State Park visitor center. There is an introductory movie, that is very informative, plus there is a bookstore there. When you check in with the Ranger there they give you a day pass and a CD to take an auto tour that leads to the ranch. No charge. You can stop and go as you please.......LBJ's grandparen'ts home, his childhood home, the family cemetary where he and Lady Bird are buried, plus the livestock barn and then the airplane hangar which is right by the Summer Whitehouse of LBJ. The hangar now houses a visitor center and gift shop area. There you can purchase your tour tickets for the retirement home (formerly the Summer Whitehouse) of Lyndon B. Johnson for $2. A Park Ranger gives a guided tour. It was wonderful. The furnishings are like you stepped back into the 1960's. We were there the later part of January and the weather was wonderful. The Ranch was beautiful. We loved our time there. After we left we traveled on to Johnson City. That is were the Lyndon Johnson Visitor Center is. There was lots of exhibits showing the timeline of his life. Very interesting. I recommend it to anyone that travels into that area.

how can you rate it less than 5 stars? Just so you are not surprised, it is not so much a park in the traditional sense, but a collection of significant historical sites in one downtown area. Independence Hall, The Liberty Bell, Carpenter's Hall, and more. Should not be missed.

I've been to Mt Rushmore twice now, separated by forty years. Certainly the access has been improved, and the site can handle even large numbers reasonably well; I found myself able to get away from the heaviest crowds and walk along quieter but still well-kept trails. The new permanent exhibit, showing how the monument had been constructed, was also fascinating. That said, as a foreigner (long resident in the US) I couldn't really see what all the fuss was about. Mt Rushmore probably means most to an American schoolchild who's been learning about the presidents in class, and who enjoys tracking down his or her state flag - the flagpoles are arranged in order of admission to the union, if I recall - to stand proudly beside it for a photograph. For the rest of the world, though, it's tempting to see these giant faces as another example of the American taste for everything large, from bacon double cheeseburgers to SUVs. Like McDonalds, Mt Rushmore is well managed and full of families having a good time, so a visit is pleasant enough. But, though other places commemorating American history - the civil war sites, the Vietnam memorial - can move my foreign soul, that's not the case with this one.

We booked this one-day trip through Viator and run by Polynesian Adventures. This was going to be one of the highlights of our Haiwaii vacation and cost me almost $1000.00for a day trip. This cost was a very large part of our budget and was greatly anticipated as a once in a lifetime treat. In retrospect, I shpuld have known better. The advertising site showed photos of smoke and red lava-flow and also indicated that a spectacular night-tour was available. I took this to imply that we had a chance of seeing some lave. Wrong! we were collected by coach from our hotel and then waited for two and a half hours at the airport before flying to the Big Island to be told immediately by our driver on the ground that we would not be seeing any lava-flow that day or any other. A bit late to cancel then. What followed was a coach trip around the Big Island visiting some sights but mainly spent long stops at souvineer-type attractions and the worst lunch I have ever struggled to force down. We did see the crater and some steam at one point but this stop was around 10% of the total time. At the end of our tour, the driver said we were very early for our flight back and did we want to roam around the shopping mall? Er, no! A complete waste of time and money. On return I complained to Viator who managed to obtain a partial refund ( everything but flight costs). This went some way to compensate us financially but nowhere near compensating all 3 of us for severe disappointment with our once-in-a-lifetime trip.

You can't help but be in awe of these beautiful mountains. We spent 2 days enjoying the park and were delighted to see to a black bear and her cub, a mama moose and her baby, pronghorns and a bull moose. The mountains even treated us to an amazing thunderstorm. Nothing like a clap of thunder in the mountains. Take your time to visit the little chapel and make sure to visit the visitor center. We stayed on the Idaho side of the Tetons and driving the Teton Pass was amazing. Take your time to enjoy these stunning mountains.

I really didn't think I would enjoy Mt. Rushmore as much as I did. It doesn't cost to go in the park, but it does cost to park your car there. Did not see the lighting ceremony, but would like to this summer.

If you want to see the power of the earth at work, this is the place. Although we didn't see any lava flows, we didn't expect the earth to perform on cue for just us. Seeing the miles and miles of craters and solidified lava areas is enough for one to grasp the devastation. The views are spectacular and the drive itself is awesome. Be sure to stop at the visitor center to the latest updates on what to see. The park roads are well maintained as areall of the stops along the way. $10 to get in is a pitifully small donation for all they do here. The steam vents area is surreal and worth the hike.

From a long gone time. Makes you realize how good we have it today with our modern convenieces, such as electricity and refrigeration. Dont recall the cost but it was well worth it, fantastic views and very informative.

Just perfect. This is one the most beautiful places in the U.S. Its very accessible, there is a small fee to enter and a very nice gift shop. You can actually rent or buy sliders for younger kids to go down the sand dunes. Bring your own water and maybe a snack for the kids because once you are in the white sands area there is nothing else around.

This is part of the National Parks and admission is free for Seniors with a National Park Pass ($10 one-time for life), otherwise a nominal fee. There are 240 steps down plus inclined walkways to the area of the dwellings. This is not for the physically impaired or for people of low endurance, the climb back up is somewhat taxing, but there are numerous rest stops with benches along the way. Be sure to take water with you and plan for 1-2 hours for the trip. Go at your own pace and take your time, no rush. The sights and history are amazing...just to see the living quarters of the natives who lived in the canyon 700 years ago is something to behold. Trying to imagine life during those times, it must have been extremely difficult; no wonder the life-span was so short. This is a very interesting park and we would definitely visit again when in the area.

Parking cost was ridiculous by the way, and you can't really see it much from the road so you have to go, and its a dead end into the parking lot so no choice on parking, but the gift shop was terriffic, and the little flags mall lets you walk up to the base and get perspective of what it must have taken to do this monument.

This was a fantastic place to visit. The hike wasn't too strenuous and we went on a quiet day with one other couple. The guide was very informative at the cliff dwellings and was happy to answer any questions. The view was breathtaking and you can just imagine living in a beautiful place. Kids loved the Junior Ranger Program and learned a lot too. Definately worth a visit but make sure you don't go too late because it's a long windy drive. Saw snow on side of road and lots of mule deer, another highlight. Had a National Parks annual pass so was free entrance.

The house is run by the NPS so it is free (although you do have to pay to park in the lot outside the house). You are brought on a guided tour which is very well done. There are several other houses restored in the neighborhood.

We stopped here based solely on the fabulous reviews from TripAdvisor and we couldn't have been more pleased. Admission is only $5 and grants you up-close access to Indian cliff dwellings that are hundreds of years old. The hike up and down the canyon can be a bit taxing on most people but there are plenty of places to rest and take in the excellent views along the way.

If you want to get in the white sands part of the park (not the gift shop part) you will need cash. I wanted to buy a National Parks Pass ($80) but could only do so wh a check or cash. So I just paid the $3 fee in cash to enter the sands.

I've been going to White Sands since I was a child and now that my children are old enough to go we can't get enough. Driving from Las Cruces or Alamogordo can trick you into thinking the effort is not worth it. Get past the towns and rising out of the middle of a desert are pure white sand hills! And park admission is only $6 per adult! Really, this is the deal of the century that the whole family will enjoy. Buy a sled at the front (you can return it after and get some money back but we just kept ours), take some water and snacks/food and go crazy on the hills. Oh yeah, take sunscreen. No matter the weather you will always get a tan (or a burn) with the sun bouncing off those beautiful dunes. Then sit back and enjoy the smiles on your faces as you try to conquer the dunes! You will not regret it.

The sand dunes are beautiful. The park is huge. Even though it was busy it did not feel that way. You can get sleds at the gift shop to sled on the sand dunes. Be sure to go into the kid's room in the gift shop to check for used sleds. New sleds are $14.50 and you get $5 back if you return them with your receipt. Used sleds are $10 and you get $3 back when you return them. Steep sand dunes are best for sledding. We also hiked the Alkali Dunes trail which takes you through the dunes. They also have a Junior Ranger Program for the kids.

Fire Island National Sea Shore is THE place to relax, enjoy summer, and thank our lucky stars for a day off to visit. The only thing about it is the $10.00 parking fee which NYS charges - no other state charges for beach admission and with Long Island taxes being the highest in the nation, limiting beach access to paying customers makes this fee appear what it is: just another fee to support excessive government.

It was an honor to see Mt. Rushmore. If you go at sundown they sing the National Anthem and light the memorial as the sun sets. WOW! The cafeteria has good food and a cheap breakfast. Had to do the early breakfast as I looked out at Mt. Rushmore justlike Cary Grant in North by Northwest. Yes...that movie was filmed on location there.

Just off the shore of Bayfield you can take a ferry trip to Madeline Island. Take your car and pay lots more, but you can use it to get to the other side of the island where there is a beach and hiking trails (2 parks).
it was interesting to hear what the tour guide had to say about the history of the fort, and how life was lived back then...it doesn't cost anything either...

For our girls' Spring Break we visited Mount Rushmore/Black Hills area. The Black Hills alone are beatiful and Mount Rushmore added to our pleasant experience. I heard that the area and faces were not in good shape but all of the faces seemed to be in very good shape. The various views among the Presidential Trail were very nice. The walk is just right. My 2 year old was able to hang in there and make it all the way around. The cafe onsite was a bit expensive so we did not eat there. Nice experience. Would recommend it. (Parking is $11 per car but that is the only $$ you are required to pay and the pass lasts for the rest of the year for the same vehicle. Not to your benefit if you rented a vehicle as we did.)

We were fortunate enough to pick one of the warmest days in March to spent at Valley Forge. After having the dog cooped up in our hotel room the day before while we toured Philadelphia, we needed some place where he could join us. We enjoyed it tremendously and didn't find it at all boring, as another reviewer stated, Maybe it doesn't qualify as an American History lesson 101 but we had a chance to talk take a really nice walk andt we even learned a thing or two. With no admission or parking fees, how can anyone go wrong?

We hired a car and decided to drive up to the National Park, it took approximately 40-50 mins easy driving out of Hilo and was easy to find. We paid a small entry fee which allowed us to return free over the following 7 days. We stopped at the visitor centre and were pleased to see they conducted free walking tours taking you to the best vantage points. The volunteers were wonderful and obviously happy to be there. Views were amazing, guide was knowledgeable discussing all flora, fauna and history. It was recommended we return at night to see the volcanos glowing and we decided to do this, it was so worth the drive, It gets really cold though so take a jumper or somthing warm to wear. You can also stop at the lava tubes and I would recommend taking the time to do this. Im glad we hired a car and did our own tour as the tour groups seemed to be very rushed. We took our time and stopped and started as we pleased. It is a very easy drive.

We just drove in from our B&B in Hereford, Arizona, which is on the western side of the park. The paved road becomes a dirt road before you get to the high pass that takes you back down to the east side of the park. It was dry and dusty. The views from the top are very impressive.

My wife and I have been multiple times to the Adams National Historical Park. As an amateur historian I can say it one of my favorite places to go. My wife doesn't enjoy history as much as I do but she also enjoys the visits just as much as I do. There is so much to do and see and for the price you can't beat it. The park provides an amazing insight into four generations of the Adams family (from 1720 to 1927). The park has two main sites: the Birthplaces of 2nd U.S. President John Adams and 6th U.S. President John Quincy Adams, and Peacefield including the "Old House," home to four generations of the Adams family, and the Stone Library which contains more than 12,000 historic volumes. You can also go across a little way up the road and visit the graves of both of the presidents in a church (for a additional fee as it isn't part of the park). There is no place else where you can see the birthplace of two presidents and their graves all at the same time.

I was fortunate to go on an only 85 degree day with just a light breeze. Many families were there with their kids sliding down the dunes with plastic saucers. When the tarred road ends and you start riding on the hard packed gypsum sand you may not even notice a difference. I did the five mile Alkali dunes hike that starts at the end of the loop road and had a wonderful time. I would not advise that hike though with kids or for people not in shape. The plastic saucers can be rented from the rental shop to the left of the main park info area. Ask for used ones and it will save money. In March of 2012 it was $20 for a new one with $5 refunded if it was brought back.

We went off season so not much to do after viewing. I am sure that summertime would be better as far as other options. There is no fee to enter the park but the parking fee is $11 per car and that is good for multiple visits for the same vehicle so you could go one day to view the monument by day and then return to see it by night another time without additional charge. Viewing by night is a must because the appearance changes according to the time of day.

There is a lot more to this park than just the volcano, though it's incredible enough in itself. There is steam and smoke pouring out of Kilauea visible from the Crater Road. Along the way, you'll pass several steam vents where you can feel the heat coming out of the earth. The lava tube is fascinating and it's eerily beautiful to drive through all the various lava flows. The trip to the end of the road, where the lava claimed the asphalt, is fascinating, though a bit lengthy. There are also a bunch of trails that meander through the park, so if you're interested in that kind of thing, make sure you leave the time and explore!

Aloha everyone, OK, so maybe Mauna Loa summit by way of the Mauna Loa Trail isn't on everyone's "bucket-list", but it was on mine... so, after several months of careful planning, a good safety plan, and a last check of the forecast, off I went. Now to be sure, Mauna Loa summit via the Mauna Loa Trail is NOT a leisurely day hike. It's a strenuous multi-day backpacking trip with several nights and days above 10Kft. Given the altitude, limited water availability, and the occasional 'outside-the-forecast' weather, if you're contemplating this one, I suggest plan, plan, plan. The HVNP has a good website for backcountry hikers, so read and heed. (You'll also need to check in with the rangers at the backcountry office to get a (free) permit to access the trail.) There are a few other websites that describe the trail, have forecasted weather for Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa summits, and there's even a 24-hour webcam at the summit so you can see summit conditions. The trail starts at 6700ft and climbs over both kinds of lava ("a'a"--the jagged, broken kind found in smaller chunks in your backyard barbeque grill (not fun) and "pahoe'hoe"--the kind that looks like black cake batter slopped all over the place). You'll definitely want trekking poles! The trail itself is marked by lots of 'ahu' or stone cairns. Your eyes will tune in to see them and the faint discolorations and wear of years of foot traffic on the lava. The ahu range in size from a foot to nearly 8 feet tall, so if you're walking along and don't see the next one, just stop for a second and let your eyes find it...it's there, trust me (although sometimes they hide behind trees and shrubs at the lower elevations). Both Red Hill Cabin and the Summit Cabin have cachement systems for water. The summit tank runs a little brown, so opt for boiling snow if you can--at least it looks better. Note: it's very arid up there, so do NOT shortchange yourself on water--drink lots). Both cabins have bunks (plywood racks) with some foam pads and some old sleeping bags. You can use them to pad the bunk and the spare sleeping bags as extra layers if necessary. There's a rustic table in each cabin and a cooking spot. The cabins are NOT heated but will keep you safe (mostly) from the elements. Red Hill is at 10Kft and is about an 8 hour hike depending on your speed and acclimitization. (FYI: I recommend getting a prescription for Diamox/acetazolimide to be on the safe side for the potential altitude sickness. I took it every 12 hours and had zero problems.) After Red Hill, the true summit or the Summit Cabin are both about 11.2 miles away--a very long, brutal, and cold uphill slog above 10Kft--- the puffing, fatigue, and pain is the price of admission to the awesome spectacle that is the Mokuaweo'weo crater. I elected to go straight to the cabin and hike the summit the next day. The Summit cabin sits on the edge of the crater so you'll have a grand view of the crater, the true summit, and the stars later. Another good pastime is to read the 'Red & Black/Black & Red' log books of all the hikers who've gone before you...great stories you'll definitely be able to relate to and you'll be proud to be in their company! I finished the adventure with a power hike to the summit and then back down to Red Hill... about 16 miles, but I did it in less than 9 hours. I paid the price of having both big toenails go black--ouch and yuck, but it's more cosmetic damage than real pain--although ibuprofen is a godsend. Overnighted again at Red Hill and then down to the trailhead--Basically two days up and two day down. I only saw three hikers on the trail going up as I was going down, so lots of solitude! Well, after all that, I'm not sure it sounds like all that much fun to a lot of people, but if you want the big get away (few, if any people) and you want to hike up an active volcano with a low probability of it blowing up in your face, then try Mauna Loa in the late fall, winter, and early spring...Anyway, do your homework and plan it well and it'll be worth every step...it's full of stunning views and the summit crater should be considered one of the great wonders of the world. The landscapes leave you both humbled and amazed at how small we can be in the universe. Enjoy!

The park is fascinating . Plan for most of you day at the park or enroute. A onetime fee 10.00 per car for 7 days covers everyone. Take a light jacket and maybe sweats it may be cool and rainy at times. I advise to stop first at the ranger station. You can’t miss it. They are great to advise you where to detour and what to see. Since this is mother nature you never know if steam and certain gases may reroute your direction of travel after you are in the park. The steam vents are everywhere and they can burn you if you are too close. If you decide to hike get advice on the website www.nps.gov/havo/index.htm , you need water and good shoes. Also when you travel the island you see helpful signs that say danger in 3 feet they mean just that. Its not like it is on the main land, where when they say danger you can kind of push it. IF they say stop turn around DO IT!! They are not playing. I have been twice to the park. I have only seen a huge hole in the ground with steam. It looks like the surface of the moon. I have never seen the volcano erupt, not many people have. And watch out for the so called dinner cruises that show you where the lava flows to the sea. They will charge you take you out and make like oh I guess you can’t see it today. Talk to the park rangers ask them questions. They love their job. Aloha

We were fortunate to have personal tour guides in this national treasure since we have family that lives in Durango. The San Juan National forest is just beautiful. We made our way up to the Molas Pass Summit, clocking in at 10,910 feet. The views are breathtaking, you get some awesome photo ops, and the signs at the top of the summit give some great historical and geographic lessons about our country. This was great for adults, and would be even better for kids.
When you go you have to first get a ticket from the visitor's center and that will tell you what time your tour is. So plan accordingly.

There's nothing earth-shattering to see here unless you've never been before, in which case it's probably worth the trip. I visited 6 years ago and since then the crater rim drive is half closed off, so there's less to do and see. The lava tube is cool. If you like hiking, then this trip is a must; lots more to do and see if you don't have a disinterested teenager with you. $10 park entrace fee. Bring food if you plan to stay!

I actually visited the Adams Natonal Historical Park a couple of years ago when I was reading "Dearest Friend; a Live of Abigail Adams" A group of my friends were reading a book about John Adams so we went to Quincy Square, boarded the tour bus and became in our own neighborhood for the afternoon. It was wonderful. For a very reasonable price the bus brings you to three of the Adams homes and a tour guide narrates historical facts and stories about the families.

My husband and I visited on 3/28. The tours run every hour on the 30 only, so if you miss one, you have to wait for the next one. There is a visitor center and short video of the fort, as well as a nature trial. To get to the fort, you have to take a short ferry ride. The entire place is free though. We had just missed the 2:30 ferry, so we decided to wait for the 3:30 and explore. We enjoyed looking at the baby owls in the trees outside and taking pictures of the area - until our camera battery died that is... No back up battery either! Silly us... Luckily the adorably sweet woman in the gift shop allowed us to charge it while we waited for the ferry. 20 minutes of charge and we were able to get all the pictures we wanted. I am forever grateful to her! The fort itself is very small and primitive. There isn't a lot to do or see, so do not go expecting a big event. It literally only take 30 minutes to explore the 2 rooms, read the few historical signs, and go to the top and back down. The guide was knowledgeable, but not very chatty. This is a good place to go if you want a free thing to do for a quick afternoon, and good pictures of the inlet and surrounding areas.

dress warmly as it is cold at 10,000 feet. walk slowly if you have a breathing problem. Look for silverswords and nene's. Walk on the trails and see if you think you are walking on the moon. There is an admission fee as it is a National Park. Go up for sunrise!

Was close to our hotel so we drove over, wife and I both enjoyed highly and it's free, although i would recommend even if you had to pay. Allow at least 2 hours to see the film and walk around to see the various stops.

We were traveling with and 81 yr old so we got her a wheelchair which limited where she could go. She was quite happy watching us from a distance. There are elevators but the paths are more for walking. There is a museum and a short film showing how they managed to sculpt the heads. We were there in March which was a good time since the weather was so nice this year and it wasn't that crowded. A lot of attractions on the way were not open at this time of year but we managed to find enough to keep us entertained. The fee is $11.00 per vehicle. They have a restaurant that was very good for a limited menu. I had the chicken fingers which were some of the best I have had. My daughter had a sore throat and could only eat soft food. The cook made her a scrambled egg even though that wasn't on the menu at that time of day. All staff that we dealt with were very friendly and helpful.

The first stop was at the Visitors Center which actually cost $6 to enter. Once we got there we realized there was actually nothing there. They had a map of the lower town, which I believe you can get online, and you can get your passport stamped. Otherwise, there's not much going on. From the Visitors Center, however, you can take a shuttle to the Lower Town instead of driving there and parking yourself. I don't know that either one is preferable. It's just something you can do. The shuttle's last trip back to the Visitor Center is at 5:45.

Walnut Canyon is right outside of Flagstaff, AZ and is definitely worth stopping by if you’re in the area. The entrance fee is only $5 per person, which is cheap for what you get. Outside the visitor center you're greeted with an amazing view of the canyon and the cliff dwellings that reside in the sides of the canyon. If you’re feeling up to it, you can walk to the bottom of the canyon for some even better views. The park ranger said it was 220 stairs or so to the bottom, but we counted 300+ from the visitor’s center down to the very end of the canyon trail. Easy walk down, not so easy on the way back up, so make sure you bring comfortable shoes and some water. At the very end of the canyon trail you walk right by cliff dwellings and get a much better idea of how people lived in them...it was pretty cool to see. We would highly recommend stopping here if you’re in the Flagstaff area as the canyon provides beautiful views, interesting sights, and a lot of stairs!

My boyfriend and I took a tour of the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall. Both were great to see- but Independence Hall was the real star of the show! The tour guide was energetic, and the wait to go in wasnt too bad, and it it was free of charge! I was truly impressed by the history within those walls- to be in the same room that George Washington, Ben Franklin and so many great others had occupied for such important events was moving. The kids seemed to enjoy it as much as the adults. Everyone should visit here at least once.

We had seen a tv documentary on Chaco and were eager to experience it first hand. It was well worth it. The detail and expertise exhibited in the building of the structures is amazing. The many theories about the area's purpose and occupancy make it even more intriguing. Plan to spend a day and hike around. As a National Park there is an entrance fee but we old folks (62+) can get a pass and it is well worth it.

Visiting the actual sights of the birth of our government is a must-do. The park is scheduled over many blocks, and it can be diffidult to see it all in one day, especially with young children. Arrive early and get tickets for Independence Hall immediately - they're free, but they are all given out quickly you can also reserve them over the internet for a small fee). The tours are very informative but rather advanced for children. There is a very good Junior Ranger booklet for children to complete, as well as trading cards they can collect at each site by talking to Rangers.

Travelled to Harpers Ferry on a whim and with no information about the area except what we learned in elementary school. First stop (logically) was the National Park Visitors Center. After paying $10 to park we went to the Visitors Center building. It was tiny and the long winded park ranger was in the midst of giving his dissertation to a group of 4 visitors and didn't acknowledge us. After 10 minutes of waiting we left to try to figure it out.

Not as well known as the Castillo De San Marcos, this fort is well south of St. Augustine, but it does not cost anything to see it. There is a short boat ride to where the fort is. When we visited there were demonstrations, and the tour guides were very knowledgeable. Also very patient with an inquisitive 9 year old boy.

For a tiny little fort there is something very charming about this place & we have been several times with family & visitors. I think the short boat ride must have something to do with it & the park rangers are interesting & friendly. There is no charge although donations are appreciated & it helps to go before you visit St. Augustine & the Castillo to put things in perspective historically. I strongly suggest that you check the boat schedule times online before you go...although there are several boat rides to the fort each day there is a mid-day gap that we have hit more than once & it's hard to spend an hour- hour and a half waiting because there's not a lot else to do here unless you bring a picnic. Weekdays are a great time to go if possible & we recently had the unexpected treat of seeing a family of great horned owls nesting near the visitor's center! It's also amazing how the tides & geography change the look of the fort over the years that we have been going & taking visitors. A great little fort to visit!

Staff very helpful and informative. A lot of steps to village so might not be suitable for everyone. But well worth the effort. If you plan to do a lot of nation parks, consider buying a national parks annual pass $ 80 dollars.Check up entrance prices before you travel. Also allowed us into some state parks in Arizona but not all states parks accept these.

The carvings of the four presidents is spectacular, and the trails that pass below the faces allow for a different perspective. The trail is not an easy one, involving hills, and steps. But it is worth it. The park was full of people on a weekend. A true tourist trap.

Incredible colors, geologic features you will see no where in the world. That is why you will see dozens of European & Asian countries represented to experience this God's gift to man! Whodo's, spires, pinnacles, fabulous hiking trails and more. Always take a huge shade hat, a big neck towel in the summer to wet and stay cool, plenty of water & energy snacks. A minimum of 24oz even in the winter and 48oz in summer. Always have anti-slip shoes, & it is highly recommended to have some great Liki Summit shock poles to take the stress off your knees & feet. They make the down hill and up hill, so, so easy on your body. Weather old or young you have to try great hiking poles if you are going to do a hike with 200' to 800' elevation changes like the ones in Bryce Canyon. I love those Austrian made poles which are around $100 at Sport's Chalet. They have the most shock which really helps pushing you up and down the Wall Street & the Queen's trail hikes. Without poles you better be young and in good shape. The weather was around 45*F which was fabulous for hiking. You never broke a sweat. I was there hiking a dozen trails year's ago in mid-August and it was around 100*F, and beastly hot to hike. I sure could of used my old US Army cool down kerchief's and wet towels. The sand stone just radiates the heat back in your face. A huge shade hat and tons of sun screen with save you from being burnt to a crisp which most of the novice hikers were every time I have been here. If you go that time of year start your hikes at sun up. The sun's rays are so intense. The elevation will get to you if you have breathing problems. It is over 7,000' to 9,000'. I did have problems sleeping at Ruby's Inn due to the elevation. Of all my hikes from Mittenvald Alp in Germany, to Switzerland and the forests of Yosemite & Sequoia California National Parks, I rate the geologic splendor of Bryce Canyon & Zion National Parks the two places you must visit before you die. If you just drive to the dozens of pull-off view points and take pictures, it is fabulous. If you are handicapped don't let this hiking turn you down. There are great ramp areas to see. If you have breathing problems, just take your portable concentrator, which I saw several. I took my Albutoral and it was fine. The roads are excellent with speeds to 65mph. The only slow and low area is the narrow Zion tunnel which they had to make one way for some big motor homes when I was coming back. On this tour from Las Vegas you get to see Zion too which has a nice shuttle bus and a handicap trail. Just do it! If you have only one place to see in the entire USA, go to the combo-Zion & Bryce Canyon National Parks. Go on-line and you will see if it is for you. I have been there three times in my 50yrs of traveling all over the world and I still come back to get close to nature and the incredible fresh air of Southern Utah.

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: LBJ's ranch in Stonewall TX was the "Western White House" during the Johnson years of the 1960's. It was and still is a working Texas ranch and it provides an insight into LBJ and the life he enjoyed. The first floor of the ranch house has been carefully restored to the way it was while LBJ was president. The media-conscious nature of LBJ is evident by the triple-screen TV arrays in several rooms, including his bedroom. Lady Bird's warmth is evident in the family photos that adorn almost all the rooms. There's a $2 fee to tour the house with a Ranger; entrance to the grounds and the CD tour of it are free.
Great National Park Service site. Lots of history and a great hike. If you can only do EITHER Sunset Crater or Walnut Canyou, go to Walnut Canyon. Fee is $5/person with kids under 16 free.

We added this national park into our tour from Canyonlands and Arches and were pleasantly delightfully surprised by the views, vistas and visit to the Mormon homestead, Giffords. At the Giffords House you can see old kitchen and bedroom set up and buy terrific home made ice cream for $1. I had a chocolate cup sitting on the hand made bench outside watching the ponies and other picnickers and it was just lovely. We also drove to the end of the paved road and took way too many photos of every mountain, point, butte, point etc., as if we hadn't see enough all ready. But the views are quite different and the feeling is more intimate in this park. Make sure you bring water and stop at the Visitor Info ctr for bathrooming and maps. The rangers there answer any questions you have about the formations and why they are colored the way they are. We also watched the movie which was helpful.
Had to purchase audio guide for $20; no rentals. It was good but rather lengthy.

Revolutionary War was over 200 years ago, but comes alive in this park. It has been nicely preserved, always a welcoming area, and deer frequently show themselves! There is generally a minimal fee to enter, but well worth the money. It makes history come alive!

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: I loved visiting this historical site! It was so lovely it was hard to remember that the Civil War ended here. The place was well marked so we had no trouble finding it. Lots of parking near the site. The staff were warm, funny and very knowledgeable. The site was well maintained and the boys were able to move around freely. The price was right too - we payed $5.00 for the family. I suggest you bring lunch because it's kind of rural, but it's a beautiful place for a picnic. We spent about 3.5 hours there and honestly could have spent more. There is some walking but it's not difficult.

My B&B had organised me a local guide for a couple of hours. ($50) Money very well spent. He took me round in his car to all the parts of the well preserved battlefield and explained the whole events in the context of the gound and terrain. I had a great morning . The centre is excellent and the park well laid out.

We were limited on time, and we asked at the Visitor's Center, "If you only have time to do one tour, which would you recommend?" Without hesitation, both employees said, "Melrose," and I must say it did not disappoint! Our tour guide was great, the price was very reasonable, and the home and grounds were spectacular.

On the first part of the hike you see interesting signatures. Amazing the quality of the work. Make sure you get the guide at the visitor center to understand the history. The hike to the top is easy and worth it considering the great view. If it's very windy, you may want to skip this especially with young children. The campground is great and only $5 / night or $2.50 with the senior pass.

The Black canyon is, well, black, it goes down almost 3,000 feet at its deepest point. Deep on the bottom the silvery streak of the Gunnison river can be seen. The North Rim has much better views and less visitors. You can drive around and stop at several locations to take pictures of the rocks that have been identified and named, such as the Sitting Camel, for example. There is no food or any facilities and we found the rangers stations closed when we visited. There was a sign to leave the admission price in an envelope by the station. I understand there is a camping in season, but we did not visit. You can go to the bottom of the canyon, we've seen some people with horses. A must visit for nature lovers
$5 charge per adult, nice historical displays & info, be sure to bring bottled water.

If you go to Philadelphia it's a must that you go and see the historic sites that is so much of piece of our history. I would suggest taking the carraige ride and pay the extra money to have the guides take you on the hour tour of the sites in Olde City area. If you like history, it's worth it. These people know more about the founding fathers than your History teacher in High School.

excellent history lesson. we bought a pass that is good forever as my husband is over 65. we got it in 2010 and when we went in 2011 it got 4 adults & 1 child in free. very educational. great views from the walls.

The park leading up to the visitor information center is very pretty and a great place to have a picnic. The park rangers are friendly and will guide you around the grounds. The FREE ferry leaves the dock every hour at half past the hour. You don't have to buy a ticket, but you need to get a pass at the visitor center. There you can read the history of the Matanzas Inlet and the fort. You can also watch a film about the area and learn about the wildlife. On the ride to the fort, you will see crabs, dolphis and lots of birds. The park is open to the public so you will see fisherman reeling in their catch.

When people have asked me about the battlefield at Gettysburg, I say it is hundreds of monuments and markers giving a visitor a good idea of what happned and where, and by whom. When people have asked me about the Antietam battlefield located an hour away around tiny Sharpsburg, Maryland, I tell them it's farmland with a few markers scattered about. It's hard to tell the single bloodiest day in American history happened over these few acres, maybe due to the lack of monuments and markers that you see on some other prominent battlefields. But what you do see, including the upside-down cannons for the six generals who fell on that day, are as telling as anything you'll see at any national park. Get yourself a good guide book and follow it along, but be careful. A lot of the roads you'll be driving on are rural, as is most of the area, so be sure to look out for the proper spots to drive down. Bloody Lane, a sunken road that was the spot of some very fierce fighting, is neat to walk down but be sure to park before you'll get there, as there really is no stopping point from the regualr road to it. The park service bookstore inside the visitors' center is small but has lot of great items not just from Antietam but also some items from the Monocacy battle that was fought around Frederick and some great maps. The visitor center film, which your admission pretty much is for, is one of the best in the park system.

Philadelphia is a city, and with common sense and comfy shoes, it is a safe and insightful place to be. We felt safe walking in this area. Street parking is scarce and limited, so plan to park in a parking garage and expect to pay $15-$25. Obvious stops include the Liberty Bell and Constitution Center and the US Mint (if it is open). But, get that free map and explore the easy to follow streets to get to other sites. Betsy Ross's house was fun ($5 pp) but small.(steps/close quarters). The 2nd National Bank is a gallery of portraits. The grand steps and columns are inviting. We didn't know many of the faces, but one portrait of a young girl is the inspiration for the American Girl doll Felicity's party dress. Ben Franklin is everywhere including statues and his grave.

The monument is nothing short of breath taking. The surrounding area has a nice little nature trail, and the visitor center is clean and interesting! Show me something else you can do that is fun for 4 hours for $11/car, and I'll be impressed. FYI, a parking pass is valid for the entire calendar year that you visited in.

The mission is under construction but we had a wonderful tour guide who helped us understand the history of the mission but also enhanced our understanding of the Presidio at Tubac and the Mission at San Xavier du Bac. Start here - you won't regret it. Because of the construction, the entrance fee was waived. Free homemade tortillas!

NP Guides are terrific, exhibits are well done and the NP Guides go out of their way to ensure that when there is a "sold out" ticket situation if there is space people who don't have tickets can get in on a stand by basis. There's no charge for tickets it is just for crowd management. Nice job with our tax dollars! Money well-spent. So interesting to see all the non-US visitors who are so interested in our story of Independence.

If you can climb stairs in a high altitude situation, this is a must see! The visitor center is small, but well set up, with a great view of the canyon, and the staff is very helpful. Go on a calm day, and make sure your camera batteries are charged. Make sure you have your Golden Age pass if you have one. It will get your whole car load(6) in free.

The timing and amount of lava you will see is decided by Mother Nature. At the time of my visit, there was no flowing lava to be seen within the National Park. We also took a helpcopter ride and did see tiny amounts of orange lava, but mostly smoke and steam. It is interesting and something you can't do anywhere else, so I do recommend it but if you are expecting huge orange gushes you will be disappointed. $10 per car fee is valid for 7 days. Chain of Craters Road (easy drive and free) is very interesting and the sea arch at the end is beautiful. Jagger Museum is a great way to spend an hour or more.

Really a hidden gem, wonderful display area, wheelchair access with a scenic place to sit if you don't want to hike, great staff and scenic trail. Cheap, only $5 a car. We met people from all over the world.

We took one of the Ode to Joy walking tours and it was amazing! Chalk full of information and you could tell the owner loved what he is doing. It turned into over 3 hours so a caution to those who might not be in good walking shape bec. it is lengthy and up and down hills. He does stop and lets everyone rest while he talks but the fact is, Harpers Ferry is not flat land and so you will be climbing. My calves were talking to me the next day but no complaints here. This is not suitable for strollers or wheelchairs. The price - which you pay at the end - was extremely reasonable and even though I had been to Harpers Ferry before I had never known a tenth of what I learned on this tour. Would HIGHLY recommend.

So glad my friend told me about this place. Who knew? Not only is the Bryce Canyon awesome to see. I mean it looks like thousand feet high sandcastles God made. They are every where. The cute western frontier stores are so cute. The nice/budget friendly gift shop and grocery store connected to Ruby's Best Western at the park entrance and Cowboy's awesome buffet restaurant. Down home cooked food. It was so tasty. It will cost you about $20 per person. Very nice National Park. You can drive yourself to each look out point and I'm not a hiker but I took the Mossy Creek hike to the waterfall and cave. So serene. So beautiful. Love, Love Loved it.

History buffs will love this small fort, really just an outpost, in the Matanzas Inlet. You need to take a boat from the main visitor center to the fort. This is a National Historic Park. More information on the park can be found on the National Park Service website at www.nps.gov If you have a National Park Passport Book you can get your passport stamped at the visitor center. There is a walking trail along the beach, a picnic area and rest room facilities near the visitor center that is located just off A1A a 20 minute drive from St. Augustine. It is open every day except Christmas from 9am to 5:30pm. There is no admission. The boat runs every hour beginning at 9:30 am so you may want to time your visit to catch the ferry. There is a short video about the fort at the visitor center. The boat trip affords you beautiful views of the Matanzas River, Rattlesnake and Anastasia Islands. The fort was built to protect St. Augustine from attack from the Matanzas inlet. The restored fort gives you a look at what it would have been like to be a soldier assigned to the fort. A national park service ranger gives an overview at the fort and then lets you roam around but is available to answer your questions. There are several cannons including two originals. If you are small enough to fit thru the opening you can climb a ladder to the obervation desk of the fort for beautiful sweeping views.

Drove over with my family of 4 (wife & 2 kids ages 7 & 8) to the Petroglyph National Monument on a Friday morning after breakfast. It's surprisingly close to the downtown area. Make sure to stop at the visitor center just off Unser Blvd on Western Trail. The Park Ranger in the visitor center will give you some great information on Petroglyph's and even recommend where to go. He recommended that we go to Boca Negra Canyon a few miles north of the visitor center. Parking was $1 and at the time we went there were plenty of parking spots. In Boca Negra there are 2 "mountains" with 1 main trail at the first stop then 1 main trail and 1 small one at the second stop. Both have parking so you can drive over after the first stop. Each trail only takes about 30 minutes max but you can spend more time searching out Petroglyph's if you like. You start by climbing the volcanic rock and looking for Petroglyph's, you actually acend upwards a decent height before you come back down the looping trail. The park service is trying to start a cell phone information line where you call a number and at different locations they give you interesting facts about what your looking at. I tried it and it was pretty cool but unfortunatley its still in a test phase, hopefully they'll improve on it as I rather enjoyed it. My kids had a great time and had no problem climbing the trails. Definately alot of fun for a few hours of exploring.

You can actually see a handprint in the side of the rock dated from the mid 1400's. That made the walk up a very steep, although beautifully paved walk well worth the effort. The blackened walls in the dwellings, blackened from the fires they used to cook and keep warm will reach your soul, at least it did mine. If you are someone who values the feel of history surrounding you then this is certainly a place not to be missed. Once again I need to pay homage to Teddy Roosevelt who was responsible for all the beautiful, mysterious, and awe-inspiring experiences I have had here in the West. These parks are a blessing to all who come here. It is worth the steep walk, you can stop and just drink in a most incredible view of Roosevelt lake a little over a thousand feet below you. If you don't do well with heights you may want to think twice, though!

We camped for free for 3 days in the forest across from Sunset Crater. Just pull into an area where someone has camped before. There are jerks that litter, but I figure cleaning up a bit was my payment. Wonderful Ponderosa pines with squirrels and deer in the area.

This review is specifically for Henninger Flats above Altadena. Started backpacking late Friday afternoon from the gate and arrived at the flats about and an hour forty minutes later. The uphill climb and afternoon sun made for a good work out! The campground offered nice, shady sites with clean restrooms nearby for our scouting group. With nightfall, came the million dollar view of the twinkling lights below....hard to believe we were only minutes from the city! Signs warn of rattlesnakes and should not be taken lightly as we saw a baby rattler camouflaged at the foot of a tree the next day. As far as things to do, you can take a hike up to Mt. Wilson (half our troop), work on a conservation project with the ranger (the other half), or read a book and watch squirrels scamper up and down trees (what I did), it's all good and it's all free! So whether you enjoy hiking, biking or backpacking the 2.7 miles, the view at the top is all the same, spectacular!

I'm sure sunrise is spectacular, but midday, if it's clear, is also amazing! Ranger says that the reflected heat of the crater means that you can usually see into the "crater" (actually an eroded valley with cinder cones) even when cloudy. I've been here twice, once (November) when it was socked in and drizzling and I nearly froze. It was gorgeous with a gorgeous view this time, looking out all the way to West Maui, and south to the Big Island, but wow, the wind will almost blow you over! If you can hit up a ranger talk at the lookout tower at the very top, do go! It was very informative about native birds, ecotones, plants, geology, etc. And the lookout is glassed in and out of the wind. Love the silversword plants. It was National Parks Week, so there was no admission that week (normally $10).

My sister and I recently walked around the Petroglyph National Monument on one of the three trails. We found numerous petroglyphs but no indication whether they were authentic or created by some kids down the street. It would be appreciated if there were plaques near some of the authentic petroglyphs or even a pamphlet that shares picturesand locations of petroglyphs that were the real deal. I would rate this a 5/5 for it's easy to reach location, fairly moderate and attractive hiking path, cleanliness, and cost (free), but without knowing if I am viewing graffiti or art, I walked away unimpressed by the experience.

We took the Frozen Niagara tour and it was just enough. the air always stays in the low 50s so if you go on a hot day you will stay nice and cool. If you have a National Parks pass you can get $5 off price of admission. If you go during the week there will be less people. We brought a jacket just in case. Low light or flash with slow speed cameras will light up the place.The whole tour takes about 2 hours. One thing if you do want the full experience of the Drapery room, you do have to hike down and up a lot of stairs. there was no "optional" about it. Just wear good traction shoes.

Everyone should visit at least once. It was very impressive. The information in the museum was very good and informative. We saw the video about it. The gift shop was excellent and well stocked with all kinds of items at different price points, so kids could even buy something at a reasonble price.

We drove through here on our way to Sedona. It was absolutely breathtaking and didn't cost anything to drive through. There were several campsites and scenic mountain and water views along the way. We wish we could have stopped to enjoy it longer!

If you enjoy geology, rocks, and fossils then this is a great stop. It is facinating to see fossils that are so old. I would highly reccomend that you make arrangements for a fee at one of the private fossil farms bordering Fossil Butte Monument, where yoy can dig for fossils and take some home with you as keepsakes.

My family (wife, son, daughter-in-law, grandchildren ages 7,5,2) all visited Mt. Rushmore on May 5, 2012. I must admit I was a little disappointed at the cost ($11.00) for parking. That aside, the setting is beautiful, the layout of the walkway, visitors center, shop and restaurant, as well as the Flag Walk. One cannot help but be impressed with the work done, and the dedication to detail on the faces of the four presidents depicted. It was really inspiring. We decided to have the grandchildren participate in the Jr. Ranger Program. If you are not familiar with this program it is well worth the time (no cost) and the kids really learned about the site. I wish I had thought to take down the names of the Rangers we spoke with, who went over the kids booklets, gave a little pop quiz (our five year old grandson, when asked by the Ranger who was the president with the glasses, proudly answered "Teddy Roosevelt!" to the pleasant surprise of his mother). The Rangers we spoke with were pleasant and well versed in the information about the monument. The gift shop had lots and lots of items, although a few items that would be what a 2/3 year old would like, would have been helpful. Overall it was a fascinating and thoroughly enjoyable experience...and rather emotionally moving as well.
I heard so much about this that I poo-poo'd it and almost took a pass. Don't. The combination of evergreens and unique formations make this a top national park, period, unlike any other.

The tour begins at the Visitors Center in the middle of town. The Visitors Center is actually in a large city building containing many shops and offices, but visible signage makes it fairly easy to find. You can park your vehicle in the building's parking garage and they will validate your ticket at the Center when you get your tour tickets so that the parking is free. After paying a reasonable cost for the tour of $5 per person, or using one of the National Park passes to eliminate the cost, you hop the next tour trolley right outside the Center. During the 2 hour tour you visit 2 homesteads, the first stop being the side by side early homes of the Adams family and then on to Peacefield. The rangers were outstanding at both locales, giving lots of interesting information and most willing to answer questions. The trolley then returns you to the Visitors Center where, if you have the time, you can take in the PBS John Adams film (not the HBO miniseries that is better known), walk to the Church where Abigal and John are interred in a basement crypt (an additional cost), visit a nearby Revolutionary War era cemetery, or stop at one of the several nearby restaurants before heading home. It was a most enjoyable day.

The Sunset Hike is absolutely free with your admission to the park and is SO worth it! I do believe sunset was the best time for pictuers of the park, really gave it color (not just reflection.) And the ranger who lead the hike was very helpful and informative. Also, dont be put off by the word hike. It was no more than a half a mile round trip, you really just have to be able to climb over and back over a dune. Also, feel free to wear sandals, shoes are definately not needed when you get into the soft sand.

My boyfriend and I were floored to see that it was such a high cost to park at Mount Rushmore and that our National Parks Access Pass did not cover the fee; we almost kept driving and just looked at it from afar because we were so disappointed. We decided to buck up and pay. However, we had been camping nearby and happened to get on the road very early (about 5:30 or 6AM); when we reached the parking area, the gates were open and we were able to park for free and access all of the trails. None of the facilities were open, but we were able to see what we came for - Mt. Rushmore!

This trip was one of those, "always wanted to go see it" type of things. We flew into Rapid City, SD, rented a car and headed out early the next morning. It is only a short 20 to 25 minute drive out to the Monument from Rapid City. It is truly an impressive place to be. Parking was $11.00, but there is no fee for touring the monument, grounds, studio, and museum. Happy to pay to park as the entire place, including the parking was paved, clean, neat and user friendly. The only problem we encountered was that we were a few weeks early for the busy tourist season. Some of the area attractions and the sculptor studio at the monument were not open. We visited during the last week in April. Mount Rushmore is truly an attraction that everyone must see! Make a time and go see it! We went back out to the monument in the evening. The faces are lighted about 15 minutes after dusk and remain lit until about 9:00 pm. Wow, what an impressive place. We enjoyed every minute of our visit. Allow a few hours for the visit and wear good walking shoes so you can take the President's Trail. It is about a 1/4 mile walk with some steps to negotiate. It is worth the time and effort. It will put you right up under the faces for some uniqe photos. Nice lunch room and gift shop on the site. Over a million visitors a year. You should be one of them!

We are glad we saw it. You can't imagine how vast it is. It was very easy to see by driving through and stopping at the various viewpoints. You can do as little or much hiking as you prefer. It was a sight to behold. Since we only did a little hiking, it only took less than half day to see. It cost $25 per car to enter the park but the pass was good for 7 days. We did notice several shuttles driving through, but we thought driving our own car let us have more control of our time. There were 2 or three restroom stops. You can eat at the lodge just inside the entrance if you get hungry.

I've been to St. Augustine many times before but never visited this Fort. I was so happy I took the time this trip. It's only about a 20-30 minute drive from the historic district. When you get there you take a ferry to the fort (quick 5 minute ferry ride) and the tour guide tells you about the fort. The fort itself is actually pretty small and only takes about 30 minutes to explore and take pictures. It's also a free activity to do but I hightly recommend donating (at least a few dollars) to the Fort. It's definitely worth at least $10/person!

I'm a big fan of National parks, monuments, landmarks, etc and this did not disappoint. They are building a new visitors center (done by 2013?) but still have a make shift one. Be sure to watch the movie before wandering around. It is really baffling to think these petrified redwoods are from 35 millions years ago. Ranger Jeff gave a great walking tour of the visitor center area. Afterwards we walked the one mile loop to see more exhibits. There are miles and miles of trails. There's a picnic area right next to the parking lot. It's a mere $3.00 per person. What a deal. Hard to believe it could've been called a tourist trap!!

Last week a friend took me to Harpers Ferry National Historical Park which is indeed a spectacular, unforgettable, and historical attraction!! We took a guided tour buss and two guides, Mike (I hope I am right with the name) and Jim both voluntarily, very knowledgeably, and in a very interesting way told us about the place. One of the guides told us that he was actually born in the area and grew up there, which I think this guide must have had a wonderful and adventurous childhood:) I really hope that such unforgettable guided tours will continue operating, and pass on to visitors the history of the place and make them feel the history so close to them!

A MUST SEE FOR EVERYONE. I had never been to a cave, and I'm told the tour I went on, "The Historic Tour", is the not the most amazing one, but I was most amazed. The tour was two hours and two miles. I'm overweight and lazy, and had no problem managing the hike. Every inch of the cave tour was fascinating. I strongly recommend a small LED flashlight to shine in the cracks and corners as you go. The park lighting is just enough to see your general surroundings, but I wanted more. The tour guides don't spent a lot of time talking, the cave speaks for itself. They stop at a few significant points, but mostly they let you walk and enjoy. I would say it's a bit much for any kid who can't get around on their own. It would be an awesome adventure and memory for any eight year old. You do NOT want to carry a child through this. If you are very obese, there are a few spots that might cause embarrassment. This is a tremendous value at $12.00, but coupons for 2$ off can be found in the area hotels. It's a national park, so every dollar goes to very good use. You could call it a day after one tour and be quite fulfilled. Book ahead because I'm told the peak season often sells out early. We had a small tour on May 11.

Just got back from a fun weekend spent exploring caves at Lava Beds National Monument. The visitor center has great detailed maps with explanations for levels to each person can go at their own pace. I found that if we went into the challenging caves we just turned around and went back when it got to be too much for us. The visitor's center sells knee pads ($13) so if you plan on crawling I would bring your own or buy some before heading out. You can also purchase hard-hat type helmets there for around $7. We brought bike helmets which were more sturdy and stayed put. The best cave for the beginner is Sentinel cave because you can walk all the way through it, the path is really developed and they even have stairs in places. Skull Cave and Merrell Cave require a lot of stair climbing to get to the bottom so be prepared for the long climb up those same steps when you are coming back up.

I don't like game plans while visiting but this is a place I would suggest taking the time to plan. (I was able to cheat a little my son lives just outside of Philly and he was with us) Many places are free however you may need a free ticket. Only 2400 tickets are given on a daily basis for Indepence Hall and are given out fast. You may get a ticket at 10 but your tour time may not be until late afternoon - which may be a problem. Indepence Hall and the visitor center where you get your free tickets are about 3-5 minutes walk apart. Depending on the time of your tour you can walk the area's other sites. Or someone can get your tickets while the others wait in line at the liberty bell for you. (In you went long ago the Liberty Bell is now in a building). Be sure to look up when you are at this and any historical site to see the great buildings. You go in and out of buildings I did see people with strollers but I don't think there are elevators because they were carrying them up and down and one place where the senate met they didn't go upstairs. Be sure you sit where you can hear your guide they do not have microphones. Not a lot of time to ask questions while viewing but after the tour the guides are around to answer your questions. So save your questions until that time. Tour guides are very informative. You will have your bag checked before you can enter. You can take all the photos you want. Get your tickets and while you are waiting to check in for security stop in the "first city hall" right there - where the supreme court first met. Planning is the key. Also, no bathrooms - however there are some at the visitor's center. The visitor's center also has several areas to walk around to view history. One of us went in line for the tickets the rest of us looked around the visitor's center.
Lehman Cave tour was excellent and very much worth the time and fee.

The highlight of our weekend Kentucky trip was to visit Mammoth cave. Although we only live 2 hours from the cave, I had never been there before. My boyfriend had been several years ago and had a good experience. I had been to Marengo cave before, so it wasn't my first cave tour. We had pre-booked the "Grand Avenue" tour, which only ran once a day. Unfortunately, after being delayed on I-65 by wreck, which slowed traffic to a crawl and forced us to detour, we were late for the tour. We called the ticket office while sitting in traffic and luckily refunded our tickets, minus a small fee. When we finally got to the visitor's center, we booked the "New Cave" tour, which was 3/4 of a mile long and started about 20 minutes after we arrived. It was $12 for adults.

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: What a great ride and you will see LBJ's & Lady Birds home and LBJ's father's homestead. Along with the Presidential plane. Beautiful ranch must see. On the way out stop at the cemetery to pay your respects to the Johnson Family. Also, see the school he attended for a short time.

We have been planning to go here for years and are so glad we made it! It's only $5 a person (or free with Parks pass) and the tour is interesting whether or not you saw the HBO series on John Adams. It covers both the birthplace homes of both presidents Adams as well as Peace Field where John retired and died. Original paintings, furnishings and even the wisteria Abigail Adams planted. We were transported!

This is a MUST do for everyone's bucket list! It should be one of the wonders of the world! Here is a very helpful tip: The lines are LONG during the weekend. Go as soon as you can to buy your tickets (or buy ahead online) for the next day or two for the tours. Also, know what tour you want when you get in line.The ticket sales people were NOT helpful at all and will make you leave the line if you don't know what tour you want. I recommend the Historic tour as long as you are ok with small spaces and lots and lots of stairs! You can take Water bottles and I wish I had some after the long climb up the stairs. Wear comfortable shoes and it doesn't hurt to have a jacket. Of course if you are a caver ...you probably know that! :)

Spent a very worthy three hours here as part of a 2,500-mile road trip earlier this month. The top thing worth mentioning is the Park's staff. They are very knowledgeable about every tiny detail regarding the joining of the transcontinental railroad, and steam railroading in general. If railroading isn't your thing, you'll probably only rate this a 3, but since it is mine, it gets a 5.

We started at the last stop on the tour not understanding how it ran as we found the recommendation on here. The initial address for the start is not 135 Adams Street, this is the last stop. Start at the visitor centre in Quincy otherwise you will find yourself very irritated by the travelling. We got on at 135 Adams Street then drove for some 10 minutes to get to the visitor centre then drove for another 15 minutes to get to the first homesteads. After 20 minutes the driver put the air conditioning on and it was hot! So we were slightly irritable by this point. Once the tour started we calmed down though and the tour was fascinating and the guides exceptional. The price was an absolute bargain compared to other attractions we visited. We knew nothing about the Adams family having come from England but now I have a real love for Abigail, a woman after my own heart! Definately well worth a visit. You either have an idea about the significance of this family or like us learnt to appreciate them and had a fantastically interesting afternoon. And the library is well worth a visit itself.

The Wall of Bones at the Quarry is spectacular. We watched the short movie at the Visitor's Center first...well done and informative. The auto tour was good. Spring the $1 for the tour guide brochure; it really enhances the drive.

I went to see the fort years ago and there was nothing to see then. Well since its been quite a few years (16). We thought we would check it out again. Still nothing to see. A bunch of empty concrete rooms. It is a total rip off. They charge $7 per adult and you can come back anytime over the next 6 days. For what I wondered. To bore yourself to death a second time. This place is just ridiculous.

Terrific National Park, no charge for entry or parking. If you have just a couple of hours and need some exercise, go for a walk or bike ride (bike rentals in the parking lot!!) through the miles and miles of roads. If you are walking, there are lots of monuments and other things to stop and see. A really great place just outside of the hustle of the city.

If one is into the civil war than this historic town of Harper's Ferry is worth checking out. There is lot's of walk and several book stores dedicated to information about this conflict from the 1860's. It is also a National Park Service Historical Site and don't have to pay admission to the various buildings in town. Lot's on information about John Brown role leading up to the events of this great American conflict.

Russell Cave is truly a beautiful location. The grounds of the park are well maintained and the staff is friendly. Upon arriving, i viewed a brief film on russell cave and quickly looked over some of the museum items they had. Then, from the visitor's center, it is only about a 4 to 5 minute walk to the cave entrance. There are good spots to take photos, as well as some plaques detaling some history on the cave. The cost of everything is free. Unfortunately there just isnt a lot to see. Wish they could give cave tours, but signs inidicated the cave and surrounding area was prone to quick flooding. So it may not be possible to do this.

The Mount Rushmore memorial is awesomely done. The Presidential trail gets you some great close up views of the memorial. Rent the audio for $5 it is worth it. The restaurant on site was very good, as well as, the ice cream shop next to it. The bookstores and gift shops were well stocked.

Wish I could rate this as "good" instead of "very good." This is better than "average," however, which is why I rated it "very good." Saw this park after having seen Zion & Bryce NPs the two days previous. Perhaps this is why I was not as impressed with Capitol Reef as I may have been had I not seen the other two parks first. This park is interesting in its starkness but not as beautiful to me as Zion or Bryce. It's also a bit of a long haul from Bryce to Capitol Reef as well, over Hwy 12 with a lot of switchbacks. There was not much to see in the Fruita area, but did enjoy eating a picnic lunch there & buying a small pie from the Gifford Homestead. Bathroom facilities are fairly limited and so is food, so be sure to take your own water & food for meals. Wish there was better signage throughout park. Lonely Planet guide said that a dirt road at the end of the scenic drive continued into the waterpocket fold and we could see Pioneer Registry & some water tanks. However, road is very rough and kept going & going, much beyond a half mile...even with an SUV, did not feel comfortable continuing. Trails / trailheads are not well marked. Also, the rock formations are not labeled throughout the park and the signs for the pullover stops are numbered only going southward (see them in order from north to south, opposite of Bryce's scenic drive, which you should see from south to north). Did really enjoy 2-mile hike to Hickman Natural Bridge and the ranger talk at the visitor's center about the geology of the park. Currently, the theatre in the visitor's center is out of order. Petroglyphs on Hwy 24 are interesting & worth a stop. Park map shows Observation Point to be on east side of park off Hwy 24 but when we drove out there, there was nothing but a small turnaround & the park sign. There was a sign for Observation Point but it was on the west side of the park right before the Twin Rocks going eastward...strange.

We were traveling with a one yr old so visited about two hours before the sunset. This place is gorgeous! It is about an 8 mile loop so you can drive through the whole thing to pick a spot that works for you. We wanted to take pictures of the sunset so we picked a spot that was facing sacramento mountains. We were expecting the sand to be hot but it was kind of cool, so our one yr old was crawling around easily. There were not too many visitors so we could pick an area where it was just us. We absolutely loved it, the sunset was beautiful! Take some water with you because there is none available once you are past the gift shop. Entry to the monument is $3 per adult and no charge for kids. The gift shop is quite nice and the prices are reasonable.

This is a gem of a spot, if you are willing to traverse the terrain to get there. The picture on the website is a bit misleading, showing elderly folks walking on a bridge with ease. Sure, that’s the first minute, after that you’ll really need your hiking shoes to make it safely up and down the narrow, rocky, root studded path. But there are numerous short side paths to make it down to the water, and enjoy a shallow pool all to yourself. Most people cross the bridge and stop at the first set of pools to bathe, here are the shallow water “falls” but keep in mind if you head for here, lots of other people will probably already be down there. This aside, getting there is the worst. There are about 13 miles of gravel road to conquer. The last 5 of these are incredible…incredibly bad, with rocks sticking up at tire puncturing angles in patches unavoidable to your vehicle, and ruts offering a jarring experience even at 5mph, it is not for the faint of heart and very time consuming to pass. Perhaps this is why there are no brochures of the attraction at the rest stops or visitors centers. Personally, I didn’t think it was worth the journey, and white knuckling the stretch of bad road, but you should definitely weight this for yourself.

the price is good but it seems like you see the same stuff over and over. But very cool to know you are 380 feet below ground and neat how it was stumbled upon. It was raining when we went so it was nice to be out of the rain.
Our family went on the guided tour of Lincoln's home and it was great. You do have to pay for parking but the guided tour is free.
I wanted to see Mount Rushmore since it's an American landmark. I'm so glad I went! It was not very crowded when I went so parking was fine, and $11 is a bargain for a 6-month pass!

When you grow up learning about it and seeing pictures of it all the time its hard to believe its real until you actually see it. Glad I can say I saw it but there is only so long you can stare at a piece of granite. Worth driving 9 hours for by itself - not so much but if your passing through sure pretty sweet to stop and check it and the views looking across the extremely flat boring plains you drove 9 hours through pretty sweet. Cool thing is parking is good for the year once you pay.

We didn't reserve a tour over memorial day weekend so the guided tours were sold out before lunch time. We did go on the self guided tour($4/person) which was fun also and a huge relief from the scorching sun. The park was packed with visitors but with so many areas of interest it wasn't too bad.
Love the history just wished we had booked more time. Day 13 of our 14 day NE vacation. Too much to see in such a short time. Did the highlights. We had a senior pass so it was free.

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: We toured both the state park where LBJ's family had a settlement and includes a tour of the house where he grew up. The tour guide was very informative and knowledgeable. The other buildings are quite picturesque. Then we drove 14 miles to the LBJ Ranch. We stopped at the info center and purchased the GPS video tour for $10.
