It was definitely worth the money, providing excellent directions and historical background, even some songs as we drove along. The ranch is very large, with beautiful flowers blooming in the fields. The ranch house tour was also interesting, and gave us a window into LBJ's presidency and the type of person he was. It was a very enjoyable day.

My brother and I spent 4 nights camping here last week. We saw the bison, wild horses, prairie dogs, and even a snake. We enjoyed the South Unit much more than the North Unit which may not be worth the trip for time constrained people. Most of the wildlife is viewable in the South Unit and the views are spectacular. It was awesome. As for the campsite, we encountered a problem along with other campers. We set up camp on a lot with 2 tents and a tarp that took a few hours. The hostess approached us and told us someone else had paid for the lot for a few more days. The prior campers had stayed 5 days and paid for a week. However, they left the site abandoned and we took a chance they had left early. We said we'd leave if they showed back up which they didn't. The same thing happened on the lot next to us a few days later and it was not used for a night even though campers had inquired about it. The campsite is set up first come and people need to leave something to show they haven't left. It says at checkin to place something in the lot to show it is occupied. We ended up with the best campsite so no complaints, but the policy needs to change where people pay ahead and leave early.
Mount Rushmore is a definite must see, when in the US. Entry is $11 but it is quite remarkable. Parking and access well organized and easy access to the monument.

$10 to get in is a little pricey as we did the walk and read all the literature on offer in less than two hours but the view is nice and the history is worth reading about...just don't expect to spend all day there

You buy a $10 dollar pass per car that is good for 7 days, so make sure you save it, because you may need more than one day to visit this vast place, make sure you visit the different attractions available here and make sure you stay to see the glow of the volcano after sunset, memories to last a life time.

I loved everything about the house. There is no charge, but you can make a donation which I did. I went with my sister and we took lots of photos which are on my other computer, darn! But we got some photos that were so good, they looked like postcards. If you visit Springfield, IL, you are nuts if you don't visit Lincoln's home.

Bryce has great photo areas spectacular views and relatively unspoiled. The rim trail is a great trail to view canyon especially at sunrise u can start near rim at first turnoff and hike all the way up along the rim but u need to be in decent shape to go all the way trail guide says 4.7 I don't think most of the numbers at this park were correct and many of the trails were not marked clearly and the are not enough trails considering how vast the whole thing is. Eat at the lodge great food but pricey, pines motel also has good food also not cheap. If u go thru park gate before sunrise the entry is free because gates are unmanned.

Probably the most overrated national park I have ever visited. The only way in is on a converted school bus (at least the seats are comfortable) on a windy, bumpy, mostly gravel and dirt road. The bus is full of tourists with cameras who run from side to side whenever a bear, caribou, moose or bighorn sheep is sited. The restrooms along the way are just fancy outhouses and there is always a wait. You are constantly warned not to leave the area around the restroom or bus or you may be mauled by a bear. The landscape is featureless and the chances of seeing Mount McKinley are about 50/50. Your are committed to at least an 8 hour round trip. A cold and unappetizing lunch is included but bring your own food. Considering this park is one of the hardest to get to in the world, it is not worth the time or considerable expense. It is unique landscape but there is a lot of unique landscape in the world that is much more accessible.

This is a great battlefield to experience by walking. I stopped here on my way to Gettysburg. After learning more about Antietam while there, I wished I would have included Harper's Ferry first, then Antietam, then Gettysburg. If you're going to Antietam, first stop should be the Visitor's Center. They have a film to watch and a nice bookstore. If you want to walk some of the battlefield, go to the bookstore and pick up their $2 booklets for each segment of the battle. The booklets are walking tours of the events of the day; the cornfield, the bloody lane, the bridge, and more. It's good to do the driving tour, but there's something special about actually walking the cornfield and bloody lane that can't be experienced in a car. It was a full afternoon trip to cover the battlefield, so I stayed at the Hagerstown Hotel and Convention Center before heading up to Gettysburg. But, if you have time, go to Harpers Ferry in the morning, then to Antietam. Harpers Ferry is less than 20 miles away from Antietam and it is part of the "story" since Confederate troops occupied Harper's Ferry and then made a rush 17 mile foot march to Antietam just in time to provide reinforcement. One other tip, do the Ranger orientation that they conduct at the Visitor's Center. It's only a few times a day, but worth hanging around to listen to the Ranger provide insight.

There is a surprisingly large amount of stuff to do here even though you'd assume it's all about dinosaurs. The visitor's center and quarry buildings were beautiful, and there was a shuttle every 15 minutes to take visitors to the quarry. The wall of bones is gigantic and cool, and there were a few hikes you could go on. Definitely purchase the guidebook ($1) for the Tour of the Tilted Rocks drive. It was a neat way to see the park, and includes three petroglyph sites and Josie's cabin, which was a neat oasis at the end of the road. The last 2 miles are unpaved, but my sedan did just fine. Geology buffs will love this place.

Harpers Ferry is a great NPS area to visit for the mountain and water gap beauty, trails, history of Civil War and Transportation and much more. Two rivers meet there, The C&O Canal is there. Two railroads of early USA importance pass through. The town has much to offer. Jim led a great tour based around the pre-Civil War attack by John Brown on the US armory there, details of the very large armory and arsenal, and battles throughout the war over the area. He made history very alive and interesting. A lot of industry started there because of the water power supplied by the rivers. The water gap in the mountains was the early passage to the west.

Very rude to paying customers. Small rental company, with staff that has no knowledge about their equipment and service provided while there. People were told they better be back in the four hours aloted as if you are five minutes late the 100.00 Charge is applicable. A flat tire while on excursion, staff stated Don't you know how to change a tire and You better call Triple A. No compensation offered for the hour delay while they had to find someone to come and change the tire.

It was unspoiled and non-commercial. You could almost see the strategies employed by both sides in this historic battle -- and the self guided tour was easy to follow and well worth the cost of the CDs we purchased.
This park is too much to describe. It is like a picture. Everyone should go to the nighttime service as well as visiting in the day time. Once you pay the parking, you may come and go as you wish.

Definitely a place to visit in order to capture the American Experience. When we visited in May we were fortunate there were no crowds and the weather was perfect a far cry from rainy Seattle and I might add the Rangers were friendly. The entrance fee is only $11 per car and the place far more organized and pleasant compared to Crazy Horse just a stones throw away. We are glad we visited Mt Rushmore.

I was visiting with a history buff. He enjoyed the history aspect of it. I enjoyed my time spent near the river. It's a beautiful, peaceful place. You will also find some bald eagles here if you pay attention!

It's always a fun & afforadable place to visit with friends or family. It only cost $11 for parking. Bring your camera. It can be a short stop or longer depending on your time frame. Great for all ages. Must see.

For $5, we saw three historical sites that were incredibly interesting. The tour guides did a great job of providing historical background of the properties. My favorite part of the tour was the Adams' main house and John Quincy's library. We didin't have a car in Boston, but accessing the property via the train was very easy. I would definitely go on this tour again!

I visited Rinconada Canyon Trail. There were NO SIGNS pointing to the location of the petroglyphs. I was just supposed to find them. There were graffite petroglyphs and no way to identify the real ones. How can I see the petroglyphs when I don't know were they are? If admission had been charged, I would ask for my money back.

My 12th trip to this national memorial and it never gets old. Something I feel every American should visit once in their lifetime. I have been lucky enough to see it a dozen times. It's affordable at $11 for the whole year. Morning is the best time to shoot photos of the mountain. Didn't see any chipmunks or mountain goats this trip. Love the native American exhibit here with the teepees.

Pay attention to the NPS website and book your tour in advance. I couldn't believe how many people were driving out on a whim to find out that no tours were available until the next day. The "Scenic Tour" is not as strenous as they make it out to be as the steps and stairs are so spread out that you don't realize how much up and down you're doing.

Great time! Driving the short loop through the sands is a must, as the dunes at the end are the truly magnificent white. The contrast with the mountains and blue sky are awesome. the 17 minute video and the displays explaining the making of the white sand is a must, and helps to understand. Nice gift and snack store with genuine articles, not just national brabds. There are markers for the trail so you won't get lost, but remember water...an umbrella, shades, hat is good, but walking barefoot seems to work the best. There is a nice wheelchair accessible trail! There is a fee, but it was free today.

It was awesome! We camped out in a tent in the south campgrounds. We were right on the buffalo trail and heard them come by the tent in the middle of the night and then back in the a.m. The scenery is beautiful. The campgrounds well-maintained and monitored. No showers, but you can get a shower in town at the Amble Inn connected to the Book Store for $6 a person if they a room available!! Great experience!

During our trip we visited Zion National Park, North Rim Grand Canyon but Bryce Canyon was the most visually interesting. I definitely recommend stopping at points along the 18 mile scenic road. Some of the points require a bit of walking while others are right in front of you. The views of the Hoodoo's & surrounding canyon are amazing! These are views you will never see anywhere else. I suggest driving to the last point-Rainbow-& start there. This will give you less traffic to deal with & all the points are on that side of the road so easier access as well. The park has shuttles which take you to each point & they really push this mode of transportation to protect the park. The only problem is the shuttle starts 8am & stops at 7pm. We drove because we started our hike early morning & we stayed in the park for sunset during our drive of the scenic tour. We viewed the sunset from Inspiration Point & it was gorgeous. You will not only have great views of the canyon but may also see wild-life on your drive. The entrance fee to the park is $25 & open 24 hours a day. There are restrooms at some of the points.

Wow, what a view. The visitor complex provided an incredible setting for viewing this remarkable site. A walking trail provided additional opportunities to view the monument and get exceptional photos. Make sure to visit in the evening to hear a park ranger, watch a movie and see the lighting of the monument America The Beautiful in the outdoor amphitheater. One price ($11) for the car provides good for the year.

Crater Lake is not just a "lake.". It is impossible to describe to anyone who has never been. Just GO, but save your trip to late August or early September, the perfect time is just after Labor Day when kids are back in school if you want less crowds (it will still be crowded.). Most people don't stay here long because it seems there is nothing to "do", meaning this is not a lake resort, it is a visual and sensory spectacular event, a place to return to yourself, if you give yourself the time to slow down and discover the area. If you want the best, stay in the Crater Lake Lodge, but you'll need to reserve far in advance to get a lake view room (the only kind worth the $$$, it isn't cheap.). Stay on the top floor in one of the claw foot bathtub rooms. A warning- no TV, nothing but the view. They do have wi-fi now, but if you have an iPhone, no service- Verizon usually works. But the idea is to unplug! Take the hike to the top of the ranger station at Hillman Peak. Drive down to the Pinnacles. Drive the rim drive and stop along the way. Take the boat tour only if you are in good physical condition - the hike back up is very challenging. The same with the boat ride and optional hike up to the top of Wizard Island. For your first time, do it all- the ranger talks, etc. Even if you are not staying at the lodge, wander into the fireplace lounge early and grab a seat by the fireplace or on a sofa. After 3pm they serve drinks and food there, and you can curl up and read for hours. Or weather permitting, go out on the veranda and snap up one of the coveted rockers to view the lake and hang out- again, they will serve you there after 3pm. The lodge staff are from many different countries and many of them are friendly and great stories abound. Dinner or lunch at the lodge is also a treat in the dining room, but call in advance to make reservations for dinner as it is very popular. This need intensifies as the summer months go on. Really, the lake is only in tourable mode between mid-July and mid-September. I was just ther in early June and there was 6 feet of snow and at times you couldn't see the lake, it was snowing so much. Ther are a number of places to stay within 30 minutes, just outside of the lake, but choose carefully, as many places capitalize on the lake as a destination and aren't as they claim.

About an hour out of Las Cruces, NM. It was an easy drive on well maintained roads. If you are planning a visit, be sure to check their website before you go. It is located near the missile test range & the area is sometimes closed when they are doing testing. When you arrive the visitor center has a 17 min. film that has great photography although the audio had some glitches. If you have kids, or are a kid at heart, be sure to pick up a sled at the gift shop so you can go sledding down the dunes. New ones cost $14.95 & they will buy them back from you for $5 or you can buy a used one for $10 and they will buy it back for $3. Don't bother to buy the wax as the sled works fine without it. Choose a sand dune that has soft sand & it will work best. Great place to hike, take photos, & have fun. Don't forget to take some water with you because it is hot & they don't have any at the dunes. Only $3 entrance fee for anyone 16+

Though not a large property, this park has lots of character and history. The park rangers are very knowledgable, leading free tours throughout the weekend. My favorite part of the park - the painting! The park supplies paper, watercolors and brushes and encourages everyone to become a part of the park's history by continuing the tradition of plein-air painting! I don't have an artistic bone in my body, and have never water-color painted before. But the artist-in-residence provided some hints, and motivation, and the park did the rest - supplying lots of inspirational spots to paint. It was one of the most pleasant afternoons I've ever spent in CT. And if I remember correctly, there is no charge to use the grounds. The park also has some nice walking trails, though you have to be careful because a couple of the longer trails weren't groomed very well. That's the only reason I'm not giving it 5 stars!
Took my son to Mount Rushmore for his 1st time. I had been 10 years earlier. Still a good place to visit. Was shocked by the amount to park , $11.00.
First time seen inperson...very impressive. you only pay for parking the rest is free. Lots of information on how built.

Even if you visit during the day (which we did so our kids could do the jr. ranger program) be sure to come back for the lighting ceremony. Once you pay to park for the day it is free to come back later. The ranger who spoke wrote a great speech, then a film was shown. The mountain was lit up, and all past and present veterans were invited to come to the stage. After the flag was lowered they all got to state their name & branch of the military. The best was having a WWII veteran in attendance! With little kiddos it made for a late night (& quite chilly), but it was worth it!

By the time we got to Mt. Rushmore, we'd been going all day, most recently spending a couple hours at Crazy Horse. Sadly, in comparison, not as impressive. In fact, as we waited at the stoplight, my son suggested we just look at it from the highway instead of paying to go in. Yes, at $11 a carload, it was cheaper than CH's $27 a carload......but MR is federally funded while CH is not. Either way, we saw it from the highway in front twice, and although it was nice, not quite the thrill the kids & I thought it would be.
Read the book saw the places! Fantastic deal. $5.00, parking validated and a great tour all in one. Felt like I was there in 1776.

Had been to wind cave a few days earlier. This is a totally different experience. The cave has very large rooms and seemed a lot more open. Several different types of cave things to see. Cave bacon, popcorn, and eggs. Tour guide was great. Lasted about 1hr 20 minutes. Everyone had a great time and worth the $$$ to see this.

Very nice place to see. Paid $11 to drive in and park. Got there 4 hours before lighting so we snapped a few photos and enjoyed the beautiful scenery. This is a very cool attraction but once you see it not much to do unless you stick around for the lighting show. We made the mistake of not eating before going here as we assumed (bad move) that the food might be good. My wife and I ordered cheese burgers for $8 a piece. The first clue they were going to be bad was seeing them take the burgers out of some little heating box. Took one bite and wanted to puke. I'm not kidding. These were not even half as good as the ones they serve at school lunches. Anyway... it sucks paying that much for food that is just crap. We are from Nebraska so we know what a good burger tastes like. I'm fine with the price if the food is good. This was not the case!

It can be disappointing if your expectations were too high. I just went for the second time with my family (kids 11, 9 and 5). I had been once when single years ago. I enjoyed it more then. My wife, 11 year old and I were a bit disappointed this time. They had not seen it before, but had higher expectations. They still thought it was interesting, but there is not a lot when comparing against other major parks (Yellowstone, Grand Canyon, Yosemite, etc.). I remembered a better nighttime presentation. This one repeated a lot from the movie. They honor veterans during the presentation. We were all still glad we went, but we did not stay long. The National Park Pass is of no use. The Park is free, but parking is not. The pass is good for admission, but not parking. That is kind of lame. We got the junior ranger books, but we did not stay long enough for our kids to complete them. We were there for under two hours as we got there just before dark so we saw the monument in daylight and lighted.

If you are at least 16 years old, and no larger than 42" in your widest point you MUST go on this tour. I have seen the Grand Canyon and it was incredible BUT the WCT at MCNP had to be the most awe inspiring and demanding thing I have ever done. It is well worth the price of admission and the personal satisfaction of lasting 6+ hours on my knees, free climbing and squeezing thru passages makes me want to do it again...... Only 14 people can go on this tour which is offered 6 days a week (1 trip a day) BOOK IT NOW...... you will not be disappointed.

went here during a week-long Utah stay. it was the off-season so didn't have to pay (but also meant having to pee in the woods due to closed restrooms). My husband tried to do the Alpine Pond Trail, but near the end the passage was blocked and he didn't get to the pond. It would have been nice if at the trail head it gave a distance-- the park brochure also doesn't mention any trail distances .

Excellent tour given by National Park Service volunteers, Jim and Howard. Park entrance was $10, we then took a free shuttle to the town of Bolivar where the tour began. For the next hour and a half we walked down hill to Harpers Ferry all the while listening to a well presented historical presentation. Then lunch in Hapers Ferry and a shuttle bus back to the park Visitors Center. Thank you Jim and Howard.

On a visit to my son and daughter-in-law I had a morning to kill. The tour of the Adams National Historical Park and the church where two Presidents and their wives are entombed was a great way to fill that time. Guides (Park Rangers?) at both sites on the trolley tour were passionate and informative about the history of the area and family. I purchased a years membership in the National Parks so only had to pay the $4 requested donation at the church for the whole experience. Buy a National Parks pass and use it close to home. It is one of the best entertainment deals going, and supports our heritage.

Another incredible example of the natural wonders of Sout Dakota. There is an entrance fee but well worth it. The Ranger-guide we had was very knowledgeable and funny (Thanks Brielly). I would NOt reccomend this tour to those who are calustrophobic because of the duration ofthe tour (about one and a half hours). If you are not claustrophobic, the by all means add this to your to-do-list in the Blackhills tour!
We hiked the longer trail. A great time was had by the whole family for only $12. Bargain of the day in many ways. One of the most enjoyable outings of the day!!!
By far the best fort we saw in the DC area. So glad we stopped by. Rolling hills and free to explore. Well worth the $5.00 car full fee.

This was my second visit to Mammoth Cave and my husband's first. We went on the Grand Avenue Tour, $24/each, which started at the Carmichael Entrance and ended at the Frozen Niagara Entrance. This tour was very fast paced, but manageable. I am not in the best shape and was 17 weeks pregnant, but I was glad I made the tour. It was very flat in the beginning and had some hills closer to the middle and end. It finished off with the Frozen Niagara formation, a great way to end our tour. After each major ascension, we were able to sit and rest for about 5-7 minutes. At this time, our guide would tell us something about that section of the cave. Our guide, Kevin, was great. He has been there for many years and is very knowledgeable as well as funny! We enjoyed his humor and fun spirit. After about a 1.5 miles (all very flat), we stopped in the Snowball Room for lunch. They had lunch you could purchase, but we brought in sandwiches and snacks. The website states that you could only bring in food in a clear backpack or ziploc bags, but apparently they've recently changed this and you can now carry in bags or backpacks. They did ask us to bring in clear water bottles, though they never checked this. For $8.50 boxed lunches, I think you got a sandwich, soup and drink. They also had bathrooms and water fountains here. We also stopped a mile later at another restroom.
Nice arranged, clean, nice personell. Although we had an beautiful pass we had to pay 11 dollar for parking.

We enjoyed it very much. We had not been there for 25 years so there were alot of changes. I would suggest you get there earlier in the day to avoid the crowds. It costs $11 per car and the sticker is usable for a year. We were impressed with the avenue of flags and the path that goes below the momument. There was also a place near the path for children to go into tepees and touch all kinds of Indian artifacts. Definately, worth the trip. We camped at Custer State Park and that also is amazing. We were unable to attend the evening light ceremony.

I've always wanted to see Mt. Rushmore and it was worth the wait. We happened to visit on a gloriously beautiful day and the first glimpse of the memorial truly took my breath away. As you take the foot tour, be sure you wear good, solid sneakers - it's a trek but worth it. Food service is limited, but snacks are available. Actually, you don't go for the food - get over it. :-) The park rangers were very helpful and the onsite exhibits were exceptionally well done. Some "complain" about the parking garage, but given the location, a garage is the best way to get everyone in. $11 per car isn't bad for all you get to see. Plan for a 2-3 hour visit - there is a lot to see in addition to our forefather's heads. Outstanding and just break taking. Enjoy!

We enjoyed this visit. You need to reserve free tickets for the home tour. This tour is free as a condition by Lincoln's heirs when the property was given away. There is a lot across the street which you pay at the pay box. If you have an America the Beautiful Pass, it discounts your parking. Tour guides great.

sliding rock was absolutely awesome. My husband and 9 yr old went while my 12 yr old and I filmed and took pictures. Couldn't talk my son into going in that cold water and my 9 yr old refused to go just 1 more time. My husband however, was all over it. Like a kid again. Loved it all. Can't beat it for $1.00 per person.

If you come to Philadelphia, get off the big bus and walk around Independence Park, the Liberty Bell, the National Constitution Center. Soak up the stories that the Park actors tell you about our country's history. It's fun - and for the most part, free! The Constitution Center costs $, but is worth it.

The drive along Haleakala Dr was beautiful and winding as expected. It was fun watching the temperature gage in our car as we went up in elevation. There is a nominal fee at the entrance to the park but it is good for several days and for some of the other parks we had intended on visiting. Once we made it to the very top, it was quite chilly and windy. We immediately put on our jackets and toured the area. There is a gift shop and clean restrooms at the top, which was a great respite from the weather. The park employees inside were very friendly and helpful. While we were there, a park ranger announced he was about to go on a small hiking tour. One of our friends was not appropriately dressed (yes, we told him to bring a jacket but he did not listen)so we unfortunately had to pass on the tour. The views are breathtaking and gorgeous. Make sure you bring your camera and video camera. It is a complete 360 degree view from above the clouds. On our way back down, we pulled over to touch the clouds (great photo op) and at some of the scenic turn offs. We also saw some of the cycling tour groups readying themselves to ride down. So if making this trip, make sure you have plenty of gas, bring a jacket, sunglasses, comfortable walking shoes and your cameras. Allow half a day for this excursion.

park: George Rogers Clark National Historical Park
text: It was a great place I learned so much. It is funny how I did not pay attention in school now I wish I did.

We have all seen pictures of Mt Rushmore. The pictures can't begin to show you how it feels to stand in front of the monument in person. Our kids participated in the junior ranger program and had a blast. We all walked the presidential loop. Lunch was very, very expensive and wasn't worth the money. The food wasn't bad, it just cost entirely too much. ($50 plus for a family with 4 small children - nothing fancy to eat. Hamburger or hot dog and a bag of chips with a coke). Overall, an awesome place to visit. The rangers are very knowledgeable and helpful. The view is incredible.

If you are in the area you can't miss this iconic National Monument. When we arrived en route for Rapid City it started to rain but the lady in the ticket kiosk said that the ticket was good for the whole year so that we could come back the following day. We did this and saw the monument in bright sunshine which made lots of difference. We walked around the trail at the base of the mountain and took lots of pictures. It is agreat feat of engineering and we thoroughly enjoyed our visit. Don't miss it.

Mount Rushmore is, no doubt, the primary objective for the vast majority of Black Hills tourists. No one should miss it. It is important. But, even though it is a national memorial and there is, therefore, no admission fee, be ready to pay substantially for your visit. Parking for an automobile has increased this year to $11 from $8 in the past. The Gift Shop prices are the highest in the Hills for popular items such as shirts, caps and baubles. The resturant, which we used to consider one of the Hill's best bargains has gone over the top with no improvement in quality. The site has instituted a "Bargain Tent" outside the main Gift Shop where all items are $5. which is truly wonderful if you are traveling with children. I hope that Tent is permanent!
Fairly cheap entry, great that it is a self guided walk so you can go at your own pace

We packed a lunch and went on a Saturday over Memorial Day weekend, which is one of the weekends that they do live re-enactments with audience participation. You cannot put pennies on the tracks anymore; however, they have a penny smash hand-crank machine inside. My children (ages 7 & 4) and various cousins (aged 8-15) were bored with the re-enactment, which is sad because it is such a historical moment in our nation's history. There are quick movies, a gift shop, and museum. There are picnic tables in the front of the building and CLEAN bathrooms with flushing toilets. There is an entrance fee, which is per carload. A must for any history buff!

My husband and I spent the afternoon walking around Lowell. We started our tour at the National Park Visitor Center, then we walked down the cobblestone roads to the New England Quilt Museum store, and from there we walked along the water canals/trolley tracks to the Boott Cotton Mills Museum. We went into this museum, which included a weave room, interactive exhibits, and video programs. After seeing the museum, we had a picnic lunch overlooking the Water Canal. In total, we spent less than $20.00 for museum tickets, lunch, and parking. We plan to go back to Lowell next year to take in the Engineering Innovation Boat Tour. This trip was stress free, easy walking distance, and low cost.
Family goes often. We bike the towpath often. We attend concerts, hikes and events. Always something fun and/or educational to see. The only national park without a fee.

This is worth a stop, just be prepared for the tourist hordes. Take the shuttle bus down to the Lower Town as there are many things to do and see. There are also several places to shop and eat within the site. I highly recommend the old-fashioned candy store for some history and tasty treats. There is a $10 fee to enter the park.

Really well organized and lovely memorial. Parking was easy even though it was busy time. The Avenue of the Flags is well done and there are tons of great picture opportunities. You should take the time to watch the movie to really understand the incredible feat this creation is. Had lunch there...not as organized I would have hoped and of course higher price than it is worth. Bathrooms were very busy and needed a bit of attention with all those people in and out. Everyone needs to experience this American landmark.

Visiting Valley Forge historical park was a real treat. While I had always known something about the revolutionary war encampment here I had no idea about the actual conditions of the soldiers. The guide on our trolley tour, Mr. Rice, was extremely knowledgeable and made the event at Valley Forge come alive for us. The costumed volunteers at one of the camp sites were entertaining and interesting. Going through some of the reconstructed huts gave us an abbreviated sense of the conditions the colonial army endured, though it was a warm sunny day as compared to the winter they went through. The Visitor Center is well staffed with park rangers. The park experience is free though you do pay extra for the trolley tour. The park has walking trails and excellent guide maps. This is a must-see for families wanting to give their children a sense of the courage and determination of those men and women who sacrificed so much for our country and our freedom.

Went to the Park Visitors Center. Paid to get in and they explained if we asked we could get a lifetime pass for the same price (we are seniors), so we did. Rode the bus to the town, but you can just go to the town directly. A lot more history than we were aware. Very interesting place to visit.

The wife is a big Lincoln buff and we took our daughter to see this place. It is basically a visitors center (admission was $3 per or $5 family), the grave of Abe's mother, the site of their cabin, a spring, and a replica working farm with live animals. There are also some hiking trails (not terribly long or difficult) which I enjoyed the best. Especially the trail with 12 stones scattered throughout, marking events in Lincoln's life (e.g. an actual stone from the White House during Lincoln's time). I found the hike very interesting! There isn't that much to see in the Visitors Center and some may balk at the entrance fee, but I found the 14 minute movie quite interesting and worth it. I was not aware of how much time Lincoln spent in Indiana and that it was during a crucial part of his growing up helping define who he was as a man. If you have young kids, since this is a National Park (this goes for all National Parks) have them participate in the Junior Ranger program. It helps make the visit a fun learning experience and when they complete the book, they get a badge. My daughter has gotten quite a few of these over the years and displays them on a vest. A nice keepsake as she gets older to remember our trips. We spent about 3 hours total there.

Although this is not the biggest park you will go to, it is very interesting. The rangers at this station make the trip fun. They are very welcoming and friendly. We watched video about the fossils and petrified red woods before we walked around the park. I think it is the best place to start so you know what you are looking at. To make it even more fun for the children, I highly recommend doing the Junior Ranger program which is free. The children have activities to complete while there after which they can earn their junior ranger badge. My kids loved it! The petrified red woods are interesting and the trail was easy. There was a wildfire nearby at our visit so several of the longer trails were closed. Currently they are having a new welcome center built so they are in a trailer, but I would not let that stop you from visiting. It made no difference to us. It is a very nice place to spend an hour or two. They also have a hut outback that opens after 1:00 where you can look at fossils under high powered microscopes which we all enjoyed looking at. The entrance fee for the park was $3 per person and children under a certain age were free.

Its a weekend trip from bay area to the land of biggest trees. We started at Friday evening and spend the night at Super8, Fresno. I will definitely recommend everyone to stay here, its really cheap but offers all the amenities generally offered by the chain B & B, specially the breakfast is good.

$6 for the car. From the Visitor Centre (with proper toilets) there is a 9 mile one-way loop with lay-bys for photos and trails. It was hot, but there was a cooling breeze. It took near enough 4 hours and we didn't hike any of the trails. You are 7000' high.
You need to establish this as your headquarters in Philly. There is a parking garage, all day is $12, you can catch the subway from here, plus there is lots to see and do just by walking around.

Well as I sat and looked at the work of art showing great presidents of the past. I was struck by how a post card or picture could not even begin to show you the beauty of our present and past. Just below me a professional photographer was snapping shot after shot. I asked him how it was going and he said exactly what I was thinking."Honestly I have gone up and down the coast and all over the west taking shots and I just can't seem to capture the feeling I get by seeing this in person". I smiled and told him I was thinking the same thing. Columns show the states first in our nation to the last. Delaware being the first and Hawaii being the last. You will have to go by to find out when your state became official. Don't miss this and Keystone is a lovely town you will want to stroll. The cost to enter I believe was $4.00 per car.

It is very impressive to see Mount Rushmore in person, and worth the $11 IF you go for the lighting at night. The lighting ceremony was a very patriotic time and well worth the time spent. It lasts around 30 minutes before the statue is lit with a ranger coming out and talking, and then a 20 minute video (weather permitting) on the history behind the presidents chosen for the monument. My suggestion is if you have young kids who are attending, make sure to bring along something for them to do if they get bored and be there early to get good seats. We hadn't realized there would be a program prior to the lighting so we were unprepared, but we got through it with 4 kids under 8 years old and it was well worth the experience. It is in fact one of my personal highlights of the trip we took through SD and WY.

If you are thinking of visiting here, read some of the reviews here, check out the Web Site and you will find some options include paying $15.00 to take the trolley tours, driving yourself and calling the phone #s posted at each stop, renting or bringing a bike or walking. Entrance to the park itself is FREE.

Sequoia Np is my fav place on earth. However, ever since I've been coming here 11 years ago, the construction on the 198 hwy has NOT yet finished and probably won't for another decade!!! They are lying when they say it will only take another year. They've been saying that to us since a decade ago!!!! They make You wait for over an hour until you can pass!!! It's a boondoggle of a government project that just keeps on sucking our tax money dry! Whenever we pass by there the workers are asleep

If you are staying on this island don't miss this site. We loved it but we left our resort at 80+ degrees and froze in the park in our shorts and tank tops. We thought about buying sweatshirts in the gift shop / welcome center but they were $50 and ugly black. Our kids loved the incredible hikes. Bring lunch, snacks and water.

Tickets are sold out early in the morning and so we wound up securing ones for 3 hours after our arrival (first available). We visited Crazy Horse memorial in between...that worked out well but of course, it is extra driving. There were too many steps for me to attempt the scenic tour but my teeneage grandson said it was the best part of our trip to South Dakota. I went on the discovery tour so I could at least get into the cave. It was okay but could be expanded to at least 3 "rooms" even with small children, etc. Don't forget to use your Senior Natl Park pass for discounts and remember to not plan to eat there. Vending machines yield terrible food.

This was one of our favorite attractions on this trip - educational, beautiful setting, and free! The ferry ride was fun, and we all enjoyed visitng the fort and listening to the guide. Word of advice - although there is no charge, seating is limited on the ferry. I believe it runs hourly from 9:30 - 4:30. The first time we went was in the afternoon, and all the tickets were already given out. We came back the next morning and had no problem getting on the next ferry.

Don't forget your parking pass ($11) is an annual one with no entrance cost. Great price for a family or group. The evening patriotic program starts at 9 pm and the lights are projected onto the monument a half hour later. We went back the next morning and ate breakfast in the cafe to see the morning light on the faces and peruse the exhibits. Worth it!

We went twice, we saw the evening show which is at 9 pm and watch the video and the lighting in the rain. It was not a heavy rain, so bring a rain coat or umbrella. We wore jeans and then the next day we went to the monument and walk the less then mile trail near the monument the weather was 65 and sunny. The area is very nice, parking is easy and once you pay the $11 fee you can use the park for a year.

It's all you'd expect and more. Go late afternoon and stay through flag-lowering and monument-lighting. It's worth it, especially if for veterans. Watched short movie inside that was really good, then nighttime ceremony includes another good movie. Ate dinner in the cafeteria which was only average at best. Presidential Trail is cool. National Parks senior citizen pass covered the admission, but not the parking fee. That's OK. I hate to resort to cliches, but this place is truly awesome.

We spent about 4 hours in the park and enjoyed the hike around Brandywine Falls but our favorite area was the Beaver Marsh. It was lovely and peaceful and we enjoyed the wildlife. The biking paths are great here along the Erie Canal so I think if you are a cyclist, this would be a great place to ride. There is not an entrance fee but there is a visitors center with a very knowledgeable ranger. Very enjoyable!
start at the visitor centre, $5 access to drive the park, watch the film at the centre, gives a good overview of what happened on the battlefield here.

We got lost getting there because you kinda can't read signs on the other side of your sign as you pass by.That part was kinda funny to us . Anyways...First of all with or with out The America the Beautiful pass it's $11 to park. When we first pulled up to the Memorial it looked so small but the more we kept on walking pass the flags to the end of the walk way it looked so big. The ice cream prices are so so for a scoop of ice cream and of course we had to get t-shirts and stuff which really wasn't to badly priced ($5) I thought hey why not. Lots of different people from all over the world are there. Which is cool! It's Really busy!

One of the highlights of our trip, its actually free to enter, you just need to pay $11 to park. Get there early, to avoid queues, we got in at 10:00 and had the place to ourselves for a while. The video is interesting, and the views of the heads are stunning. Do the presidential trail as you get many different views and also visit the hut at the bottom of the trail, it has the original mock ups, and alot of information.

It took us awhile to find this place in Quincy, MA, due to unclear, or hidden, signs, so by the time you find it and then find a place to park you are a little frustrated. After we got to the Visitor's Center, the Park Ranger was terrific. He first validated our parking ticket and then set us up on the next tour, which was on a trolley. We saw birth homes for both John Adams and John Quincy Adams. These were just 2 houses sitting on a corner with no signs to tell anyone what they are. We then were taken to a home that held 4 generations of John Adam's family. During the last part of the tour in the library, we were crammed into a small space with lots of people and neither of us could move. It made this part of the tour painful and very uncomfortable for both my husband and me. The park rangers gave the tours and I would have prefered a tour with more information given on the family and less on the artifacts in the homes. I realized my lack of information on this family and wanted a book to tell me more about their lives. One of the rangers in the visitor's center helped me choose some books to buy. Overall, this was a good experience and helps visitors learn about this important part of our country's history. I would recommend it to anyone. If you are 62, or older, get a park pass for $10 and thereafter every visit to a National Park will be free of charge.

I had a hard time deciding what cave to do. Everyone said Wind and Jewel are so different, but either one is a sure bet. We all really liked it! My husband said the tour was a little slow for him, but my teens did not complain. The guide was friendly, informative and patient as we had a group of Girl Scouts that were distracting. The nailhead formations were very cool and filled the cave. The most variety of rocks was in the formation room. We were able to be on two levels of the cave. The was an small area that had some of the box work that is described in the wind cave, so we got a little sampling of that. The tour started with going to 17 stories in an elevator first and then continued to walk down stairs and pathways. I didn't feel claustrophobic at all. But then I usually don't have a problem with that either. We called in advance for tickets like the reviews and NPS.com website suggested. (pay in advance too.) We got the scenic tour which took about an 1-1/2. When I picked up the tickets for the 1:20 tour, I over heard the Ranger say there next available tour was at 3:00. You can call 7 days in advance if you want too, but I think a one or two days would be fine. At least for June when it's a little less busy. Bring a sweatshirt because it's a consistent 49 degrees in the caves. We had just been horseback riding and had jeans on, so that worked out well. Most people had shorts and a sweatshirt. We brought fixings for lunch sandwiches and ate them on the shaded picnic tables. There where several around the parking lot.

park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park
text: Carved out by glaciers 13,000 years ago the Great Falls are 77' high and a wonderous natural phenomenon. The Lenape Native Americans first made use of the fall and later the Dutch in the 1690's. By 1793 the falls was used to develop mill works, locomoter works, and the Colt Revolver. All this history and more can be learned at the visitor center located adjacent to the falls or by visiting the Paterson Museum. The best views and photography can be had on the foot bridge over the falls, Haines Overlook Park on the south or Mary Ellen Kramer Park on the north. As of this date the National Park System has not developed the Great Falls area or Historic district so self-guided tours and free admission exist. The downside is that the Great Falls are in a troubled neighborhood. Once federal money is pumped into the park things should improve.

Why is this National Memorial not free to visit. After all we got the Alakian Hwy opened to all for free. The Blue Ridge Parkway was only given to the people if it was FREE. The memorial itself was worth the visit but not the payment of a fee for parking

It was our first beach trip with our 11 month old son, so we wanted to make sure it was a clean beach, not overly crowded, and comfortable to stay at. It only took us about 45 minutes from Queens, and we left early so that was great! Very easy to get to and very family friendly. There were visible lifeguards on duty, two on each bench. Flags everywhere letting visitors know where to swim, and just felt so much safer then other beaches, even police vehicles drove up a couple times. It was clean, the people that were there were clearly there to relax, and the service area for food and restrooms was convenient. Will definitely start going here vs. the other options for NY. By 5pm the winds changed, umbrellas starting flying off everywhere, and the water came up to our area. We had enough time to pack up and move farther back, but would have been nice to know! $10 parking fee.

At first, we were shocked at the $11 parking fee, but then we discovered that there was no admission fee. Our visit was also damped by a downpour, which limited our time at the site (we didn't do any of the hikes). The cafeteria food was ok. The presidential faces monument is an artistic achievement. There is also a museum.

Access to Mt Rushmore National Park is free tho' you have to pay for parking. You could spend several hours here taking your time exploring the trails and going to the Museum which has lots of interesting artifacts and movie clips about the making of the site etc.
Drive the Encampment Tour... worth it. Lots of joggers and cyclists around. Nat'l Parks are America's hidden treasure...visit them when you can! (Annual Pass is a huge plus)

I took a day long tour which include Rainbow Falls and Volcano National Park. I'm from the east coast, so I've never been so close to the core of a Volcano. Be warned that Kilauea is not producing lava, but lots of sulfur. So if you have any breathing problem bring a mask and beware of the wind. The guide warned us to pay attention, if the wind changed. There is a museum and several viewing areas along the rim drive through the park. One group hiked down to one of the craters which looked really cool. I did not have the stamina.You can walk through a section of the Thurston Lava tube which is 26 miles long - that was awesome in itself.

The entrance is free but the parking is $11. Pull up to the entrance and ask if you can turn around. On the way out you can get a great view and pictures. I dont recommend getting out of your car since there is nowhere to pull off. But if theres no traffic you can get away with a few good pictures. I did.

It's free, but there is a two dollar parking charge. They have restored the whole block you can stroll around and see the inside of three houses. The Lincoln house requires a guided tour. Very pleasant.

We were able to view it both at night and during daylight. We weren't able to attend the lighting ceremony because it was cancelled due to very bad weather. We enjoyed both times of day. The entire facility is well done with a very patriotic feeling and the services that were provided. $11 parking fee but we didn't mind at all to help maintain such a nice place. The boardwalks with different views of the monument were great, they take guests around to different views of it. We enjoyed the videos and museum exhibits very much and spent quite a bit of time enjoying the history behind building the monument. We were there on a Saturday night and Sunday morning in early June and didn't find the crowds to be an issue at all. Cafeteria with typical options, there was also an outdoor grill set up with burgers and dogs. Overall we are very glad we made the stop.

We had not planned to stop here before the owner of our motel in Monticello told us not to miss it. We arrived before the park opened and the rangers actually opened the Visitor’s Center early for us! We used our Senior National Park Pass so there was no entrance fee. The rangers were very friendly and helpful and actually gave us tips for our visit to Monument Valley and other places. We had been to Arches National Park the day before and wondered about the difference between arches and bridges. Natural bridges are formed by the erosive action of moving water. Arches are formed by other erosive actions such as frost action and seeping moisture.

Lowell is where America's industrial revolution started. It became a world leader in mass producing textiles - especially cotton textiles - starting in the 1820s. Lowell's downtown still has many remnants from that time, though the mills have all shut down as the textile industry shifted first to the south and then to Asia. We found the National Historical Park visitor center and the sites they operate around the downtown to be a really good way get a feel for how Lowell grew and changed over time and why it is important to US history. It was so well done that even our children thought it was a great visit. The best thing to see is the Boots mill where they have a restored mill with a couple of hundred looms - some of which are operating. The noise and speed of these big looms is almost overwhelming. They provide free ear plugs. The boarding house and canal locks are also good. The visitor center gives you a map to use to follow the path between the sites. It is a fairly short walk. The park offers a good overview movie at the visitor center. You can sign up there for several ranger lead walks, including one via a canal boat and another on a restored trolley. The visitor center has a gated parking lot, but parking is free. Just bring your ticket to the visitor center and the rangers will validate it. The park was not busy the day we visited. It deserves to have more visitors.
Enjoyed the tour. Make sure you get tickets ahead of time so you can choose your time for tour. Only $1.50 a ticket. http://www.nps.gov/inde/planyourvisit/feesandreservations.htm

Drove to the national park from Kailua-Kona. Despite that fact that it was either drizzling or lightly raining the entire time we were there, it was awesome!!! BUY CHEAP RAIN PONCHOS IN THE CAMPING SECTION OF WALMART and keep them with you on your journey to the park!! Wear sturdy shoes or hiking boots. DO stop at the visitors center...there are park rangers there who will give you suggestions and a map based on your desired time in the park. NO lava, but plenty of steam!!! I was pleasantly surprised to discover an Army camp within the park... as my husband is active duty, we were able to eat in their cafe (at the camp bowling lanes)... Never saw the cashier ask for military ID, so I don't know if civilians could get away with eating there.... a phone call in advance could answer that. Otherwise, pack a lunch: not much 'civilization' out that way!!!

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: Great tour...free ranch tour, audio cd guide, and the you pay a couple of bucks per adult for a tour of the Texas white house. Great tour, they have opened a cople of new rooms, worth your time.

First, I feel the parking fee is a little high. Second, should you go during the day save your money for the customer appreciation bargain souvenir table. For $5 you can purchase great t-shirts, ball caps, recycled shopping bags, coffee mugs, & other items.
Independence NHP is very good. I recommend the guided tour of Indep. Hall. Can get tix online before hand for a very small fee. visit the national park website for the link.

A must see historic attraction in the Black Hills of South Dakota. Great for photos & interesting historic information. Easy parking for a fee, but no charge for the attractions. A fun drive to Mt. Rushmore and then you can continue on thru the Black Hills for even more fun & history. A must see when in the area along with much more in the South Dakota area.

We stayed in Custer during the week of June 25th and some of the days were getting a little warm so we picked the coolest day to visit Mount Rushmore. One thing I would recommend is to go early and have breakfast with the Presidents at the Carvers Restautant. They have an open air deck and you can sit outside & look straight up at the Presidents while you eat. When we were there, we were the only ones sitting outside and it was a beautiful morning. You get a really great breakfast for $5.99 (The Monumental Breakfast - eggs, bacon, sausage & gravy and potatoes) - can't beat this deal and it was good! My other tip is right inside the entrance you can rent a hand held device for $5 and hear all of the background information as you walk the Presidential Trail. Wow, this is really an awe enspiring sight to see. I was there as a child and I thoroughly enjoyed going back!!

With navigation we found the visitors center difficult to find. We arrived just after 3:00 on a Saturday so we bought tickets for the last trolley tour at 4:00 then asked for a place to have a late lunch. We were told the nearby snack shop closed at 2:00 so we were directed to a small place not owned by the park behind the nearby Washington Memorial Chapel. It was cute, full of souvenirs and home made goodies. The lady there was happy to tell us about the church as we ate our hot dogs. We made it back just in time to hear a man speaking about events in Valley Forge, much of which I had no idea. It was very educational. There are many displays in the visitors center which we didn't have much time to look at. The tour was great, there was even men dressed in period clothing who gave a gun demonstration. Very interesting. I took many pictures I will try to post later. I would say the tour was very much worth the price of $15. But i would only reccommend it for older children since there is alot of sitting and listening and no seat belts. It was a great day, but next time we will be sure to go earlier, eat before we go or pack a nice lunch, there are plenty of places for a picnic. We plan to go back in the fall when the scenery will most surely be breathtaking. Visit their website for info and coupons before you go! The park is free, shuttles are free too if you don't feel up to the tour.

Being a history buff I could not wait to finally take a tour of the homes of our 2nd and 6th president John Adams. We took a two hour tour of three of the home which was so informative. Peacefield was fabulous as the house is filled with original items of the Adams family. Would recommend this to anyone!! Might be a little long for younger children so I would wait till they are older. With so much original items in last home you have to be to careful to take little ones in. Price could not be beat. It was hard to find visitors center in Quincy even with the signs that were up.

Stayed in Panguitch Lake and stopped at Cedar Breaks on the advice of a friend- well worth it- the wildflowers were spectacular- from Aspen bluebells to white columbine. Saw no flowers in or near Bryce or Zion. The park rangers have a telescope set up so you can see the arch you might otherwise miss in the overwhelming beauty of the canyon. Unlike Bryce and Zion, which were crowded, even on the 4th of July there were always parking spots available at the overlooks at Cedar Breaks. If pressed for time, you can see a lot in an hour. At 10,000 feet, the cool air was a refeshing change from the heat of the other parks. Coming from the East Coast, the drive down to Cedar Creek was a bit of a white knuckle ride- would not attempt it in off weather but the views were literally breathtaking. If you're going to do several parks, buy the annual National Park Service pass for $80, which also gets you into national monuments like Cedar Breaks.

My mom was in elementary school as the monument was being finished, and she has always wanted to see it. We took a road trip in October, and thoroughly enjoyed the monument, the museum detailing it's history, and the really beautiful way the park was designed to feature the monument. Due to the cooler temps at that time of year, my elderly mom was not up for the Presidential Trail. Flash forward 9 months, and off I went again with my husband, adult children and their families, which includes a 9 yr. old. We all enjoyed the same things I had seen before, but added the Trail, which, as others mention, is a must see. There are some really wonderful views from lower vantage points, but do pay attention to the 'level of difficulty' signs, if you are typically sedentary. There are at least 2, and the "strenuous" trail is NOT difficult at all if you are in moderate shape, there are lots of stairs. The gift shop is LARGE and has something for every budget and taste. My mom and arrived at the park following the hwy from Custer City, my family and I entered from the Needles/Wind Cave area of Custer State Park taking Hwy 87. If you have the chance, choose the second route, it is SPECTACULAR, and you will get amazing glimpses of the monument before you arrive.

Mount Rushmore has been on my "bucket list" for many years and seeing this impressive sculpture on the mountain was well worth it! Plan to spend at least 2 hours to see everything. Take in the "Sculpture's Studio" which has detailed information about how the busts were carved. The museum has many interesting photos, actual artifacts - drills, bonsun seats, etc that were used in the actual carving. There is a nice restaurant and ice cream shop with plenty of indoor seating. Don't miss the bookstore which has many historical books, children's books and great postcard selection. We went back for the lighting ceremony at 9 pm and I was slightly disappointed. After watching a video presentation, all they do is shine a light on the monument faces and that's it. I expected something a little more flashy. Fee for parking is $11 but no entrance fee is charged.

As a kid, I was always curious about this place, so far away. I Am glad I was able to finally see it in person. It was all I believed it would be and more. I think the 11 dollar fee for parking is acceptable, it is good for the year ( i doubt we will get back again by Dec though).

The entrance fee of $10 for 7 days any day any time best value for money in any resort. Good information centre very helpful staff, maps and walking routes available. Access to the craters very good some are quite a walk but worth while.
The park fee is very reasonable at $10 a car. Many many stops and parking for picture taking. The weather on July 7 was 72 degrees while the metro areas nearby were 99 degrees or more!

Having grown up while spending many summer vacations camping in the SW USA, I have always loved SW Colorado. The San Juan National Forest and the Million Dollar Highway are my favorites of the region! I love to revisit the area and do so at every opportunity that I have!

This is a site of important historical significance to the settling of the west. They have several restored buildings that have been filled with period pieces. There are several foundations being preserved as well. The grounds are well maintained. On the 4th of July they throw quite presentation with lots of games with prizes for the children and adults, period actors and historical presentations. The presenter for the Plains Indians did a wonderful job, and on the 4th the fee is waived. I highly recommend bringing the family on the 4th of July to this great piece of history, though is is worth seeing at any time.

You have to take the tour of the home if you’re in town for all the other Lincoln stuff. Free admission (at least was when we visited) but you do still have to go to the Visitor center and get tickets for a specific time – but worth it. Hard to imagine you’re walking thru that history, wonder how much of the site is actually re-built from the ground up as probably thousands of folks walk thru it annually, and yet the floors and stairs don’t creek and yet my home does?! Still, worth it.
Nothing to dislike. Had $$$ to spend and they provide the absolute best there is to offer. Eddie is the best guide I've ever encountered! Great place!!!!

These sand dunes are amazing. Definitely worth it to buy a sled but much harder and you don't go as fast as sledding on snow. Sleds must be returned by 7 to get $5 buy back at gift shop. It is quite the workout to walk up the sand dunes.

Visited White Sands today with my husband and 10 year old son. We went to slide down the sand dunes. We went to the gift shop and got our plastic saucers and don't forget the wax (you go down alot faster). Also don't forget to pick up water if you don't have any. The air is very dry and it is a good workout to go up and down the hill! We spend about 1 hour and 30 minutes. You will need more time if you want to walk the trails. If you are in the area I would recommend that you stop by. The cost is $3.00 per adult to enter the park.

The Evening Canal tour combines the history of Lowell's historic water-powered mills with a refreshing ride on the Merrimack River. They have preserved the historic flood gate (which has only been dropped to prevent massive flooding 2 times) and the locks to go through passing from canal to river. The guide mentioned that they are starting a bike tour of native american sites in the area, and a new ranger is starting to give bird-watching canal tours. A very nice way to spend the evening (they also have them during the day). $8 per person.
Well done - so much history! Liberty Bell is great and even if you don't pay for the tour of Independence Hall, you still get a good feel for the area
Been here several times before..I disliked having to pay for parking. Its rather high. Learn something new each time I visit. Was neat to see Abraham Lincoln and Ted Roosevelt impersonators there!
I was blown away at the size of the carving! The memorial(no fee) and convenient parking ($11)
$10 bucks gets your car load in. 32 mile loop through some great scenery. You have a chance to see wild horses and buffalo. Great hiking spots, some as short as a 1/3 of a mile.

Capitol Reef doenst seem to be the reason many go to Utah with their other high profile amazing National Parks, but that shouldnt mean it should be ignored either. We only had time for about a day here but it was a special visit completely different from every other park we visited. A real historic feel has been preserved here throughout the years. Take the scenic drive for 5 bucks (you dont even need to pay the park entrance fee for this) and then drive up the capitol gorge and do a few hikes from there. Also some awesome buildings around the visitors center and other historic sites as you are enter the parks land are worth visiting.
This is a National Park, therefore for you seniors out there you buy the lifetime pass and you are good to go.

Before our recent trip to Crater Lake I tried to find reviews online to determine if the boat tour was worth the effort and expense (adults $32, kids $22). I couldn't find much info, so I decided to add my own here now that we did it. Crater Lake itself is an amazing natural wonder of course, but the boat tour itself is a mixed bag. Overall, I'd rate it a 6 on scale of 1 to 10. Here's what you need to know.

If you really want to enjoy all that Pisgah National Park has to offer I strongly suggest you stay at the Mount Pisgah Campground off of the Blue Ridge Parkway. It is just across from the Pisgah Inn were you can get a delicious meal. If you like high elevation and you really like peace and quiet then I suggest you stay at Mount Pisgah Campground. It is by far nicer than any campground that we have seen in the Great Smokies National Park or on the Blue Ridge Parkway. If you are a hiker then you got to hike the 1.5 mile trail to Mount Pisgah where Channel 13 TV tower is located, The trial is a little streunous at the end but we did see people from ages 4 to 70 up at the obervation tower. The view from the top of Mount Pisgah is incredible and worth the hike. Buck Springs trail is another trail worth checking out! Mr. Vanderbilt of the Biltmore House had a hunting lodge there in the early 1900's. We also went to the Crade of Forestry and were skeptical of the $5 per person fee but we spent the day there and thoroughly enjoyed it. You will learn so much about the history of forestry at the Cradle of Forestry. You will find plenty of things to do in Pisgah National Forest!

This is not an all-day adventure - not THAT much to do here. But gazing upon the carving in Mount Rushmore is truly a moving experience and well worth the time and cost to see it. I didn't think much of it as a kid, but as an adult it makes a real impact. Mount Rushmore makes you feel proud to be an American - you just feel good being there!

Well worth the visit, and for $11 per car (valid for the year) you cannot complain about the price. Also worth going back for the nightly light festival when the sculptures are illuminated, (this festival is a highly patriotic affair, so if you have a problem with that then it's not for you). We loved it!

I was on the last days on june 2012 and almost all the trails were closed. We just see the lake of the park. It was beautiful.We stay in the hotel of diamond lake, 30 minutes aprox. away from the entrance of the park. The cost for a room for two person was US$100. I was an average hotel with a nice view. Close by there is road with very nice waterfall. you find brochure in the park
house is in remarkable shape, and a great tour given by the national park ranger. a small fee for parking, but house is free. also see the two excellent short films they show in the visitor center

We visited White Sands in July and had a great time. I was traveling with my husband and 2 girls (aged 9 and 12). Everyone loved it. We bought the sleds from the gift shop (expect to pay $15 for a round plastic sled). They do have a buyback program, too. Best to bring your own.

The monument is free but there is an $11.00 parking fee. The visitors center is very informative and interesting. Make sure to catch the short documentary on the monument's construction. The amphitheater and porch behind it provide an unobstructed view.

This should be on everyone's "Bucket List!" One of the prettiest places I've ever been. Breathtaking views. Take a picnic and stop at one of the viewing areas to soak in the scenery. If you have time and want to spend the extra $40, take the boat tour around the lake. We did not have time this trip but I'd love to do that if we go again. The east side was not open all the way, but you can still see all of the lake from the viewing areas along the west. Don't miss this one!

We left Hurricane, Utah and it was 106 degrees and got to Cedar Breaks and it was 60 degrees which was a nice relief. The parks if very small but scenic, first stop should be the visitors center to pay your entrance fee and get your first view where you can get some great photos or do the junior ranger program for your little ones. Next there are two trails in the park, we did the Alpine Pond Trail which provided some great views of the canyon and really good views of the interior of the Forrest and windflowers. Just remember you are over 10,000 feet and it takes your breath away if you're not used to it. Overall the park is excellent, the rangers are great and helpful, take the time to check it out.
We live in El Paso and the drive to White Sands makes for a perfect day trip. We love the covered picnic areas. Great deal for $6!!!

We rode our bikes through the park and had a blast! The views are beautiful and the staff was friendly. We paid $3 a person and this enabled us to come back for the next 6 days if we wanted to. Well worth it! Bring a picnic lunch.
We took a canal tour, part trolley and part boat. Interesting history of the town and its part in the industrial revolution. Need to reserve in advance. $8.00 each

You cannot go to the Black Hills without stopping at Mount Rushmore. It is amazing. Nice museum with information on the making of president's heads. Worth the stop. Free, but fee to park (I believe it was $11 this year.)

The monument is an amazing thing to see and the views available inside are definitely worth seeing. There is a fee to park but once you walk up you are happy you paid. The view from the front is great, but the pretty simple walkway allows you to see the monument from different vantage points. The sculptor's studio and museum were definitely worth checking out to see how and why it was made. We had our dogs with us and though dogs are not allowed inside, they do have pet areas in the parking lot for them to get out and you can see the monument from those, however I would recommend finding a way to go inside to see the views because it is not the same from the parking lot (we took turns going inside).

A must-see for a trip to Boston! Quincy is easily accessible via the T (red line), and the tour begins across from the station. It's only $5 for adults, kids 16 and under free, and free for National Parks passholders. The 2 hour tour takes you by trolley to the birthplaces of John and John Quincy Adams and the post-presidential Adams mansion (with the 1st Presidential Library) and is conducted by extremely knowledgeable guides (ours were Bob and Dennis - both terrific!)

I wanted to see the Independence Hall, so I went to the visitor centre nearby - only to be told that I needed to go to the other visitor centre (beyond the building housing the Liberty Bell) to get a ticket. When I got there, all the tickets for the day had sold out! You can walk in the park without a ticket, having passed through the security checkpoint, and that's a very pleasant thing to do on a hot day, but it was rather disappointing not to get inside. The queue for the Liberty Bell was very long and lacking in shelter from the sun - there was even a shorter queue just to look through the window! Clearly (as the review below says) timing is important.

The 4 carved presidents are a must-see for any vacation to the north country, that is for sure. But, go here before you go to Crazy Horse. My wife and I went to Crazy Horse and then traveled to Mt. Rushmore... and we were not blown away... and we felt guilty about it. Take the audio tour if you want to know more about the making of the monument. The restaurant had decent food, but prices were high- I had a ham and cheese sandwich, a bag of chips, and a water, my wife had a salad and a water, and our bill for lunch was $28. My suggestion: go to Mt. Rushmore early in the morning, enjoy an hour with the presidents, then leave and eat lunch elsewhere. In the afternoon go see Crazy Horse to really get your socks knocked off!

We had a beautiful drive to Mt Rushmore the mountains were beautiful. It cost me $12 for my family to park and go into the monument. Parking was unbelievably convenient for accessing the monument. Inside everything was absolutely top drawer: clean, immaculately maintained, there was a real sense of reverence and the staff were extremely nice and polite. A truly great experience.

It could have been the long drive leading to our visit or the history lessons at every turn but the family didn't exactly enjoy the visit. New parking structure is paid for by a parking fee not covered by Golden Eagle Pass. The "light show" is not, it is a monument lighting show with a history lesson leading up to it.

It was nice to see the Lincoln home and get a formal tour. Also took a tour of the neighborhood. Be aware that the home requires a ticket--and the tour is at a specific time. The best part--it's free!

Went early and walked around trails taking pictures at various locations. Excellent ranger talk on history and tools used in making Mount Rushmore. Had lunch in outdoor lunch shack. Good buffalo burgers. Went into Keystone for afternoon activities and back to Mount Rushmore after dinner for evening program. No fee to get in but you pay for parking which is good for at least as long as we were going to be in South Dakota which was a week. The evening program is led by a ranger and it is very good. At the end of the program Mount Rushmore is lit up in floodlights. Take your tripod for good night shots.

The park is sprawled over several buildings in the historic town of Harpers Ferry. In fact, the National Park Service has taken over the whole lower part of the town, beautifully preserving many old shops and business buildings that stood just before the Civil War. We enjoyed seeing the story of John Brown, which is told in three rooms of one of the larger buildings. But we also enjoyed the effort to recreate the dry goods store and the rifle manufacturing operation that existed back in the mid-19th Century, when the Industrial Revolution was transforming lives and changing the way that goods were made and delivered. There is no admission charge.

good experience and reservations can be made in advance for campsites and pavilions at Buffalo Point, for group campsites at Tyler Bend and Erbie, and for pavilions at Tyler Bend, Ozark and Lost Valley by calling (877) 444-6777 or on line at www.Recreation.gov . A fee will be charged for handling reservations through Recreation.gov.

While vacationing in Vernal, my family went to the Dinosaur National Monument because it's one of the few things to do in Vernal. I wasn't overly impressed but that might be because I'm not a huge fan of dinosaurs. We had to pay a $10 fee to enter the park.
Fee: $11 parking fee - a national park pass does not circumvent this fee

Crater Lake National Park is THE National Park in Oregon. You can stay and relax at the lodge for an amazing experience if you book well in advance, or you can camp in the park. (We camped.) But don't be afraid to just make it a day trip. It is definitely possible as a day trip from Bend, Grants Pass or the like. Even transiting on I-5, taking a few extra hours out of your route to see the lake is worth it. While the full loop is nice, you can get a lot just by driving the north-south route that borders the lake. Visit the lodge area, and a few turnouts, then be on your way as you need. As well, if you have the time, schedule and take the lake boat tour. It is about 2 hours on a boat, touring around the lake and seeing things you cannot see from the crater wall. The hike to the boat is not easy - 1.1 miles, 700+ feet elevation. Think of climbing the stairs in a 65 story building. But take it slow if you need to. But if you do have the time, there is a lot to be seen on trials and it would be easy to spend several days soaking up the place. Any time the road to the lodge is open, it is worth seeing.

Grand Tetons are adjacent to Yellowstone and your entry pass works for both locations. Jenny Lake is beautiful. Find the stop offs that over looking the lake and the pictures you take look fake!!! Fresh air, sight seeing, wildlife are all areound. Just beautiful!

Went to Rushmore and had expectations that I was going to be dissappointed. We first rushed there to get there for the night lighting as we heard how great it was, and that's where we were dissappointed, as we found it overrated. Almost did not go back the next day, but we did, and really enjoyed it, as it exceeded our expectations. Went on brief Ranger walk and Artist studio, both worth the time. Daughers of 8, 10 and 14 really enjoyed it. (Regarding people "belly aching" about $11 dollar parking, don't listen to them, as its only $11-get over it)

We travelled across country to visit Mt. Rushmore and it did not dissapoint us. To view such a magnificent sight is just wonderous. We also came back the next night to view the evening lighting ceremony. It will stir your patriotic juices. The only thing confusing, is that we have visited Washington, DC on 5 separate occasions and always found all the sights, the Smithsonians, the monuments, etcetera to all be free. Why the parking charge to see a national monument, when it it is to be free to view the monument? Just another way to sneak one past us?
