Only $10 to get in for the whole year! Great value and very educational. I wouldn't recommend this for younger children though. My five year old was NOT impressed.

With this being a national park, there is a lot of land that is a part of it with sights that are both natural and man-made. The first thing to do on the visit is to pay $10 at the entrance if you are arriving by car ($5 per person arriving by foot or bicycle) and from there, you're free to walk around the park. There are a lot of different types of attractions within this one park, and it is a must-see for many different types of travelers, whether it be hikers (any nature-oriented travelers really), history buffs, or travelers looking for leisure. My visit primarily focused on historical sights in the town, although I also enjoyed some nice scenic views, and I recommend visiting Jefferson's Rock for the beautiful view of the hills (but prepare to walk up a LOT of steps!).

Many of the destinations on this part are Mammoth cave tours or part of tours. The Historic Tour takes groups of up to 120. It was difficult to hear the guides due to people being rude. There are stairs on this one and the website gives you details of tours and making reservations in advanced. The trog tour for 8-12 years old was great for my son. He talked and talked and new everything when we took our Historic tour. For only 1$ more than historic tour, you can take River Styx tour MAX of 40 people and it includes the whole Historic tour plus a bit more. Did I mention only 40 people. Make reservations in advanced or it may be full for you. Oh yeah, the Trog and River Styx leave early morning. The Historic is at different times all day. There are othere tours. Fat man's Misery, bottemless pits, and Tall man's Agony are on Historic tour. The Starlight chamber tour is easier walking it leaves at 6:30 at night 40 people using laterns. You see some of Historic but you see the chamber, wedding chamber, and some other things. The rangers are knowledgable. If you can do it take the tours with less people it is easier to hear the history if you care about that stuff. Wonderful to take my kids to where I went as a kid.

The tour is an hour long - twice the length of any other mansion tour in Natchez. If you're fortunate enough to get Barney as your guide you're in for a real treat. The time just flies by as he regales you with the history of the mansion. The admission fee is a little less than the other mansions. If you plan on seeing four mansions, use the 3 mansion ticket package on the more expensive mansions (available at the visitor's center). This mansion should definitely be on your list of must see mansions.
We paid $12 each for going through the museums and taking a 90 minute canal tour by boat. Very informative, well informed rangers, great museums. Well worth it!

We went twice. Once in the day time and once to watch the lighting. Your parking pass is good all year so why not come back. Just skip the whole lighting ceremony. It's not worth it. Yes, seeing the vets come up on stage and saying who they are/where they're from is nice but overall.. you get the same info of the movie from a free Ranger tour. Just stop by a half hour after the show to see the lit monument against a pitch black sky.

This was our second trip to Mount Rushmore. I must say I felt the same awe seeing it again this time around as I did the first time. We decided to see it at night and arrived around 8:30 for the 9:00 lighting ceremony. Many others arrive for this as well, so plan ahead if you attend to see this. We didn't get there early enough to get a seat at the auditorium for the ceremony. The experience at night would be best if you get a seat to see the movie that accompanies the speaker. We did not and it made the speech harder to follow without seeing the screen, especially for younger children like our 5 year old. While it was nice to see the mountain at night, the detail of the faces is better appreciated by day. We came back the next day to take it all in completely. The walk at the base of the mountain is easy and gets you up a bit closer. Overall, its worth the stop, especially for only $11 for a year, and for me makes me feel all the more American. Its an American Icon that shouldn't be missed if in the area.

We did a day trip from Maui. Booked flights and a rental car myself and saved >50% over the cost of an organized tour. Well worth the trip! Steam vents, lava tube, chain of craters road, amazine crasing waves at the end of that road. Spectacular. Museum is very nice too. Nice educational and scenic trip for the family. Memorable.

While finishing our trip from Yellowstone we decided to drive through the Tetons. It was the best decision we took and we will never regret that. The park pass for YNP also works for Grand Tetons. The views are awesome with many overlook points for taking pictures. We just wish we had some more time to spend here.

Don't pass up the grand Tetons this is just as good as Yellowsnow take the road to Teton Village to grand Tetons it's a narrow road right in the wilderness and that is a drive not to be messed a wonderful park as good as Yellowstone lots of wildlife up close

We booked two tours: Grand Avenue a 4.5 mile, 4.5 hour tour that is very strenuous, many steep hills, some spaces that are not wide, but are tall, other spaces that are very wide, lots of steps. Guides did an excellent job of telling all participants of what to expect, when breaks would occur, what could go in the cave, what could come out, advised to consider personal health problems or limitations if they exist, and so on. Guides are very knowledgeable and share a lot of information. Lunch is available on this tour (extra charge) and was sufficient. There are two bathroom breaks on this tour. There are breaks at the top of steep ascents. The tour was fascinating and we saw amazing sights everywhere. This is a must if you are able and want a good long tour. Tour begins almost mid-way in the cave system and ends at Frozen Niagara. The second tour we booked was the River Styx tour. It is 2.5 miles long, 2.5 hours, does not include food options or bathroom breaks. It begins at the Historic Entrance of the caves, enters massive chambers, then into more narrow spaces that are not as tall as Grand Ave. tour. Tour meanders down to the underground river, finishes by exiting near Mammoth Tower (lots of steps). This tour is not as strenuous as the Grand Avenue tour, but there are plenty of steps and some hills. Both were fantastic and gave us a great view of most of the cave system. The River Styx tour focuses on the geology of the cave.

My husband and I had been here about 12 years ago. For some reason we thought there was more to see. This time we did the presidential train and went into the museum. It took us about 3 hours to get through the entire thing. One thing we thought was cool was that they only charge for parking $11 for a car. The tag is good for the rest of the year. This allowed us to come back on a different day and watch the night time lighting and program.
Can't beat it for the price. You all know what it is...the price is $11 for your car for the year! Everybody should see it once!

I went to beautiful and scenic crater lake to camp in June. It was very sunny but the temperature was just above freezing and the campground had three feet of snow, and i arrived at 830pm, so I decided not to camp and stayed in the $170 (overpriced, but it is a national park and someone has to pay to plow the roads) manassas village lodge. It was clean and very basic with no tv, radio, coffee, candy, water, magazines, or anything to suggest hospitality or comfort. Like a large outhouse with a bed in it. There was a ticking baseboard heater that was welcome on the cool evening in June that i stayed there. Unfortunately the smoke detector outside the room beeped and alarmed every 5 minutes all night, and i was unarmed. I decided to walk to the beautiful log cabin village restaurant for breakfast as a treat to start my day. I ordered a poached egg and it came on a white plate, all alone, cold and slimey and raw. After I gagged that down I ordered a nice warm "home made" cinnamon bun from the huge open gourmet kitchen that i could see and hear was staffed by a whole line of blue ribbon chefs. Over the banter of the line chefs and orders I heard the beeping of a microwave oven, but tried to remain optimistic. Eventually a plate arrived bearing a microwaved "heat and eat" premade bun that was dry outside, cold an dgoopy inside, and coated with weepy white icing from a tube. I was saddened, but even more so when I got my bill and saw the bun alone was $7. Tv chef ramsay would have asked them to turn in their aprons.
I paid the $1.50 for the reserved tickets for the tours. The visitor center was air conditioned and was a welcome relief from the heat.

While the masses went to Sequoia and Yosemite, our family headed straight for Kings Canyon this past July 4th weekend. All of the campgrounds were open and all had spaces available. We chose one in Moraine, the "overflow" campground and it was quite pleasant. Although we had neighbors we never felt crowded. The river was nearby, and after a short drive we found plenty of firewood. We spent a day in Sequoia looking at the big trees and doing the Crystal Cave tour (highly recommended), the rest of the time we were in Kings Canyon. The only drawback is the expense of buying ice to keep your beer cold!

We spent 2 weeks in Colorado and only 2 nights in Black Canyon. It wasn't enough time! But there aren't any showers!!! Just outside of Montrose there is a truck stop with cheap and CLEAN showers. Only about 15 minutes away.

The El Morro National Monument is a hidden treasure in New Mexico. In the dessert as you are driving along there are rock outcroppings interspersed throughout that jut out from the ground, yet none can equal El Morro. My husband said that the sheer sandstone cliffs at El Morro reminded me him of the glacial carved rock walls from Yosemite, although they are a totally different color. While visiting El Morro we learned that it had a constant and reliable source of water around the base of it which made it a very popular watering hole. Back in the day of horse and foot travel, El Morro's reliable water source was a Godsend. On El Morro's walls Ancestral Puebloans, Spanish, and American travelers carved their signatures, dates, messages and petroglyphs; ancient graffiti so to speak. The1/2 mile trail to the base of El Morro is paved and handicap accessible and reaches the lovely water pool. The 2 mile loop trail over the top of El Morro is well maintained, well marked and well worth the little extra time it takes to do it. The museum is free and the self-guided tour on the trails is $3.00 per adults, children 16 and under are free. The movie in the museum is a definite must for detailed information as to how, why, and when the ancient graffiti was created. The cliffs of El Morro up against the deep blue sky, and large, puffy white clouds of New Mexico is spectacular and without a doubt worth the 1 hour drive both ways to and from I-40. Make sure to call ahead or check out their website for guided tours, and special events.

After our recent visit I most recommend when seeing this attraction, that they take the free tours given by the Park Service. The information gives the visitor insight into the making of Mount Rushmore and the why the men depicted were chosen. The night time lighting is something that will not be forgotten. Make you very proud to be American. The Ranger who gave the introduction and speech was outstanding. A must see Attraction. Parking fee covers return trips to the Memorial (no fee for park entrance)

Good walk down and up the loop track with an informative commentary from a park guide. It was hot but we came prepared with water bottles, hats, sunscreen etc. Lots of steps so you need to be fairly fit. $5.00 per person entry. The canyon was very quiet and, although there were a lot of other visitors, it didn't feel crowded and we were able to get a sense of how things were for the inhabitants some 1,000 years ago.

I share the joy and excitement of all the previous reviewers. Instead of repeating highlights already mentioned, I wanted to entail that the National Park is organized for self-exploration. I often heard tourists, including myself, inquiring about arranging paid tours of the park. There is no need. At least not while the lava is not actively and excessively flowing. The park rangers and the locals will tell you that you are just paying $100 plus dollars for someone to keep you company. Visitors are able to access all the same places as the tour operators.

I love the historical sites and the classy way they've been preserved! So many places cake on the paint and don't do the buildings justice, but this park is exceptional. The sites are awesome, but the regimented way things are run is not the best way, from a tourist's point of view. Go to the Visitor Center first to get tickets to Independence Hall, Todd/Bishop White house, and whatever else you're going to need a ticket for. They also give you a "newspaper" with coupons and monthly happenings in them, too, so that's handy.
If you're in the area this is a must see! Cheap $5 per car. Magnificent views from a very impressive old stone fort on the river! Go there'bn

We saw the visitor center and the Liberty Bell. We were unable to get tickets to Independence Hall and I am still unclear how to obtain this tickets. We were told to get them online and then were told by an employee at the visitor center that you can go in without a ticket after 5. But then we were told it closes at 5. The liberty bell was great though. The line moves quickly, but I was glad we waited until about 4:00 to go see it - by then the line had died down.

I guess because it is in Quincy, this doesn’t show up on many lists of what to do in Boston; in fact, I heard about it from a friend. It is super easy to get to Quincy; simply take the Red Line T to Quincy Center and walk across the street to the National Park visitor’s center. A shuttle is provided, and it runs approximately every 30 minutes. It is only $5 (free if you have an NP pass) for two full hours of informative history about our 2nd & 6th presidents – John Adams and John Quincy Adams. So here is the coolest piece of trivia – John Adams and Thomas Jefferson, both signers of the Declaration of Independence and 2 of 3 signers still alive to celebrate our countries 50th anniversary, both died on the same day – July 4th, 1826. How ironic! The tour includes the house that John was born in, the house John Quincy was born in, the Adams house post Europe diplomat tour, and the best of all, the Adams library. Follow this with a trip to see where John F. Kennedy was born.

Everyone has to see Mount Rushmore. It is a very historic landmark that is just cool to say you have been to. The trail up to the mountain gives very nice views. It is a nice walk but does have a lot of stairs. The gift shop is huge. It is kinda funny to see a huge parking garage in front of a historic monument though. The fee is very reasonable. While it was nice to see it is just a short stop. We didn't spend more than an hour there. There are only so many ways and angles you can photograph it before its redundant.

but, more interesting was it's construction, and it's historical value...much of the "furnishings" were removed as the place is being restored, but, it's got an uncomfortable price tag to get in, for what you get back.....

We had limited time on our visit to Springfield and didn't want to spend the money and time at the museum this trip so we opted for this tour. It did not disappoint. First off, the price is just right-FREE! You have to get your ticket at the Visitor's Center which is clean and has great displays. We didn't get to see the movies, no time, but we wanted to.
Although it is free to get into Mount Rushmore, the parking is $11 per vehicle. Keep the receipt as it is good for a year.

1st of all, people need to realize Mt Rushmore is nothing more than a huge sculpture. Don't set aside an entire day to see it. It is one of those things you should see up close if you are in the area. I remember seeing it when I was a kid. I don't remember there being much more than a big parking lot with lots of trees in it and a visitor's center. It was a sculpture surrounded by nature. Now they have permanently scarred the area by building all this crap around it. There are restaurants (think $9 for a plain cafeteria burger), gift shops, an amphitheater. I think they are building all the stuff around it to compensate for the fact that all it is is a sculpture. If all you want is to see the faces, save yourself the $10 "parking" fee and look at it from outside. One thing I think is an improvement are the trails that let you walk all the way up to the base of the sculpture. Other than that, it is nothing more than a big tourist trap and an embarrassment to America.

We really enjoyed the scenic tour but had a hard time getting tickets. First, we tried to call about 4 days before we went to Jewel Cave. I didn't get through once. Even during our vacation, we called all day trying to get through...with no luck. Finally, we drove to the visitor center to see if anything was available for the next day. They said they couldn't sell me a ticket because the ticket guys were gone but they thought some were available the next day after 11 am. My husband left at 8:00 am. from our hotel to get tickets and found they had added an 8:30 am tour...which we could have taken if we were with him. He was then able to get tickets for 2:20 pm that day. I can't figure out why this is so difficult. We waited at Wind Cave for about 1 hour to go on a tour. It was so much better than going back 3 times to finally get in. I know the National Monuments may be under staffed but it seems more like lack of planning and organization. Why couldn't they just sell them first come first serve and then maybe it would be easier to get in if people weren't making phone reservations....???? Although I'm not sure who was making phone reservations if you can't get through. I'm glad the kids were able to see it so we don't have to do it again and go through the stress during our vacation. I'm not sure what I'd recommend. The ranger said many come and buy tickets and then come back a few days into their vacation. Many of us don't have the time to spare to do all the running around. I wish the phone reservations were not offered if they don't have the staff to take the reservations. On the website it says they're highly recommended.
Free .Got tickets on line for a fee,but was worth it.Arrived before 10 AM less crowded. Park rangers were helpful and friendly.

For the people who didn't do their research and planned a 2 day visit to Mt. Rushmore...don't. Mt. Rushmore is stunning as it is, but it is not a 2 day visit. It is 2 hours well spent though. We did not mind the $11 entrance fee. Go in the morning (8am is when it opens) to avoid the crowds and to take pictures without jostling for space.The visitor's center is really nice and informational, albeit a bit repetitive at times. We learnt a lot about the sculptor himself. The hike to the base of Mt. Rushmore was easy but pleasant. It was nice to soak in the atmosphere and reflect on the achievements of this nation.

We have for years seen pictures of Mount Rushmore but the in person experience is the real deal! Wow! When you gaze at this awesome picture looking right at you you get a sense of America the Beautiful. You feel proud to be an American. We you take the closer walk up to the monument you look straight up at the magnitude of this structure and you wonder how did they do it? I would suggest you go during the day as well as return at night for the night lighting ceremony. We went to the night lighting the night we arrived in Rapid City as we would be taking an all day tour the next day which included Mount Rushmore. I high recommend this attraction to everyone. No cost to get in but you are charged $11 for parking. But do it... it's worth it.

Ten dollars per carload for a week pass? What a great value. This is a fascinating place - go on the Kilauea Iki hike and the Chain of Craters Drive. One can easliy stay busy for 2 days if you are willing to do a couple of 2 to 4 mile hikes.

I reserved tickets for my family two days ahead of time via the phone ticket sales. The gentleman on the phone was very helpful when I was deciding which tour would be best for us, as we have a 11 year old, 8 year old & 10 month old. We went on the Scenic Tour & it did not disappoint! Our guide was very knowledgeable & everyone was very patient with the smaller children on the tour. We were able to bring a front pack baby carrier to strap on our little one & it worked great with this tour as the walkways were easy to navigate. There were lots of stairs, but not too strenuous at all. I would definitely recommend.

We knew tickets could be hard to come by, so went to purchase our tickets a day in advance. Unfortunately, our car broke down on our way there preventing us from making our tour. After talking with a Park Ranger, they sent us to the ticket sales counter to exchange our tickets for the next day. We were thrilled, we didn't think there was any hope. . We didn't want to loose our money, and the tour we wanted to attend were already full for the next several days. The man at the ticket sales window said, "Absolutely not, you can pay for more tickets but I can't (won't) do anything for you." We were sent back and fourth between the Rangers at the Welcome Center and the man at the ticket counter 3 times. The people at the welcome center saying that he could exchange the tickets for the next day and had done the exact same thing recently for guests in the park. The man at the ticket window simply said he couldn't do anything but sell us more tickets... We eventually just left without attending any tours. Oh well, maybe next time...

We were only 10 miles away doing the Wolf Sanctuary tour and decided to take 10 minutes to drive a little further to see what the Florissant Fossil Bed N.M. was all about. They are in the processing of building a visitor's center which looks like it will be really nice when finished. We got there a little late so we missed the fossil education in the Yurt (over at 3pm). All the staff was extremely nice and had alot of information to share. I don't know that it was so much about the fossils but more about the petrified redwoods for us. Be sure to catch one of the ranger's presentations down in the pavillion. They give alot of history about the area and information on what happened to the redwoods. We almost didn't go down to the homestead but the kids forced me and it was worth it. The volunteer did a great job telling us he history of the homestead and pointing out little things that we missed. All in all I think this is probably an easily missed placed to visit but well worth it if you're in to fossils and VERY LARGE petrified redwoods. Fee is minimal....only $3 per person over age 16.

I thought there was a large carving in a body of rock, I would snap a few photos and then leave. However when I got there it was a different story. This park really takes into consideration everything that you might think of. They are environmentally conscious, have very good food selections too. It is a great place to sit in the open space and read a book or listen to your MP3 player. Then you can reflect on the beauty of this sculpture. I strongly recommend everyone do the audio tour which will share a lot of insider tidbits with you. Without the audio you will miss so much about the history of the location and the people's stories along with it and might be tempted to say this was 'boring'. We arrived at 11am and didn't leave until 4pm. I truly didn't think the day would fly by so quickly. The gift shop offers some amazing items Made in the USA also. A nice touch given everything imported from overseas nowadays. Treat yourself to an American piece of history. PS all you pay is $11 for parking and you get to use the pass for 1 year.

Even during one of the busiest weeks of the year, we had an awesome time at Mount Rushmore. We were in the park on July 3 and got to participate in some of the Independence Day activities. Even though the park was full, parking was painless and access to bathroom facilities and concessions was easy with very little wait. While I wouldn't plan more than a few hours in the park, we had a great time going through the museums at the welcome center and hiked up to a view Rushmore from a different vantage point. We packed a picnic lunch and ate before we got to the park, but had AWESOME Raspberry soft serve ice cream cones. We didn't travel with kids, but saw many taking part in the awesome "Junior Ranger Program". Would definitely be fun for kids ages 6-11 or so. There was an $11 parking fee, but no fee to enter the park. I think they discouraged outside food and drink, but we each carried a bottle of water in without any problems.

I teach 4th grade United States regions. For as much as we have read about Mount Rushmore and seen pictures, nothing can prepare you for the real thing! It was a true work of ate! We were lucky enough to meet and get a book autographed by one of the original carvers of the monument. Our only disappointment was that our annual National Parks Pass did not cover the $11.00 parking fee, not sure why that is.

The rock formations would inspire any sculpter to marvel at such forms with the beautiful coloring swirling throughout. Saw many bison & wild horses. Cottomwood Campground is quiet & scenic with Golden Age pass just cost $5. It is dry camping. Very glad we visited Roosevelt.

Having already visited Death Valley, Grand Canyon, Lake Powell etc we were prepared to be underwhelmed by a more minor National Park. How wrong we were - it was amazing - the colours, rock formations and sights were brilliant. Prior to entering the Park you pass through Red Canyon - another pocket of visually stunning scenery. We loved our visit to Bryce Canyon and would recommend it wholeheartedly.

We camped at Diamond Lake which is only about 14 miles from Carter Lake with our 10 year old twins. The bugs there were horrible but I will save that for another review. We went to Crater Lake on a Monday so it wasn’t too crowed. I have been to several national parks and would have to say this was the most accessible park yet. They charge a $10 entrance fee per car. The view points are not far from each other and very easy to get to. The parking was easy also. I would not recommend traveling with an RV since there isn’t really any RV parking at the view points. They do have a trolley you can take if you don’t want to drive. If you are travelling during the summer all the roads Should be open and you can drive all the way around the crater which I would definitely recommend. If you get nervous with driving near cliffs be aware for a good portion of the drive around the lake there are cliffs right at the edge of the pavement. I was very nervous but made it through. We drove very slowly on those parts. One day is plenty of time to spend at the crater if you don’t plan to take long hikes. The mosquitoes were pretty bad so bring plenty of spray and wear long sleeves and pants. We ended up eating our picnic lunch in the car because of the bugs. We decided to take a boat tour. Since we didn’t book tickets in advance we were able to go to a kiosk at the lodge to purchase tickets. We weren’t sure if we could get tickets, but they did still have some for the same day on a late afternoon tour. The hike to the boat launch is 2.2 miles round trip with a 700 ft. elevation and is marked strenuous. This is very similar to the hike for Multnomah Falls in the Columbia Gorge, OR. You need to take into consideration the elevation and the weather for this hike at Crater Lake. I get pretty nervous with heights. Three out of four of us slipped on the way down. The trail is dirt and small rocks which makes it very slippery and dusty. We held the hands of our kids the whole way. It took us about 25 minutes to get down and about 45 to get back up. The tour cost $108 for the four of us. It was two hours long and drove very slowly around the perimeter of the lake. They have a park ranger who tells the different theories of how the lake formed on board of the tour. Most of these facts you will read at the view points and you can see nearly everything from the view points. It was a very slow tour. The kids and I were bored and ready to go after about an hour of it. You must bring plenty of water and food for this tour. The bathrooms were disgusting (out houses). I would bring some TP with you just in case. I could have lived without this tour. I would not recommend this excursion to families with children 10 or younger. Driving around the crater and stopping at the view points was good enough for me. The lake is beautiful and I was able to get some gorgeous pictures.

Correct information about the tours was not forthcoming from the official who was set up outside for that purpose, but I went inside the visitor center and asked the young rangers in the building. They recommended the self guided tour for $4 if you wanted a brief cave visit. The official outside had told us there were no self-guided tours at all on Sunday, but the young rangers looked mystified, said they were running the self-guided tours themselves, and assured us they were on duty from 9:30 AM Sunday. Yep - next morning they were there, and we enjoyed the no-fuss tour.

We found the exhibits very informative and enjoyed the canal tour. With an apparent surplus of rangers in and out, we were never told that we could take the trolly to the mill. My wife was clearly using her cane to move slowly about the visitor center so one would expect to be informed of the alternative to the long walk. In the mill we were never given nor advised to use ear protection. The machines are VERY loud. It would also have been nice if some of the many rangers seen moving in and out could be stationed along the exhibit to answer questions or direct us. We also were surprised to learn our Senior Passes did not work and we had to pay a discounted fee.

Great must see spot. $11 parking pass lets you go for the calendar year. Went back for evening lighting - awesome. Take the trail to get close - start on the left for easy ramp or the right for lots of steep stairs! Great value for the price.

I took my two boys (4 and 9) tent camping at Buffalo Point Campgrounds and we loved it. We were at campsite E, right off of the river, and we could hear it babble at night. The area designated for swimming was awesome - huge bluff made for great pictures. There were many people who utilized the locoal vendors who offered canoe rentals; if my boys were older we would've done the same. The water was very clear and a comfortable temp for swimming. Lots of deer. Can't wait to go back. Reservations were made online and super easy. No fee for going through the park, just if you want to camp.

Pure history! We started with the one hour movie - told the story of the preludes to the battle, the days up to it, the battle, and the aftermath very well. The small museum has a smattering of artifacts worth viewing. We then purchased the audio recording to tour the battle sites, along with it's excellent booklet. I thought the price was high, but after the tour decided it was a good purchase. We also visited the Pry House, which was Little Mac's headquarters, and then a hospital. The weather cooperated; it was a great way to spend the day. Good gift shop, too.

He sure made some gorgeous islands! We took the Apostle Island Cruise out of Bayfield WI and cruised for two hours among these federally protected islands, some have lighthouses. You can camp on some of them. Our tour was cut one hour short due to bad weather coming in from the west but was great anyway and they even refunded one third of our fare...classy eh?

You must make a reservations. Phone: 605-673-8300 8:30 and 4pm. They fill up quickly. They only have so many tours a day. Make sure you call ahead and make those reservations. The tour we took in the second largest cave in the world (JEWEL CAVE) was the scenic tour. It last about one hour and twenty minutes. Make sure you wear something warm. It is about 40 degrees in the cave. There are about 720 stairs you climb up and down. They do have plat forms that you can rest at. The trip is about 3/4 of a mile. Even though the trip is a little strenuous it is well worth it. You don't even notice the hour and twenty minutes going by. They have an elevator that that takes you down to the cave. Also, wear tennis shoes. The floor is slippery at certain points. Hold on tightly to the rails. Children five and up will love it. There is a fee of $8.00 per person. Not a bad price for what you get to see.
If you are visiting Philly, you have to visit! Get the timed ticket to go into Independence Hall, it is a great time saver.

This is must see. I will make some suggestions. Find out what time the Ranger Tours are and go on one. You learn so much. Wear good shoes and take your time if you use the steps in front of the memorial. It is a long and tasking walk up and down steps but they have levels you can rest at. I would also suggest if you go in the summer to buy what is known as FROGG TOGGS. I found mine at Bed Bath and Beyond. Read how to prepare the cooling cloth. This is a neck wrap in a plastic bottle that you wet and wear when you get hot. It saved me from over heating and kept me cool. If you are older take the steps slowly and walk slowly and rest often. Take water and drink as you go. The walk in front of the memorial is worth it. The beauty of the landscape is unreal. You see pictures and movies of Mt. Rushmore but you just can't appreciate how huge and wonderful it is until you see it. You will pay for parking only and they have covered parking which we liked for keeping our vehicle cool. Cost around $11.00 for the day.

Although we've all seen pictures of Mt Rushmore from time to time, there's nothing like seeing it in person. The first view is an awesome sight and the size of it makes it all the more spectacular. I've visited the Black Hills four times during my life, and each time I've paid to visit Mt Rushmore. It's a national monument afterall...and a bargain at $11 a carload.

This has clean, modern buildings for a national park. You have to pay to park, $11.00, but your pass is good for your car for the calendar year. Great Design and this park made me want to linger. Mt Rushmore is a must see, but the way the park was designed makes it a nice place to spend some time.
Absolutely stunning scenery and amazing story behind it's existance. Picnic lunch saves $ for families.

Other reviewers have said it well. This place is smaller, more compact, nothing like Gettysburg's tourist congestion. Antietam is only about an hour south of Gettysburg in miles, but light years from it in quiet, understated historical impact. Early Sunday morning, we were nearly the only people there. The Visitors' Center is well done, as is the gift store. Our grandsons became Junior Rangers and the Park Ranger made the 'ceremony' quite nice by really checking their work, administering an 'oath', presenting certificates and badges, and giving congratulatory handshakes. We, too, were initially dismayed at the admission fee, but in retrospect, decided it was more token monetary support to the upkeep of the battlefield than any true financial hardship. At $10 a car, you really can't complain. There was a small demonstration of the way infantry troops advance presented at the center. And while there were only four soldiers, they did a nice job showing troop movement. The movie was quite informative. The small exhibition area was well done and the artifacts well chosen. Presentation was staightforward and effective.

This was a nice weekend getaway for us, One of the two national parks near the East coast, and where we could drive to without losing the entire day. Of course, this is probably the most underwhelming of all the national parks in the country (mind you, I have been to only two and just seen pictures of the rest !). Still, it provides some nice hikes (the Ledges trail is a must do here), and a wonderful biking route following the Cuyahoga river. If you have your own bike, you can ride as far as you wish and then take the scenic railroad back (tickets are $2 if you have a bike, $17 if you do not !!). If you rent, on the other hand,as we did, then you have to meticulously plan your schedule to catch the train. Otherwise, you can end up paying quite a bit since rentals are $9/hr. There are a couple of quaint little towns here, and we happened to run into an enjoyable farmer's market in Peninsula, OH on a beautiful day. Also, it is really close to Cleveland. So, if you get a little bored, you can easily go spend some time in the city. Overall, a really nice getaway for a day or two.

No charge for admission, just for the parking. We used parking pass, as it expires at end of yr, relatives mailed to us and we used! Lots of history for children to see. Presidential trail gets you real close, unusual vantage points. Lots of stairs to climb at the very end to get back to main level, they dont tell you that part. Told it was all downhill. One person in our party with bad knee had some issues. Cafeteria run by Xanterra was quite good actually, some healthy choices. Good film in building monument. A must for school age children.

This is an amazing place to visit. Just going through the pack was great but we spent the $5.00 for the audio tour. It gave a great deal of extra information and helped explain a lot. Make sure you arrive early to avoid huge crowds of people. We arrived not long after it opened and had no problems walking through the park. When we started to leave it was filling up and made it hard to walk around and enjoy. All the people we came in contact that worked at Mt. Rushmore were extremely friendly and helpful.

This National Forest is beautiful! The waterfalls are very pretty and most are within a decent walking distance, if not pretty much off the road. Make sure you visit Sliding Rock! It's so much fun, but a little scary! Sliding rock is the only area with a fee...it's $1 for everyone over 5 years old. It's so worth it!

Even the 95-degree temperatures didn't keep us from enjoying our day here at Independence Historical park! The wait for the Liberty Bell was fairly short--they still need to put some fans up out there. Touring Independence Hall is free--you just have to pick up tickets at the visitor center. Actually, we found that the rangers would take a few extras in each tour regardless of whether you had picked up a ticket or not (and regardless of your assigned time). Basically, if you were willing to wait in the sun, you'd most likely get in reasonably quickly. Parking is easy in the underground garage on-site. For a nice day trip, this was well worth the time and money.

We recently spent one day touring/hiking in Bryce NP. It has been many years since my last visit there, and I was really amazed at the beautiful scenery. We did some hikes near Inspiration Point, and they were great. Bryce NP is a great summer destination because of the higher elevation; we left the 107 F heat in Las Vegas and really enjoyed the sunshine and cool air in Bryce. We had our own food and didn't spend the night nearby, so we can't rate anything other than the scenic beauty. Inspiration Point and around that general area was our favorite place to visit. There were monsoonal thundershowers all around us, but we had no problems with rain or lightning. In fact, the weather really added to the incredible vistas around us as we walked.

We have been in the area many times and had never stopped before. Actually we made stopping a priority this trip. My wife acquired one of those National Park Passport books ($10) where you put in an ink stamp at every park you visit so National Parks have become a must and that is a good thing. We are revisiting many parks and definitely seeing others in quest of those stamps. Quite fun actually. (How do you spell obsession?)

I have been to Bryce at least three times in the past and always enjoyed the magnificent vistas. This time I ponied up $60 and went on a horse ride down into the canyon. It was well worth it. Though they cater to huge crowds of 60 or so, the cowboys break everybody up into groups of 10 and assign each group a guide. I was aware of some other groups while on the trail, but it wasn't distracting.
Daily 8:30 to 5 PM 8th and Jackson Streets. Free Admission

I went there later on in the day and the tours were full, so set that up early. I still got to walk up the street there and see the neighborhood as it was in his day, even got to speak to honest Abe as I found him relaxing in his back yard. This area is blocked from general traffic and a couple houses in the area contain artifacts from his day. $2 for parking but you can walk around for free so well worth the 2 bucks! Next time I'm in the area I will be sure to go back to get the full tour!

This is an attraction that you cannot fully appreciate in pictures. You have to go see it sometime in your life. It is well worth the nominal the fee to get in and it gives you chills when you are actually standing face to face with this masterpiece. Use your binoculars to view the faces up close to see the scars left from all the chiseling that was done. It really gives you a sense of how challenging it was to create such an artistic image while while blasting through solid rock. The movie in the musuem's theatre tells some of the history of Mount Rushmore but I would have liked to have learned a little more. Conversely, I thought the movie at Crazy Horse Memorial was more informative.

Bryce Canyon is spectacular. WOW! You don't have to go on hikes to enjoy the tremendous scenery at this park. The rock formations are incredibly beautiful and offer so many opportunities for photographs. If you do opt to hike, there are several trails to choose from. There are strenuous hikes and fairly easy hikes so you have a choice. Each trail is well-marked and you are given information about each trail's distance and approximate time it takes to complete it. Wear good hiking shoes - I can't stress that enough! What is great about this park is that it is only 80 miles from the Grand Canyon, so if you visit one, it is no too far to go to the other. Zion National Park is also in the area so go there if you can, too! Get a yearly pass from the Park Service to get the most out of your dollar. Enjoy - Mother Nature really outdid herself in this part of the country!!
Make sure you get your ticket for the guided tour. It is free and the best bargain around. Friendly informative staff makes it an interesting tour. Great for my 3 boys

I am 45 years old and I giggled like a little kid the morning I woke up to drive to Mount Rushmore. After seeing this iconic sight so many times in movies, posters, tshirts, television - I was so intrigued to see it in person. I drove from Pierre, SD and stopped at Wall Drug. Then onto Rapid City and Keystone. The drive from Rapid City to Keystone wasn't bad at all. I took off early in the morning so there wasn't a lot of crazy traffic. As you're driving up the winding roads, all of a sudden BOOM there it is. Of course it looks smaller from this distance but everyone gets out and takes a picture. The smell of pine trees is wonderful. Then onto the Visitor Center. $11 entrance fee was well worth it. Lots of parking (several outdoor levels). Then a nice walk up to the main plaza. There's a very long row of flags for every state in the union. A great gift shop and cafe. And the sight of the presidents up close is truly breathtaking. Just the sheer human achievement of actually getting something that huge and detailed carved into a mountain side is truly awe-inspiring. I couldn't stop looking at them. Don't miss it. Then when you leave, follow the signs west into Black Hills National Forest and you'll see some fantastic roadside photo opps of George Washington in profile.

This was my first visit there, and will probably be my only one. Nothing against it, there just wasn't much to do. We stayed in Rapid City and it took about 20-25 mins to get here. Admission to it was free, but parking cost $11 and is good for the rest of the year. The facilities here are on great shape, and looked virtually new. The staff said that it was a slow-ish day there, but with the crowds of people, I would hate to be there on a busy day. I would have liked to see more history of the presidents depicted in the monument. Being a foreigner, I have never taken any American History courses, but I felt like I walked away learning more about the sculpture than the men he so carefully crafted. Having something like a rock carving demonstration or more interactive exhibits of the construction of it would have been nice. We only spent about 2 hrs there, and then came back at night for the illumination ceremony which was a disappointment. They basically just played the same video that loops in the exhibit hall, and slowly turned the lights on. Unless you're already there, I wouldn't go back there for that part. It would also have been nice if there was a restaurant on site, not just a burger-shack. We were pretty burger'd out by that point on a road trip. I'm glad I went once, but it wasn't the highlight of my trip.
Did the Audio tour for $5 bucks best money I ever spent.

It is so amazing and cheap. Still can't believe that we only had to pay $11 to park! Would recommend doing the 30 minute walking tour. It is very interesting and our tour guide was very knowledgeable! If we had more time we would have visited it again and gone to the lighting ceremony at night!

On our stops of great battlefields we decided Antietam was a must see. Arrived at the Park and the ranger provided us with a brief, but complete synopsis of what led to the battle, the players involved and the battle details. Great orientation (included in the $6 we payed for family of 4). We then watched a 20 min. movie, which corresponded with the orientation and is also included with the entrance fee. They have a very small, but cool museum. Did the driving tour and in the opinion of the whole family, it was far more enjoyable than Gettysburg, which we had just visited a couple of days earlier. Don't get me wrong, Gettysburg is an awesome experience, but it has gotten to be very commercial. Antietam however is not, yet it is also a must see for historical battlefields in the area.

Everything beautiful in nature to see in Alaska is here! We drove all around the National Forest while visiting Anchorage and Eagle River. Be prepared to pay any time you park for more than a few minutes, but all facilities are well marked and maintained.

Walked the camping/backpacking trail barefoot. It was fun. The dunes are amazing. But after awhile you see enough sand. The park is amazing & the cost is great. It is a must do if you are in the area. BRING WATER.

I wasn't sure I cared to see this, but am so glad we did. It was very impressive, and the area surrounding the memorial was very well done. It was definitely worth it. The only problem is that we have a pass to all national parks, but this one required a fee for parking and wouldn't let you past the gate house without paying. Also, I love animals, but I did notice a sign that said absolutely no dogs...and there were dogs everywhere.

You might compare this to Mesa Verde N.P even though it is a lot smaller, but it is very cute and an easy escape from downtown Flagstaff. The island trail is the better of the two trails offered. It is short, offering a hint of challenge in its 200+ stone steps up and down. But the views are intriguing every step of the way. The ruins of the Indian dwellings were easy and fun to explore. We did the whole trail easily under an hour and half. The entrance fee is a bit pricey - $5 per head rather than the usual per vehicle charges by Grand Canyon and other large national parks, but since we have the N.P annual pass, we had nothing to complain.

National Landmark everyone should visit. $11 for parking gets everyone in. We thought this would be a quick stop, but ended up spending a few hours here. I recommend walking the path, but be prepared for lots of stairs. A little way into the path they have a teepee & artifacts, with employees there to answer questions & give information regarding the area. Clean restrooms & a large gift shop as you are walking up to view the monument closer. Our kids 5 & 8 really enjoyed it.

We bought 2 sleds in the gift shop to slide down the dunes and had a blast. Used sleds were $10 and you would get $3 back if you returned the sleds which I thought was kind of a rip off. We went to the visitor's center and watched the short movie which was the perfect lenghth for us, we had 2 small ones in our group with not much attention span. It was about 15 minutes. Everyone really enjoyed sledding down the dunes, the little ones didn't want to leave. The bad part was climbing back up to the top of the dunes to do it again, it's quite a workout!

i've always wanted to see this when i was just in 3rd grade and seeing it in person was just awesome! worth the long drive. went there before noon and as expected there were a lot of tourists. travelled with a toddler, a grade-schooler and a teen-ager, which limited our exploration of the place. just walked through the avenue of flags, took a perfect place to take our pictures, ate at the carver's cafe and visited the souvenir shop and that was it. i will definitely go back to walk through the presidential trail and see the lighting ceremony. take a bottle of water with you, there's a free refill station (price of a bottled water at the concession is stratospheric). take level 6 parking if you don't like to walk up and down a stair (though i think there is an elevator to every parking level). no entrance fee but there is $11 parking fee...

Have done the paid tour twice and wasn't happy with the guides, the bus comfort, or the food. To pay that much and be uncomfortable, while eating a glowing green nasty tasting wrap for lunch isn't fun. On the plus side, the farther in you go the more wildlife, so take a shuttle bus to Eielson or Wonder Lake, it's cheap and they always stop for wildlife. This park is gorgeous, we saw 20 bears and herds of caribou, a ptarmagin family, tons of arctic squirrels, a few moose, and a snowshoe hare. The park is amazing, the tours not so much.

I have a National Park "Senior Pass," it is the best travel value in the USA. I stopped to get my National Parks PASSPORT stamped at the “Cancellation Station.” The Park Ranges at the Visitors’ Center were extremely helpful. The NM was well worth the efforts. The sky was blue it was before the afternoon rains; and the petroglyphs were easy to see as the paths were well marked and signed; it was great to see the messages from the ancient native peoples.

Don't miss the sledding. It is GREAT!!!.. Buy the saucers at the gift shop for about 15.00. Buy the wax too.. (less than a dollar) When you go into the park, keep driving until you get to pure sand (no vegetation) and then pick a good spot. When you sled, there are a few suggestions to help.

Independence Historical Park is a MUST SEE for any American and for any tourist with the desire to tour essential American history. It is FREE, but touring Independence Hall requires a timed tour ticket. They can be reserved online for $1.50 a piece, but otherwise are free if you pick them up at the Visitor's Center.

All I can say is WOW! When walking from the parking area to the mountain, the four faces come into view and grow larger - it was breathtaking. We stayed for a couple of hours and did the walking trail. There are lots of steps up and down so be prepared. Well worth the time and parking fee.
The smoke from the Lakefield fire makes all viewing terrible and very smoky to breath. It would have been nice if the park rangers would have let us know BEFORE paying the park entry fee.

We have visited caves before, but this one is the best! Our guide Nicole was very interesting & informative. Make sure to order you tickets by phone (online ordering is not available). They are available for purchase up to 7 days before your visit. Bring along a jacket and comfortable shoes. There are some tight areas and lots of steps (723 altogether), but 60% go down and the 40% go up. It's not all at the same time and there are plenty of breaks. The admission is very reasonable too!

Although you can see this for miles away, do not miss out on the opportunity of getting up close to this astonishing sight. There is plenty of background information to learn more about the hows and whys and a big enough gift shop selling descent souveniers to make this well worth a day out. Do not miss staying on or returning to witness the lighting ceremony - a truly moving experience. The entrance to the park itself is free with an 11 dollar parking fee which is valid to the end of the year.

The visitor centers and some of the sites along the way are terrific. Make sure to go to both the North Bridge and Minute Man visitor centers! The former is in an historic building and shows neat films on the beginning of The American Revolution; the latter has a small wonderful theater designed to look like a colonial home in which they show the course of the initial battles. The displays at the Minute Man visitor also offers more historical information. I stopped at the Hartwell Tavern to hear a talk about the Minute Men militia by a history teacher dressed in period costume and learned a great deal. If you have time, try walking a little of the paths to some of the national landmark homes that might not be open but this offers a serene retreat to contemplate these historic events. The NPS just does a terrific job of educating the public about our parks. I have a National Parks pass but this is free.

The white sand dunes surrounded by mountains was beautiful, especially at dusk. The park rangers were very helpful and friendly, and the girl that did our sunset tour. I would recommend going in the late afternoon and taking the sunset tour, as it's not so hot. Sledding wasn't as fun as we expected (we're both in our early twenties and under 150 lbs) but the young kids around us had a blast. If at all possible, bring your own sleds as used ones are $10 and new are even more expensive. You can get a little money back if you return them. This place is definitely a must see!

Jwahely46 said it right, "God's Country". While taking the Hwy 550 north to Silverton, Ouray and Montrose is one of the finest road trips in the USA, it is getting off the road, lacing up the hiking boots and walking the trails that bring one ever closer to the Creator. I remember that after living a few years in Phoenix, I took a road trip and went hiking in the San Juans and it renewed my spirit as it exhausted my body getting over a high pass. This summer, my wife and I went camping on the Florida River and went hiking in the area. Even when the smoke blew in from fires to the south, it was great. ps No fees to hike, but most campgrounds charge these days.

My wife & I were staying in St.Augustine with our daughter & grandkids.Our daughter was there on business & we went along to babysit the grandboys.The first thing we did in the morning was visit Fort Matanzas.The price of admission was $7 for adults & children under 14 are admitted free.As I am a disabled vet,my wife & I were admitted free of charge.This was a pleasant surprise! We found the entire experience very interesting & a huge amount of fun.The tour was informative & interesting if one is interested in the past.Of course,the boys being boys, loved the shooting of the cannon.I recommend this experience,if you love history & a real bargain,over all the usual tourist trap attractions.

We visited this site in July 2012 and it is just wonderful. The entrance has been updated and handicap friendly. There is no fee to get in so your senior pass for national paks is not needed but there is a $11.00 parking fee. When you get to the ampitheater stay left as the walk way is ramps, there are more steps if you go right. The views are just awesome.

This is a sensational sight in the sense that the dinosaur quarry is a fascinating repository of finds left in situ and there's no place like it. BUT given the huge amount of money spent to restore the building it's a real shame the standard of presentation is so weak. When we last came ten years there was a coloured panel that helped you pick out the jumbled bones of each animal by using a different colour for each one. Now there's very little to help you understand what's going on - just a couple of well-intentioned rangers, a few basic information panels, a $1 kids' booklet, and very little else. The truth is that you are looking at a large grey cliff face scattered with a large number of disarticulated grey bones, some of which are quite a long way above you and it's very hard to make sense of, especially for kids who are probably expecting something far more dramatic. None of the skeletons is complete which means you are looking at a stack of vertebrae here, a bit of tail there, a couple of leg bones over there and so on. This is a place that is screaming out for a presentation video, better labelling of the bones and so on. Ironically, the wall displays of skeleton plaster casts are considerably more informative and easier to understand. We came a long way to see this and we were in and out of the cover building in about 30 minutes and that was stretching it. In some respects the 1.5-mile trail back to the parking lot (you have to come up to the quarry by shuttle) which takes you past an open-air section of the quarry with bones in place was more evocative. So, it's undeniably worth visiting and very memorable but I had the feeling it could with some time, trouble, and money, be a lot better.

spent a day in each park camping & hiking, seeing the sights, Saw some bears... pay attention to the food storage requirement by the NPS... This is an active Bear Area. I camped out on the ground without a tent... sleeping under the stars, Forgot the tent, actually, so I had to be aware of the noises in the campground... heard many, saw nothing because my food was stored in the bear boxes provided in each site.

park: John Day Fossil Beds National Monument
text: Despite my last visit was 1 yr ago, I still highly recommended my friend to pay a visit there if they like to look at rock scenery. Prepare for long drive to go there but it is absolutely worth. Search more information before driving there as not too many people are aware of this place. Don't stay too late as it will be too dark to leave - easy to get lost. GPS can help but not 100% guarantee unless yours is a good one.

We made another visit to Mount Rushmore. On the grounds we found outdoor shops set up selling tee shirts at a tremendous price. There were also actors dressed as the Presidents and they did a wonderful job as when you listened to them talk you just drifted back in time to that era. Great - Great - Great place to visit even if the traffic is a mess.
Absolutely first rate destination. The facilities at the Memorial are incredible. Very well maintained and the staff are overly helpful.

A lot of stuff in a small area. The late light show was over rated. Lighting is TOO bright so faces look washed out and flat. Lots of things to buy in the giftshop - too many with "made in china" on them. The walk is great but recommend the guided or self-guided tour. Just a shame that parking is not met by the Annual State Park ticket.

If you are in southern Utah make sure you set aside time to visit this beautiful park. If you are not hiking, you can drive to all of the overlooks in a relatively short amount of time. Not that far from Zion National Park, and definitely worth the drive. If you want to hike, there are several options which range from easy to moderate. On these hikes you will see the fabulous "hoodoo" rock formations which jump out at you like a 3-D movie. Truly breathtaking. I believe the Navajo Loop is the trail we took, coming out on the Wall Street corridor of the hike. About 2 hours for this hike. Take time to eat at the Bryce Canyon Inn, where we were served a great lunch at a very reasonable price.

Maybe I had read too many five star reviews, but for me this park disappointed. We took the six hour return shuttle, which is the shortest you can do. Honestly it was very long, very dusty and many miles of scenery which did not vary that much. We saw almost all our animals in the last hour; I know this is the deal with animals but it was just so long in a bus with not much to see or do. I think the shuttle bus system is overly complicated and the documentation about options (eg the times the huskies show is on) not particularly good. The one redeeming feature was our shuttle driver, who was excellent. I would definitely recommend a low cost flexible shuttle over an organized tour. If you are interested in views of Mt McKinley, I recommend Talketna. While I am glad I can say I have visited Denali, I would not recommend going out of your way to see it.

The Mammoth Passage Tour doesn't require a reservation and is only $5, so we went on that one. Our ranger was friendly and informative, telling us a lot about saltpeter mining and slavery and Native American artifacts. The hike to the cave (1/4 mile down a relatively steep slope and then 80 steps, reverse on the way back) wasn't as bad as it sounds, although we agreed that we'd have to spend a night if we were going to do more than one tour.
Went to the exhibit and seen it in person absolutely awesome, we also took a helicopter ride pass the front of it so worth the money

Whether you've read David McCullough's John Adams or not, this is a site that you shouldn't miss. For $5, you get a guided tour of John and John Quincy's birthplace, the latter's library, and the home at Peace Field. The NPS annual pace can be used here in place of the fee.

Although this fort is small, the history and the artifacts are amazing to see. There was an explanation on our tour about the area, the history and the fort. The ferry ride is fun and once in the fort you can climb to the top via a short ladder that is in the room. I think that this is a fun and very interesting trip for no money. Even if they charge a minimal fee it would be worth it.

I recently did a 3 night backpack trip at the Grand Tetons National Park. I parked at the Leigh Lake Trailhead and hiked up the Paintbrush Canyon Trail the first day. A challenging but worthwhile hike. I saw a big black bear midway up the canyon eating in a raspberry field next to the trail. I set up camp just below the end of the upper paintbrush camp zone. A beautiful view all around. The next day, I went over the Paintbrush divide and also summited the peak to the north of the divide. 10820 ft. Great view and easy climb. Then down to Lake Solitude. This area is full of flowers and the lake is wonderful. I continued down and saw the largest moose I have every saw. It had 8 points but another 10-12 points that were about to complete. A sight. The South fork Cascade was fully of waterfalls and cliffs. Going to the end and climbing Hurricane Pass is well worth it to see the perfect view of the 3 Tetons and the valley where the South Fork Trail runs. I stayed two days in this area. Well work it. Lastly, I hiked down early the last morning down Cascade Trail. A very easy slow decline. I will go back.

It was my son's first time to the Black Hills & he really wanted to do Jewel Cave. We called a couple of days in a row, different times of day and could not get through on the reservation line. Always the same greeting-- due to high call volume, they couldn't take our call. (It didn't matter if we chose the ticket option or the park attendant option.) Finally, on the third day, we did get through and were told that both tours we could likely do with a small child would require the elevator, which was out of service. I had read on the reviews prior to coming that a new phone reservation system will be coming. I recommend offering an internet reservation option as well, similar to the state park's system, so people can get immediate results about availability. The reservation line was a frustation.

Liked that it is within walking distance to everything in Old Town and the admission is reasonable. They have good video support for the explanations as well as pictures. My kids loved going up to walk on the top area too. Be aware, if the weather even hints of lightning they will make you come off the top area due to it being a lightning conductor up there. Not a bad idea really. Overall a great experience not to be missed in St. Augustine.

It has been several yrs since I had seen Mt Rushmore and I thoroughly enjoyed seeing it again with my family. Such a beautiful and patriotic monument! Our family really enjoyed the walking trail, which is nicely done with walkways and railings. Muliple steps but easily navigated, and it provided a closer view of the faces. Also enjoyed the little building below that houses the sculptor's model and some factual information. Although I love the improvements made with the avenue of flags and the columns and granite walkway and grand entrance to the monument, I was disappointed to see the associated artifacts and pictures and factual information about the formation of the monument is no longer on site. Instead there is a restaurant. There is also a gift shop. The fee was only $11 to get in, so a real value to enjoy the beauty of this majestic monument nestled in the beautiful black hills.

The location is a serene setting and the replica buildings are very impressing . It's a short walk through some huge trees from the visitors center. There is a charge of three dollars per person unless you have a golden age passport.

We booked 7 days in advance and had not problems picking up our tickets. Lots of people turned away disappointed. Book well ahead and you will have it made. The cave is awesome and the guides are excellent. This was one of the best parts of our vacation. There is not much to do at the site though, there are a few trails and a very small gift shop. There is alos a fairly interesting video but we got more from our guide. Really good time and very good price. We did a family of 4 for $24, and were there for over 2 hours. Excellent value and good time.

Just one of those amazing things in the world that you just have to see if you are anywhere in the neighborhood. Thought $11 to park seemed steep; however, we enjoyed visiting the monument and got some great photos.

We took the kids (age 11, 11, and 9) to Mt. Rushmore. Getting there is easy, as there is signage everywhere pointing the way. There is no fee to visit, but there is an $11 parking pass (which is good for the rest of the year).

I was a little skeptical about how entertaining this carving could be, but I really enjoyed this stop. It was $11 to get in and was a great value. There was lots of parking and a great gift shop. We went early in the morning and it was quiet, we left about an hour later and it was packed. There is a small walking trail that goes close to the mountain, and you must do this for the full effect, this trail is pretty well marked. I can't wait to go back.

I expected to drive into a parking lot and look up to see the Monument. However, there is a lovely entrance, promenade and viewing deck. Very nicely done. A grille for snacks, even breakfast and a nice gift shop. We had a pass from our hotel for parking but even so, it's only $11 for the car. Well worth it.
We frequently take guests through the park. We have a CD that takes you on a guided tour of the part and is very educational, well worth the price at the gift shop.

This was a great tour of Mammoth Cave. The guide was very informative about the history and uses of the cave in the past. The hike was not strenuous and was well lit. There is an area called Fat Man's Misery that we were warned about at the beginning of the tour; it was no big deal, so don't let that deter you from this tour. We visited in early August. I brought a long sleeve shirt into the cave but did not wear it over shorts and a t-shirt. If you only have time for one tour, I would take the New Entrance Tour over this one as it has more of the scenic cave features. I believe each tour was $12/adults and $8/child.
There is no admission for Mount Rushmore, but instead, an $11 per car parking fee.

We spent 6 hours in the park learning and viewing everything volcano's. We even did the Crater hike into the lava lake and up the rain forest. There are easy to advance hikes available. The steam vents, Crater ring and lava tubes are amazing and easy to access. The views of lava paths to shore lines are breath taking. A great was to spend a day with the family and learning something new at the same time! Plus its only $10.00 per car to enter and its good for a week of visits.

They have done a very good job of laying out the park. Very easy to get around, and the .6 mile trail is well worth the effort. Admission is free, however to park costs $11 per car that is good for a year. Many fantastic photo opportunities. Be sure to rent an audio guide, its only $5 and you can easily skip to the section you want to listen to.

Easy to get to, easy to park ($10), short walk to beach, beautiful white sandy beach, protected by attentive life guards, snack bar, free showers (cold), and rent umbrellas and chairs ($10 each for day). Love love love this beach.

Was neat to see the LARGE trees - but was a little disappointed because as a child remember driving through a tree and weaving around roads checking the big trees out. But was told these areas are privately operated now and charge fees.

Be sure to stop at the visitors center before doing anything! They are very knowledgeable and will give you excellent advice for things to do that suit your family. Also, you must answer some screening questions before entering any caves, to prevent the spread of white-nosed disease among the bats there (it's a fungus that likes caves, and you are in danger of infecting the bats, not the other way around!). The rangers will provide free flashlights for cave exploration, and you will need them, because the caves are not lighted at all. Great short hikes abound. Be sure to have sun protection if you plan to hike, because there is very little shade, mostly juniper trees. Bring food and water as well. The caves are amazing and some of them easy to do with families and children. Good idea to bring a helmet to avoid ceiling bumps. Interesting history, too, and some of the trails provide history lessons in addition to the fascinating geology of the place. Note that the road leading into the park from the southeast is in bad shape and there are lots of potholes. Drive slowly and pay attention. The roads within the park itself are in great shape, however.

Revisted after 30 years and WOW has it changed. The presidential trail is a must see. The evening lighting ceremony was really moving! The admission is good all year too which was a bonus if you want to come back!

We stayed in Bend the previous night and approached the park from the northern entrance - park fee at the time of writing was $10 per vehicle. The road climbed to the rim and we caught sight of the lake from the first lookout there. he colour was a deep blue, lighter green in the shallows and it was magnificent. We travelled down the western rim and took the walk up the the Watchman - another fine view. The other spot we visited was Sun Notch and the view over the Phantom Ship - the water seemed its darkest here. Crater Lake sure is a lovely spot - a little out of the way, but lovely nonetheless.

If you don't mind hopping rocks, walking across logs, and ducking branches to get to the falls, then try Switzer! This hike should be on everyone's bucket list. Located above La Canada on the Angeles Crest Highway (don't forget Adventure Pass), it's an easy drive to the Switzer Truck Trail. Get to trailhead early for premium parking at the BOTTOM of the fire road. Otherwise, it's an UPHILL walk to your car after the hike in the overflow lot!

The battlefield is very well preserved and work is on-going to return parts of the battlefield to the condition it was in during the battle. At the visitor's center you can view a short video that depicts the events plus get your map, visit the bookstore, etc. The park itself has a number of walking trails that wind throughout. There are also numerous unit markers, memorials, and stands that explain the battle. I suggest doing a little reading before hand to get a full picture of the events, or use one of the many audio tours available. Markers are quite as good as Gettysburg, but plenty of explanation and identification of units. The map lays out a pretty good driving route from North to South. Be sure to step out into the cornfield as well as the sunken road and Burnside Bridge (all must see areas). You can probably drive around in an hour if in a hurry. I wandered for 3 hours and didn't see everything. Admission is free for active military.

I came here the first time 40yrs. ago. Parking was free and you had an unobstructed view of the monument. Well, the natural beauty of the surrounding area has been ruined by the greed of capitalism and for so many people who need to be "entertained" rather than just taking in the site itself. Flags and buildings hocking their wares obstruct the view. Parking was $11. It just diminished the whole experience for me. Husband, who had never been there in his 71yrs. was much impressed. And don't eat at their Carvers Cafe, it's worse than bad.

The Memorial was very easy to get to and had no trouble parking for a fee. It was a short walk from the car to the entrance. They had a wheelchair that my wife could at no cost. Just check it out with the ranger. You could see the Heads when you walked in the entrance. It's 100 yards from the entrance to the end of the walk. You can see the Heads all along the walk and take pictures.
Its a great monument, but you will be charged $11 to park (even a motorcycle) - but your ticket is valid for the season. Expected more. The area is very scenic and the roads excellent

Tucked away at the top of California, near the Oregon border, Lava Beds is an interesting glance into time when active volcanoes dotted the landscape and lava flowed freely. Miles of frozen lava rivers and deep lava tube caves make this a worthwhile stop for whole family. Admission is $8 per carload, or if 62 plus you can buy a lifetime $10 golden pass that will get you and the kids into all national parks as many times as you like. The caves are not developed and cool, so dress appropriately with good hiking boots (rough floor) and bring a flashlight. If you forget, the rangers will lend you one in exchange for a copy of your driver's license. There are a lot of caves with varying degrees of difficulty, ask the ranger for a recommendation of the best ones for you. Also check out the nearby national wildlife refuge for the breeding ground of the white pelican. Area also was the site of a battle between horse soldiers and the local Indians.

This is a tourist trap at it's finest but it's also an American Icon that you must see. Yes you have to pay an outrageous parking fee, and in the middle of summer it's hot and miserable but it's worth it. You can see the monument from outside it's boundaries if you want, but the exhibits and information on the inside is well worth it. It's cool to see how the faces change from different vantage points too. We went of Independance day and that made it feel even more inspiring. To think that I can't even draw a face on a piece of paper and these brave people carved four faces into a granite mountain is just incredible. Be on the lookout for mountain goats along the road that leads up to the entrance. We saw a family of them around dusk that evening.

While in the Blackhills one has to go to Mt. Rushmore and we did. Felt strangely patriotic while there; not something that happens to me often, so that was nice. Was glad to have given my children the opportunity to see it. Both the drive in and out were delightfully beautiful (and sometimes scary while at the edge of a mountain). Unfortunately, they do charge to park - we were short on time and didn't take in any of the programming at the monument, so we did feel a bit robbed by paying $11 to park for 1/2 hour. Overall, I say go. It is a marvel.

We stopped at Mammoth Cave on the last day of our 3300 mile, 13 state in 12 days road trip. The Visitors Center is well run and they help you pick the appropriate tour. The caves are simply awesome and are a must do for anyone who enjoys the power of mother nature. It's chilly in the caves (a constant 54 deg) so don't forget your long sleeve shirts. Sweatshirts are $40 in the gift shop. Ouch!

This is one of those places that I try to find the time to go to every year. You always see something new. Like any National Park this is an enjoyable experience. It is staffed by Rangers who know what they are talking about and who certainly seem to enjoy their job. To think what this whole system meant back in the day and what it took to design and build will astound you. The Park service has trolley rides and several canal tours where you have a narrated boat ride through the canal system. Simply amazing. It's a National Park, you aren't going to get ripped off, you are going to learn a lot, and if you like history at all you are going to really enjoy yourself. This is good enough to be a vacation destination, not just something to stop in to see as you pass by.

I live in Flagstaff and have an annual pass, which I would recommend if you plan on visiting two other sites – Sunset Crater and Wupatki National Monument. Only for $24 you get an annual admission for an entire family.

We love Civil War era history. We had visited Harpers Ferry several years ago with our children but went for a second visit as a couple. If you haven't been there in some time it is worth a more recent visit. They have definetly revamped some of the attractions, reconstructions. There were no reenactments going on but it was stil a good visit. But if you have trouble walking keep in mind that it is alot of walking, some of it up hill and on very old steps. Parking is limited in the main town and it is much easier to take the frequent shuttle down from the visitors center. You pay by person but per car rate is cheaper if you are a couple. The pass is good for 3 days. We drove from exit 29 Hagerstown MD and it took us about 30 minutes to get to it. There are places to eat in the town but we enjoy doing a tail gate kind of picnic up in the visitor center area. I would love to return during the peak of fall. The river and the hillsides would be spectacular. We spent 4 hours there taking a small break. If there are reenactments you will probably need more time.

This park is off the beaten path but it's worth the effort to get to it. I knew about the Johnstown Flood but not as much as I learned here.
