There's a good film (if maybe a bit overwrought) you shouldn't miss. The displays in the center are very good. I thought the display showing the progess of the wave by using lights was especially helpful in understanding how quickly and how far the wave traveled. You can see remnants of the dam from the Center so you don't necessarily need to go anywhere but the Center but there are other vantage points around the lake for those wanting a closer look. One thing I was not happy to learn is the park's naturalist has advocated for letting the lake bed grow back vegetation so the valley will eventually look as it did before the dam was built. Apparently, this is the path the Park Service is taking, after years of cutting back brush so visitors can see the extent of the lake. I feel that once the valley has grown back there will be nothing to show visitors other than pictures. What would be the point of the Memorial after that? Why keep funding a Park site commemorating an event if the site no longer looks like it did at the time of the event? So if you're interested in learning about the flood and seeing what's left of the site after the flood you should go sooner rather than later. There is a fee of $8.00 if you enter the Visitor Center.

After an overnight stay at Klamath Falls, we headed north on SR 62 to one of the deepest, clearest, bluest lakes in the world. Would of been nice to stay at Crater Lake, but like most national parks, the lodge (on national register) and cabins book up months in advance, especially the three months of the year the area is not covered under several feet of snow. Approaching the park from the south is on a two lane blacktop road climbing up through a lot of countryside. Make sure you fill up the tank, because there are not many amenities until you reach the volcanic rim. Beautiful scenery, clean spruce-smelling air, but warm in August (hit 90 degrees when we were there). $10 admission per carload or use your golden pass. Very popular so cars get backed up at the entrance. We were traveling with our beagle and disappointed we couldn't take her on any of the trails, but dogs are allowed on one closed road and all the public areas. Beautiful views of the lake from several places along the circle rim drive, but the best are from the walkway at the rim village. Lots of events on the weekend. We had to pass several cyclists, and there were a hundred plus runners doing the loop early in the morning. Several waterfalls, one right by the east loop road. There is a boat trip on the lake that allows you time to explore Wizard island in the crater, but it takes several hours. Camping available and trams if you don't want to do the drive yourself. We took the north exit to the park and headed back on SR 138 to the I-5, also a scenic highway right along the beautiful, trout-filled North Umpqua river.

We arrived to find $6 got 2 people admission for three days. Awesome. We only stayed about an hour and a half due to a bad storm that moved in and pour rain down. While it was still dry we managed to see some of the monuments on the left side of the visitor center and the Dunker Church (which I swear is haunted!). We also witnessed a cannon firing demonstration before the rain hit. WE WILL BE BACK!!!! Hopefully better weather next time.

We took one of the 16 passenger boats for the captain's choice tour. We think it was probably a lot better than the larger boats. We saw lots of great bird like hundreds of puffins. The captain actively searched for birds, whales, animals, and good glacier views. It cost each of us more about $225 for the day, but it was worth it.

Minute Man NHP is worth a visit to the area for the park alone. You can visit the site of the first shots of the Revolution! I suggest starting at the visitor center and then visiting the North Bridge last. If you're inclined, you can bike or walk through the main section of the park along a nice gravel path instead of driving to many of the sites in the park. I certainly plan on returning to the park in the future. Check the website for details regarding fees for the Wayside House but the rest of the park is fee free.

We only had two hours in Philadelphia, but we tried to make the best of it, we saw the Liberty Bell first, then we headed over to independence hall, but you needed ticket to get in, these are available in the tourist visitor centre, for free, but you get allotted times, which were a few hours in advance, so we missed out on that one. We did go on a tour of Congress Hall,that was alright, very historic still. Independence Square has a special feel to it, surrounded by historically significant, buildings, but try to make your way over to Benjamin Franklin's Post Office, on Market Street, it is a very memorable place.

On a recent trip back home to Massachusetts, we decided to visit some places I had never seen, although I grew up there. We started our tour at the National Park headquarters in Quincy. It was a little tricky to park and find the HQ, but it was highly worth the effort and the small fee for the trolley, which takes you to three homes, the first two homes of John and Abigail Adams, and the home of John Quincy Adams. All three are meticulously maintained and are hosted by knowledgeable guides. Make sure you plan your timing right, as there's a time limit with the trolleys. I was disappointed that we couldn't take pictures inside, particularly at the library at Peace Field - it was spectacular! Make sure you go to the United First Parish Church in Quincy to see where they are interred - that tour is offered by members of the parish for donations, and gives the visitor a true sense of awe for our founding fathers and mothers.

Fabulously interesting national monument. You don't even have to be a ten-year-old or a dinosaur geek to appreciate this unusual site and the steps that have been taken to preserve and interpret a slice of it. New building was great, and the interpretation and exhibits were first rate (exhibits also good in the visitor center). Two members of our party were disappointed by the trail from the dino hall back to the visitor center ... that could use more interpretation.

We went with friends this past week and had the BEST time! The white dunes are absolutely stunning and make you feel like you are on another planet. We bought used sleds for $10 each at the visitor center and had a blast sliding down the dunes. Just like being in the snow without the water and chill. A truly unique place to visit and definitely worth your time if you can stop by.

I honestly didnt think I would enjoy this attraction as it seemed so cliche, but I went thinking the kids would enjoy it. I was startled at how beautiful it is! Great evening program where they pay homage to veterans and the monument is lovely all lit up. We all enjoyed the visit and would go again if ever in the area.

It is easy to simply pass through Grand Teton Nat'l Park as the main highway offers nice views of the jagged mountains. However, it is well worthwhile to take the short road that runs along Jenny Lake as that lake is among the prettiest we have ever seen. One of the parking areas there allows incredible vistas of this beautiful lake with the impressive mountains as a backdrop. Trails lead down to lakeside and there is a great view just steps from your car. The lush trees in the area invite artistic views of the mountains and lake framed by the trees. Definitely worth a visit.

I've never been to a cave before, but this one seemed to be quite professionally set up. We took the moderate tour and that lasted 1.5 hours. There are lots of steps. We took an elevator down 240 feet and then started the tour! Everyone in our family enjoyed this, there were about 30 people in our group and that did not seem to be too many people. We especially were happy to get out of the 100 degree heat. It is 50 degrees down there and close to 90% humidity. The trail is all aluminum no-slip steps, and rough concrete paths. I didnt see anyone fall or even come close to that. you do want to make sure you use the restroom facilities before going... checking that your kids do too!(our 8 year old was really, really wanting to get to the surface after about 1 hour!) Also, this is a very good deal when considering how much everything costs around here. This was only $8 per person, NOTHING else so far has been less than $10 in the black hills area.

We stopped in on a Sunday before lacie day and missed the reinactment. It sounded as if it would be cool but we could not wait two hours. The ranger was friendly & showed us a movie on the event. We had no idea that this was an important site. Kids will be bos bored unless the is a special event. Donation admission
Came to Philly for a ballgame, but couldn't pass up the opportunity to try and interest and inform my 12 year old son about the great history and heritage of the USA,

this is a great area, and has not been crowded the two times i've been here. i had been looking for a cliff dwelling in southern new mexico and found this one. i'm not going into great detail about the site , as that has been done a hundred times already. there are also free camp grounds in the area, most not for big rvs. last time i tent camped in the fork campground, next time will try the grapevine. very few people were in the campgrounds. it's a slow, but pretty drive up to the site. i got in on the middle of the 1p.m. tour and the guides are well informed and do a great job. time permitting they will answer any questions anytime of the day. THE ONE BIG THIG IS, THAT AT CERTAIN TIMES OF THE YEAR, LIGHTNING CAN CLOSE DOWN THE TRIAL. seems to be more in the afternoon, but check the website. the cost is very low, and the golden age pass is accepted.

The better prepared you are to explore lava tubes, the more you'll enjoy this park. (There is great hiking and historical sights, too, but I was really impressed by the stuff underground.) You'll want several lights. The Visitor Center will let you borrow -- free of charge -- big, bulky lights. Having your own smaller, LED light (or headlamp) can be simpler and lighter (bring backups and/or batteries). I highly recommend a helmet (I used mine several times). Bring gloves and knee pads if you want to really explore. Many of the "advanced" and "expert" caves can be entered by beginners (you just won't go as far or see everything, but most are at least worth checking out). Definitely check in with the visitor center to see which caves are open that day, and what their suggestions are for you.

After seeing photos of Mount Rushmore in history books all of your life, expect that the monument will seem smaller than you expect it to be! Don't get me wrong, it is still amazing and definitely worth a visit. On this trip we included the evening program at Mount Rushmore because we had heard that it was very beautiful with the monument lighting ceremony which was begun at 8 P.M. Actually, the entire ceremony lasted about 90 minutes. It started with a history talk by the ranger at the beginning, then the lighting ceremony & patriotic music, and lastly, a call for all veterans to come to the stage to be recognized by their name, rank, and service affiliation. As you can imagine, this took a long time. There were many families with young children & I think they were getting a little antsy by the conclusion - if you have young ones, I would recommend leaving before the vets portion of the program. The monument is free but the cost of parking is $11.00. Be sure to remember where you parked your vehicle - yes, it took us a while to find ours! If you go at night, I would recommend staying nearby in Keystone as it was about a 30 minute drive in the dark back to our Rapid City motel. Keep in mind that there are many deer nearby & in the roads at nightfall, so the drive can seem longer than it actually is!

We went on the "historic tour" for $12, it is a good 2 hours of walking through the caves with a very nice tour guide. Not strenuous at all, but some neat things to see. Definitely a good time when it's hot or rainy outside.
Don't miss taking the Million Dollar Ride from Durango to Silverton, Ouray, Telluride, Lopez etc. Spectacular photo ops, lovely western towns, etc. Well worth the time. Leave early and return late!

We were passing through on our way back home and decided to stop here since we were so close. I am so glad we did. It was very easy to get to with lots of signs. It was a pretty drive to the park as well. We went in the early afternoon. The traffic was not bad getting into the park. They had a really nice little town before the park that was full of places to eat and buy souvaniers. It was $11.00 to park, not bad. The park was clean. Other than it being smaller that I had pictured it, it was really a very cool experience. When you see it on TV it looks like it is a massive mountain. But it is not quite as big as it appears on TV and in pictures. I am so glad we stopped here. A once in a lifetime experience....
Easy to get in and out. Parking fee is pretty high, 11 dollars, but it is valid all day. Recommend to go early in the morning for great pictures and attend to lighting ceremony in the evening.

This was our first visit and will not be our last for sure. What an amazing part of history. The park itself, even on a rainy day had reenactors onsite in the encampments and buildings to give background and answer questions. Photographs are permitted everywhere in every building ( something very uncommon anymore at historic sites due to restrictions on flash or insurance issues). The park tourguides themselves were also on hand and very knowledgable and animated in their presentations. The drive tour is free and you can access info at each stop via cellphone. Or you can purchase a more detailed driveguide via cd for about $15. Very similar to Gettysburg. Their is also plenty of areas for cycling walking running picnicking and a host of other outdoor activities. Washington chapel is on the tour but is not part of the NPS and the church charges a $2 admission fee..well worth the small donation. The architecture is fantastic and the folks providing info about the church know their stuff. Even in the pouring rain ( which it did for most of our visit) you can still enjoy the entire area. A trolley tour of 90 min is also available for a fee of $16 for adults and $12 for children. But check as prices can change.

This was a fun family Labor Day weekend trip with 3 other families. 18 of us aged 45 thru 6. We arrived late Friday night to Grants Grove Village for our lodging. We picked this location because it was a great center point for all we wanted to see and do. The lodging for the four families different areas but so close we all walked the 50 yards to and from the different camp sites. We stayed at the John Muir Lodge, Tent Cabins and Camp Cabins. The Lodge is your basic hotel with an nice cozy gathering area. The Camp Cabins are clean, warm, and the wood burning stove was a must have for our group. The tent cabins were a step above Housekeeping Camp in yosemite and was perfect for the price. The tent cabins also have the nicest showers (compared to the Camp Cabins).

We went on August 10 and it was very hot. In the morning around 10am, we went to the Bear Bulch Cave from the east entrance. The park function on an honor system, so you pay the park fees at the visitor's center. There is a restroom facility at the parking lot where the Bear Gulch trail starts. The hike was not far (less than one mile for sure) and when we got to the cave, it felt like it had air conditioning!! We didn't want to get out. The upper half of the cave was blocked off though because bats are still hybernating in there. There are concrete steps inside the cave. The cave itself was nothing spectacular; just more like a vertical cave where you see a little bit of water. We didn't get our shoes wet at all, but I think that's because we went in the summer. We drove back to King City for lunch and went to Balconies Cave (west entrance) in the afternoon. There is a brand new visitor's center at this entrance. Since we've already paid the admission when we went in throught the east entrance, we didn't have to pay again. (I think the ranger drives around the parking lots to check if you have the receipt taped to your window). You need to take the road going to the Balconies Cave trail all the way to the end where there is a parking lot. I can't remember if there was a permanent restroom there or porta-potties....I am leaning towards porta-potties. The hike was also less than one mile, and the Balconies Cave did not feel air-conditioned like the other one. However, I found this cave more interesting. There are many huge rocks (some very round) which have fallen from above and have gotten stuck, forming the talus cave. Some portions of this cave are quite dark, so you should have a flashlight. At a couple of spots, you really have to climb up/down by stepping on rocks. The climbs are short though, probably less than 8 feet. We did not encounter any bugs or insects or snakes inside the cave. The cave is not long, just right for little adventurers. If you have an agile kid, I think an 8 yr. old will do fine, but make sure it's the dry season. Some of the rocks can get pretty slippery if wet. From King City, both entrances are a little bit over an hour away. You cannot drive from one entrance to the other....but you can hike across (they say it'll take you a few to several hours). If you want to visit both entrances, I think King City is the best place to stop for a bite to eat. There are no restaurants at the park. At the east entrance, two people manned the visitor's center; at the west entrance, one person manned the visitor's center. Oh, and there is no cell phone reception for T-Mobile or Verizon at the park. However, I was told that along the road before you turn into the east visitor's center, there is reception for another carrier...maybe AT&T?

We stopped at Harpers Ferry on our trip from NY to Atlanta. Thought we would just grab a bite for lunch and move onto the Skyline Drive. Once we found out that there was no parking in town, and that you had to take a shuttle bus from visitors parking, we almost left. That would have been a mistake. Fantastic views of nature combined with quaint village and historical sight. If you are ever in this area, don't drive past here. Best part was we got in for $10 since I was able to buy a lifetime senior pass (age 62) for national parks.

This is one of those places that I could go back often, and be perfectly content to just sit & stare at that very blue water. If we weren't on our way south-to-north, I would've liked to ride the Trolley one day, hike some trails on another, etc. I had to hold myself back from taking gazillon pictures - there are just not enough words to describe the ambience. My advice to those thinking of this visit: plan on taking your time to let the beauty impress you. The $10 entry fee to the park is good for 1 week, so you can go on more than one day.

The tent cabins at Colter bay are spacious, clean, easy to 'live' in. They have a wood burning stove to heat the inside, a firepit and picnic table outside. Reasonable price. There are 4 fold down bunks, or do like we did, and bring your air mattress for the floor.

Just happened to hear about this on Tripadvisor. The drive was a little far from downtown St. Aug but worth the trip. The only cost was the gas to get there. The fort is in great shape, you won't need more than 30 minutes to explore it. There were no lines, no waiting.

This is a must-see in person, it's beautiful. The viewing area is convenient to get great photos, and the historical information available at the site is thorough and interesting. No admissions fee, only a parking fee. If you want to avoid the crowds/car jams I recommend getting there very early. I arrived at 8am and had maybe 50 other people there. By the time I left (8:30am) there were many cars lined up waiting to gain entry and heavy crowds were moving into the viewing/shopping areas.

Having visited most all the main attractions in Colorado, we decided on the spur of the moment to visit this park. About three hundred & fifty miles from Denver by way of Tennessee Pass, this is a wonderful relatively not well known Nat. Park. The South Rim entrance is a short drive from the main hwy.& what a surprise. Similiar to the Grand Canyon in depth, but the magnificence of the sheer walls of multi colored rock far surpasses anything in the Grand Canyon. Very well kept roads, very clean restrooms throught out the park & Rangers who were very helpful with information. You can drive down to the bottom of the Canyon, but the drive is posted as 16% grade & it looked to be more than that in several places, its not for the faint of heart as my co-pilot said.. There are plenty of Motels in Gunnison & Montrose to accomodate any size party & reasonably priced. We were told the view from the North Rim surpassed the South , but the 92 miles around to the North Rim will be for another long weekend.

From some point of view I found it more impressive than Grand Canyon. Many views are simply magnificent. We visited both North and South Rim (not doable in one day), The North Rim is much less developed but I would say that it offers nicer views and better trails although the trail to Warner Point on the South Rim is also very nice. The entry fee is $15 per vehicle and cover both South and North Rim.

This place is fantastic!! We ended up visiting the park on November 11th, which was Veterans Day…so there was no admission fee. We stopped at the Visitors Center, which is just inside the park gates. We looked around a bit and picked up a map. Then we hit the road. We headed down Crater Rim Drive first, toward the Jaggar Museum. On the way, we stopped to check out the Steam Vents (easy walk from the parking area). It was really odd to see steam coming from the earth like that. This is where we got our first look at the Kilauea Crater…you can see it in the distance from a little viewing area near the vents. After our first look at the crater, we were so excited to see it closer!! We headed to the Jaggar Museum (when we visited on 11/11/10, Crater Rim Drive was closed beyond the Jaggar Museum). We got out of the car and walked toward the museum. This is the only place during our entire trip where we detected a sulfur-like smell in the air. Certainly not overpowering in any way - and once you pass the National Park sign for the museum, the smell went away. We walked around the museum to check out the displays. They have a bunch of huge rolls of paper behind a glass wall which appear to be tracking seismic activity all over the area. They also have some samples of lava for you to check out. There is also a small Vistors Center where you can pick up some souvenirs. Don’t plan to eat here – there is no food or drink. Then, the big moment….we walked over to the viewing area and there it was….the Kilauea Crater!! There was a vent in the crater with steam pouring out constantly (thankfully the steam was heading away from the viewing area). As of our visit, there was no visible, flowing lava here….just steam. But it is an amazing view. According to one of the rangers that was walking around, the lava is about 150 feet below the surface. I could have just starred at it for days. But, we didn’t have days….so we left the Jaggar and came back down Crater Rim Drive, heading back towards the Visitors Center and the Park Entrance.

The Redwood National and State Parks are absolutely amazing! I started the trip from the south on Hwy 101. The Avenue of the Giants is an incredible drive. Me being a forester from Louisiana, I was in complete awe of these giant trees. The trees here would fit underneath the first limb on most of these trees! The Lady Bird Johnson, Founders, and Stout Groves are home to some of the largest trees in the world, definetly check them out. The National Park is free, but the state parks require small entrance fees. There are some drive thru trees along highway 101, there are signs to them, and you can drive thru for a 5 dollar fee, kind of a tourist trap, but where else can you drive thru a tree? If you're ever in California don't miss this magnificent place, they will render you speechless!

We visited the monument on the Labor Day weekend. Very nice and attractive place. We reached Alamogordo around 3pm so got a chance to visit the monument for sunset. Entrance fee was $3 per person good for next seven days visit. The sunset stroll was very good and informative. After sunset they had a Music show at the amphitheater, it was very good especially listening to the music under full moon. Next day we started early in the morning, it was too hot to do any activities. Had to wait till it cooled of a bit to enjoying sledding. Picnic tables were very nice and attractive.

Being from the south I had always wanted to see Mt Rushmore. It was really awesome to see how large these figures are. We visited their gift shops and the prices were good. Watched a movie, didn't cost anything, about the people who worked on this project. If you visit Mount Rushmore be sure to visit their museum. Was very educational.

I had passed the signs to this National Park many times on road trips and made a point to stop this past summer. We were so glad we did. The park is so well organized and they have to be. There are over 350 miles of caves! We took the 2 hour historical tour and thoroughly enjoyed it. Two tour guides took us through 2 miles of cave and we saw stunning caverns, long low-lit passageways with fallen boulders, odd little crevices that we had to climb down into and shimmy through, and deep, dark holes with "waterfalls" that rose back up to the surface. Practically anyone could do this tour. An older woman in her seventies was in front of us and she struggled a little with the area that we had to duck down to pass through but otherwise she was fine. We were astonished by the darkness and with the way the cave just kept opening up to more and more fascinating scenery. There are many tours to take and many above ground trails to hike as well. Don't pass this unique experience by.

Spent an enjoyable 1/2 day at the west Pinnacles. No crowds if you get there early but by midday on a weekend it becomes busy. The scenery and solitude were fantastic. We took the high peaks trail which provided a good workout so morning with cooler temperatures is the preferred time. Be sure to take some water along. There is a modest entrance fee and well maintained restrooms. Trails are dusty and dry so expect to pick up some trail grit.

We stopped by here on our way to Yellowstone & I'm so glad we did. The colorful rock formations are spectacular. Most view points are now Handi-accessible with asphalt trails & hand rails on inclines. Bring lots of water in the summer as it can be quite hot. If you are disabled or a senior recommend you get a National park pass it will save you $$$ or if your going to visit more than one national park in a year... they have yearly passes as well. I'm Disabled so mine is a lifetime pass & is free and good for all National park entrance fees. to see everything not including some of the long trails plan at least a half a day. There was much wildlife running around while we were there ( deer, prong horn sheep and lots of ground squirls) Zion & arches are close & also worth seeing if your going to be in the area for a bit.

Firstly, we can't comment about parking as it was not required. Gift shop & visitors centre @ 1250 Hancock st was friendly and informative. Really good film show. Trolley to the houses was quick and easy from outside. Great guides to take you around the first two houses then another short trolley ride to the big house..... WOW! What treasures and detail to behold and the guide was again informative. Then short ride back... Absolutely worth the $5. Also when you've finished walk up to the gold domed church two minutes away, for a couple f dollars you will gain entry to the crypt where the two generations are buried and sit in the Adams family church pew!

Active and retired members of the military were recognized during the lighting ceremony, bringing tears to my eyes. The carvings are magnificent, but the area was very crowded - much better and a little cooler when we went during the evening. $10 for an entire year admissin is such a huge bargain.

For $11.00/annual pass, you get to see this magnificent display and I actually got goosebumps walking up to it! There is a light show with ceremony apparently which we didn't get a chance to check out, but heard it was pretty cool! They have a museum as part of the exhibit and rooms with little 15 movie clips about the creation of Mount Rushmore, very fascinating. There was also an Artist Studio which housed a replica of what Mount Rushmore was suppose to look like if it was completed. A lot of historical facts, known and unknown to me!! Must see and you can't beat the price!!

Would rate it 3.5 stars... good place for walking, biking and horseback riding... seems a little light on the history part, but that's me... I grew up near Williamsburg and Jamestown... it is a huge park and you can usually see deer and other wildlife around, but is mostly open fields with a few log cabins and some houses where George Washington had his headquarters... so that is pretty cool.

Fantastic views. Breathtaking picture opportunities! great signage and very clean. Ran into some Park employees and they were very helpful. I would definately rate this as a must see on any trip to Alaska.

If you are traveling in the area, Mount Rushmore is simply a must-see, and everyone visits. However, for a national monument, I thought $11 for a couple hours to look at a giant statue was a bit much. I know it's good for the entire calendar year, but really, how many people visit Mount Rushmore multiple times in a year?

The Visitors Center and the film in it are very good, but the exterior- the actual battlefield - is poorly planned for visitors. The website said that there is a self-guided tour that can be taken by car and that an audio tape or CD can be rented for that purpose. But they had only a $20 CD for sale, nothing for rent. We bought the $20 CD but found that it was not possible to tell which of the tour stops (numbered on a map) each CD track was talking about, so we ended up not using the CD and wasting our $20. Also, the website said that they encourage people to walk or bike on the self-guided tour, but there is no walking/biking path - one has to walk or bike on the very narrow road used by cars, which would be dangerous ( We saw nobody walking or biking). Also, along the self-guided car tour, there are many roadside signs explaining what had gone on at that part of the battlefield, but these signs were far from the parking areas, and it would have been dangerous to walk on the narrow road from the parking area to the signs. The road was too narrow to park near the signs in order to read them - we would have blocked traffic if we had done so. Very poorly planned out site from the visitor point of view.

This is a free attraction - you may have to get a complimentary ticket to reserve your time for the tour but you should get right in. The whole neighborhood reflects the 1800's, and it's fun to visit the adjacent shops, etc. The tour of the house is fascinating. They have preserved furniture, wallpaper, etc. and it's fun to imagine what life back then was like. Be sure to check out the outdoor privy! It's a triple holer! Note, though, that there are tiny stairs to get upstairs, and that wouldn't be handicap accessible.

When we last went to Mt. Rushmore almost 35 years ago, there wasn't anything more than a rudimentary parking lot and a gravel path to lead you to the base of the monument. As I recall, it was free, so the $11 annual parking fee was a bit of a shock on this return trip. And, because it is a (private) parking fee, our Senior National Park Pass would not cover it.

Start here at the visitor center to get information on Boott Mills, a Jack Kerouac self-guided tour or a NPS canal tour. Movie showing background of Lowell and another movie with Lowell scenes and Jack Kerouac's words. Read the NPS site on how and wear to park, we put directions to the parking area into our GPS, found it no problems. Free parking when you take your ticket into the visitor center for validation. Nice place to park and walk over to Merrimack street for lunch too. Read reviews about Boott Mills for more info on this attraction.

I have an annual park pass and for some reason this park isn't covered which is just a con really. I drove slowly enough round the edge to get good pictures and read about it on wikipadia, I think $80 is enough for them to have from me already.

This place is beautiful! I really wanted to drive down to the bottom but after driving the million dollar highway i was a bit nervous, so we didnt do it...It was so amazing from the top! Next time for sure driving to the bottom

We did the Scenic Tour which is 1 hr 20 minutes. This is a moderately strenuous activity according to the ticket window and they were right !!! Remember once you start the tour, you can't just stop if it is too much. You are stuck and have to finish. The park ranger was very good - enthusiastic and funny. If you think they may be too much for you, there is a shorter (20 min.) tour that is much less demanding.

We went to this mission as it was being restored (and that's a blessing) but we're unable to enjoy the mission except from a distance. Compared to San Xavier to the north, this is much more rustic, but beautiful in its own right. We weren't charge an admission fee as construction was underway, and we're sure this will be a gem once restoration is complete.

We visited Mt. Rushmore during the day and the lighting ceremony was talked up so much, we decided to come back and see it. The easiest way to get through the traffic (and there is a lot of it) for the lighting ceremony is to buy your pass during the day and then show your pass when you come back for the ceremony. It's a whole lot easier that way. Parking was very easy.

We took a daytrip to Cumberland Gap National Historic Park driving Hwy 58 from Kingsport TN to the park which was gorgeous. There was little traffic and it was an easy drive with beautiful views. The park visitor center is not to be missed - see the film (about 20 minutes) which is free and explains the history especially involving Daniel Boone. There are other exhibits in the visitor center along with a gift shop. Very helpful attendants too. Make sure to do the drive to Pinnacle View - it is only about 4 miles from the visitor center and though there are some hairpin turns, it is not too scary. There is a short walk (about 200 yards) from the view's parking lot - all paved nicely. You are in KY and VA on the walk to the view and then can see stunning vistas of Virginia, Tennessee, and Kentucky. There are lots of hiking trails in the park though we didn't do any besides the Pinnacle. Admission to the park is free. A wonderful short trip for us, going home by way of Hwy 25 and then 11E. We stopped at Morristown for lunch at the Java Garden. A nice day trip.

First time after wanting to see Mt Rushmore for about 50 years. Not at all disappointed. Went during the day and then again for the Lighting Ceremony. Yes the parking is $11.00 but then parking in any large city for a day is more than that. The pass was good for the rest of the year and we used it again for the lighting ceremony. The ranger presentation is great and the film was very interesting. A real history lesson for us Canadians. Have driven by the Memorial about 6 times this week - can't seem to get enough of it. Going back today for one last visit before we leave this area. Only downside was the restaurant being closed when we went for the lighting ceremony - but the buffalo burgers at the little stand were great.

I have to admit that we had never heard of Capitol Reef until we decided to spend a month exploring SW Utah. Although all of the Utah national parks relate to the geology of the Colorado Plateau, each one has been preserved because it is different. Capitol Reef is newer (1971) than its national park siblings in the state and, by comparison, suffers from the fact that it is huge and doesn't have as many well marked vistas that you can drive to and take a picture at. Not that it doesn't have absolutely stunning views, but they aren't the great amphitheaters of Bryce or the temples of Zion. The majesty of Capitol Reef is the fact that it is literally a hundred miles long! Some tour guides mention that it is better appreciated from the air than at ground level. Although many people probably just stop at the visitor center and then continue across the park on Route 24, you won't appreciate the geology nearly as much unless you drive on at least a portion of the scenic drive. It's only from the drive that you can truly see the extent of the cliffs that are the primary feature of the park. If time is limited you don't have to drive the entire distance; it's only a $5 fee so it's not a big expense even for a shorter drive. When you do drive across on Rt24 be sure to stop at the petroglyphs; they are the easiest to get to ones we've found anywhere in the SW.

Three friends and I visited Mount Rushmore National Memorial in late July. I can't say I was disappointed, but at the same time I wasn't that impressed. There is a small charge to park at the monument ($11, for a car), but the actual admission is free. You can see the monument as you get closer to it while driving which kind of makes it less exciting when you arrive. The memorial looks just like you expect it to look. There is a nice easy to use walkway that circles the area with information about the monument and different view points, but you can't really get that close to the sculpture. We stayed for the lighting ceremony and while I thought the presentation was nice I was expecting much more. It was a cool sight to see, but once you've seen it I don't know if you'll ever need to go back (I know I won't). There is a cafe with typical cafeteria foods (burgers, chicken, etc.), drinks, an ice cream shop, and a gift shop. Everything is overpriced but that should be expected. If you really want to visit Mount Rushmore I recommend spending a few days in the region so you can visit other attractions.
Don't miss this attraction if you're in the area! Parking was easy, food was typical park fare, but with a great view. Take the walking path to the monument, it's worth the trip.

This park is a must see for history buffs. The state flags and dates they entered the union are impressive along with the artist studio. Spend some time in the studio and ask questions. This place is very important. Catch a ranger doing art, take the path closer to the faces or just sit and admire. Great photos everywhere. We had the National Park Senior pass we bought for all park entry ($10) but be prepared to pay about $11 for parking.

While a little out of the way, this National Park is worth going to. Crater Lake itself is an amazing site, plus there are spectacular views of the surrounding mountains on a clear day. We took a two-day Amtrak trip to Crater Lake (and Klamath Falls), so we did not have a car to get to the lake. Instead we used the Crater Lake Trolley to get up to the lake (about 1 hour ride) and to take the tour around the rim. It was outstanding. A volunteer National Park guide boarded the trolley and provided excellent information for two hours about Crater Lake, its history, and the geology. We made many stops to view the scenery and learn about prominent points. The cost of the rim tour was $22 for seniors and was worth every penny. The lodge is beautiful and worth exploring also. Although we didn't have time to hike, there are many trails of varied length and difficulty. One could easily spend a full day exploring this treasure.

Stopped by Jewel Cave National Monument on our way to Mt. Rushmore; we're glad we did. Turns out Jewel Cave is the second longest mapped cave in the world. We took the Scenic Tour($8 each for adults); the tour is about 90 minutes long, with a park ranger as guide. Pretty amazing sights; would recommend
Relatively easy hike to see two spectacular falls. Fun drive from Sisters, OR on Route 242 over the MacKenzie Pass and lava fields.

This was AWESOME, AMAZING, and quite HUMBLING!!!!! The monument is just undescribable .... no matter how many different photos you look at of Mt Rushmore, you will never get the same effect as being here and seeing it with your own eyes!!! The park is very well maintained and clean, considering there is no fee to get in that is a testament to the dedication of the people who work there!!! There IS a fee for parking ($11) but once you pay it, your parking pass is good for the rest of the year....not too many places that can make that claim!!
This is on the West side of town and very easy to do. Kids will love it, but don't take rocks or you could get a $25,000 fine! ( you can get some volcanic rocks just outside of the park)

The National Battlefield at Antietam is a beautiful historic park kept in its original state. There are no housing projects, freeways, or anything else that distracts the visitor from submerging into the sobering experience of what happen over 150 years ago. Cornfields, houses, churches, bridges, etc. are intact or restored and open to view. The Visitor Center offers a short film that is worth watching and also has many artifacts in an exhibit downstairs. I suggest seeing both before you set off on your tour. If you want a bit more history, go to the back viewing room (huge windows giving you a bird's eye view of the countryside and battle fields) where a ranger or docent will narrate and answer questions. The center provides you with a map that clearly shows roads and places to park your car for those that want to get out and read one of the many plaques posted throughout the park. There are so many statues, markers, monuments dedicated by various states and civil war divisions that it is overwhelming! Beautiful, but sad. Length of stay is totally up to the visitor. Go as fast or as slow as you like. Roads clearly marked. Restrooms available. Handicap accessible in places. There is a fee. (Do not forget to visit the National Cemetery in Sharpsburg. Parking free. Access free.) Soldiers slain in the battle are buried there.

We went to Valley Forge National Park to kill a few hours with a walk and a look at the sites. We decided to rent bikes. There is a well marked 5 mile trail for bikes, families with strollers, walkers, & runners. The bikes were $10 an hour and excellent quality, easy to rent. We decided to go off the beaten path. Our 5 miles turned into 15 as we kept making left turns to see what was down that path into the woods. We ended up discovering wonderful 200 year old houses & farms, maintained by the park, and completely off the beaten path. I understand why the Park does not advertise these beauties, they are not set up for tourists, but if you love old houses and the feeling of being in a place that hasn't changed in 200 years try foraging through the woods to find these spots! There are trail maps,(for when you go off the 5 mile trail), that are NOT well marked, but they do generally tell you where these spots are. We went on a glorious fall day and spent 4 hours getting a great workout.

My husband and I LOVED Bryce Canyon. We had come from the Grand Canyon South Rim, so we didn't think it could get any better! We arrived right before sunset, so we drove in to get a glimpse and try to catch the sunset. The weather was not on our side and didn't get to see a sunset, but it didn't matter because our jaws were on the ground at the hoodoos. The fogged rolled in and the sky was dark, but still amazing! We didn't get a sunrise either and it rained almost the entire day we were there. Usually rain would ruin a vacation, but it didn't matter here because every view is spectacular and it didn't get us down. We stopped at Ruby's to buy a rain poncho, but I highly recommend packing your own rain gear if it's in the forecast because the quality of the cheap ones is not that great and I tore it half way through the day.

My friend visited here with his wife and two sons all the way from Texas, so I went a long. The caves are amazing, and if you want to explore, bring proper gear and clothes, like gloves and long sleeved shirts, and flashlights. You can rent some of those goods at the visitor center, but it's better to bring your own. I hard hat is worthwhile too. The caves were exciting and nice to cool off in from the hot July sun. Went to the talk about the Modoc war in the evening which was very eye opening to the history of the area. The night sky is very beautiful and intense. The campsites are only $10 per night, which is a bargain in California. They are fairly spacious and have picnic tables, fire pits, a hand water pump adjacent, and clean latrines nearby. Very remote park with ancient beauty.
$11 to get in. The museum was really neat, the view is unbelievable. My 6 & 4 years old had a wonderful time. They liked the Indian village, the museum and hiking the trail.

If you have never been to Crater Lake--GO! It is not a hiking destination, although there are several good hike and walks. Be sure to take the time to visit the Pinnacles--they are very different from anything else in the Park. If you opt (I would) to stay in Crater Lake Lodge pay the small extra fee to have a room overlooking the lake. And be sure to get up before sunrise--if there are clouds you will get pictures that willamaze you.

It was an amazing experience to walk down the crater to the lake. We took the boat tour (very good) out to Wizard Island (Mt. Mazama) and were dropped off for three hours - we climbed to the top and back down again - wonderful anguish! Although there is no hurry on the climbs, I suggest you wear the right shoes, suscreen, set a pace, bring water and a snack...and expect to stop regularly for both air and the wonderful views. Well worth the effort and the price.

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: Regardless of political views it is always fun to visit Presidential homes or memorial sites. We took the drive through the ranch and listened to the free CD provided ****You must get a pass from the visitor center before entering the property and the driving tour is free. There is a 6300' runway on the ranch where the president and guests used to land. It is now only used by LBJ's grandsonThe house tour was very interesting to go back in time to the 60's and remember what our furniture used to look like and how they lived behind the public scene. It was very auhtenticly preserved. I was having trouble with my back that day and got behind with the tour. The guide took us around after the tour was over so we could see what we missed.

We spent about an hour and a half at this historic site. There is a great movie in the Visitor's Center about Abe's life and how he got to the White House. Several of the houses are open for self-guided tours and the tour of the Lincoln home is led by a very knowledgeable and friendly park ranger. It's a great field trip for those interested in Abraham Lincoln. The house tour tickets are free, but they do "sell out" early. We got there at 1:50 and had to wait until 3:30 for our house tour. The rest of the tours booked up very quickly after that and a "sold out" sign went up on the door. Parking was $2.00 and the rest was free. You could leave a donation after the house tour to help fund additional restoration projects. The gift shop was great too. It was filled with many books on Abraham & Mary Todd Lincoln along with other memorabilia.

I had been to Oregon many times to visit family but never did I know this place existed. This is the number 1, a must, to visit if you ever get the chance. Crater Lake is absolutely beautiful. No words can express the beauty of this grand lake. If you go do the drive around the entire lake stopping off at all of the places mentioned in the guide you receive at the ranger's station. The cost of $10 is well worth it. Make sure you have your camera on hand.

We arrived on Monday and before we left for vacation, we had gone to their website and decided which cave tour we wanted to take. They are divided into catagories that have descriptions such as...easy, strenous, very strenous, etc. When we arrived, we checked the board to make sure the tour we wanted was available. It was listed so we proceeded to the ticket line. We waited in line for tickets no more than 10 minutes which is definitely a plus. (But I should mention here that it was raining so maybe that's why there weren't too many people there.) When it was our turn and we told the cashier which tour we wanted, she informed us that the signage was wrong and that tour was not offered during the week. We picked that particular tour because it was only going to take an hour and 15 minutes and also because it was described as "easy". Our choice when she told us the tour we wanted was not available was take another one or leave. We chose to leave because we had other places we wanted to see that day so it was a waste of time for us to go there, but I'm sure had the tour we requested been available, it would have been nice judging by what we saw on the website.
Expands on your experience after visiting the Lincoln Museum (and before the grave site). If you're in town, don't miss it...you've got no excuse--admission to the house is free.

Lava Beds is a great destination although no more than 1 day of activities. The caves were awesome and the landscape is gorgeous in an unforgiving sort of way. The park staff generously allowed us to pay later.

What a great place...if you are a proud American like my husband and I are, it will move your heart. The presidential faces are so regal and so beautiful--be sure to look at them up close and you will marvel at the detail. Seeing all the flags of each state is fantastic. One warning--if you are going to stay for the evening lighting ceremony (which I HIGHLY recommend), BE SURE to take a jacket or sweatshirt. It gets pretty chilly in that outdoor amphitheater, even in warm weather! It lasts for about 45-60 minutes and consists of singing, presidential trivia, and a video. It will all put a lump in your throat, believe me. The parking costs about $11, but the attraction itself is free. Absolutely beautiful!!

I last saw Mount Rushmore when I was 8 or nine years old. At that time it still had the Lodge that was in the Cary Grant-Hitchcock movie, "North by Northwest". the lodge is gone now and replaced with an approach lined with columns inscribed on each side with a name of a state and year of admission to statehood. the state flags are at the top of these pillars.

Of all the federal holes in the ground...Bryce is by FAR the prettiest. Take your car up to the highest point and then work your way down as all the look-outs are on the RH side as you descend the highway. You pass through Red Canyon on the way and this is extremely beautiful as well. Again, if you have the Federal Geezer pass there is no admission charge.

If you can only visit one cave in the Black Hills area, choose this one. More varied formations than Wind Cave and the ranger staff really enjoys giving tours. The movie was excellent and the narration on the scenic tour (90 minutes) was first rate. Has 700+ steps but they are in small groups with lots of stops so that you don't notice them.

We spent a long weekend exploring Cuyahoga National Park (between Cleveland and Akron). This is the first National Park I've visited where you hear a lot of road noise. Major highways run over and around the park. Consistently travelled local roads run through the Park. In the beginning, this was a turnoff but after a few hours I didn't seem to notice as much. The Park has beautiful trails for hiking and biking. This is the first National Park I've visited where dogs are welcome on the trails -- I wished I'd known that ahead of time. There is an excellent option where bike riders with their bikes can hop the CVSR train for $2 and get dropped off at a distant train stop to ride the trail back to their cars. Interesting history on the Ohio canal. Cool waterfalls. The Farmers Market at Howe Meadow on Saturday morning was the BEST market I visited this year. We brought home apples, potatoes, zucchini, squash, raspberries, tomatoes, and goat's cheese. Yum! Yum! Yum! Overall, a nice place to visit for a long weekend.

2nd largest national forest in the nation, so don't expect to see it all. but what we saw was mag-by-god-nificent! Homer was our favorite city, followed by Seward and Anchorage. Best drive was up to Hatcher Pass out of Palmer. More fishing than you can shake a rod at, if you're so inclined.

My kids love to go here. A little commericalized as is with most National Park properties now days- lost the mission of providing a rustic appearence of the 1930's. The interpretive displays are well done and designed for 3.5 million visitors a year. The night lighting ceremony is excellent and when you can catch a "president" presentation- it is a treat. The parking fee was suppose to be temporary but the NPS must think that no one will notice the high price (we locals are not stupid). If you have not been there- it is well worth the visit- after that there are other places in the Black Hills that provide a much better family experience. The concession food is nasty (steam cafeteria style) and if you are truly starving to eat then go for it. Much better in Hill City and Keystone. Oh, and the Parks and Recreation membership does NOT apply to all parks- so ask the questions before you pay the big bucks up front.

We visited the Mt Rushmore Natl Memorial this August for the first time. It was a great experience, we are not Americans but as ever we were highly impressed by the nationalistic fervour of Americans. The Memorial is a well constructed and organized place for visitors, with lots of information about the creating of the sculpture, and the evening lighting of the mountain was spectacular. It is a gentle up hill walk from the parking area so even older folks should be able to make the trip. It cost us $11 for parking when we went in the late-morning and that ticket was still valid when we returned for the night show. Nearby Keystone through which we passed but didn't stay looked very interesting with numerous small stores and eating places and some nice looking hotels. The surrounding Black Hills area is beautiful and the scenic drives over the "pigtail bridges" and through some very narrow tunnels along the Needles highway were nothing short of spectacular. Nearby Rushmore Shadows RV Resort where we stayed is also highly recommended.

I knew of Harper's Ferry and John Brown/civil War but no where near to the extent that they played in the Nations history or the Civil War. The old town is very interesting and well done, full of neat shops, museums, history, scenic views and more. If in the area I would rate it a "don't miss" and if I'm ever in the area again I'll go there again!
You can get a multi pass for both parks definately should. We wanted to be able to go in to use as a short cut and had to pay again. SO much wildlife in the area.

I wanted to show my grandaughter one of Americas wonders during a trip to the midwest. On the way was Mammoth Cave Park. I have been going to this park from the time I was pre teen and that was in the 1950s. I have seen a lot change as time passed. But the main item, the cave still remains the best part. We took a light tour of four hours and viewed some of the History of the cave and heard stories and History from a very special guide. Our Guide was a direct decendent of the three original guides from over a hundred years ago. On our tour we viewed the large passages and areas where products used to make gun powder were mined. We also did some twisty cruves and climbing that was hard at times. But we survived and had a great time. Staying at the Park has many levels. In the past I have stayed in cabins that were very low end in price, and once in the big lodge that was high end on price. My favarite was the old Hotel now torn down. Food options are good with a reasonable priced full service resturant to a modern snak bar service. The full sevice resturant has a good but basic menu and is based on country family type foods. All very good and filling. Little stores abound to see any type of Tenn or cave rememberance there is. This is a more than one day and less than two day for a quick visit but my recomedation is to stay for three nights. That was one can enjoy a day under and a day over on a trail or river visit. They have a web site for information and it can be helpful but if you travel like me, it will serve only as a guide. If your going to stay in park you MUST secure the room, if not you will pay $$. The entire staff down to the kitchen staff have a very friendly attitude and seem to be sure to make the visit a good one. In my youth i used to do "wild" caving or spelunking as it is called. You can do some wilder caving here but need to be in much better shape than I am now. Go, enjoy, and experence wild America.
The walk is nice. You really have to pay attention to spot the etchings which is ok.

park: Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area
text: This park has fabulous views. Very clean and nice trails. Usually you will pass and meet others which gives a sense of security if help is needed.

Great National Monument but note that you must pay for parking. The Memorial is easy to view and there are good walking trails to get different views of the faces. The exchange students were impressed and really enjoyed it. Remember that any wildlife cannot be interferred with. The mountain goat eating the bushes cannot be disturbed.

Four Virginia guys, average age 68.5, left VA on 8-22-2012 and traveled twenty one states in twenty four days on our Harley's. Indianapolis Speedway, Sand Hills, Deadwood, Black Hills, Spearfish, Sturgis Canyon, Custer State Park, Devil's Tower, Big Horn Park, Cody, Red Lodge, Bear Tooth Pass, Mt. Rushmore, Crazy Horse, Yellowstone, Jackson Hole, entertained at Bar 'J' Ranch, Rapid City, Durango, Red River Mountain, Durango, Four Corners, Albuquerque, Santa Fe, Madrid, Amarillo, then back east to ride The Dragon in Tennessee. What an exciting trip covering 6,789 miles!

Was lucky enough to get here on a beautiful day in late September. I knew very little about the Battle of Saratoga and now know so much more. Get the vehicle pass - it's cheap - to drive around to the different locations. They're beautiful and it's interesting to think about what happened there. Unfortunately General Schuyler's home is only open certain days of the week and I wasn't there that day and only had about an hour to spend in the park on the drive. Would have been better if I had more time to spend.

What a great place to go. Make sure to start at the visitor center. Great historic building. Ranger was very helpful and informative. Rocky paths fairly easy to navigate. Don't bypass the Gift shop (extremely reasonable) Bought some CD's for $5.00 less than anywhere else. The Petroglphs are amazing and it only cost $1.oo to park and they were not too far off the parking lot to see some of the closer ones! There are several different trails varied in length. Talk with the ranger to decide what meet your needs.
Didn't like the fact that there were steep admission fees. The Liberty Bell was free to see. We even paid to see Ben Franklins grave site (but only $2).

Finally getting into Keystone, SD and checking into our room, we had a room with a view of Mt Rushmore. We drop off the bags and headed over tot he memorial as it was becoming dusk and at the memorial they have a lightning ceremony where as the sun sets and gets darker, they off lights and tell you the history of Mt Rushmore. As they finish up -they ask everyone to stand and join in with reciting the Pledge of Allegiance and then the monument is light up starting from the bottom. Visitors try to gather around the stone edge to look down into the amphitheater to see what is going on there. As much as this might be interesting, if you want good pictures, hang back a little for pictures. As for Carver's Cafe, if you want a snack then grab a bit here before it closes. Check with park as hours may vary. The cost to view the monument is $11 for car. If you have the opportunity, grab the opportunity.....
Be prepared for lines so plan ahead. It didn't take to long to see the Liberty Bell and it did not require a ticket like some of the attractions did.

It's free to get in but you have to pay for parking $10 which was good value. There is a multistory car park then it's a 5/10 min walk to gain a view of the 4 presidents. There is a visitors centre, but please note there will be a lot of school parties.

Every person should see Mt Rushmore and hear the story of how it came to be. You do have to pay for parking, but the pass is good for the entire day so we were there in the morning, then came back for the lighting ceremony. We highly recommend taking the free Ranger led tour (maybe an hour long) along the Presidential Trail. If you have kids, stop to get a Jr. Ranger book at the entrance so they can fill it out and earn a badge. The lighting ceremony at 9pm is very patriotic, with a 15 minute movie, flag ceremony, and members of the armed services are recognized.

When you enter the park you pay $25 dollars for a weeks pass which includes Yellowstone Park. We drove in to the park and within 5 mins out of the mist a stag appeared!! We then drove up the valley wow you can see the glaciers still in September.

best time to visit early morning or late afternoon. It was a great surprise for us to find this magic place. A must to visit if time too short to travel to Bryce Canyon. It is just a short drive up from the City. Ranger at the small visitor center are very helpful and knowledgeable. Entrance fee is $8.00 p.car

We almost always take our out-of-town guests to White Sands. When it is hot outside, we take the self-guided drive thru. If you can plan ahead, there are lots of fun activities: full moon night, evening bike rides, hot air ballons, etc. Check the website for listings. Free admission to the Monument with the National Park Senior Pass.

We like to include a little history into our vacations. The park is located on an active volcano, during our visit we only were able to see the "glow" from the Jagger Museum. The only visible lava was minimal. Not worth the cost of a heli tour, boat tour or private guide. That can change day to day. Pick out one of the more knowledgable Rangers to explain what there is to do. Numerous hikes, lava tubes, steam vents, etc. It really does get cold and it really rains a lot, so be prepared. The park is open 24 hours. The magnitude of this park is amazing, it tell's the story of how Hawaii came to be.

US 101 is called the Redwood Highway and runs the length of Redwood National Park. The redwoods flank the highway and you can view them right from your car. The ride is very enjoyable and peaceful. We went in May and there was very few crowds on the road and also in the grove. This is a 1 mile loop and very easy for walking. This is a old-growth forest and left in its natural state. There is a booklet available that explains all about the Nature Trail. There is no cost in this park.

We came on a Sunday morning in October, just after the 150th anniversary of the battles here. The weather was perfect and we bought the Auto Tour CD from the gift shop to explain the highlights of the self-guided tour in the car. The cost was $20 and well worth it. There are ranger-guided tours and based on our experience in Gettysburg, they are worthwhile if you have the time.

People, stop traveling to Europe, start traveling the roads of America. This is one of the most amazing sights not to be missed. Take a guided tour with one of the many college students and be impressed with their knowledge and pride of being an American and love of country. For only $11 (parking fee) you get to enjoy the sights but they offer good food, a well stocked store and you get the opportunity to meet one of the men who worked on Mt. Rushmore. If your lucky you get to see a mountain goat.

At only $8 an adult, this was a great tour. We went Oct 3rd and there was only 8 of us on the tour, we did not have to call ahead for reservations. With a small tour group we were able to go slower and learn more about the cave. Our tour guide, Melissa, was fun and knew her stuff. She tried to get everyone involved in the tour. The views in the cave are absolutely breathtaking.

It's a very large cave, so for those of you that are claustrophobic, I don't think you'll have an issue. I don't like enclosed spaces, but I didn't even really think too much about it when I was in there cause there's so much room around you, and it's well lit. The tour guide was awesome. Her name was Lydia, and she was extremeley knowledgable. She answered every question that was asked and spent a lot of time teaching and sharing personal caving experiences she has had. Great tour, only $8, tour groups leave often throughout the day. It lasts somewhere between an hour and an hour and twenty minutes. Jewel Cave is a little off the beaten path, but worth the trip :)
Amazing canyon, nice easy hikes with strategically placed benches so you can enjoy the view and solitude. A short ride from Flagstaff. $5 per person seems reasonable.

I am working on a contract a few hours away, so I have gone there a few times already. I took the Wizard Island boat tour, which was well worth the $42. We explored Wizard Island for 3 hours. Bring a picnic lunch to eat at the top of the crater. I swam in the refreshingly cool water, but wear water shoes because the bottom is rocky. We traveled around the rim and looked out at each viewpoint. We hiked to the top of the Watchman Peak to watch the sun set and the full moon rise, which was spectacular. The blue in the water is an incredible color and pictures cannot completely capture the reality.

I traveled through right after Labor Day in early Sept. Campground was pretty much deserted. Did not do the tour but the Rangers told me of another smaller primitive site for tents (no electric or fresh water) next to Green River. Envelopes and a lock box for a $12 camp fee. (honor system).
Loved the history and guides telling the story as you viewed Lincoln's home. Surprised there wasn't a charge but happy as everything else was at a reasonable cost.
It is hard to picture this place. Miles of white gypsum in huge dunes. You can get sleds at the entrance to ride on the dunes. If they charge a fee we didn't have to pay as we came on a weekday

After a visit to Yellowstone we made the drive to Mount Rushmore, with an overnight stop in Deadwood along the way. Keystone is a small town but quite a few hotels. Headed to Mount Rushmore around 10am. There is no entrance fee but parking was $12, which is valid for the calendar year, so keep your parking pass for a followup visit in the evening. Parking was not a problem, albeit a little walking involved. The visitors center is nice and staffed by pleasent folks. As you approach through a walkway edged with each state flag the magnificant memorial comes into view. It is quite astounding and worthy of many photos. We took the Presidential trail, which is a nice walking trailing affording various views of the memorial, many photo opportunities along the way. Hint, take the trail in a clockwise direction for less uphill climbing. The walk is easy with many rest stop benches along the way and if taken in a clockwise direction you are doing more walking downstairs than up. Take the time to visit the artists studio towards the end of the walk.
Went for apple picking on October 5, 2012. Got some very nice apples for $1 a pound. It was fun picking my own apples. The National Park Service provides the containers and the picking pole.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: We were lucky to experience two tours led by Warren Taylor who spoke with few notes for over 3/4 of an hour each time. He is one of the best tour guides we have ever met. His knowledge of the subject is first rate but more important, he speaks with emotion, evoking the pain of that time. The National Park Service has done a great job with the buildings, the reenactors and the diplays of artifacts.

If you are in western South Dakota, in the Black Hills you really need to take some time to see Mount Rushmore, even if it just from the highway. This is an American icon, though steeped in controversy, due to the desecration of a native American sacred mountain. However, a native American is now in charge of the park and they are finally beginning to relate the Lakota, Dakota and Sioux history and experience to visitors.

Unique park to visit and get close to active lava flows. One can also go inside an old lava tube and overlook volcanic craters. Entry fee is reasonable and not tourist gouging. Usual souvenir shops available. You can hike around if you wish.

I was there in late september 2012 to avoid the crowds...Ok but because of winter shutdown of the park only 2 campgrounds were open. Lots of wildlife, mostly bisons...nice autumn colours. Campgrounds without showers i found overpriced at 23$ and 20$ . Side gravel roads are open and in good shape. Lots of access to lakes and rivers for fishing and canoeing.

Do not miss this drive. We did the Durango-Silverton railroad the day before and were on our way to Ouray for the night. We followed the rr for a short time and then climbed high into the mountains. Different views than from the railroad car but spectacular. I am so glad we did both. It cost a million $$ to build this road in its time but worth every penny!!

The dunes were unbelievably beautiful. The dunes sit at the bottom of a basin surrounded by mountains. When it rains, all the water runs down to the dunes, therefore, the sand is moist and very cool. For hikers, there are trail markers, as it would be easy to get lost. The sand is incredibly white and the dunes reshape with the wind. There are some nice picnic areas if you bring a cooler. Next time we will be there when we can take advantage of the night programs. As awesome as it was in the daylight, I can only imagine how gorgeous it is in the moonlight. If you have a National Park Pass, it would take care of your admission.

I was somewhat disappointed by the fact that there aren't any easily seen hot springs in Hot Springs National Park. We learned from the 15 minute video at the Welcome Center that the main street where all of the springs used to be was covered over years ago to make room for more tourist attractions. The only way to see one of the springs is to go to one of the Bath Houses and pay to take a bath in it. My 8 1/2 year old and I didn't have the time to do that, so we toured the National Park building and saw all of the old tubs, recreational faciltiies and learned a lot of history without ever seeing a hot spring. It was a side trip on our way home from Texas to Ohio and I am glad to say we have seen another National Park, but it wasn't really worth the added time or expense. Just a word worth noting: there was a sign in the Welcome Center that said the building was going to be closed soon for remodeling so I would call ahead to see if it is open or not.

Whether you go the loop (1-2 days) or Durango to Ridgeway(few hrs), you won't be disappointed. The Million $ Hwy will take your breath away! Stop at Mola Pass and Red Mt. Pass and get your camera-WOW. Easy on those curves.

Awesome tour and a great price. It was just $20 for one adult, 3 kids over 6 and one under 6. This is one of the best bangs for your buck in the Black Hills area. We did the Scenic Tour which runs about an hour and a half.

Enjoyed the visit to the battlefield. Very well conserved. Purchased the $20 CD that gives you some additional audio as you do the self-guided driving tour of the battlefield. It gave quite a bit of additional info, but you could easily get a lot out of the visit without. Definitely worth visiting whether you're big into civil war history or not.
We spent two fascinating hours exploring this historic site. Very good visitors' centre and excellent video. Low entry fee makes this excellent value.

I had a day off from work and decided to go for a ride. Taking La Gloria Road from Gonzales over the Gabilan Mountains I turned South on Airline Highway and used our National Parks and Federal Recreation Lands Annual Pass at the Visitor's Center to cover the entry fee. After a little driving in the park I checked out the map and decided to park at the end of the road and take the Moses Spring Trail to the Bear Gulch Cave Trail. After going through the caves, I took Rim Trail back to the parking lot. Except for a small group of oblivious kids sitting on the trail eating their lunches, I had a good time. Remember to bring flashlights for the caves.

Four popular presidents are carved into the mountain.To reach the observation area,there is the Avenue of Flags that sets the symbolism of the sculptures.. There is a visitor center that will direct you to the museums,movies ,programs and all the info you would ever want to know..I recommend you visit in the morning when the sun is on the monument, to be able to really appreciate it..there is a cafe and ice- cream shop..to relax in. A parking garage remember where you park,,( I forgot ) And there are park rangers that have programs for kids..Even though it's a National Park there is no admission fee just a parking fee...This is definitely a must stop for a family...

Whenever we are in Key West, we try to get out to this national park. It is accessible by seaplane, ferry, or private boat. During our most recent visits we've used the park's high speed ferry service. Be sure to enjoy the views of ocean surroundings during the trip out and back as it is part of the whole experience. From the deck we viewed various wildlife, including boobies and frigate birds, dolphins, etc. The guide explains the history of Ft. Jefferson and the ecology of the Dry Tortugas while you're on the island and a lunch is served after, down by the shore. We used the snorkeling gear included in the trip price and explored along the fort wall. My floatation vest had a leak but it was no trouble to exchange it for one that worked. (P.S. Spelling on Tripadvisor for this attraction should be "Tortugas", spanish for turtles.)

Mt Rushmore was great,but could not walk on side trails due to snow. Keystone, the town at the base of the base of the mountain was closed except for a few small places which were closing the next week. Parking was $11.00

In the mid-seventies I dropped by this impressive site - very natural and fee-free. The information and viewing areas have been redone to made them look like any plaza next to the most modern skyscraper in a large city, replete with many flags and tons of flashy stonework. It rather overwhelms the experience of the sculptures. More egregious is the multi-level concrete parking garage - no attempt to hide it for what it is. There is a fee to park in it. I asked a ranger whether there is a fee to visit the memorial, and he said no - it's free. I asked about the charge for parking, and he said that's a private enterprise. I further asked him where the free parking is. He said there is none. I told him that the fee for parking is really a de facto fee for the memorial, and he got very defensive.

Beautiful scenery, less crowded than Bryce (and cheaper, if you don't happen to hit a public lands day). Aspen were yellow on the rim with spires of red rock at the "breaks." Not a lot of hiking trails in the immediate park. $4 fee for a week more than reasonable.

One cannot pass up Mt Rushmore National Park if and when in South Dakota. It is a site to be reckoned with. Magnificent and Majestic! I had to take my wife back on three occasions while in and around the Black Hills. We were able to see the last night illumination of Rushmore before closing for the season. Most moving. Do not rush through this site. Take the walk around the pathways leading around the four great Presidents. And please see the movie on the carving of Rushmore and the beautiful museum available to the public.

For the price of admission one gets a movie at the Adams National Historical Park Center and a two hour trolley tour to 3 Adams' houses. Rangers are at each site offering an interesting insight into the personal stories behind the history. All 3 houses are different, John Adams being born at one, bringing his bride into another one and spending his last years in the last and larger home with the original furniture. The larger house includes an English garden and a separate stone library containing 12,000 of Adams' books. The rangers were so knowledgeable and enthusiastic. It was the highlight of my 8 day visit to the Boston area.

My husband and I were on a road trip from Missouri to Wyoming. Our first stop was the Mt Rushmore National Memorial. You have to pay for parking but the attraction itself was free. We didn't stay very long but we received the purpose it served. One of the original drillers was in the shop and it was great talking to him. He told us what he did and the tools he used the 3 years he worked. It was really something. We also ate at their cafe. We had the buffalo stew...yummy. My husband and I enjoyed our stop and we can now check this off our bucket list.

We didn't swim at this park. We entered through the main park entrance and the historians were super friendly. They suggested entering the park through the neighboring harbor. That saved us at least 30 mins walking in the sun. There is a long area of hiking that you can explore along the beach and see ponds and ocean. Initially we saw tons of swimming turtles. Once we started our walk down the long sandy shore, we started seeing them resting in the sand. It was hard to pass them without disturbing, so we turned back.

I had heard about sledding at White Sands many years ago and have always wanted to go. My friends and I were not disappointed! Our Super 8 Motel in Alamogordo lent us three saucers and wax (which saved us about $45) and we didn't have to worry about being back at the gift shop at a specific time to sell back our saucers.

I first saw Mount Rushmore in 1958 as a 13-year old on a family motor trip to the West. I was excited to return on my motorcycle trip to the same area. Long story shortened: it was better the first time. Then: a drive up a long road, park in a lot (free parking), a walk through some woods and there it was! Now: a drive up a long road, park in a parking garage and pay $11 for my motorcycle (same charge for a car), then a walk through an elaborate and (in my view) unnecessary granite-paved plaza, and there was the same mountain sculpture. The magic sure was gone, and feeling that I'd paid $11 to some entity (not into the Federal treasury) left a bitter taste.

Getting a ticket for this tour was a bit confusing but after we finally located the National Park Service building things went very smoothly and our guide had both knowledge and a terrific sense of humor.
