Our family went on a day trip to Harper's Ferry. From Southern New Jersey, it was only about a 2 3/4 hour drive. We love historical places, especially the areas that had involvement with the Civil War era. The town of Harper's Ferry is a must see. Great little town with a lot of history behind it. The location is beautiful, sitting between two rivers and tall mountains. We paid $10.00 to park our car and took the "Top to Bottom" tour of Harper's Ferry. It was so interesting and the park guides were awesome!!! This is a must do if you are going to the town. The tour runs once a day at 11:00 am, and lasts about 90 minutes. Great little restaurants and shops are also scattered throughout the town. .

This is a great side trip if you're into scenery, shops, history and hiking. The Maryland Heights Trail is fun, with a spectacular view at the summit, but it is strenuous, so you have to be in decent shape. The John Brown Wax Museum was "ok", but overpriced,and not included in the park fee. It's short , and interesting . Some of the wax figures have darkened through the ages. The park fee is $10.00 and good for three days so that came in handy as we stopped by the next day on our way home, to walk another trail. There are also flat trail options there. The restaurant there in town, Hannah's, was very good.

Visiting Hawaii Volcanoes National Park was a very neat experience! $10 fee per car to enter the park. Although we didn't have the perfect timing to see lava, we saw lots of steam. Please see my photos to share in the experience. Nice walking paths, historical sites, panoramic views, learning to be had, and a fun family activity!

I did not, but I saw them at Bryce. They are vertical rock formations formed by the freezing and thawing of water. They have 200 days a year when it both freezes and thaws. The only other place on earth like it is somewhere in Turkey. Bryce is technically not a canyon, because there is no river. We went to Bryce for the hiking. We went in the fall so as to avoid the summer crowds, but it turned out to be busy then too, with older people (like us) and foreigners. I didn't think it was too bad, and because we did some of the more difficult hikes, we saw fewer people. There is a shuttle system in the park, but you can also use your car if there is room in the parking lots. We had no problem with that and did both. The in-park lodge is very nice, but we were happy with our less-expensive accommodations at the nearby Bryce Canyon Pines. I would also recommend the free narrated bus tour, which we did the first day to get the lay of the land. You sign up at the Visitors Center. I thought this park was the more unique of the two we visited this trip (we also went to Zion). Pay attention to weather averages because it can be colder here because of the elevation (8,000 feet), also be aware that elevation can cause problems if you are not prepared for it. Most of the viewing of Bryce is from the rim, but you can hike down into the canyon as well. If you are a senior citizen you can buy a Golden Pass, giving you free entry to all national parks. I would also suggest spending several days here. We spent three days.

This is a very scenic national park. It takes a long time to get to it, which is probably why it has a low visitation rate. My girlfriend and I thought we were on the planet Mars because of the unique rock formations. If you like to hike, there are plenty of trails to occupy your time. Make sure that you bring plenty of water. If you have a sense of adventure, you will have fun exploring Capitol Reef National Park.

Get your free ticket to go inside Abraham Lincoln's house. Thanks to his son, Robert Lincoln, we can visit the home for free. In it are some of the original furnishings and decor.. The tour guides are very knowledgeable. Photos are encouraged. Fee for the parking lot. One of three excellent attractions (Lincoln tomb, Lincoln-Herndon Law Office and Lincoln home) in Springfield.

We arrived about noon on Saturday, Oct. 13, 2012. Unfortunately all of the guided tours were already booked for the day so we took the self guided tour. It was interesting and easy to walk. However, we were only there for the one day and wanted to see more. The Park Ranger suggested Diamond Cavern which is a private cave. The tour was only $4 per person and is worth it.

Visiting Hawaii National park was a good experience and is worth the $10 admission fee for a vehicle if you are going with others. Unfortunately when we visited, about 1/2 of the crater rim drive was closed due to sulphur dioxide fumes. We drove the portion of crater rim drive to see the jaggar museum, view the active crater from a distance, see the steam vents, and the sulphur deposits; however, after driving first to the museum, we realized that you can and probably should just walk as there are a few trails through the rainforest worth seeing.

They have a nice informative film in the visitor center $6 per car. You also receive a drive thru map that is well marked with the stops in the national battlefield. Watch the film first, or look thru the museum area while waiting for the next film to begin, which is a reinactment of the battle in area that you will be driving thru. It appears you could just drive thru the battleground; but the film and map help to give you the history of what you are seeing. The park rangers were very friendly and helpful with any questions.

Did a day trip here and was definitely impressed by the park. There are lots of activities and things to see, definitely worth the price of admission. The Visitor Centers are clean and well staffed with up to date exhibits.

Have wanted to go here ever since we were forced to pass it by 25 years ago. Finally got there and it didn't disappoint. Also, finally got to hear what it sounds like when a rattlesnake rattles! We encountered 2 while walking the trail around the ruins. They were crossing the trail in front of us and rattled to warn us away. Per the ranger, in October they are migrating - moving back to their winter dens. In April they leave their dens so most sightings are in April & October. It was an additional excitement to seeing the ruins and learning about the people who left them.

On October 22nd 2012 we drove from Colorado Springs-about 8 hrs with "potty Stops", to the Memorial. It was a very tedious ride..we listened to an audio book. It was worth the drive. Once again the National Parks have done a wonderful job. Anyhow there is a museum, a movie, a trail around the base of the sculpture, a very nice Cafe ( had a piece of the Berlin Wall on display) and of course the Monument of Mt Rushmore itself. The builders' workshop, and many other pertinent items are also on the grounds.( We were unable to see the lighting ceremony in the evening due to lack of time) You come away amazed at what this team of men accomplished. Probably the highlight for us was meeting a gentleman (92 yrs old) in the gift shop who had worked on the carving crew for Lincoln and Roosevelt. He was signing copies of his book. Of course we bought one. Only $10.00. It is wonderful to read about this project from his perspective. We spent about 3-4 hours and felt we had done about everything. Then off to "Crazy Horse".

Go to the visitors center and watch the movie first. Good information presented well. If you want to play on the dunes, you can get a sled from the gift shop. You drive your own car out to the dunes for only $3. Stop as much as you want and walk around. It starts out a little less than spectacular, but gets better as you go out. 30 minutes If you never leave your car. Stay as long as you want and take advantage of the ranger tours, or stay for the once monthly full moon strolls.

Visited on an October morning when the wind was raging. But the sky was blue and the experience was amazing. We had heard that some people found it "underwhelming" but I think they must have been on an off day because the whole experience was fantastic. Did Crazy Horse on the same day and rate Rushmore much better.

This is an incredible National treasure. From the sheer cliff walls and towering ponderosa pines yourwalk a trail through history. Humans have left the marks on these stone walls for centuries and you will see dated scripts of the first spaniards to pass through the area in the 1500s to the US Calvary in the 1800s. Once you follow the trail to the top you will look into a beautiful box canyon and travel around to the restored ruins of the areas first people. The view is astounding as you look out over the canyons, mesas and rolling high desert. Watch elk passing through, and many birds and reptiles basking in the sun. Yucca plants, and prickly pear cactus, beautiful pines and cottonwood. You'll forever be changed.

Mammoth Caves is a very interesting NP with all it's various tours within the cave system. Although there is no admission to enter the park, you have to purchase a ticket for each tour, per person which adds up very quickly. My wife and I went on two tours, the "New Entrance tour" and the "Histroric Tour", and the combined cost of just those two tours for just the two of us was $48.00. If one were to come with their family and do multiple tours the price would be astronomical. This differs greatly from most other NP's which charge per vehicle, only one time for an entire week, all-inclusive.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: We really got the feeling of what it may have been like back in 1865. Enjoyed the presentations by the rebel and union soldiers. An inspiring national monument. Parks pass works here.

We drove to Walnut Canyon to get away from Phoenix and to see some colorful trees. We were not disappointed. The scenery was beautiful and the national monument was awe-inspiring. There is an admission fee of $5 a person but there was no problem in paying to help preserve a place as amazing as this one. It is a short drive up the freeway to the park and the monument is just inside. So, you can plan to spend to spend an hour or a day, depending on how much time you have to hike the trails. The canyon is deep and long with lots of wildlife. If you want to avoid the fee, you can drive to Old Walnut Creek Rd. It is not paved and has plenty of easily visible trail heads with parking for hikers To access it from US 40 take the exit for US 180 (Country Club Drive) and Old Walnut Creek Drive will be between the houses and the driving range.

Melrose is part of the Natchez National Historical Park, so the tour guides are either National Park Service rangers or volunteers who provide a historically accurate tour, rather than one filled with urban legends and myths. The history of the house and the families who lived there are interesting and intriguing enough -- they don't need artificial embellishment. The guided tour is certainly worth the fee -- and you're helping to continue the restoration -- and then, you are free to wander the grounds for as long as you like and visit the slave cabins and other buildings open to the public. The gardens aren't at their best in November, of course.

The entrance fee is free! Make sure you get there early as the tour groups are small and if buses are there they book up fast. Take time to see the movie that is offered at the visitors center, it gives you a better appreciation for the house. We took our young kids and they loved learning more about one of our greatest presidents!

Be sure to reserve your tour spot early as the popular ones sell out. There are several to choose from and I wish we could have gotten in one with more open spaces. We took the one 1 hr. 15 minute tour that was reviewed as an easy walking (some fairly slanty ramps though) tour for people who didn't like tight spaces. There were some areas that we had to duck down to pass through and while they wouldn't qualify as tight they were narrow. When the guide turned the lights off in one of the more open spots so we could experience total darkness for a few minutes I realized just how much I didn't like caves! Glad we went, however, no more caves for me.

We have visited the Antietam battlefield on a few occasions. Once we witnessed a large re-enactment that was awesome. It was truly living history. Even camps with civilians playing their rolls as I was scolded for having "demon rum" on me. They had cannons firing and hundreds of soldiers from both sides demonstrating the hell of war. On another occasion, we went to the Memorial Illumination that takes place at night where they light a candle in a bag and place them at every spot where a soldier fell that day, 23,000 of them! You drive the 5 mile course and as you pass so many of those candles, you can really see where the deadliest action took place. It's quite moving. This year it's held on Dec. 1,2012.
House was in great condition. Loved this site! Great guides. No fee, however donations encouraged. Make sure you see the Lincoln video before leaving the Visitor's Center.

This is a very easy ride from Boston on the metro. When you exit the station just walk straight across the main road to the visitor's center. I was on the 1st trolley of the day and it was only myself and one other couple. I saw the next trolley and it was packed. I have seen some that say skip the first 2 homes, but I found them very interesting along with the stories the rangers told. The Peacefield home is the highlight of the tour. Also, be sure to visit the church across the street from the vistior's center where you can (for a small fee) see the crypts of John and Abigail, along with John Quincy and his wife Louisa. Counting the metro time, you should at least allow for an entire morning or afternoon to see these sites.

Stopped by the visitor center, listened to a brief ranger presentation about the trails and petroglyphs, then headed to the trails of our choice. There are several trails available of varying lengtghs and difficulties. There is a trail for everyone - one was literally a total of about 30 yards while another was a 2 1/2 mile hike through the desert. All of the trails are interesting and you are virtually guaranteed to see petroglyphs at them all. It is very interesting to scan the rocks, locate the petroglyphs, and think about someone carving the figures in the volcanic rock long ago. It provided a pretty cool connection to the past and I thought it was well worth the visit. Be aware though that this is a fairly low-key activity and people with little to no interest in history may actually find it boring. The only cost is $1.00 per vehicle. As several others have noted, this exhibit is outside IN THE DESERT so it is usually HOT. Take some water, wear a hat and some sunscreen, and enjoy the petroglyphs and hikes.

From the views driving up to the Memorial, walking in and going through all the state flags, getting closer views to seeing it lit up at night - worth every moment! The price was great (FREE), with the exception of a one-time parking fee (good for a year), so you can go back as many times as you wanted. We went a couple of times, including back at night for the lighting ceremony (check the calendar for seasonal times). Very patriotic...makes me proud to be an American!! The pictures and stories from it's origin on site was very impressive! We also enjoyed the Ranger Tour (and the facts and views shared along the way to the Sculptor's Studio)! Awesome!

Only $3 per person to see this amazing world wonder. You can drive an RV (we have a 30' 5th wheel) in and around the loop. There are lots of pull outs more than big enough for an RV so you can get out and feel the sand for yourself. This sand is amazing - it's not hot! It's actually quite cool and doesn't stick to your bare feet. In shaded areas the sand is actually cold. There are sunset walks, overnight back country tenting, bugs and so on for different interests. There is a 15+ minute video (free) to watch first - it is well worth the time as it explains so much. Lots of locals go there for weekend picnics like others would go to the beach or the lake. If you have children, take a plastic sled - you can slide down the sand like snow !!

Definitely lives up to the hype. No charge to get in but there is a parking fee – for which you get a permit valid for the rest of the year. I went twice – on the evening I arrived and again the next morning. The evening talk and ceremony was very moving then afterwards the faces were illuminated.

Such a wow experience to finally see them yourself and just on TV. It is incredible to see the four heads carved into the mountain. Since it was already late that day I decided not to pay the 10$ parking fee and who knows if there is an additional entrance fee. I just stopped on the side of the road and took a picture. Of course if you have time and want to learn more about the background of Mount Rushmore, I suggest you actually park your car and go inside;)

Went on a Tuesday. Not crowded at all. Chose the historical tour. $12 adult. 2 hours long. Not real small places except fat mans misery. Lots of steps uphill so be prepared. On this tour you do not see the cave formations known as stalagmites & stalactites. You do see gypsum, old trees hollowed out to run water thru for the saltpeter process. Nicely guided tour. Don't forget the new museum with interactive displays. The visitor center is new and beautiful. Tip: if you go during summer months or busy times go get your tickets early as the tours do sell out. They had over 400,000 visitors to the park last year. Don't forget to see the mammoth cave railroad cars on your way into or out of the park. This use to be the way in before cars.

OK.. this is National Park #29 for us in our quest to see them all before we can't get around. Why we have driven past this one so many times and never stopped has me stumped. I think it is because we have been to other major cave systems and figured "seen one, seen 'em all." Couldn't be more wrong on that - this place is freakin' amazing. The ranger who guided our tour (the "Classic" tour) was great at his job and added a lot to the experience. We will absolutely go back to see other sections of the cave system - the historical uses and details are fascinating. One surprise is that the Annual NP Pass which we have did NOT cover the cost of the tour. Finally, when the ranger goes over the physical demands of the tour - trust that there is no exaggeration and if you don't feel up to it, choose a different tour. Your fellow visitors will appreciate it :-)

We went over fall break and ordered our tickets over the phone ahead of time. Good thing we did as most tours were sold out. We took the New Entrance Tour and Historic Tours. Tours were $12/adult, $8/kid.

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: Having lived through the tumultuous years of the Johnson presidency and the Vietnam War, I was quite interested to see his boyhood home and the Texas Whitehouse. The experience was very enlightening. Johnson was obviously something of an outsider in Washington -- rough and unsophisticated by Eastern standards yet his outsized ego, ability to read people and his uncanny political acumen elevated him to the presidency. Here, in his element, you see him, warts and all, as the larger than life figure he was. You can see and undersatnd the hard-scrabble beginnings and the over-the-top showmanship he developed at the height of his power. The old, tired 50's furnishings of the "whitehouse" contrast starkly with the airplane hanger he had built. The big cars and lavish gifts all were part of his "texas" persona. Its' all fascinating and it's all here. Our NPS tour guide was very good, knew a few stories to pass along and painted a well-rounded, even sympathetic, portrait of the president my generation helped driver from office in 1968.

Loved it!! It's on a nice piece of beach stretch. Not very busy on the roads. It's absolutely free which is the best part!! There is a nice little ferry that goes over. Make sure you stop in the little room to get your boarding pass (free) so you get on the first trip over to the Island. The fort itself is really cool and the firing of the canon was my favorite!! Would stop here again!

It was a very cloudy day and it was closed when we drove through. We were looking for the monument and out of the blue the clouds cleared and we were looking at the monuments. Beautiful! Also there is a road that each time you come or go out of a tunnel you look back or ahead and can see the monuments. LOVELY. No pics on this computer to share. We did not go in but still saw the monuments. There is a fee but just a drive by no cost.

Interesting place to visit if you are on the Big Island. I think you really need to do the Helicopter Tour to see the lava flow, but on the cheap, this is a good place to start. Very informative walking tours, well worth the visit.

I decided on this particular route after talking to some of the rangers at the Summit Visitor Center for advice. Their recommendations and warnings were spot on so I would like to pass them on to you. If you want to do some amazing hiking after watching the unreal sunrise at the summit and are in good physical condition I would highly recommend the circuit listed in the title. First obtain a trail map from the park rangers in the Summet Visitor Center. Next drive your vehicle down to the trailhead for the Halemau'u Trail. This will be about 3.5 miles from the Summit Visitor Center. The reason for doing this is to have your vehicle where you finish your hike so you won't have to try to hitch a ride back to the Summit Visitor Center at the end of the day. You will be tired, sore and very dirty! Once you leave your vehicle in the parking lot of the Halemau'u trailhead go to the main road up leading up to the Summit. There is a designated area that you can hitchhike a lift back up to the summit. You may have seen the sign for "Hiker pick up when you were making your way up. This may take awhile as no tourists want to pick up hitch hikers nowadays but someone will. I waited 30 min before a couple of local guys doing dry wall at the Science center picked me up. Get dropped off at the Summit Visitor center and the trailhead to the Keonehe'ehe'e Trail (aka Sliding Sands) is to the right. The is the start of your 11 to 12 mile journey so be prepared with fluids and warm clothing! The first leg of the journey will be about 4 miles and will take you to the floor of the crater. There will be a junction where a single large yellow flower bush is that is populated by a million wasps (so take care). Here you then cross the basin desert to the base of one of the cinder cones. Again you will come to a junction where you can either go left (the sign with say around take an extra 0.4 mile tour around the cinder cone by going right. This is what I did and I would recommend it as the views are worth it. While circling the cinder cone you will hit the Halemau'u trail. Kawilinau is the "bottomless pit" that you will see surrounded by a fence. Continue your counterclockwise journey around the cinder cone along the Halemau'u trail towards Holua cabin. En route you can take the short silversword loop. Beautiful rare plants that you propably already saw plenty of while decending so it can be skipped in my opinion. You will see the Holua cabin and their is an outhouse here for a bathroom break if need. There is also water but you need to treat it first to make it drinkable. Rest up and the final leg to the Halemau'u trailhead is next. The first half is no problem. You may see some hikers coming in the opposite direction which I thought would be unpleasant as they are hiking with the sun directly in their sight. The worst part of the circuit is unfortunately at the end. You have to climb up the mountain via multiple switchbacks. The view is great but it can take around 1 to 1.5 hours depending on how many breaks you take. After 10 or so miles of hiking the last think you probably want to do is ascend a 2000 ft but better to do this between 7000 and 8000 feet vs the opposite direction which would be 10000 ft at the summit! I started the journey at 7:45 am. It took me 6 hours and 15 min to complete. I saw a total of 6 people only so don't worry about crowds. I took hundreds of pictures and stopped 2 or 3 times for 10 minutes each. My Jeep was waiting for me and I was so happy I didn't have to hitchhike back up to the summit. You'll sleep like a baby that night! Good luck.

Be prepared to stay in Cuba or Grants unless you're ready to camp in a dusty place. The clays and silts will get into everything. You'll end up taking it home in the car, ears and mouth. There are no running streams except for a few muddy rifles in Chaco Wash. A good place for biking and hiking, suggesting hiking if you want to see all the scattered artifacts and pueblo housing. The easiest are hugging Chaco Wash, but there's more to see on top of the mesas which are easy climbs. The trip in can be made easily with a touring vehicle, but be weary of rain and or snow fall that melts during the day....the chances of getting stuck on the road in-between civilized areas will be high...whether you have 4 wheel drive or not. The park tends to like the dirt road in and out because it does not allow traffic like Yellowstone. Pueblo architecture is first rate...right up there with Mesa Verde. It is obvious these people were excellent farmers and they thrived when the climate allowed, but as usual with all ancient cultures, climate change brought them down and the place has not been taken apart by the next culture that came in, so it's still somewhat complete and intact and a great place to get that real feel for pueblo culture in the southwest.

Although impressive - especially the history of the place, it was just another government run memorial and seemed very sterile. The weather was great with blue skies , and the mountain looked great. Would have liked to get closer though and the parking fee was a bit rich.

We'd been to Chaco Canyon 40 years ago when our children were small and we did the grand tour of the West. It was magic then and even more magical now as we were able to indulge only our own interest. Because it's such a long trip in off the main road, I couldn't imagine not extending our stay by camping in the canyon which we did for two nights. I know lots of people do an in and out in one day but there's so much more to see and learn than that kind of schedule permits. The walking tours from the Visitor Center are a terrific way to get acclimated. Then you can take off on your own, stepping out of time to be with those who came before. The architecture, for me, was the compelling element and a two dollar poster we picked up at the Visitor Center now reminds us of the mystery every time we go up and down our stairs.

We picked the One Day Hawaii Volcano Evening Eco Tour from Maui tour. Accent on the "ALL DAY! Cost for two people $710. Only critism is the plane ride back routes through Honolulu adding about 2 hours to your day. Left from our hotel in Lahaina before 7 am, and 0n a Hawaiian Air plane from Maui by 9 am, in Hilo within 30 minutes, then picked up quickly by Jay our tour guide. From there it is a tour of a candy factory, a 2 & 1/2 mile deep pond, a Japanese Park, Rainbow Falls, then lunch at a not so great country club restaurant, (since we didn't take the tour to eat it wasn't a deal killer). From there we headed on a great drive to the park being enlightened by Jay along the way. He is funny and knowledgeable & made our time on the bus great. The Park is remarkable! You'll hike through a lava tube, over lava flows and fields, past and present. Then to dinner at a not so great park campground... Then to the museum and another hike around the park and explore steam vents. Then nightfall and the show starts with the glow of the lava. It is surreal and hypnotic! Then back on the bus to the airport, Honolulu, and then finally Maui. Back at our hotel at 11:40 pm.

It is fun to combine history with fun. You go to the visitors center to get your free ticket to tour the home. It is fun to wlk through the house where Lincoln atually lived while in Springfield. The home is very well maintained, and has great staff.

Fort Matanzas is a great way to spend the day for any age. It is a free attraction and, when you get there, you pick up your ferry pass at the visitor's center. The ferry is a short boat ride across to the watch tower "fort". The fort itself is fairly small but the history is very interesting and the role it played in the history of St. Augustine is extremely important.

This national park is simply amazing. Well, that's my opinion but I was just so impressed! The entrance fee is $10 and that's good for 7 days. Even if you only have one day, the fee is worth it. Start at the visitor center. There you can find out about current activity, ranger talks, get maps of the park and check out the gift shop. I would then take the Crater Rim Drive. This road currently only goes as far as the Jagger Museum due to the activity in Halema'uma'u Crater. Along the road there are several places to stop with great views of the Kilauea Caldera and some short hikes. The other drive is Chain of Craters. The map suggests a driving time of 3 hours and this is pretty accurate if you spend a short amount of time at all the pull offs. The road starts near the visitor center and winds up down at the coast. There are stops at a lava tube, Devastation Trail, petroglyphs, craters, old lava flows and the coast. You can walk to the end of the road where the 2003 lava flow went over. From this side you can also hike the 15 miles to the current flow activity or drive south of Hilo and take a shorter 2 mile hike in the afternoon. There are lots of longer hikes in the park and other roads up Mauna Loa. The thing I liked most about the park was the diversity of the landscape. You have tropical plants and barren lava flows, tall peaks and crashing waves. All this in one national park. There is a small store in the lodge that sells sandwiches and salads, but I would suggest eating in Volcano Village where you get more for the price. It was misty and cool in the park, but the sun peaked out at times and it was sunny and warm down at the end of the Craters Road. Prepare for a variety of weather and don't let it hamper your visit. The mist just adds to the scenery!

Stopping at Mammoth Cave National Park on our way to Florida we discovered that we will have to return and spend a few days. There are miles of bike paths and hiking trails, numerous cave tours, and a hotel and cottages to stay in that will allow you 24 hour access to the beauty of this park. There is no entrance fee for this National Park which is a plus and if you have a senior access pass all the tours are half price. Tour reservations can be made on line which is ideal when planning your schedule. We took the "historic tour" which requires two miles of walking and 550 stairs. Don't expect to see any stalagmites or stalagtites on this tour because the cave is limestone and there is no water seepage to form them. The huge underground rooms are impressive and you feel like you are in the movie "Journey to the Center of the Earth". Lunch in the Mammoth Hotel after our tour was reasonably priced and tasty.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: We stopped here with only an hour and a half until closing. We wished we had another hour or two to really explore the park. The $5.00 per vehicle admission is good for 7 days if you have time to come back within the week. The area had more to offer than we realized. There are a number of buildings you can tour on our own and there are a few cemeteries within the park. We enjoy photography and the setting sun cast a wonderful light for photos. The park rangers were knowledgable. Would definitely stop again.

I just went to Mammoth Cove over the Thanksgiving holiday weekend. My husband and I did the "Historic Tour" and the "New Entrance Tour." Each ticket was $12, which is a bargain considering that you get a guided tour for 2 hrs. The "Historic Tour" was exactly that- facts about history. It doesn't show the "prettier" parts of the cave, but it does offer some interesting facts about earlier cave tours. The "New Entrance Tour" ends with some pretty formations (stalactites & stalagmites).

As many of the other reviews have stated, this park seemed to be one missed by many. I started at the walk-in entrance by the marina. There is a map of the park just a short way on the trail and a box with park brochures. Just a quick 2 minutes or so brings you out to the shoreline. The water here is so clear and it's quiet and peaceful. There are several hiking trails, but pay attention to the note on the brochure about this being a park with limited facilities. It's warm and there is not much shade. I chose not to do any of the other trails for this reason. I did head further along Hwy 19 to the actual park entrance and visitor center. There you can learn more about the park and start any of the walks. Bring water and a hat if you plan to do the trails. But for quiet reflection while standing in the cool water, I highly recommend walking in at the marina entrance.

Just completed a two day hiking, sightseeing adventure to Bryce Canyon. From the moment we entered the Park, you were greeted with spectacular scenery. Traveling the Rim Rd, 18 miles out and then back, was one of the most scenic rides one could take. There are many scenic pull offs for viewing the Canyon and plenty of hiking trails for the more adventurous. Navajo Loop, Queens Garden, Sunrise Point and Bristlecone were hikes that we enjoyed and were listed as moderate hikes in the Park. Going in the off season we did not have to worry about crowds, and the weather was sunny and in the mid 40's, great for hiking. As a added bonus, over 62 you get a senior pass for $10, good for a lifetime at all National Parks.

I took the most scenic hike, beginning at Sunrise point around Sunset, taking the Navaho loop back to Sunrise. It's advisable to take a small pack of water and muchies as a midway break; however, good luck finding a private tree or rock to go to the bathroom. It's difficult to find and may require you to head off the trail somewhat. Navaho is moderately stressful, elevating 500 feet up to 8,000 feet, so you may need to stop before reaching the top. November was perfect weather for this type of hike...can't imagine it in the summer. It's worth spending the extra $$ to get an annual pass to also use for Zion Kolob and Zion National Park

This is is real treasure, plus it gives us a glimpse back at the Civil War era. Low cost, buses take you to esch srea and besutiful dcenery. This atteaction can get crowded and its best to arrive early. Will take 3-4 hours minimum to see most if the area, more if you are a history buff.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: A significant moment in US history. You can see it in an hour or explore it for an afternoon. Grounds and buildings are well maintained and the US Park Service volunteers are friendly and enthusiastic about the material and their jobs. The visitor center has 2 slide shows, 15 minutes each, and interesting exhibits. The site of the actual surrender is a reproduction but very well done and accurate. You can spend more time touring more buildings or the grounds. Entry fee is $5. If you like civil war history or US history, this is a must see site.

It was my first time visiting the Big Island and I had to see the volcanoes! I visited Kilauea Volcano where I went at night and got great pictures of the active Halema'uma'u Crater. If you listen closely, you could hear the pop and boom noises from the lava rock falling into the hot lava below. I went down the Chain of Craters Road and what an adventure I had walking over the different shapes of lava and looking at the different craters. I even had a chance to see the Hawaiian bird - Nene - walking among the lava rocks. I saw the Thurston Lava Tube, walked down the Kilauea Iki Crater and back up, and saw the Pu'u Loa Petroglyphs. If I returned again, I will definitely go back and see the Volcanoes again. There is still a lot more to explore. The entrance fee is $10 with a car for one week.

Definitely take the hike to Wiamoku Falls. One of the best experiences you will have on Maui! First through the Guava patches, then the bamboo forest. You will pass several waterfalls on your way to the 400ft Wiamoku Falls. Unbelievable!

We rented a car and drove to the park, using our Senior Lifetime Pass to gain entrance. Although part of the scenic road was closed due to high sulfuric gas activity, we still were able to see quite a bit of the inside of the crater, steam vents all over the place, and were able to hike through an actual lava tube. We viewed a very informative film at the Visitor Center, and the souvenir shop had some quality items as well as the usual tourist souvenirs. We were able to go as far as the museum, an interesting place also. Quite a few observation outlooks made for quality photo ops. A little bit scary, since, after all, it is an active volcano, and could theoretically erupt at any time. Although the seismic measuring instruments would likely give plenty of warning, we were told that in a few instances, form was not followed by the volcano. Apparently the volcano has not read the book! All in all, a very interesting and informative activity in beautiful Hawaii.

This is a piece of history and national recognized. Anything else you see in the Black Hills is good but not nationaly recognized always. You can say Mt Rushmore to anyone anywhere in the country or even workdwide and people know what you are talking about. My recomendation is to see Mt Rushmore before you see Crazy Horse. Crazy Horse is so much bigger that it takes away from the awesomeness of Mt Rushmore if you see Crazy Horse first. Parking is $11. Being a National Mounument would be nice if could get a discount if have the America the Beautiful Pass. We had 4 teenagers sho had not seen mount rushmore with us and they loved it. If trying to save money plan to eat before you go. The restraunt there is pretty high priced.

So quaint. You're ferried across the inland waterway via a little pontoon boat. not too crowded because the boat acn only hold so many people at a time. Up close and personal guides are there to answer questions. great wildlife, great phtos and got to explore the fort and hear the history. It's a mini version of the big fort in town but that one costs a small fortune to get into. This one was just a couple of $. Way prefferred.

If you enjoy history, architecture, or the beautiful caribbean vistas, then this trip will be a tripple-crown for you. It's an all-day adventure. The ferry boat takes about two hours each way, but it's worth the trip, which is about $100 per person. If you're in a hurry, you can hire a seaplane for about $250 a person, and it only takes about 20 minutes. This is a Civil War era fort with no fresh water source. So the design had to incorporate means of collecting and storing enough rainwater to last through the dry seasons for 1,500 troops. Stunning views from atop the fort. If you're going to spend a few bucks on some activity, make this a top priority. Other adventure will give you a thrill, but you'll never forget your visit to this fort. Perfect for kids.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: The park is well signposted on approaching Appomattox. The visitor centre (housed in the court house) has an exhibition and two films about the history of the site. This is a fascinating place with both original and reconstructed buildings. This site is a good stop as part of a tour of the Civil war sites in the area as it's where Lee signed the surrender. The $5 per car charge is very reasonable and there is ample parking. The lady at the visitor centre was very well informed and made us feel very welcome. Some of the buildings you can just wander around but the Maclean building (where the surrender was actually signed) is by tour only - we didn't do this but it is included in the $5 fee - you can view the outside of the house and look through the windows without doing the tour if you're pushed for time.
OK - I have to tell you upfront that I am a geologist which means that geology related places will always rate high on my list.

Absolutely amazing! The main reason we came up to the Black Hills area and it was well worth it. I highly recommend hitching on to one of their free ranger led programs. We followed one with the kids and it walked us down to right below the presidents (note: you can go there without a ranger program as well) but the material they presented was fascinating. Very informative and fun too. Parking seems a little steep at $11.00 per car, but you do have free reentry with it. We stopped by another time to see it at night as well so we did actually use our parking pass more than once. If we were in the area again we would definitely stop by and see it.

This is a great park and you stay a little while or a long time. The best part is parks in NM are just $3 a person. The price can't be beat. Driving in is just amazing and when you reach the parking area, walking in the sand is a great work out. The sand is very close to the type in Destin. Its so white that is doesn't burn your feet. Great place to visit in this area.

park: George Rogers Clark National Historical Park
text: It is an interesting place but there is not much there unless you go when they are having an reenactment. Then you can spend the whole day they have earphones that you ware that are like a guided tour of the place and history. They have a flea market but that was to expensive to go in at $ 7.00 and is very small I passed on it, But the rest is worth the trip there

Be sure to bring a jacket, and your listening ears. The rangers are very knowledgeable. You will find that Jewel cave is one of the largest in the world, and still being explored. You can also see photos in the visitor center of some beautiful formations that are deeper in the cave than the tour takes you. Spelunking tours are also available. I've seen people bring small children, but I was glad mine were old enough to pay attention.

Mount Rushmore is a stirring memorial and a tribute not only to those who adorn the rock, but to the people that labored to create it. The amount of rubble alone is amazing. The negatives for me were the cost for parking (don't remember the exact amount) and that you could not get closer (I understand the reasons for this). It is something that should be seen, but it is not something that you can easily visit on the way to anywhere. That makes it a little nicer too.

Depends what you want, I suppose, but for me it is all about scenery. The Grand Tetons are just more spectacular in my opinion. Yellowstone is bigger and has more features, but for sheer grandeur, I found the Grand Tetons altogether a better experience. But they are both definitely worth seeing. As they are on the same entrance ticket, kinda dumb not to... Must do the boating thing on Lake Jenny.

We stopped in here on a short weekend in southern oregon. There isn't a whole lot in the park to do in the winter, unless you are a hard core winter recreationist (the park doesn't charge an entrance fee during the winter months). We aren't. But, since we had never been there, the view of the park, and the history of the site, were worth stopping by. We ate lunch at the rim view cafe. It was surprisingly good for Xanterra food. Be sure to check the local conditions before you drive up, as the roads that are open in the winter may be closed due to weather. Also, make sure your vehicle has good tires at the very least. You will drive on snow covered roads quite a bit.

It's a good idea to have a vehicle if you want to see a lot here. It's also not a bad idea to take a few days if you want to see it all and not feel rushed. Talk to a guide when you get to the first visitors center. tell them the kind of time you have and what you'd like to see. They have Great advice and are very knowledgeable. There are a lot of great views you can see from your car. but if you like walking/hiking at all, there are a TON of great hikes. Come prepared with water and snacks/food. Entrance fee is low and it's good for a week. The park is a short drive from Hilo, so if you want an early start, the hotels in Hilo aren't as great, but it's a long drive from Kona. The best part was viewing Kilauea at night as we could see the glow from the lava.

location: washington DC, District of Columbia, USA
text: The Liberty Bell exhibit is really good. Take the time to read the exhibits leading up to the actual bell. Independence Hall was great to see, but our tour guide was sort of lame. The guide at the Congressional Hall right next door was excellent, and we really enjoyed that tour! Don't miss the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution in a small building right next door. It's also nice to see some of the preserved houses nearby and to learn about what life was like back then. Great time, and I don't consider myself to be a history buff. Don't forget to book tix for Independence Hall in advance. There is just a $1.50 per ticket reservation fee, but otherwise it's free.

I recently enjoyed seeing Mt. Rushmore. All the people working there were so friendly as well from the parking attendant to those working in the restaurant and gift shops. The museum that tells the story of Mt. Rushmore is very informative and interesting. I loved my trip there. There is no fee to the sight but there for parking, however, the parking is good for the whole year so you can go several times in one year and only pay for parking the one time.
It was nice to find a place that didn't cost anything to go to and that parking was free. the Fort is far smaller than the main one but It was very informative and the staff was friendly.

If you like to visit remote places, if you like historical sites, if you like tropical fish or snorkeling, the ferry trip to the Dry Tortugas is for you. This is a full day experience and at approx $160 pp, it ain't cheap, but it was the highlight of our Key West visit and I have wanted to visit for years!! This trip did not disappoint.

Fantastic! Magnificent! Awe inspiring! A national treasure. And only costs $10/car. Don't bother with an outside tour guide. Park visitors center is filled with very knowledgeable Rangers that will provide ample guidance on how to see all the sites. Even advice on park hikes and durations. Throughout the day the Rangers give guided tours. Just join one for as long as you care. We took loads of pictures. Thoroughly enjoyed this National Park.
Being operated by the National Park Service is a plus. There is no charge and the grounds are well maintained. We did not take the tour but wandered around and enjoyed our time there.

I spent two fantastic two days in the Volcano national park and 10$ one week pass is the excellent value. I visited the Jagaer museum during the day and than late evening to see the glowing lava from the museum viewing point, sulphate bank, Lilauea Iki hike, Thurstone Lava Tube, Devastation trail (the shortest trail at the park) and down to Pu’u Loa Petriglyphs and end of the road. You can do many different and long hikes in the park with a diverse landscape and scenery.
a perfect day excursion with some history, outdoor fun and beautiful scenery. Its right off the highway and you can get in for free with your parks pass. Enjoy it!

So you can take my review with a grain of salt. My son and I took the New Entrance Tour, at a cost of $12 each. We boarded the bus with 59 others and drove about 4 miles to the cave entrance. The guide was very informative, but the fact is that Mammoth is just a hole in the ground. Slightly less boring than lava tubes, but if you're expecting giant rooms full of stalactites and stalagmites, you'll be disappointed. Keep in mind I have been in several dozen cave systems across the US and Europe, so first-timers might find this more interesting.

I am giving this only average rating for a couple of reasons: it is not a cheap trip by any means, and they nickel and dime you once aboard. Water, $1, dramamine, $1, on and on. Also, 4 hours on the island just got to be too much for most of us. That being said, the boat ride is 2.5 hours of joy on the water, even tho it was chilly. There was loads of room, inside and out. Facilities were clean, and the staff was super friendly. Our tour guide of Fort Jefferson was knowledgable and funny, the fort is quite something to see. Our daughters snorkeled while we did the tour, and they saw all kinds of fish and coral. Breakfast and lunch on the boat was very pedestrian, and my vegetarian daughter had little to choose from, cheese and bread. I would not do it again, and I would caution others. It's a long, expensive day.

It was nice to go the day after Christmas as it was not busy at all, but do to snow/ice the trail was closed so you couldn't walk up closer, but it was still nice. No fee to see, just pay for parking.

We visited Bryce Canyon as part of our trip over the Zion National Park from Page, AZ. We were expecting beautiful rock formations, but not as beautiful as we saw. We used a lot of TA reviews and pointers to figure out if we were going to drive through the park and pull off at overlooks or if we were going to add in a hike. It is easiest to see the park by stopping at the park entrance/information center, getting a map, and then driving to the one of the further away over looks as most of them are on the left hand side of the road. We drove about 20-30 mins, turned around and then began stopping at the overlooks. We visited the park after lunch time so we missed the sunrise at Sunrise Point, however it was still beautiful. We parked at the Sunrise Point parking area and did the Navajo Trail from there to Sunset Point. The trail was steep at points and is about 3 miles. In the beginning of the trail it is a steady hike down and then you're on part of the canyon floor. On the way back up to Sunset Point, you are climbing back up to the rim and that was the hardest part of the hike. Leave yourself about 2 hours to do it and also let yourself rest in between difficult parts. Definitely a great hike and you get to see so many hoodoos and rock structures. There is a $25 fee for entrance to the park, but with the America The Beautiful Pass ($80 p/ year), you can enter for "free." If you plan on visiting 3-4 parks on your trip, the ATB pass is a wonderful deal and you're contributing to our national parks.

I had not been here in years so decided to visit! Got to read about the Chamizal treaty in 68 happened when I was just a child. The grounds are still well kept and I would have walked it if it had not been so cold. Got a 20% discount at the Gift shop since I am a teacher, but should have had more stuff..I would have bought more. Rangers very nice..recommend to anyone who wants to know about the history in my hometown!

Our whole reason for going to Key West was to take the boat to the Dry Tortugas for a day trip of snorkeling and fun. The day before the scheduled trip, I called just to check on whether lunch was supplied or whether we should take some food. I was told at that point (at about noon) that the boat was cancelled due to mechanical difficulties. I was offered a chance to book for two days later, but we couldn't stay so I took the refund. The person I spoke to said he was going to start making calls, but I have no reason to believe that. I asked about other trips and there was a more expensive seaplane option. I looked into it, but it's practically a flyover and costs more than the boat (which already is expensive for a day trip). Those are the only options for a day in the Dry Tortugas. I have no idea how frequently these service problems occur, but it really was a pain in the neck. We did get our refund, but it might have been nice if the company had maybe sent us even an apology (a discount coupon in case we decided to chance it again would have been nicer and maybe the only thing that would persuade us to try again).

This was my favourite day on the island (and it was only a day because we had limited time). We came from Kona so it was a long drive (about 2 hours – no traffic), but it’s worth getting to the park early. We arrived about 8:45am. It’s $10 per car for 1 week entry – very reasonable. Speak to the rangers at the main visitors centre first. They’ll give you ideas on what to do given your time frame. We found this really helpful. They also have guided tours you can go on, but we decided to explore the park on our own. My favourite trail was devastation. Even if you don’t walk the whole trail it’s worth walking a few minutes in to see part of it – the feeling was one that I’d never had before. It was breathtaking and eerie all at the same time. Make sure you stay to see the glow from the lava after sunset… worth the wait! Take your water bottle and snacks/picnic with you – there isn’t much in the park. Also, it does get cool and wet (weather changes in a heartbeat up there) so be prepared. We had a bite at the Lava Café nearby – check my review list for thoughts on it.

My first visit to Mt Rushmore was awe inspiring. I had seen photos of the mountain in books for 50 years, but nothing can prepare you to see it first hand. As you're driving up the mountain, you get a little peek of it up on the right side. If you have never been here before, its worth the visit. I walked around quite a bit and got some great exercise in the process. I enjoyed going reading all the material about how the mountain was carved, and all its history. There is a visitors center and a gift shop you can educate yourself and bring home a souvenir. I went on a weekday and apparently is the best time to go. It was not very crowded. There is no entrance fee but you do pay $11. to park. Be sure to drive around the side of the mountain where you will get a really cool side view of the monument. I have never seen a published shot before like that. See my photograph below.

I was really excited to see Mount Rushmore. I never got to travel as a kid, so I missed out telling all the good stories you did as a kid. My husband and I decided to make this a stop on our move from Alaska to Minnesota. It was a beautiful drive, but after getting there and realizing that parking was $11, we were a little bummed. We parked and walked up to the monument, got our pictures, saw the flags and went into a few stores then it was done. That's it. $11 to park when we could have taken the same kind of pictures from the road. It is quite an experience to see it up close though.

Not sure what caused me to spend a weekend in South Dakota. I suppose coming from Niagara Falls I kind of think of it as a slice of the American pie, like the Falls or the Grand Canyon. Your parking pass allows you to return so I recommend a visit in the morning and evening both. We did this over a weekend in September and it was the first and last thing we did. Walk around during the daytime; watch the video (it was always curious to me why Theodore Roosevelt was chosen to be honored here instead of Franklin or another President). In the evening stay to listen to the park ranger talk about Mount Rushmore. There's a moment when everyone in attendance will feel like an American.

Capitol Reef sits somewhere between Arches/Canyonland and Zion/Bryce, so it you plan to visit them all, this is the mid point stop. We were surprised there is no charge to visitor unless you take the scenic drive, so you can stop at various viewpoints for free. The ranger at the visitor center recommended that we take the scenic drive and head for Capitol Gorge in our car even though it was not 4WD. It was a small dirt road deep into the canyon with spectacular views above (lucky for us to have a big sunroof).
Fun place to go to sled! If you don't want to ski or just want to have fun with the kids you can sled at Hyde park for free. Actually you do have to pay to park but it was cheap!

We were surprised how quickly we entered the mountains after leaving Santa Fe. The park is only a 10 min. drive out of downtown. Beautiful views overlooking the valley below if you continue on past the park a little ways. We plan to return to hike and camp in this area in the summer! $5 day use fee for park. If you want to sled for free drive just a little further to Tesque Campground. Our two year old enjoyed sledding. The scenery is worth the drive as well. It looks like this is a great place to check out fall foliage.

plan to stay and spend the day, go to walmart and buy some $5.00 sleds or bring yours from home because this place is so much fun. ( the sleds sold there are wayyyy expencive. Take the time and drive to the very back for the highest peaks. A low cost way to spend the day.

Guess we just don't get it. We felt like driving through Joshua Tree National Park was like coming to see what the surface of the moon looks like. We drove up from south to north, and we were almost 2/3 through the park before we saw anything of interest--the cactus garden. Never did figure out what a real Joshua Tree was since even the displays at the Visitors' Center seems vague. Even the oasis we visited was just a group of palm trees that managed to come up through the rocks and sand. We were glad we had a National Park Pass so we didn't pay the $15 day pass to get through here.

I took atrip to UTAH this november for 3 daysDAY 1) I drove from vegas to ZION NATIONAL PARK first i stopped at the visters center and payed entrance fee 25$ and got a map and some ifromation on the trails they where very helpfull. I filled up a whole day hiking the emerald pools its a beatiful trail it took me 2 and a half hours then i went to the wheeping rock trail its about half hour hike up and down then i drove the park road till the end and stopped for the view a few times IT WAS GREAT from there I DROVE TO THE BRYCE CANYON via MT CARMEL TUNNEL on the way i stopped at the OVERLOOK TRAIL overlooking the whole park it has great veiws. the drive to bryce canyon was beatiful i stayed at the BEST WESTERN for 2 nights

Yes, it's free! You get on a boat. They take you to an island with a genuine 300 year old fort, a mini-fort really. If you're lucky the guy dressed up like an old Spaniard will be there to guide you and answer questions. You get to play with the cannons, climb ladders and go through doors made for people much smaller than you. Then you get back on the boat and they take you back to your car and they charge you nothing! Donations gladly accepted but not required.

We loved White Sands! I am a photographer and hiker, so I was in heaven at White Sands. There are a couple of trails at White Sands to hike further into the dune field. We took the campsite trail loop and were alone on the trail. The sand dunes are easy to hike on and the trail is well marked with poles that you can see along the trail. Another day we were off trail to do some photography and got lost when we were ready to return to the car. We had made note of our location by compass before we went into the dunes, so were able to find our way back using the compass. Don't rely on your footprints to get you back if you get off trail. The park's website has information on open times, etc. You can enter the park earlier or stay later by applying for a permit a couple of weeks in advance and paying a $50 fee per each half hour of time. Highly recommended !

This is a whole day trip. We took the boat tour out of Key West with Yankee Freedom II, a brand-new high speed ferry. You spend 2 1/2 hours each way on the boat but it is quite comfortable and breakfast and lunch are included. You get to spend 4 1/4 hours on the Island. It has a big civil war era fort, now a near ruin, with a tour of the fort included, and there are two small beaches with good snorkeling around. The beaches are white sandy bottom and the water a gorgeous turquoise so very pleasant for shallow water swimming and snorkeling. Good quality snorkel equipment is also provided to everyone included in the tour fee. You see coral and colorful fish. They sell cocktails on the boat on the way back. A pleasant day. The only annoying thing was the unexpected $4 "fuel surcharge" that we were forced to pay when we showed up at the boat AFTER buying the supposedly all-inclusive tickets and then the incessant begging for tips for the staff. Please people, pay your staff properly and stop making them beg for tips, it is really degrading all around.

We visited Crater Lake on 17th January and had to drive through the snow ploughed roads to get there but it was well worth the drive as the lake is beautiful. It was surrounded by snow and had a sheen of ice on it in most parts and the snow covered trees around it all added to the beauty. It was very peaceful and the colour of the water was fantastic. Nature really does do a better job without us. There is no entrance fee during winter.

First, as in any other outdoor activity, go prepared. The hikes to the petroglyphs are easy, but good hiking boots, sunscreen, windbreakers, hats and water make for a much more comfortable experience. If you are not a walker, you probably won't like this attraction. Much of the trail is sandy which increases the effort required. Take a good camera, and be sure to stop at the visitors center, talk to the experts, and pick up a map and information sheet that describes the various glyphs. Kids LOVE this hike! Give yourself at least half a day and have fun. PS: $2 parking fee at trailheads.

This is your US tax dollars at work. No cost to go on a short boat ride out to the island where the fort is. If you went to the fort in St Augustine first, you may be disappointed in this. But this comes with a personal guide who is very informative and by his answers to the questions posed, you can tell he is quite the history buff.

Unfortunately, we did not have adequate time to really tour the battlefield on this visit, but we did take the narrated car tour, which skips some of the stops on the car tour. Hopefully, we will return sometime in the future. Because the car tour tries to illuminate too many general facts about the Civil War at each stop, it doesn't do a very good job of actual instruction about the battle. However, since I had read extensively about the battle, being there did help me better understand the geography of the battlefield. If you have time (at least half a day or more), I would advise skipping the CD (which, in itself, cost @ $20) or audio tape and simply getting out at each stop, reading the historical markers and walking the relevant parts of the battlefield. If you have time before going, I would read Shaara's Civil War Battlefields, for a brief (24-page) description or Sear's Landscape Turned Red for an extensive history of the Maryland campaign.

My sister and I were on a meandering road trip from Phoenix to St Louis during the summer...taking major detours along the way. This is one that we "happened upon" whilst making our way to Roswell and Carlsbad. We were mesmerized by the gorgeous, white glimmering mounds ahead of us. It looked like nothing else on earth that we had ever seen. We stopped and played in the sand like kids. Actually - we were kinda jealous of the kids that did have their sleds and were literally sledding down these seemingly "permanent mounds of snow". The sheer size of these peaks - amazing. Super fun "road trip" break and we had an amazing time for no cost. One of the HIGHLIGHTS of our entire road trip and we covered A LOT!

Kaloko-Honokohau National Historical Park is located on the west coast of the Big Island, just three miles north of the town of Kailua-Kona, on the ocean side of Highway 19. There is no entrance fee to this beautiful park. There is a small covered outside visitor’s area with a gift shop and very clean restrooms. We chose the perfect day to visit, as locals gather each Thursday to play their ukuleles, guitars, and sing various tunes, including a number of lovely Hawaiian songs.
There is no cost to view the Lincoln's homestead. The parks officials go out of their way to put a personal touch regarding the Lindcoln's life In Springfield

2 hour boat ride out with modest breakfast and lunch plus hours more to snorkel off the island and tour fort Jefferson. If you love history and the outdoors you'll enjoy this...oh and you must have $164 to do it also!9 hours total day. Gorgeous views. Completely

First was the winding drive north of Silver City, with breathtaking views. Next was touring the interpretive center to obtain a sound feeling on who made the cliff houses, when it was done and how important it was to make this a National Monument to preserve this history. Our January walk to the cliffs was cool (below freezing), giving us a feeling of just how the local peoples would have endured. Volunteer guides explained all aspects at the cliff site and we were able to walk into many of the living and working quarters. Admission charge was so very minimal. Highly recommended for all ages, but you must be capable of a little bit of walking and climbing.

What more can I say other than this place is nothing but pure history. I highly suggest going. Independence Hall is great, but be sure to stop by the visitor center well in advance to get a free ticket for the tour.

Rough seas yesterday! but excellent staff. Fort Jefferson was fascinating to see and experience, but be prepared for a bumpy ride. Take motion sickness pills before you go. The new ferry bounced on the waves in the open channel. The staff was attentive and helpful. The crew served as our tour guide as well. Breakfast and lunch were included in the cost. They told us the best months are April or May when the waters are calmer. Snorkeling would be great but the waves were rough. The fort had stairs with no handrails and you can walk the moat but no handrails there either.

To view Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, you need at least two or three days. But because we only had one day, my companions and I decided to focus on the highlights. We first stopped at the visitor’s center to pick up maps and trail guides ($2 each and very useful in determining what you are looking at during your hike) and ask about current lava viewing conditions before heading off to the Kilauea Iki trailhead. It’s good to go early while there’s still plenty of parking. I believe we got there around 9am and the lot was about half full. The hike itself is amazing and it was easy to see why it’s the most popular hike in the park. The rainforest makes you feel like you’re in Jurassic Park and walking the still steaming crater floor was like walking on Mars or another barren planet. We were even able to see a couple of nene geese waddling by. The hike is 4 miles long and normally takes 2 to three hours but we finished in 4 hours due to taking a few “detours” from the official path (not recommended as there's quite a bit of loose rock around). Since it’s a long hike, it’s a good idea to bring plenty of water and snacks, as well as sunscreen as there is very little shade on the crater floor. Near the end of the hike was the trail to the Thurston Lava Tube, basically a large, mostly underground, cavernous passage set amidst a tree fern forest. Because it rained the night before, it was an adventure trying to navigate around the water dripping from the ceiling and the numerous puddles on the floor. All in all, the walk took about 15 to 20 min. We spent more time exploring the rainforest outside the tube than the tube itself.

Be careful, be aware of Altitude Sickness. It is dangerous and serious. You can not do anything other that wait and become acclimated to the altitude or go to a lower elevation. You will get dizzy and feel like your heart is going to pump right out of your chest. Very scary. I still had to drive over the Continental Divide and waiting it out for a few days in a cheap Durango motel. Got a traffic ticket for running a red light, I was that out of it.

Stunning landscapes. Great paleontology and Plains Indian history exhibits in the Visitor Center. No cost for admission. A few miles of interpretative trails available. Best of all, no crowds and off the beaten path. Enjoy!

Very beautiful area of the United States, with the Black Hills nearby and a very mid-Western feel. Mount Rushmore was, of course, neat to see but impossible to see without paying $11 for parking! Expensive, like the town around it.

Since there is very little info. out there on camping at the Park I am writing a somewhat longer post in the hope of answering most of the questions we had before we went; just got back from three days of tent camping. This is an extraordinary and unique camping experience that we highly recommend. It requires a little more advance planning, and quite a bit more expense than a normal camping trip but it’s well worth the time and money.

We had a lovely walk on a shady path through to the beach. Many turtles resting in or near lava-rock pools at low tide and the fish-trap was interesting to see (more easily visible at low tide). Park is well-maintained & equipped with toilets. There's no charge for entry which is always a bonus, although there might be a parking fee if you go to the visitor centre. My advice on that is -- don't. It's a hot walk over lava fields from there to the beach. This is a beautiful natural site, nice and quiet because of the park rules.

This venue memorializing the Johnstown Flood opened on the 100th Anniversary of the disaster. It was built by the National Park Service [seniors, your Golden Pass works here] who left the site pretty much as it was --and from the several lookouts, the disaster becomes very real. The show stopper, however, is the film in the main building. It is emotional, threatening to small children, but you'd swear it was filmed during the actual flood. A masterpiece in editing and sound --pieced from other flood films and at the same time accurate to the Johnstown event.

My husband & I are visiting ALL the national parks in the country. The Dry Tortugas NP did not disappoint. Takes about a 3-hour boat ride from Key West to the Ft. Jefferson dock. If you even THINK you'll be seasick, take the Dramamine or whatever. You're in trouble if you get sick en route. Too late to take the meds. Also take another dose on the return trip. The cruise price includes breakfast and lunch. The rangers are full of knowledge about the fort & the surrounding islands making the trip particularly meaningful. They also provide snorkel gear for everyone who does not bring their own. Small beaches but good snorkeling areas and plenty of picnic tables. Also some campsites for those who wish to extend their stay.

Visited Big Island for one day with the sole purpose of seeing the live volcano in the national park. I flew into Kona, which was almost 100 miles away from the park, a bad choice. If you only want to see the volcano, you'd better fly into Hilo, which was only about 30+ miles from the park. You definitely need a car there unless you go with a tour. We also visited Black Sand beach and saw a couple of turtles; didn't go to Green Sand beach, no time as it required walking 2 miles each way from when a car could reach. In the volcano park, you need to check with the rangers at the visitor center to see where you can go on that day, and at that moment. It's best to see the volcano after dark (6:30 pm). You need to get there early as the parking lot got full quickly. If you need to eat, there's a Military Camp close to where to watch the volcano. The camp's cafeteria and bar were open to public; the food was decent and price was reasonable there. How much of the volcano you can see depends on weather. We had a heavy fog day, so just saw the red glow dimly in the distrance. The lava tube in the park was also worth visiting.

We drove to Haleakala; the drive from Wailea is about 2 hours. I'm glad that I read about this adventure before we went. We purchased the GyPSy Guide and put it on our IPAD. For $9.99 ( for all of Maui,) you can have a GPS/audio tour in the privacy of your own car. if you plan on hiking at the summit, layer/bring warm clothes. It was 75 at the beach and 47F at 10,000 feet. They had had snow flurries 3 days prior to our trip. Bring your snacks/camera/ and a camelbak if you're planning on hiking for awhile. The vistas are truly amazing and become moreso the further you go. We started on the Slippery Sands Trail. Pace yourself as the hike back is much harder than going down; for moderately in shape mid 50 year olds, we felt it on the way back. This was one of the highlights of our trip to Maui. We also learned via the GyPSy guide that one entrance fee is good for 3 days to Haleakala Natioanl Park as long as you save our receipt; we used it on one day during our trip to Hana and the next day at Haleakala.

We visited the Big Island with hopes to view the volcano. Because of my husband's disability, what we saw was limited. We did see the huge crater and steam vents. Unfortunately a large portion of Crater Rim Drive was closed. Beware before planning your trip that to see the lava flow, you need to take a 2 hour (28 mile drive) down a steep winding road. Also make sure that you fly into Hilo. We made the mistake of flying into Kona and the drive to the park is long and very windy. This is definitely a trip for the physically fit! On the plus side - we did buy a senior pass for the national park system that was a real bargain!

The fort was interesting, but there isn't a whole lot to see there. The snorkeling was good, but you need to get out a ways to the coral heads to see much. It was definitely worth the $$ to go once, but I won't need to go again.

I remember taking a family vacation back in the 70s and seeing the Lincoln Home and Memorial. I got out of an appointment early and decided to re-visit the Lincoln home. It is free to get into the Lincoln home, you just need a ticket from the welcome center, parking however is not, but the price of parking is reasonable. I did have the one to one tour with the ranger, probably because it was a week day and about 16 degrees outside. Honestly I didn't remember much from my first visit 40 some years ago and now. I remember more the outside of the house than the insides. I do love that they have two blocks around the house so you got a feel of what it "looked" like when the Lincolns lived there. The Welcome center does include a introductory movie on Lincoln which acts as a refresher to Lincoln's career prior to the Presidency. It was nice to re-visit this place.

A group of us took the boat to the Dry Tortugas, but if I did it again I'd take the seaplane. The ride out on the boat isn't bad, but the ride back is pretty boring. It's worth the extra $$ for the plane. If people in our group hadn't wanted to do the boat we would have flown.

We visited Mount Rushmore and I honestly felt it was overrated and didn't live up to it's hype. The sculptures were much smaller than I thought they would be. The drive to the Memorial was very nice and very picturesque. In my opinion, the trip wouldn't have been worth the admission except for the discovery of highway 16A/16 to Custer State Park. That drive made our visit to Rushmore worth the effort. It is a beautiful, interesting part of our country.

location: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
text: Be sure to go to the Visitor's Center. A large percentage of visitors miss it. It is located below the Grand View Terrace. Take the stairs or elevators located left and right. View a short 14 minute film and walk through the museum. The displays are very nice and tell the story of Mount Rushmore, the artist Borglum, and the workers. We've been there often with family, friends, alone, and for business. There is a parking fee but the grounds are free.

Approaching it, you have no idea what is there.. Can't see it at all off the HWY. It should be considered for National Park status, but it is probably too small. Entrance fee is a lot less to National Monuments. Isolated and very high elevation. Not much in the area food or gas wise. Fill up before heading up. Same goes for food. Lots of CCC era buildings.

We stopped here on a road trip from Michigan to Florida - Mammoth Cave happened to be on the way. The surrounding area is very, very touristy (there's nothing in the area except the cave, so locals want to cash in on tourists). When you finally arrive, though, the tour is absolutely worth the fee. The tour is great for kids and adults alike, and I'd highly recommend it if you're in the area. I hope to be able to return someday!

Let me just say that we did the overnight camping trip the morning after our wedding! It doesn't sound like the romantic and pampering way to go but we just couldn't pass up the opportunity to see the amazing sunset, stars, and the sunrise that many reviews and websites encouraged and for extra few dollars, it seemed like a bonus to experience a remote island getaway.

These dunes are really cool. There is an 8 mile drive through once you pass the ranger station/gift shop. there are picnic areas and I think you can camp out there. I have heard that some people have gotten lost while hiking across the dunes. Its definitely worth driving all the way to the end and you need to get out and climb to the top of one. From the top you can see miles and miles of white. Its really pretty. It was quite cold but we climbed around and got a lot of pictures. Its very deserted and beautiful. They also offer sunset strolls.

This site is historically, militarily and culturally fascinating and is a must see when visiting Key West. Breakfast and lunch are included in the fee, but any afternoon snacks on the return leg need to be purchased. Our tour guide for Fort Jefferson, Chelsea, was very knowledgeable about the history of the Fort, going into compelling details about the life of Dr. Mudd, for example, but was very loath to entertain questions. Travelers need to be warned that the Fort has no railing on the second or third floors so young children must be carefully monitored to make sure they don't fall off the fort which is easy to do. Finally, if one does seek to snorkel, be sure to around the fort to the right of the port-sally to the back side and then head out in the water with the beach to your right to find coral and fish. Otherwise you may see nothing more than sand. Be aware that the snorkeling is not monitored and the surf can be strong. Be mindful of your own personal swimming capabilities and I suggest you not let kids go into the deeper water without being accompanied by an adult.

I took my family here to sled in the sand. Though there's not enough to to do to spend the whole day here it is still very much worth the trip. Bring your own sled disk with you unless you want to pay 10 bucks for one. It is an awesome experience since it isn't everyday you will see sand dunes you can sled on, hike in the area or just walk around in awe at the breathtaking views. Make sure you pack a lunch, snack, etc because it is a desolate area and the choices at the nearest gas station and gift shop is bleak. They also have free guided tours on certain days/times. Other than the entrance to the national park it's free.

HVNP is a must see if you visit the Big Island ... even if you've been there before! There are already hundreds of reviews, so I will pass on some tips I received from my sister (who had visited before):
