The gate attendant did not advise us that due to hi levels of methane gas, 3/4 of rim road was closed. Our $10 got us less than quarter mile, to only two viewing points and the visitors center. It's a long drive; we wasted a full day's vacation. Take food unless you like packaged white bread sandwiches.

For $160 you get breakfast, lunch, refreshments and great service as you enjoy a comfortable 2 and a half hour cruise out to the park. Beautiful beaches, good snorkeling and an interesting old fort to explore make this a truly unique day. The Yankee Clipper is a great boat for the trip and it sails back into town just before sunset. To top off the day you can take a quick walk over to Mallory Square where you can join the daily sunset celebration. I would highly recommend this trip!

This was a great tour which included a boat ride to the fort. A lot of history given by a very nice and knowledgeable guide. Most National Parks charge a fee but this one was free. We were able to take our time and look around as much as we wanted. It was a slow day and there was no waiting. Take the time to see this out of the way attraction.....some of these are definitely worth the time.

We travelled to Dry Tortugas just before Christmas on board of Yankee Freedom II. It was a beautiful day for travel. Clear sky, calm water and temp. in 70s. The national park is very small consisting of 7 islands and we were allowed to go only in the Garden Key where the Fort Jefferson is located. The fort is massive but unfinished. NPS is trying to restore many breaking walls. We took a tour guided by the Yankee Freedom stuff and it was for an hour. After the fort tour we went for snorkeling in one of the beaches in the island.The water was really calm, beach is beautiful without any pollution. Since very few people manages to travel this far, place was like a tiny dream island. Actually there are ~5 NPS rangers stay permanently in the island. Snorkeling was great particularly near the harbor where ancient iron pillars are located. There war corals, star fishes and schools of fishes consisting of thousands of fish. I must have seen ~100 different kind of fish in the couple of hours I did snorkeling. DTNP is only reachable through Yankee Freedom II (can carry ~200 people) or by sea plane. Yankee freedom cost ~$165/ person and they will take care of the breakfast and lunch. There are nothing in the island except a tiny gift shop where you can buy souvenirs and stamp your National park passport. Overall the trip was from morning 7:30 to evening 5:30. On the way back we even saw dolphins and sea turtles swimming in the sea. We were back on time for the beautiful sunset from the Mallory square.

Aworld class, world famous, one of a kind view that will astound you! Hiking, photography, tours, seminars, kids education and entertainment, clean air, power of nature, bluest of blue water, huge trees, wildlife, restaurant, gift shop (!), plenty of restrooms, multiple view points, disabled friendly, dog friendly, Incredible lodging, camping, good roads, excellent customer service and information, small entrance fee (by comparison), and quite honestly a sight you will never, ever forget. This is Crater Lafe and I only scratched the surface. If you come to Oregon, for any reason, it is a MUST SEE. Be aware the this is at high elevation and weather can be a factor in your visit, check ahead. While winter there must be beautiful, parts of the park shut down due to heavy snow accumulation. A true wonder of the world and not to be missed.

If you do only one thing on Maui visit the volcano. The vistas are breathtaking. Like the Grand Canyo it is a real challenge to take photos that will do it justice so have patience. It was only $10 per vehicle for a visit. We loved the winding road. It was in great shape. We saw the Hawaiian state bird, the Nene, and some wild goats. Bring you coat and hat. It's cold up there at 10,000 feet.

Since most of the resorts on the big island are on the opposite side, it takes a long time to get there. We also had dinner plans back at the hotel that night so we were left with only about 2 hours at the park. The rangers at the visitor's center are super friendly and very helpful in planning your visit. The movie in the visitor center is good. You get to see the smoldering crater, but here is the bottom line: if you want to see glowing lava you have to go to the end of Chain of Craters Road or to Kalapana and still have something like a 3 mile hike one way, or you can take a helicopter tour at $200pp or a boat trip. I really wished we had time to take one of those options. If I come back, I will plan to stay at least one night closer to the volcano to do this place justice.

Crater Lake is one of the most beautiful blue lakes I have ever seen! The drive through this small National park is pretty, but the view of the lake from the top is awesome! There is a nice gift shop up on top, for those wishing to buy postcards,etc. The beauty is seeing the lake in person, photos can't totally capture the blueness of the water. If you make the drive 'around the loop' of the lake it takes about 3 hours, or longer if you stop at the overlooks along the way. There is a $10 National Park fee.

Let me first start by saying the historic cave tour is not for the faint at heart although we had a couple of mid-60's in my immediate group along with a 4 year old and a couple of 8 year olds. I'll say that we made it though the 2 hour guided walking tour because we are all fairly active but if you aren't I wouldn't recommend this tour as there are over 400 steps to retreat the cave. Now on to the fun stuff, we saw a couple of bats on the ceiling, there were "fat man squeezes" (our biggest guy is 260 so...), lots of history, opportunities to ask questions, plenty of photo opportunities, they even turn the lights out so you can see just how dark it is inside. Children must be well behaved and accompany an adult the entire tour or they will be escorted out we were told, we didn't have that problem! :) Make sure you dress warm as it's in the 50's year around. Tickets were $12 for adults, $6-8 for kids and the tour guides made it worth it. Would love to go back and try another tour next time but this one was great!

Both the Balconies Trail Loop (70-90 minutes; bring a flashlight) and the High Peaks Trail Loop (2-3 hours; bring water) are outstanding hikes that can both be done in a single afternoon. These hikes are among the best that California has to offer and comparable to many elsewhere in America and Europe (Yosemite, Columbia Gorges, Grand Canyon, Cathar Trail, etc.). But beware, you must be fit to do them and not afraid of heights or darkness! Especially good when the weather is dry, but not hot. Helpful to know German because you may pass serious German hikers who know that these are breathtaking hikes!

I've been there twice and pkan to go again, it is absolutely gorgeous. Try to catch the sunset and also go early in the morning as well. You can purchase a used sled for $3.00 at the visitor center, and its a lot of fun. Take your time, the park is not too big. Be carefull, i almost got lost at night, its easy to just keep going nad then the suroundings look the same. Make sure you HAVE GLASSES on, its very bright, and wear sunscreen. Go in the winter, i heard the summer is too hot down there.

I had no idea this was here! Kind of blown away by the things that are hidden in the canyons here in Arizona. We had hoped to hike the Island Trail Loop but upon arrival we were informed that part of the Island Trail was closed for construction. I think it is opening up again in a couple days but will be closed on & off for the next few months for trail repaving. Anyway, regardless of that, it is still worth going to (especially for $5/person) because you can still hike down quite a big and get a better view of the ruins. The views are pretty amazing. Crazy to think about how they lived back then. You would have to be tough as nails! There's also a very tiny museum at the visitor center worth the quick walk through. There are quite a few steep stairs on the paved trail down which I can see being difficult for some people but there are quite a few benches a long the way if you need to take breaks. Also, if you bring small children, for goodness sake, keep an eye on them because you will be walking along a cliff that's easy to fall off of!

We took this tour because we were crunched on time and have two young children. The cave was pretty cool, but the tour was unimpressive. The guide did not introduce the different rooms we went to well. He said you will pass Crystal Lake before we entered the cave, but half of the people in the tour did not even realize they should look down to see it at when passing the spot (myself included). The guide often spent his time speaking to a few individuals in the front of the group and ignoring the rest of the group. At one point he said watch your step it is slippery. My 5 year old asked him where and his response was "you'll find out". That is okay to joke with adults like that, but not sure I thought it was inappropriate for my 5 year old daughter. The tour was short, part of the hour being the bus ride to and fro. Seeing deer along the ride was nice, actually sad to say one of the highlights of the tour. There were a few neat spots along the tour with interesting things to look at and the history of that part of the cave was good. In general though while this is worthwhile if you are just looking to kill a small amount of time, it isn't exactly an awe-inspiring experience and we left a little disappointed.

We drove up to the Santee area for a weekend, and spent several hours at this breathtaking park. It is literally in the middle of nowhere, although Columbia does not appear to be that far of a drive. Unlike most other National Parks, there is no entrance fee, but also no food vendors (nor any restaurants nearby). The visitor center gave a nice overview of the park, and the boardwalk trail was stunning. There were so many tall and beautiful trees, although the gigantic ones are mostly in areas well off the beaten path. The boardwalk took us over many different habitats and we saw many birds such as woodpeckers and a barred owl.

If you're trying to see all the US National Parks like we are, then this is a must-do while in Key West. If being on an island for several hours with an old fort and no restaurants isn't your thing, then think again before visiting. We look a sea plane out there -- it cost a lot more than the boat, but we saved several hours of time and would recommend the adventure of flying out there and landing on the water if you can afford it. I was hoping for better snorkeling, but it was windy and the water was stirred up so I was a bit disappointed in the fish. Still, this was a fun adventure.

This tour, and home, are owned by the National Park Service. There IS a fee for the tour, though you can tour the grounds without paying. It is a five dollar fee, cheap for what turned out to be an hour and a half VERY informative guided tour. A very interesting look into several families's impact on the home.

Outstanding piece of history in the middle of the Gulf. 65 mi west of Key West. You'll need 45-60 mins to tour the fort and then you'll have time for snorkling or just sitting on the sand and taking in the view. You get there by ferry (about 3 hrs) or seaplane (35 mins). Plane is about $260/each, but worth it.

You can drive through the park for free but you can also pay to drive through a tree. It's cheezy, but fun :-) If you are short on time, you could put aside maybe 2 hours to drive through and enjoy the view (especially Avenue of the Giants), but I highly recommend allowing time for some walks. Most are very easy to do. We saw two herds of Elk during our day exploring the Redwood forests - what a treat.

My husband and I heard about this place on the local news so we decided to take a day trip there one Saturday. From the Orlando area it is about a two hour drive. Once you get there, check into the Visitor Center and get your ticket for the boat ride to the fort. It is completely free! On the day we were there the boats ran on the half hour and the boats did fill up. They use a pontoon type boat that seats maybe 20-30 people. The boat ride is short, maybe 5-10 minutes and they give you about 20-30 minutes at the fort. It is small and doesn't take much time to walk around it. The day we were there, they had a gentleman dressed in period attire and he gave a wonderful description of what it was like back in the day when the fort was operational (hundreds of years ago). If you are in the area, we definitely recommend it and again, it is free!

The Mount Rushmore National Memorial is a sculpture features the faces of four American presidents: George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt, and Abraham Lincoln, sculpted by Gutzon Borglum and his son, Lincoln Borglum. The lighting program takes place at approximately 9 p.m. nightly (May-September) in the park's amphitheater. No entrance fee, but paid $11/car parking fee which entitles us unlimited entry to the memorial for the calendar year.

If you are on this side of the island, you need to go to the park. It is $10 per car, but that gets you a week of coming and going whenever you want. The park is open 24 hours. Go to the Jaggar museum overlook at night for an amazing sight. We missed seeing the lava flow, but the park was still one of our favorites.
Well kept trails and education center, very friendly park rangers, close to hwy, check it out! Only $5 park fee.

It had snowed overnight so it was a long snowy drive in. When we finally arrived it was well worth the effort. We thought we would be the only ones there but that was not the case many had also made the trip also. The volunteers that manage the sight are excellent and very friendly. The few dollars it cost is well worth it! We quite enjoyed the whole day.

This is a real gem in the rough. It is a small fort built by the Spanish to help defend their holdings in the City of St Augustine. Tiny by comparison to the Castillo in St Augustine. To reach it go about 15 miles south of St Augustine on A1A and turn right at the sign. The fort is reached by a National Park Service boat and the ride is about 5 minutes long. No fee whatsoever for the attraction or boat ride. Usually a guide is there to explain what happened there, why and when. The fort was typically staffed by 7 troops. This fort has a historical connection to Fort Caroline near Mayport, north of Jacksonville. Back in the day the French were anxious to get a piece of the new world and clashed with the Spanish. If a storm hadn't wrecked the French fleet, the history off the United States would probably have been much different. There is also a 1/2 mile nature trail. The ferry boat leaves on the 1/2 hour, weather permitting.

We enjoyed our stop at Fort Matanzas. It's a Spanish fortification that can be reached by ferry. There is a short nature trail near the visitors centre. You get your boarding pass from the park ranger at the centre, then board the ferry which goes every hour. The ferry is a little unpredictable due to the weather. When we arrived the signs said the ferry wasn't running that day since there had been a tornado warning in the morning. I wandered down to the dock to take some pictures of the fort since we couldn't go over. I then asked the ranger what the next day's forecast looked like. It was then that she told me the ferry was about to make it's first run of the day.

There are many more things to see at the historical park other than Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell. There are the First and Second Banks of the United States, Carpenters' Hall where the first Continental Congress met, a few historical houses. All of the park itself is free but places place Christ Church Burial Ground costs around $2 per head to enter. All in all it is a great park with a lot of history.

From strange endemic plants and birds, to lush fern and ohia forests, to stark lava fields, to other-worldly volcanic craters (some with molten lava), to local art work, this place deserves five stars. Don't miss the hike around part of the crater on the crater rim trail, a hike at the Jurassic feeling Thurston Lava Tube, a hike on the Devastation Trail, a stay at the Volcano House on the edge of the crater, the Visitor Center (buy inexpensive pocket guides to the local plants and birds) and the nearby Volcano Art Center (check out the beautiful and dirt cheap signed prints by Dietrich Varez and other local art priced from less than 20 dollars to thousands), the ranger talk on the volcano at the Jagger Museum (very funny and informative), a drive down the chain of craters road including a walk to the petroglyphs near the coast, and a visit at night to see the glowing lava from near the Jagger Museum. This is a great introduction to volcanism before a hike or boat ride to the actual flow. I haven't hiked up to the summit of Mauna Kea or hiked across the main crater, so I have something new to do when I return! Arrive early for the crowded hikes and dress in layers as it can be cool and windy, or hot and still. The hotel and restaurant were being renovated when we visited in March, but they still sold sandwiches and other lunch fare at the hotel which we ate across the street near the visitor center.

The entire day was great. Four hours at the park was just right. You could tell this company (Yankee Freedom) had every detail of the day figured out to run smoothly. Staff were very friendly. Perfect day. Definitely worth the price. A must visit for anyone staying for longer than just the weekend.
A lot of these Spanish forts look the same in Florida and the Caribbean, but this one is done up really well with activities and cheap to get in.

I loved going to this park! It was 10$ a car to get in, which I find reasonable. The lava tube is pretty awesome, and found the closed road at the bottom of the part very interesting. Best place to see the glow of the lava is from jaggar museum! The people at the visitor centre is very informative and friendly, and the art gallery beside the center has some interesting stuff.

I wasn't sure what all the excitement was about when researching this online, but after spending the day there I can see what all the fuss was about. We started off by renting sleds in the gift shop. They rent for $10 used, but if you bring them back they will refund you $3 per sled. Make sure you bring your camera, I probably snapped about 200 photos of my children sledding, rolling, and making sand angels ! The weather was perfect , high of 56 but my children's faces still got a little sunburned so make sure you bring sunscreen. I would loved to have stayed for sunset as I can only imagine how beautiful it must be. Next time I plan on camping there for the night.

A lot of people don't know about the battle of Kings Mountain, but it was a key to victory in the Revolutionary War. Fought in October 1780 it was a turning point in the war in the south. If you saw the movie "The Patriot," some of the events at Kings Mountain are portrayed in it. We were there in December, and it wa spretty empty of tourists, which for us wa sgreat, but the Visitor Center was open and the staff extremely well informed about the battle and were also very courteous. There was no charge and the exhibits, monuments, and free brochures made it a very worthwhile side trip on our way to Asheville.

If you are in the Flagstaff area and like History, don't miss this stop. Part of the National Park system, so there is a $5 per person charge unless you have the National Parks card. The canyon contains the remains of rock dwellings that you can walk DOWN 240 steps to reach. You are permitted to walk through the houses, browse, enjoy the scenery, etc. It feels like it is an additional 40 steps back to the top and they are steep. Warning, not really for anyone with arthritis or back problems, as the climb will really aggrivate the problem. There is a trail around the ranger station that is suitable for a lesser hike and viewing the canyon. Rangers on duty for questions and a small museum on site.

This National Park is located about 15 miles south of St. Augustine and is worth the trip. There is a boat ride to the Fort as well as an informative guide who goes along. The scenery is beautiful. There is a walking trail as well as a beach. There are areas for fishing too. The park is shaded and family friendly. It's hard to believe all of this is free (not even a parking fee).

We stopped here to see the white sands and this a must see on your trip through southern NM. Rent one of the sleds in the gift shop for $10 and you get $3 back when you return it. The park is 8 miles long so go to the very back for the highest dunes and find a dune that goes straight down for the best sledding. The sand is beautiful and breath taking. We spent about 1.5 hrs here and that was enough time.

Take a picnic after you visit the park. Watch for whales in season. Enjoy the history. Comfortable shoes. Uneven surfaces be careful. When sign says high surf pay attention and stay away from the immediate shore line. We take bets on who will be the first unobservant visitor to get a smack down, don't spoil your visit use common sense. There are tidal pools for the little ones to play in.

Seriously, they should charge atleast a car fee into the park. You get to watch a short movie then take a quick ferry across the river to Fort Matanzas. Once there you get a little historic insight from the period dressed tour guide. For those who are able, enjoy a vertical climb to the roof top for a great view. It may not be big but, it is worth seeing. After, enjoy a peaceful walk along the trail and a picnic lunch under the majestic trees. Can't say enough about it, we had a great time !!! Make sure to check tour times and there is limited seating per trip.

This is part of the NPS, so there is a visitor center, which is where you must start (where you get your free ticket). The tour itself is around 30 minutes. Our guide was very good and informative. There is one more home in the area you can visit. The tours are small in numbe rand fill up fast.

Fascinating place to visit. Certainly a wonder of geology and the environment. Visitor center is well done with a nice video that well explains how it all came to be. And the park rangers were very helpful. Gift shop was typical -- some interesting stuff, though at high prices. Very modest collection of snacks, but sufficient, and lots of water at a reasonable price. Walking about in the sand was much fun, but the sledding is greatly overrated: The runs are very short, end on concrete-like desert floor, and that only matters if you can get the sled to travel at more than 1 mph. Rent is $17, but they will refund $5 if you return it. A bit of a ripoff in retrospect. Nonetheless the kids had fun and learned a bit about the desert and how White Sands came to exist. There are many bathrooms on the grounds. The main bathrooms were small and well worn, and they were not overly clean, but functional. There was supposed to a a $3 per person fee, but for some reason it was waived the day we were there. In all we spent about 4 hours on the site. Certainly stop here if in the area.

I never been here before, and while waiting to pick up a load on Monday we decided to visit Mt. Rushmore especially since learning it was 1/2 hour away and semis sans trailers could also park. We went in the off season so the town of Keystone looked like a ghost town, everything was closed. Nevertheless, it thought it was cute and I imagined it crowded in the summer. There is no fee for the park per se, but there is parking fee of $11, and I really loved that it also serves as an annual pass, that way one can visit again and again, that was a nice surprise. It is definitely amazing and inspiring just to imagine what it took to make this monument happen. One can't fathom such ingenuity and such desire to honor history-changing presidents. The park is well kept, it's informative, and accessible. I really liked that it's clean and well maintained, and I never though I could enjoy it as much as I did.

Some reviews are negative about the day trip from Key West to Dry Tortugas but it was one of our most memorable and fun days. We took the Sunny Days fast catamaran trip which included breakfast on the boat, lunch on the island, soft drinks/water all day, snorkeling equipment, and a guided tour of the fort. The ride was 2 hrs. each way and we had 4:30 hrs. to snorkel, eat and tour. We swam along one whole side of the island and saw lots of beautiful fish. The history of the fort was very interesting and topical as Dr. Mudd who treated John Wilkes Boothe was imprisoned there. I believe the ferry would be too slow and not leave much time to enjoy the island. One of our group gets seaside very easily and cannot snorkel but the catamaran was so fast that even he was fine. The food was not great but it was quite adequate and we liked the all inclusive price. The crew and staff were very helpful and kind. All in all, a very fun day.

good trip, a lot of walking, so wear good shoes. Walked thru lava tube, saw a lot steam vents, craters, and lots of people. Still worth the trip. Cannot see lava flow from this side. $10 fee to get into park.

Crater Lake is wondrous at any time but you may think summer is the only time for hiking or family...not so. We visited on a Sunday, busy but not crowded, clear blue sky and light clouds reflecting in the lake. So what to do: only the visitor center and small store/deli are open?!? Take a hike! The rim road is snowed in but cross country skiers keep the track fresh. No skis, no problem. We did not even use snow shoes and hiked nearly 3 miles out on a pretty well packed snow path. Most of the time we were by ourselves. And if the quiet of nature is important, know that snowmobiles are not allowed at the south end of the park at all, so it is just the wind and the voices, yours and the others who take the chance to get out of the car. Several families with smaller children also hiked or skied that afternoon. Highly recommended! No fee in winter.

What an unexpectedly beautiful place! The entrance fee is well worth the trip thru the park. You can buy sleds for sand sledding at the gift shop ... $16.99 each (or $10 for a used one) but get a $5 ($3 used) refund when you bring it back. Tip: If it works out ... watch for someone returning their sleds and grab them before they get into the gift shop - offer even $1 more than they'll get and you're still ahead of the game!)

Volcanoes National Park was $10 per car and the highlight was the Thurston Lava Tube and interpretive centre with its awesome view of the crater. We learned a lot and drive down Chain of Craters Road, making sure we stopped at all the look-offs along the way. Very educational.

We paid $20/person to take a 45 min tour of Melrose. Our guide was very knowledgable and we learned a lot about the history of Natchez and Melrose that we otherwise would not have known. One of the richest families in the pre civil war US once lived here. Our whole view of Natchez changed after this tour.

park: Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park
text: Not actually one big park, but multiple locations. We went to the Complex which has a museum and the bicycle shop. There is a replica Wright flyer and a few hands on displays showing how their plane worked. They also had several exhibits about Paul Laurence Dunbar and other writers. They offer a short movie about him and another movie about the Wright Brothers. 2nd floor has an interesting exhibit about para shoots along with more Wright Brothers items like their printing press and other machines. There was an unexpected exhibit and we were interested to learn about the original Kroger and how they got their start, so a little of everything here. Next door is a small shop filled with bikes and a repair shop. Could spend a couple of hours here. Great for families and adults. Has a gift shop. Best of all FREE ADMISSION! We thought it was as good or better than Carillon Park which has a costlier admission.

A visit to southern New Mexico should include a stop at one of this nation's most unusual and interesting national treasures...White Sands National Monument. Coming down out of the Mountains east of Alamogordo you can see the amazing stretch of white sands reaching out in all directions for miles. Comprising 275 square miles this amazing anomaly is interesting and a fun stop for persons of any age. The white sand is created from gypsum in the surrounding mountains as it is broken up by nature and then washed down into the valley by rains. Blown by the winds the pieces of gypsum are eventually ground by the wind and water into the finest sand-like particles and then formed into 60 foot high dunes again by the prevailing winds. A national park staff operate a small visitor center and are extremely helpful in educating visitors about the dunes and providing maps and guidance for venturing. A 15 minute narrated film show the high lights of the dunes, along with the plants and animals that make their home in the dunes. Day camping on the dunes is permitted as is "sand boarding" down from the tops of the dunes on plastic round snow discs. The sliding is exciting and fun for "kids" of all ages. The cost to enter the 16 mile round trip driving loop into the dunes is only $3 a person and you won't even have to leave the comfort of your vehicle to enjoy this incredible national treasure, unlike any other in the world!

Going to Harpers Ferry make sure you have 3 hours to hike the Maryland Heights Trail! You can park your car at Train Station (very limited spaces available with a $10 fee), cross the bridge (take pictures of that view), walk the Appalachian Trail (take pictures on the poles that have the AT symbol for your memories), cross the C&O canal and start hiking up the mountain. The overlook trail is the short one and have attonishing views of Harpers Ferry and the confluence of the two rivers: Potomac and Shennandoah. If you have more time and energy go ahead till the end of the trail and enjoy more views and nature.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: Touring Virgina with my friend and fellow Civil War History buff Appomatox Court House was bound to be on our list of sites to visit. We were pleasantly surprised to see that there was much more than just the McLean House - the wee town has been resurrected as well. In addition to viewing the place where Grant met Lee to accept his surrender we also got a most excellent feel for what a small community clustered around a court house would have been like. The park ranger was very informative, the film at the visitor's center was very comprehensive. Give yourself at least 3 hours to investigate the entire site well. One caution....there are two "courthouses" in Appomatox - be sure you are headed to the National Park Site and not the courthouse where one would pay a parking fine. Also..be aware that the hotels in Appomatox are substandard (at best) so staying in nearby Lynchburg or at a local B&B might be a good idea. I stayed at the Super 8 - the people were nice and the place is clean but the mattress was a dismal lump, the sheets were gray and worn thin and the bedspread was straight from the 1980's.

We spent a couple of hours in Hot Springs National Park. Worthwhile if you're in Hot Springs, but I don't know that I'd make a special trip. The lookout tower is nothing special (but costs $7/person). There are some decent short hikes. We hiked down from the tower on the 0.6-mile Peak trail. Trail was mostly gravel, had some decent views, but nothing outstanding.

A group of six of us went off season (recommended), it was a long three hour boat ride out there, but they serve a continental breakfast and had plenty of room to stretch out and nap. When we arrived, we had to remove all our possessions from the boat and park them on the beach area, you could tour the prison, snorkel, lounge on the beach at this point. We opted for the guided tour, which I recommend, our tour guide was informative and humorous. This lasted about an hour. There was a deli style lunch available back on the boat, so after we wandered around the prison a little more we went and ate lunch. From here we took our cooler and blankets and spread out on the beach. The day was quite warm, but the water was wonderful. Part of group opted to snorkel, while the rest of us sat about waist deep in the water and chatted the afternoon away. We walked around the prison on this brick path that was in the water and could watch other people snorkel and could see fish. they allow you to bring your own coolers full of refreshments. They also have a cash bar on the return trip. It is a little pricey, but since we are locals, go a good discount. It is very worth the price to go, but I couldn't imagine being out there if our boat had been full (as it was maybe at 1/3 capacity). Fun day, great crew (tip them-they appreciate it!!)

My husband and I took our boys on a trip to southern Utah and northern Arizona to see the national and state parks of the area. Bryce Canyon was one of our favorites. Amazing scenery, friendly staff at the park info centre and no huge crowds. Even though we are Canadian, we purchased a US state park year pass... Very worthwhile since we visit the US 2x per year. The boys loved the hike into the canyon and my husband took hundreds of pictures. The snow in the canyon this time of year makes the red rocks glow and the temperature was good for hiking. We also visited the Grand Canyon on the trip, but honestly, we enjoyed Bryce much more. The Grand Canyon was, of course, spectacular, but the crowds of people, the fighting for parking and most of all the agree of watching people do silly things so close to the edges (I can see why people have unfortunately fallen there) really took much away from our enjoyment. No such worries at Bryce.

We visited the Kilauea Visitor Center while on an excursion with Kamaki's Authentic Hawaiin Adventures. We booked this excursion with him as we disembarked from the Sapphire Princess. The price was way less than the cruise excursion, the bus held 24 people, it was clean and he was alot of fun and vibrant with his hawaiin look and knowledge of the island. We spent about 45 minutes at the volcano sight where you can see the smoke coming the active volcano. The museum had alot of valuable information with pictures and demonstrations and I can see this place being a hit with kids. It has a huge parking lot and the walking paths were very easy to follow. I would certainly recommend a visit and plan to spend lots of time visiting the park areas.

The drive from the DC metropolitan area is easy and doesn't seem very long since the scenery is so pleasant. The museum is the town down by the river. There is a small fee to get into the park area which includes a bus shuttle down to the town. Cars can drive down but there isn't much parking; there is also a train station in town, which may have been a fun way to travel. The streets are narrow and steep, so be prepared for climbing. The town is not very big and can be seen in a few hours. There are many merchants in the town for food and gifts and the prices are reasonable. This is also a starting point for many hikers who we met on the bus into town. Bathroom facilities are located in the town and at the park entrance near the visitor center.
Excellent interpretive program, Exterior of the building currently being rehabilitated. A visit here is inexpensive if you have the federal senior pass.

Fort Matanza is a cute little fort near St. Augustine. For an outsider it really isn't as close to the other attractions as I thought it was from the information I had read earlier. The ferry ride is literally just across the river, not a long ride. You only have about 30 minutes or so to see the fort but that is just about right. There is a nice 1/2 mile trail at the visitor center. Check out the website for more information as you do have specific time frames and rules to follow. There is no fee, but they have a little box for donations.

So finally we can take off this site on our bucket list. It was an awe experience being able to see it by yourself. We went there early march, so it's a little bit cold, bring jacket and prepare for layers. Parking is $11 but is for the whole year admission.

Buckstaff Bathouses on bathouse row is still fully functioning, and offers both mineral baths and massages. I got a Swedish massage. It was very enjoyable and relaxing and well worth the price. There are several quaint specialty shops along the opposite side of the road facing Bathouse Row. Also, the drive between I-40 and the park is beautiful.

This was the only home that Lincoln ever owned. He lived here for roughly 18 years prior to being elected to the Presidency. Not only is the home still standing and restored, but roughly half the houses on his block and the neighboring block are as well. You can only go in a few of them - but that's not the attraction. The attraction is Lincoln's home. The cool thing about the street scene is that you feel like you're back in 1860. Cars aren't allowed. The sidewalks, the street, the houses - are all as they were 150 years ago. Although, I admit, you can't look straight north - you need to block out the Hilton. Since this is free; you can't beat the price!

We stayed nearby in Volcano Village, which I highly recommend. Why? Because park admission for one car for an entire week is only $10 and we went back 3 times over 2 days and it was easy to drive back and forth from where we were saying. The first afternoon we arrived, it was rainy and foggy. We stopped at the visitor center which was busy and crowded, so we quickly left and went to the Jagger museum which is right at the edge of the crater. The museum is small but interesting. Unfortunately for us, the crater was socked in with clouds and we couldn't see a thing. So we drove down to the lava tube which is on the other side of the park. The tube is well-lit, easy to walk through and pretty impressive to see. We then continued to follow the park roads down toward the ocean and down to lower altitude where there was far better visibility and we could view the old lava fields all the way down to the ocean. It was spectacular.

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: We were surprized at how much we were able to see. The self-guided tour was easy with the map and CD given to us at the Visitor Center. The tour was very well done and included recordings made by the President and the First Lady. The family cemetery and gravesites of the Pres. and Mrs. Johnson seemed like a quiet country cemetery that could be found anywhere was quite a contrast to the sprawling "Texas White House" with the presidential jet and luxury cars just down the road! The house has been restored to the way it was during Johnson's presidency and a $3 ticket gets a quick tour with basic information of the main floor. There is not much time to really look at things, but the tour guides answer questions. Groups are moved through the house quickly, but you can take as much time as you want wandering around the property, seeing the oak tree under which Johnson held meetings (one quarter of his presidency was spent here so the run way was well used by those meeting with him here rather than in Washington), the river bank where barbecues with top entertainment for up to 1500 people were held, the garages with glass sides providing easy viewing of Johnson cars etc. Very interesting were the cement slabs on which guests to the ranch "wrote" their names. It was fun finding names of other presidents, politicans, entertainers, astronauts etc. Our only downer was leaving the park at closing time when we stopped almost at the gate, hoping to take a quick final picture from the car. A car with a guide pulled up beside us and told us to leave immediately as she was locking the gate and we would have to call 911 to get out! That took more time than it would have for us to take the picture - and left us feeling a little less enthused about the experience. There are also very good exhibits etc. at the visitors' center.

I only rate it a 3 because for me it was less impressive than some other ruins but very worth the stop. Ah, I'll give it a 4 instead since I like the isolation. I was on my way by motorcycle from Durango to the Moki Dugway and Monument Valley and on to Kayenta, AZ. Was it ever hot. Take water just in case and check your fuel before you head out. There is drinking water there and I had plenty with me. It is really in "Nowhere", Utah. I wasn't sure I'd ever find it. I did have to guess which way to go at least once. But I like these out of the way places most people never see. The visitor's center is nice and the rangers seemed glad to see me. A couple was there in a motorhome and another motorcycle rider came in while I was leaving. The hiking trails did not seem too rough. The trail signage was very good. If you have the time take the hike.

Melrose is operated by the National Parks Service, so there's no question about the quality of the interpretation here; no admission is charged to enjoy the grounds, but I strongly suggest the nominal fee charged to see the interior of this unforgettable house. Among the furnishings that set this apart are the original floor cloth that is a National Treasure in and of itself, and the massive Punkah over the dining room table. The time I visited, photographs were allowed IF you disarm the flash function. It's possible to make an afternoon of this, if you take a picinc to enjoy on the grounds and take your time looking at all of the available interpretive sites on the property. Again, this has to go at the top of your list of places to see, even if you have to come back to Natchez over and over again, like I do.

We visited Melrose House in October 2012. The mansion is furnished with original items. Barney was our guide and was outstanding in telling the story of the original family and life on the plantation. This tour is not to be missed. Plan on about 1 1/2 hours. The Golden Eagle card is not valid here, but the fee is nominal.

We took the all day sea plane adventure, which allowed plenty of time. The fort tour is interesting. The kids became junior rangers. The beaches were nice and never too crowded. The snorkeling was only okay though, best around the pylons on the south side. Bring plenty of water and sunscreen. Entrance fee is $5 per adult, children free.

Stopped by the VNP yesterday. $10 per car to enter. the view of the caldron is spectacular. There was lots of "Peles hair"...fine strands of glass...just like hair of lengths of 1 foot or more, being produced by the volcano. Huge plume of smoke! Near are the steam vents you can stand next to and feel the steam. It is very hot so be careful, if you like your hair thick and curly, and it wasn't before, standing next to the vents will get it done. We only had 2 hours so we also did the lava tube that is enormous and you walk through it, probably 300' long...amazing.

We booked our 150$ per person, 2 1/2 hour trip to the Dry Tortugas with great anticipation. We purchades the tickets 2 days before the sailing. The morning of, we were informed that the seas were a bit rough and choppy and we were offered Dramamine for sale. We asked about the snorkelling and were told it was still a go. If we cancelled there would be no refund. After an extremely unpleasant 2 hours (people were throwing up all over the ship - luckily we did not) we arrived at the Park, were given an interesting tour of the Fort (30 Mins) and then sat there for the rest of the day as the snorkelling was a bust because of the wind and waves. The organisers new this before we left Key West and I feel it was dishonest of them to not allow refunds. If you plan on going check conditions carefully before purchasing your tickets.

Our Young @ Heart senior group took a bus tour of Antietam Battlefield. Our tour guide, Gary Rohrer, was superb, making what could have been a long and boring morning really fascinating! To hear his stories, one would have thought he'd been there to experience the battle and all that led up to it. We felt like we were a part of the action. The visitor's center, where we first watched the introductory film, is beautiful, and watching the film first gave us insight into many of the stops along our tour. It was well worth visiting. Antietam is a National Park, so anyone who has a Golden NP Pass can visit free of charge.

Two young children and I stayed overnight at camp site no. 1, about .7 miles from trailhead at end of February near almost full moon. Temperatures fluctuated 50 degrees between day and night. (Frost on tent in the morning; only the slightest of breeze just before dawn.) Cost about $9 total at gate for admission and camping permit. Checked in at visitor's center for assignment. Ranger very friendly and helpful. Nice small exhibits. Children wished bathrooms were more clean; they didn't like graffiti. Very little in way of sundries at gift shop. We brought one plastic disc for dunes. They sell them there but at a premium price. They also sell wax, which might have been a good purchase. Trailhead is about 8 miles from visitor's center, with large lot and vault toilet. As mentioned, the "trail" is from post to post. Easier on top of dunes; climbing can be soft and tough with weight on your back. We planned only for one overnight: brought lots of warm clothes, bags & blankets, food, stove, tent, lots of water, etc. Even for our short time in winter, I can imagine you could get burned easily. Children loved playing and a little exploring. This is Leave No Trace (pack in/pack out) camping. Actually got a phone signal from top of dunes near our camp site. Quickly warmed in morning; fun trek out; you can see road and lot from distance; saw other early morning hikers. Afterward we visited the Space Museum in Alamogordo, which we liked.

Had no idea what to expect - but for a fee you drive into a loop road and can stop lots of places. There is just stark white large sand dunes everywhere and you can get out and play! Some people had snow disks to try to slide down, but our kids (2 age 6 and one age 12) just started rolling down and making sand angels and digging - just terrific fun! There are hikes you can take as well. But it is something you won't want to miss!

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: This is just a fantastic trip, no matter what your age. What a wonderful bit of important American history. From seeing what the US was like just a little over 100 years ago when LBJ was born (and you can visit a working farm that was down the road from his birthplace), to the "Texas White House" it's a lovely way to spend a day. On top of that, if you DON'T go inside the Johnsons' home, it's FREE (and even to go into the home is a nominal $3/person fee). They give you a CD to pop into your car that is a guided tour as you drive around the ranch. The cars/airplane (Airforce one) were a big hit with our son - as was the working farm. All in all, a great way to spend a lovely day in the Hill Country. While you're there, take the drive on in to Fredericksburg - a jewel of a town with wonderful shops and places to eat. And there are all of these wineries on the road into Fredericksburg - so plenty to do.

This is a bunch of natural gypsum dunes just off of I-70 between Alamogordo and Las Cruces, New Mexico. It is definitely worth a few hours of "stop and relax". There is a fee to drive into the park (unless your have a National Park Pass) but it is reasonable. There are bathrooms outside of the park entrance as well as a gift shop and visitors' center. All are well-maintained and staffed with friendly workers. It is 15 miles from Alamogordo (if you have young kids, this is a decent potty stop as Alamogordo speed limit will drop to 45 mph as you hit town).

Our Photo Club spent two days at White Sands National Monument. Ranger Kathy Denton made certain we were shown the very best places for sunrise and sunset photos. For a mere $50 we were met by Ranger Terry Wilder at 5:30 AM , given quiet time to explore and get ready for the glory of sunrise. The 15 minute video gave us a good understanding of the geology of White Sands and gave us an even larger appreciation of its natural beauty and magical colors.

Wilie getting out to the Dry Tortugas via the Yankee Freedom is not cheap, it is certainly a place you should consider putting on your itinerary if you are spending some time in the Keys. It has both the historical aspects, as well as the environmental interests. You can lounge on some nice beaches, look at the birds, or, best of all, go snorkeling. We say barracuda, a shoal of shrimp, some (very large) lobsters, tarpon and a range of the more normal sea life. Probably the best snorkeling we have done in Florida, though that is not extensive.

First - a must is to stop at the Visitor centre. The trails aren't right there but the ranger on duty will give you a map and help you decide which trail(s) you might want to take. There are things to see on them all ... some are longer than others. We chose the 2.2 mile round-trip Rinconada Canyon .Trail. Not difficult, but be advised it's like walking on a beach ... but with some up-hills. All sand on the trails so you get a bit of a workout. The petroglyphs are amazing, and you see more with each turn of the trail. You can do a loop back to the parking area but we chose to walk back on the same path which worked out great as you see stuff you didn't see going the other way. Water is advised as it is a hot, exposed hike. I also saw a lizard which was cool! There is no fee for this site.

I was a bit hesitant to go at first, but was persuaded by my bf. I was pleasantly surprised! $12 gets you a two-hour guided tour. Your journey into the "twilight zone" as they referred to it was filled with history and humor. You could tell our guide really enjoyed his job and his enthusiasm was contangious. We did the historic tour which took us over 300 feet below the surface. I wouldn't recommend this tour if you have a bad back, neck or knees. There were close to 500 stairs and lots of crouching. The ground you walked on was often rocky and muddy. Wear a comforable pair of gymshoes that you don't mind if they get dirty. You will come out a little dusty! Also, make sure to wear long pants and a jacket or a heavy fleece as the temperatures below drop to a cool 50 degrees. Overall, a great experience for people of all ages! The property also has their own postal office and grocery store. Edmonson County is a dry county, but Mammoth Cave is government owned so they are exempt. Be sure to stock up on liquor at the grocery store. Their prices were cheaper than most liquor stores in Bowling Green!

If you plan on taking the house tour, get your tickets here first before you do anything else, like the Lincoln museum or library. We made the mistake of not getting tickets for the house tour right away and ended up not getting to go inside. Unlike other Lincoln sites, there is NO fee for a ticket, but you NEED a ticket to get into the house.

Spectacular, with forests, marshes, a bike trail, cliffs,an old canal route with some of the locks still visible, a train that runs through the park and will pick you and your bike up and take you back to where you started for a small fee (must get ticket ahead of time), beautiful in all seasons.

I was a little nervous about going to Mount Rushmore in March because it had just snowed two days before we went. The roads getting to Mount Rushmore were great, even after the snow. They keep the roads cleaned off well, which is really important. It was beautiful and worth the visit! I took great pictures of the kids, and it made me realize how I need to take advantage of the different sites in our parks. The only cost is parking and any additional souvenirs. The parking pass is good for the entire year, so we may go back later in the summer. I would recommend going when it warms up because everything going to the park was closed for the season. Wonderful experience, and if you are in the area, you need to go! It is definitely worth the visit!

So how old are the petroglyphs? no one knows. and there are some that are actually dated (feb 22, 1919). there are other more exciting places to visit first (e.g., Tent Rocks), but these are a pleasant way to pass some time closer to Albuquerque. There are several different trails to choose from - we did Rinconada Canyon, where we saw plenty of petroglyphs, and the terrain was a mix of rocky and sandy (sometimes feeling as if you were walking on the beach). Be forewarned, the "bathrooms" have no running water...

The National Park service gives free guided tours of the Lincoln Home. Robert Todd Lincoln sold the home to the State for $1 on condition that no admission be charged to visitors. You must obtain a free ticket for the tour, which you get in the visitor center. The home has been beautifully restored, and most of the furniture is original. The Lincoln Home is a short 4 block walk from the Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum.

During my Google search of the area before departing from home, the National Park sounded so intriguing that we did not want to pass up the opportunity to visit the attraction while in the State. To comment that we were not disappointed would be considered an understatement. The protected area is so diverse and unique in character that our only regret was our later afternoon arrival, preventing us from spending more time enjoying this treasure. An evening sunset stroll conducted by park staff was the highlight of our visit, etching fond memories in perpetuity. A must see!!!

Harpers Ferry is wonderful to visit for many different reasons. Parking at the Park Service welcome center is super easy and inexpensive ($10/car). There's a restroom and welcome station where a staff member will tell you all you need to know. From there you take a 5 minute ride down to the historic town and there is a brief introduction to the history of the town to listen to.

This place is a little far from everything in vernal, UT, but its worth the drive if your kids love dinosaurs. We took a trip out to Vernal UT last June 2012 when we attended a family reunion. We stayed in Provo, UT and we decided that we wanted to check this place out. Vernal is less than 200 miles away from Provo, but the scenery is awesome on the way there. Other than the the fossils on the side of the mountain, you can do other things while you are there. They have a hiking trail or you can camp on the colororado side. We went to the utah side where the monument is at. There is a $10.00 fee for the national park entrance. Thinking of doing this again this year. Vernal has a museum that houses dinosaurs.

Camped at the Fruita Campground ... for $10 a night. Fabulous clean campground with well spaced sites. Awesome hiking right from the campground in a nice slot canyon. Short drive to other nearby awesome hikes. For us, this was better than Zion, Bryce and the Grand Canyon. We were there in March 2013 so weather was a bit chilly but it was still awesome.

So interesting and unique! I recommend going in the early morning in hopes of better weather. This is a rain Forrest and the weather changes in an instant. It seemed to be clearer in the mornings. We were lucky to catch the sights before the fog rolled in and left no visibility. Be aware of the sulphur gases in the air because they can give you a headache pretty quickly if its smoking a lot. Take your time and enjoy all the sights that aren't blocked off. Don't forget to hike to the lava tubes! Also there's a $10 admission per car but it was well worth it.

While we've lived in New Mexico for several years and had intended to see Chaco sooner, this was our first trip there. It did not disappoint! The drive there from ABQ is about 2 1/2 hours (via US 550 turning onto County Road 7900 -- we inquired about the road from Crownpoint but were advised not to use this road as it's very rough, even for 4x4 trucks). The last 14 miles are over unpaved wash-board road. We have a large 4x4 truck and so this was no problem for our truck. We did see and pass several passenger cars (Camry, Civic, etc.) and they can make the trip in with no problem (other than having to go about 5mph for these last 14 miles). Once in the road around the park is well paved. There are several outstanding examples of ruins all built between 850 and 1250 AD. You can walk around everything you see but of course not within the ruins structures (same almost everywhere in the southwest). You must stop into the park headquarter building to pay your entrance fee and when you do you'll receive a map to the area. The map is very helpful for pointing out what there is to see. We were there a total of about five hours and filled the time completely. On a return trip we plan on taking the hike from the parking area at the top of the loop road (the loop road is four miles long) to the mesa overlooking Pueblo Bonita so we can get the overview of these unique ruins. If you have day while in New Mexico (ABQ or Santa Fe), MAKE THIS TRIP!

Mammoth Cave N P is wonderful the staff is knowledgeable and the grounds are well maintained. My son and 12 year old grandson and I took the 4 hour tour through the cave. It is listed as strenuous but it's not as hard as it sounds. Probably just staying on your feet that long is the most difficult. However they do stop for breaks regularly including a lunch break where you can purchase a sandwich, soup, cookie and drink for $8.50. Personally I'd recommend packing a light lunch and taking with you. A small daypack is easy to manage as you walk through the cave. And I'd take a small flashlight too. They're nice for looking into dark places just off the path. We purchased our tickets for the tour online well ahead of our visit. I'd recommend this as there are always crowds at this park and some of the tours do sell out ahead of time.

You are transported back in time when you step inside his home. On advice from others, we made this our 1st stop & glad we did. You need a free ticket to tour the home as they limited the number of people inside. We arrived at 11:30 on a Tuesday morning & our ticket time was at 1pm...they fill up fast. We had our kids take part in the Junior Ranger program, which kept them busy. We walked down a few blocks to the Old State Capitol. (Free inside self guided tour) by the time we were done & had lunch, we walked back & toured his home. We then did the museum & tomb the rest of the afternoon. Parking was $2 an hour...should've/could've found parking on the street for a $1 an hour.

The Park Service has done a great job of attempting to preserve this old mission. The self guide the rangers give you, helps you understand just how thins were in the 1700's and what the missionaries attempted to accomplish. It is sure worth the $3.00 entry fee. When we were there restoration is continuing. Check it out

Took the ferry out to Dry Tortugas. It was rather expensive, but it was a long trip, 2.5 hours each way, making this an all-day activity. Food was part of the fare, but it was what it was. Not thrilled that one had to purchase bottled water. As we were planning the trip, I noticed that each day we waited to book, the further out the available days went, so pick a date and book your ticket at least a week in advance. You can cancel I think 24-48 hours. The ride back was a bit bumpy, so if you get motion sickness then be prepared with some Dramamine, which they also sell ($1).

We arrived at the park around 9.30 a.m. It took us 3hrs 15 mins from Kona taking hwy 19 although we stopped at a few view points on the way and also for coffee and snacks. We left the park around 8 p.m. and took hwy 11 back to Kona, taking 2 hrs 15 mins. On arriving we went for a short walk with a Ranger which was very informative. Crater Rim drive was closed at the Jagger Museum so after spending some time in the museum and viewing area, we drove back, stopped at the Thurston Lava tube then onto Chain of Craters Road. Park signage could be better as a few times we stopped at areas that didn't seem to be much but turned out to be really worthwhile.... 1969-1974 Mauna Ulu lava flows for one.... short walk from parking lot. Went as far as we could go on Chain of Craters road...to the 2003 lava flows and walked on some of the youngest land on earth.... where the lava flowed across the road. In the distance on the shoreline, we could just about see some steam where the lava is presently entering the ocean. Went back to the Jagger Museum stopping at the Military Camp for Starbucks (Yes!) coffee.... they also serve good food at the camp. The Jagger Museum car park filled up very quickly around 6p.m. and people had to park in the overflow parking lot a short walk away, but by about 7.30 p.m. it was half empty.... perhaps because the temperatures had dropped considerably and it was cold... bring a jacket. Awesome to see the glowing flume cloud at night. So much to see for only $10 per vehicle! My only regret is we didn't get time to hike the Kilauea Iki trail which I really wanted to do.... will have to go again!!! If we were to go again, I would make this trail a priority and maybe stop off at the military camp for dinner before heading up to the Jagger Museum (around 8p.m.) for nighttime viewing of Kilauea. Apart from driving through pouring rain in Hilo area, the weather in the park was sunny and warm.... shorts and t-shirt.... although around about 5p.m. a fleece and/or jacket plus gloves was needed.

We wanted to see this historic Monument and drove the 28 miles to get a few pics. The car admission is $11, but the gate was open and unattended as we were in off season and near the end of the afternoon. Great views and pics from the parking lot and with some hiking you can get better shots. Worth the trip. Keystone town was closed as off season. No gas or places to eat.

My family and I have gone to 10 National Parks in the past nine months and they continue to impress me! First of all, there is no admission price and the visitors center is very neat, clean, well organized and kid friendly. The ranger behind the counter was very knowledgeable and patient with ALL of my 9 year old son's questions. Having two younger children with us, we chose to take the 2+ mile long boardwalk self guided tour. The path is VERY well maintained, safe, and easy to walk for kids. The only slight at all is the limited parking and the number of people enjoying the afternoon on the boardwalk, but apparently the word is out and the public recognizes this tremendous resource!!

Antietam National Battlefield is an educational and interesting place to visit. There was a nice reception area with a decent tourist/book store, clean bathrooms and a place to watch a nice 30-minute introductory movie. We bought and used the auto tour CD. It has more information than expected. You can choose to walk the 8 1/2 mile path if you want. Military can get in free if you have the National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Pass. You can get one there, I think, if you haven't already gotten one. I would pay to see it again even if we didn't have the pass.
didnt want to pay the admission so we drove the very long road around and got some great pictures don't feel like i missed all that much

Harper's Ferry is a great place to visit. It is a beautiful and educational place with tons of history with little museums throughout the town. There is a very visible church on top of the hill that is lovely. We weren't able to go in, however. There are some nice shops and decent places to eat. We went into several stores, but there was a pottery store that had some really gorgeous pottery at fairly reasonable prices that we loved. If you are military you can get the National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Pass and get in free. I would do this again even if I had to pay the regular $10 entrance fee.

We stopped by to visit on our way from Florida. Easy access off I 75. I tried to reserve tickets the night before but most everything was sold out. You do still have to pay for the "self discovery" tour, but it is a nice walk through a beautiful park, and a nice break from driving. We spent about 2 hours here, and I was travelling with a 12 and 13 yr old. I would recommend getting tickets prior to a visit. We'll definitely go back to see the caves.
Wonderful guides and beautiful restorations. Our grandson was full of questions which were encouraged by the period actors. Pay a visit if you can.

Great, but quick visit. Very informative, our guide was super. The tour was free, but there is a limit to group size. We had a 2 hour wait. (Parking is $2.00 an hour.) We toured the other lovely houses and walked across the street and had a wonderful lunch before returning for our tour. The guide was good at including our children in the conversation and pointed out what life was like for the Lincolns. Overall, we thought it was the most touching stops of our Springfield visit.

Admission is free because Robert Lincoln left this as a condition of his donating the property to the park service. There is a visitor's center where you can register for a tour of the homesite. There is also a small gift shop area and a brief movie on the life of Lincoln. Park guides will direct you through a tour of the home. There are not many original pieces in the home but there are a few, including Lincoln's original desk and reproductions of the wallpaper that was originally installed. If you love Lincoln, this site is a must see. You can also walk the streets of old springfield and learn a little bit about Lincoln's neighbors at the time. Very interesting.

My daughters (ages 7 & 8) love earning their Jr. Ranger badges and collecting National Park trading cards so while in Springfield we had to stop at the Lincoln Home. They enjoyed searching for the info needed to fill out their Jr. Ranger booklets (available at the visitor center) and earn their trading cards. The Lincoln home offers free tours however you must get a timed ticket at the Visitor Center. They did run out of tickets the day we were there by 3:00 so if you don't want to miss it make sure you get your tickets early. The park rangers all seemed to love their job and were very friendly and helpful. The house is situated in a neighborhood of preserved buildings of the time period making it especially interesting to see.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: This is an outstanding way to learn about our countries history. At $3 per adult, 15 and younger free or $5 per vehicle, this is a great value.

We didn't expect too much when we stopped here on our way home to NM, but we were pleasantly surprised by the things we saw. Not only is there the mission church with unfinished bell tower, but there are large grounds to explore. More recently, where the mission garden used to be, they have planted heritage trees, much like the fruit trees that would have been there when the mission was operational. There is also a small museum well worth walking through. We were there Easter morning and a lady was outside the Visitor Center making torillas, which was a plus. They offered a booklet to use (but return) so one can guide oneself, and that was worth it. Otherwise, it is hard to know how and when the various buildings, etc. were used. There are more preserved mission churches, but this is a nice place to stop. They also have a small museum store. There is a cost for admission, unless you have a Golden Age Pass -- something well worth the $10 that we paid years ago.

Very impressive to find dunes that large in an area like this. The sand is so white you do need sunglasses;) Entrance is surprisingly cheap and I think I saw options to rent sleds to go sledding. I just walked a little bit and followed a signed tour (1 mile long) that explains the habitat of the animals that live there. Beautiful thing to see.

You should definitely pay the minimal parking fee which is per vehicle and good for up to 1 year so you can go back as many times during your visit as you wish. The best views are from the Presidential Trail which takes you by the base of the monument and over to the sculptor's studio. also the lighting ceremony, museum and theater that shows the making of the monument are equally enjoyable.

If you are in the Black Hills area of South Dakota, Mount Rushmore is a must see! My daughter and I travel to the black hills every few years and Mount Rushmore is always one of our stops. There is a small entry fee which will give you access for up to 1 year. As you enter the National Memorial, you walk through the hall of states, which has a flag from all 50 states on display. Below the National Monument is a large ampitheater with lots of seating, and excellent viewing of the stone faces. There is a paved walking trail that loops around, and gives you an up close view from directly below the faces. The trail also leads to the sculptors workshop, which is loaded with information on how the memorial was carved. Along the trail there is also a possibility for wildlife sightings, we have seen mountain goats and wild turkeys. Many times we have visited the Memorial right before dark, to see the evening lighting ceremony. There is a video presentation with recognition of past and present military members, then the memorial is lighted for viewing for a short while before the nightly closing.

I did not mind paying the fee to enter the park which was $11 because the structure is very big, beautiful and impressive. The park itself is very well taken care of and reverent with all the flags of the states leading to the area where you can see the sculptures very well and take very nice pictures. I like shopping for souvenirs from all these attractions around the world and they have a very large variety of items there. The good thing about going to Mount Rushmore is that Rapid City has a lot of things to do so it is not just seeing a big mountain with the faces of Presidents. I mean it: there is A LOT to to there. The sculptures themselves are very simple. The artist did not use of many traces to make his point. Reminds me of Egyptian sculpture actually. Their eyes impressed me the most. I could stay there for hours just starring at every trace carved in that mountain. I hope you go and have the same good impression I had. Don't be cheap. It is worth driving up there to the park. No, you cannot climb those heads. Just enjoy the view!
Great exhibits, good for school children to visit. Bring your walking shoes. Most of the sites are no fee.

We spent 5 days at Capitol Reef. We camped in the Fruita campground. We loved the family-freindliness of this campground. It is grass--which is nice for the kids to play on. The campground is paved-perfect for bikes. There is a trail that goes along the campground that the kids can ride their bikes on (and dogs are allowed on--a rarity in National Parks). The Gifford house is fun for $1 ice cream and pies. The orchard is fun to play in.

We stopped here on our way to Nashville and are so glad we did! We did the $4 self guided tour, which is pretty limited. I think if we had more time we would have wanted to do the full tour but they were sold out that day. It was still incredible to see the underground workings, and I'd recommend it if you have 45min to a half hour!

We stumbled across this national forest and just loved the scenery throughout our drive through it. We came across so many trees and stunning vistas that it's hard to pick just one. Walking and hiking trails are all over the place. A beautiful and serene area, just what you need to relax. We were lucky to have gone in early April before the heat and before the crowds. I'm not sure about the fee as we used our National Park Pass to go to Zion National Park and Bryce Canyon, both of which are in the Dixie National Park.

If in the area this is a must see. You can easily access it from 191 (half way between Blanding and Bluff Utah) on 262. Don't get discouraged as you drive along 262. There are really trashy looking houses and the road is littered with trash and empty beer and soda bottles. This hwy is nothing to write home about and makes it hard to beleive anything of interest could possibly lie ahead. But it does! The road is paved all the way albeit a little rough and any vehicle can make the drive. Once you arrive the canyon and ruins are visible. It is one beautiful canyon and quite different from the all so many red rock canyons of the area. It consists of large sandstone (I think) rocks but they are whiteish. Pinon pine and junipers cover the nearby terrain as well as the valley floor. The ruins look really unstable since many are on rock bed which is sliding down the hill. They are still amazing structures to look at. The National Park service has wonderful facilities and drinking water. They have a really nice network of paths which allow you to get up close to the ruins without disturbing them while keeping you safe and giving you the best views of the canyon. Warning. Stay on the trails and leave everything you come across alone. They have people disguised as tourist watching you and will gladly give you a $275 fine.

I searched on Trip Advisor for info on what was available in the Independence Hall area. I enjoyed 3 days in Philadelphia-that was very well done and gave a reasonable idea of how much you might do on each day. I found that ordering timed tickets on line for Independence Hall was a big time saver; it cost $1.50/ticket and was priceless! It was Spring break, so there were plenty of people around, but it all moved well.The area is much easier to navigate than it was in the 60's and 70's.

It takes a long time to get up to the site from Silver City, NM but it is a spectacular drive. I had a dog with me so I wanted to get up there early so it would be cool enough for her to stay in the car. I got half way up right at sunrise. I had no idea how wild and beautiful it is up there. They do not allow dogs on the Dwelling Site trail but I found out they do have dog kennels right there for no fee and they are located outside, behind the interpretive center in the shade. There is a great museum and store with lots of books, tee shirts, etc. and clean rest rooms a few miles south of the site. Very nice, friendly people running the whole National Monument. I could tell they all really cared about the park. The trail to the site itself is a steep but not really all that hard and there are lots of benches to rest on. There is a guide up there to explain the dwellings. There are places a bit down below the site on trails (one is called "Lower Scorpion Campground") where it is ok to walk dogs. There are some ancient dwellings and petroglyphs there also. It was cool, sunny, and dry and I (and the corgi dog who was having a great time on the trail) did not want to leave the place. There is a nice, well-stocked general store just down the road from the interpretive center that has coffee, pop, and ice cream and gift items, etc.

Such a great house to see. The park rangers are very friendly and helpful. It is really interesting to see the place where the Lincoln's lived while in Springfield. Every room has a little piece of history for you to see and hear/read about. Love that it is free to see. You do need tickets, but those are free from the visitor center and they have a nice picture of the house on the back if you wanted a keepsake photo. We were early so we found parking easily on the street and only paid a dollar for 2 hours. We were able to take our time and really look around the little neighborhood, (several of the houses have self-guided exhibits inside them) and browse the gift shop afterward.

White Sands has a lot to offer. There are nature trails, picnic areas, ranger programs and so on. But the most exhilarating thing to do is sliding down the dunes on a plastic saucer. Fun for everyone from 3 to 80 years of age. 'Buy' a saucer at the gift shop for 10$ and receive a 3$ refund when you return it (keep your receipt!). So it's basically a 7$ rent. Also buy a piece of wax to keep the pace of sliding. Don't miss to walk one of the trails, it's just such an incredible environment and trail posts provide some information what's going on regarding plants, animals and geology.

Fun to see the monument which is a short walk from the parking lot. $11 for an annual pass is reasonable, but the weather is a bit hit or miss the first part of April so upon arrival it was clear, but after about 2 minutes the fog rolled in and you couldn't see anything. I would definitely do it again if I'm ever in the area. Very pretty.
The park entrance fee was $25, and this gives you a one week permit. There are other types of permits, such as annual but I do not recall the cost of those.

Surprise!!!!----it rained on the way up to the park but that only made the visit much more interesting as the rain made the steam vents more visible, even the small ones along the road to the visitors center. There's something that tickles your funny bone once you park and walk toward the center---the "NO Smoking" sign you pass. Could spend hours just checking out the crater, the vents and sidewalls. Bring binoculars as well as your camera. My favourite part was the walk through th Thurston Lava tube. That makes you realize the force of both nature and Madame Pele. Stop and view the black lava lake on the way to the lava tube. I never realized fern trees grew to such huge sizes. Just about drained my camera battery taking photos on this tour.

I liked everything about the time I spent in Harpers Ferry. Their exhibits are worth taking the time to visit and spending time listening and reading about the area. I especially appreciated the exhibit that had video and a place to sit while watching it. Being able to see how everybody lived and the actual buildings was fun and interesting as well. I would go back there in a heart-beat. Just make sure you purchase a parking ticket.

We have visited Mammoth Cave in summer. Visitor center is very clean and spacious, they have a lot of tours. Need to pay attention what level of difficulty the tour is. Some of them are pretty long and have a lot of steps. Early tours are better, less crowded. It is a bit cool inside, so, make sure you have a light jacket with you even if it is hot and humid outside.

My family and I went to White Sands last year. I had never been, or heard of it, before. I was struggling to get my head around it just being a big beach, minus the water, and what could have been so fun. Once I arrived, however, the view was exceptional and the sand was mystical. We had a blast sliding down the dunes and it was something the whole family could get involved with. I would have liked to see the night time walk but it was not the season for it when I was there. Great day out though! Advice: bring your own things to slide on, we did, then we seen the same things for triple the price in the gift shop!

This attraction consists of a 5 hour boat ride that starts at 8:00am in the morning to a National Park on an island 70 miles from Key West , FL. in the Atlantic.
