The trip includes breakfast and lunch. The attraction consists of an old fort that was never finished. You arrive about 10:30am; have lunch from 11:00am to 1:00pm. Then back on the boat by 2:45pm for a 3:00pm departure. Bathroom facilities on the boat; none on the island. The snorkling is not much to brag about. The fort is consists of a shell with an empty center. Basically, this is a long boat ride to nothing much. For over $300 per couple, I expected more.

Excellent place to learn about the volcanoes and everything that goes with them. LOTS to see (allow time). Wonderful place to learn about Pele. I will go back as I am sure there is much I missed. Be sure to take water and food (flashlight might be needed too as well as good walking shoes!). $10.00 National Park fee (good for 7 days)(per car).

Russell Cave National Monument is a bit out of the way, but worth a stop for those who like to enjoy nature while learning a bit about pre-Columbian natives in the Southeastern U.S. There is a small museum on site, adjoined by a small gift shop. The truly great feature is the Cave itself, which is located a short distance from the visitor center, down a beautiful wooden walkway. The site also offers demonstrations of primitive weapons some days, unfortunately this wasn't offered on the day of our visit due to a lack of staff. Admission is free and the site is beautiful;if you're in the Chattanooga or Huntsville area it's worth the drive.

My wife and I decided to use a guide to access slot canyons in the Escalante area. Escape Goats' service was located by reading Trip Advisor. The trip was booked directly with Shawn, owner and guide and he tailored the half day hike to our needs (photography). Shawn had a relaxed manner, got us to the right places at the right times and provided excellent background on the Indians of the Escalante region, the plants and the geology. Our main destination was Big Horn Slot Canyon; however, we also visited a small slot off the Harris Wash that most hikers would pass by, not knowing it was there. Because of Shawn, we received far more knowledge and enjoyment, not to mention better pictures, from our 5 hour outing. Great value!
Small park with no entrance fee. Nice movie and displays. Easy ride or walk around the loop. We had visited here several years ago and stopped back again.

Kayaking the sea caves from the Meyers Beach is a trip I like to do every 2-4 years. Parking fee is $3/day. Bring your own kayak, or rent from several area places. Camping at Little Sand Bay campground is right next to the Apostle Islands Lakeshore visitor center and is another good place for a kayak day trip to Sand Island.

We stopped to walk the grounds but decided to tour the house -- good decision! The National Park Service guide gave an excellent, informative tour. The house is well-preserved with beautiful furnishings. Non-flash photography is allowed; I couldn't resist taking photos of the lovely rooms. This tour is certainly worth the price of admission.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: We stopped on our way to Richmond,Virginia as part of our Civil War Tour. It was a little out of the way but a scenic drive, and worth the trip. Inexpensive at $5 a car. Certainly worth the trip for Civil War buffs.

I think Lincoln's home was worth a visit. Be aware that you need to get tickets for a particular time slot. All free but we missed the last ticket offering and didn't get to see Lincoln's home. There were two other house on the street that were open to see inside.

This Park is about 2 Hours east of Los Angeles and very easy to get to. The park has a small per car fee upon entrance but well worth the cost. If you are and avid hiker or even photographer this is an awsome and goregous place to get the perfect landscape shots. Numerous Parking areas for the Hiking as well as many small picnic type areas. If you are afraid of rodents, snakes and bugs, this is not the place for you..Trying to find the spot where U2 made ther Joshua Tree album cover is like trying to find a needle in a haystack.

Bryce Canyon is a feast for the eyes. If you didn't see it for yourself you would ever believe it. I recently had the rare treat of seeing Bryce covered in snow. A real treat for me as I have only seen it during the dry seasons before. The winds can be quite fierce at some of the overlooks so if you go in winter and through May, take gloves, coats and cover your head. Regardless of when you experience Bryce, it is truly that, a unique experience that you will remember the rest of your life. As always, a good camera with fresh batteries is a must as you will stop and marvel at the creations before you. Limited number of toilets. Bryce is a 15 mile long, one way in and one way out drive. There is a campground and small lodge but accommodations, fuel and food are before the park entrance. A must see attraction! Fee as for all National Parks is $25.00 per auto and includes up to 4 persons.

Lots of lovely hikes, lave tubes (caves) and history await you. Bring cash as credit cards and debit cards are not accepted for the entrance fee or gift shop. Pack a picnic too. There are no restaurants here but some nice picnic areas and a campground. There is a small visitor center and gift shop. I would go late spring or late fall. I suspect the summers are hot. Visit the National Monuments homepage for details to plan your trip and get background information. Food and lodging is several miles outside of the Monument in little towns nearby. We stayed at the Winema Lodge just outside the park, which was convenient, fun and different. (Check out separate reviews) Be sure to bring headlamps and gloves are nice.

I could not believe I was still in the state of South Carolina. Once leaving the visitors center you quickly realize that you are someplace very special. Taking the to board walk through the forest, seeing 1,000 year old trees, the flora and fauna it's all amazing. There is also a place to fish and camping. There is no admission! Truly a national treasure here on the east coast.

This is a great place to hike - and one we visit at least once a month. Highly recommend for families with kids or anyone who wants to get some fresh air in mother nature. Would recommend making sure you pay the park fees as you will be fined.
This is well worth the extra cost to spend the day and see history and beauty! I loved every minute of my day here and have NO dislikes from the trip. We took the boat and had such a great time

We stopped here during spring break and enjoyed our visit. The staff were really friendly and helpful. We decided to fork over $80 to get an annual national parks pass otherwise it costs $3 per adult to get in. The movie is good and there is a nice exhibition of artifacts from the time of Lewis and Clark in the visitors center. There are also nice walking trails around the visitors center which were good. But, this whole area is interesting - Astoria and the mouth of the Columbia River plus Cannon Beach so the whole area is worth going to as well as the visit to Fort Clatsop.

Although I lived in St. Augustine for about 30 years I never visited the Fort til this visit. The day was beautiful which added to the enjoyment. Personally, I like this Fort experience better than the Castillo de San Marcos in downtown St. Augustine. Operated by the National Park Service, this does not have an admission fee and the boat ride over to the Fort is also free. Visitors are given about 20 minutes to view what life was like this Spanish outpost centuries ago. Seven soldiers manned it. The Fort was built to protect the south access to St. Augustine via the Intracoastal Waterway.

En route back to St Augustine on A1A, we happened to see the sign for Fort Matanzas. WOW, I sure glad we made this unexpected stop. Fort Matanzas maintained by the National Park Service. The park is open to the public with NO FEE to include a free ferry ride to the fort located on an island a short five minute boat ride away. Dolphins frequent the area and are an added treat. The park ranger was very knowledgeable and allowed ample time to enjoy the fort and its surroundings. Don't miss this worthwhile and FREE attraction!

There is no charge for this event. Take the short boat ride to Fort Matanza on Anastasia island. It was a beautiful trip and we spotted a dolphin in the water. The ranger gave us an entertaining and detailed historic account of the forts history that kept everyone including small children entertained. Climb to the top.

Minimal entrance fee. Picturesque canyon with many old cliff dwellings. Not the big kind you see more to the south but houses made in rows under layers of overhanging rock. See pics. There is a rim trail (which we did not take) that would be better for the stair challenged. We took the Island Loop trail which begins and ends with 240 steps and more steps as you circle around an island/peninsula of rock in the canyon. This trail gives you views to all parts of the canyon and the cliff dwellings around the island and on the canyon walls. Trail is well maintained but there are MANY steps. Plan accordingly.

This is the world's only "drive-in" volcano! Upon arrival (after you pay a small fee for your car), turn left to the Kilauea Iki Crater Overlook and the Thurston Lava Tube. Then keep driving around (if it's open) to Halema'uma'u Crater where you can see current lava steam. If you go straight you will see the Visitor Center and steam vents and end up at the Jaggar Museum where you'll be amazed by the vast power of the Kilauea Volcano. You can take the 38 mile drive on the Chain of Craters Road as far as they will allow. Be prepared for a windy road downward to the sea. We enjoyed the whole wonderful and enlightening experience.

This is a national park that has some of the best historical sites and ruins in the USA. We did it in a day trip out of Albuquerque, so we left at 6 a.m. and were there before 10 a.m. It is a beautiful drive, and if you get going early, you can easily spend 6 hours at the park exploring the sites and be back in Albuquerque by sunset. It was a wonderful day of sight seeing, and the ruins are truly stunning. There are examples of different brick patterns, and the circular buildings are amazing. There are picnic tables nearby, where you can enjoy a lunch (bring your own food and beverages), and there are bathroom facilities. The interior park is paved, but there is a 10 to 15 mile stretch of unpaved road you have to drive, so an SUV, or higher off the ground vehicle, is the preferred means of transport. You can maneuver it in a car, but you will have to drive very slow to dodge all the ruts.....and you can't dodge them completely. It does feel like you are driving on a washboard. But do not let that stop you from going, as that part of the trip is very short compared to the payoff when you see the sites. There are many trails, and if you stay longer, you can hike to the top and get a cliff view of the ruins. We saw lots of lizards and birds. It is very remote, so do not plan on cell phone reception. I also recommend taking pleny of sunscreen, as even when it is cool, the sun is closer and burning down. We went in Spring, and I can't image going at the height of the summer as I bet the temperatures get extremely hot. The winds can also be strong, so if you can, it is best to go on a nice day, especially since the unpaved road section can be problematic with rain, etc. Chaco Canyon is totally worth the trek, and it is one of the few places in the USA where you can find important ruins from over 1000 years ago. It cost $8 per car for our visit and was quite the bargain!

A visit to Independence National Historical Park will lift your American Spirit. The well preserved site is a reminder of how many varied opinions came together for the good of a new nation. A spirited tour of Independence Hall, with one of the National Park Rangers, brings to life the struggle. Make sure to visit the Tourist Center early for your "timed ticket", tickets go fast and you must have a ticket to tour Independence Hall. Even during our visit in April, tickets were limited by 11am. Other Historical buildings on the ground and The Liberty Bell are open access, no tickets needed, just stand in line. Short videos and displays, in the Tourist Center, explain the nation prior to the Revolutionary War.

I was amazed at the beauty of Mount Rushmore. Did not realize in our initial looking for attractions how much there would be to do and see. This is a great place to capture beauty and scenery. The kids enjoyed the hiking and the statues. The price to get into the park is only $11 and if I remember correctly it is good for the whole year.

This is an amazing place, where you can get a real sense of the power of the volcano. There are a lot of things to do here, and I'd budget at least 2 days to do everything, particularly if you want to see the volcano at night. We'd strongly recommend planning for an overnight in Hilo, which will give you the time to see all that the park has to offer. At a minimum, plan on hitting the visitors center, the Jaggger Museum, Thurston Lava Tube, Devastation Trail. Also highly recommend the Chain of Craters road and the hike out to the Petroglyphs. Lots of chances for hiking in a variety of different climates. Bring snacks and drinks, you'll need them. Also, we wouldn't recommend flip flops or flimsy shoes. You are better off with something a little sturdier. If you are planning on doing Haleakala and Pu'uhonua o Honaunau consider purchasing a tri park pass.

A very nice visitor's center greets you with some artifacts, info, gift shop, and two movies. It's all free, except parking, which is $2 an hour. Get your tickets as soon as you arrive for the tour. The tour is brief, but neat. There's plenty to fill 1.5 - 2 hours while you wait for your tour to begin.

We had a terrific time visiting Mount Rushmore. The facilities are fabulous, plenty parking and the amenities were clean and easy to access. We got great photos and in general had a lovelyrelaxing time. The snow was melting and we enjoyed the streaks on the faces of Mount Rushmore. The museum was interesting and the gift shop had something for everyone. It was well worth $10 for a car load. We had some disabled folks with us and everyone was comfortable going up the steps and hill. The flags were a nice finishing touch and educational!

park: John Day Fossil Beds National Monument
text: There are three units to the John Day Fossil Beds: Clarno, Sheep Rock, & Painted Hills. We visited Sheep Rock and Painted Hills. You'll pass the Mascall Overlook on your way to the fossil beds.

park: Brown v. Board of Education National Historic Site
text: I had heard the phrase but did not know the extent of it. This museum tells the whole story. It was quiet emotional. There are quizzes to take, videos to view and many, many signs to read. The ranger was so helpful and the book store was wonderful. I plan to return as soon as I am in Topeka. Guide book says minimum of an hour....make that at least three. Price is free.

The fort is a good history lesson for everyone. There are re-enacters to give you a look-back in time. But the best thing is that it has the most magnificent view of the town--worth the admission price in itself.

Driving there is already half the fun. The road is narrow and winding, offering nice views. On arrival you should go to the visitor center to gather some information, watch a little introductory movie and get an area map. There are quite a few nice places for a picnic. The dwellings are just two miles down the road from the visitor center. A few dollars entrance fee is due if you have not one of the annual passes for the National Parks/Monuments. Volunteers provide you with some more information and send you up the trail to the dwellings. It is a one mile round trip. Don't miss out on the free ranger tour at 1 pm! This is the best way to really see the dwellings and imagine what was going on there hundreds of years ago. Without the ranger most people just walk through, missing the somewhat hidden petroglyphs and stories behind.

Kings Mountain was a Revolutionary War battle many are unfamiliar with. If you like history, this is a must see. Many of the locals call it Battlefield Park. This is a nice park overseen by the National Parks Service. Very educational. A nice paved hiking trail. Go through the welcome center first before you walk the trial. You will get more out of it. If you are looking for a nice place to walk, the trail is heavily forested. I go often in the summer when other location trails are just too hot. Adjacent to the Kings Mountains State Park. Not to be confused with the Battlefield Park. There is an admission fee to the State Park. Kings Mountain National Military Park is free to enjoy.

Even before Spielberg's Lincoln movie, I had long wanted to visit the 16th President's home. It did not disappoint. One should allow time see the video at the ticket office before the tour. The ranger gave an excellent presentation. It was a freezing, day with sleet, so I was unable to see the rest of the historic buildings on the block. Perhaps one day I will return.
Only God creates these kind of vistas. Well worth the trip. We lucked out too and it was "free week" no park fee for entry.

This park is a long drive from Salt Lake City but I'm glad I went. Spent the night three miles from the park at The Pines motel. Could have gotten a cheaper, closer and modernized room but I didn't do my homework. The canyon is awesome. Some of the best pictures I've ever taken which I owe to the bright, clear days and the vivid canyon colors. Very walkable and you can drive right up to a number of scenic lookups located all along the one main road that runs thru the park. The historic lodge at the park is a classic, ate breakfast, lunch and dinner there, a bit pricey but great wait staff. Attended an evening presentation by the park ranger about bears that was very well attended and very interesting for all ages. On site corral with twice a day trail rides, $60 for two hour ride. I would definitely visit again.

We came here with our two small children. We only did the short hikes but it was very enjoyable. There were a lot of petroglyphs all along the trail. My kids liked climbing the "mountain." The ranger at the visitor was very friendly, knowledgable and helpful. And you can't beat the price- $1 for parking and that's it!

This desert national park is a true treasure. We bought sleds from a couple of people returning theirs. So you buy the sleds for 17 bucks I believe, although I think the used ones cost $10. You return them and receive $3 bucks back. We just bought ours from someone else for $5 and still saved $2. It's incredibly hot during the day to go walking or hiking or sledding - it can drain you. Consistent with desert climates, it does get chilly at night so dress in layers if you go. I recommend visiting either early morning and/or right before, during and after sunset. We particularly enjoyed the sunset views, walking deeper into the sand dunes to find better and bigger ones to sled down. Feel free to keep driving as far into the park as you can to find the untouched, cleaner dunes (less plants). The only comparable place that I've seen to White Sands are the Sossuvlei Dunes in Namibia, Southern Africa (but they are golden sands and not white). The white sand really does look like an Arctic landscape. Be sure to wear bright colors for an awesome photo-op. We took a picture of my friend jumping up in a red outfit and caught her midair- it came out phenomenal in the sea of white. You'll see some professional photo shoots also. I know they have sunset strolls, we missed arriving for that on time but I bet you learn a lot with the ranger. We just enjoyed strolling about on our own and trying to climb the dunes after sledding down. It's a workout! We also saw a cool beetle or two which was fun..it's an ethereal and unforgettable landscape. You feel like you're on another planet. Oh and they had the full moon bike ride that night too which we could not sign up for..if you're in town for that next time, you should definitely do it.

There are 4 parks operated by the National Park Service on the Big Island. You can easily see them all in one trip. Two have park entrance fees and two do not. Active military can get a free annual pass good for ALL National Parks. These four were all different, all beautiful and all educational.

Not much there. John Brown's Fort remains, but all the other buildings are just the stone outline of the foundations. There is an admission charge of $10. There is signage to tell you about what happened there. Vistor center is very small, with no services like were available at the other parks I visited on this trip.
I would recommend everyone to do this. It's free and they could easily charge a small fee. Very nice guides. Interesting fort and area.

Go ahead and get up early to watch the sunrise. It was a wonderful experience. Such a great trip up and make sure you start about 3-4 ish so that you don't almost miss it like we did. It's a bit of a drive with curves so you don't want to rush. It was so pretty being above the clouds. Got some great shots. Loved it. I think it was $10 to get into the park?

Did the Battlefield Tour a couple of days after visiting the Gettysburg Battlefield. Of course, not as big. The Visitors Center is tiny, but I came in during "no fee day", so I can't complain. Although shorter than the Gettysburg Tour, I saw some places where a lot of lives were taken. Can't look at Bloody Lane or Burnside Bridge without being overwhelmed by history. Loved my tour and would go back!

This fascinating national monument is about 2 hours drive west of Albuquerque. Now that I've been there, I'll return, bringing visitors to our home in New Mexico with me. I was very pleasantly surprised. This is not just about the physical beauty of the spot but also about the human history of 3 people groups. We were offered a free guide (in fact the whole darn experience was free...no entrance fee, which we would have gladly paid). There is a 2 mile walking loop that ascends the mesa after an interesting walk along the base. The lower section is paved and easy. The ascent to the top is not at all difficult but does go UP. We took our time and were rewarded with a remarkable view as well as what was, to us, crazy eery topography as we walked along the top. There is a bench under some trees not far from where we crested the mesa that would be a good place to stop, eat a light lunch or snack (self-provided of course), relax and enjoy the serenity of the place. We had allotted two hours for this visit but in fact were there for 3 & 1/2 hours and could have stayed longer. We really dawdled along the base, looking at the inscriptions.

Haven't been to Valley Forge since grade school trip. A lot nicer than I remember. Also I had more of an interest in it now than I did then. The park was very well kept and organized. It was a driving tour of the park and every stop was well planned out for accessibility to the attraction. There was no charge to this Federal Park unless you wanted a narrated tour of the park. I am happy I went back to see the park as an adult. Been taking day trips and this was well worth the drive.

Pay the extra and take the sea plane over rather than the ferry. The plane only takes 30 minutes vs. 2 hours with the ferry. You arrive with the whole island almost to yourselves. Plus you get to see turtles, sharks and shipwrecks on the flight over!
Take the seaplane and book well in advance. 2 oclock is best as the boats leave by then and the water and air will be warm. $$$ but amazing if you like to snorkle

Spent 3 nights in the Fruita campground which is pretty large and very improved - that is to say paved. There are 3 loops and all loops are close to fruit orchards and a trail that can be taken to reach the Gifford Homestead. There are plenty of RV sites and some will accomodate the large Class A rigs. We were very surprised that there was no entrance fee to the park (there is a fee to camp). A stop at the visitor center was completely worthwhile. We saw a very interesting and informative video presentation in the theater after which a curtain above the screen was opened revealing a jaw dropping formation. We quickly got the idea though that if you want to see the best of Capitol Reef you need to hike it. There are wonderful trails you can pick up right at the campground. We hiked the Fremont River Gorge Overlook Trail, the Fremont River Trail heading away from the

We recently stopped by while taking back roads on an interstate road trip. This place doesn't get too many visitors (especially in the off-season), and we were greeted by friendly rangers who offered our children a Junior Ranger booklet and gave us a "self-guide" for the lower hike. The short loop to see the inscriptions (and the historical information provided) were fascinating. We did not do the longer hike to see the ruins because of the age of our younger kids, but I'm hoping that we get to go back someday to see what's up there! We homeschool our kids, so got to have some interesting discussions about when this area was not part of the US, etc. Also, this monument is now free, so no admission charge - what a bonus!

Went to the mountain to see the sunset, even though Lonely Planet advised against it. We drove two hours from Paia and arrived at 6pm, just above the rain clouds, we watched a glorious sunset by 6:50. Well worth the $10 entrance fee, that gives you access for three days.

Only way to get there is by boat or seaplane (we took the boat --- $$ fee) --- but worth the trip. We've been to other seacoast forts (Ft. Monroe, Ft. Sumter, Ft. Pulaski) but Ft. Jefferson at Dry Tortugas is definitely one of the more unique outposts of the Civil War. Beautiful waters, many birds, and brilliant, sunny, vistas from any of casemates at the Fort. A strange solitude lingers at the place where the Lincoln assassination conspirators (e.g., Dr. Samuel Mudd) were held after the Civil War. Small beach with snorkeling allowed. A birdwatcher's paradise.

After living in Illinois the majority of our lives, my husband and I finally drove to Springfield and took a tour of the Lincoln house. Entry is free, but you have to get a ticket at the visitor's center. Donations are highly encouraged. The tour is brief, but very informative. There are many guides throughout the house to answer your questions. The entire neighborhood has been restored, which gives it an authentic feel. Highly recommended.

location: Long Branch, New Jersey, United States
text: This is another must see sight in Springfield, IL. The Lincoln House. It is very well maintained and you get an excellent half hour tour with a Park Ranger, but because it's free and because it is what it is, you are rushed through the house with another tour fast on your heels. I might suggest you do the tour first, and walk the street looking into the other "Unfurnished" houses, then go back again and tour the house a second time. It's worth it, and you'll probably get a different Park Ranger to guide you through. Parking costs about $2.00/hour, so plan to be there for about two to three hours.

We visited Fort Jefferson & the Dry Tortugas by boat aboard the Yankee Freedom II. The trip itself was as good as it could be considering the choppy seas. The breakfast & lunch that were a part of the boat ticket were satisfactory. I was grateful for all of the coffee after a late night out in Key West prior to the trip!

There are a number of trails at the park and some ranging from 1/2 a mile up to as long as 3 days worth of walking trails. This is a huge wilderness area with over 30 miles of trails. There is plenty of parking and restrooms are available.$10 per car

The fort is very well taken care of. It has a lot of interesting things to look at on land. The snorkeling isn't that great because there aren't that many areas for fish to hide. The beach is beautiful. There were a few people camping but there are only 4-5 spots where you can set up and have tree cover; some were set up in direct sun, I couldn't imagine staying there without tree cover in the summer. We took a seaplane to get there; it cost $280.00 pp and took 40 minutes. The boat cost in the mid hundreds but takes over 1.5 hours each way. It was worth the xtra money to not spend half the day on a boat. The airplane service we used was seaplane adventures; they provided drinks and snorkel equipment for free.

One day was not enough! NOTE: If you don't have a National Park pass, consider getting one! My Senior pass @ $10 when I was 62 has been the best buy ever for access of 4-6 people as I take family & friends into parks like this and save $25 or more each time.

Our trip 's purpose was to visit 7 National Parks. Bryce was #7. We didn't know it, but we did save the best til last. The park can be appreciated from the numerous pull-off and view points with very little effort. Unlike Zion or Arches National Parks where hikers have the clear advantage. Bryce is breathtaking. We traveled in our own vehicle but later in the season a shuttle is used to get around in the park. We have the Senior life time National Park Pass ($10)

I stopped to break up the drive from northern Indiana to nashville. The two hour cave tour was great. It was easy to get on the next tour as we were traveling during the week in the spring season. A little more planning maybe required on summer weekends. Admission to the park itself is free and the cave tour was only $12. It would be completely free to explore some of the hiking trails on your own. I was not impressed with the restaurant selection at the park. There are sit down dining options only and even ordering a peanut butter jelly sandwich was slow.
We traveled to the DT on the Yankee Freedom III. Great trip but a little on the expensive side as the trip for two cost over $300, but worth it.
What a great place to go and spend a few hours! You drive down a sometimes winding road after you go through the entrance (I think the fee was $3/pp good for 1 week).

At first I wasn't sure what all the hype was about. Bryce Canyon is mis-named ... it's not really a canyon and you don't drive into it ... you're driving on a ridge high above it. The entrance fee is $25 for 7 days. You can drive all the way to the end point - 18 miles ... with scenic points along the way to look down into the 'canyon'. THEN you can see what everyone's talking about. Each viewpoint is different and the colours and shapes are awesome. Note: the parking lots at each viewpoint can accommodate both cars and RV's but they can fill up quickly as some of them are the starting points for hikes. The park has an excellent shuttle bus service that picks up and drops off at many different points along the way and is an great alternative to driving and it's free! Camping in the park is limited and fills up VERY quickly in the summer - we were there in May and one campground was full although the other one was only about 1/2 full. Prices are $15 for an RV with 2 people per night. If you're looking at them on-line it's confusing as the on-line maps show 'North' Campground and 'South' Campground but when you get there it's North and SUNRISE campground. Not South. The North one is the first you come to and of course that fills up first - also it has a shower and general store inside the campground. The Sunrise is actually a little nicer tho I think. Both campgrounds have NO hookups at all so be warned. There are private campgrounds near with full hookups although they're pricey. There is a lodge also which looks pretty cool. It was built in the 1920's and just looks like it's out of a movie! I don't know the prices for the lodge. (There's also a very cool gift shop inside!)

We stopped here on our way to Yellowstone. It is much like the Grand Canyon in that after you've seen it ... its time to go. We paid $11 to park and were in the park maybe 30 minutes. We met some folks from Indiana (always happens) and took a ton of pictures. Then we took off for the next site.

This is not your run of the mill historic tourist attraction. While there is plenty of history to learn about at the visitor center you can take in as much or as little as you desire. The walk around the island is not a task and I recommend taking your time to step out of the real world. We met a 65 year old woman on the trail who was on her own. For a nominal $5 entrance fee you can spend hours looking at the beautiful scenery.

I don't know what I was expecting, but I was completely underwhelmed by Mt. Rushmore. It's exactly what you're expecting; tall carvings of the faces of four presidents. Your entry fee doesn't get you within 500 feet of it so you can't get a true scale of their size/detail, and even if you did, it's not as big as you initially expect.

Remote but accessible, Chaco is absolutely worth the effort to get there. You can do it in a day, but I recommend to camp overnight to be able to take in all the Great Houses. If a one day trip, I recommend starting early heading to Chaco on U.S. 550 from Farmington or Bernalillo. That way you can get to CR 7900 turn off (Mile marker 112.5) by first light and brave the sometimes rough dirt road. Actually the first 8 miles (5.1 miles on 7900 and 3 miles on 7950) are paved. The last 5 miles before the park entrance are the slowest. Once in the Park, all roads are paved (except in the campground). Stop by the Visitor Center to pay the day fee, and get a brochure. Head first to Pueblo del Arroyo parking lot and take the Pueblo Alto trail (trailhead just behind Kin Kletso site) and proceed to the Pueblo Bonito overlook (about 0.7 miles) to get a panorama view of the complex. Backtrack to the parking lot and take one of the Pueblo Bonito tours given by informed Rangers at 10am, 2pm, or 4pm. Tours begin at the Pueblo Bonito/Chetro Keti parking lot. The best petroglyph viewing is at Una Vida, a short hike from the Visitor Center. Other sites are also worthy of exploration.

The Lincoln Home is one of Springfield’s Premier attractions. I arrived shortly after the site opened and was greeted in the visitor’s center where I found the rangers and staff very helpful and knowledgeable about not only the Lincoln Home but other sites in the area. There are a limited number of parking spaces available in the lot adjacent to the visitor’s center. Payment for parking is done through a kiosk which takes cash or credit card. After a brief stop at the visitor’s center I was directed to the Arnold House where I was met by a Ranger who escorted our group on a very informative tour of the Lincoln Home. The guided tour of the home took about 45-minutes and our guide was quite knowledgeable and more than willing to answer the questions posed by the members of our group. I was very pleased to find out that photos inside of the Home are not only permitted but encouraged. Following the guided tour we were free to visit the other home and sites around the historic area. Admission to the Lincoln home is free, donations are accepted in the visitor’s center. The Lincoln Home is one of the must see attractions when visiting the Springfield area.

Most of the historical sights in Philadelphia are located within walking distance of each other. Many are free of charge. For some you can get tickets in advance online, which is very much advised especially in the Summer. You can easily spend two full days perusing the historical exhibits, with time out for lunch at the nearby Reading Market or Chinatown. Highly recommended.
Interesting scam. No entrance fee however, you pay $11 to park. It was worth 30 minutes and a few quick pictures. Certainly not a "do over"

Sure, we've all seen or read about Mount Rushmore but to actually be there in person was quite thrilling. Although we had a National Parks Pass that gets us into national parks for free, we did have to pay $11 for parking. We had our dog with us and since he couldn't accompany us to the actual monument, he had to stay in the car. I suggest parking in the lower level of the garage with the windows mostly open to keep your pet cool (leave fresh water for him too). My husband and I walked the trails around the monument and even a few trails outside of the official monument area where we saw mountain goats in the distance. At night, we returned for a special salute to veterans accompanied by video and the lighting of the monument at night. The park ranger asked all the veterans to come forward and selected 6 (my hubby included!) to retire Old Glory for the evening. It was an exciting day to be part of such iconic America.

We did this trip by excursion so I don't know about the entry fee. We visited Halema'uma'u Crater overlook, the Jagger Museum, walked through a lava tube and saw a number of steam vents. It was a nice, sunny day which made the trip perfect. It would not be enjoyable on a rainy day. Due to the volcanoes, the air quality is not always good.

The trip was expensive, for not a lot of return, I found the snorkeling very boring, (nothing but sand to look at) and the food quality not good. They even limited the free drinks to lunch and breakfast times. Also, while the offer a military discount it is only for the active duty, not for retirees.
This place is a must see! The Inspiration point is the most impressive place in Canyons. This is 100 times more impressive than the Grand Canyon. 25$ for the car definitely worth it.

What an amazing place; you see the start of the world here! For $10 you are given a week long pass for the park. You can walk through lava tubes, hike around a giant creator, see the Jagger Museum and take a breath-taking 20 miles drive down to the coast. Simply one of the best experiences I can think of!

This place was awesome. Definitely a unique experience. Half the time it looked like we were at the beach without an ocean and the other half of the time it looked like snow! We got there a little before the sunset tour. We were able to stop at the gift shop to buy a sled. The sled cost $15 and sled wax was 75c. Apparently they will buy it back for $5 but unfortunately we didn't get to do that as the gift shop closed promptly at 7. So if you go for the sunset your (7:45pm sunset last night and the tour starts an hour before) and do a little sledding there is no time to visit the gift shop after which seems kind of silly to me. You would think the shop would stay open until the park closes...at 9pm.

Four of us hired a car and drove up to Haleakala. The road is windy but quite wide and well marked. Be careful though as there are cyclists and skate boarders to be weary of. We did not see any cows on the road, but were warned about them. Entrance into the park was $10.00 for the car.

You have to pay $11 to park and it lasts all the day, if you want to go back for the night. It did not disappoint and a very nice walk around. It is well built and loved the grand view to take photos. The flags on the way in looked great and the columns with each state on a lovely touch. Nice shop and helpful staff in the visitor center. Worth every penny to our trip

What a place, you cannot even imagine you are in the present day. Standing under the ancient giant redwoods, you feel as if you are transported back in time. The enormous trees are over powering, you almost fall backwards looking to the sky to find the very tips of the trees and a speck of blue. A must place to see, the Ave of the Giants. No fee involved. Drive and walk though the undisturbed woods at your own pace. The visitor center rangers are so helpful and they don't want you to miss a thing.. Enjoy this natural area. Almost all the trails are handicap friendly.

Having stayed close to Mt. Rushmore in Keystone we spent some time here the first evening (mostly indoor stuff). Came back the next morning and did the Presidential Walk. Seeing Mt. Rushmore from different view points was wonderful. Don't miss the sculptors studio toward the end of the walk. Went back that night for the lighting of Mt. Rushmore. Enjoyed the film about the four presidents. The lighting was not spectacular - it just lite up but it was very cool to see it at night. Once you pay the parking fee you can return as many times as you want and throughout the year.

Visited Cumberland Gap National Park. I recommend stopping by the Visitor Center and learning about the history of the Gap. Sign up for the Gap Cave tour led by park rangers($8/adult) which last 2-2 1/2 hours. The tour starts with an easy half mile hike to the cave entrance. You spend about 1 1/2- 2 hours inside the cave. There are 183 stairs inside the cave. Got to see a bat pretty close up. There is another hiking trail which leads you to a nice waterfall. Also take a four mile drive up to the Pinnacle overlook and see a panoramic view of Tennessee, Kentucky and Virginia.

The national park is well worth the visit. I was there from May 12-16th 2013 with my parents aged 76 and 82. We stayed at Bryce Canyon resort just three miles from the park. There is a park fee of 25$ per private vehicle which I believe is waived if you have a National Parks pass. Use the shuttles to go into the park, they are free. There are two shuttles, one a three hour guided free guided tour that starts at the Bryce Canyon shuttle staging area opposite Rubys and goes to Rainbow and Yovimpa point. These are the farthest points towards the south of the park (40 miles round trip). To get on this shuttle you need to reserve a place by calling 1 435 834 5290. This shuttle stops in several places along the way so people can get out and look at the view points. The bus driver served as a tour guide and was very knowledgeable and patient. This shuttle stopped at the following points:

This tour is just a nice way to spend a nice day outdoors. It's free to go on the little boat ride over to the fort and you get an informational tour about its' history. It's just such a quiet and lovely location, even if you're not huge into history, I would still recommend this. You'll see lots of fish and little crabs on the shores! There are picnic tables and a walking trial here, as well as restrooms and vending machines. I think they have a gift shop but I can't fully remember, since we didn't go in. They do ask a recommended donation of $2.

Went there in May. Several very nice easy hiking trails and a few fossilized trees. That's about it. A few interesting things to see in the Visitor Center but I thought there was a lot of wasted space. To be honest, I was not impressed. Fortunately I have a Senior Pass otherwise I don't think it's worth the price. Good for a one time, short, visit.

After driving upto Hana, we went onto the Haleakala National park and were awed by the scenic natural splendor and beauty. Make sure to save your $10 entry ticket as you can use the same ticket within a 3 day window to re-enter the park at the base or even the top. Spend time to enjoy the natural beauty!

No entry fee...just a short distance off SC I-77...easy access y handicapped, many options for walks (short & long). One of the hidden niches of big trees, swamps, and natural wildlife. Go if you can. Each visit is a different experience.

As other reviews have said, not many people were at this park. Which made it that much more enjoyable. Sad that there was not more time to do some hiking. There is a fee if you go past a certain point. The drive was awesome. We were able to get some good photos. Would like to come back here and do some exploring.

My husband and I went on the Historic Tour and enjoyed it. The cave system is amazing and the tour was worth the $12 entry fee. We only had time for one tour and we were glad we picked this one, as you get to see a lot of cave in the two hour tour. I'd recommend booking your tour online ahead of your visit if you have your heart set on a certain tour and time (the tours sell out fast). My only complaint about the tour is that the other tour group members were a bit inconsiderate (which I suppose happens in a group of 120 people). Even though our tour guide reminded people many times to be careful with their camera flashes, people still were flashing away whenever they wanted, which meant we were often blinded! This tour has some slippery, uneven footing, tight spaces and many stairs. I wouldn't recommend it if you are not in decent physical condition--there are other easier tours to take instead.

We were very surprised to arrive at the ticket booth early in the morning and find out that all the tours were sold out and "you should have made reservations." Our children were so looking forward to seeing the cave, and we could not come back on a different day, so we decided to settle for the 20 minute tour. The cost of the tickets for the 20-minute tour were very reasonable, but the tour itself was disappointing. We got to see one room of the cave and listen to a quick talk from the ranger. What a let down!

I left Ohio and drove to South Dakota to see Mount Rushmore, something I have wanted to do for 20 years. It was worth every mile and every dollar I spent on this trip. It is an awesome sight and I made good use of my time while in the area and went back two days before I left the area. In the gift shop I met Don "Nick" Clifford, he worked on Mount Rushmore from 1938-1940 and he wrote a book with questions from people he met over the years and his response(s). Very nice touch to my visit. One other thing I loved about the area was it was not commercialized at all!!!

We first saw the figures from two miles away and my first thought was OK, we've seen this, now let's go somewhere else. But the family wanted to do the tour, so we paid the $11 parking fee and then rented the $5 audio tour - DO THIS! The $5 was very well spent, the audio tour gives you the history, the background, profiles of the people, and really makes the place come alive. This is not just four faces on a mountain: it is a monument to the qualities that make America great: freedom, justice and equality for all. This is time well spent.

We stopped here on our way home from Yellowstone. It was so exciting to see the presidents faces as we were driving up the drive. It cost $11.00 per vehicle, which I thought was very reasonable. I was so awe struck at seeing Mt Rushmore in person after seeing it so many times in books and on tv. However, I was a bit surprised at the size....I imagined it to be larger. We spent about 2 hours there and my children earned their Junior Ranger badge. There was a video about the making of Mt Rushmore, which was very interesting. And there was also a museum with various exhibits that were interesting to our entire family. The gift shop was very big and had plenty of souvenirs to pick from. There were also trails available to explore, but we were limited on time. I think this is a must stop for every family!!!!

This is the only place in Connecticut where you can purchase a Senior pass for all national parks in the country. It's a lifetime pass for ten dollars. The Historic site must be very pretty in the fall.

The Apostle Island area is beautiful. It does not have the same feel as the Mn side of Lake Superior. The water is much more tranquil than the Mn Superior side. The ferry is a bit expensive as they charge per/vehicle plus per/person.

We really enjoyed our visit to Melrose. It's a National Park Service site. The admission was $10, and students were $5 for the tour. The grounds were free to explore. The out buildings were also free, including the carriage barn, stables, and slave cabin. This tour was so much better than the "plantation" tours we did. Slavery was explained, and there was an exhibition explaining the effect on families. I would choose this hands down over any of the much more expensive, sanitized plantation tours.

We had a great time touring Jewel cave this past weekend. We took the hour and twenty minute tour with our grandson. Tickets were on a first come first serve basis and we only waited about an hour for the next tour. Great guide, terrific tour, but not for the out of shape, the tour is only a half mile walk but also has 700 plus steps. We are senior citizens (in good walking shape) and our eight year old grandson toured with us. This is a do not pass attraction, total cost for two adults and one child, twenty dollars. Best bargain in all the Black Hills.
If I was writing a book "Florida on a Thread" (because we have a really tight budget and a shoestring would cost too much, lol), Fort Matanzas would be one of the highlights.

The National Monument - the small outpost - is a great tie-in to the much bigger and well know fort in downtown St. Augustine. The history the park rangers have to pass along is fascinating and gives you a real sense of how life really was back then. Don't pass this one up!

Mount Rushmore is definitely a place to be seen with your own eyes! You pay $11 for parking, but entrance to the monument is free and your parking pass is good for a year. Upon walking up to the monument viewing area, there are state flags lining the way. It gave me chills, seeing all the flags with the Presidents faces in the background, not to mention it is a great photo op. There is a walk around the grounds where you can get several different vantage points along the route. It is actually quite breathtaking to see in person. I didn't do the audio tour as I didn't realize that was an option when I was there. My only criticism is that there is not a film to view during the day. You have to go back at night to see the film at the lighting ceremony. I went to the lighting ceremony. When I got there, fog was completely covering the monument. For about an hour, it lifted right around the faces. A few minutes before the ceremony was to start, the fog covered it again. The ceremony began with a 20-minute film. Just as the National Anthem began, the fog lifted and the faces were lit up. It was spectacular and I highly recommend it, even if it is a foggy night! You never know what will happen.

The center is essential to start off with although I would skip the film if you know even a little about the Revolutionary War (18 minutes of boredom). The site itself can be driven through if you choose to do so which I did.Taking advantage of the audio tour is helpful. However, I would plan to spend between 2-3 hours at the site minimum. The basics are provided in the museum which should take about 30 minutes to go through and while not cutting edge was certainly acceptable. There are numerous stops along the way including replica barracks, a memorial arch, and the memorial chapel (which I did not do). The stop at Washington's residence and command center really helped to piece the entire site together for me. The NPS Guides were particularly helpful and the more experienced guides were very good at rooting out the knowledge level of the visitor and helping them out. Free of charge to go through the site on your own, a small charge to go into the Washington Memorial Chapel, and of course a higher charge should you choose to do one of the guided tours. Gift shop not all that good as it mostly has the generic touristy items for sale. Probably easier for adults to appreciate that young kids, but maybe I just did not pay special attention to the programs specifically designed for kids.

this park is not as big as the grand canyon but what it lacks in size it makes up in beauty The colours of the rocks are stunning and a photographers dream come true well worth $25 7day pass for the vehicle so as a couple even better

We did the 8.5 hour tour out of Seward. It was a beautiful day. This is the third time that I have done this trip. When we have friends come from out of state, they usually go on this trip. We saw humpback whales, porpoises, goats, puffins, glaciers, etc. It is a great way to see a lot of things in one day. The food is good, we always order the half pound of King crab with dinner for $12. This time it was cold, but was great crab. Great trip to take out of town friends coming up to visit on.

I've lived in the Boston area for over 10 years now, but never even thought to look up John Adams' home until my father came to visit (a history buff). Using our National Parks Pass (costs $80 bucks and allows everyone in your party free entrance into any National Park), we were able to get on the Park's trolley which took us over to the visitor center in downtown Quincy. There, they have a short video which covers some of John Adams' life and a gift shop. The tour has an itinerary and runs according to a strict schedule. From the visitors center, the trolley takes you to the birthplaces (homes) of both John Adams and John Quincy Adams. The park rangers take you inside each residence and give you a quick back story on their lives in those homes. Next, they take you by trolley to the "Old House" where four generations of Adams eventually lived. The grounds here are beautiful and the National Park Service clearly puts in a lot of time and effort to maintain the land. I was very impressed, and can't believe it took me this long to come here!

We were staying in Harper's Ferry and decided to drive out to Antietam to see that battlefield. The price was extremely low at $3 an adult. We did the driving tour and it was really a lot of fun to just explore the battlefield on our own and read about the battle as it happened. The stillness of the day truly added to the somber feeling that the battlefield itself evokes. I felt very glad to be able to experience the battlefield on a day that really made you remember all the young men that passed away that day.

location: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
text: We took the day trip to the Dry Tortugas on Yankee Fleet. We initially were undecided about going. A bit pricey and our college kids were skeptical but decided to give it a try. What a great time we had!! The trip provided two better-than-expected meals, a full breakfast and lunch, arranged by professional and knowledgable staff. We arrived at the island a little over 2 hours from the time we left and participated in the 45 minute tour of Fort Jefferson. Lots of great history and the tour guide knew his stuff! He allowed plenty of time for questions. Worthwhile to go and learn about the fort and the island. We then returned to the boat for lunch and to get snorkel equipment. We spent the next few hours snorkeling after some brief instructions by the staff. What an experience!! This was the first time our kids have gone snorkeling and they were blown away!! The setting is gorgeous, the water clear and lots to see. Returned to Key West at about 5:30, a perfect day and well worth the price!!

A great place to ride your bike. If you don't want to ride round trip on your bicycle, you can go one way on your bicycle and return on the Cuyahoga Valley Train for a minimal fee per person. A great way to spend the day. If you don't have a bike, you can stop by Century Cycles (located in Peninsula) and rent one. You won't be disappointed.

First time taking my family here. I loved coming back with them since visiting with my parents 25 years ago. The $10/car cost to visit is well worth the price. Start at the visitor center and catch a shuttle to the Lower Town. Plan on at least 6+ hours to really see and experience all their is to see and hike. If you have Children be sure to stop at the information center and ask about the Jr. Park Ranger program that is available at every national Park for little or no fee. It really helps kids of all ages to understand why the park is important. It also gives you a good idea of what to see and do while there.

We traveled to Mount Rushmore by way of Hill City, SD. We drove Iron Mountain Road, oh my how extraordinary that drive was. When we finally got to Mount Rushmore, there is a parking fee, to be expected. The walk from Parking to Monument is not far, an easy walk. The sight as you walk in with the flags flying, amazing. Then you are up close to the mountain. Again, amazing. I never thought I would be doing this trip, but I am so glad my husband suggested it. Everyone should try and see our countries landmarks like this.

The National Monument itself is free to the public, but you pay $11 per car to park. This is good for that car for a year. After you have viewed this inspiring place and walked the trail to get different views, be sure to return at night. There is a half hour program followed by gradually increasing illumination of the mountain. At the end of the evening program, veterans were invited on stage to participate in the lowering of the flag. A must see if you are in the area.

The gap cave tour is definitely worth it. While not a large cave - it has lots of interesting formations , pools, large rooms , and history. You make your reservation over at the park's visitor center , then meet at the parking lot over in Cumberland gap, tenn . It is about six tenths of a mile hike to cave. The tour takes a little more than an hour . There is some ducking low in places and several steps to navigate on the tour also. We had a great guide ( Lucas). , and the experience was definitely worth the $ 8 admission fee !

This was actually my second trip there in ten years. The 2 1/2 hour ride to and from the park on the brand new ferry was spectacular, and the 4 hours on the island seemed like it went by in an instant. Our group spotted several very large loggerhead turtles and the color of the water changes with the time of day. The crew was phenomenal, and they put on a very nice continental breakfast and a satisfying lunch that was available for two hours. I liked the fact that you could eat at your leisure. Water was available all day for no extra charge. Words cannot describe the environment that awaits you, so I wont even bother....just go. This is a once in a lifetime trip for most and the cost is justified. I had to laugh at some of the negative reviews...I don't know where these people thought they were going. A few warnings...if you can't part with your smartphone for a few hours DONT GO...if you expect shopping DONT GO...if you think you are going to a tropical resort DONT GO...if you don't want a long boat ride DONT GO. If you want to experience one of the most pristine areas left in the United States then this trip should be added to your "bucket list"! The weatherman was calling for torrential rains all day long on the day of our trip (the flooded streets were eveidence upon our return) but the crew stated that the weather on the Turtugas,70 miles out into the ocean, would be partly cloudy and beautiful, as it usually is. They nailed it! In a nutshell, if you love the outdoors and have a strong appreciation for mother nature without all of the comforts of home, then this is your trip.

The visitor's center and Boca Negra Canyon are in the midst of residential neighborhoods, so it's a little odd. The rangers were very helpful in our decision of which trails to visit with two children (ages 8 and 12). We decided on Boca Negra based upon the fact that the trails were paved; however, only one of the three is truly paved. The other two have some paved stairs, but there is a lot of climbing on rocks. In fact, I would not recommend the trail up the "mountain" for small children or anyone with mobility issues, because you have to scramble over rocks. The view from the top was awesome, and there were several signs that told us what petroglyphs we were looking at, as well as more information about the volcanic rock. It gets pretty hot out there, and there's not much in the way of shelter. We did find some graffiti written on a rock; however, the ranger had already told us what was real art and what was not. All you have to do is ask! Our kids did the Junior Ranger program, which was easier than in other parks, and you get a badge, patch, and certificate, which is also more than some other parks. Admission to Boca Negra was $1. All in all, we spent about two hours, and it was well worth it.

If you love history, there are plenty of petroglyphs to be viewed. If you love hiking, it is beautiful with a great view of ABQ! First off - BRING WATER! I am always amazed at how many people bring kids but not water, or just don't bring water. The main loop is challenging if you have difficulty with mobility, many steps. The other two are less demanding. Morning is always best for temperature and lighting for photography. Parking is $1, and no other fee is assessed. It is easily the best spent dollar ever!

It had been almost 20 years since I had first visited Mount Rushmore. I’m sad I waited that long. It is truly breathtaking. The gift shop has a nice selection of souvenirs; I love the books on South Dakota history. We walked around the Presidential Trail, and on the back side is the sculptor’s studio. I bought some postcards, and the historian was helpful and answered all of our questions. I’m so glad I went back as an adult. There is a large parking lot that costs $11, but is good for a full year. Not too bad for a couple of hours of entertainment.

I must admit, I've always wanted to visit this attraction so I'm biased. But this is an iconic site and they do a good job of presenting it's history and providing a trail with many different viewpoint and photo spots. They charge for parking and it is an annual pass for your licence plate (we were in a rental vehicle). The site is open til 10pm which was great for us as we were driving in from Denver and that is a LONG drive. I like to read all the exhibits and it took me slightly under 2 hrs to see everything and take lots of pictures. As we arrived late, we ate at the cafe so we could stay for the evening lighting ceremony which takes place at different times during the season depending on sunset.

We rented a car from the port, we were on an Hawaiian cruise. Total time from port, shuttle to car rental agency, stop for snacks, to Park was approximately 1 hour. The admission fee was $10 per person. Stop at Jagger Museum first, the rangers gave us great planning ideas considering we only had a few hours. We drove the Chain off Craters road. We drove down to the ocean, where the lava had crossed the road during a previous eruption. We found this to be a wildly beautiful spot. High cliffs, with the ocean waves crashing off the cliffs. We then drove to Thurston Lava Tube and walked through the forest and then through the tube. Beautiful hike, short, easy to do. Then back to the visitors center to view the volcano. That was a little disappointing, it was drizzling rain, misty, just not much to see. For those of you seeing the park during a cruise ship excursion, I would recommend renting a car and doing this park on your own, as opposed to paying for a tour. It is easy to find, an easy drive, and more independent. I feel as if I saw everything I wanted to see.

We took the trolley tour from the visitor's center which takes you to the birthplaces and retirement home. The trolley is just used to give you a ride to the homes and then back again. There was no guide on the trolley giving information, but if you have an America the Beautiful pass, you get the tour for free. The home tours were wonderful!! The guides at the homes were like talking encyclopedias with all of their information and were extremely interesting. The church near the visitor's center where they are buried is also a must see!! Definitely recommend seeing these historic places!!

After paying up to $25 at other presidential homes, I couldn't believe this was only $5. Free for me since I have a senior park pass. A trolley takes you to 3 homes. You must have a ticket to see the inside of the homes so be sure you have at least 2 hours. Parking tip: the garage is behind the visitor center and free on weekends.

Took my roommate, who'd never been to this part of Maryland or the battlefield before. We had a great time. The park service employees are so amazing and helpful. We went into the gift shop and besides purchasing the auto tour and other books, etc., I also bought my roommate a national park senior pass. There was a little confusion as to whose license needed to be checked but when I had a question about an item, the young lady at the checkout counter excused herself and went to get the answer. Not one but two other employees came to answer my question and even suggested another item that would suite my needs better. What great customer service!!

Beautiful natural land bridges. Simply view from the overlooks it descend the 500' or 600' to go to the canyon bottom and marvel at these natural wonders. It's always warmer in the canyon and you work up some heat ascending so have fluids and snacks. Some ladders so if you have fear of them or heights, then pass on descending .

We arrived at the dunes at around noon time. Stopped in the gift shop to pick up a sled and headed out to the loop road. Sleds are $15, but if they are returned you get a $5 refund with your receipt. It is extremely hot during the day time, so we did a limited amount of sledding and hiking, before heading back to the hotel with the intention of returning for the sunset. We followed through with the plan, and it was amazing. We hiked out to a very large dune and took in the sunset while doing a few more runs with our sled. There was a nice breeze and the temperature was perfect. Traveling from MA to CA, this was probably one of the most memorable experiences we had on our trip. I can't believe someone rated this as "terrible".

We spent the money for the one day excursion and it was worth it. If you enjoy the ocean, and dream of a one of kind experience this is it. The Yankee Freedom ride was painless (the food & staff were professionals); however crossing Rebecca Channel on our ride back was more than some people's stomach's could handle so be warned to take something for sea sickness people and don't load up on the beer & frozen mixed drinks after an afternoon in the sun before heading back to key west on the boat! (Wait until you get back to Key West...the schooner wharf is right down the street) Once at Dry Tortugas; We stayed for part of the fort tour; but lunch on the boat and an afternoon of snorkeling was our plan. It was truly awesome; mixing history with recreation in a breath-taking location was worth every dollar.

If there's one thing for me as a Brit that symbolises America it's Mount Rushmore. I've seen it in so many films over the years, so I was very excited to actually be going there. I don't think my brother shard my excitement but by the time we had left he did say he had enjoyed the visit. We arrived around 5pm one September evening, had a walk to the Grand View Terrace, where I was impressed by the size of the amphitheatre. We then took the walk around the base of the monument which gave some good different perspectives of the 4 famous faces. Even though there's no admission fee for the monument itself, you do have to pay a fee to park, which I think was $15. When you think of the work that went into creating the monument itself, never mind the parking structure, I think $15 is a bargain. I'd happily go again in the future too.

We took the boat ride to the for. You get breakfast and lunch and use of snorkel gear (mask, fins and snorkel) with your paid admission. The ride takes 2 and a half hours and the crew keeps it interesting. They also give a free guided tour of Fort Jefferson when you arrive. They sell t-shirts, underwater cameras and food on board.

Came here for historic Harper's Ferry holiday events. Love the park and all the history here. The geological formations are fantastic too. Not sure the gate fee is worth the time you spend in the park; I guess each visitor can decide how they feel about that.

My husband and I enjoyed our visit to El Morro National Monument. The rangers in the visitor’s center were knowledgeable and friendly. There are two trail choices. Inscription trail is easy, paved, a half mile long and goes by petroglyphs, very old inscriptions and a pool/oasis. The longer 2 mile trail goes by the same petroglyphs, very old inscriptions, a pool then to the top of the mesa. The nice 2 mile trail is a little steep at times. At the top there are beautiful views of a canyon and surrounding areas not in the canyon. Be careful not to get too close to the edge. I was pleasantly surprised the see Pueblo Indian ruins on top of the mesa. We were at the park for about 2 hours. The park closed at 5 pm. $3 per adult.

While my husband and I were vacationing around Grants, NM, we stopped at the Northwest New Mexico Visitor Center. We ask a ranger about the south route/road conditions into Chaco Canyon. He said the road (57/14) had just been graded so it should be in good condition. Not so. The dirt road was very wash board and had thick sand in many places. The 19 miles of dirt road took about 90 minutes in my 4x4 truck. Once there, the park was awesome. We saw six of the main ruins in 6 hours and they were all close (1/2 mile or less) from the parking lots. The six main ruins are Una Vida (ruins and petroglyphs), Hungo Pavi (ruins), Cheltro Keti (has the largest Kiva I have ever seen, ruins and petroglyphs), Pueblo Bonito (very large ruins), Pueblo del Arroyo (ruins) and Casa Rinconada (ruins). My husband and I have toured many Indian ruins across a few states and I have to say these are the best. The weather was perfect (about 75 degrees) the last weekend in May.Cost $8 per vehicle.

This a great stop that is about 20 minutes south of St. Augustine. The National Park Service is in charge of the land and provides a FREE short boat ride to the island where the FREE fort is located. Make sure you stop by and grab a boarding pass at the fort's welcome center. You will not be allowed on boat without one. It is first come, first serve and the boat holds 36 people (I believe).

This is an American icon. You must stop and see this when you are in the Black Hills! Be sure to watch the film on the carving of the faces on Mount Rushmore. It is a good, informative film. We enjoyed walking the presidential trail and getting up close to the mountain. The lighting ceremony is worth attending. Your parking pass is good for a week. So come back at night to see the faces lit up against the dark night sky. The cafe, gift shop, studio, parking, and whole area is very well done. I recommend stopping here for all ages.

You really must visit these trees once in your lifetime. They should be ranked among the ranks of the Grand Canyon as a necessary visit in the United States. So many gorgeous campgrounds; so many gorgeous trails to explore. Stayed at the Elk Prairie campground - beautiful and serene with a mellow creek running through it. Bathroom facilities were topnotch: showers were extremely clean and water hot - there is a fee for the showers (25 cents per 2.5min). Also stayed at Mill Creek campground: further north with secluded campsites. Bathroom facilities older, showers not as clean, and varying prices for the showers. Viewed the Jedediah campground even further north - close to Stout grove, but no more special than the other two. Tons of hiking nearby; ocean always within 20m drive. Most of the park sites were free admission and parking, but $35 fee per night for the campsites.

what can I say ? this is the best national park I have visited so far . the rangers are great , they give wonderful tours and made our visit most memorable . the tours were spectacular ,we went on the Historical tour the first day , and our daughter did the Trog tour , the guides on the Trog tour took our daughter Age 10 and six other kids on a spelunking tour without their parents. although I was concerned at first , these two ladies ( Rose and Pat ) know how to take charge of kids and were just wonderful, I think these kids will remember this trip for ever !

The audio tour $3 was excellent using clips from former residents set in context. Allow. Enough time to amble round and chat to the knowledgable volunteers. A great start to our American Rockies tour.

Haven't been here in over 20 years, the park service has done a great job with the facility. I just don't like spending $4.50 for a soft serve cone, seriously, the only advice is, eat before you come here, the vendors here charge way too much!

Take your time and walk the President Trail. It is an easy walk near monuments. A must visit in the Badlands. Their restaurant has good seating with a view of Mouments. Good food at a reasonable price.

I recently became a walking enthusiast. This park has the former Ohio and Erie Canal towpath. Visitors may stop in any of the towns in the National Park and join the towpath trail either on foot or bike. This one combines both my love of history (the remains of the canal are viewable from the towpath) and walking. In addition, in season, the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railway runs through the park, and hikers or bikers may flag the train and get on, although there is small fee for this.
What a great place to take our young kids. 11 and 12 years-old. We rented the audio tour and for $15 for 4 of us, it was worth it.

I've been to Bryce Canyon twice, and it is my favorite of all the parks in this area, including the Grand Canyon, simply because the scale of it is smaller - though it is still very large and impressive - so you can walk (or drive) around the rim and look down into the canyon, or you can hike down into it, and then hike up at various spots. There's great diversity in the different sections of the canyon. And great beauty. And there are hikes that are more demanding, or less demanding. The ranger station was bustling but it's well organized, with excellent maps and info and staff on hand to give advice about which hike might be best for you, etc. The entrance fee is about $25 if you're just going to Bryce, but the best deal is to buy a seasonal or annual pass that works for all of the state or national parks. But it's worth $25 or more, alone, and in spite of there being a lot of visitors it did not feel crowded. Also, just outside the park, we encountered a little rodeo late in the afternoon which was a charming addition to the day. I think those happen twice a week in the summer. It is a magical place, more special than photos can show.

We travelled with Cosmos - the cheap alternative. An excellent tour - the scenery in Bryce Canyon, Mt. Zion and the Grand Canyon was amazing. The autumn colour increased as the tour progressed into autumn. I believe the tour is called National Parks and Canyon Country and at a little over $100 pp per day is highly recommended.

As you enter the monument via tram your thoughts turn to Jurassic Park. The excitement builds and then you realize there aren't any live dinos. However there are more dino skeletons than you could imagine and they are everywhere! The enclosed hill side museum is a wonder of skeletal remains and the rangers are happy to answer your questions. Outside you can walk along paths and see actual bones protruding from the rocks. And, yes, it is ok to touch them. The geology of the area is fascination and gives you a real feel for how the earth changes and moves. Also around this amazing place are petroglyphs and an old western cabin owned by Josie Bassett. While at the cabin my husband and I had separate and slightly unnerving experiences, which lead me to believe it is haunted. If you read up on Josie, you will see that she lead quite an interesting and eventful life. So if you like dinos, fossils and geology don't pass it by.

This place looks like piles of snow. The stark white sands are beautiful and fun to play on. Get a cheap plastic slide and have fun sliding down the dunes. There are a few walkways that make good overlooks of the area.

If you are just interested in seeing the president's faces in the stone, then save the $$$ for the parking fee and pull off the road as you approach the attraction from the town of Keystone and look at them there. Inside, there is a gift shop and lots of exhibits and a movie to watch and I don't know what else. W

Quite an artistic and engineering feat which is not to be missed. Enjoyed the video and the museum. Parking is easy. The entrance fee allows you to return anytime during the rest of the year. We went twice in two days as the monument was fogged in the first day we visited.

My wife and I both love living history museums, and this falls into my top 10 list!! This historic place has it all - wonderful open fields and woods, a ton of history since 1771, and a chance to see 1800 era technology at work and at a friendly price - free!! It is located near French Creek State Park near Elverson PA. Although I'm from Oregon and we think we have the great scenery thing covered, there is nothing more beautiful than the woods and hills of Pennsylvania! This historic community and furnace is settled in a lush valley, with the original buildings and a working furnace. There are re-enactors who operated the furnace, made a mold and actually poured hot metal to make a casting. You can see an original water wheel, the blacksmith shop, and the original "big house" that is open for touring. There is lots of open space, perfect for a stroll or a simple hike. Note: there are some steep steps or, alternately, sloping but gravel paths. Strollers and wheelchairs seem possible but check in advance on this point. Highly recommended, and please make a donation!!

This trip would have been WELL WORTH IT, had the weather been nice. But our tour was completely rained out, making the fort soggy, the snorkeling cold (in JUNE!) and the color of the coral/fish were all brown. Very disappointed that we were not offered a discount or return option.

We took our 83 yr old parents on a road trip to see things they've never seen and we all were in awe of the beauty found @ Bryce Canyon. We weren't able to hike but the view and colors from the top was breath taking. There are so many hidden treasures when you take the time to leave the highway and try the scenic roads and if you're 62 you can buy a lifetime national parks pass for $10, now that's a deal.

Excellent trip. the entire park and employees are great (sometimes a little crowded). Bring your camera, you will use it. Lots of attatrctions (some of these cost money), lots of shops to browes through

We spontaneously decided to visit Hovenweep on the way to Four Corners and are glad we did. You can walk the routes within an hour or so and view the ruins. We visited late May and the weather was beautiful....sunny, a nice breeze and pleasantly warm. The park ranger provides a map with the walking route around the ruins and the cost was $6/car. Very nice, easy walk with lots of ruins and picturesque views.

We were in Philadelphia visiting the historic sights and certainly this was on our list to see. It was OK and was definitely worth seeing. My only minor complaint is that you need to get a timed ticket and have to go through security to see "Independence Hall". While we did not run into any problems or issues, its just sort of aggravating and I guess it just a sign of the times. It did take us a while to get in as there was a small crowd of people waiting to get in. The volunteer tour guide we had for Independence Hall portion of the tour was very good, knowledgeable and made the tour very interesting. However, the park ranger that we had for the congress hall part of the tour was not so good! But anyway it was definitely worth seeing and I was glad we visited it while we were touring the historical sites in Philly.
