After the disappointment and expense of tourist-trap (and waste of money) Crazy Horse monument, Mt Rushmore was great. I didn't want to leave. The park rangers even gave me the best route back to Missoula. Unlike Crazy Horse, it's possible to get very close to the actual carving for photo ops, and learn fine details of construction. $11 what a deal!
First visited this site 29 years ago, on one of my first visits to the USA- so decided to pay a repeat visit en route to Gettysburg- and it was well worth the stopover.

This is a great place to learn about the westward expansion. Some restored original buildings and some in ruins show the facility that existed here in Frontier times. As someone else pointed, historical treaties and events took place here. Very modest fee for entry. Best visit in spring or fall after hot weather is past.

After being here for a few minutes I now finally understand where allt he cool films that have desert scenes are filmed at. You will know what I mean when you see it with your own eyes. I did get a backpacking pass and stayed the night. The only problem was there was too much light pollution from the nearby town. Too bad because everything else I read talked about the clear skies. If you want clear skies go to the Petrified Forest National Park in Arizona.

This is one of the places you read about in your elementary history book. You think I will see it one day but you get side-lined and go to the beach. I finally made it to Mt. Rushmore and I'm so glad I did. When we first got there it was raining in the mountains so there was a lot of fog. We couldn't see anything and then when some of the clouds moved we snapped a couple of pictures. I also thought they did a good job with the museum that contained pictures and video explaining how the mountain was completed. Don't miss the museum and the film that tells the story of Mt. Rushmore. There is also a path that you can walk and see different angles of the president's heads. The gift shop had a Customer Appreciation day while we were there. I was able to get t-shirts and a coffee mug. The cost was $5.00 each! That is hard to beat.

If you're visiting Bryce Canyon or Zion, a side trip to Cedar Breaks is definitely worthwhile. Since you'll be above 10,000 feet, the daytime highs will be 15-20 degrees cooler than in those other two parks. Cedar Breaks is fairly small, so the rock formations can be seen in less than two hours. But this is also a good place to hike -- especially because of the cooler temperatures. So if you're a hiker, plan to spend most of the day. Since it is not well-known, Cedar Breaks does not draw large crowds (like Bryce Canyon does), and the entrance fee is quite modest. There is a small campground, but be prepared: at this altitude, overnight temperatures can dip into the upper 40s. Rangers provide a variety of interpretative lectures, so a trip to Cedar Breaks National Monument can also be educational.

This four-block neighborhood includes Lincoln's home that he bought in 1844 for $1,200 and lived in until he went to Washington in 1861. Lincoln's home has been restored to it's 1861 condition and many of the other homes in this neighborhood have also been restored (at least on the exterior). The visitor's center is excellent and there is a very interesting video on Lincoln's life that you should see before you tour the neighborhood.

This is so awesome. I truly felt the Lincoln's presence in this home. So much is as it was when they lived there. The only home he ever owned. Be sure to walk thru the neighborhood. It is as it was during that era. You need to get your free ticket to go into Lincoln's home and they ran out the day we went. We luckily already had ours.

National Park Pass not valid here - you'll pay to enter and park. Very good and affordable late dinner in the cafeteria. Moving lighting ceremony with all singing and honoring service men and women :)

Bryce Canyon National Park is laid out in an 18 mile (one-way scenic drive). There are 14 view points and if you stop 15 minutes at each you would spend 3-4 hours at Bryce. There is an entrance gate, $25 a car, $12 on foot, motorcycle, etc., and for me $0.00 because I'm 62+ and bought a Lifetime Pass for $10. The visitor's center is about 100 feet from the entrance. Stop at the visitor's center.There is a free museum which is very informative. A 22 minute video, wildlife taxidermy, geology and more. Free WiFi, publications, backcountry permits, lost and found, shuttle service and most importantly Ranger advise. Tell them how long you plan to stay and they will develop an itinerary for you. This way you will get the most out of your stay.Most people do Sunrise, Sunset, Inspiration and Bryce point, That is where the amphitheatre can be viewed (Hoodoos). I think World of Warcraft (thousand Needles) was designed after the Hoodoos.As you travel further from the visitor's center (6,900')the elevation rises. At Rainbow point, the farthest point, it is 9115 feet. The oxygen level is 70 percent of oxygen at sea level. Figure in the heat and sometimes steep climbs on hikes if you plan on some of the hiking trails. You might want a guided tour on horseback into the canyon.After the amphitheatre view points are mostly about long distance views of up to 100 miles. Shuttles are free but only run to Rainbow Point twice a day. The other points every every 15 minutes. There are Ranger lead Geology talks, Rim Walk, Canyon Hikes, Astronomy lectures and telescope use and Full Moon Hikes which you need to sign up early for.Ruby's Inn located before the entrance has a Post Office, ATM and Internet. Speed limits in the park run 15-45 MPH. Yes, people are stopped and fined. If you are going to Capitol Reef after Bryce Canyon take Scenic Byway 12. it might be the best in Utah and maybe the country.

Took returned from a trip with the family to Mount Rushmore! I remember going when I was young with my parents and sisters and really enjoyed mine now! The whole atmosphere is still amazing that people carved this in the mountain! You can see Rushmore from the outside roads but well worth to pay $ to park and get up close!

WE arrived at the visitor center just a few minutes before the 20 minute ranger talk. We then went to the 20 minute movie. WE bought the auto tour CD and booklet for our tour of the battle field. This is an inexpensive way to learn about Civil War history. Admission was $6 for the car loan. The CD / booklet were $20. I would suggest going to the ranger talk before the battlefield. You sit in a room with many windows and get a battle overview along with getting to see the lay of the land so you have some idea where each side set up and in general where the battles took place. The CD tour takes you to a number of stops. You can get out and walk a number of pathways around the park. WE mostly listened to the CD. The auto tour took us 2-3 hours. We had a great time.

We headed up to Hyde Park to hike and check it out as a future camping site. The visitor center was closed- permanently. The "lodge" behind it was empty and shuttered. A sign said you had to pay a park fee (put it in the envelope) but there were no envelopes, no trail maps.

The campground host is now selling firewood. This is the first season they are selling @ $7 bundle. We were unable to find any firewood in tulelake. Also they sell ice at the visitor center, but it is much cheaper at the grocery store in tulelake.

I've grown up in SD and have traveled all over the US. We've gone to many National and State Parks. I still love Mount Rushmore. What a great piece of art - carved into hard rock. A great patriotic tribute to this wonderful nation that I love! I so glad to be an American. It is beautiful to walk the trail around and take so many photos. I like to take a blanket with the kids and get some ice cream. The gift shop is nice too but we don't always go in. We go here every time we are in the area. You pay for parking and it allows you to get in for the rest of the year. I think it is $11 per car.

I've been to the park several times and always enjoy driving to the top of Pinnacle Overlook. My recent visit included the tour of the Hensley Settlement. The tour is led by a park ranger in one of their 12-passenger vans. The tour price is $10 per person. Reservations can be made one month in advance and are highly recommended. Take the tour. It was informative, it was fun, and Ranger Matt, was the best tour guide I have ever listened to. We all enjoyed ourselves and came away facinated at everything we had seen and heard. The tour lasts approximately 4 hrs., so plan ahead. You won't be sorry.

It costs $10/per vehicle. The drive took us about an hour and a half. We stopped a lot to take pictures and look a scenic spots. Lots of buffalo, close up. We were told there are herds of wild horses, but were unfortunate and didn't see any. Lots of Prairie dogs. A little bit of construction on the roads, but no big deal. Traffic isn't too bad, so you can slow down or stop to look at things.

It is about $10.00 for two adults (can't remember), the drive is about 1 hour and a half. Lots of buffalo close up, and prairie dogs, and apparently wild horses, but didn't see any. Lots of pretty scenery!

We took the 6 hour tour to the Holgate Glacier on May 31, 2013. We had calm seas and dry weather. There was plenty of room and seating on our boat, the Alaskan Explorer. Well narrated tour with many wildlife sightings, orcas, humpback whales, porpoises, stellar sea lions, otters, mountain goats, puffins, and eagles. The boat was well run with no rush to see the highlights and had plenty of time for photo oportunities. The Holgate Glacier was great with the calving and with the engines turned off or idling quietly. On the return leg, they served a chicken ceasar wrap. Well worth the $144 price per ticket.

Capitol Reef is part of a 100 mile area that was created some 65 million years ago when dinosaurs roamed the landscape. The "Waterpocket Fold" defines the landscape with it's bulging uplifts, rainbow-hued sandstone reefs and canyons. Entrance to the park is free. There is a visitor's center which is open 8-4:30 and has geology, natural science abd cultural displays. A short orientation video is also given. As with all National Parks, Rangers will assist you in planning an itinerary for the duration of your stay. The highlights of Capitol Reef are the Fremont petroglyphs, the Mormon Homestead, the school house, blacksmith shop, Ripple Rock Nature Center. the Fruita (orchard) and the 16 mile Scenic Drive and backcountry. There are two dirt roads off the Scenic Drive which take you to Cathedral Valley where you walk between vertical cliffs. The Scenic Drive ends in a loop where you turn-around and head back to the visitor's center. The Scenic Drive costs $15 dollars but is free with a Senior Lifetime Pass or other National Park Pass. The Fruita grows apple, peach, cherry, pear, and apricots. Pies and other baked goods are available during the harvest season. Eat what you like for free. If you want to pick and take home there is a minimal fee. They have historic and heirloom varieties. Off of Scenic Highway 24 westbound and about a 1/2 mile from the visitor's center you will find the old school house and Fremont (700 AD-1250 AD) petroglyphs. Capitol Reef and the Hickman Bridge are just down the road on Highway 24. I wish I was there for the fruit harvest. I would have given the park a 5 star rating.

We read the descriptions of the available tours and decided to take the Lantern Tour. I can't believe it only cost $8. It was easily worth 10 times that much. Nicole, our tour guide did a great job and led us through the very dark and challenging caves to both the "Heavenly Room" and to the "Dungeon". If your guide only lets you choose one, the Dungeon adventure is really really amazing and memorable. Make sure that you do not being mind dark, tight places as it is both. You will need to be in pretty good shape with a sense of adventure. It is one of the coolest things I've ever done!

The Lincoln Home was one of the premier stops during our Lincoln Weekend. A bonus for us was the fact that the entire neighborhood was restored. It is a National Historic Site and every tour I have ever taken at a site administered by the National Park Service has been top notch. The Visitor Center provides a good start to the tour with a good orientation film. However, this can actually be viewed either before or after the neighborhood tour. The tour requires tickets and the number of participants is limited for each time slot. Several Rangers take you through each stage of the Lincoln Home explaining each room and the significance it played in the Lincoln family life. The rest of the restored neighborhood extended one block in each direction. I recommend using the cell phone tour to explain each of the homes and lots that were in the Lincoln's neighborhood. There are two other neighborhood homes that are open allowing visitors to walk through. It is incredible that there is no fee for this tour (as per Robert Todd Lincoln's condition for turning the house over to the government). This is not only a must-see in Springfield, it is a must-see for all Americans. Lincoln's story is one that is emblematic of our history and is seminal to understanding who we are as a nation today.

So, I'd always wanted to see Mount Rushmore. It is AMAZING! We were so lucky that when we got there it was a little bit overcast. The faces are so defined and it is just an awesome piece of America. The park is really first class and the trail around the park is a nice way to spend some time at the park. The sculpter's studio is pretty interesting, but the real draw is the actual monument. We left and went back that night (the $11 entry fee per car is good for a whole year!) for the lighting ceremony. It was a very reverent and inspiring ceremony and especially cool that all past and present servicemen were invited to walk to the stage for the lowering of the colors. It was really great how respectful the huge audience was throughout the ceremony. It is a really beautiful monument, outdoor theater, park, etc.

There are trails, lots of wildlife, a gift shop, Visitor's Center, and sites to see. I also recommend anyone visiting several sites in this area to purchase the National Parks Annual Pass for $80. It is good for a year and grants you free entrance at the National Park/Monument Sites. This place will take your breath away.

We only spent a few hours in the Pisgah forest, but we could probably stay there for a month. The giant water slide rock was hours of fun for the kids and it only costs $1.00 to get in the park. It's worth the drive. We also spent some time in the Davis River fishing and swimming. It's an inexpensive way to spend a day out with the family. Next time we will probably try tubing.

Majestic view and interesting history of its creation. Lovely hiking trail with great photo ops. Very close to Keystone and parking pass is good for the year, so we visited again the 2nd day of our trip. Beautiful display of state flags, also great photo ops

Coming from "down under" I had heard very little about this National park . Although the park is adjacent to Yellowstone National Park, it has its own, unique flavour. Make an extra day to spend time to See the Massive upright mountains, the lakes Surrounded by aspens and other trees and of course, the wild animals. The wildflowers are coming out beautifully at this time of year. The $25 you pay for a Seven day entry pass into the Yellowstone National Park also covers Grand Tetons.

Whether you are a history buff or not, this is a very interesting place to visit and if you have the chance to take the trolley tour with "Bree" as your guide you will have a great appreciation for the strategic insight of not only George Washington but others important in this war. The tour takes about 1.5 hours and there is a charge. We were very lucky to have re-enactors in the encampment area, so heard about life in the camp "first hand" from the enlisted men and a surgeon. You can imagine what life was like in the small cabins inhabited by the ranks and officers as you stand in them. As one other reviewer noted, the quarters of George Washington are quite impressive and the rooms are decorated in a very believable manner. If you are not into history and don't want to ride a bus, but would like to take a hike or a walk, there are maps at the visitor's center with trails and approximate length of most of them. There is no fee to visit the park itself. You can also visit each site/monument in the park on your own either walking or driving as the map of the park is quite detailed. If you are in the area, miss the shopping at the King of Prussia mall and come to Valley Forge for a beautiful and interesting piece of history.

During the busy season, Bryce Canyon park has a shuttle service which stops at the major view points. We entered from the north and took the shuttle bus from the visitor's center all the way to the last stop at Rainbow Point. We walked the short paths to the observation points. Then we took the bus north stopping Natural Bridge and then Inspiration Point. We walked a short distance to Inspiration Point overview (well worth it) and then walked the mostly downhill Rim hike from Inspiration Point to Sunset Point passing Bryce Amphitheater with an early audience (keep an eye out for the hoodoos which look like an audience) and Thor's Hammer. Then we hopped back on the shuttle to take it to Sunrise Point and access to the Queen's Garden trail. The Queen's Garden walk descends 320 feet below the rim with rest benches near the formation called Queen Victoria. On the way down you will pass the Boat Mesa, the sinking ship, Queen Victoria and her castle (these are easily recognizable with just a little imagination). I suggest you just note where they are on the way down because when you turn around to come back up, you will realize the trail was much steeper than you thought. That's why I suggest you take pictures on the way up. This will give you an excuse to stop frequently and catch your breath and you won't look like a wimp. This trail is really the best for seeing the most interesting hoodoos close up.

We loved hiking among the hoodoos, but do remember that if you have problems with heights this may be a pass for you. The trails and views are awesome, but some are so steep that the cliffs and drop-offs may be a concern for those with a fear of heights. We found a surprisingly beautiful hike along the Mossy Cave trail just outside of Bryce Canyon proper, which was easy and did not involve a lot of steep drop-offs. We also had to traverse trails with winds approaching 50 mph in early spring. This is something to add to your bucket list!

My husband and I took the New Entrance Tour and were extremely satisfied. We were a little worried about the amount of steps (500 total), but they were spread out with places to stop while the guide talked. It is an amazing cave and this tour allows you to see the stalactites. It's cool, so you may want a jacket and there are some tight squeezes around rocks and places you have to bend down. I was a little worried about 2 babies that women strapped to them when we walked in. Within the first few steps, the babies started screaming and they had to turn around and walk back out. I do think the park service needs to make some stronger restrictions on who is allowed in the cave. The tour is well worth the $12.
No charge so go inside and get a closer look. Line is swift but be prepared to get your bags searched by security.

This is on my bucket list of to do's and it really did live up to expectations, It was amazing, entrance fee wasnt expensive and admission is reusable for a year (not good if you have a rental car though, as its done on Licence plate #). I was in awe of how close you were to the carvings, excellant viewing area and nice walk (250 steps one way, ramp on the way back).

We arrived on the way to another event and wanted to take the walking tour that was shorter and involved a bit less climbing/walking (for seniors with bad knees). The tour was scheduled for 9:15 and we arrived at 8:30 and went right to the box office. We stood in line for 25 minutes and when we got to the ticket seller were told that the tour we wanted was "sold out".

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: Take a nice day trip from Austin and visit the Texas White House in the Hill Country.Allow a full day for stopping to visit all the sites in the Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park. The only park fee is a modest $3 for touring the Texas White House, otherwise, there are not entrance fees. View the film at the visitor center, it is well worth the time and sets the context for the visit.

My daughter and I enjoyed our visit to Adams National Historical Park. Begin at the Visitor's Center in downtown Quincy. There is a parking garage behind the Center, though it's kind of confusing as a good deal of the spaces are marked "reserved" for local business employees. Head up to the third level for visitor parking. And take your garage ticket to the Visitor Center with you - they will stamp it so your parking will be free (otherwise, it will cost you $4-5 to park for the lengh of a tour.) The tour costs only $5 and starts at the Visitor's Center with a movie (about 15 minutes). A trolley picks you up from there and drives your group to the first two Adams homes, and then to another site where the third home is located. The homes are very interesting to see, and the tour guides - as the National Park Service rangers usually are - are wonderful and very knowledgeable. Allow about 2 hours for the tour, plus extra waiting time for the next tour to start (there is a gift shop in the Center to keep you busy). I believe the tours run every hour. The only negative thing I can say is that we weren't encouraged to walk around the gardens at Peacefield (the third home), though I believe you are allowed to if you want to. If you are looking for a meal or snack before or after your visit, I recommend Gunter Tootie's across the street from the Visitor's Center for a yummy sandwich, salad, or pastry.

Plenty of room on the battlefield for the RV weather towing or driving. $6 for vehicle or $4 per person on a bus to get in. Informative and driving tour layed out well. You could spend as little as 1 hour to 3-4 days depending on your level of interest. Well done. JR ranger stuff to do also.

My daughter and I arrived at the visitor's center in the late afternoon just in time to look around a little and take the canal boat tour. We boarded a trolley to take us the few blocks down to the boat dock for our tour. Cost for the canal tour was $8/person or $4/person if you have a National Parks annual pass. This tour was well worth the cost. Emily, our ranger, was very knowledgable about how the canals allowed Lowell to become one of the 1st big factory towns in the United States. She discussed how/why the canals were built as well as pointed out areas of interest along the way. We even disembarked upstream to get a close look at one of the locks. Originally, we had planned to spend an afternoon in Lowell. After taking the canal tour, we decided to come back for a second day to see the rest of the park.

The fee for this is to park. It's $11 for any vehicle, motorcycle, car, etc. No military discount, etc. Not so great, but there is a lot of maintenance involved in the monument. The viewing floor up top is very fancy from floor tiles to lights. Inside there are videos and displays with information about the making of the monument, each of the presidents, and the surrounding areas.

Mount Rushmore has always been on my bucket list, and it did not disappoint. The best thing about being in the area is that you can see these men everywhere. Take some time and view all the different areas in the park to see the figures. The lighting ceremony for me was a must. We went two nights and the better place to see is the seats above the auditorium by the elevators, just not the first row. The best place to hear is on the auditorium floor. We got there by 8 to get to our seats, the ceremony started at 9. We looked around a little while my husband saved us seats. The highlight of the lighting ceremony is the retiring of the flag with the veterans or current people serving in the armed forces. The lighting ceremony was very informative and patriotic. Make sure you view the movie, see the sculptors studio, and walk the presidential trail. If you have kids the must do is the Jr Ranger program, my 10 year old loved it. My fourteen year old also did it. You have to get the book from any ranger anywhere in the park, and when you complete it you take it back to any ranger. The ranger will ask them a few questions and then they take an oath of a ranger and get a badge to wear. A great program and it focuses the kids on learning something other than just looking and not learning! The park spends a lot of time on the making and history of Mount Rushmore, which is all centered around Borglum. As you make your way around the park and the exhibits you really start to feel the passion of Borglum and what he wanted to do. The park also has a great gift shop, one of the biggest and best in the area we saw. The ice cream shop was ice cream, nothing special. The food was good and not overly priced. Do the presidential trail had lots of steps but well worth it. Like my husband says you can always stop to rest! Parking was $11.

You know when the captain guarantees that you will see whales that you are in for a wonderful experience. We took the 6 hour tour of the park with Kenai Fjords National Park Tours. The catamaran is large and comfortable. Lots of seating. Seas were a bit rough due to some recent storms in the area and some people got sick, so definitely think about taking some seasickness meds if you are prone to this. The tour was amazing. We saw whales, otters, seals, mountain goats. Got close to a glacier and heard the eery sounds of it calving. We had some rain, which cleared toward the end of the trip, when the sun actually came out. It was pretty cold, too! So dress in layers if you go early in the season. All in all it was stupendous. I highly recommend. If you can use one of the coupon books (we did and saved $100) all the better. Some of the most beautiful scenery I have ever seen.

This was a truly incredible experience. Although a bit pricey, it was great to walk through a monument built in the Civil War. Sad to see that it has not been maintained throughout the years but there is construction going on so maybe that will be corrected. Snorkleing was great and the crew on the boat were really nice. The breakfast was marginal but the lunch was good. The only drawback was after paying a high price and tipping the bartenders we were asked again to tip the staff. Then when disembarking a staff member was standing there with the tip jar.

My husband and I took the Yankee Freedom ferry to Dry Tortugas. It was a 2 1/2 hour trip, each way, but gave me some time to cat-nap. The fare for the Yankee Freedom includes breakfast and lunch so no need to pack food. Plus you have a place to use the bathroom. They also provide snorkling equipment and a tour of the fort. Hubby did a self-guided tour and then headed for the beach to snorkle. The water was as clear as a pool and the marine life was plentiful. This was more than I expected. I hope we can take our grandchildren next time.

We visited Mammoth Cave National Park on a Thursday and Friday in June. Our first stop was the visitor's center. The visitor's center is one of the best that I've visited in a National Park. It's quite new and very well organized. There is a museum with information about the formation of the cave and the history of the area. There is an information desk that includes TV monitors listing the tours and times that they depart. We noticed that some of the tours were sold out. If your schedule is tight or you are visiting on a summer or holiday weekend, then I recommend purchasing the tickets online before you arrive to the park. We purchased the Mammoth Passage Tour ticket onsite and the New Entrance Tour ticket online. The ticket counter was very efficient and we did not have to wait.

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: We stopped here unexpectedly as we were early for another event in the area. I had been here as a child with school but had not been as an adult. Living in Austin you are surrounding by LBJ and Lady Bird History and influence. This was a delight. First, I had no idea they were both buried on this property. No fan fare. In a family graveyard with nice grave stones but nothing over the top. The main house is $3 per person to enter but worth the effort and price. They have kept it as it was when they lived there. There are many of their personal items still in the home. Extremely interesting to look in their closets. Lady Bird sure did love color. The landing strip, the cars, etc are all interesting to see. I can only imagine what the world thought of Johnson City. Extremely glad we made the stop. Hope to return in the near future and spend more time on some of the other buildings on the property. We did the loop drive and spent our time at the main house. We also stopped at the graveyard. Nice that they let you do the loop in your own vehicle vs the bus I remember as a child.

This is an impressive piece of workmanship. We knew we were going to impressed, but wow. Pictues can't do it justice. You must see it. The walk in to the viewing area, through the granite arches featuring the flags of the states is so neat and then you imerge for an unobstructed view. Just so neat. Do the Presidential trail for closer views and different angles. Also, don't forget the famous cafeteria and ice cream shop. The staff in the store and ice cream are great and for me went above and beyond. As far as admission, if you are senior get the lifetime pass and get in lots of NPS sites for free.

If you have an extra day in Key West and want to get away from the general crowds in old town, visit Dry Tortugas National Park. It's something you might only do once, but it's time well spent. The boat ride was nice and relaxing, although it might be less so if the seas weren't fairly calm. I noticed quite a few people dozing...maybe they had taken motion sickness meds, but the boat is very large and I think most people won't be bothered much by sea-sickness. The water is beautiful and Garden Key, where you will land, offers snorkeling and the historical Fort Jefferson. We did not see a large variety of fish, possibly due to recent storms, but the snorkeling was fun anyway. Breakfast and lunch offerings were plentiful and the crew members were friendly and efficient. Well worth the price and highly recommended.

This was my 4th trip. The 8.5 hours went fast, it is beautiful. But they shortened the time at the stops and increased the price, $43.50, significantly. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars. I would plan on taking the next bus to enhance your visit and have time to experience everything at the different stops. So take backpacks so you can catch different buses. Take bug spray and food and water. There is a water station at Eielson. A must do if you can get there. Will need to spend the night so you can get an early bus. Lots of great info on the Denali Park site.

Fort Mantanzas (Spanish for 'massacre') is about 20 minutes south of downtown St. Augustine but it well worth the drive. First, it is a National Park Service site, so it is well maintained and staffed by a professional and enthusiastic ranger (despite one of the previous reviews, the workers are definitely INTO the history). Second, it is FREE! A nice boat side across the Mantanzas inlet, admission into the fort (really an old Spanish watch tower), an easy hour with friends and/or family, and a spectacular view at the fort top for no cost? You won't find many bargains like this in St. Augustine! Finally, if you plan well you can visit during living history demonstrations, when volunteers dress as 18th century Spanish soldiers and tell you about the site in full character!!!!

This was the obvious site to see after Cape Disappointment the previous day because it is where Lewis and Clark's team chose to set up their camp for the winter of 1805/1806. The movie is excellent. The actual fort is a good 2006 reproduction and was built in accordance with Lewis's carefully recorded specifications. None of the interpretive sites are operating until the beginning of July, but, hailing from Virginia's Jamestown and Yorktown area, we have seen plenty of those and did not miss them. The walk to the spring and the canoe landing site through the forest of tall Sitka Spruce trees is well worth it. It was frustrating to a "wrinkly" with a "pay as you go large button" cell phone that much of the self guided walking tour is reliant on smart phones for commentary. Take a look at the quilt in the visitor's center - designed by 8th graders it is worth closer inspection.

The cave is accessed only by elevator from the surface. You must pay for all tours. Tours are offered at various times, but they tend to fill up fast, so it is best to arrive early. Park entry is same for all National Parks. Cave is large and interesting. It is filled with calcite crystals, but does not have the variety of cave formations that are found in Carlsbad Cavern, or Louray Cavern. But, it worth the time to take the tour. There are a lot of steps up and down but paths are paved so is easy to walk.

We considered just viewing it from various places along the road rather than actually driving in and parking. I'm glad we paid the $11 parking and made the visit. We walked the Presidential Trail which offered some interesting viewing angles. The sculptor's shop was very interesting including the model and we got there at the right time to hear a Park Ranger give a 15 minute talk that was very informative. Driving the Mt. Rushmore road trip (local guide map) it was amazing how many different times we could view Mt Rushmore. I especially liked the long distance view from Norbecks's Overlook.

I have been to Mount Rushmore three times now, and it is does not get old. I especially love the first glimpse of the stone faces peeking through the trees as you wind your way up to the parking area. While the grounds have continued to be developed over the years and made more accessible, the efforts have only enhanced the visitor's experience. This visit was a quick stop en route back home, but it was the highlight even though the visit was short. Had we had more time, we likely would have grabbed a bite to eat and then stayed for the lighting ceremony. Instead, we took our time on the walking loop (both directions can be a bit strenuous with the steps, but we would recommend starting the trail by going to the right since stone steps seem steeper than the newer composite steps that you'll encounter the rest of the way), and then perused the large gift shop. Public parking fee was $11 per vehicle, but that is good for the year.

Mount Rushmore is an amazing sight. All cars must pay an $11 parking fee. Senior Pass is not good at the Park. However, there is no other "fee" once through the parking gate. You must really enter the Park to get a good sight of the four presidents and take good photos. Be sure to see the short theater film describing the sculpture and how the images were positioned and blasted from the rock. There is a path/walkway that winds around through the trees below the presidents and leads to the sculptor's work studio. We did not stay for the laser show at night, but we were told it is a great experience. This is one of those "must see" monuments for anyone residing in or visiting the USA.

The tour guide is Excellent. Everything seems so real. There is a fee for some activities and no fee to observe the park area. They also offer a visitor center movie. Everything is so spread out, you can visit and observe at your leisure. The Gift shop/ book store has lots of educational information. Very enjoyable for all.

We took our motorcycles from Durango and rode the "Million Dollar Highway" from Durango to Silverton, Ouray, Ridgeway, Telluride, Dolores, Mancos and back to Durango. It was a BEAUTIFUL ride with some excellent scenery. It is a full day trip so leave early in the morning so you don't get caught in the mountains at night. If you are riding a motorcycle make sure you are experienced as there are some pretty scary twists and turns on this route. The east side of the trip (Silverton and Ouray) is pretty "twisty" so make sure you go the speed limit the signs tell you as there are some parts that you don't have guardails on with steep drop offs. It is definitely worth the day doing the whole route....left me speechless with the beauty of it.

walking the landscape is the real highlight of the memorial, and, for this reason, should be saved for a day when spending time outside can be done the best part of the museum is the LED-model of the path of the flood; the film is frankly bizarre and in some viewers might result in inappropriate laughter rather than mournful reflection; it is rumored that there is an annual walk that approximates the course of the flood, and this memorial could be much better with a riverside trail of that distance; also, other than cost, it is unclear why a bridge has not been constructed across the entire dam wall - that would be a fantastic improvement

Mount Rushmore lives up to its billing as a national treasure. You can't grasp the enormity of the monument unless you see it in person. There is no charge except for the $11 per car parking fee, which is good for several days if you want to return. You can see it for free at several spots on state Route 16. There is also a trail that runs close the mountain for a closer perspective. There is a lighting ceremony every night which is worth attending.

Why is it that a non-governmental entity charges $11.00 for the only parking near the National Memorial Mount Rushmore? That pretty much spoils the entire reason for having national parks. Private companies have no business controlling access to our national treasures.

The visitor's center is free and has a great gift shop. The tour of Independence Hall is free but you must have a ticket. Get there by 8:30 am to make sure you get a ticket, or pre-order online. The Liberty Bell tour is free and can take place while waiting for your Independence Hall tour.

We visted with 2 friends who had been here several times in the past. It was $10 a car to get into the park and there is a vistor's center with lots of info and people who will answer any questions you may have. There are shuttle buses right at the Vistor's Center that will take you up to Bolivar Heights where you can walk around and read about events that occurred there, and then they also take you to lower downtown Harper's Ferry. When we were there I'd say busses (air conditioned thankfully) came by every 12-15 minutes.

The views are SO beautiful and amazing!!! We took so many pictures so we can remember our trip forever. We left Jackson, Wyoming heading for Yellowstone and went to the Grand Teton Park. We had lunch in our car beside the National Elk Refuge and sat and watched wildlife. It seemed like we turned the corner in our car, and there were the mountains..... We just were speechless. They are so tall, and gorgeous. Breathtaking. We stopped at Jackson Lake for great pics along the drive. It was gorgeous. They have a $25 entrance fee which is also good for Yellowstone. Glad we were there and have this memory, everyone should see it.

You have to visit Fort Jefferson at least once in your lifetime. The boat ride on Yankee Freedom is awesome - they have the best staff & a great, large boat. The park is a wonderful part of history & the location is so isolated & beautiful. Great snorkeling for novice - not as deep as reef snorkeling but almost as pretty. Well worth the price to get there - this park needs to get our donations so that we can preserve a historic fort that was built under extreme circumstances. Great trip - I've been 3 times - each time we take someone that's never been.

Hard to say anything negative about one of Mother Natures best works. Snow, still too much of it in mid June. Just sit and gaze across the lake. Lowers the heart rate and BP, relaxing. Could not believe the blue color of the water.

The tour is free but be warned, you must have tickets and they are distributed in the morning and are usually gone well before noon. We found this out our first day and opted to reserve online and pay $1.50 per ticket to select our time. We arrived at 10am, picked up our tickets and headed to the Liberty Bell. The line was short at this time but we noticed throughout the day, it was very long. It's definitely a must see thought! The tour of Independence Hall is well organized but a bit rushed. It was awe-inspiring to be in the same room that our founding fathers had debated and adopted the Declaration of Independence and Constitution. I must say that our guide, Ranger Eric Knight was the BEST guide that I have ever experienced. He truly made you think and appreciate the significance of what we were experiencing. Throughout the park, the park rangers have trading cards for the kids who answer historical questions. Great way to make learning fun. If in Philly, this must be on your to-do list!

Very impressive night program with the lighting ceremony, veterans dedication, film and talk by ranger. amphitheater full and expected problems getting out, but got out quickly. Well worth the night time visit. Program starts around 9 but get there before 8:30 for seats. Parking is $11 which is only fee and parking pass good for one year. We plan to go back today to hike the presidential trail.

We flew on a seaplane to the island for the morning, which, for us, was plenty. We are not much for laying on a beach, soaking up cancer- and wrinkle-causing sun. The flight was were the extra cost, as opposed to taking the boat. We arrived earlier than the first boatload of tourists, so were able to enjoy seeing the fort, swimming and snorkeling long before the crowds arrived.

I guess you get what you pay for. Do Not do the self guided tour if it is your first time and you drove awhile to get here. You really do not get to see much and it is very short. We will come back next year and do one of the longer , more expensive tours and see if they are better. We had 3 children ranging in age from 9-13 and they kept acting up so we could tell they were bored. Afterward we went to the Lost River underground cave tour and they were quite as church mice and not acting up (it was awesome). Prices at Mammoth are reasonable. Take a jacket because it is in the 50's down there ALL the time. My husband didn't want to take a jacket but thanked me later.

This is a long hong up and down caves. I am a physically fit person but I should have stretched before walking this trail. Two days later and my calves are still sore. Don't be afraid thought there are many stops to catch your breath. the caves are extraordinary. We payed $10 each for a 2 hour tour. The guide stops and gives us interesting facts and does a Q and A. She makes jokes and keeps it lively for all ages

One of those places every American should visit. An important part of our history. To be able to stand in a room where he lived and walk where he walked to me is just awesome. We have been there several times and are still awed by the experience. I like that it is free to everyone. We have learned to get there early in the morning to get a tour ticket to avoid a long wait for the tour.

Mount Rushmore is a must for families. My husband and I first went with our daughters, and are thrilled we did. The walk to the Grand Terrace is wonderful with all the flags flanking you as you pass by. There are restaurants, gift shops, and snack shops all at the monument. The park pass lasts an entire year, and is exclusive for your license plate and vehicle. We took the Presidential path in a clockwise manner (another TA review noted this would be less strenuous), and it was an easy walk. Be sure to stop along the way to read about the chosen presidents, and take advantage of plenty of photo ops.

Up close and personal, it's unbelievable how it was accomplished. The facility is extremely well maintained. Don't budget more than an hour or two at the very most. You can see it all very quickly. Do was the entire President's trail if you are able. The views of the sculptures are wonderful. One can almost see Cary Grant hanging on for dear life. It is highly recommended to see it in the late evening when it is lit. Unfortunately we didn't get to do that. It is most certainly something for you to put on your bucket list. NOTE: admission to the facility is free BUT you have to pay $11.00 to park. Now that will cover you for a year but I can't imagine anyone making weekly visits.

The Volcano Park offers something for everyone. The lava fields resemble old battle fields with the remnants of previous eruptions - the lava has encased tree trunks and left oddly-shaped outcrops that make perfect backdrops for pictures. The lava tube is breath-taking and worth the walk through to see formations in what looks like a glowing cave. The museum is fun for the kids, offering a seizmeter where you jump as hard as you can and measure the size of the 'earthquake' that you created. It is also educational, with the history of the park and previous eruptions covered in spectacular photographs and written accounts, you can also fee the lava rocks on display. The highlight of the visit is to stay till after sunset and witness the red glow coming from the active volcano. You need to be prepared to fight for space to see the active volcano as everyone wants a turn and take a jacket because it gets chilly after dark. The museum shops offers a variety of souvenirs to mark your visit and professional photographs of the volcano. The bathrooms are clean and well-maintained. Prepare to be awed

Make sure if you are in the Boston area that you take the time to go just a few miles South to the Adams National Historical Park. Go to the Visitors Center to get tickets. They are very cheap-$5. Kids under 16 were free. They will direct you to the Church where John Adams and John Quincy Adams are buried with their wives. We were greeted by Gary who gave us a quick tour of the church that the family belonged to as well as their graves. The trolley takes you to the birthplaces of both presidents as well as to Peacefield, the home of 4 generations of the Adams family. The house went directly from the family to the National Park System so it has not been changed and contains the original furnishings. Our guides were all interesting and informative. It is a must see and gives you a greater appreciation for the contributions that this family made to our nation. They were ahead of their time on many issues.

One of the nation's longest but nothing really special when compared to the world's best. Great place to bring people who have never been to a cave since it is well equipped and safe. Children will be fine. I took the 1 hour 20 minute Scenic Tour with 732 steps and it was pleasant . Reasonable price, too.

I can't top the other wonderful reviews about this gem. It is really well organized and very impressive. Be sure to see the night time lighting ceremony. If you're able to handle steps, the Presidential Trail is an essential part of the visit. I also highly recommend the audio tour. Everything was top rate. No fee for the attraction, but $11 for parking.

Great experience to see one of our nation's historical landmarks; well maintained facility with a restaurant and gift shop, trail, etc. It seemed strange to go in for free but pay $11 to park. We drove by early in the day to visit and decided to come back later in the day for the lighting ceremony. Ranger presentation and video are interesting. Only disappointment was that the parking pass we purchased earlier in the day (which was still good) didn't allow you to get around the line getting into the place. Definitely a must see when in the Black Hills area.
What to say - you cannot miss this. Your entrance fee is good for several days and for return to see night show. Not strenuous.

You probably traveled to South Dakota in part to see Mt Rushmore - so don't get put off by the $11 parking fee 9 (Charged to pay for the new garage to accommodate all the visitors that they get in season). This is a major landmark in the USA and everyone who has a chance should see it at least once. The facilities have been recently rebuilt, and there is a beautiful stone walkway leading to a viewing platform for the monument. There is also a nature trail that takes you closer, as well as leads to the artists studio - be prepared for a bit of a hike, but it is worth it if you are able. If you are serious about taking perfect photos, get there before mid afternoon, before the shadows start to affect the monument.

We spent 6 nights camping at Colter Bay June 5-11. It was a GREAT time to go...no crowds, very comfortable temps (high 30's overnight; 70 during the day). Highly recommend Colter Bay Campground. We have a pop-up camper. There are sights with full hook-up, but we opted for none. The sites without hook-ups were much better. Full hook-ups were basically on an asphalt slab...not our idea of camping. There were clean restrooms (flush toilets only) near camping sites. You could shower for $3.75 at the laundrette in Colter Bay.
Great tours for everyone. We did the historic tour which was 2 hrs and 2 miles long and $12 for adults and well worth it

First, you should know that parking fees at the monument ($11.00minimum) are mandatory...no senior free admission. The buildings up to the faces remind me of a grey, lifeless, concrete fortress and there are throngs of tourists. That being said, the faces themselves are true marvels of both art and technology and are a part of our heritage. Better, fewer tourist filled photographic shots of the monument are to be found on the wonderful road to Custer Park from Keystone. Frame the faces through the forest or through a stone car tunnel. Just keep your eye open on this auto tour and you will come home with great shots of Mount Rushmore and no shots of the tour bus crowd.

This was the reason we flew out from New York and it did not disappoint. No fee to get in, but you do have to pay to park. So very stirring and majestic. The audio tour was great and a bargain at only $5.00. The Presidential Trail was a bit of a hike with the warn weather- not that long (maybe a 1/2 mile) on a paved path, but the stairs did leave us huffing a bit... still well worth it. We came back at night for the closing ceremonies... so very stirring. Tip- come a bit early to get a seat.

Absolutely stunning! I have to admit I wasn't too keen on paying the park entry fee when we arrived because I didn't know what to expect. However, once we got inside it was definitely worth it. Our family spent a good amount of time stopping at the various views and we took the best pictures of our entire vacation from here. The kids loved it too, we just had to watch them very carefully because there are some places where you can get very close to the sheer sides. The view at the Painted Wall reminded me of scenery from the Lord of the Rings. Pictures don't do this place justice. This is a place I would love to go back to and spend more time exploring.

if you want to see live lava running its hard to do unless you rent a helicopter, a boat, or are willing to hike 17 mi. one way over some pretty scorched terrain. The road the could take you there was taken OUT by some lave about 15 years earlier and while thats cool to see, it wont get you very close. There is some 'private' property you can cut through outside the park for about 2.5 mi. but apparently the property owners charge you $100 for privilege. There is opportunism at its best!

Some parks charge $10 for the audio tour on CD. At Capitol Reef it's a value at $4. It's like having your own tour guide as you go through the park. Don't miss the left turn off Scenic Drive into Grand Wash; our favorite part of the park with the narrows, Pioneer Register, possibility of seeing big horn sheep, and seeing one of Butch Cassidy's alleged hiding areas.

We drove the scenic drive which costs $5 to enter however quite a few of the parks attractions are along highway 24 which are free. Unfortunately we did not have time to do any hikes but were able to view the varying rock layers and subsequent colours from the paved road and stops along the highway.

It is hard for something like Mount Rushmore to live up to expectations since you've already seen so many pictures and heard so much about it, but the carving of four great Presidents on a South Dakota mountain is awesome and inspiring. Here are a few tips. Parking is $11 but it's good for a year so if you are staying nearby come back a couple of times. We went during the day and came back for the evening lighting ceremony. Don't miss the Presidential Trail that will give you a very different view of the Presidents and leads to the Sculptor's Studio. The food at Carver's Café is better than you would expect. We met one of the original carvers in the gift shop selling a book. Take your time because there is a lot to enjoy. Hats off to the NPS for taking great care of this wonderful monument.

First, the entrance fee of eleven dollars per vehicle is quite reasonable considering the upkeep of the park. The parking garage is very user friendly, and the ice cream was quite tasty, and not much more than what you would expect for an ice cream chain. We did not try the food but the cafe had quite a selection, and there seemed to be plenty of seating considering it was a Saturday during lunchtime. The gift shop and bookstore have several interesting and possibly difficult to find selections, for fairly decent prices. The grounds and restrooms were clean and staff was friendly. We did not take the walking trail nor did we visit the Lincoln Borglum Museum as we were already beat from a busy day in Keystone, but we intend to head back up the mountain tomorrow at nine o'clock in the evening to see the Monument lighting ceremony. For just five dollars, you can partake in the audio tour and learn even more about everything.

What a park! Lots of different hikes available. Main visitor center has a wonderful information center that basically gives you any and all the information you need about how this place and how it was formed, and what may happen in the future. Chain of Craters drive was absolutely amazing. What a view! Don't pass on seeing this park!

This place is amazing. From the old calderas and old lava flows to the active volcano, the scenery is breathtaking. We saw the glow at night from Kilauea, and the constant smoke during the day. We didn't see a live lava flow, but just seeing the old was great.We were going to take a helicopter flight but I wasn't prepared to pay for two seats for myself.( if you weigh more than 260 pounds, 118kg you need to buy two seats). We visited the Pu'u Loa Petroglyths and the Holei Sea Arch, both worth the scenic drive to. If you want to visit this area over a few days, buy the Hawaii Tripark Annual ticket, as it allows you entry to three of the great parks and works out cheaper. Definitely worth the visit.

This was the highlight of our trip. The memorial is amazing. So glad we went in the late afternoon so we could see the monument while there was still daylight and then stay for the evening lighting ceremony. The parking fee was reasonable and I liked that ticket was good for a week. As with most public venues the food prices were steep.

Recently visited with our grandkids, aged 9 and 10. You never know how kids will react to things, but they absolutely loved it....not only the grandeur and scale of the carvings...they also enjoyed the States' flags, the information center and film about the making of Mount Rushmore as well as the hike across the base. It was a rainy evening so at times we had to wait for the clouds to move out of the way, but that just made it more mysterious. I think the parking fee is quite reasonable. We did find the signage on the highway puzzling...the sign said something like " turn here for the 'concession' "--which made us think of food--I think something like "turn here for the 'monument' " would be more understandable.
You have to see this! Great during the day and come back at night for the lighting ceremony (get in all day on one admission).

Great Memorial, laid out beautifully. As you walk towards the sculpture down the aisle of flags the view is fantastic. No charge for entrance, but there is an $11 parking fee. Food is available in a very nice cafe style restaurant. If I go again, I would stay for the lighting ceremony, which everyone says is fantastic. There are two pet exercise areas either side of the parking lots, just in case you have your pet with you. You cannot take your pet inside the memorial.

Whilst travelling along Interstate 10 heading towards Phoenix, Arizona I saw a sign stating Joshua Tree National Park ahead. As I had plenty of time before arriving in Phoenix, I thought that I would drive through this park and see it's attraction. It was a quiet and pleasant journey through the first stage of the park to the Ranger station. It had outstanding natural views with plenty of charm and character. I entered the ranger station to purchase my ticket and was informed to take the left fork of Park Boulevard as it would provide me with better views of the Joshua Trees. The journey in total took about 3 hours to Joshua tree and was a delight, the park has a rugged feel about it and it's various rock formations and colours was a beauty to behold. Well worth the extra time, It would have been a disaster to have missed this hidden gem, pity that I did not have a picnic hamper but Subways had already provided me with adequate fayre.

Spectacular views! We visited in early May and recommend visiting in the off-season if possible. The crowds were sparse and there was plenty of room for parking at the scenic pullouts. While Zion NP is looking from the bottom up, this is looking from the top down. Start at the Visitor's Center and Park Rangers will give recommendations for the best views in the time you have. There is an entrance fee, but check if you qualify for the $10 senior lifetime pass (age 62) or if you get an annual pass, both are good for all National Parks. The Painted Desert, Petrified Forest, Zion, Bryce and Grand Canyon together are easily a one week trip

Dylan, our guide, did a very good job. The 4 hour ride is about $80 a person, but uncludes all the best of the canyon, along with a great time on the mules and/or horses. The trail is steep, but the guides move at a steady, safe pace.

$10 to enter the park. Went to visitor's center. They have a video with an overview of the park's history. Then drive up to the rim and parked at the main building there. The rim trail is only a few steps away and the beautiful blue waters of the lake await you. I didn't really believe all the hype about how blue it was until I saw it for myself. It really is 2000 flushes blue.

My three year old daughter and I visited Mammoth Cave today. It was a nice experience. We went on the "New Entrance" cave tour. My daughter's admission was free & I think I had to pay twelve dollars for mine, which is well worth it. Took a short bus ride to the cave, then headed underground. To start, you'll have to go down approximately 300 steps or so, and they're all different sizes, heights, and shapes, some where you need to weave around portions of rock. I'm not complaining I had fun, and surprisingly, so did my daughter. I just wanted to give out this information to help anyone considering this adventure-- definitely not handicap accessible, or for anyone with bad knees (or any other major health concern). My only real complaint, which I know is no one's fault & there can't be anything done about this, is that there were way too many giant legged cave crickets crawling inches away from my face, clothes, and hair, on the low ceilings and cramped walls. Those things terrify me, so I shrieked an awful lot more than I'd care to admit. Otherwise, a fun outing! Thank you, Mammoth Cave!

Take an hour or so out of your day and visit Petroglyph National Monument. The art work has stood the test of time and are very interesting to see. Cost is either $1 or $2 depending on weekend or weekday. Short walk up side of hill. Easily done. Other walk is along base of hillside, takes 10 minutes, if that. Worth the visit.

One of the neatest Forts we have explored! Full of information and artifacts. Fun for the family or the history buff. There is a nice grassy park near the river where you can picnic before or after the tour. We chose a self guided tour towards the end of the day, but there are audio tours available. Check the website for fee info.

We had a good time. Super cheap family fun. Would rate it Excellent except we got attacked by bugs the whole time. Little green iridescent beetles that were everywhere! Might ask about some kind of repellant before you go.
Well worth the entrance fee to see the cliff dwellings. Easy hike and up close and personal into the cliffs. Awesome!

If you are visiting Yellowstone, be sure to drive another 90 minutes to Jackson Hole, Wyoming and see the Tetons. Their rugged beauty will take your breath away. It is smaller than Yellowstone, but it still packs a punch for activities and hiking. Your Yellowstone pass will get you into the Tetons for free. Be sure to see Jenny Lake, Inspiration Point, and Lake Taggart. If you are more of a hiking enthusiast, Amphitheater Lake will leave you breathless (literally). You have a 3,500 feet change of elevation in about 4 miles. Keep going because the pay off is worth it. Be warne that the trail will be covered with snow in higher elevations even into mid June. Just follow the footprints ahead of you. Be sure to pack plenty of water. My girlfriend and I LOVED the Tetons.

The 2 hour historical tour was worth the $12 adult and $8 child admission fee. Plus kids 6 and under are FREE!! Our tour guide was knowledgeable and humorous. Temperatures is chilly so long sleeves are recommended but not needed. My kids didn't seem to mind since they were distracted by the rocks lol. Some of the trail is steep and slippery so good walking shoes are a must! Nice family fun at a great price!

The place was so amazing that I came back a second day for a second tour. It's not for someone with bad ankles/knees, the stairs can be difficult. From what I could tell the Frozen Niagara tour is the easiest to walk. If you have health issues of any kind, I suggest a fruit/breakfast bar in your bag. As I noticed the temperature difference from outside to inside the cavern....bothered some people. Inside temp...around 54 degrees. Tour fees are reasonable, if you have a National Parks Access card, use it for a discount. I understand they do have a program for children that is free. There is a snack wagon available near the Welcome centre, or three restaurants to choose from. Two of those do not open early in the morning. There is also the Mammoth Caves Hotel. There is a Park store available, as well as a full Post Office. This whole area is a great spot for family fun.

The friendliest park rangers you can expect. Always happy to assist with anything you ask. It is definitely cold underground, so be sure to bring a jacket! The museum is informative. There are several free trails/tours on the surface. The area was very kept up, and restrooms were very clean. Nearby picnic area. Underground tours fill up quickly, so be sure to book ahead or plan to arrive before opening to guarantee a spot. The tours are not cheap! A family of four will cost about $40+ a tour. Don't expect to take pictures with your cell phone because the caves are so large and you will not be close enough, nor is the light bright enough.

Go for the evening show. I just went and the show was at 9 pm and lasted until about 9:40. Also see the movie and the exhibits on the sculptor. Be aware that entrance to this site is through a vendor, not the National Park Service. The vendor has constructed a parking structure, so there is an $11 charge per standard vehicle for parking at the site. I believe that allows you multiple entries on future days as well. If you have a NPS pass, it won't work here.

This is definitely something that everyone needs to see in their lifetime. We got here in the afternoon and surprisingly there wasn't a lot of people, we did not stay for the lighting ceremony that was held at 9pm. The price to get in was $11.00 per car I personally think this was cheap. There were trails, but we did not go on them.

What can I say that has not already been said about Mount Rushmore. This is something every American should see and experience at least once in their lives. From the mountain itself to the stories about building this great monument take the time to see everything while you are here. Listen to the stories told by the workers, read about each president, walk the presidents trail and truely enjoy this place. The cost to ge in is minimal. ($11 for parking and you are in) I have been here a couple times with my kids as they have grown up and we have all truely enjoyed it.

I have always wanted to see Mount Rushmore and it didn't disappoint. Pay the $5 to get the audio tour. It is full of historical information and details about the sculpting of the monument. It is certainly was an amazing feat. Take the few minutes to view a movie narrated by Tom Brokaw that runs every 15 minutes. Be sure to walk the Presidents Trail for a multiple view of the monuments. It's an easy 20 minute walk.

Mt. Rushmore is a special place! Be sure to use the audio tour that is available. It is $5 per person and well worth it. If you are able to walk up and down numerous steps, take the full circle that gets you closer for even better views. Parking was $11, but the park is free. It can get real crowded in the mid morning and appeared to be less so in the early afternoon. Allow 3-4 hours for your time there. Be sure to see the 14 minute movie that details the history of the project. Great outing for the entire family!

We took the six-hour boat trip through the park from Seward. The weather was sunny in Seward but turned overcast and intermittently rainy as soon as we left port. We moved from the outside top deck to a table on the inside lower deck as the inside top deck was full. In six hours we saw marine animals for a total of about half an hour and spent about half an hour at a glacier. The "wraps" served for lunch did not taste very good and were not filling. Bring your own lunch if you go. I slept during the two-hour return to port. To avoid too long a day, we spent the nights before and after the boat trip in expensive Seward. The total expense was not worthwhile. The Portage Lake glacier boat trip near Girdwood was a much better glacier experience. It was much less expensive and only an hour from Anchorage.

Snorkeling was amazing. The views were incredible. Our second time there and it still takes my breath away. The boat ride is kind of long but the boat itself was brand new, the staff was awesome, and overall I would rate it as my Top 3 things to do while in Key West.

Nice boat, great trip but not worth in excess of 150.00 they demand. If the seas are rough and it bothers you, too bad, you are screwed. Food and beverage is average buffett fare worth about 1.69 a person. Do something else with your vaction money.

The scenery in this Park is really amazing. Grottos and other features really make it unique from some other parks around Utah. We also took advantage of a trail ride with Ruby's Inn folks through the red cliffs. It was a great trail ride and well worth the price. As far as the Canyon goes all of the overlooks are great places to stop and see the views. I would recommend spending a day a hiking around to see all this place has to offer. We stayed in tropic which was only a 20 minute ride away. This should be a must see park while traveling through Utah.

If you are planning a visit to Hawaii, and are interested in some adventure beyond beaches and snorkeling, and want to see a wonder, then Hawaii volcanoes national park is a MUST. It can be seen in half a day, one day or several days depending on how much time you have. We did two half days as we did not have enough time to do a hike the first time we went. It is closer from Hilo than from Kona, so would suggest spending a day in Hilo and going to the park from there. If you want to do both sides, Kona as well as Hilo, you could fly into one airport and leave from the other. You can finish up Volcanoes national park while in Hilo and then proceed to Kona visa Mauna Kea/Mauna Loa so that you get to cover that as well. The best way to see the sights at the national park is to make your first stop at the visitor center - depending on the amount of time you have, they will explain in detail what you can see, when, and how to get there. the Kilauea crater should be seen both in day light and in the evening to really see the effect - especially if you are going at a time when lava flow is not great, this can give the desired effect of seeing a volcano. The Thurston lava tube is a short walk, but beautiful as it takes you through lush green rain forests and imagine walking through the tube, where once lava used to flow! The other place worth visiting is where the lava flow has blocked off the road, this was the impact of a more recent lava flow in 2002 or 2003. The road is buried underneath lava rocks and you can walk and hop over black lava rocks, alongside the beautiful blue ocean; the arch along the ocean formed by lava is also here. If you have 2 to 3 hours, a must do hike is the Kilauea Iki, it is not too difficult, there is some amount of up hill and downhill, but if you are a moderate hiker you can do it. The best thing about the hike is that it takes you through a volcanic crater, this volcano last erupted in 1959, there are still steam vents around and you can smell sulphur and how cool is it to walk across a volcanic crater! There is supposed to be another hike along the crater of the active volcano which is about 11 miles or so, since we did not have more than 2 to 3 hours we did not do that one. If you want to see the lava flowing into the ocean, that happens near a private property, so there is no access from the national park, you have to take one of those expensive private hiking tours. We also did the helicopter tour, I would say it was average as the volcanic activity was not very high, the tour on top of the volcanic region was definitely very good, but we took one that goes over water falls as well, I would rather skip that and pay less. The chopper ride seemed quite over priced for what you actually get to see, so if you really want to do it, take the minimum one - the one that goes just over the volcanic crater. There is also a boat ride that takes you close to the lava flow into ocean, they have a facebook page wherer they post pictures on a daily basis so that you know what to expect, but the boat ride itself is supposed to be very choppy. I have severe motion sickness, so we dint want to venture and regret, but if you can manage choppy boat ride (the waves literally throw the boat up and down), you will get totally drenched (so you can imagine how rocky the ride must be), and take medication before the ride, may be you can try it, the view is supposed to be out of the world.

This cave was magnificent! We choose the cheapest tour which was $4 but I wish we would have chosen a longer guided tour because I would have loved to see more of this cave. I would say you probably wouldn't want to bring children under 3 because there are a lot of stairs. And if you have to carry them getting down to the cave it would be difficult. Be sure to make your reservation before you come, the $4 tour didn't need one, but I noticed the others were booked up quickly. And bring a jacket it is cool down there. What else can I say about mother nature it speaks for it self. I will be back. OH they don't make you pay for parking either! I was shocked because most state parks do.

WE had never travelled up here; we usually pass through Cedar City on our way to Colorado. This was a beautiful area, with stunning red rocks and canyons and meadows and wildflowers. I would love to see this area in the fall when the leaves are changing.

Amazing! Budget cuts have hurt though. You have to get ticket time early to get into the Lincoln home. Our docent was great! She didn't rush us through and answered all of our questions. There are 2 houses you can also go in to see models and renovation of these old homes. Docents also had games for kids while we waited. We also took a Ghost Tour the night before which was excellent. More than one Ghost tour available, ours was suitable for children.

The park was great. There was a small fee to enter but that pass is good for a year. I won't be using it again but the $11 was worth it. We went to the movie before we walked around to the viewing points and it was nice to get a little background of how they built the monument. We did go back later in the evening for the light show which was inspiring. The July 4th holiday is a couple days away there were quite a few veterans around and the acknowledgment that was given to them by all of the people was amazing.

We went by Mt Rushmore on the way to Yellowstone and it is really neat to see it in person. Parking is $11. No other fees. We had to go because we were going right by there, but I won't feel a need to go back. Being there gives you a sense of being American with all the flags and celebration of presidents. We took a few photos and stayed about an hour. Did not really have time for much more, so I can't comment on the hike or audio tour. Gift shop is big and loaded with stuff.

I know people complain about the $11 to park, but guess what? Unless you have an annual pass or a senior pass, you are going to pay to enter any national park. We spent about 2 hours at the park, taking photos of the faces, walking around the trail, exploring the sculptor's studio and going to the gift shop. I'm happy to spend the money to keep the upkeep of the park. If you don't want to spend the money, you can see the faces from Rt. 244, but I think it's totally worth going into the park. You can use the pass for up to 1 year, so if you decide to go back a few times during your stay, as long as your have your pass, you don't have to pay again. Something to keep in mind. Worth the money.

We took the 4 hour tour to the homestead near the park.It is well worth it and only$10/ person.It is a trip for the whole family so the kids can see the one room school house and sit in the desk and imagine what life was like there on the mountain.

We visited here because hubby had been to Grand Canyon two or three times and wanted to see this. The admission is $25 and there is a free, hop on/hop off shuttle that runs all day inside the park. Well worth it. There are three or four main stops within the canyon that you can be let off or on at and spend as much time as you like. The buses run every 10 minutes to pick up and drop off. There is a Visitor's Center with an orientation film which tells the discovery of this region by a Mormon preacher and his wife - the Bryces. They were sent by the church to travel and educate the people in that region and built a very small cabin with the canyon as their "backyard." They moved to other places with their message and the canyon grew in popularity over the years. I have not seen the Grand Canyon myself but I don't think that I am missing anything after seeing this. And, there is a large, casual restaurant right outside the park called Ruby's (separate review.)

We traveled to Mammoth cave knowing a little about it, but I was overall impressed with the tours. First off, we have 5 and 6 year old children. The 5 year old did not have to pay to do either of the tours. Nothing was too difficult for our children to do.

Visited with my wife and Son, and we watched the movie and then took the path that leads closer to the monument and also goes to the sculptors cabin. What a great experience and a great place to go on the 4th of July. It was pretty crowded, but still worth the visit. The $11 parking fee wasn't too bad, and it's good for a year, so we are planning on coming back one more time before we go home.

We took the Yankee Freedom ferry to this unique, fascinating & gorgeous destination. It combines a 5 hour plus boat excursion, a top-notch guided tour of historic Fort Jefferson, & uncrowded, pristine beaches with fine snorkeling. The generous buffet breakfast & lunch served were very basic fare that was fresh & tasty with plenty of healthy choices. Really fine bagels in the morning, but lunch dessert cookies should be upgraded. Appreciated the snorkel gear & fresh water showers furnished. The ferry crew was completely professional but also extremely congenial, well-informed about the voyage & all aspects of the destination, & willing to share their knowledge. We rode outside going which meant eating without a table; coming back those sitting there got lots of hot sun & a brief rainstorm. We ate lunch inside the air-conditioned main cabin. On the return voyage, we opted for the smaller upper indoor cabin where a group of 10 started drinking as soon as the bar there opened & until it closed. They were not obscene or inappropriate but VERY loud & frequently moving. The gals were actually rowdier than the guys. We eventually fell asleep for a while, so It didn't bother us enough to move downstairs. At that time it would have been a challenge to find a place together. . The crew had stressed that passengers should not take up extra seats; I'm sure they would have found us seating if requested. Best advice is to board early. We have no regrets about the cost. It is a rare national park unlike others. The value is good for a full day of safe, worthwhile experiences on the sea with meals compared to many commercial tourist activities. And seniors who are active but have back issues do better on boats like this! It was as cheap for us to take a taxi from our B & B as to use the all-day parking lot. The terminal itself is quite nice, & everyone from the check-in person on acted happy to have us on the trip.

We travelled to Bowling Green this summer and decided to make a stop at Mammoth Cave National Park. I was unaccustomed to a national park being so tour oriented, but that's practically the only way to see this park. The focus is a cave system that has a network of over 400 miles of caverns below ground. There are none that you can see without taking a scheduled tour. Topside, the visitor's center has a really nice museum to pass time while you wait or even if you opt out of a tour, which we did. If you don't go on a tour, the park offers extremely little to see and experience. There is a nature trail that offers a few nice overlooks and we were able to come face to face with a few deer and wild turkeys. If you do plan to see the caves, allow yourself 4 hours in the park and get there before 2 pm.
