Totally different experience from more familiar deciduous forests, or from conifer forests at lower elevations. We were there during the Wolf Creek Pass fires, and the results of previous fires made very clear the effects on whole communities, not just the forest itself.
This is a must see if you are visiting America. It was very crowded when we went The parking price of $11 was reasonable. Also their was a sale of t shirts for $5 which was nice.

This was truly a destination stop for us! It is awe inspiring to see this cliff carved with dynamite! What if the charge was wrong and Lincoln didn't have a nose? Don't miss the night-time show either! And make sure you drive Iron Mountain Road! The tunnel views of Mt. Rushmore are very cool!

Booked Yankee Freedom Ferry on line, very easy. Leaves from ferry terminal in Key West at 0730, check in at 0700. The ride out/ back is pleasant as they have several films on flat screen playing information about reefs, the fort and history about area. Breakfast and lunch included in price, was good, fresh and multiple variety for all tastes.

Interesting cave. The tour guide can make a difference and our guide was not the best, being loud and bossy. Also, if you have a National Parks pass (in our case, a senior pass), make sure you carry your ID to gain discounts...My husband had his; mine was in the car and I had to return to retrieve it.

This was amazing to see! Miles and miles of white sand. The visitors center will sell you sleds and then buy them back at a discount but it is so worth it ! Pack a lunch make a day of it ! There are shade shelters and barbecue areas and you can sled to your heart's content. We took the sunset tour with the ranger to learn about the dunes and the wild life and found it very informative and enjoyable. Definitely worth the stop for $3.00 per person.

This memorial could be underwhelming for some. You stop, you look, you leave. We were worried this would be the memory our kids had so we paid the $15 for the audio tour. It gave us 4 listening devices. We took our time and enjoyed the tour. The parking is $11 and is a garage structure. if you have a topper on your car, they will make you park on the roof and you get no shade, something to consider if you have pets. They won't let you bring your pets into the park.

I had been very much looking forward to seeing Mt Rushmore, but when the time finally came, I was quite disappointed and unimpressed. The carvings are much smaller that advertising would lead you to believe. Plus, despite the fact that this is a National Monument and if you have a parks pass, you get in free, they charge $11 for parking. For me, it just wasn't worth it. I was happy just to do a drive by.

When Mr. Borglum sculpted Mount Rushmore, he wanted it to be free for all to enjoy. Unfortunately, based on greed, not need, the current concessionaire, Xanterra, owned by Denver Billionaire Philip Anshutz, convinced NPS (National Park Service) he needed to build a parking garage and charge everyone to see Rushmore. A parking garage is not necessary in the Black Hills. There's plenty of open space. Xanterra employs many foreign nationals and is constantly fined by the United States Department of Labor for failing to pay them minimum wage. That is a travesty. Having said that, it is a beautiful National Monument to see. The food and drinks in their cafe are disgusting and terribly overpriced.

Even if you're not terribly patriotic, this HAS to be on your list of things to see and do! How they carved this monument in a mountain of granite is amazing! Make sure you take the time to go into the exhibits and museums and read about this. Totally PHENOMENAL!!!!! The sight itself is incredible and the drive in is one to be savored and enjoyed. It takes an effort to get there but more than worth it. For the $11 per carload entry fee, you can spend literally hours enjoying the spectacle. You should budget at least two hours to walk the 1/2 mile Presidential Trail and stop in the museums and exhibits. You can easily spend more but make sure you enjoy your time there. It is truly a wonder.

This is one of those savor the moment kinds of trips. For a $10 per carload entry fee, you can spend literally the entire day exploring and viewing spectacular scenery and wildlife. The main drive is a 36 mile loop that should take a minimum of two hours if you just drive it. More if you enjoy some of the relatively easy hiking trails that gets you off the main road. Regardless of how much time you actually spend, you're going to see some wonderful sights. It's going to be relatively slow going because there's tons of cars taking their time so it's best not to be in a hurry. It's not crowded in the Yellowstone crowded and there are plenty of turn-outs so it's extremely pleasant. You'll see tons of prairie dogs, hopefully a lot of buffalo (although we only saw two!), wild horses, and hopefully other critters. Even if you don't see a ton of animals, the scenery is worth the drive. If you have time, do the drive twice, especially if you can do it later in the afternoon. Just make sure you visit it - it is DEFINITELY worth it!!!

Excellent sea plane trip. Views of the quicksands, atolls and shipwrecks was amazing. Fort Jefferson and Garden Key are absolutely incredible. Well worth the time and expense. So glad we decided to fly versus the boat trip. Highly recommend it!

We walked the trail through the park into town and rode the bus back at the end of the day. The bus to and from town is free if you pay to park at the visitor's center. With very limited to virtually no parking in old town, parking at the visitor's center seemed the best way to go. It costs $10 per car. The hiking trail has a number of steps, but if you have no mobility problems it is a relaxing short walk to town. There is a little gurgling stream that runs along part of the trail and you pass by some of the old canals as you get near town. Along the way we saw bluebirds, cranes, deer, ducks and turtles sunning themselves. It made for a fun relaxing dayall around.

The memorial building has nice carved murals on the outside, small gift shop inside. Historical artifacts are lacking, but what they have is interesting. Trails are well manicured. Pioneer cemetery marks resting place of Abe's mother and other settlers from the area. Bronze casting of the original cabin gives a nice feel for the historical significance of the spot. The park employee in period clothing at the recreated cabin was a wealth of information on the area of the time and the Lincoln family. Family pass was only $5. A definite must see if in the area.

We were there with our three kids ages 14, 12 and seeing Mt Rushmore in person was so much more spectacular than in pictures! We highly recommend the lighting ceremony - was awesome! We really enjoyed the audio tour and Presidential trail. Not sure anyone would complain about the parking fee - admission to the park is free - and parking fee covers at least a week of return visits. (we went twice!) Will make you proud to be an American!

Our family of 5 (kds ages 13, 16 and 22) did a tour of the Kings Canyon and Sequoia National Park area in June of 2013. We were coming from Yosemite (via Fresno) so entering at Kings Canyon and then going over to Sequoia was a good plan. We spent a day in Kings Canyon and then a day in Sequoia National Park and that was enough time to see the major attractions. The Giant Sequoai's are the main attractions at both parks and these groves alone are worth the trip as these trees are truly majestic and immense in size (the largest by volume in the world). The drive into and out of Kings Canyon is also a great drive with a lot of scenic overlooks and then the road follows the canyon floor and the river towards the end. There are several great hikes to do in both parks. The meadow trail in Kings Canyon is very nice as the views are excellent and the birds and wildlife on the loop trail are diverse. There are seveal longer hikes that looked good in the canyon but we ran out of time. The Grant's grove in Kings Canyon is home to the General Grant tree which is very impressive as is the dead tree in the Grant Grove that has been there for hundredes of years as the trees decay at an extremely slow rate due to their high tannin levels that ward off insects and degradation. I would allow for a full day in the Canyon staying at the lodge in the back of the canyon and then drive over to Sequoia the next morning and stay overnight in the Three Rivers area the next day. In Sequoia there are several groves of giant trees including the General Sherman (the largest tree in the world by volume). The walking trails are farily flat and some are paved in this area so there are hikes for every level of hiker. The Giant Tree Museum is very intersting and I recommend stopping for 30-45 mins to read all about the giant trees and learn a lot of neat facts about them. We also did the Meadow trail and saw the house built out of a fallen redwood at the end of the meadow trail which was amazing it has lasted so long and that someone lived it in every summer for multiple years. We also saw our only Black Bear on our trip to CA that included Yosemite and the Kings Canyon/Sequoia area so the family was happy they got to see a bear. The two days in the two parks was the right amount of time and then we flew out of Bakersfield on United which gave us a shorter drive then driving back to San Fran (where we flew in) and I was able to get better prices then flights out of Fresno which is the closest airport to the parks. FYI-the entrance fee to Kings Canyon and Sequoia are combined so once you pay the entry fee for the week it is good for both parks.

We took the seaplane after not taking it the last time we were there, deciding it was a once in a lifetime kind of a thing, and we were not disappointed! The fort is interesting, the snorkeling great; but the best part was e seaplane there and back! Would recommend it as a must do - well worth the price!!!

This park has a nice entrance from the National Forest. The Forest is prettier than the National Park. Although the hoodoos are interesting to see, it isn't much different from what you will see at Canyonlands or Arches on a grander scale. This is a small park and easy to see within a few hours. I was not really that impressed as with the other National Parks in the state. If you have kids who are doing the Jr. Ranger program, you have to go to a Ranger led activity. Avoid any after 11 AM. It is hot and there is no cover. They have a bus shuttle service for free with the price of admission to the park. I recommend paying a bit more for your car and driving through unless you are staying in the park.

We did the Historic Tour at Mammoth Cave. It's 2 hours, considered "moderate". Current price was $12. You can pay and reserve online. Many tours sell out so see the website for availability. They will email a confirmation number. The tour was a challenge for me, I'm 6 ft 2, just under 300 lbs, with bad knees. Take the precautions seriously. There is a "fat man's misery" section that was difficult, plus lots of sections where a man of my height had to stoop. Narrow, damp footing (wear sensible shoes). The Rangers gave a good tour explaining the history of the cave. ~Two miles of walking, and about 500 steps to climb. One stretch was over a long drop off. Not for those who fear heights or are claustrophobic. But very much worth it, to see that the Dave's is appropriate, "Mammoth."

We showed up to find out that there are limited spots available each day and if you weren't in line by 7:00 a.m. you would not get a ticket for the day. Very disappointing since we drove over an hour to get to the cave.

This little gem was an unexpected pleasure. We arrived at the park and were able to immediately board the ferry over to Fort Matanzas. When we got there, we were able to see them fire the cannon which apparently doesn't happen often. The staff that was there was knowledgeable and fun to talk to. The Fort is very small but worth the visit! It didn't cost anything at all and my 3 year old had a blast.

Very enjoyable tour of the Lincoln home and the block of historic houses that surround it. It is free but you must have a ticket. We arrived too late on Sat. to see it but went to the visitor center 8:30 Sun. morning to reserve tickets for later in the day which worked very well for us.

Visited on July 5th - was crowded as expected but the place is organized to handle crowds so we never felt uncomfortable. Parking was ok. $11 parking fee is super reasonable for something this significant.

I was in the black hills for a few days in June 2013 so we decided to go see Mount Rushmore. It was awesome to see and we got some great photos, but it's not something I need to do more than once. If I'm in the area some other time I might check it out again, but I'm definitely not going there specifically for that. There is not a fee to see the site, but you will have to pay for parking, unless you have friends that live near there that have an annual family parking pass.

Get there early in the day. The line to get in is shorter and it is not that hot yet. We went on July4th (day) and it was not packed but it was crowded. The parking pass is good for a year, I think. So go one time during the day and on a different night for the lighting. Even in the rain (at night) the lighting was very cool and informational. Take the time and walk the trail and see the museum. Bring your camera and refillable water bottle. Park in Garage number 5 it is less crowded and is closer to the entrance.

We visited Mount Rushmore on July 5. We planned on going on the 4th but the lines of cars were wrapped down the street and we figured it would be way too crowded. We didn't spend much time there, maybe an hour. I assumed it would take a lot longer than it did. After driving past it several times during our trip, I almost felt like I didn't need to actually go in and see it but it was pretty neat seeing it up close. The gift shop had some really nice items and when we were there, there were two drillers signing books. I also appreciated that they sold $5 t shirts, hats, bags and cups outside the gift shop under a big tent.
3 hour boat ride to and from, but the 4 hours at the island are extremely wonderful and worth the $170 per person ... a wonderful day trip.

Very interesting national park as in includes battlefields as well as the town of Harper's Ferry. The park welcome center is 2.5 miles from the town. Park there and ride the shuttle buses! The buses also stop at a battlefield above the town. Park entrance fees are less than many others, if you're 62 GET AN AMERICA THE BEAUTIFUL PARK PASS!!! Bus rides are included in the entrance fee, as are ranger talks both in town and at the battlefield. Was there on the July 5 and the busses were overloaded (rangers blamed the sequester for lack of staff and more buses), but folks were patient. The town has Civil War era restored interior buildings as well as modern day eateries, souvenir shops, a great bookstore with DVD and CDs as well. There is unattended river access, so be careful with your kids. You can watch the tubers, rafters, and kayakers go by. Those tours are purchased outside the park. Well worth the visit, probably much better not close to a holiday. The town is on the side of rock slab mountains, so be prepared to hike up and down hill. Some pats of street and sidewalks are cobblestone...bumpy for strollers or wheel chairs. The buses did not appear to be wheelchair accessible. There is VERY limited parking in town.

Every part of this National Park is awesome. It's well worth the drive all around the west and east rim - a little over 60 miles. There are so many spots to pull off and taken in the amazing views. 1943 ft deep and over 6 miles across, this place is awesome. Plan for a little extra time if it's a holiday weekend as it will end up taking a little while to get into the park. If you have a park pass, don't bother sitting in the car waiting to get to the entrance gate -- just drive right up to the window on the other side of all the waiting cars and flash your pass. I also took a hike partway up Mt. Scott. Lovely views and a well managed trail. This is the highest point of the park at over 8900 feet.

We're hiking the top 20 National Park hikes, and this one was in Grand Teton. Take the Jenney Lake ferry from the east to west side. It's $12 per person, but saves 2 miles of hiking around the lake (free for military!). Hike .7 miles to the waterfall, and then another .3 miles to Inspiration Point. Many people turn around here, but don't! It's another 6 miles up Cascade Canyon to Lake Solitude, but well worth the moderate hike. We saw bear, moose, marmots, etc. along the way, all the while enjoying countless waterfalls and rushing water from the melting glaciers.

We went on a tour of the mammoth cave and really enjoyed it. The rangers are excellent tour guides. It is well worth the price of the tour. They offer many different tours during the day and reservations are a good idea. Some tours are offered infrequently and fill up days ahead of time. Look at their online web site to choose your tour and make the reservation. They explain how many steps and involved in each tour. If you are not that physically fit, pick the tour that has about 15 steps. Even those steps are optional. The regular tour has many more steps. One tour is a first step in learning to explore caves. Those people crawl through small areas with jump suites and head lamps. There is a tour for every skill level.

If you plan on doing some sledding go to Big K in Alamogordo and buy a colored sledding disc for about 10$.At the park they charge 15$ a piece and if in good condition they can buy it back from ya for 5$.But do buy the wax from the parks gift shop.It WORKS!!.I applied it to ours each time after each time going down the sand hills.DO WEAR SUNGLASSES!!!~The white sand is very bright!!!~TAKE PLENTY WATER AND SUNBLOCK!!!!~The bathrooms as mentioned.GROSS!~We drove about 8-9 miles back toward the back and we looked for the tallest hills as possiable~We got us some SPEED going down it!!~The place is AWESOME views of the mountains in the back drop and sand hills for miles to see.

Always wanted to see this iconic memorial. While there were many visitors, it did not feel crowded. A cut above many National Memorials and inspiring. One note of caution, the evening program was stirring and patriotic but a little long... particularly for the folks with kids who were expecting a "light show." No lasers, no strobes, not fireworks, just simply lighting of the sculptures as the flag is lowered. Rain or Shine, (it rained), so be prepared with raincoats or umbrellas held low to not block the view of others behind you. We timed our arrival at Mt. Rushmore for the 9pm ceremony and used the same admission ticket, (good for multiple days), to get back into the Park in the morning for the full visit of the Memorial and then driving to the Needles Highway in the afternoon.

Mt. Rushmore is amazing! You pay a 10 entrance fee, park the car, then walk up to the monument. I recommend watching the movie. It's amazing how they used dynamite to build it. A must see in a beautiful part of our country
The park is very nice, but it did feel like a rip to pay twice the price to park that a car full of people paid.

$10 to get in. Was amazing! We called it the road to heaven. We did a light hike with the park ranger, Honey Girl. She was amazing. We learned a lot about the birds and plants. Call and ask about times. The last one was 2pm on the day we went. Hiked around and saw the sunset at the peak. Absolutely gorgeous! Bring a jacket, pants, and a blanket! But totally worth it! The drive is SCARY! so bring someone who is comfortable with driving.

Cant say enough about this trip. Everyone need to experience this amazing combination of history and nature. Boat trip can be rough, so bring your Dramamine, although the staff is great and provides for $1 if you need.

We drove from the Ashland hills Hotel to Crater Lake, it took about 2 hours,because of the variety of traffic lights and a Route 22 or Route 17, N,J. type traffic. The roads start of with 4 lanes and wind up with 2 lanes,and then become like the roads in Acadia National Park in, Maine. When you get close to crater lake you drive through a road that is bordered by very tall trees. The ride is tedious and you wonder what happened to a nice 4 lane highway, but the trip is well worth it. A gorgeous ride up to the park gets you to the toll both. If you don't have a Senior Pass it will cost you some dollars per car load. After the Ranger gives you a map and brochure you drive up a winding road and then search for a place to park your car. You walk over to the rim and the view is SPECTACULAR!! The is a beautiful dark blue that is rich and deep. Since this is a lake that formed after a volcano erupted eons ago, you find out that it is the deepest lake in America. The view is spectacular and there is a Trolly that will take you around the rim. If you are adventurous you can travel to the bottom and take the boat ride that is offered around the lake. If you are in the area take some time to visit this natural wonder.

Part of the Natchez National Parks. Toured Melrose and the plantation buildings. Very informative! Main house is enduring some rehabilitation work slated to be finished in September of 2013 according to Rangers. Slave quarters contained a slavery exhibit that was very worthwhile. Melrose guided tour is $10 for adults. Grounds are free.

We enjoyed our visit to Jewel cave overall. They are not taking reservations this year so make sure you arrive early to get tickets. They have been selling out for the day before noon. They were supposed to be doing road construction and work on the parking lot, but thankfully they are not. We took the scenic tour which is nice but beware; there are 736 steps on this tour, and they run you through FAST. There is hardly any time to actually LOOK at the cave, because they run you through it at a high rate of speed. It's also wet, and the handrails they want you to hold on to are wet, which to me makes for dangerous walking conditions. The ranger got rude with us when we lagged behind the front part of the group, but honestly I wanted to look at the cave AND was trying to be careful because it was wet. Overall it was interesting, but I don't need to see it again.

I wanted to take a sight seeing cruise in St Augustine but couldn't swing $17 for all 9 our our group. So...we combined a fun free ferry "cruise" (5 min.) with a fun historical field trip while on vacation. We had a great time. There is an informational video before or after the short ferry ride over to rattlesnake island. The park rangers are friendly and informative even pointing out dolphins swimming by and green sea turtles poking their heads above water neat the fort. This was really fun on our vacation without breaking the bank. Even our older teens and young twenties kids had a great time! Thanks so much!

Another must see if you are anywhere near the area. It comes out of nowhere, and the white sands are mesmerizing. Sledding is popular, but just driving throuhg the park is worth the entrance fee. It's further than the White Sands Missle Range, so don't use that as a map destination.

I haven't been here since I was 4 years old. It has changed so much in +30 years! Despite the holiday weekend the crowd wasn't horrible. Museum is nice and taking the foot path is great. Your entry fee is actually an annual pass to the park.

We visited the south unit, the north unit and the painted canyon in our two-day visit to the area. The charge was $10 per car and I would have paid $100 to see the south unit. We saw beautiful scenery and so many animals I lost count. At one point we were about 6 feet away from a bison. Of course, we were in our car. There were numerous wild horses as well. What a national treasure and so much less crowded than Yellowstone.
This place is so unique, it's worth a stop. Catch a free ranger talk and tour if timing is right. Skip the sledding - it was difficult to slide down the dunes, not worth the $$.

Cross country trip NYC to Seattle with kids, had to go to Mount Rushmore. it really is a must-see National treasure. Get the $5 audio tour. Bring a good camera. if you're American or American-friendly you'll enjoy. Great history for kids. The surrounding area is beautiful and cheesy, but no lack of things to do for whole touristy family. I've been three times, and though we didn't have the time to stay for the light show this time... plan your day around being there for the nighttime show.

It's one of those things in life that if you've never done it then do it! Put it on yor bucket list and make plans to do it. Enjoy the 6 hour drive from Denver but I got to bond with my husband. I've never seen so many cows and farm lands! It was worth ever minute of it! To see how awesome the monuments were made is incredible. The people way up there were very nice and kind. It's worth the trip. The attraction is free but you pay for parking.

After reading all the reviews I wasn't super excited about seeing Mount Rushmore, but I'm glad we went. It is cool to see the carved faces of some of our greatest presidents, it gives you that patriotic feeling. And it is amazing that something that massive could have been carved. You can see the monument from the road and that might be enough for some people. I'm glad we paid the parking fee (however I wish it could have been covered with our America the Beautiful pass). The walk way with all the state flags s a nice touch and l gives presidents a nice frame. To be honest to look at the monument doesn't take that long, and we took the walkway around the base just because we felt like we should spend more time after paying for parking. The walkway was nice, and gave us different perspectives of the monument. If you take the trail start out to the left (while looking at the monument head on) it is less steep than starting on the right. If I was in the area again, I would be content with looking at it from a roadway pullout. The drive through the forest to get to the monument was pretty.

On our visit to the Park, the Rangers were very informative of the crater, Park area, Maui history and Park wildlife. Be sure to take drinks and snacks/lunch on your visit. Additionally, be sure to keep your Park ticket so that you will be able to visit additional Maui National Parks without paying additional fees

Capitol Reef is a little out of the way but the drive there, especially if you are coming from the east (for example if you are coming from Arches or Moab) is as scenic as it gets. It was a little warm in July but we got thunderstorms in the afternoon that were a delight. We had a family football game in the rain; what a memory. We camped in the Fruita campground in the middle of an apricot orchard. Deer walked through our camp 2 or 3 times a day and twice we came across groups of Desert Bighorn Sheep. We had little ones with us so we took one of the shorter hikes called Cohab Canyon, and it was a kids dream playground. there were dozens of places to climb and explore. Be sure to visit The Gifford House. Not only is it a step back into pioneer times but they have fresh pies and scones every day. Most of the park is no fee. One drive costs about $5.

Since we were staying at West Yellowstone we thought it would be great to take a full day and travel the 42 mile loop in the Grande Tetons and as much else as we could fit into a day. It was about 3 and 1/2 hours to Jackson where we entered the park at Moose and traveled a rough road a few miles until we it turned to pavement. Stopped at the Visitors and then headed up the Grand Teton Park Road stopping at Jenny Lake, Signal Mtn,and Willow Flats. By this time it was clear the loop would have to wait for another day and we continued on to Colter Bay and then to the south entrance to Yellowstone. Nine hours well spent in a most beautiful National Park which is very different from Yellowstone. I would recommend others who plan a similar trip to stay over a night and break the trip up over two days. We stopped and took pictures at all of the turnouts, so that added to the time. Used our senior pass.

white sands is amazing place, the outside is not appealing. but when you drive between sand dunes, and walk on the sand. sand surfing must for kids. kids will have a lot of fun. you can buy used "sand plate" around $10 for them.do not need to buy new one$16.99. you can return it for $5. also get wax for sand plate. because the day before it was raining, sand is not smoothing.must see this place in the area. we have annual national park pass,we do pay entrance fee.

This was a great experience taking the ferry to the middle of the Gulf of Mexico. However, I definitely recommend taking dramamine a good 20 minutes before the ride. The sea was a bit choppy. The great thing was that they offered Dramamine on board for a $1 per dose. Snorkeling was fun, the staff was great. The tour of the fort was most interesting. The best part was seeing a homemade boat that 27 Cubans were in we they landed at the fort 3 years ago. It showed how desperate they really were.

When the unlimited hydroplane races at Madison, IN were cancelled, I was already miles from home with nothing to do. So I pulled out my trusty Rand McNally to see what was between my hotel in Lake City, TN and Madison - Mammoth Cave. Even though I'd been there before, it had been over 30 years ago, and I remembered little of my visit. So, I did something I rarely do - I went to an attraction for a second time. Glad I did - I got the last spot on the two hour guided tour of the New Entrance, and it was entertaining and educational. The National Park Service ranger was, as usual for this bunch, excellent, providing us with fun facts and figures throughout the tour. Hard to beat for $12. If you do go - make reservations! I went on the Fourth of July weekend and the place was packed! A ranger told me that they'll get 3 or 4,000 people through a day on holiday weekends.

My roommate and I stayed there last week for 2 nights. This is my new favorite Campground in the US. It has hot showers, which you don't have to pay for, flush toilets ,the sites have shade from the bristlecone pines, it is very clean, they also come with a fire ring and grill. It is quiet, and the trails are to die for. The flowers are spectacular, meadows covered with paintbrushes and all kinds of wild flowers.The sunset at Point Supreme is unbelievable. The sky is wonderful at night . Watch for afternoon rain, which is typical here. Make sure you have a good, closed up tent, that you can zip up entirely in case it rains.
Just awesome. Go to the evening lighting also. Price included if you go during the day. Everybody should see this first hand. Beautiful park.

This was my second time here and it still remains a must stop. There has been considerable development/improvement since 1985, all necessary to handle the huge number of visitors. The facilities are clean, the food acceptable and the grounds clean and safe. Don't miss the introduction film and do walk the trail up the mountain to get a closer look...there are many steps but it is best approached from the sculptors display center. Spend time looking at all of the historical artifacts and displays as there is much history here besides the rock work. Yes, parking is $11 but that is a small price to pay to see a most impressive work dedicated to our country's patriotic past.

Mt. Rushmore is something everyone should see. It's truly stunning in person. The presidential trail that leads up to it is worth the walk. If you go right after walking down the walkway where the state flags are presented you will have to walk a lot stairs to get close to the base but if you go left there is a large ramp that leads up to the same area. Either way it is worth the walk. There is a platform area where you can take photos and Mt Rushmore is right above you. Plan on 1-2 hrs. There is a small museum that is included in the admission (it's $11 to enter the monument per car). Not much else to do here, but it's worth the drive and a must see while in South Dakota.

Mt. Rushmore is almost a duty to go and see for any American. It is a beautiful testament to the American dream. If you can get there close to the evening ceremonies in order to see it during the day and when they light it up at night I would say that's the best. The evening ceremony is touching. Parking is $11 but that is good for a full year. Otherwise, the rest of the memorial is free.

Pay for parking; not covered by Access Pass. Attraction itself is free. Avenue of flags is pretty nice. Be sure to watch the short video. Entire facility is accessible. Encourage you to walk the trail to the mount from left to right, as it is less strenuous as the other way. Plan to spend a couple hours there, plus the lighting ceremony.

This is a free attraction, but $11 to park. It is well worth it. We watched the video, which was very informative about the building of the monument. We walked the Trail from left to right which appeared to be easier than the other way according to the people we passed. Check out the sculptor's museum. And of course they have a nice gift shop.

This National Historic Site, is an artists heaven! The farm is also part of the Nature Conservancy, and an art center. It is located in a "remote" part of south western Connecticut, driving through hills and winding treed backroads! It is indeed a jewel in the hills, with apple orchards, old farmhouses, rock walls, and secret gardens! The art center provides art materials, etc, for anyone who desires to paint! What a serene and inspiring peaceful place! It is a photographers dream! We will be coming back to this Weir Farm National park in the Fall for the foliage! Enjoyed our tour of the place immensely. A great family outing! Admission is free!

So much fun and educational! My kids are on summer vacation and still learning! The price was a very good value for the tours we took, they were 2 hours long and well worth it. The tour guides were great, they kept it very interesting and kept the kids involved in the discussions. My kids stayed interested thru the whole tour and will have memories to last a lifetime! We would definately go back and take other tours!

We did the Historic Tour ($12 each person) which took 2 hours, 2 miles of walking and climbing about 500 steps. Many tours sell out so see the website for availability. There is a fat man's misery section that was tight and narrow plus lots of sections where my husband who is 6' tall and he had to bend down. The Ranger was very informative and gave a good tour explaining the history of the cave and answered all questions asked. This attraction and tour is very much worth it!!! A must see!!!

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: We started the tour in Johnson City at the museum and the boyhood home. Museum is small, but pack a lot of information into its displays; the home is one block away and the tours start every half hour. Its a typical turn of the century furnished house, with some stories to go along. Next stop was the ranch 15 miles west of town, started the tour at the schoolhouse, then the birth home, then circled the ranch to the "hanger" which is a display and where you pay to tour the "Texas White House". The house is very 1960ish in its furnishings and decor (which doesn't seem all that old to me, but I'm in my 50's); still its interesting. historic, and very much worth seeing. It was a 100 degree day, so we didn't walk the grounds much, but it seem liked it would be a good thing to do on a spring or autumn day. All in all pretty good, but you leave wishing there was a little more to do or see after driving all the way out there. The staff was nice and friendly even though you know they've seen and said it all before. I recommend it.

While not the scale of Gettysburg, this site was great for gaining an understanding of the Civil War. The audio CD was worth the cost and gave much information about the site and the battle that occurred there. Glad to have visited!

This was our first family cave tour ever so we weren't really sure what to expect. As usual the National Park Service has done a great job of taking care of the site and making everyone feel welcome. The only issue we ran into was that the ranger near the ticket booth said my wife and I could take in a couple small packs we had with us. But about 1 minute before our tour was to begin the ranger that gave us the tour said we had to take them back to our car which was not parked very close. So to be safe just leave all small packs and purses in your cars. The cave is fairly cold at about 49 degrees so be sure to take in a coat. If you have younger kids there is a junior ranger program that is not too hard. They do not take reservations anymore so if you are tight on time you will want to get there first thing in the morning. We got there at 8:15am and we were in the third tour group of the day (tours don't begin until 8:30am).

Visiting Mount Rushmore will cost you $11 (per vehicle) and allows you to see some great American history and inginuity. There is a half mile wooden trail that leads you to view the presidents. There is a gift shop and a small restaurant/ice cream shop as well for those who are looking for a bite to eat. The views are great even though you are not allowed to get real close to the monument. Lots of good photo ops.

Mount Rushmore was on the tail end of our Yellowstone adventure. We decided since we were "up there," we had to drive over to Mount Rushmore so the kids can see. When we arrived, there is a $11 parking fee. We headed up, saw the mountain, oohed and awwed, snapped some family pictures and went into the museum downstairs. We probably spent a total of one hour viewing the mountain and touring the museum and headed out. It was a quick stop, we were tired and just ready to head home the next day. Maybe if it was the beginning of the trip we would have gone back to see it lit up and there was a trail of some sort off to the right that you could hike. I'm not sure where it leads, but it would have been fun if we weren't at our wits end by that point. We're glad the kids experienced it, though!

I went here as a small child, about hmm..25 years ago? So when we were passing through the area en route to Yellowstone/Tetons, I wanted to stop here. I assumed it was free, but as we were driving along I-90, I was doing some research on my phone only to find that they now have a giant parking ramp in the area and you need to pay $11 to see this.

Great family attraction. If you can, do the hike path its very scenic and enjoyable. only $11 for a car load and the pass lasts the entire season. The cheapest thing we did while in the Black Hills and one of the most memorable.

It was a little out of our way and we were tempted to skip it, but so glad we went. The caves are in the gorgeous mammoth cave national park, which in itself is worth the visit. We went for an easy hike through the trails in the woods. We went on a busy Saturday. Most of the tours were sold out, and I was a bit nervous about going on a long tour anyway. We opted for the short discovery tour which is a self-guided tour, meaning that we were on our own to stay longer or leave quickly if we wanted to. I was brave and got over my initial fears and enjoyed walking through the cool, damp cave with my family. Plus, it was only about $4 each.
Beautiful views. Adequate accessability. Too many dead and dying trees in some areas. Very few fee areas.

I took my daughter to see the Lincoln House and we both loved it. It is a National Park right in town. There are 4 blocks that you can walk through that are a step back in time. There is the Lincoln House and 2 of the neighbors homes that we got to explore. The guides encouraged picture taking which is rare. She also said be sure to use the hand rail going up the steps, not only for safety but because it is the original handrail that President Lincoln used himself. Very cool. Many things in the home are actual pieces the family owned. A must see for any American. There is also a gift shop and information center. The tour is free. There is a $2 per hour fee to park but you can get through everything at this site in about an hour. I would definately go back again.

At long last we were able to get to Mount Rushmore on holiday this year. As an international icon, we had wondered whether it would live up to its reputation. It certainly does! As a concept, it is inspirational and it just has to be seen in place. The sculptor's studio was particularly interesting, and the distant views around the area and from the Cody state Park were memorable. The car parking charges are a minor gripe - they seem quite high especially for National Park pass holders - but it has to be said that the arrangements are first rate. Definitely an experience not to be missed, with the bonus of being in a beautiful part of the USA.

We took the New Entrance Tour with kids ages 5-13 and all really enjoyed it. It is amazing to see. The only drawback is there were a lot of people in the tour, so it took awhile to keep the line moving, and we were rushed through some of it. But that's the price you pay for a popular site.
long scenic drive..lots of deer don't text and drive..duck creek rentals for ATV'S not cheap bring cash!!

Our grandson loves historical things and learning about past history, he found this to be exciting and loved to read the markers and hearing the story of how the town was flooded out and rebuilt. I loved it this time as much as the first time I went. I think the price has gone up and is a bit much now just to take a ride up for only a few minutes.

Another hit for the National Park Service. We have had some great experiences with everything we have participated in lately with the NPS. Lincoln's Springfield home is run by the NPS, and to tour the home is free. You need to get a timed ticket at the visitor's center to do a tour of the house, but it is all free. There are also other houses within the historic site, and it is interesting to walk around and view them. The visitor's center also has 2 short movies about lincoln, a nice gift shop, etc. Our tour guide through the Lincoln Home was very good, and answered everyone's questions. 2 thumbs up again!

Having already visited Crazy Horse (and being disappointed), I was really impressed with Mount Rushmore. Only $11 per car (compared to $10 per person at Crazy Horse), it was easy to park and a short walk to the Visitor Centre. It was very busy on the day we visited but did not feel overcrowded There are lots of people stopping to take photos but that is to be expected and there is plenty of room for everybody.

Rather than drive around the Rim Drive on your own,, venture forth and enjoy the Trolley. ($25/$22 seniors). You will see everything and learn about what you are seeing. The ride is two hours of nothing but enjoyment.

You needed a National Park pass (cost $10) and there was a $10 (I think) parking charge. Otherwise, entrance was free. I was happy that I brought binoculars--so we could all see the carvings close-up. It was awe-inspiring as you would expect. We returned the next night (used same parking pass--so it was free) to see a patriotic movie and the Presidents' faces lit. It was very worthwhile. And don't miss seeing the sculptor's original model in his studio--though it is a longish walk down (and then up) a lot of steps. A definite item for your bucket list.

This is one of the must-do things if you like to travel the U.S. We have been before and wanted to go back. There is a small parking fee and then a very nice restaurant and gift shop. The mountain view is fantastic. We went to the evening lighting of Mount Rushmore too and loved it.

What a scenic place this is, once you get in. The cost of entrance was pretty steep in my opinion, $15. It is good for 7 days, but that won't do us any good. It would be nice to simply see a cheaper day pass. Regardless once in, we started on the scenic overlooks on the south rim. The first few are of the open gorge which was cool. I'd recommend to keep going to the other overlooks because they do get better. My favorite was of the Painted Wall. It is basically a flat piece of the mountain that has all different patterns from molten seeping into the surface millions of years ago! I'd also recommend taking the curvy road down to the water. The drive down is steep, its 16% grade but we managed just fine in a small Kia. There is a visitor center with more information about the park and rangers there. Pretty cool place!

We are 2 adults, 2 kids, 10 and 11. We visited Grand Teton NP, Jackson Hole, WY and found a place for $100/nt at the Hostel in Teton Village, saved alot by staying there. We arranged to eat our breakfast at the hostel (an old ski lodge-from Olympic trials or? .. it seems), and ate dinner we prepared there. Saved alot of money, saw incredible animals, did alot of hiking, went to top of Jackson Hole Ski Resort (a little spendy but well worth it). the Hostel was pretty sparse, it had small bathrooms, the rooms were narrow, dark, with only one window, might be some dust in the corners, no desks or swimming pool here, but they were comfy. It had bunk beds, the floors creak --creaks alot, a large rec room in basement with a large frig for all to keep their groceries (all were labelled) and rec room included a toaster, a microwave, lots of tables and a tv, a ping pong table, and more games that i can imagine, a table just for checkers and chess. OK..it wasn't the Marriott, but neither were the prices. Alot of younger college age kids working at the place, my kids made friends with some at the front desk, and they liked their dog Cinch. I saw quite a few families, and older couples who look like they were in good shape and maybe retired but saving money while visiting the area, also saw plenty of Foreigners who know how to stay in hostels. Grand Teton NP is just up the road from the hostel, as well as Jackson Hole which has a cute historic downtown- our kids did a stagecoach ride, short and sweet for $4/each, and check out the Million Dollar Cowboy Bar, too. We did alot of hiking in Grand Teton, ate lots of PBnJ sandwiches, baby carrots, string cheese, beefsticks, and always brought our own water bottles. Loved this area!!

We chose to go to Mammoth Cave because we wanted something cool to do on a hot summer day. The park is beautiful, we saw wild turkey, deer, squirrels around the park. The scenery is gorgeous. The building where you buy your tickets is very clean, restrooms clean and well stocked, plenty of park rangers around that all were very friendly. Our guide for the cave tour we went on was very knowledgeable, and provided very interesting and pertinent information about the cave as we toured. The tours are reasonably priced, our tour was 5 $ for adults, 3$ for our son and last 1 1/4 hours. Don't forget to take a light jacket, the caves are 54 degrees, also take a flashlight so you can see more of it, the caves are just dimly lit. I would not recommend the cave tours for very young children or babies. The babies that toured with us cried to entire time and our tour guide had a hard time talking over them to narrate the tour. Overall a great time!

Worth the trip and the $11 parking fee (bring cash as the credit card reader wasn't working at our entrance booth -- we read ahead of time they only took cash but that turned out not to be true, officially anyway). I heard from many sources that it was much smaller than they expected, so I expected it to be small and it was, then, larger than I had imagined. I wasn't disappointed at all. The Presidential Trail is a must too. It gets you much closer to the monument and boulder field and affords you a number of less-cliched photo opportunities. We arrived a little before 7:30 on July 15th which gave us plenty of daylight to walk the Trail and be in our seats by 8:25 for the 9pm night-lighting program. If you want a decent seat, get there by 8:30. Like a movie theater, the prime seats are in the middle and upper areas. You probably don't want to be right at the front, and that's what was left by 8:45. The program featured a brief talk by a ranger (including reciting the Gettysburg address), a video about the four presidents, the lighting of the monument and the retiring of the flag with the help of all the active and retired military members in the audience (which was a really nice touch). We bypassed the visitor center but spent a little time in the gift shop and restaurants and both were perfectly fine and exactly what you would expect. This is an iconic stop and must-do if in the area.

After reading the descriptions of all the available tours I was disappointed to see that many of them involved 500+ steps so I had limited choice. Although I arrived early they were all booked until the afternoon so I was left with the Mammoth Passage option - what a waste of time! It only cost $5 but was a huge disappointment. The guide was lovely and she gave us a brief history and answered questions. Unfortunately there was virtually nothing to see apart from the remains of a saltpetre mine and 5 Indian artefacts.

This place is amazing. Recommend watching a documentary or two about it prior to visiting. Very easy for RVs to park and we were there on 4th of July! We ent to the lighting ceremony which was wonderful as well. All you have to pay for is parking.

I enjoyed the hike. All real pictures are amazing, and fun to see. I saw a snake, coyote, millipedes, and birds of all types. Note: There are like 3 - 4 sites a few miles apart. The parking pass is $1.00 M-F or $2.00 sat-sun, and is good for all parking locations. You don't have to keep paying.

From our base in Monticello it was a pleasant and not too long of a drive to reach the Natural Bridges. We were surprised that there were only three bridges, but each one is different and quite splendid to see up close. We parked at Owachomo bridge and hiked the canyon bottom trail to the next bridge, Kachina, We planned on hiking all the way to Sipapu Bridge, but it took longer than anticipated to reach Kachina so we hiked out of the canyon and took the trail back to our vehicle. We then drove back to Sipapu bridge and hiked down to it. Sipapu is probably the most impressive of the three bridges, but the entire park is scenic and well worth a visit. If one does go hiking, take plenty of water. Even though we were there in late May the weather was quite hot. Sitting under Kachina bridge in the shade was a pleasant spot for lunch. The park entry fee was only $6 per vehicle.

Stop and pay the $5 for the audio program. It gives so much more than the information posted along the way. You get American History, the history of the building of Mt Rushmore and short talks by people who helped build it. You spend hundreds or thousands of dollars to go there and you miss out on so much because you wanted to save $5.. Yes the parking is also $10 but that allows you to come back for the night lighting show either the same night or a different night. The Presidential Trail is fantastic but make sure you take water as it is over a mile with lots of steps. We spent almost four hours there to do the Trail, the Video and the Museum. Posted by grinandbrakeit.com

excellent - for years we have done what many others do during the rally and pull over at the side of the road and take a picture but this time we decided to pay the $8.00 and park in the lot and have a good look round . it is well worth it

No matter how ingrained the image of this site has become, it is still a thrill to encounter it first hand. The site is so clean and well-maintained, despite the throngs who pass through here. The display hall and informational films add to the experience. And the park rangers provide additional pertinent info, both in scheduled talks (go Tyler!), and at the information desk. But the spectacle of the sculpture itself is just awe-inspiring.

Ranger Rick was our guide for our tour, it was amazing from start to end, he knew those caves inside out, any question could be answered and he had some fascinating stories from the past. The caves are breath taking! It is cool inside of the caves, which was a welcomed break from the intense heat outside. The tours are very well organised from start to end which is perfect and to be able to say you ate lunch in a cave is pretty fun. In one part of the cave there is an opportunity to buy a lunch box, which includes a drink, sandwich, fruit and crisps and a very reasonable price. I will return again in the near future, it is a must do for any nature lover out there, the bus from the centre to the cave was beautiful also as you get to drive through some of the park, and we saw some native wildlife on our journey including deer! Make sure you get there at a good time as the tours sell out fast! Definitely worth the trip!

The NPS has a true set of treasures with the Adams National Historical Park consisting of three historic homes filled with tons of history and impressive art! Their guided tour lasts approximately 2 hours- touring through each of these houses, with a trolley shuttle between the sites. The NPS tour cost $5 and my son was free. The tour we took was fantastic!

We really enjoyed this cave, I have visited a cave before so I can compare it to others. The scenic tour and tour guide were very great, very good for the small fee you pay. Amazing what nature can do. My kids 8 and 6 loved it, it was difficult carrying our 2 year old, but not impossible to do.

A great place to see where our great country began. It's a lovely square of things to see. The parking really isn't cheap but it's worth spending the money to stay and see everything there is. Get your tickets online or get there early. We arrived at 10 AM and it was already packed. The park rangers give free tours so if you have time I suggest taking one to learn what they have to offer.

I've been going to Harpers Ferry several times a year for the past 10 years and never tire of it. It is a quick 60 to 90 minutes from Baltimore and Washington D.C. and a great place for a one day or weekend get-away. The views of the town and rivers as you drive in from Maryland are in themselves worth the trip. And yes, there really is something for everyone. Lots of hiking trails with georgeous scenery for both serious hikers and strolling types, kayaking and tubing on the Potomac and Susquehana rivers, The Appalachian trail, even a trestle coming out of a mountain side with trains coming through every 20 minutes. Of course the big attraction is the history, and being a National Park, other than the entrance fee, everything is free. Don't miss the historic negro Storer College, or Jefferson Rock, or talking to the historically outfitted re-enactors. There are lots of short programs to take part in within the various buildings. And don't forget to take a stroll through the historic town of Bolivar which is literally right next door.

I always think of "John Brown's Body" when I think of Harpers Ferry. But the town has a much longer and important past than that, as a port of trade on the Shenandoah and Potomac Rivers, and industrial center since the 1790s. You can fight for parking at the Lower Town or, recommended, head to the visitor center for orientation and info and a shuttle which drops you at the beginning of the town. The national park incorporates preserved buildings from mid-1800s, which are interspersed with park concessionaires and current non-park businesses. It's time-traveling into the middle of the town. Say you've been on the Appalachian Trail by accessing it via the old steps right here. The whole old town was a nice surprise. A good spot for young and youngish families. standard national park entrance fee, but great for us retired folks with Golden Eagles. Food available from concessionaires and private businesses - home made ice cream, sandwich shops.

Last time I visited Crater Lake was some 30 years ago, when we stayed in the lodge because the snow in June was too deep to tent camp. I remember the tiny room and bathroom down the hall - happy to say that the hotel has been completely remolded - removed some rooms and added in-room bathrooms. Not as quaint, but more worth the price.

We stopped here before going to Holiday World. This memorial is a good stop to get some Linciln history. Be sure and see the informative movie and exhibits in the memorial. The family price is only $5. Take the 1 mile hike to the working farm and pass by Lincoln's mothers grave. The first part of the hike is downhill but if you take the 12 stones path back, it doesn't seem so bad coming back uphill. The Park Rangers and farm workers are all very nice and informative.

This place is awesome! We brought our 7 and 10 yr. olds here, arrived at 10am and left at 4:30pm. It was a full day of caving. We felt like we had a really good idea of what the park had to offer, but could have stayed for days longer if we had the time. At US$10/car to get into the park, we felt guilty about how much fun we had! It is a steal!

I visited the North Unit of Roosevelt National Park with family and was blown away by its rugged beauty and wildlife. The park offers a 14 mile stretch of paved roadway that takes you through the park. There are also many walking trails throughout the park. Definitely stop at the entrance before going in and pick up a map. Entrance fee is only 10$ per vehicle. The park has about 3-4 scenic overlooks where you can park and walk out to get great pictures and view wildlife. We were able to see several bison, a buffalo crossing the road, mule deer, and big-horned sheep. We drove about four hours from Minot to see the park. Definitely worth the long drive!

This is a wonderful sight/site. The audio tour is very long but filled with information about the people and events surrounding the carving. Our brains couldn't handle all info. and so we skipped the last four chapters. Our 14 year old daughter was a little disappointed in the size - she thought it was going to be larger. The movie isn't necessary if doing the audio tour but a must see if not. For only $11 per car, you can not go wrong with this.

It's hard to believe it only costs $10 per carload to view the spectacular 36 mile scenic loop. Make sure to take your time - it took us about 3 hours to complete this journey. There's several places to pull over and view the gorgeous colors and topography of the rolling hills. Animals abound here - although we only saw two single buffalo, there's hundreds in the park. Wild horses were everywhere, as were prairie dogs. As is common with animals, timing is everything. If we would have had more time we would have done the loop again. Be sure to visit this gorgeous piece of Americana - you will be glad you did.

We went to Pinnacles for a two night weekend trip in mid-July. We came from the East entrance and stayed at the camp site. The camp sites cost $23 a night and you pay a $5/car fee (valid for 7 days). Make sure you reserve your tent sites online before you go!

While quite hot in June, there was always a place to find shade and cool off if need be. We enjoyed the Fairyland hike the most, but also the peek a boo loop (a bit more crowded), Grab your chair a bottle of wine and watch the sun go down at sunset point. We were the envy of many as we enjoyed the changing scenery. The little store by that area has remarkable micro brews for $1.50. The free transportation system worked well, but we took our car most of the time.

As we've learned on this vacation... the least costly things to do in Hawaii are absolutely the best experiences! Today was the BEST $10 we have spent! Rainforests, lava tunnels, steam vents, hiking down into the crater, exploring the formations and steaming cracks, and then hiking back up - an accomplishment but well worth the effort. It was an overcast day (our helicopter tour was cancelled) so we spent much more time in the VNP and enjoyed every second. I actually don't know how we would have made the trek back up if it wasn't for the overcast skies and the light mist in the air. It is not for elderly or those with a disability. Such an interesting adventure for any age and any member of the family. The rangers are top notch and so good at directing you to the exact right excursion for your skill set and interests.

We left our hotel near Kona at 3pm to head to the Volcano. It is a very long drive due to low speed limit and twisty roads. Looking at the map I would have thought it would only take an hour to get there! In reality it was a 7 hour round trip, including time spent at the park. It was only $10 to enter the park. We went to the volcano museum where there are great views of the steaming crater about a mile away. Our young children were fascinated with the displays in the museum. We stopped at the steam vents which the children enjoyed. The heat from the steam is quite amazing. We also walked through the lava tubes. We were completely along for this. I don't know if it is usually busy.

Great opportunity to visit the first national monument. Finding connecting caves causes this cave to cycle between the second and third longest cave ever discovered. We went on the most popular tour which was perfect for our entire family. They have various options depending on your desires to cave. Only down side is that tickets must be purchased in person at Jewel Cave. I called from Custer, SD and was told that there were 19 tickets remaining for the last tour, but I needed to head directly to Jewel Cave. They could not hold the tickets or take payment over the phone. We traveled from Custer to Jewel Cave to learn that there were only there remaining tickets when we arrived. We had a party of six and we all wanted to go....That was disappointing!!! The next morning we went there first thing and were able to get tickets no problem. Could be a problem for someone traveling farther that 20 minutes!! This is something that the NPS needs to address. Otherwise it was one of our highlights of a great family vacation!!

The busts were smaller than I expected, they have a large parking garage they charge $11 for, the walk to the base of the mountain if free, if you want a self guided audio it is more, but they were out of them at the time

It was neat getting to see Mount Rushmore up closer but almost wished we hadn't wasted the money because it poured on us and really didn't get to enjoy it. There was really no place to take shelter from the rain and hail that was coming down. Not sure I would pay to see it again when you can see it really good on Iron Mountain Road.

This is great to see in person. You can see all the pictures you want, but to see it yourself makes all the difference. You pay for parking (which was about $10 and there was lot of parking) and then you get in for free. The walk as you move toward the faces was amazing! There were flags flying of every state and on the pillars there was information about each state, telling when they became a state and in what order that happened. Inside, there was a film that you should see while you are there that lasted about 10-15 minutes. It showed the making of this monument.

As a National Park this has well-marked roads and nature trails to navigate. We went in July with 110 degree temperatures, starting at the southern Cottonwood Springs entrance. After paying the "entrance" fee of $15 per car, we made stops along the way, getting out of the car to observe rock formations, exhibits, signs, and plants more closely. The signage is very informative about varieties of plants, rocks and desert changes. Paved road lead to northwestern entrance/exit with many more places to explore in the northwest and temperatures decreasing slightly. Two gallons of water per person per day is the quantity suggested by the park when hiking and exploring. Also plan for gas fill-up prior to approaching on southern side as exits on HWY 10 and available gas stations are few and far between. The plant life and rock formations are unique to various parts of the park.

We took the Yankee Freedom out to Dry Tortugas and it was one of the highlights of our trip touring the Keys. It's a little pricey but worth every dollar. Breakfast and lunch were included in our tour and we had hours for good snorkling. We didn't spend too much time touring the fort but it is impressive. It's nice that only a limited number of people go there each day so that it's not crowded at all and it helps preserve the island.

I visit Gettysburg very often,and was therefore a little surprised by the entrance fee to the NMP. it was the last stop of our family road trip of 2013. The weather was in the high 90's and very humid. But we'll worth the stop

Bob Murphy (bob@sunnymeadows.net) is extremely knowledgeable and provided a terrific tour of both locations at a very reasonable price. Highly recommended. Jerry & Barbara Benvenuto, Lanoka Harbor, NJ

I routinely visit Gettysburg NMP and was initially surprised by the entry fee for the battlefield. It was the last stop on our family's 2013 10 day road trip through the South. It was approx 95 degrees and we were dying, but nothing compared to what the soldiers back then had to wear on hot days. The history is great and seeing Burnside bridge was cool. I suggest taking the self guided tour and walking the battlefield. It gives great perspective
Great piece of history! This is a National Park, so if you already have a park pass you'll be able to get in free along with 3 others in your party.

The fort that was built to guard the "back door" of St Augustine. It is interesting for a history buff, the fort, but, the fee is cheap, and they take you to the fort in a boat, which is pretty enjoyable. Drop you off to explore and return at your will. Makes for an enjoyable 2-3 hour relaxing excursion.
Really neat to see monument in person. Beautiful entrance lined with state flags; great viewing area, informative exhibits. However, parking is $11 and the site is crowded!!

We hiked down into the canyon, pausing to marvel at the views and the cliff dwellers homes. it was really lovely, but be prepared for a lot of steps, especially on the return (and it was very hot even at 10a.m. In July). Really fascinating, and so nice as few people were there to disturb the quiet nature of the place( a couple of loudish groups were not appreciated!) well worth a short detour outside of Flagstaff if on your way to or from other more well known canyons!It also is a bargain as costs just $5 if you don't have an annual pass.

As an undergraduate history major and big Lewis and Clark fan, I did not pass up the opportunity to explore Fort Clatsop while on the Oregon Coast. I was highly impressed with the museum, the staff, and the site itself, which is a very close replica of what the Corps of Discovery lived in during their winter on the Pacific Coast.

Make sure you stop by the store at the entrance and grab your discs for sliding down the sand dunes. We made the mistake of getting all the way to the middle of the dunes before we realized we needed discs. They are about $17 per disc and they will buy it back from you for $5. They are well worth the money for hours of fun. This attraction is well worth the drive. We drove in from camping in Cloudcroft. We took a bunch of teens from our church youth group. ages of sliders ranged from 11 to 46 and we all had fun. also a fee of $3/person is charged at entrance. They also have well shaded picnic tables.

The site is quite inspiring. There is a State Flag lined, walk in, entrance-way.....that leads to the most common photo spot. A museum, sculptures, ice cream, outdoor eating and cafeteria style cafe is all available. It will be busy! Parking cost is about $11, National Parks Access cards are not valid as there is no entrance fee, only a parking fee. Visit....it's a chance of a life time.

It's a place you want to see. The parking is $11 which is OK as it's no entry fee, and the parking is very close to the actually sight. The avenue of flags is fun, and the view from the terrasse is great. But the heads are so small - at least much smaller than I imagined after seeing "North by Northwest". Which really tells me I must not trust the movies. I enjoyed it,but the teenagers we brought along didn't get it at all.

My family had a great time doing the Historical tour. We reserved our tickets as suggested from the parks webpage in advance for 9:30 am but got to the park about an hour earlier then we expected so switched out tour to the 9Am tour. Their was a small fee of $3 per ticket but since we are on a long road trip we didn't mind spending the extra money to move our time. The gentleman who gave us our tour was incredible and had extensive knowledge of the caves and the history of the people who made the caves the magical place it is today. My family had an awesome time kids ages 8 and 12 loved the tour and I wish I had given this area of our road trip more time. I wouldn't do the Historical tour if you have a problem bending over or if you are over weight because there are some tight spots you have to squeeze through.

If you like history and hiking this is the place. Learn about the end of Lewis & Clark's voyage and their winter camp from 1805 into 1806. The video was a little corny but the indoor exhibit (maps, tools, canoe, etc.) were terrific and the costumed interpreters surrounding the reconstructed fort were very knowledgeable and entertaining. They brought to life the daily experience for the members of the Corps of Discovery. It rained all by 12 days over 3 months!! Then, take short (or long) hike on some of the nearby trails and imagine yourself trying to hunt in the mud and thick forests. Another great National Park. Can easily do in a day along with Ft. Stevens, or a trip to Seaside or Cannon Beach. Fee was $3 but very worth it. They also take the National Park Pass.
We had a fun trip. We got to take a trip in the boat across the water to the fort and we like the fort itself. Great no cost trip.

A definite must do. We did the presidents tour which is a self guided tour. A must do. We also did the audio tour which cost $5, but gave a lot of insiteful information that I otherwise would not have received. Last time I was there was 20+ years ago. Allow at least 3 hours to complete if you are going for the full effect.
This is a unique trip that you can't do anywhere else, but it is also one of the most expensive things to do on the island. We enjoyed the trip, but I don't think it was worth the price tag.

This place has the best views I have seen in my life, crazy, pshychodelic. At least spend a day here, walking through the Hoodoos for an out of this world experience. The entrance price is a bit steep but it is worth it in my opinion. The shuttle is OK, but won't get you into the deeper canyons of the park.

I don't know, while it was big I wasn't overly impressed. I think part of that is my own misguided idea of what I was going to see. Our guide was fantastic though, have no complaints there. We went on the Mammoth Passage Tour and despite having a National Parks Pass, had to pay (didn't have to at Carlsbad so it was odd... ). Got there about 1 hour early and the line was out the door, but managed to get a spot without reservations anyway. The tour DID fill up fast though but there were plenty of tours to go around. Perhaps doing a different tour would have left me more satisfied... ?

I teach fourth grade in New York State. Part of our curriculum is to teach about NY history. The Battle of Saratoga is always one of my favorite topics to discuss due to its importance in helping us convince other countries in the world that the young upstarts in America could possibly defeat the most powerful military in the world. Therefore, I decided to pay the actual site of the battle a visit this summer in order to get more material. I was not disappointed. Check out their website first in order to plan your trip accordingly. The site was very helpful. The grounds are beautiful, with incredible sights and parklike vistas. I was shocked at how empty of visitors the place was (it was a Tuesday though). This made for a very peaceful trip. Important areas of the battlefield are signed. A CD is available for a small price to help explain these areas in greater detail as you drive from place to place. Basically, if you have been to the Gettysburg battlegrounds, consider this seld guided tour a smaller version of that trip. Be sure to check out the fiber optics interactive map that explains the battles first. This is a very original idea and can be found in the visitors center. I also recommend traveling to the Victory Woods after your tour. This site is just north of the battlefield and is where the British finally surrendered. Basically, if you like U.S. history, military campaigns, and enjoy taking your time walking around the actually places these events took place while reading signage about those places, then this is a trip worth taking.

Took a quick scramble up the fairly steep Mesa Trail at Boca Negra in the western part of the park. Amazing petroglyphs, some possibly thousands of years old. Sweeping views of Albuquerque and environs, including extinct volcanic cones and that gives-you-chills wide open New Mexico sky. Just wish I'd had more time to explore more trails. A bargain at $2!

As national parks and memorials go, this has to be one that I probably will not come back to. It was almost as exciting as going to see 4 corners. I stopped here because I wanted the stamp in my national parks pass. The way this park is set up, you pay for parking which is good for the car for the calendar year. They have 2 different garages to park in so parking is not a problem. You then walk into the viewing area of the monument. They have the visitor center, a place to check out head phones to listen to the tour, and when you walk further down, they have a gift shop and a food stand and restaurant area. After you pass all this, you walk the row of flags to get to the viewing area. They have a short hike you can take as well, but you can't actually climb on the heads or anything like that. As this was the main highlight of my cross country trip, I was a bit disappointed. It really wasn't that much. It's a check in the box, but I wouldn't place it that high up on a bucket list if you have other things you want to do.

Fifteen of us visited the battlefield together. It was nice that we did not have to pay any entrance fee. Parking was convenient to the visitors center. Some of us wanted to go outside and walk the loop around the battlefield. The trail had informative signs explaining key points in the battle. It was shady enough to be pleasant even on a hot day. There was nice landscaping of native plants. Some cousins were content to remain in the visitors center and look at the film and other interpretive presentations like an illuminated map with an audio narrative. Some people browsed the small gift shop. All of us learned about the battle where our Laney ancestors fought for our freedom. The materials did an excellent job of making the battle come alive. We had a lot to think about and discuss on the van ride back to our hotel. It was a long drive, but worth the trip.

If you're in the are this should be on the list of things to do/see. Only had a couple hours so we did the museum, ranger talk (there are many and these guys know and love telling stories) and half hour movie cost? $6 and this was good for 3 days and a audio tour we didnt have time for. We will definitely to come back for the "lumina" in Dec.were they light 23,000 candles along the battlefield road for every soldier killed and the audio tour with the car.

We (husband, me, 2 daughters ages 8 and 10) recently visited Jewel Cave and really enjoyed it. We got there at about 9am and were able to get tickets for a 9:20 tour, which was perfect (apparently they used to let you reserve tickets on the phone but aren't do that this summer). We took the scenic tour ($24 total for the 4 of us) and it was about 1.5 hrs. The ranger who led it was informative, interesting and funny. You take an elevator down to start the tour and there are lots of steps up/down but it was totally manageable for us. There was one woman in our tour who had asthma and hadn't brought her inhaler and she was having trouble, but everyone else was fine. The tour goes ~350 feet underground and though it's dark you can see some need things (though there are very few stalagtites/stalagmites here). If you're in the black hills, Jewel Cave is worth a visit!

park: Brown v. Board of Education National Historic Site
text: Well organized displays of the times and events that led to the famous Supreme court ruling. The site is lightly attended making it easy to get through it. Beware of your surroundings though because of the high crime rate in this part of Topeka.

There is no cost to do this tour. The boat ride across the intercoastal waterway is beautiful. When you get there a park ranger gives you some history and you get to climb all over this very unigue little fort.

Take a trip with the Lincolns back to the mid-1800s. Visit their fully restored home and imagine how the Lincolns were a Midwestern family before he was elected Pres. It is the only remaining Lincoln home. There are other homes open on this beautifully recreated street. Go to the visitor center first to receive your FREE ticket(s). Only a limited number are shown through the house during a tour. The home has many stairs and is not handicap accessible due to the vintage era of the home. While you wait for your tour, enjoy the visitor center or stroll through the neighborhood. For something to eat, visit Obed & Issacs. Great food and a short walk from the site.

park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park
text: It at one time was a beautiful place,I grew up here and it was always a thrill, as I got older it got worse and nobody wanted to go there except if you were from outside of Paterson. But since it has become a National Park things are beginning to look up. During the month of August the City holds concerts on Saturday evenings showcasing local talent. If it's raining or it has recently rained the falls are beautiful and lets not forget the Hydro-Electricity Plant which is the original purpose of the falls. History, It has lots and as a National Park every American should at least try and pay it at least 1 visit, but give it some time so that it can be returned to it's glory.

After we dropped off the red-headed stepchild at Golden Bell (where he did in fact pass his louse-check), we took a side-trip over to Florissant Fossil Beds National Monument. It falls under the National Park Service.

I'm a local resident who has grandkids to entertain. This was just the ticket - beautiful walks with informative guides and great exhibits. My youngest was allowed to be a Junior Ranger and can't wait to share at show and tell in school. The homestead was really amazing, and the fact it belonged to a woman was just awesome. It was really a great way to spend the afternoon.

I am 43 and had never seen Mt Rushmore - this summer my husband and I took our 2 daughters (ages 8 and 10) to see it and we were all awed by it!
