It's truly huge and amazing to imagine how it was carved. The site is well organized and nicely layed out too. It's technically free but $11/car to park (so I suppose if you walked there it would truly be free ;) but totally worth the money. Seeing it from a distance as you drive up is cool too. When you get there and park, you walk in to an area with all the state flags, which is nice, and then out to a platform that overlooks the amphitheatre (there is a show there at night but we didn't go). Lots of people take photos there but it's crowded and there is a better photo spot later. The Presidential Trail walk is worth doing - it's easier (fewer stairs) if you start it from the left (when looking at the amphitheatre). It takes you closer to the monument and also passes the sculptor's studio, which is interesting. At the end there is a path to the right to an overlook that is a better place for photos. Also, the gift store here is great (and the day we were there, there was a man there who had actually worked on the monument so we got to meet him!). And the ice cream store there sells huge cones for $5 - yum!

What more can be said? I went as a child and then took my 3 children. Parking is $11 (good for whole calendar year) and admission free. Nice museum with video on how it was made and about the workers. New trail leads you up the mountain for some awesome views. Very well laid out. It's about 2-3 hour deal.

I love the overall beauty and tranquility of the entire Cuyahoga Valley National Park. The park covers a great portion of the Cuyahoga River Valley and runs parallel to the Ohio and Erie Canal, which was built in the early 1800's and is responsible for making it possible to settle the Ohio wilderness. The park boasts a great number of attractions and activities for all. Hiking and bike trails, Skiing, Wetlands, several Waterfalls, The "Tow Path Trail" (which was the original tow path that the mules trod upon for pulling the canal boats along the canal) is very flat and well suited for hiking, jogging, bicycling and sight seeing. Along the towpath trail are the remnants of the old canal locks as well as many of the historic building and stores and villages built along the canal, etc. There is also the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad which runs along the 26-mile length of the park 3 times daily with stops along the way, including the historic sites of Hale Farm, the old train depots in Peninsula and Independence, etc. If you have a family and you haven't a lot of money to spend on a vacation, you should really consider Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Hotels in the area are inexpensive and there is absolutely NO ADMISSION FEE for the park and most of the activities (though there is a charge for snow-skiing and the train excursion, etc.).

We stayed at Raven wood Motel. Raven wood motel is a small locally owned motel that offered a clean room and the owner was quite friendly and had maps of locations that were of interest and offered directions on what route to take. The motel had a washer and dryer that came in quite handy. Breakfast was included in the price. This was a motel that I call "A diamond in the rough".

Take Paulina Lakes road, pay your 5 dollars (well worth it) and hike to the Falls. So easy an 80+ year old who is healthy could and did do it. Don't miss the Obssydian Flow either, it is a wonderful 1 mile loop (maybe less) and it is gorgeous. (Don't wear flip flops though, OUCH). Take a Camera.

To get the Dinosaur National Monument, you have to drive a while, in my case I drove from Park City. But the magnificent place preserve the most realistic experience in Dinosaur. Unfortunatly with payed a visit from one day, but is very exciting make camping there. The Quarry preserve the Dinosaur exactly they were found. An excellent work in conservation and very educationally, a Great experiencia, very cheap and unforgetable

I'm a Lowell native and I didn't take this tour until a couple of years ago while entertaining an out of town guest. I want to take everyone I know on it now! Our guide was not too keen on us (she must have been one of the stricter ones and we were just having a good time) which is why I gave it 4 instead of 5. I'm sure some of the guides are great though! Cheap and really educational - plus it's so nice to see Lowell from a boat!

Many times places are overhyped. This place isn't. Once you get out of the tourist trap Keystone, the park and monument are wonderful. You pay an $11 parking fee (per car) but everything else is free. Don't miss the movie and museum. We walked the presidential trail and really enjoyed it although it does get a little strenuous.
need to see this once in your lifetime but once you've seen it that's it. nice time not too expensive to see, no admission fee but parking is 11.00

We visited Mt. Rushmore as part of a 13-night Globus bus tour from Rapid City to Las Vegas. This was one of my projected highlights on a tour filled with bucket list highlights, and being a historian l had a real sense of anticipation as we arrived at the site. That anticipation is heightened as you pass along a pathway lined with state flags and plques identifying each state and the date it entered the union. At the end of the pathway you emerge on a viewing platform where the carved faces of Washington, Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt, and Lincoln appear before you. I was prepared to be wowed, but at first glance this carving in the mountain, as beautifully detailed as it is, left me a bit disappointed. Perhaps my expectations had been too high; the carving is considerably smaller than I had visualized in my mind's eye, and when the Crazy Horse Memorial is completed, it will dwarf the carving of the presidents.

Amazing views of the eroded limestone. You can stand at the ridge, look west, and see nothing but green - look east, and you see nothing but the eroded landscape. If you are a senior, get the senior pass (I paid $10 several years ago) - it is good for free admission to any national park (good for life).

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: We had been to this Historical Park niumerous times. We started visiting since early 80's with guided tours. The bus took people from Lyndon B Johnson's boyhood home in Johnson City then to his Ranch in Stonewall, Tx. It is approximately 14 miles apart. We have seen the transformation of this historical site. I remember seeing Ms. Lady Bird outside their house while our tour bus was passing thru. Now that she has passed, we take self tours with our out of town visitors. It is very easy and convenient. You stop at the LBJ Boyhood home in Johnson City first then drive to the ranch. We stop at the visitor center to pick up a CD which will instruct and guide you throughout the park in the convenience of your private car and company of family and friends. The LBJ house is partially open now. Every year, they add a room or two available for public to see. A nominal fee of $2.00 or $3.00 is paid prior to entering the house. It is educational. The place history buffs will enjoy. Donations are accepted. There is a drop box for the CD at the end of the tour. You do not even have to go back to the Visitor Center. How cool is that?

This was my third trip to Mount Rushmore and every time it amazes me more and more! For the first time, my party did the walking - listening tour. For our party of 4 it was $15. (I was with 2 of my friends and my 14 year old and they let us do the family price! Very nice!) The audio tour was amazing and you learned so much more about the making of Mount Rushmore. Staff was very willing to answer any questions we had.

We had a great time here. My niece loved it, and enjoyed the outdoor observation areas. She also loved the chance to push the plunger and "explode" a portion of dynamite on Mt. Rushmore (on a screen as part of an exhibit). Rushmore was impressive, and the drive there is quite nice. The only critique I have is that while the giant ice cream cone was delicious, the portion size was too large for all three of us (my husband, niece, and myself). Specifically, I don't think most 6 year olds need 3 scoops of ice cream, so a child size cone would be a good addition to the menu. That said, the cone was only $5, so it was a good value.

We stayed in Alpine TX and had a 90 minute drive to park entrance. Drive is good, with speeds on 65-70 and little traffic. We stopped in Study Butte to top off our gas tank and get coffee. Gas price in Study Butte was the same as Alpine. The park is huge. We drove to Santa Elana trail along the Rio Grande river. The first quarter mile is flat and easy. Then the trail climbs several hundred feet to get a good view of the river. Other than the climb the remainder of the trail is easy. We took many pictures along the trail.

After moving to Quincy five years ago I would pass Peacefield and think "I need to do that" and finally did two years later- so worth it. The Adams family is fascinating and their history is all over Quincy. From the homestead to Peacefield you get a full picture of their life. After visiting I read McCullough's book and watched the HBO mini-series and it made me want to go all over again. After the tour ends walk around Quincy center and explore the cemetery. There are several great restaurants within a few blocks too.

After spending a week on a cruise, we decided that we didn't want to take a boat tour of Kenai Fjords. Instead, we opted to spend a few hours at Exit Glacier. Exit Glacier is approximately 11 miles from downtown Seward. It is an easily drive or bicycle ride from the town. The road is mostly flat. No entrance fee is charged at Kenai Fjords Nat'l Park. There is a visitor's center which was staffed by helpful rangers. A small gift shop/bookstore is located inside of the visitor's center. The rangers can provide you with a trail map. There was a guided walk that was leaving as we arrived that went to the edge of the glacier. We decided to do a self guided hike to the edge of the glacier. There is a 1 mile accessible trail that makes a loop from the parking lot to view points of the glacier. A 1/4 to 1/2 mile trail that leads to the edge of the glacier connects to the accessible trail. There are information boards along the trail that explains about the glacier and the National Park. There are also signs that show where the glacier was located in past years. It's really sad to see how much the glacier has receded in the past few years. At the end of the edge of the glacier trail, you can get fairly close to the glacier. I thought that we would be able to touch it, but it has receded too much. This area is definitely a beautiful place to visit. Unfortunately, I believe that Exit Glacier will cease to exist in 10-15 years. Visit before it's gone. We would love to come back sometime and hike the trail to the Harding Ice Field. We were unable to this time because not everyone in our family was able to hike such a strenuous trail. We didn't see any bears in the park. Overall, this is a nice place to spend a few hours and enjoy nature.

We loved our first visit to Harper's Ferry. We went mid week - no crowds. You could move easily throughout the buildings and step back in time. The scenery was unforgettable and we took lots of pictures. A few glitches...We took the shuttle bus from the Visitors Centre which was a good idea but the driver was nasty. When my husband thanked her for the ride as we exited, she literally growled at him. She did the same to other passengers. We also were less than impressed with the treatment our son received when he tried to sign up for the Junior Ranger's program, which he has done at other parks. The girls made him feel very uncomfortable and he decided not to participate. Other than that we enjoyed our visit and hope to return someday. Need at least 2-3 hours. Very reasonable entrance fee - $10 for the family.

This was a great disappointment for us. Although free, you must get a boarding pass at the ranger station to ride the small ferry over to the tiny fort. If you aren't at the ferry the very moment it gets there, they will leave without you! The ferry fills up very quickly and takes way too many to the miniscule fort. The rangers were nice and informative but there were too many people at the fort making it impossible to access . Wouldn't have wasted our time.

One of our aims in taking a road trip to the western US was to see Mt. Rushmore at least once. We had a gorgeous, sunny day to view this spectacular icon of Americana! A person can just go and look and be satisfied or spend hours here. We went down to the sculptor's studio which involves going down and up several flights of stone stairs, but it is manageable for most. At the studio, a guide gives about a 15 minute talk on the history and making of the mountain. It is well done and not tedious. We then walked the trail that views the other side of the mountain (to get a better view of Lincoln's face). There are many vantage points from which to take pictures, both on and off the property. (I think my husband got them all!) There is an $11 fee which, when paid, is valid until the end of that year. This is a must-see if you are near the Rapid City area.

Beautiful. We had seen a great show on TV the weekend before arriving, that gave us much of the history on the creation of the landmark, so honestly we didn't spend a lot of time on the exhibits. I enjoyed the before and after pictures. I cannot imagine having the vision or skill to create this. The most interesting part, to me, is the illusion of spectacles on Roosevelt. My only complaint - a fee to park.

Having been to a few national parks now, we as a family agreed we loved Bryce. We spent only the day but did everything. We entered the park with the car ($25) valid for 7 days. We went straight away in the morning to do a hike from Sunset Point. We left the car and walked clockwise, Queens garden, Navajo loop and the rim. We are experienced walkers so it took just over 2 hours round trip. This walk takes you right down into the canyon and so one must remember if you go down you have to walk back up. It might be tough going for young kids or the elderly or people with any heart convictions. Otherwise a must as this canyon is fantastic and you see lots of wildlife on the way. We then had a picnic at Sunset Point. There is a small general store to purchase snacks pizza or soup should you desire. We then drove to all the other viewing points starting with Rainbow & Yovimpa Points . Each one special with something amazing. My personal favorite viewing point was The Natural Bridge. The light was stunning (late afternoon) and we got some fantastic photos.. There is a shuttle bus but it doesn't go to all the viewing points so check before you leave the car parked for the day. Take as always lots of water, sun cream, hat and a map and .......Have fun!!

One of the main reasons we wanted to visit the big island is to go to Volcano National park. The park has some rally amazing views. The crater rim road is partial closed but still can get to the Jagger Museum and the other side connects with the chain of craters road. If you take the chain of craters road all the way to the end the road stops because of the Lava flows. Along the way there are interesting stops and short walks and hikes. You can get some trails maps at the visitor center. If you can I would recommend that you get your own car so you can do things at your leisure and not be rushed. The island is big and to save a lot of driving I would also recommend staying on the Hilo side a few days the village of Volcano has a number of rentals to stay at. There is a lot to see and you get a sense of old Hawaii and you can eliminate a 3 hour drive just to get to the park. We actually went to the park a couple of days. Over a half day we did the crater rim area and see the sulfur springs, Thurston Lava Tube, devastation trail and the Jagger Museum. The next day we did the chain of craters road. There a number of short hikes we did enjoy the Kilauea Ike Trail which is about 4 miles to complete the loop. At the end of the day we had dinner in Volcano Village and then went back a dusk to see the glow from the Caldera. My kids really did enjoy the park the highlight was to see the glow at night. I think they would have liked to see some real lava flows but that takes a pretty long hike to go to that area a stop at the historic Volcano House is nice and they have a better gift store than the Visitor Center. Also the Volcano Art Gallery is a nice place to stop by and look around. I would recommend a specialty tour for that activity. The other ways to see the lava is to take a helicopter ride or a lava boat tour. If you do a full day trip to the park I would recommend getting cheap Styrofoam cooler at Wal-Mart for $9 so you can put some water, fruit and sandwiches. We picked up some subway sandwiches so we can have lunch in the park without having to leave. Not much to offer in the way for food or snacks in the park unless you pay for an expensive lunch or dinner at the Volcano House. My wife and I were here in the mid nineties and the whole crater rim road was open and the lava flows covered less of the road so we almost drove up to where the lava is entering the ocean. Today it is about a 7 mile hike. If you have time a drive down to Kalapana is cool and you can see the other part of the lava flow which is not in the national park. There are some tour offered from that side and since it is on private land they have the permits to take you to the ocean opening. It is shorter hike from that side. There was something different this time. The fact that the crater rim road was closed because of vog seemed weird since it was not really blowing on the road. I can see if it does but when it doesn't why not open it. The activity today is far less than it was before and the road was open before the government always trying to protect you. Also we noticed there were a lot of rangers milling around and really did not seem to interact with people like they did before. I tried to ask a few questions and I barely got an answer. Even with the changes it is worth a visit and try to plan your day so you can take a short hike or walk so that you get a better sense of the power that the volcano has and how it has shaped the islands.

The best part is that you get to go inside the Lincoln's house. The tours are regulated by the National Park Service so you need to get a ticket and show up for your tour time. We were able to lunch in-between getting our ticket and our tour time. The quality of the tour is dependent on your guide. As I was waiting I saw 3 very different guides -- probably all good. Don't missing seeing the other structures in the area. This area has been much improved in the last 40 years.

This natural phenomenon is something to behold! The largest gypsum sand dunes in the world! When you first get there, you can visit the visitor center and watch the 17 minute movie on the history and science of the dunes. The visitor center offers a wide variety of interactive displays that teach you about the dunes and the wildlife that lives there. After that, you can purchase a pass to enter the park at $3.00 per person, unless the ranger isn't there, then you just drive in. White Sands offers many little hikes throughout the 7-8 mile driving loop. You can bring your lunch and your saucer for a day of fun! The saucers are used to slide down the sand dunes, similar to snow saucers. You don't even need to wear shoes! The sand is so soft. No matter how hot it gets, the sand does not get hot, but if you're there in the winter, the ranger said to wear 2 pairs of socks, because the sand gets so cold it could go through your shoes to your feet! Pretty amazing. During the summer, White Sands hold Full Moon Nights, three nights out of the summer. We attended this, and I highly recommend it. They have a band out there playing on the natural amphitheater the dunes create. The moon comes up and illuminates the dunes. At first, everything looks blue! It's so nice being our there at night. Definitely look into this if you plan on going in the summer. We also partook of the Sunset Stroll ranger guided walk. Our ranger was very informative and had samples of natural artifacts the dunes create and are created from. This stroll lasted about an hour and you don't walk very far. Check the visitor center or website for other ranger guided tours throughout the day. Have fun!

I think that Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell are places that every family should take time to see. Make sure that you reserve your tickets to go into Independence Hall. They only cost $1.50 each, and reserve you a timed entry ticket to get in. This can be done online. Make sure you get in line to see the Liberty Bell well before 5:00. They will close the doors, even whey people are in line. At 3:45 daily, in the park behind Independence Hall, there is an interesting reenactment that children love. Some kids are even asked to participate.

It's Mount Rushmore- everybody has to go just to say that they've seen it! Parking is $11 which is the only cost. Souvenir show had outside stand selling t-shirts for only $5...don't take a baby stroller on the presidential trail like I told my wife!

Mr. Rushmore was the main attraction of our 5 day road trip. Just like most popular tourist site, seeing them in person is so much better than you could imagine after having seen them in books or on TV. Your first view of it as you drive the road into the area is stunning. There is a beautiful walk way with all the state flags that you pass on your way to the mountain from the visitor center. We spent about 3 hrs. here taking pictures from every possible angle. We totally enjoyed our visit and recommend you make Mt.Rushmore a stop on your Black Hills vacation.

A bit expensive, but worth the $$. The snorkleing is great, but if you don't want to get wet there is plenty to see there. Your out there for 5 hours;with a 2 hour boat ride there and 2 on way back. I've been out there about a dozen times over the years with different friends and family and they have all loved it. They also give you lunch and breakfast with your ticket purchase. the tuna salad is THE BEST!

Found out about this wonderful tourist destination from a friend. It costs $165 per person, but it is worth every penny. The ferry is operated by the National Park Service -- with the Rangers running the entire operation. You must make reservations in advance in order to get a seat and be at the ferry terminal by 7:15 AM. The ferry leaves by 8:30 AM and you arrive by 10:30 AM. They tell you about the park on the way over and show a snorkeling video. They serve breakfast on the way as well as lunch while you're there. The park rangers will take you on a tour of Fort Jefferson shortly after arrival. Your snorkeling gear is already paid for, so you can skip the tour and go straight to the water if you wish. There is a reef that you need to swim out a little ways to reach. However, if you don't want to swim too far or deal with a current, you can see a lot of fish by swimming along the walls of the fort. The BEST place to see a lot of fish is around the pilings -- you will see more fish there then you will at the reef. I was surrounded by schools of small fish. The store/gift shop is small, but they do sell cheap cameras as well as SD cards (-- I forgot mine). Be sure to wear sunblock! Boat debarks at 2:45 PM and arrives by 5:30 PM.

I have visited Fort Clatsop many times in my life, and each time I do I come away with new information about this famous "end of the trail" camp of the Lewis and Clark expedition. The "fort" -- really just a simple stockade -- is a reproduction of the original winter camp of Lewis and Clark and is situated within yards of the original "fort". The setting, under the huge old-growth Douglas Fir trees, definitely gives the visitor the feel of what the Pacific Northwest would have looked like to those early explorers. Well maintained trails and an excellent gift shop and bookstore add to the enjoyment of this unique place, so important in the history of our country. If one is anywhere near Astoria and has a love of history, Fort Clatsop is a "must see" in my opinion, and the $3 entrance fee makes it affordable for everyone.

I did not feel the need to rate the monument, which completely deserves all the superlatives which others have bestowed on it. But I was looking for a place to rate the on-site restaurant and apparently there is no listing for that. I would have given it zero stars if I could! We went at the start of the lunch hour when there was almost no one but discovered that they had grilled a bunch of burgers and hot dogs in anticipation of the rush. Everything we got was cold and tasted like how you would expect something would taste after sitting in a greasy warming bin for hours. And it was not cheap either. This was our first run-in with a Xanterra property and was a signal for more bad things to come in other parks. A complete shame. So enjoy the monument, but just don't eat at the Xanterra cafeteria!!! Eat before you go!!!

Even though it is smaller than Crazy horse memorial it is better finished and more peasant to walk around and take photographs. There were ranger guided tours and I participated briefly in one of them. The presidential trail was a bit strenuous for some people. The fee is for parking, not the monument

We made this our main stop in the Black Hills. It was certainly worth it. The museum and film were very well done. Make sure that you come back for the evening lighting ceremony as it was beautiful. Best of all it is free except for parking and your ticket is good for the rest of the year.

We went to Mt. Rushmore with our 8 and 11 year old kids. We all really enjoyed it. Only cost is to park but it is good all week so we didn't have to pay again when we came back for the night time program. Grounds were very nice. Be sure to do the Presidential Trail. There are some very cool views from the trail. We also did the optional audio tour. Can't remember how much that cost but it was worth it. It gives so much more background and historical information. We also enjoyed the night time program. My kids were underwhelmed with that part as they expected fireworks but it was a nice outdoor movie about the presidents and lighting ceremony. HIghly recommend it.

If you are anywhere close to this park, you must see it. We were on a driving trip near Gunnison and almost returned to Denver without seeing the canyon because it was somewhat out of our way and would add a few hours to our trip. Luckily, I came to my senses because of course you never know when you will pass a place like this again.

My boyfriend and I were brought here while visiting family nearby, and it was definitely worth it. There is a $15 admission into the park, but it's per car not per person. The park is very beautiful, but it is definitely in the desert. The rock formations were my favourite part. They were stacked so intricately, it almost looked placed.
The access is very affordable ($10 for a carload of people) and there are MANY things to see. So keep the access ticket given at the gate, because returning after dinning is REALLY worth it.

location: New Providence, New Jersey, United States
text: Cedar Breaks is a National Monument 45 minutes north of Zion NP Kolob Terrace (the west side of Zion). Cedar Breaks is basically the same formation as Bryce Canyon NP but at slightly higher elevation making it the highest point on the Grand Staircase (for those you interested in geology). It views are incredible and, given the elevation, markedly cooler than Zion, GC, Las Vegas, etc. I highly recommend stopping here, it does not require much time (though some nice hikes are available if you do have time) and admission is inexpensive.

Thoroughly enjoyed our trip to Mammoth Cave! Took 2 tours: Historical and New Entrance. Recommend both. Taking the 2 will give you a very complete look/understanding of the cave system. They are honest in their description of "moderate". I am 49 and in average health; I made it and was totally fine. My just turned 4 year-old completed the trek just fine as well. Did have some very obese folks as well as folks using canes on trip that did not fare well. RE: booking online, we did and while we wouldn't have had to as the park was not crowded on this day, I am glad we did to ensure we could make the tours. Also ate in the restaurant onsite and loved it!

My wife and I arrived about 1230 and were told the next tour would be at 215. Tours last 2 hours and reservations are not accepted. My advice to casual travelers is to pass. The US Park Service web site is poor since it fails to explain these facts. You can walk around the grounds but at is hardly worth the effort. Do not try to visit this Park on the fly.

I am not the outdoorsy type, and no way am I going in a cave, yet I LOVED the day we spent here. The vastness of the park and all there is to do is amazing. It was $10 a car to get it which is an amazing price especially because it would be very easy to spend an entire day here.

This is such an amazing place. I live at a beach town and the dunes here were incledible. I loved driving the roads covered in sand. It looks like snow but when you step out of the car the heat kills you. It was 99 degrees. We kicked off our shoes and strolled the dunes. There are cute little covered picnic tables on the drive. Take some food with you and enjoy the beautiful views. You can rent a sled at the visitor center for $10.00. You will not want to leave!!!!

Mount Rushmore is a great place to visit for couples, singles, families, young and old. The admission is free, but there is a parking fee. The grounds are beautiful and you can stay as long as you want. If physically able, make sure to walk the trail to get as close as possible to the sculptures. There are 250 steps, with landings along the way.

My son and I took advantage over this national park's Junior Ranger program over the weekend. There are two programs to choose from - we completed the Letter-boxing. We enjoyed our time together looking for the letter boxes for no cost!

We looked forward to our visit to Seward mostly for the Kenai Fjord cruise. Unfortunately the weather didn't cooperate and we had rain, fog and clouds the three days we spent there. The morning of the cruise the fog started to lift and the grand mountains started to become visible. I was optimistic about the boat trip. When we arrived at the terminal we were told of a weather alert and that we may not be able to complete the trip. Not paying attention to other recommendations to cancel the trip (which was offered with a full refund) we decided to press on and try our luck. We were told that we would receive a partial refund if we weren't able to complete the whole tour, roughly 45 percent of the cost. As soon as we pulled out the fog lowered and the clouds and rain started. We got to the entrance to the Alaskan Gulf and the captain tried to cross into the next safe inlet. Other boats had tried and failed and we did too. We did see some marine life but very little on land. They still had our morning snack ready and we stopped for lunch instead of dinner on Fox Island. The food was good and it was warm and a nice stop. We still stayed out until around 3:00. When we returned to the dock I expected a huge mess and hours waiting to work out everyone's partial refund. Instead there was a full crew waiting for us with paperwork ready to sign. We received a prepaid debit master card which was issued in seconds with my signature. Although we probably should have cancelled the trip, I didn't want to miss out on any of the beauty and we took our chances. The company was more than ready to deal with the bad weather and appropriate compensation. Kudos, I wish every company did this level of class act when mother nature doesn't cooperate.

It was only $5 for all of us. The small museum had tons of wonderful information and we were able to watch a small video about Ad Lincoln and the park. We also took a stroll through the woods to see Abs farms, what was left of his house and what it would of looked like. All three of the girls enjoyed the sites and the small farm animals.

We went to the evening lighting ceremony. It was a beautiful drive from Rapid City to the memorial and we found it to have a good parking facility, pretty grounds, reasonable entrance price, touching and informative film and ceremony, nice gift shop. Also appreciated the deer lookout warning when driving home.

We go to Mammoth Cave whenever we can, it is an absolute treasure and just amazing that we have this resource available to explore. I've taken two tours there recently. The "Historical Tour" is the traditional one that is nice to do if you went when you were a kid. It is relatively easy and has a variety of different views. Last week we took the "New Entrance Tour" and that was just amazing. This tour is not easy, though - lots of steps, ups and downs, etc. However, if you can hike 2.5 miles without much difficulty then you can handle this tour. The tour had 3 parts - A, B and C. A was the climb down. 280 steps straight down with twists and turns and small spaces. Wear tennis shoes and even calf-high socks if you have them, as the back of my calfs were scraped from the steps down. You open-up into a large room, which starts B. B is climbing up and down and around with some beautiful sights. C is the Frozen Niagara, which is a mineral deposit that looks like a waterfall. They give you the option to take an additional 48 steps to go under the falls - DO IT. It was my favorite part of the tour and even though I was pooped by then, it was well worth it and not a lot of extra effort. Looking up at the falls - wow. They let you rest in between each stage and you're in a cool cave, anyway, so it wasn't too strenuous. And the Niagara is near the exit, you did your climbing-up in stage B. Each tour was about $12, I believe, and takes roughly 1.5-2 hours. You have guides with you. If you're vacationing anywhere near western Kentucky then Mammoth Cave is a must-do!

well organized, great crew. We were blessed with good weather and many whale and animal sightings. Food was good and worth the extra price. Now just need the morons who have never been on a boat to take sea sick meds so they don't ruin others experience by vomiting over the side (vomit streaked windows give a nice touch) IT IS ROOUGH IN THE GULF OF ALASKA. I thought it was great, but the bozos that did not heed the warnings made a real mess.

The snorkeling was awesome, the boat over and back was extremely nice and the food was as well, the crew couldn't have been more helpful and knowledgeable. Ft Jefferson is very interesting and the price for the trip is very well worth it. Take the Yankee Freedom lll over to the island not the plane.

This is a great National Park. We enjoyed our visit and found the Historical Tour very interesting. There is a lot of walking and stair climbing, so we felt we had had quite a workout. Our family of 4 paid about $40 for a 1.5 hour tour through several interesting "rooms" and areas of the cave, with a knowledgeable park ranger sharing great pieces of history. I think he could have answered anything about caves, geology, Kentucky and local history!

If you are a history buff, as my husband is, this is a must see. Very interesting to even someone who isn't that much into history, such as myself. A note, it is $3 per person and the booth was closed when we were there, so you had to "self pay" and take a receipt. Make sure you have the correct change.....

We drove our camper van into Chaco on the northern route, supposedly the better way. Yes, it is horrible; dusty,and the worst washboard ever! Still worth the gruelling 23 miles unpaved part. Go REALLY slowly and you'll be all right. The ruins are spectacular; some are all excavated and you can wander around in them at your leisure. It's worth doing the hike up to the bluffs above Pueblo Bonita so you can see them from above; an incredible half circle of kivas and dwellings. We took in the astronomy presentation at the visitor's center one evening as well. Very basic astronomy, but you do get to look thru telescopes which is always cool. The campsite is basic and in a nice setting, cheap too. So glad I went.Spent 2 nights, May 31 st to June 2nd. Already hot; wouldn't want to come here in July or August. We did a 5 week road trip in the 4 corner states starting in early May and it was great, cooler and not as busy.

We stayed in the campground for one night (cheap at $10) and toured the bridges the next day on our way to Moab. Great hikes to the bridges; great opportunities for photography. we were there on June 4th, already hot but not unbearable for a couple of Canadians. Worth going to, esp. if you want to avoid a lot of people.

I guess I get the point of getting to see this and being proud of what it is, however I am sorely disappointed in the park itself. First if you buy an annual national park pass, this park does not honor that for entry. Their "claim" is that they don't charge for entry only parking and its an "independent company" that collects the parking money, so even though its a national park you will pay $11 to get in even if you have the annual park pass! While we were there it was packed!! The kids exploration area was closed, so we were not able to do that. And, without paying extra for the "tour" Most of what you could do it hike around and take pix. By the way .... You can see a GREAT view from a pull off on the road coming in to the park and there are a lot of free places to hike while driving around the parkway roads. The only reason I can even give this a two is that there is a little movie you can see telling about Mount Rushmore and I've heard if you go at night it's fun to watch the lights, however we were not going to be there at night, so we were not able to enjoy that.

My family and I arrived at Mount Rushmore in the morning, shortly after it opened. We got a great space in the parking garage. There is no fee to get into Mount Rushmore, but there was a fee to park ($11.00). From the entrance, we walked through the Avenue of Flags, which was quite nice, with Mt Rushmore as the backdrop. We visited the Visitor's Center, where my son got a booklet to fill out to become a Junior Park Ranger. As we walked around, we found answers to the questions in the booklet. He then filled in the answers and turned it in to the Park Ranger at the Visitor's Center information desk. My son was then given a certificate & a badge & sworn in as a Junior Park Ranger. He thought that was awesome! We all enjoyed the information and displays at the Visitor's Center. Also, we walked the Presidential Trail, about as close as you can get to the mountain. I got some great pictures! The trail has ALOT of steps. The Sculptor's Studio was nice as well. I was very happy that there was a vendor table set up when we were getting ready to leave the monument that wasn't there when we came. The table was set up as a "Guest Appreciation" day and all the items on the table were being sold for $5. So we were able to score some Mount Rushmore t-shirts & coffee mugs at a great price! We were at Mount Rushmore about 2 hrs and as we were leaving, people were pouring inside the entrance. We were happy to have beat the crowd and people were waiting to get our parking space!

I read reviews prior to going and I wish I had listened. I paid $22 in parking and stayed 15 minutes. The only thing to do is to look at the mountain. It's something to say you've seen it, but it was disappointing. Yes, you can see the mountain as you are travelling the highway around it, but there isn't anywhere you can easily stop and take pictures. I thought for the money I was paying, there was going to be something more to do, read, something.

Walnut canyon almost stumbles upon you. You arrive at the information centre and suddenly its there. You can almost not wait to get there and then you pay your $5 per person and suddenly you can start snapping away. But wait. There is a stiff climb before you can really see it all. And what a stiff climb it is. But take your time. You have all day. Then you see where Honi Indians made their homes and storage areas and you think: they must have been crazy. A definite must see when you are in the area.

While there are forest fires that smoked-in Medford, the recent rain made it relatively clear at Crater. This lake and surrounding landscape has to be seen, as photos just doesn't show its splendor. 90 minutes northeast of Medford's airport. I listened to a presentation by a park ranger at the Lodge about the creation of this national park which has the US's deepest lake (and it us very blue). Took me 2 hours each time to drive around the lake and there are many viewpoints along the way. For the $10 park entry, you get a great map. At many of the viewpoints not only is the view fantastic, but the chipmunks and birds are good entertainment as the chipmunks will come right up to an outstretched hand. Afternoon best viewing is on the west rim (where roads are the best) while AM on the east (where roads a a bit bumpy). Don't miss the Pinnacles (a turn near the ??Ship viewpoint on the SSW side).

Once again the National Park Service delivers a great history lesson in easily digestible chunks. We started with the small museum and a short film about the importance of this battle and some of the strategy. We purchased the battlefield tour on CD in the giftshop for $20. For us, it was worth it while we drove through the park as it kept our kids a little more engaged than just the written plaques. Tour was great except we never did find one particular statue of a lion. Great visit!

You get it all with no fee! Boat trips leave each hour on the half hour, a fort to climb without much walking and a great presentation by park rangers, beaches on both sides of the road, and trees that are easy to climb for picnicking. This has been a favorite destination of ours when our kids were tweens and it is still lots of fun. Be sure to cross the street and enjoy Crescent Beach. Great sand, waves, and even some shelling. It is the last easy accessible beach south of St Augustine's pier and fountain area (also a must)!

You've seen pictures your whole life. Go and see it! We watch the film and went in the exhibit hall. expect to spend at least one hour. I think it was $10 for one car. Worth the time it took to fly and drive there. We drove from SLC and saw other sights. Expect lots of motorcycles if you go the first week in Aug,

Yes, you have to pay for parking and yes, there are a lot of people, but it is so worth the experience of seeing Mount Rushmore in person. On so many levels seeing Mount Rushmore has to be a bucket list item. I so admire the passion it took to make this and the vision to look at a mountain and say I will make the Shrine of Democracy on the side of a mountain. I also admire the four Presidents, they were some of our best Washington, Jefferson, Roosevelt and Lincoln represented the birth, growth, expansion and preservation of the union.

This one of my favorite places to go in Arizona. No matter the weather, this is a wonderful stop with a "reasonable" hike. Visitors love it. What a view ! A park service "geezer" pass gets you and 3 others in for free.

We visited the GTNP, along with Yellowstone and Glacier National Park. Glacier National Park was our favorite, hands down. The Grand Tetons and Yellowstone are certainly worth the visit...each park has its own kind of beauty and uniqueness. I would highly recommend this park...it's worth it. Take the air tram in Teton Village to the top of the mountain ...awesome!!!! Lots of things to do and see in the area. Come prepared with appropriate hiking shoes and gear, and of course, a camera! Buy the bear spray if you plan to do any hiking at all. Take the road up to Wilson...and drive up the pass, beyond Wilson...beautiful up there !! We saw an eagle in its nest along the road.

We had road bikes and were worried about riding the towpath - with the exception of a few short muddy paths, the path was well packed tailings fine for any bike. We parked at the north end of the park off Rockside road and headed south to the Canal Visitor center (closed for renovations). Round trip was about 10 miles. You hit lock #39 about a mile from the parking lot (headed south) - in pretty bad shape. You pass a couple of other canal historical markers along the way before you get to the visitors center where there is a lock with what looks like working gates. The visitors center is just a couple of blocks from the train stop (trains run several times a day - riders can catch the train one way for $3, runners $9 - schedule at http://www.cvsr.com). There is also an extensive paved bike path system that looks terrific - we hope to get back and explore more!

If you ever are to visit Alaska, this is a MUST SEE. The park limits private vehicles from entering in to the park completely (I think you can only go 15 miles in). You need to take a tour bus into the park which I highly recommend because many of the guides have spent time hiking, camping, etc in the park. Our guide Peter is a sub teacher in his other job but does this during the tourist season. He was well versed in the eco system, the animals, the history of the park and all that have traveled through the park since the early 1900s. You have the option of a 6-8 hr trip or a longer one. We chose the 6-8 hr because we do have an 8 yr old. We were even leery that he would hang on for 6-8 hr but let me tell you, he did and loved every minute of it. Part of the draw to this trip is that everyone on the bus participates in eyeballing animals. On our trip, we saw a momma bear and her 2 cubs whom gave chase to a male bear, caribou & their little ones, moose, porcupine, sheep and some birds. They film what you see on your trip and you can purchase that for $35-which they send to you via mail after editing. The mountains that you see throughout this great park are spectacular. They will take you to a spot to see Mt McKinley (aka Denali). This is hard to see in its entirety because of the clouds but we were able to see quite a bit. There isn't a bad Kodak moment and well worth the effort for the early rise. We did the early AM trip and when I say early..I mean..EARLY. They pick up at various large hotels in Denali starting at 530AM so be forewarned. Don't worry to doll up-no one will care at least I don't think so because I am sure I may have scared a few bear with my morning hair. The tour bus (which is a school bus configuration) we took included a light snack (reindeer sausage, cheese, bread, & bottled water). We opted to have our hotel pack us a lunch as kids aren't so thrilled with the bus snack option. They do make potty break stops often. Great trip for all ages.

Visited late July 2013, did the boat tour and stayed in Crater Lake lodge overnight. The boat ride was fun, informative. The hike down to the boat tour is strenuous: it's essentially going down and then back up 76 flights of stairs (about a mile hike). Apparently they have to "rescue" people every few days, so be careful!! Older kids seemed to handle it without problems. Crater lake lodge was historic and a real treat. We didn't want to spend the $$$ in the restaurant, so we brought a picnic meal and that worked out fine. No refrigerator in the room though. TIP: As we planned the trip only a month in advance, crater lake lodge was booked. I called the lodge every few days and to my pleasant surprise, a room opened up. They have a lenient cancellation policy, so it wouldn't surprise me if this isn't uncommon.

I had a great time visiting this National Historic Park. The homes were flawless and really told a beautiful story. My favorite part was the library at Peacefield. However, the young women selling us the tickets was overly loud even though we were standing right next to us. She also was not clear what type of ticket she was selling me. Overall though, the experience was a pleasant one.

My friends and I arrived at Mount Rushmore at about 5:00AM, just when the gates open. Our goal was to catch the sunrise over the memorial- and how oh so beautiful it was! Having arrived so early, we did not have to pay for parking or entry- SCORE! Though some of the vendors and visitors centers weren't even open yet, we didn't find ourselves to be missing out on anything- the beauty and history was still there! Not a tourist in sight- just the serene hush of nature... 5:00 AM is the time to be there! Great memorial to say the least....

We arrived at our motel in Custer, SD, around 5:30 p.m., and decided to take in the evening program at Mt Rushmore National Memorial. While this is part of the National Park Service, many of the improvements to the memorial have been funded by donations to a non-profit support group and Xanterra. One of those improvements is a $17 million parking garage; so there is an admission charge for the parking garage of $11. There are no discounts for NPS annual passes, senior passes, etc. There are a number of exhibits and things to do, and a food court for meals. The evening program takes place in the amphitheater, includes a 20 minute movie that emphasizes the four presidents carved into the mountain side, lighting of the monument, and a special tribute to the veterans and active service members in attendance. While we didn't have time to do everything, we enjoyed the evening program.

By happenstance, we arrived in Rapid City to tour Mount Rushmore the same two days and my wife's cousin from Colorado. We toured together. We arrived early, around 8:30 AM, which was great since it was not yet too crowded. The day was absolutely beautiful - clear blue skies (after a storm with hail and a small tornado the day before!), The carving and the overall facility is spectacular. The artist's studio is very interesting as is the walkway of flags. Entry is free, but parking is $11 per car which interestingly is good for a full year! The parking ticket has the date and most of your car license plate number on it, so if you wish to return, maybe at a different time of day (or dusk) or another day, parking is free IF you save your initial ticket. Access and viewing is easy although there are a fair number of steps down (and back up!) to the studio, but it’s worth it. My only slight disappointment is that the actual carvings seemed a little smaller than I expected,, but yet it was spectacular and well worth the trip. I highly recommend it.

This was our first visit to Bryce Canyon NP. While I enjoyed our visit, 2-4 hours was sufficient for us. From what I could see, there wasn't a whole lot to do in the park to keep families occupied for numerous days. We also saw Arches and Zion NPs, so perhaps we were just "red rocked" out! Very pretty park to visit! The annual National Park Passes are well worth the $80 if you can plan ahead to visit lots of federal parks and monuments. There are 2 places to sign on the back of the cards, so in theory 2 families could use the same card!

It is very impressive to see the plumes of smoke and the view from the visitor's center. The visitor's center has a great deal of interesting information and there are park service rangers available to answer your questions. Do visit all the different buildings and drive through the park. We drove down from Kona for the day (several hour trip). I would have loved to have seen the lava flow, but the boat rides out of Hilo were the only realistic choice for me. We were on the opposite side of the island, so driving to Hilo was out of the question for us. The Lava Tubes are very impressive and are a comfortable walk. If you have the time, do stop by. We don't have anything like it in Pennsylvania. Just a note: if you are 62 or older be sure to get a National Park Senior Pass for $10. It's good for parks through out the United States for your lifetime. For more info on the pass, go to the National Park Service website.

My younger kids were a little nervous when we entered the cave, but they soon relaxed and had fun. It was neat to see the main cavern and the graffiti room. It was a fun memory and the tour was not more than $5 per person. This was a quick rest stop for us on our way to Nashville on a family roadtrip. A perfect place to relax and walk around for a few hours before getting back in the car.

If you have an interest in the American Revolution, or at least some curiosity and an interest in learning more you will enjoy the Minute Man National historical Park. While the Museum is not elaborate it does a good job of setting the stage for what is typically an excellent retelling of the events that unfolded here by the Rangers. To fully appreciate the motivations that caused the Minute Men to open fire I recommend coming to the Park from Concord Center (Wright Tavern, the British headquarters is still standing - although it is now a funky office building, so enjoy it from the outside.) If you travel up Monument Street to get to the Park you will pass by the Old Manse, which abuts the Park close to the North Bridge and is famous as the home of Rev. William Emerson (father of Ralph Waldo Emerson) who observed "the Fight" from his property along with his family. (The Old manse is famous for other reasons as well as is maintained as a historic site.) You will also pass "The Bullet Hole House" which still has an errant, embedded shot - it is now the home of the Park Superintendent.

This home is part of the National Park Service & is worth a visit. As we are Johnson's my husband especially enjoyed this stop. There are lots of beautiful homes to visit in Natchez but this one gives you the prospective of a freed man of color's life in that time period. And the fact that there is no entrance fee there is no reason not to add it to your itinerary of Natchez.

This place was on my bucket list. I was on a family vacation in Denver and decided to make the seven hour drive north to see it. It was worth the long drive. The monument is a beautiful site to be seen. Especially if you are an American History Buff like me. I love each and every one of the presidents depicted on the granite. There is an $11 parking fee but if you make the trip to this place it is more than worth it. There is no price for getting into the park. The park is beautiful! Also, there is a big gift shop that will sell you souvenirs (my recommendation is to get them elsewhere because they are expensive there) For those people that complain about souverniers not made in the US, then good luck finding any because everything has been outsourced by the US Corporations. The grounds have a great restaurant and great ice cream shop. There is a pathway to walk up and get really close to the faces. If you go to the right it is over 200 steps but if you choose the pat on the left it is an easy paved walk way. Like I stated before, an American Gem not to be missed. Loved every minute I spent on those grounds.

Took a 5 hour boat tour of Resurrection Bay and the Fjords. Most boring 5 hours of my life! Half the boat was laying across seats sleeping! I can only assume that the others who wrote glowing reviews for this would be excited at watching grass grow because this tour was in line with that! My 80 year old father my brother 49 son 21 and myself 53 all could not wait to get off that boring boat ride! They told us once we got on the boat you rarely see whales or other sea life. Instead of spending $70 on this tour send me $35 and I'll come over to your place and hit you up side the head with a 2x4!

Ohio's only National Park is in name only. Just a wooded area with a small stream and a 30 foot waterfall that was half flowing when we were there. There were some trails which amounted to nothing more than a walk in the fields. There are some bike paths if you are so inclined. On the positive side there is no entrance fee and it is a short walk to the waterfall. But to call this a National Park stretches the imagination. Had I read my own review before I went there I would not have gone.

We've been trying to go here for about 10 years and just made it this past summer. We could not believe how beautiful this lake and surrounding mountains were. To see the sum rise and set on the rim, to hike to the top of the lookout paths, to just sit and experience the awesomeness of this natural attraction was a boon. Don't leave here without taking the boat ride on the lake. We didn't go to Wizard Island, just the lake tour, but it was well worth the ticket price. We even got to see the 'old man of the lake.' It helps to go on a day with sunshine, but the natural phenomenon of the rock formations, lava flows, and water color can be seen anytime. There's only one path up and down to the water's edge, but the park did a nice job of keeping it graded, although I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who wasn't fully ambulatory--it is steep.

Only an hour south of Gettysburg is another historic Civil War battlefield. Great job by the NPS. History, history, sobering history. A great film and small museum are a great introduction and all for a single low price per car. The CD auto tour once again was our choice, having done the same the pervious two days in Gettysburg. Also learned where the term side-burns came from.

If you visit White Sands National Monument in the summer, I strongly recommend that you spend the night in Ruidoso or Ruidoso Downs which are less than an hour away. Ruidoso is in the nearby mountains, has pine trees, and averages 20 degrees cooler temperatures. White Sands itself is unique and amazing. It is so beautiful, and I've never seen anything like it in the world. It has the largest white gypsum sand dunes in the world. The visitor center is a few miles southwest of Alamogordo. You won't miss it because there is nothing else there. The visitor center has a free 17 minute video that gives a good description of the dunes. It also has an outdoor garden of area desert plants with plaques and descriptions of those plants. I've always heard of creosote covered telephone poles, but never knew what creosote was. Creosote is one of the plants growing and described. The gift shop has plastic sleds available for kids to slide down the dunes. To get to the dunes, you must pay $3.00 per person, not per car. The older lady at the gate was extremely slow, but that is my only complaint. To get to the heart of the dunes you drive an 8 mile road. The first several miles are paved, then you drive on graded white gypsum sand. There was no problem with getting stuck in the sand. The first couple miles of sand dunes have quite a few plants growing on the dunes. The farther in you go, the fewer plants. Eventually you get to the truly white bare sand dunes. After you drive past the paved road you will see pullover areas to park your car. That's the place to get out of the car and climb some sand dunes. I'd say the average height is 30 feet or so, but some reach 60 feet, The contrast of the very white sand and the nearby blue mountains is so beautiful. Make sure to take photos. As I said, if it's summer and daylight, you won't want to stay a long time. It's hot. They do permit visitors until 10:00 PM though. Then spend the night in cool Ruidoso. If you want a longer side trip, check out Carlsbad caverns. Hope you enjoy it..

Crater Lake national Park is huge with a good variety of viewing sites, walking trails, naturalist led hikes and other educational experiences. There were forest fires about 100 miles away near Grant's Pass so the visibility wasn't as good as it could be but still spectacular. Prepared food availability isn't great and the prices high so be prepared. Quality is average. Ambiance is great.

This is a guided tour run by the National Park Service. The ticket is $10, but if you have your senior entrance card to all the National Parks, it is free. You can get one there for that amount. A trolley takes you from in front of the office where you get the tickets to the 3 Adams' houses where you visit the interiors with informative guides that give you historically accurate information and make the tour not only educational but really enjoyable. Your are reliving history. If you read McCollough's book ot saw the PBS documentary, this gives life to it. Don't miss visiting the church, practically next door, where John and Quincy Adams are buried with their wives. The entrance there is a $10 donation. In both places, not much walking for seniors, just a few stairs.

My husband and I visited the area and I'm so glad we did not miss valley Forge historic park. Start at the visitors center. It has a map to follow, a good shot film, a gift shop and a 40 minute walking tour with a ranger. Then either take a trolley for a fee, rent a bike, take a hiking trail or your car on a tour of the park. The tour was very educational. We were there in Aug. 2013. The grounds were beautiful, we had a great time!

We were looking for a new vacation trip and decided to do the Bourbon Tour and added the Mammoth Cave as a side attraction. The tourist center is first rate with a self-guided learning center (museum quality, very high tech use of computers and video). We chose the historic, 2-hour tour. It was reasonably priced and was conducted in a first rate manner. Be prepared, if you are not capable of walking 2 miles or are not comfortable in tight dark places, the historic tour is not for you. The cave is well lit for the tour and we got a chill in the cavern when they turned off the lights for the longest 2 minutes of my life. The tour guide does a good job describing the history of the cave. We were just amazed at the size of the fallen limestone that littered the ground off the trail. We'll go back to see the waterfall stalactites tour the next time. We had a blast walking through the skinny little caverns and low ceiling caves. And to top it off, we saw some little bats snuggled in the ceiling.

A bit out of the way but if you have the time, well worth the effort. Stunning view from the top. Entrance fee is $4 per person. Ranger are on site to tell more about the geology of the region and why it is unique.

This was a juggle to fit in because my husband dives so we had to work with altitude allowances- but it was worth every headache to do it. You can't do the park justice in one day. Given that it is 91 miles from Kona- you think you would be there in about 90 min- give up that thought- the speed limit for a good part is 35- miles per hour. With the curving roads, change in speed- you are looking at about 2.5 hours maybe closer to 3 to get there. The first stop should be the Visitor's Center which is on the right just pass the information booth. If you are staying at Volcano House- it is across the street from the visitor center. At the center you can see a movie and get oriented to what there is to do. DO YOUR RESEARCH BEFORE COMING. You may or may not be able to actually see lava- it depends on where it is currently flowing- this was upsetting to so many people we met in the center. Does it mean you can't see lava? No- currently you have to go outside the park to do it. So- know what you want to see and do before you get there. If lava is important- research how to get there (lava hikes with David Ewing is one resource).

My wife and I stopped here last year in august while the kids were at universal, and we had a lovely ride out to the fort and got to crawl all over it so we took them there this year to let them see for themselves you go to the rangers gift shop and get your boarding passes then wait at the dock for your ferry boat, we got to go out and stay quite awhile since there were only nine people total and it was near the end of the day the kids enjoyed the ride out and back and really liked exploring the old fort while listening to the park ranger tell all about the history and things about the area also a good point this is a federal park site and there are no charges for anything but the items from the gift shop, a really relaxing stop and no real cost what a deal these days and then friendly park rangers to great time.

Fort Jefferson was beyond my expectations! Great snorkeling too! This is a must do! I would go back in a heartbeat! I would pay extra for the seaplane though. On the way back, we experienced extremely rough seas. If not, at least pay attention to the wind speed when booking. The Yankee Freedom was a beautiful boat and the crew was top notch!

Canyon viewing consists of two parts. The main canyon which is also serviced by frequent free shuttles and the secondary canyons which are accessible by private vehicle plus one shuttle in the morning and one in the afternoon to the furthest point (Rainbow point) only. The canyons (all of them) are simply a must see. One runs out of superlatives to describe the magnitude that awaits your eyes (and cameras). There are several hiking trails graded as "easy, moderate or strenuous" Allow yourself at least 3-4 hours if you have your own vehicle and wish to see all the viewpoints. If you have limited time, do the main canyon first. Higher Inspiration Point gives a good overview of the main canyon but it does involve a bit of climbing. Costs are $25 per vehicle.

just a lil south of st Augustine. free to visit, but you need a ferry pass. once at the fort you get the sense of what it would of been like to protect the cities backdoor. nice and pleasant visit. really cool fort.

This house is part of the 4 blocks of historic area managed by National Park Service. The entrance to Lincoln Home is free. You need to pay for parking ($1/hr at NPS lot, but street metered parking is only 1 quarter per 30 minutes). Go to visitor and get a ticket for a free guided tour of the house (you are only allowed to enter with a guide in a tour group of 20). Tour lasts about 20 minutes. The guide (park ranger) will explains to you all the rooms, funitures inside the house, and Lincoln's family life before he became the President. Most funitures are still original. Photography is allowed. Allow 1 hr.

The canyon was a favorite place to spend Sundays by the locals way back before the depression. It is right off I-40 just a few miles east of Flagstaff. The parking lot is right at the visitor's center, and it does cost $5 per person to get in. The visitor's center has some displays to explain the native dwellings, but all of them have been reconstructed so I suppose it's our idea of what they looked like, not necessarily what they did look like. The trail goes down and around a tight bend in a dry river bed and then back to the visitor center. It has concrete steps and wide flat concrete or crushed stone pathways. Be aware, the trail isn't long, only about a mile, but it has a great deal of vertical relief (280') and you are hiking at 7000'. That means you are walking down and back up a 28 story building, so leave extra time and stay within your limits. The trail along the top rim is flat and easy to walk and you see everything, just not up close. We visited on Aug 17th and were treated to a fantastic storm. We arrived at around 11:00 A.M. and had finished by 12:00 noon just as a huge storm arrived. The lightning hit in the canyon several times and the rain poured for over 45 minutes. Then it started hailing and the entire area filled with white slushy pea sized hail stones. What a hoot! I suppose it wouldn't be so great if you were out in it, but from the huge windows of the visitor center it was FANTASTIC! When the rain let up we walked to the rim and saw the flash flood in the riverbed below. Even if you don't get the weather to cooperate for you the way it did for us, you'll still love the hike. Take water and sun screen if it's sunny and dry clothes if it looks like rain.

The cost of the trip to Dry Tortugas by ferry may seem too much, but it really isn't. When Fort Jefferson appears in front of you and you see the waters around it, we knew we made a good choice to go there. The 45 minutes guided tour of Fort Jefferson was amazing, full of historic information. We spent half an hour more visiting the fort at our pace and then headed to the ferry for lunch, buffet-style. As the breakfast, it was simple, but fresh and very good. We spent the rest of the day, around two hours, swimming and snorkeling around the Fort. Although the sea was choppy, the snorkeling sites were good and impressive for first timers like us. Being there, in the middle of nowhere, with this huge fort is an experience definitively worth the price.

Where the Potomac and Shenandoah Rivers meet the Blue Ridge Mountains - that is Harper's Ferry, a town with not only stunning vistas at every turn, but loads of history as well. John Brown the abolitionist is famous for his raid here, which ultimately lead to his lynching and foreshadowed the Civil War. The park area itself is split into two parts - a nature park above town where one should park and shuttle to the downtown historic area. Downtown there are exhibits, shops and lots of places to explore, including a fascinating walk over a railroad bridge which emerges from a tunnel, but parking is almost impossible, so don't even try it - pay the fee and park in the upper level shuttle lot. Plan carefully if you have mobility issues, as the downtown area shops run up a very steep hill, and several viewing areas require long, uphill walks. Or, bring a picnic lunch and hang out by the river - several parents let their little ones "swim" in the cool shallows while they ate their lunches and enjoyed the beautiful surroundings. Something for everyone!

We were here on the holiday weekend, July 4, 2013. Crowded right around park entrance but not too bad once we were in the park. What can i say? Beautiful, just beautiful blue lake. Wish we had more time there so we can take the boat tour to wizard island. Do reserve if you want to go on the boat tour. We heard the tour booked up pretty fast. It was 2 hour easy (in good weather condition) beautiful scenic drive from Medford, Oregon. The rim drive took about another 3 hour drive (with plenty of stops for photo ops). The park entrance fee was $10/car (which i think pretty cheap). Do bring snacks and water along. We got hungry driving around. Definitely worth the visit. And oh the park is super senior friendly (my mom was with us and she was able to enjoy the park without doing lots of hiking while having a bad knee).

This was my second trip to Dinosaur National Monument and loved it as much as my first visit about 30 years ago with my children. It was the first time I had been up close and personal with dinosaurs and found it to be an awesome thing. There were a few changes since that first visit. They now have a shuttle near the entrance of the park that takes you to the quarry site because the upper parking lot is not large enough to accommodate all the visitors and the gift shop is located at the park entrance also. I don't remember the price of the entrance fee for the park, but we opted to purchase the senior pass for $10 which allows entrance to all the national parks for a lifetime. A very good deal if you are 62 or older..

Great photographs were taken prior to realizing the end of the road to view Mount Rushmore contained a blockade which one must pay a fee to enter. Our photos were sufficient so we declined to remain. We were followed by a Security Guard on a Golf Cart who continuously and loudly stated, "Move along." This type of treatment is uncalled for under any circumstance. Be sure to turn around when possible and not ride to the end of the road. The entry we discovered is just around a curve, and you will be instructed to enter to be able to exit. The harsh treatment truly left a bad mark on me crossing seeing Mount Rushmore off my Bucket List.

Your NPS pass does not work here. The parking is owned by a public benefit organization that is not part of the NPS. They charge $11 for parking your personal automobile. The parking structure is divided into 6 sections, section 3 is closest to the entrance to the venue.

This was the reason for visiting South Dakota. We loved the monument, visitor's center and the hiking trail. Everyone must see the monument during the evening for the lighting ceremony. Made me proud to be an American. There is no fee except the $11 parking fee which is good for 7 days.

My boyfriend, parents, and I stopped here on our vacation. Whenever we got there, the rangers told us that we probably couldn't go to any of the trails because of them were washed out because of the rain. They also told us that the mosquitoes would eat us alive even if we put on bugspray. They gave us a map and highlighted the trails that we could probably attempt (the boardwalk trails) and told us to bring plenty of bugspray. Their mosquito meter was on "War Zone" and it wasn't lying. It was awful. If you stopped walking, you were swarmed and bitten a zillion times. When you weren't walking, they swarmed behind you. We walked to the lake and back on the boardwalk trail. We saw where other trails were completely washed out which was scary to think that snakes and other critters could possibly be on the trail. We did see a big snake on a log at the lake. We also saw a lizard in the water on our way back. The whole park is swamp which was nothing special since we are from Florida so we didn't see any "oooh" or "aaah" from it. I rate the park poor because the trails were washed out, it was just swampland, the mosquitoes were awful, and it was dangerous that snakes could be on the trails. There were mosquitoes in the bathrooms but other than that the bathrooms were clean. The visitor center was nice and had a museum and a small gift shop.

The Hawaii Volcanoes National Park is just awesome! Near the little village of Volcano you will find the entrance to the Visitor Centre.Fee is 10 dollars and is valid for several days, so keep the receipt. The main attraction is the crater of Kilauea, by the Jaggar Museum. The visitor centre has great exhibits, films, and ranger led programs, a hop and restrooms. The Ntl Park also includes Muna Loa and Mauna Kea, don't miss them!

An unusual national park in that the park intersperse within Harpers Ferry the town. Doesn't look like much until you start walking around and found that there were a lot to explore. Many displays tucked away and integrated with the historic building of the town. There's also rafting, tubing, or hiking opportunities in town. $10 gets you three days entry, day parking, and shuttle ride.

Visited Mammoth Cave with my husband and took the 2-hour historic tour. We reserved on-line about a week before we went, and from some other reviews, it sounds like it's a good thing we did. The historic tour entrance is walking distance from the visitor's center - no bus ride like some of the other tours. 2 hours sounded like a long tour, but the time passed very quickly and I was not bored in the least. Tour guide was extremely knowledgable and the cave was just fantastic. Not a whole lot of formations, but large, large rooms, and the history is very interesting. It is an amazingly big cave, though there are some sections on the tour where spaces narrow and ceiling heights come down. At 5'7" tall, I had to duck in places, particularly some of the stairways, and the "Fat Man's Misery" section is curvey and narrow from about the waist down (several of us on the tour had to pass through sideways) but it's a short section and everyone in the tour group (all sizes and body types) all fit through.
This is an awesome place to view, a must see. Pictures do not do it justice, in person it is awe-inspiring. Go see it!! I think we paid $12 for a carload?

Load your car full of people and pay the $11 to park! We left one car in Keystone and packed the whole group into one car. I see reviews about the parking fee, and it really could be worse--they could charge you to see the whole thing. There were 5 of us in the car, so really, it amounted to less than $3 a person. You can't beat that! It is something you are going to want to check out-- The sculpture is amazing, I love the entrance, it's beautiful and you get an overwhelming feeling of patriotism. We had fun finding our state along the pillars of flags, and loved the trail that gave you a different view of the sculpture. The gift shop was nice, and we had fun just hanging around and enjoying the scenery. Cough up the money for parking and check Mount Rushmore off your bucket list!

My husband and I were at Bryce Canyon National Park on July 27. We had purchased a one-year national parks pass and went to Grand Canyon, Bryce and Zion within 4 days. Bryce was by far my favorite!!! The landscape was amazing and best of all was the hiking trails were right near the lookout points. The ability to hike into the canyon really adds to the experience. Hike into a trail, even if you only have a couple hours to visit the park... Take Queen's Garden trail in to get an upclose look at the hoodoos, rock formations and dramatic scenery. Lots of trails to chose from and the guide tells you about their length and difficulty level. I would love to go back to Bryce Canyon NP to do more hiking and camp there. After spending just a few hours there, I'm a walking advertisement for this place. Me+Bryce= <3

My mother visited Crater Lake more than 50 years ago and has mentioned it many times since. Having heard her rave about it so many times, I had to swing by there while on a three week vacation to Washington and Oregon. It is everything that people say it is. Picturesque, serene, huge & surreal are just a few of the adjectives which describe our visit there. Admission is $5.00 per person or $10.00 a carload, but a national parks pass gets you in free. The senior pass is only $10.00 to purchase and gains admission for the holder and three other people at no additional charge. It is also valid at other national parks.

Me and my family went here, expecting to see the "great and beautiful Mt. Rushmore" but all we saw, was a big mountain with four little faces in a corner. We were all very disappointed, but we took some pics in order to show them to our friends. We stopped in a parking spot near to the street, and we jumped back into the car. Then, we decided to do a "u" inversion near to the entrance, but we couldn't, so we had to pay 11$ only to come back. The only reason why I think people should go there, are: 1) It is probably the most famous attraction in this zone (Even if I don't understand why) 2) It is so amaizing how people from that time period have built such a precise thing.

Add another absolutely gorgeous National Park to our long list. What a great place to explore & hike. We drove out to High Point & hiked to Warner Point. Wonderful, easy hike with awesome vistas. Made our way back to Visitor Center, stopping & hiking at most of the views. It's such a relaxing place. We did not have to deal with crowds of people. Enjoyed the Movie also. The next day we explored the canyon on the Gunnison River on the NPS Morrow Point Boat Tour. We had another fabulous day. The steps were fine. We expected them to be more difficult. It was a lovely walk to the boat ramp along the river. The boat tour was awesome. Fantastic scenery & a very informative presentation by the ranger. So glad we decided to experience this beautiful Park and we were able to use our NPS senior pass!
