I was in Key West last week and I heard about this trip. I asked my friend to go and he was scared of the price. I explained that the price is set at the level that is suitable for the adventure and he should not turn it down by that account.

Awesome place. Need two full days minimum - one to take your time on the Rim Drive and one to do the boat tour. No accommodations near the park so plan ahead to stay in the park, or you spend all your time driving back and forth. Limited food options, and expensive, but that is true for most National Park given the difficulty of getting supplies and the overhead of a contract with the US Government. Can see result of funding shortages - many blank interpretive signs on the rim drive. 10$ entry fee - we spend more than that for one person to go to a movie. They need to increase it to 25$ to help fund the park.

This place is excellent if you are a Lewis and Clark enthusiast or historical buff. They have people dressed up in period costumes and they have a life sized fort of L and C's winter encampment. If you have a year round NPS pass, this is included and they have many activities aimed at kids. This is a good place for the whole family
Great for the kids to see this and understand the magnitude of the monument. Can't go wrong for $11 per carload.

This site has much debate rather you should take the long 8 hr ride or the shorter rides. I highly recommend the long ride, now having said that I did not get boat sick (I took Dramamine)and it was a bright and clear day. I loved the ride going from island to island , the stops to see various birds including Bald eagles, sea otter, whales, and the Holgate glacier. well worth my time and cost. The boat had a nice lunch available and the crew was very attentive getting us food and delivering wine, soda and beer orders. Everyone aboard this trip had a wonderful time. Highly recommended.

This is so worth the cost of taking the 2.5 hour boat trip on the Yankee Freedom. You would not believe that you are off of the coast of Florida. The water is crystal clear blue green (see my profile photo). You would swear you were somewhere in the Caribbean.

We are history buffs. Driving from NYC to Dollywood for summer vacay and made a clear point to visit Andrew Johnson's NHS. Visitor Center is very good-rangers extremely helpful and clear. Video presentation delves into his presidency and conflicts with Congress. Johnson isn't one of the most remembered Presidents, but he not only ascended the presidency upon Lincoln's assassination, but also was the first (but sadly not the last) president to face impeachment. A remarkable time in office was preceded by an interesting life-no formal schooling, professional life was a tailor! The actually building that was his Tailor shop exists WITHIN visitor's center-incredible! His home is a time capsule of civil war life. He was extremely thrifty, dare I say cheap. Almost his entire family suffered from, and many died from tuberculosis. So many interesting and new things my family and I learned on this visit. The NHS consists of 3 free sites. All together very very good. Highly recommend!

Although the memorial is very impressive due to its huge size, going there is a waste of time. You can actually see the monument just as well from the viewpoint on the road from Keystone. Entrance is free but you have to buy a parking ticket for $11. I don't think I have spent 20 minutes at the place and have then seen it all. I can appreciate that Americans will feel different as this is a monument of four of their presidents. Being a tourist I have no such sentiments. Defacing the mountain like that remains questionable. Not worth the trouble and expense if you are not an American

Key West has this hidden Gem off its coast line that everyone must see at least once. You should book in advance to ensure a seat, and the 2.5 Hour one way Catamaran ride is very comfortable. The price includes a Continental breakfast as soon as you depart Key West. The vessel has comfortable seating both indoors and outside top/bottom deck. Once at the fort, the snorkeling and turquoise water is fantastic. Use sunscreen as you are guaranteed a nice burn for this full day of relaxation. A good sandwich lunch is also provided at the boat docked at the fort. For the return trip back to Key West, enjoy the daiquiris for sale on the Catamaran. The journey on this trip is as close to the Caribbean as you can get.

This park has exhibits as well as shops and restaurants, but all are small. We toured the entire park in half of a day, even looking at all of the exhibits and going in to all of the shops. One other thing- parking is horrible and if you go on the weekend expect to pay $10 for a tiny parking space up on a hill.

Denali, the mountain, finally started to appear, just as we needed to board the bus to Talkeetna and the train. The station is a small building on a long paved roadway about 1 hour away. We waited for the train about 55 minutes. We would have preferred to wait on the deck of the lodge and the beautiful vista than along a roadway with bus fumes. Boarding the train was easy as seats were already assigned. Had to show a photo ID to board. Drink service was at your seats. Meal service by appointment was downstairs. Live commentary for the entire trip by Helen. She had fun stories to tell. They did not allow the large camera bag on board with a couple of other larger rollies. They stowed them in a small compartment right by the door. We had Chena Club car – Row 16 ABCD. The car was actually Holland’s car, not Princess. So far the left side, seats AB, were the better side for sites along the river. The windows are large and you can see views from either side. The ride was fairly smooth and quiet with a large comfortable area for your legs and feet. There was the ability to climb over the person sitting next to you without disturbing them. We did notice that towards the back of the car it was nosier with plate/meal service noise. And towards the front the blender noise for mixed drinks was prominent. Abby was our drink server. Smoothies were $4.75 and very good. There is a total of 22 rows, 4 across.

A boat ride, an historic fort complete with cannons, and a boardwalk hike with guided readings...all for a donation!!!! The rangers all have wonderful stories to tell, and if you look it up, there are cannon firings and dressed soldiers! This is a wonderful park experience for kids of all ages....You do need to get a boat pass for a designated time so go early to guarantee your spot.

The $11 parking fee is a bargain. We spent several hours walking the grounds and learning about the carving process and history. The entire area is well designed for smooth flow of visitors. I would recommend avoiding the over-priced gift shop, restaurant and ice cream shop. We asked questions of several of the staff around the monument and they were extremely knowledgeable. Definitely a good visit.

...but the reality of the infrastructure they built around it is not for me. The model and talk about how it was created was pretty good, but the rest of the displays didn't really give you a good feel (updating the displays could do wonders). Parking was $11 and it doesn't matter if you have a parks pass or not. Truly fascinating that this could be made in the era it was, but not a little diminished by the buildings, etc. they've surrounded the cliff with.
Everyone needs to see Mount Rushmore at least once in their life. Try to plan to be there for the evening lighting ceremony. While there is no entrance fee, there is a parking fee.

This is a great place to visit...no matter who you are! The cave is expansive and beautiful. They have a variety of tours for you to choose from: from the basic "passage tour" you can take it you are just passing through town (I've done that one a couple times) and want to get a quick peek at the cave... to the adventure tours where you need full gear. We just took the "New Entrance" tour in August 2013. It's a great tour because it covers some of the features from two other tours. It gets chilly underground, so you may want to bring a sweater...even in the summer! And gym shoes because it can be damp and slick. The tours are cheap, and the guides are great. Unless you can't walk or handle the thought of being underground...I can't think of any reason not to go on a tour. There were folks of all ages on our tours and not once did anyone have a problem. You will be amazed by the sights you see.

Chaco Canyon has been on my bucket list for a very long time. We finally made the day trip out there from Albuquerque - about 3 hours one way. Best to go I-25 north to US 550 northwest, and then south on CR 7900 (just like they suggest). BUT . . . that dirt road at the end was brutal. I called in advance just to check if my Toyota Sienna minivan could make the trip. The woman who answered at the Visitor's Center told me she makes the trip in her Nissan Sentra. So we gave it a go. I would NOT do that again in our vehicle. I would make sure you go in a 4x4 or in something with superior suspension/shocks. The grading on the dirt road (the final 13 miles before entering the park) is so awful that it nearly rattled the teeth out of my skull. At times I could only go 5MPH because of the continuous, tiny bumps. I'm not exaggerating. The bumpiness was so bad that it rattled the DVD right off the ceiling of our car! So . . . getting past that, Chaco Culture Park is simply amazing. If you're into history, architecture, ancient culture, etc. then you MUST see Chaco Culture. $8 park entrance fee for one vehicle, good for a week. We brought our 3 very young kids and they had a blast. It's mostly safe for them to run around, especially within the maze-like complex itself. But keep an eye on the little ones because there are some spots where they could have a serious fall if they take the wrong step. I guess that advice is true for adults, too. I didn't realize it until after, but this could make for a fun overnight camping trip, too. Check with the visitor center for availability and price, but there are several camping spots available. You park inside the park and pitch your tent right there. There are toilets and running water, but nothing else. So be prepared to pack in your own food. To sum it up, Chaco Culture National Historic Park is amazing and we are so glad we finally made it.

My lady & I drifting towards the west coast. Had never heard of El Malpais before but we both like to hike so we thought we would stop in. Beautiful area...we hiked in the El Calderone area and for most of the time we were completely on our own. Caves, volcanic rock, cinder cones, trees, silence, birds. Magnificent way to spend a couple of hours. We were both amazed that there is no entrance fee for a National Monument - truly your tax dollars at work in a good way.

It was an awe inspiring site to see! Come during a clear sunny day to see it in the best light. The parking is 11.00 per vehicle but if you can hike up to it along the road from a nearby parking area (about a mile down the road behind the faces) you get in free since there is no charge to enter the park. The parking pass does last a year so you can come back for the lighting ceremony at night for free and see this amazing site. There's music and a ceremony at night. Worth coming to again. We didn't walk on the trails below the main area to the faces. We stayed on the paved paths at the top but we still enjoyed ourselves. Not much else to see here so it's a quick trip unless you visit the gift store and hang out there.

We took a cruise with Kenai fjords tours. It was expensive, $162 per person and included a sandwich and snack. It was a hazy day and rained,so sadly the view was compromised, but still, we saw plenty of animals, and an up close view of the glacier. The 6 hour cruise did have at least 1 hour in choppy waters. It was very cold to stand outside, but we braved it for photo ops. The competition offers a salmon and prime rib buffet for $20 more. I don't know how I could eat that with the choppy waters...Suggest dramamine before just in case. They pick you up at the train station and drop you off afterwards wherever you need in town. Very friendly staff. Not sure if worth the cost. But, a fun day overall. They also offer 4, 5 and 7 hour cruises.

Bryce Canyon is amazing and fascinating and composed of the most weird and intriguing rock structures we've ever seen. Mother nature had paint brushes flying when she designed this canyon with its wildly beautiful reds, rusts, golds and oranges on natural bridges & all kinds of strange rock formations called Hoodoos. These tall, thin spires of rock protruding from the bottom of the canyon are also called tent rocks, fairy chimneys & earth pyramids. There's wonderful hiking everywhere and amazing photo ops from down below and above. Signs remind you to watch your kids (and pets) as the cliffs are sharp & steep. This canyon is so unique, it's a must see for all including the kiddos. It does require a park pass and seniors get a lifetime all park pass for $10. You can pay by the car/person/day or annual all park pass (recommended).

This park is beautiful, especially in the fall. With white water rafting, swimming, tubing and the Appalachian Trail running through it and restaurants nearby. There is always something to do. There is limited parking in the lower part of the park for $10 or you can go back up the hill to the visitor center and park for $10 and ride the shuttle down for free. If you arrive late in the day on a Saturday be prepared to park free at the visitors center, but know that many attractions close before 5pm and the last shuttle goes back up to the visitors center at 6:45pm. So be prepared to walk back to your car on a dirt path, or watch the clock and get on that shuttle. Be sure to walk out towards the water and visit shops with many unique gifts and find many restaurants and ice cream shops. We will definitely be back, although I really wish that at least during the summer months, everything should stay open and running later.

It was truly amazing to see the work of art. We enjoyed the movie and all displays. Nice looking cafeteria that we did not use. We went early in the morning and returned at night. The night lighting and program touches the heart. One annual parking fee is all we paid. Reasonable.

We really enjoyed our visit to Mt Rushmore especially the lighting ceremony. It made us proud to be Americans! A short film is shown before the ceremony begins highlighting the most significant events of each of the four president's terms. At the closing all veterans and active duty military are asked to come down and help with lowering the colors. Then each member gave his name and branch of service. Really glad we went! Only fee was a $11 parking fee. Stop if you get the chance, you won't be sorry!!
was great to see, the trail was fun and informative. Any age can do it. something to see once. You have to pay to park but the attraction does not have a cost.

This is truly an amazing feat of man. We origially saw it from needles highway as we came through a tunnel; but don't stop to take picture as you might cause a bad accident. Just go to the memorial. I had a senior pass to see this but was charged $10 parking fee which I was very unhappy about. I saw a lot of people taking pictures from the side of the road outside the park and basically saw what we saw. It is not the $ it is the principal. We saw a video while we were there and that helped ease the pain. LOL.

Nice day trip, 2.5 hrs, boat very smooth and we had pretty nice weather. Boat seemed to move quicker than we imagined. Breakfast began shortly after boarding and consisted of cold breakfast, bagels, butter, jam, fruit, lunch meat, coffee, juice, hard boiled eggs, good for cold breakfast and had plenty to eat, wished they would have had toaster for bagels or toast as they aren't too good cold. We were a little disappointed in only having a few hrs on island to explore and snorkel, after a very short tour with the guide of the Fort, we felt we didn't have time enough to even walk all around the fort if we wanted to snorkel and also had to return to the boat before 1pm to eat lunch.. Had hoped to be able to walk all around the fort and in the office there, ran short of time as we wanted to snorkel. Snorkeling not so good outside of the pilings around the fort. Pilings had quite a bit of coral to see and we saw a larger tarpon and Permit fish along with many very small fish. I guess we expected a little more brilliance in the fish and those we did see were very small. A few said they had seen some larger fish. Area around pilings is the best place to see anything. It's approx. 5-9 ft would recommend that inexperienced swimmers use a vest provided by boat to help keep them above water. Waves kept bouncing us back and forth around pilings so it was hard to get good underwater pictures and hard not to get pushed into the pilings at times. The guide was fairly fast on tour of the fort, however they do not go around the entire fort and if you want to explore the fort you must do so within the few remaining hours. We left feeling we did not get to see all of the fort, it's shop, etc. Arrived island approx. 10:30, obtained snorkel gear and then guided tour of fort, this all took almost 1 hour so approx. 11:30 we felt we had better eat before snorkeling so we wouldn't have to rush back before 1pm. If you didn't eat by 1pm there was no food later. Good decision to eat right after tour as bulk of the crowd returned to eat approx. 12pm. Longer line to get food, fewer tables, etc. After lunch felt we only had approx. 2 hours to snorkel or explore as had to turn in snorkel equipment, change clothes, board by 2:30. We enjoyed the trip and would recommend it to others. Staff on boat were helpful and all very cordial. If I had to do again, not sure if I'd go again, but if so I may opt for the Sea Plane as it is only about $100 more and may provide more time on the island and believe it would be beautiful to see from the air. Lunch was also good, cold sandwiches, fruit, chips, cookies, salads, etc. Plenty to eat with decent variety of meats, drinks, etc. Wish lunch could be served on return trip to not eat into time on island. All personnel were very helpful, cordial, etc. On return trip they sell drinks, cocktails, frozen drinks, beer, some snacks but all to be paid for to include soda and water. Frozen drinks about $7. Bring change of clothes if you want, dressing rooms on island and the boat has outdoor showers to rinse off. It was nice to change to dry clothing for ride back. Sun is bright and suggest sunscreen. We enjoyed the trip just wish it was a longer day. We thought it was expensive, but figured that breakfast and lunch would have cost about $15-$20 each meal, snorkel rental, and boat ride, I guess if you look at it that way it is not so bad and it is something you most likely will only do once unless you are fortunate to be able to camp on the island. I think that would have been the best way to see it. If you have the time I would recommend doing a few day camping trip.

As always, I recommend starting with the visitors center video. The video gives tons of information to help understand what you will be seeing. We arrived just in time to catch the trolly tour which was very informative then went back to see the video. We then walked along the canal to the other sites. There is a charge to get into the factory but it was well worth it (I found it to be a highlight). Also enjoyed the boarding house. We asked several questions of the rangers throughout and as always I was impressed on their level of knowledge.

I am amazed at the dedication of people who built the monument....One has to see Mt. Rushmore at least once in their lifetime. The whole area is wonderful. I thank Teddy R. for keeping this area for the American People...the world. No fee to see the monument, but there is a fee for parking.

Incredible - stunning views. The park was very quiet at opening, but was busy by noon. You can drive in and park at the various scenic points, but there is not that much parking. If you are traveling solo, park at the shuttle parking just outside of the park and use the regular shuttles. Instead of $25 to take my car in, I only paid $12! Couples or families might also want to consider taking the shuttle – parking within the park looked to be a bit tight by noon.

The Grand Tetons mountain range are beautiful and rugged. Go to the park. Go to Jenny Lake and take the hour boat ride. The ranger that gives the tour will tell you about how the park came to be and the intrepid explorers of the area. Worth price of admission!!

As a UK citizen I do so wish that we presented our parks and monuments they way the Americans do. Even more so the charges that we seem to make but they don't. We were there for about 2 hours, 4 of us in the car and parking was $10. No admittance fee was charged. A free shuttle bus to the 'wall' about every 20 minutes. The wall and exhibits were incredible. A quite enjoyable 2 hours. Teenagers in the party thoroughly enjoyed it to.
Amazing drives up and down mountains! Scarry if you don't like heights! The Red Mountain Pass to Silverton is incredible! Very beautiful!

everyone should visit if they can possibly do so. While you can actually see the mountain carving from the road, you really should pay the $11 per car parking fee and visit the very informative visitor center.

Highly recommended. My wife and I went on the 8hr trip with the dinner stop at Fox Island. The Captain Tiffany and crew were very good. We saw sea otters, eagles, humpback and killer whales, porpoises, huge glaciers, puffins, harbor seals, stellar sea lions, etc, etc. Well worth your time & $.

Our party of 6 took the multi-hour round trip on the boat. They served food and drinks on both legs. Service on the boat was very good. The guided tour of the fort was professionally done by a knowledgeable, enthusiastic guide. Our kids snorkeled around the fort. The Gulf water was quite chilly, they need to do something about that. All-day trip, not cheap, but worth the money.
We've been here 4 times and the newest renovation is wonderful. The parking garage is great even though they charge $11 per car which includes admission. The visitors center is very informative.

I paid for the trolley tour of $16. It was not the best tour that I have had but I recommend it. Most people did not tip but I did. We had a full trolley car and one woman had her lap dog with her that was quite annoying! This park is free otherwise. It gives insight on how we came to be what we are today. Also, reminds us of our history and how very very smart our forefathers were setting foundations in place that pulled us together as one nation.

A visit to the Redwood National Park is a must. It brings all your senses back to reality after a visit to SF. It shows the grandure and grace of nature juxtaposed to the man made grandure of the Golden Gate Bridge and the vibrancy of San Francisco. If you arrive before 9:00 a.m. entrance is free. After 9:00 a.m., $7 for adults. Paths for easy strolls around the base of the redwoods and paths for hikes half way up and higher than the 300 foot giants. This is my second visit. Will go every time I'm in the area.

If you are interested in Cave Dwellings and can't get to Mesa Verde the Tonto dwellings are a perfect substitute. Located East of Phoenix in a beautiful area the Tonto Dwellings overlook Lake Roosevelt. They are easy to get to, just a short hike from the parking lot and you can enter into them being careful not to climb or touch walls. The entrance fee is $3.

A highly educational stop in St. Augustine and a break from the unrelenting tourist trap of the downtown, this is a good place to go for a few hours. Try to catch the cannon firing, a drawn out ritual. The fort is well preserved and gives an great sense of what it was like to be here in the various national periods. Excellent displays and a good place to go before it gets too hot, it is free on your senior national parks pass.

This national monument offers some spectacular views and if your intention is to visit each bridge via your car and view them from the overlooks you will probably rate it higher than an average. However I would still recommend you at least walk down to each bridge as they each look far more spectacular when viewed from below rather than above. If however you want to hike the park there is a 8.6 mile loop trail which starts at Sipapu Bridge parking area. The 0.6 mile trail down to the bridge is steep, but has steps,ladders and rails - at the bottom the views are awesome. The trail then meanders alongside the stream, crossing it several times. The route was not well defined and in a number of places seemed to just disappear. If you persevere you will in 2.3 miles be rewarded with views of the Kachina Bridge - again spectacular. The trail goes under the bridge and up the left side of the canyon. It appears you are walking out towards the Kachina trailhead, but the trail does kick right back down into the canyon, this time following the stream in Armstrong Canyon. Again it meanders alongside the stream, crossing several times, it is not well defined and has very limited cairns. After about 1.5 miles the trail plunges into a deep part of the stream (thigh high the day we hiked) as we hadn't really been prepared for it and wasn't wholly sure this was the correct route we searched for alternatives for a while before turning back and exiting at Kachina trailhead. On our way back towards Kachina we passed a German family and advised them of the lack of defined trail and deep stream. They continued. We then visited the last bridge after making our back to Sipapu trailhead to collect our car. The hike down to Owachomo Bridge is short and relatively easy although I wouldn't recommend flip flops! Again the views are magnificent. At the bridge we met the German family who had waded thigh high through the stream, got lost a bit more and finally made it to the last bridge.

DH had never been to Mt Rushmore. I had not been since the early 70s and has it changed. It's more commercialized, of course. You pay for parking, but entry is free. Lots of shopping options if you want to buy trinkets. There is a made in the US section. The cafeteria is pricey with not many healthy options.

Great tour, very informative. Makes you realize the historic importance of the decisions made then and longevity of our constitution. Go early if you want to about wait. We had 10:00 am free ticket but wee were there early and were able to get into 9:30 tour. Do visit the other wing that is not part of conducted tour to view the historic documents. We were at Liberty Bell at 10:30 and didn't have to wait in lines at all. Aim to spend 30 minutes reading related material before you actually get to the bell.

Wonderful to visit Mount Rushmore during the day...the drive and seeing it as you approach is excellent. Once you're there...wow! The Visitor Center is great...so much to see and learn. And, a couple of nice gift shops. Your pass is good for more than one day...so, be sure you return in the evening for the lighting and evening program. I don't think there was a dry eye in the entire place the evening we were there. The program is so wonderful and just so moving...only an hour in length but so worth it and something not to be missed! Excellent, excellent, excellent!

Mother nature at it's unspoiled best. This is a refuge that is free of cell phone service. Super clean air. The lake is so absolutely clear that the color is out of this world. This is a rural, national park, with great effort to keep it as pristine as possible. Appropriately, it is two hours from the nearest freeway. Views are fantastic and the rim drive is a good example of Civilian Conservation Corps construction from the 1930's. Spend some time to explore the park. There is a new, free and good video at the visitor center near park headquarters. There are lots of hiking opportunities, including one to the lake for guided boat tours (Advance reservations are required.) The facilities are classic and include the lodge with a spectacular view. The Lodge restaurant is expensive, $20-30 per person. The rim Cafe is $5-10 for very simple fare and prepackaged food. At Mazama village, 7 miles from the rim, there is a campground, restaurant ($10-15 per plate), cabin motor inn, small general store and gas station. If you can, attend a ranger talk at the campground amphitheater This is higher elevation 5-7,000 feet and the snow remains through July. So, take appropriate clothing; e.g. jacket for cool evenings in August. The lake can be clouded in often from fall through late spring. Often the "fog" doesn't burn off til mid afternoon. Winter time visitors need to be aware that one entry is closed. Check their website.

I chose to visit Mammoth Cave as it was mid-way on a road trip. I bought my ticket online ahead of time for the "Historic Tour". The visitor center is beautiful with large, clean bathrooms. The tour guide was very punny (a mix of groans and laughs). But was very knowledgeable. The tour lasted the full hour and we wound around a number of passages. I would say the physical ratings of the tours are pretty true. This one was rated moderate. Most of the walking was fairly easy, it was the 150 stair climb back out. I can't wait to go back and take others of the tours.

We brought the entire family (23+ pp ages 8-77). The area is very green but there is a lot of walking so I recommend bringing water bottles. We enjoyed some root beers from the old fashioned gift shop/general store. There was also a few people dressed in period clothes and one guy riding a wooden sled pulled by two horses. A few of the people in our group went apple picking for $1/lb. The apples were small and tart, but they had fun nonetheless.

My wife and I were on the road, passing through Springfield. We took a short break and visited the Lincoln home ( took the house tour ). All of the logistics of parking, getting a ticket for the house tour and actually seeing the house were easy and convenient. The ranger showing us the house was knowledgeable and friendly. Kudos to the Park Service they have done a nice job as usual. If you are in the area, I highly recommend stopping by. Next time I'll visit the Lincoln Library.

I was so surprised at the majesty of these rock carvings. They really are quite amazing. The kids really enjoyed doing the Junior Ranger program and were rewarded with a badge at the end of it. Keep your parking pass (good for a week) as you may want to go back to see the lighting of it at 8pm, or just do the hike one day and hang out another.

Amazing! Hike the hoodoos! There are three trails the Navajo Sandstone Loop, The Queen's Garden Trail, and Mossy Cave. If you hike all the way down it then you will see a board saying "Hike The Hoodoos". Take a picture with you next to the board for at least two of the trails and earn an awesome pin as a souvenir. Those trails are the climax of the park and are must sees. I would not recommend it for families with children under 8 years old. They should be mature enough to not play around as if you joke around you can fall off the cliff. You should be fine if cautious. They have overlooks for the hoodoos which are breathtaking and beautiful. I suggest this place. Stay at the lodge if you go here, you can we the most and it is worth a little increase in price.

We have visited the Durango area many times and always spend some time up in the mountains. The scenery is spectacular and the opportunities for outdoor activities are unlimited. If you enjoy hiking, consider the Pass Creek trail. The trailhead is located very near the Coal Bank Pass rest area on highway 550. It is a high altitude and fairly steep trail (2300 feet in elavation gain) but after only about 2.6 miles you are near the base of Engineer Mountain and rewarded with amazing views in all directions. If you are more adventurous you can continue on a much steeper rocky trail to the summit of the mountain. We were there on Labor Day weekend so the trail was fairly busy but I imagine at other times (especially during the week) it is not very crowded. It is appropriate for older children who are used to hiking but not for younger ones. Please be aware that it is a strenuous hike at a high altitude so you should have a decent level of fitness before attempting it.

What a nice surprise. We came across this memorial as we were in the area with some extra time. I was surprised how much of my Indiana History I had forgotten. This is a very interesting place to visit. Entrance fee was low, just $5 for two. Make sure you watch the 15 minute film. It puts everything in context.
Our fascinating trip started at 10 AM and we were back by 5 pm. The cost was $60 and well
Pros: cast demonstration, well preserved water wheel, apple picking ($1=1LB), nice rangers and no fee entrance.

At the quarry you can see many dinosaur fossils, they are very impressive; you visit will take between an hour and no longer than two. As you arrive at the visitor center you can take a free shuttle to the quarry, about a mile away There is a trail from the quarry to the visitor center, about 1.2 miles, very easy and beautiful surrounding and you can explore some fossils at some rock walls, use the trail from Quarry to the Visitor Center.; the other way around is a steep incline. Park entrance is $10.00

This was our first trip to Mount Rushmore and we loved it. Dress for the weather, wear your walking shoes & bring a camera (smartphone cameras work well). There's no entrance fee and parking is $11 per car. The lot was full but we found a great parking space near the entrance anyway. The monument is amazing, huge and a must-see! The area is pristine with trails, tall trees, lots of greenery (we're from Arizona), an educational center, amphitheater-like area, state flags and magnificent views. It's a photographer's dream. We learned so much about our history and each president, too. There is an Ice cream shop & cafe & a gift shop. Steps & an elevator, too. As we drove through town, there was a motorcycle event going on and it was an awesome sight. I would recommend this trip to everyone! This visit was on my bucket list. And, we did it all in about five hours! http://www.nps.gov/moru/planyourvisit/feesandreservations.htm
Great tour guides, very knowledgeable. Free tickets at the visitor's center. The Liberty Bell, also free, no ticket needed is across the street.

We spent a lot of time at Valley Forge since it was of special interest to my boyfriend. As it was August and the weather was hot, we opted for buying the vehicle CD (about $15) and driving the park and stopping at the sites instead of one of the bus tours. The CD was quite informative and gave exact directions as long as you followed the 15 mph speed it suggested. We were ahead or behind on it but got back on track by pausing or sitting in the car a few minutes. There can be a lot of walking involved if you get out at each stop to walk around. Most areas are pretty pedestrian friendly. I happen to have asthma, so walking back up the hill to the parking area would have been asking for an attack if I had been alone, however, my boyfriend walked to the top parking area and brought the car down to pick me up. There is a cute little gift shop where you can get a hotdog and drink behind Washington Memorial Chapel, but otherwise, refreshments are pretty sparse until you leave the park. There is a covered bridge on the route that I suggest you cross and see some of the homes on that road, go as far as the park sign and turn around to come back. Some of them were used as headquarters and are not on the main cd tour but can be seen on the park service map (which you should get at the visitors center from a ranger). Overall, it was a very nice park. Most areas with buildings close at 5 or 6pm, so when we arrived on Fri and went to the park, we only had a short time to explore before things closed, but did a quick tour and went back on Monday to spend the day. It was nice knowing where things were before the deep exploration on Monday.
$18 per nite plus Park entry fee($20)

On a recent road trip through CA, I decided to add our nation's newest national park to my stops. I made a reservation at the campground (east side), and was pleasantly surprised to discover that the fee was $26/night instead of $35+up at most CA state parks. I went in mid-July, and a reservation was far from necessary. There were very few people there, and there are plenty of camping spots. However, sites range from small to large, from totally secluded to totally exposed and from totally private to neighbors in your pocket. Here are some thoughts:

Could not get 10 feet into the water. Jellyfish everywhere. Multiple people were stung - one boy 4 times just trying to get to the reef. My girls, 9 & 10, wouldn't go into the water. The snorkeling trip was supposed to be the highlight of our trip and it was a HUGE disappointment!!! No one warned us. Probably because they wanted our $700!

If you have extra $$ It is worth the seaplane ride to the park. It is an island prison,whos only prisoner was Dr. Mudd, who treated Lincoln's assassinator. The plane will provide snorkel gear and te waters are clear and teaming with topical fish. On the flight to the island you can see tortugas (giant turtles) swimming in the sea. Sharks and other giant fish are also viible from above. The planes hold 6 people

A 21/2 hr. boat trip each way with 5 hrs or so on an island occupied by a huge historic fort/prison and nothing else. Tour the prison/walk around the island(its very small)/go swimming and/or snorkeling. Breakfast and lunch are included in the $169 per person price and are nothing special. The crew is great, very helpful and informative. Snorkeling gear is also included and was very good. The snorkeling was much better than I anticipated. We snorkeled with a 5 foot tarpon for a while and saw some great coral/sponges and fish including jellyfish and little cuttlefish or squid. The cost is high but its a once in a lifetime type of thing.

Originally we were going to take the ferry, but I talked my husband into the sea plane - so glad I did! I think 4 hours on the island would have been a bit much, plus with the plane (we did the afternoon trip) the boat was leaving just as we were arriving so we had the island to ourselves (10 on the plane plus a few campers). The snorkeling was amazing, definitely worth the expense of getting there, although we had some jellyfish to contend with. 2 hours was plenty of time to explore and snorkel.

My wife and I went on a cruise that included 7 days on a Nowegian ship with 6 more days on land . There were so many high points that it's not easy to be brief. The inside passage included so many great sites, Ketchikan, Juneau, Skagway, and Whittier. Glacier Bay, the Hubbard Glacier, at the stop in Skagway, we rode the train up Chillkoot Pass, retracing the trail that the many prospectors took on the way to the gold fields in the gold rush of 1898, 99. The crown jewel of the six days that we were on the land part of the tour was, for me Denali Park. What an immense park it is, and if one is fortunate, a view of Denali itself, capps a 60 mile ride into this absolute jewel. 30 percent of the visitors to the park get to see this huge mountain. Denali is the largest mountain on earth. Everest is taller as everyone knows, but in terms of mass, Denali is the biggest mountain on this planet.

We were on an RV trip to Alaska (2nd time we've done this in 2 years!) in July 2013 when we decided to camp a few days in Denali. While out the park is VERY commercial- hotels,rafting businesses, restaurants, tourist trinket shops etc.- the park itself is outstanding. Unlike most national parks, Denali doesn't freely allow visitors beyond the 10 mile marker with private conveyance. If you want to go further into the park (and closer to Mt. McKinley (or Mt. Denali as the local indigenous population call it) there is a fee to allow access to interior campsites or via NP buses to sites. We tried to see Mt. McKinley via their 9 hour r/t "tour" but it waass a rainy day and we couldn't see it at all. We did see it for free on our way down to Anchorage....it was SPECTACULAR !.

We loved Mammoth Cave. The park is small and other than cave tours, those who aren't all that "outdoorsy" may not find much to do, but it's beautiful and the cave tours are worth the visit even if you do nothing else. We did the Historic Tour. I was a little worried because I'm a more-than-chunky guy at 5'7" and 230 pounds (38" waist), but I had no trouble at all fitting through the tight parts of the tour. I was a little worried about stairs since I'm out of shape, but even there, it's not too taxing for most people. Unless you struggle with stairs ordinarily (knee problems, very low stamina), I would say if you can handle an ordinary pace up a few flights of stairs, you will be okay. There are 155 steps at one point (in flights of maybe 10-15 steps each flight), but the pace is fairly slow on these as there are so many people taking them at once. If you are worried about being slow there, try to get to the front of the pack and you can allow people to pass you on the way up. At the end of that climb, you enter a cavern full of benches and sit to rest for several minutes while the Ranger talks; the average person won't need the rest, but for the few who might have trouble with the stairs, I suspect that's helpful.

We found this attraction very interesting, although there was not a lot to see or do. A movie and museum (interesting on the history) were on the premises, as well as the standard gift shop and snack bar/restaurant. Parking ($25) was near, very convenient and plentiful. Other than the figurines, there was not much else to do or see. I believe you could see everything in less than an hour, if you so desire.

Ah, I always read the negative reviews and consider them. I took away the idea that the parking fee was unfair; the surrounding structures were garish, and the carving blocked from external viewing due to the money-grubbing erection of buildings to force your payment.

At the time visited (January, 2013) I was a little miffed because I considered the $11:00 parking fee excessive for that time of year but I didn't realize that it was a years pass and as it turned out worth every cent.

We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the monument. I was thinking it might be cheesy but it is very well done. The grounds are beautiful, the cafe has tasty and not overly priced food (and good espresso drinks), the monument itself is very impressive, and the rangers were very helpful and welcoming. Enjoyed our visit very much! We went in the afternoon and the faces on the mountain were shadowed, so we went back in the early morning (parking pass is good for the year) to see - would definitely recommend orienting your schedule to see it in the morning when the sun shines brightly on the faces!

This is our second trip here and so glad to stop again as the monument is so amazing. The information area is very easy reading and helps to appreciate the dream of the sculptor and what an achievement this was.Free entrance but parking fee. We were there late afternoon after Labor Day and no crowds at all.
Super busy place. It’s free to get in but parking is $ 11 and not really worth it for the 10 minutes you’re there. If you’re in the area you might as well stop but don’t make a special trip for it.

This should be listed as one of the wonders of the world. Totally breath taking and the most spectacular national park we visited. More spectacular than the Grand Canyon and the colours are beyond belief. One visit was not enough, buy a season national park pass and visit as much as you can. Even the wild animals were pleased to see us and posed for pictures.

It is one of the smaller monuments. Really only a small building and a place to pay to get in. I think it was $4 each to go in. They had some Native Americans dancing - that was fun, and the view was terrific. It is high up in the mountains. It was August but it hailed while we were there and it was a little chilly. You may need a jacket.

We arrived in the area late afternoon and before visiting the monument took some time to drive around the area. We booked a hotel in Hill City SD and it was about a 15 mile drive to the monument and Keystone SD. The towns were small and reminded me of movie sets at places. There are plenty of campgrounds and numerous hotels in the area. We visited the monument in the evening/night and then again in the morning. There was a parking fee of $11 but it was good for the same car until the end of the year.

Beautiful by day, touching by night. You have to stay or come back for the lighting ceremony. You parking ticket fee can be used throughout the day; meaning you can come back as many times as possible without repaying for parking. Otherwise entrance is free.

The campground is beautiful and we enjoyed the three day weekend. There are no showers but flush toilets & potable water. We tent camped and while we were away from our site one afternoon, & upon our arrival another vehicle was parked on our site & put up their tent. Our pole was clearly marked & stated paid with the three nights & our one picnic table, tent & grill was all set up. We got the host to our site & then the intruders drove up-the host told them they had to leave. Upon putting their tent down-they cursed at us & told us "now we can invite our friends". The campground had empty sites yet they wanted to piggyback & get not pay $10 for a night.Same thing happened the next day. We were very sad that people are doing this in this national park. the host told us 20% of people do not pay their way!

We visited here on our way to Monterey on Saturday August 31st. We drove to the East side first and wasn't too impressed but then again we didn't hike the many trails as it was hot and not shaded. We then decided to drive to the West entrance where we saw more rock formations. We again didn't hike the many trails as it was in the mid afternoon and the weather was in the 90's. I hear the trails have some good sights to see but go early in the morning when it is cool. We only paid $5 and it was good for both sides.

This was my first experience in a cave, and what an experience it was. Because we went during the off-season our group was smaller than normal, and we made a few extra stops on the tour. Our guide Lydia was very knowledgeable, articulate, and had great stories to share being an explorer of Jewel Cave herself. Expect to see lots of crystal formations, and jewel like formations. The scenic tour itself is well planned with railings, stairs, lighting and concrete paths making it appropriate for people of all ages. The caverns are very, very large, so no real worries of claustrophobia. Being a government run sight means the entry fee is nominal. Lots of free parking, a little gift shop, interpretive display, and clear directional signage to get there. Check the website ahead of time for tour schedules to plan your trip. Bring your camera, but please leave the flash at home or warn people ahead of time when photographing with the flash to avoid temporarily blinding them.
This place has changed a lot in 20+ years. Neat to no know why these people were chosen. Ice Cream on site is some of the best ever - not cheap but about the best ever!

This is an AMAZING monument, and to me, illustrates the incredible vision and fortitude of people. We went during the off season so it wasn't too crowded, and the day we had was beautiful and clear. The drive up was lovely, and the sight itself provided lots of covered parking, audio tour, a large gift shop, eatery, lots of clean washrooms, drinking fountains, and a walking trail that gets you closer to Mount Rushmore itself. Be sure to visit the sculptor's studio to learn more about Borglum. Be sure to bring your camera and extra memory cards, sunblock, a hat, and drink lots of water to combat the heat. Parking fee: $11USD. Fee also covers any re-entry into the park for the rest of the year.

Red color of the rock is almost unreal. Stunning vistas at every turn. National Park Service at its best. Guided ranger tours and talks. Hiking trails for all levels, beginner to hard core hikers. Great maps to navigate the park/canyon. National Parks have a life time entry permit for seniors for $10. Best deal around!

I was not really interested in the long drive from downtown to the volcano, but once we got closer it was pretty amazing. You can smell the gas before even entering the park which made me a little uncomfortable. When we were there the volcano was quite active and parts of the park were closed from the smoke. It was definitely a cool experience and we took some really amazing pictures of the crater. There are also a few rainforest walking trails which are also pretty neat. Even just driving though parts of the park (i.e going from volcanic to rain forsest) is pretty cool. Worth the trip. Be sure to bring some snacks, water and get gas because there is not a lot along the way. You also have to pay a small fee to enter the national park.

Never have I seen so much wilderness, terrain change, wild animals and a road barely wide enough to pass. Simply have to be amazed that someone had the forethought to preserve all that land. Hopefully it will still be there when my great-great-great grandkids visit it. Worth every penny that it cost me, to see what an amazing place in this world this is, waiting to show off survival in so many ways.

This was a highlight of the trip. We took the boat ride around crater lake which was about 2 hours in length. The cost was definitely worth it!. The hike down was approx 1 mile and had plenty great opportunities for amazing shots. The ride itself was an open face boat with about 30 other people and a guide with driver. The guide had a microphone so you could here all the fantastic details as we went around the lake. He also took time in between to answer any other questions. The hike up was a bit gnarly, but with frequent stops and taking our time, we managed to the top. Great for couples, families with older children and friends - or even solo!

Start at the Visitor's Center where friendly and enthusiastic staff will guide you as to where to go. We went south a mile first, for the longer of the petroglyphs walks. The sandy trail makes walking a little sluggish, and definitely don't war open toe footwear. There are lots of petroglyphs, and most are quite faint; only a couple of other visitors on the trail, but we went midday, which (in summer/early fall) would not recommend. We then went to the smaller city-operated site north of the Visitor's Center, small fee without Park Service pass. Lot less petroglyphs, fading, and because there are no interpretations, takes a lot out of what could be an informative look into the ancient past. Supposedly, current native Americans (1) won't reveal the meanings for religious reasons, and/or (2) don't agree upon the interpretations, and/or (3) don't the meanings. Regardless, adding even guesses or conflicting interpretations would turn a boring, uninformed hike into a cultural awakening, and to me is a huge missed opportunity for the current Pueblo people.

This is one of the "must see" sites in America, particularly early in the morning or in the evening. No entrance fee, but $11.00 for parking, which is good for an annual pass, if you want to return another time in the year. Early morning light provides excellent shadows for photos, rather than the wash-out that occurs mid-day. With evening comes a lighted opportunity of the monument, adding artificial sparkle. Take time to visit the designer's studio to learn more about the history and fabrication efforts of the monument.

Mount Rushmore is one of those American attractions that everyone should see once in their lifetime. Set in the Black Hills the drive to the monument is just as incredible as the monument itself. It will cost you $11 to park but its worth it. We did not have much time to be there but I would recommend taking 2-3 hours to do the trails around the monument. You won't be disappointed.

This is one place you have to see. I've seen this place in advertisements, movies and photos but you have to see it in person to appreciate the amount of work involved and the Beauty of this landmark. $10 entry fee to park but its well worth it. Beautiful viewing area and good place for photo ops and a walkway that takes you right up to the base of the mountain. Very patriotic feeling when you are there. The monument is also lit up at night til 10 pm. Take binoculars to view the faces and you would be amazed how much detail and how finished the faces are. Park is well maintained and staff was friendly and helpful. You could tell they enjoyed their jobs.

Took the tour last year and I'm glad I did, this place is the real deal, it happened here and if your an American, don't miss the chance to see the place our great country was born. If you don't get something out of a visit to Independence National Historical Park then something is wrong with you. It is all a lot smaller than I had envisioned, but happened here is really big, be sure and take a carriage ride the Historic District, the carriage drivers are very knowledgeable and it's worth the $'s all in all I would do it again, the Liberty Bell is also a great place to visit, it's right across the street.

The one day Bryce Canyon and Zion National Park tour from Las Vegas is a long day, but well worth it, especially if you are short on time. Bryce Canyon is spectacular, and if you have a lot of time to spend, you may want to book an over-night trip. I had limited time in Vegas and wanted to see Bryce and Zion National Parks. They did not disappoint. The one-day trip hit the high-lights of both parks. Bryce has several points around the amphitheater that are accessible from the tour bus. Most of Zion is accessible only by park shuttle, which we were told runs frequently in the summer, but the tour bus drove by Checkboard Mountain which lived up to its name. Google Bryce Canyon Tours to find different tour companies offering the one-day trip. I would love to go back and visit both parks when I have more time to spend, but this tour hit the highlights. The park fees were included in the tour price.

This is a gem of Northern California scenic places to visit. It was a labor day weekend, we 3 families stayed in one of Trinidad's vacation rental (Retro Retreat $900) for 3 nights, we planned for 2 but the minimum was 3, in fact it turned out to be good other wise it would have been a exhaustive trip. On Day one we just roam around Trinidad, beaches, light house, Paticks Point, once passing Patricks point there is an RV park and old school museum where they do have a community music band and free food (you can donate $$ for the food) on weekends, we had great burgers and coffee, then proceed to Gold Bluff's Beach. It's a 20-30 minutes drive through the woods, slight rough roads and small creeks you can drive through. You need to walk down to see the fern canyon and water falls which is a mind refreshing experience, I would suggest plan for an afternoon at this place. We didn't that much time so we spent some time at fern canyon and didn't reach to falls as it was farther and park hours are about to close for the day. We had a close encounter with Elks at this place. Day two we took south to visit shrine drive through tree as we didn't know there was another one in Klamath, so that we could visit drive through tree and trees of mystery in one trip.It turned out to be good as this place has few parking spots inside the park. Even though the tree is supported by the cables and it's leaned to one side. It's not a tall tree, it's a hollow tree vertically (been cut off) and horizontally where you drive through.They are saying that the trunk of the tree has been burned off and fall down ~100 ft from the level. Tree is still alive and it has leaves and branches as well. I visited the leget drive through tree as well, more or less you 'll get the same feeling as you drive through the tree, if you expecting for a fully sized tree from top to bottom, it's not what it is. We still had time to spent but not enough to reach Klamath for visiting trees of mystery. So we took a tour through avenue of gaints and swim at one of the river passing near by. You can drive in to river and park next to the water. The water was not that cold too. We spent some time playing with water, and refreshing swim. Then we visited the one of the beaches at Crescent, it was early evening and a bit cold but kids enjoyed it's fullest as the beach is more of sandy than muddy. On day 3 we went to visit trees of mystery at Klamath, we could have do both day 2 and 3 in one day if we went to Klamath on day 2. On our way back we took a stop at Carson Mansion which is a really great place to visit.

We thought about the long drive and went anyway. It is a magnificent destination. The cost is $10 per car for entrance. The pictures we are attaching can go on and on. It was worth every minute spent in the car

I had always wanted to visit Mt Rushmore and was a little concerned that it might be overhyped-definitely not. Our visit was super and met all my hopes .Get up close on the presidential trail and also get way from some of the crowds. A really good place to go and great value with the ticket valid for 12months. We went back one evening 4th July) to watch the sound and light show and again found it really good.

Majority of reviewers cite the beauty of this Memorial as outstanding and it truly is. We usually use our Natl. Park Senior Pass but for Mt Rushmore you are charged $11.00 for parking and I concur, a small price to pay for a great day. We had the honor of meeting Mr. Don "Nick" Clifford at the visitors center gift shop. Mr. Clifford is the last living Mt Rushmore worker and at 92 years young, it was a pleasure to talk with him. Your parking pass allows you to return for the evening ceremony. With the faces lighted and a presentation by the Park Rangers, this is truly moving ceremony. As a veteran it was fun to be called onstage with my brothers and sisters to be recognized for our years of service. Both the day and night visit offered numerous opportunities to meet and talk with our guests from other countries, a great honor.

There's nothing I can say about this memorial and the area in general that hasn't been said a zillion times. You have to see it to believe it. The only thing that still bothers me and always will, is the FEE that they charge to park!!! It's supposed to be a FREE monument / memorial but you have to pay $11 (2013) to go there!! What a horrible political move that was. They were building the new plazas and parking ramp when I was working in the Badlands in 1995 and I wrote several letters to the superintendent at Mt. Rushmore about it and was told that the then $8 parking fee would be dropped once the ramp was paid off. Well, now it's $11 and there's no end in sight. I guarantee that Mr. Borglum is rolling in his grave at this travesty to charge people to go to a "free" memorial to the four Presidents he took the last 17 years of his life carving. The guy at the entrance said that our $11 parking pass would be good for ONE YEAR, but on the back it says that it expires at the end of the year. They really need to get their act together on this, for those of us who might actually be back more than once a year it's really bad PR for those who run this otherwise breathtaking and mind-blowing carving. You will not forget seeing this whether it's your first time or your hundredth time.

It took us a while to get our bearings here as it is spread out with several information sites scattered through the park. We should have studied more about the park on line before our visit. At any rate we spent a very nice afternoon hiking several trails and seeing several pretty waterfalls and lots of wildlife. (This is a wonderful outdoor resource for folks in the Cleveland area!) There is a lot of history here about the Canal and some nice exhibits about the boats etc in the information buildings. Check it out on line before you visit. It doesn't have the grandeur of some National Parks but don't let negative reviews keep you away.

We love this area. We hiked several trails in the area and visited a nature reserve and had a great time. We loved the Crow Pass Trail but it can get a bit treacherous at stream crossings and along some of the ridges but worth it. We will be back again.

You might think you get a good enough view of the monument from outside on the highway. Think again. It is well worth the $11.00 parking fee, to go into the park and see all the extras. You even get to go back for the lighting ceremony on the same parking ticket.

Certainly a very impressive memorial, there is an $11 car parking fee which enables you to return for the lighting ceremony at night. Despite the crowds the viewing deck gives you an amazing look at the four presidents carved into the mountain. Take the Presidential trail, it snakes around the base of the mountain with very informative signs telling you about each president, you also go past the centre devoted to the guy who carved it before returning to the viewing deck.

Visited twice because came a bit close to dark ( around 5:30 ) and just miss some places to see. Hold your entrance receipt ($ 10/car) that good for 1 week in case you have to come back again, like we did because we miss the Thurston Lava Tube due to less information before we go (thought close due to dark after sunset and the Jaggar Museum closed at 7:30 PM ). The Thurston Lava Tube OPEN DAILY for 24 HOURS and don't worry there are lights inside the cave and bright enough for you to see in there. Make sure spent your time at least 4 hours to enjoy the Hawaii Volcanoes NP and go further more after see the Tube for another scenic drive to see another different world. We didn't see the entire HVNP even visited twice and will come back again someday.
We stayed at Lizard Creek and Gros Ventre Campgrounds, which were clean, hosts helpful and animals abound. We could easily drive to Colter Bay where we could pay to take a clean shower.

This is a nice piece of history. It is the place of encampment for Washington and his troops during winter 1777-1778. No battles were fought here but this is where troops were properly trained and lessons in perseverance were learned. Valley Forge is easy to get to from the highway and entry is free. We arrived around noon and went to the visitor center. Be sure to ask where the kiosk is located where you can enter an ancestor's name to see if he was at Valley Forge. We purchased the self-tour cd for $16 (I would recommend this) and then we watched the free short video about Valley Forge and the Revolution and then walked with a Ranger to a few stops for about 1/2 hour. We took a break and drove to King of Prussia for a quick lunch (a few miles away) and then came back to start the self-tour. We ended up driving around the park until 5:30 p.m. and we didn't even get out to see everything. Washington's headquarters was at a good spot for us to stretch our legs after driving around for a while. This is a beautiful, peaceful park where it seems locals come to take advantage of the great spot to picnic or exercise. We did Gettysburg and Valley Forge in the same week and it is interesting to compare the two. Gettysburg is more hustle and bustle while this is more serene. Both equally nice. In retrospect, we should have stayed in King of Prussia afterwards because this was an all day event for us and that area looks nice and new with plenty of restaurants, hotels and a mall. An overall great visit to Valley Forge.

Since we visit Key West often, we have debated many times on taking the trip out to the Dry Tortugas. We finally made the trip and were so glad we did! It's not a cheap trip, but it's well worth it. The boat ride was long, but we were fed a good buffet breakfast almost immediately after leaving the port. A decent lunch buffet is served while you are on the island. You can eat on the boat or take your food to one of the picnic tables on the grounds. when you arrive, I highly recommend taking the guided tour because you'll get to hear some very interesting facts and information. You'll still have plenty of time to explore on your own or visit the beach. You'll get a beautiful view walking the top of the fort, and walking around the fort along the sea wall was incredible. I would recommend grabbing a table when you arrive to put your belongings on while you're on the tour or exploring on your own. There aren't many tables in the shade but there is one that we grabbed right off the dock. The return boat ride was fast and very windy for about an hour. We had 4-6 foot swells, but even with all that, I saw no one get sick. There were plenty of seats inside and out. This is definitely a "must go" trip!

at just $11 early bird special at the parking, you will see the marvels of men with none of the heavy equipment that todays contractor's have. what can I say that others have not, I do not know. there may be something that we may over look, the flag stations at the entrance o yes look for your state or the American territory where you live for a little bit of history.

When you visit South Dakota make sure that you pay a visit to Mt. Rushmore. Its a sight that you wont want to miss. A huge mountain with the 4 presidents faces in the granite side of the mountain located in the Black Hills of South Dakota.At the National Park there is a gift shop. restaurant etc. Also underground parking garage close to Mt. Rushmore. As you approach the mountain you walk under the avenue of flags which is very impressive.Free to visit the attraction but a $10.00 parking fee.

You can’t travel to this part of South Dakota and not visit Mt. Rushmore. Access to the park is quite easy and there is a fee to get in (look it up online), but the ticket you get is good for several days (you can’t give it to someone else because your license plate number is on the ticket). There are several vantage points; an overlook point, an amphitheater, and a wooden trail that gets closer to the sculpture. One note for pet owners, dogs are not allowed. Make sure your digital camera is fully charged with plenty of room on the data card because you’re going to take a lot of pictures. If you go early in the day there should be less of a crowd which should reduce the likelihood of someone photo bombing your selfie with the four presidents. Find another person (with an expensive looking camera) to take a photo of you and your significant other (don’t ask), and make sure you return the favor. Be sure to walk the wooden trail that brings you closer to the rubble field below the sculpture. You’ll get some good photo ops and it gives you a different perspective. They say the trail is strenuous…if you’re in reasonable health you’ll have no issues. There are a lot of stairs so a wheelchair will not make it. There is a display at the end of the trail where you can try and heft some of the typical tools used to carve the mountain. It’s amazing that they had a pump at the bottom of the mountain that ran a pipe all the way up to supply the air pressure to run all the tools. There is also a small museum and (larger) gift shop at the bottom of the overlook to get your fridge magnets and souvenir caps. It took us about two hours to see everything we needed to see, your mileage may vary. It is one of the top ten American icons that everyone should see, so make the trip. You won’t regret it.
Liked the way the cruise was managed. Advised to take sea sick tabs, purchased on boat for only $2pp. We were warm and adequately fed.

Lincoln's son, Robert gave this home to the federal government under the stipulation that it would be taken care of. And that it be open to the public at no charge. What a deal! This puts you into the Lincoln family from his lawyer days in Springfield until his election to President. Awesome.

Wonderful place. There is real beauty in the monument. They display and share with you all information about the monument and its builder. When you go SEE THE CLOSING CEREMONY!!!!!!!!!!! The closing cannot be explained, you have to experience it. They have a nice book store and gift shop. The park is free but you do have to pay parking.

You may pass the rental of the self guided tour like we did because it's to the left of the breath-taking entrance! The walk under the monument was worthwhile but be prepared for stairs- what goes down must come up! The movie was good too- wish it was longer with more information. The only disappointing aspect was when I went to visit the last worker on the mountain, per the sign outside the bookstore. He had no interest in visiting- the sign should have read come buy the guy's book. Most authors understand that not everyone wants to afford their particular book but nevertheless they are polite.

Wow, learned so much early American history here. Part of the USA National Parks so if you have a Parks Passport you can use it here otherwise the entry fee is very reasonable. Canon firing demonstration was exciting and the "character actors" were very informing. As someone said before a great break from the commercialism of St. Augustine.

We go to Ft Matanzas about once a year. We often take a picnic and have our lunch under the live oaks in the picnic area before heading to the island. The trip is free, but I'd recommend getting there early to get your ticket and then either having lunch or leaving for a bit and coming back. We've arrived 15 min before launch and it's booked.

Always wanted to visit. Had seen recent documentary on PBS on its construction. No disappointments here. Others have complained about the parking fee $11. There is no entry fee for the monument which more than compensates. The walk around is a bit tough in the second half - suggest turning back half-way if you are not good on steps/stairs. The evening show is excellent. Host from National Park Service was great. Short movie on the Presidents and history including First Nations. Altogether a very emotional evening culminating in the National Anthem and lowering the Flag. Armed Forces Veterans invited on stage for the finale. Recommended for all Americans. And Canadians!

Mt Rushmore is one of these places that everybody has seen pictures of, but until you go there you can’t tell the scale of it, hence are potentially up for a disappointment. But luckily there is no disappointment with this national monument. The entrance fee is very reasonable ($11 for a car and occupants), parking is good, and the walk up to the main viewing area is nicely done.

I appreciate that Mt. Rushmore is more important to US citizens than tourists but charging $11 to park appears a little stange and overpriced. Also, if you mistakenly enter the area towards the parking there is no way to legally exit without entering the car park. As for the actual monument we had a "is that it" feeling. Probably the most disappointing monument we have visited in the US.

Iconic, beautiful, serene. This memorial is a must see destination while in the Black Hills. It's incredibly accessible and an easy walk for kids, seniors and those less mobile. They have a cafeteria and gift shop on sight, great for getting a few souvenirs and getting a snack. Consider going in the morning, when the morning light makes it come to life and then return at night when they light the memorial and have a moving closing ceremony. If you are fortunate to be there on the 4th of July, don't miss the fireworks! Entrance is free, but there is a charge for parking.

We thought this would be a nice stop to take a break from highway driving. My husband and boys probably would rate it higher than I did, but they cannot argue that June is not the time to stop. The visitor's center was small and the side that sold cold drinks was not open until 3pm. We got there at 2pm, so no cold drink for us. The attraction itself was nothing special. True, they were pinnacles, but they were so far in the distance that I found them of no interest. The extreme heat and dust did not help matters. We also saw a turkey vulture, which was interesting to say we saw one, but it is one of the ugliest creatures ever!

Not the biggest of parks and located in the middle of nowhere but a great park with real diversity. The Lehman Cave - Great Palace guided tour was great, the ranger was really knowledgeable, happy to answer questions - it lasts 90 minutes and is well worth the $10 each. Rangers in the park visitor centre were really friendly and made you feel welcome.

Yes we paid $11 for the car. It was just me and my husband. Price is good for two people or a car of $20. So $11 isn't unreasonable to see such a patriotic grand memorial. We attended nighty lighting ceremony and then viewed it the next day as well. We were told our $11 pass was good until December. Only too bad we live in PA! Worth the price and don't miss out on side view when exiting monument.

This park does an excellent job of setting the scene of life in Springfield in Lincoln's time. They provide a good tour of the home. It is the only part of park that requires a ticket - no cost but there are a limited number so get yours early in the day. Film and other exhibits are nice as well. Very glad I toured this site.

A spectacular sight only experienced in books until this visit. Every American should visit and learn who built it, why, and the entire background of how it was sculpted. The $11 parking fee is very reasonable, since there is no entrance fee. Tip for parking - use the Lot 6 (not covered) on the top level as it is a very short walk from the entrance. Recommend the movie to help explain the memorial, and also do the Presidential Trail walk (only a bit strenuous on the uphill portion). The walk gives you views of Mount Rushmore that are not available from the viewing platform. Did not get to see the lighting ceremony (nightly at 8), but am told it is very impressive and patriotic. And one last tip - have the Thomas Jefferson ice cream (only vanilla) in snack building - his original recipe and it is great!

This place was really easy to get to, and surprisingly close to the city. At the visitor's center, there are guides, maps, displays, gifts, books and helpful staff to answer questions. You'll drive to a separate site about a mile away, where there is a $1 parking fee. There are self guided tours of the monument that you can link up your iphone to, which was really neat. The paths up to the top of the monument can be steep at points, and rocky and gravelly. I made the mistake of wearing flip flops, and going during a super hot time of the day, but that was my fault. Just have water, as there really is no shade at all. If you are interested in history, it's a neat way to spend a little bit of time. The petroglyphs are definitely pretty cool to see. It was very bright during the time that I went, which made it kind of hard to see many of the petroglyphs, so I decided to only hike one trail. There is a lot more to see. For me, it was just was a so-so experience, but I would definitely say it's worth visiting.

The fort is small, but that really shows the hardship they endured. Nice interpretive center and well maintained grounds. Minimal admission charge. Good for all ages -- we arrived early on a Monday only to see several large groups of students going out on the hike to the sea. Went inside and it was full of retirement age couples (including ourselves!)
While wandering around the area we stumbled across this little fort. No entry fee, a free ferry, and an educational tour of an old Spanish fort.

Absolutely a fantastic trip!! The flight out was amazing, incredible views, beautiful ocean. The pilot was great. Lots of interesting info about the trip. 45 minutes out to Fort Jefferson. Amazing place. The largest brick structure in the western hemisphere, out in the middle of the ocean. If you have not heard of it - google it. Fascinating piece of American history. Snorkel gear is provided, as well as beverages. The only down side is cost. That is the only reason we didn't take this trip sooner. $280 per person. Now that I've done it, it was worth it. Great memories, and great photos.

We spent over 3 hours in the park – quite a bargain for a fee of $10 per car! Most of our time was spent driving to different locations and viewing something or walking/hiking to see the sights. It would be easy to spend the whole day or several days in the park but with a 3 hour trip each way from Kona, we were simply tired of driving. It’s worth a stop at the Visitor’s Center for information and a short movie about Kilauea volcano. There is a restaurant in the park but we brought a picnic lunch and enjoyed sitting in the shade at one of the picnic tables while eating it. I would recommend staying on the Hilo side of the island for a couple of nights to be able to spend as much time as you want at the park.

Pictures and words cannot adequately describe the sights, sounds, smells and tranquility of this majestic forest. This is one of the best outstanding attractions and natural wonders of America, and it is without cost. Take time slowwwlly drive the Avenue of the Giants, walk through one of the many Redwood Groves which are easy access for even the disabled, walk a trail away from the main road, reflect on the wonder of this creation.

If you get a chance to hear the interpreter give a presentation, take it. The visitors center has a three sided view of the battlefield and our interpreter gave a very clear and moving presentation on what was going on. With the view of the entire battlefield before you, you can actually see the how the terrain would affect the battle. Pass on the film if you hear the interpreter. The film covers the same information.

Agate Fossil Beds is kind of in the middle of nowhere but it's definitely worth a visit. The short walk out to see both the once mysterious beaver burrows and the expanse of the plains is great. The small visitor center with numerous fossils and also a small Native American collection is worth visiting too. The rangers were helpful and we made sure to leave a small donation since admission is free.

We visited this one late afternoon to seeing the evening lighting presentation. It was awesome. There is a nice amphitheater to sit or you could stand at the back. While we waited, we watched the sun go down and it was a very pretty sunset. They had a nice presentation and then slowly illuminated the memorial with a very nice musical score playing. We chatted with several people. We came back the next morning to walk through the sculptor's area and the walking tour. That was nice. While there is no entrance fee, it did cost $11 to park and there is no other place to park. However the parking fee was good until the end of the calendar year. Nice Visitor's Center.

I enjoyed seeing this iconic monument. It was actually smaller in size than what I had imagined. You do have to pay to park and it may be a long walk for some. You can get some nice photos from the road in various areas. Make sure you include going to see The Crazy Horse Memorial while you are in the area. Both are a must see.
