We saw Mt. Rushmore initially on a cloudy day. It didn't interfere with our pictures. But with your paid parking entry, you can enter the memorial for a year, so stop in again when it's sunny. On your parking pass ($11 USD) it prints out the make of your car and the state on the plate, so it is nontransferable.
Great trip. The ferry ride over was great, with views of the ocean. Breakfast and lunch included in the cost as well as snorkel gear and a tour of the fort. Well worth the cost

I've been to most of the National Parks across the country and Crater Lake offers a scenery unlike any other, it's easy to see in a couple days unless you want to do some back country hikes. If you can afford $200 a night Stay at the Main Lodge, Dining is not the best but you can't beat the scenery while you're eating mediocre fare.
You must stop here and see this. You only pay for parking and the views are amazing. Very clean! Nice gift shop. Took wonderful photos and will cherish this for life!
for $10 enterance fee its excellent

This fort was small but it was by far my favorite in the area, a much better experience than Castillo de San Marcos. It is free to enter and a free boat ride over to fort, leaving every 1/2 pasted the hour. We were lucky and only our party was there for our tour. There was two rangers on our ride that told us all about the area and answered any and all questions we had. He said he was also in charge of the reenactments and told us how many of the weapons worked. Overall this fort is a little out of the way but worth it to visit!

The NPS acquired about 4 blocks of the Lincoln home neighborhood. The actual home and furnishings can be seen on a free timed ticket. Two other homes can be seen at your own pace and have exhibits about the renovations the Lincolns did to the house. The visitor center has 2 films about Lincoln's early life and times. No admission but there is a $2 per hour parking fee which is half price with a NPS pass.

Amazing place to explore early Southwestern/Mexican colonial ruins. It was fascinating to see the blend of European and native cultures in how the buildings were designed and used. The museum itself is quality and for only $3 it is well worth the visit. There are not a lot of buildings in the western United States that are from the 1600's so this is a rare treat to explore.

It's hard not to be impressed by the carvings of the presidents at Mount Rushmore. The Memorial is well designed with visitors centre, gift shop, and dining room. The promenade is beautifully laid out with granite walkway and flags, an excellent viewpoint, and then an interesting walk that goes through the woods and closer to the mountain for interesting photo ops. There is an excellent small museum with a good film and a chance to see the sculptor's studio. The fee is $11 for parking but that is actually an annual pass so you can go back to see the night show or visit a second time. We were in an RV and there is space for parking as well as an area to exercise dogs (they are not allowed onsite)

If coming by car, park in the garage behind the Visitors Center which is located in Galleria @ President's Place Mall located at 1250 Hancock Street. Enter via Saville Avenue (just before the Visitors Center). Use the middle gate entrance on the right & proceed to level 4 or 5, the lower levels are for Reserved Parking. Take the parking ticket to the Visitors Center to be validated...then there is no charge.

park: Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park
text: I went to the Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park on a Thursday 9-19. I went right after it opened. We where the only ones there for a while so it was quiet and it was easy to just take it all in. It is at Williams St in Downtown Dayton. in an old building that used to be a print shp the wrights used. Right next door in cycle shop you can tour also. The place was set up nice and had a lot history not only flight or Paul Dunbar but all Dayton. There was a lot things I never knew. There is also a parachute exibit. YZou can go next door and tour the wrights cycle shop. It had a lot same info but it was a good tour. it is a small shop took about 20min with a ranger explaining a lot. This whole thing and the shop bit ore than 2 hours. You could take less or more. It was great because it was raining out and we did this. I you are in town this is worth the trip to see. We did not do the prarie that is out by the WPAFB because of therain but maybe next time. there is no fee for this building and the cycle shop. I am not sure on anything else.

Just as awe inspiring as I thought it would be. One of the things that I have always heard of and wanted to see. Located right beside Keystone. Its about the only reason to go to Keystone. But the sculpture itself was everything I thought it would be. No admission but their is a parking fee. So, the free Sr. pass for national monuments is not valid.
We stopped at Exit Glacier and took a boat tour to the park to view wildlife and glaciers. Saw both. Well worth the expense. Seward is a nice town.

This is one of the most unique and beautiful sites i have ever seen. Formed by a volcano the lake in this mountain is the bluest blue i have ever seen. The 30 mile drive around the rim offers spectacular views from the many overlooks! Dont miss this if you are anywhere nearby. We drove a couple of hours from Eugene to see it and it was well worth it, just be sure you have plenty of gas! We left the interstate at Roseburg and drove hwy 138 through the mountains. Its a gorgeous drive along the river but there are no gas stations or restaurants etc along the way! If hou are a hiker there are many many trails along the way and in the park. If you do nothing in the park but drive up and around the rim you will need about 3 hours, however you could spend an entire day easily! This is a DO NOT MISS Oregon attraction! We made many stops along the way to the park along hwy 138 as well, and then drove back through Bend And Sisters Oregon. This route allows you to see more of the Cascade Mountain Range and the Lava Fields if you want to (unfortunately we did not have time to stop by them). Stopped for dinner in Bend at the Riverhouse on US 97. Beautiful dining overlooking the river and food was great. This entire round trip from Eugene took about 12 hours and we could have used much more time!! Missed several things we would have liked to have seen along the way! $10.00 fee to get in Crater Lake Park. Dinner at Riverhouse Any where from $15 for fish and chips to $30 for a big steak.

The drive up is absolutely beautiful ... when you get there it is $11 for parking - which is very organized and seems very secure. Then a short walk up to the viewing area ... there are rangers everywhere to answer questions. You can view the sculpture from the viewing area - quite pretty or take the trail to the base of an even better view. Also you can go down to the artist studio for info on the making of the sculpture and models. The only draw back was the gift shop had a sign out that said "American Made" - we went in and there was only a very small section American Made

On our way to Yellowstone from Salt Lake City, we took a detour to the Promontory Point where the east and west railroads came together to form one rail from the mid-west to California in 1869. It is about an hours drive north from Salt Lake around the great salt lake! Interesting museum with video and displays of the work that was done on the railroad and laying the track. Steam engines come down the tracks twice on Saturday and also a reenactment of the last spike driven into the rails. A VERY out of the way place but a pleasant drive through meadows and horses. Worth the stop for a different site. Rangers are especially enthusiastic and knowledgeable. No charge for those with federal park pass.

This was one of the places my friend and I had to stop on our cross-country trip! While the monument itself is free, the parking, which is managed by a contractor, is $11. The monument, exhibits, and overall presentation are excellent! I wish we could have stayed longer, but we had a schedule to keep. It is amazing that these were carved out of the rock, and are quite impressive. It is an American icon that everyone should see once in his or her lifetime!

I loved the entire monument, it was better than I imagined. It is beautifully designed and engineered, easy to get around, see and take photos. There is even a place for people to pull off and get a photo if they can't or don't want to pay the $11.00 per car to drive into the actual monument. We chose to go in and it was worth it. Bathroom facilities were easy to find.

I've wanted to see Mt. Rushmore since I was a kid and it definitely did not disappoint. An awesome sight and great setting. We did the $5 audio tour and would highly recommend it. Made the Presidential much more interesting and shared interesting tidbits of information. The evening lighting ceremony is emotional and patriotic. A definite must see for all.

Very scenic place, we exited Yellowstone at the south entrance into the Grand Teton National Park on the John D Rockeller Jr Memorial Highway which took us to Jackson Lake Overlook, worth a stop, and then to Jackson Lake Lodge where we stopped for lunch. If we could have afforded it we would have stayed here but unfortunately it was out of our price range. We headed east towards Moran Junction stopping turnouts at Willow Flats and Oxbow Bend, past Moran Junction to Snake River Overlook and Teton Point Overlook. Headed back the way we had come to Jackson Lake Junction and then south and up Signal Mountain. Onto our hotel Signal Mountain Lodge where we hired a boat and sped around Jackson Lake for an hour - excellent and would recommend doing this. Stayed at Signal Mountain Lodge, which was ok. Next day headed south to Jenny Lake overlook and onto Jackson.

It took our breath away! We did not know what to expect as we did not research this destination (which is something we normally do), but in the end it was one of the very best trip we ever took. We also took the scenic drive to get there (From Cedar City, Hwy 14 to Duck Creek, then north on Mammoth Creek Rd to Panguitch) which is a route we highly recommend. It also takes you through Red Canyon which is worth a trip all by itself. Getting into Bryce was easy, and once inside was not congested and we found parking at every stop. And while the Park is essentially a huge canyon, the drive is along the rim at an elevation of more than 9,000 feet in places. Bring extra batteries for your camera, as you will find lots of lots of photo opportunities. And bring a jacket, even in the summer, as the high elevation also means cooler temps. I would also recommend watching the movie in the Visitor Center as it helps explain the history and how the stone formations were created. - - As far as lodging, there are LOTS of (locally owned) motels and lodges along the way, but we did not see them on the sites we normally use for reservations and so we spent the night in Cedar City. That is too far away, and the next time I would put in a little more effort to make a reservation closer to the park. - If over age 62 or disabled get pass to enter park for free.
Be sure to stop by Escalante Outfitters for Pizza, camping, $45.00 cabins, coffee, beer and amazing people.

I have been hiking and enjoying the San Juan N F since 1968. I started back packing with the Boy Scouts on trails behind Vallecito Lake 17 miles east of Durango. There are two trail heads that make access easy. They are the Vallecito Trail Head and the Pine River Trail Head. You can also access the forest via the train into the Neddleton area. A trail there will take you up Chicago Basin and over Columbian Pass at a little over 12,000 ft. One piece of advice go into Durango and buy a good trail guide book, and read it before deciding where to enter. This simple act will make your trip that much better. Also, buy the forest service pass or a fishing pass, it is about $15.00. BUT if you get into trouble, the search and rescue with a helicopter wont' cost you a dime.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: Appomattox court house was a nice peaceful visit. It's onl $5:00 for all of the park, you just walk at your leisure and spend all the time you want.very informative.the guides are great and helpful. We especially loved the provost as he talked with us, never leaving his character.

How can one actually rate something this majestic as anything but excellent! But, add to that the fact that the ice cream cones were great, the audio program was awesome, the people in the information center absolutely dedicated to taking care of the visitor and two mountain goats that graced us with their presence in the amphitheatre, and I stand by my rating.

In a recent hike out to the site discovered that some second rate contractor who cut a dirt road to the top of the mesa to build over priced rich housing development dumped their dirt over several of the best images. this site has been significantly diminished over night by hasty actions from a careless construction firm who destroyed and buried centuries of history robbing future generations of the experience. How can this level of complacency go unpunished? makes one wonder if it was intentional. Expansionist greed will be our undoing.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: The grounds are beautiful, and it is awe-inspiring to stand where Grant and Lee met. There was a very knowledgable ranger named Ernie Price working the McLean House -- he was full of all manner of information and insight, so bravo to him.

No visit to this part of the world would be complete without coming here. The immensity of the monument strikes you as soon as you leave the parking area. The walkways give the feel of the place, especially the avenue of flags. The view from the Grand terrace is spectacular. You have to be amazed at the scale and the amount of work that must have gone into it. The walk round to the bottom of the monument is essential to give different perspectives on each of the Presidents. You must visit Borglum's workshop to see the models. The video below the Grand Terrace and museum area there are good. But this is primarily a place to stop, stand, look and reflect. A word of warning, your American national parks pass is not valid here.

Visited Mount Rushmore on our way out west the second week of September. We planned it so that we would get there a couple of hours before sunset - giving us time to look around and then see the light show after the sun went down. The drive to the Memorial was beautiful, the parking convenient and the area well-kept and clean. There was a bookstore and food on the site. The walk-way was easy for people with mobility issues. It led straight towards the mountain, giving you plenty of ways to set up your photos, and was lined with state flags. I would have liked to have seen it the way it was before they put in all the concrete, concessionaires and $11 parking fee (your national park pass is not honored). We didn't take the opportunity to do so, but I understand there is a trail that takes you closer to the monument. There is seating on an upper level over-looking an amphitheater below. After sunset, a park ranger came out on the amphitheater stage and began a video that was part history lesson, part flag-waving rah-rah. The video concluded and he droned on and on about how we must put aside our differences as a country and come together as one nation. Huh????? I didn't expect to be chastised on my vacation! What a downer! Finally, they turned on the "spotlights" so that we could dimly make-out the faces of the presidents. What a let-down! Not at all what I expected and not something that I'll visit again. The next day, as we were driving along the scenic roads in the area, we came across numerous viewpoints to take better photographs than we were able to get at the monument itself. If you've never seen it, go - but don't expect much.

Visiting Mount Rushmore is an inspiring experience. If you are traveling and get into town in the evening, go to visit for the ranger talk and the lighting of the monument. The sound in the amphitheater is crystal-clear. Like other national parks, the ranger talk is excellent. I suggest taking a basic pair of binoculars to help see the detail of the monument carving. We also went back the following day and did the walking tour in the morning daylight (the path isn't lit at night). Rent the audio guide for $5. It has over 20 stops and provides and incredible amount of information and is well worth the price. Admission to the monument is free, but there is a one-time fee for parking (we paid in the evening and just had to show our receipt the next day).

Go early in the morning to beat the crowds and get the best morning light views. Travel counterclockwise on the road and you will beat some of the traffic. The most magnificent view is your first look over the rim. WOW! The water is bluer than blue and breathtaking!! Take the short walk down to the lookout by the Visitor Center. I thought it was just a lookout but it has a wonderful museum inside. And the views are great too!! If you are 62, get a Golden Age Passport at any National Park for $10. Free entrance fees for life!!

Excellent national trust here, comprising the Independence Hall, Constitution centers with movie theatre, the first presidential homes of Washington and Adams, and, of course, the Liberty Bell! Lots of history here! Tickets to Independence Hall are timed but free and available at the Will Call desk of the Centre. You will pass through airport type security to get in.

We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to Jewel Cave. Ranger Melissa's Discovery Tour was informative and humorous and her knowledge and love of the cave added to the experience. The ladies at the ticket desk and bookstore were unable to answer a question we had about local animals, but went above and beyond by locating a book which did. Do a little homework so you'll know what to expect (it's not Carlsbad) and you won't be disappointed. We had a great visit and hope to come back again! PS Save yourself a walk back to the car, cameras are welcome, but bags, not so much.

Visiting Mt. Rushmore is always a very interesting and exciting event. The sculptures are fabulous and the museum is well worth the visit. Lots of good history for the children. Take many photos---it is a truly picturesque location. Entry is free, but the parking is $11---kind of an odd way to get revenue for the monument?

We entered the park from the Bend Oregon area. Glad we went in September because the crowds were down. There was a little snow and windy the day we were there but it just added to the experience. The downside of this park is that they will close half the park for a bicycle rally but not let you know at the entrance. The entrance fee is $10.00 but you only get an abbreviated look at the Crater and you do not get to hike some of the trails that take you down to the water.

We stopped here on our annual national parks trip- this time to the East Coast. We always buy the national parks recreation passport which allows you to get into all of the national parks for a full year for one price. If you are visiting multiple national parks you should look into it because it will save you money, often paying for itself after only two or three stops.

I'm lucky enough to have this National Forest virtually in my backyard. I haven't hiked all it's trails, but have done several of them, over the years. I've done the Resurrection Pass trail in a day twice, although at the age I am and in the condition I am in I wouldn't try it now, and have done it in five days, using cabins reserved ahead of time, with my wife and her eldest sister and her husband. But it's a great place to hike, and I recommend it highly!

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: This national park is about a 20+ minute drive from Lynchburg and a nice diversion. We were fortunate that it was national park day and there was no fee.

Since we were staying in Flagstaff, Canyon du Chelly would have been a very tiring trip, so we opted for Walnut Canyon instead. From the time we arrived, it was fantastic. The ranger at the desk steered us to the senior's pass, which has already saved us almost $100.

This was a highly worthwhile attraction on your trip through Albuquerque, New Mexico. The cost is nominal ($2 per person). You will get in some mild hiking while you see the petroglyphs. The site of the petroglyphs easily catapults one into antiquity from present day as one tries to decipher what each of the petroglyphs says. This is a good choice for an outside venue.

We had the good fortune of arriving shortly before they would be moving one of the engines. Great sight to see so I suggest calling in advance to find out the schedule so if possible, you can see one of the engines running. While in the area also go and see the rocket display, including one of the boosters from the space shuttle, which is close to the turnoff for the Historic sight. There are signs. Remember that the National Monument is free if you have an annual or life pass to the National parks.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: Today was a gorgeous Fall day to walk the beautiful grounds at the Appomattox Courthouse Village and the connecting trails between the "last-stand" camps of Lee & Grant. Many of the buildings, including the famed McLean House where the actual surrender documents were signed, have been reconstructed based on historical documents and photographs. Only $3 per person or $5 per car is a great value to see and learn about one of the most crucial turning points in our country's history.

The fee to enter is per person, but its good for 5 days therefore a good deal. This place needs to be seen at different times of the day. The first time I went was a little after noon and thought the sand would be hot. Wrong. It was nice a cool. I would recommend going early morning and sunset for the best pictures. At high noon its a blinding, white, no definition plain. I'm sure that different times of the year at different hours will keep this feeling like a new place every time. And yes, do go into the information center and watch the video.

My son took us to White Sands for the day! September is a wonderful time to go. The kids loved climbing the dunes and sledding. I found the sledding a little disappointing, we rented 2 for $18 each, go with one and share. Great place for photographers, go in the afternoon when the shadows are great.

I visited Mount Rushmore in the 1950s as a child. I remember being fascinated with the faces of former presidents so high up a mountain. Going back in my 60s did not diminished the excitement of seeing this marvelous work of art. It was a beautfiul day with dark blue sky and white fluffy clouds. The national park's facilities were beautiful and modern. We enjoyed seeing the videos and visiting the museums about the making of Mount Rushmore. I enjoyed walking the trail loop to the foot of the mountain. Renting the $5.00 audio tour was worth it if you are doing the trail loop. Do note there are a lot of stairs leading to the scuptors cabin, but there were plenty of benches to rest.

Really a fantastic place to check out - the gal we spoke with at the ticket counter was very helpful in assisting us with selecting a tour that my mother and I could do (she's older and both of us have some pulmonary issues that make the more strenuous things challenging) - the tour we took was really fantastic and the two guides with our group were both informative and very down to earth (Chris & Joel, you guys made it a blast, thank you!) There is also a pretty surprisingly extensive museum that you can check out if you have a bit of time to kill before (or after) your tour(s). I may stop by for another tour before I head back home :)

They have plenty of tours to pick from with plenty of time frames. Some range from short half hour wheelchair accessible to long 6 hour endurance tours. Like any cave system, the beauty is outstanding. Because the park is federally owned, the price is well worth it.

A long day for sure,but so worth it. Lots to see during the ferry trips. Beautiful water for swimming or snorkeling. Just walking around the outside moat wall of the fort, there is so much to see--soft coral and reef fish. Food is provided but very basic sandwich fixings and continental breakfast. Drinks are free during meal service but cost at other times. Crew is very friendly. And tour guide is very knowledgeable.

At 10350 feet, 30 minutes from Cedar City, and a view that is guaranteed to leave you speechless, Cedar Breaks National Monument is a gem amongst our national treasures. This is a first rate experience and highly recommended. We saw while driving from Cedar City to Bryce Canyon.

Something for everyone. Drive, hike or do both. We are 60 somethings and found doable trails and breathtaking views. The park is not crowded a nd every bit as spectacular as Canyonlands. If you have a senior liftime pass entrance is free.

Little foggy when we visited but still visible. Very impressive. Nice historic center and gift drop. Nice entrance and accessibility. Parking is easy and convenient. Easy wheelchair access. Parking $10 even with Sr pass.

Did not expect such a beautiful place. The visitor center is very nice. The rangers helpful and exhibits good. Watch the film if you have time. Then you step out on the back patio and it is outstanding. So many places to take breath taking photos. On the drive there are several pull offs and walks out to the drop offs. Take water with you. It can get hot. My only down side was the restrooms. They were awful. No water to wash your hands so take wet wipes with you. If you have a National Park Pass for seniors use it here for admission.

While we went in August, the desert heat was not too unbearable. This popular destination perched on the crest of the Little San Bernardino Mountains is an impressive array of geologic rockpiles. It is a fascinating place to visit-with several nature trails and short walks available to explore. Camping is available as well.The park entrance fee is $15.00 per vehicle and the campgrounds are $15.00 per night. Ranger programs are available as well. This is a site worth visiting!

We purchased airfare and made reservations at Mazama cabins in May. When we arrived at the park on Sept 21 for two nights we found out the entire East Rim Drive was closed to cars! The entire weekend was devoted to bicycles on East Rim Drive. I have nothing against the bikes, it's just that I would like to have been informed of the event so I could make other plans. 3/4 of the things I wanted to see and do were on that road. Boo!- to the NPS for completely alienating a whole lot of people who showed up that weekend. The least they could have done is open the road to cars for a couple of hours before sunset, or they could have made a ton of money by running the trolleys along the East Rim with the bikes. At $25 bucks a pop, I would have paid it just to see the things I wanted to see. Poor planning, NPS! I want $5 of my $10 entrance fee back, because I could only see 1/2 of the park!

We reserved a site for a family reunion from 2,000 miles away. By the time we were ready for the reunion the weather was not going to cooperate! We did do a "drive by" inspection of the site just in case the weather broke... The site was so ready, and clean... Toilets set, tables and grills ready. We pre-paid for the area #3 and seeing how well they prepared it for us regardless of the weather we were glad to pay the fee without being able to use the facilities... what a beautiful piece of America. Please visit!!

Clearly everyone likes this attraction but I was very disappointed. It IS spectacular but all you're doing is looking at it - a similar experience can be attained by looking at a picture on your computer and you can save the drive, the hassle, and the money on parking. On the same trip I visited Yellowstone, now that is worth it because it's very interactive and you have to be there to appreciate it. Also, if you don't want to pay for parking you cannot get a good look at it from anywhere else. It's a bit of a drive off the highway but the drive there is beautiful, if you ignore all the cheesy tourist attractions. This may sound cynical but it was a big waste of time....just my opinion.

Really enjoyed my first trip to Mount Rushmore. Property is immaculate. Staff was very kind and friendly. We were there on a beautiful sunny day - great for photos - everything was spot-on! Gift shop carried everything from books to clothing and most were resonably priced. Very much enjoyed the video presentation. Will always remember my first glimpse of the monument. Parking fee was the entrance fee to the Monument. very resonably priced. Would reccommend to anyone!

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: For $3 you will receive a high quality tour of the inside of the Texas White House. Our guide was informed and enthusiastic. The inside of the LBJ home is almost exactly as it was when the Johnson family lived there. Really, if you are at all interested in going then you should go because you wont find anything quite like this anywhere. You even have exposure to the former president's vehicles and airplane. Worth the trip from Austin or San Antonio. You wont be sorry.

I feel bad if you traveled a long distance and at a great expense to see this...its much smaller in reality than what you seen in photos. And once you're there, you really don't need more than an hour poking around the grounds, taking some photos, and in the gift shop.

This is one of the most sacred shines in American (and world) history. It's quite a humbling experience to stand in the rooms where democracy was founded. First, go to the visitor's center for a ticket to Independence Hall, it's free. You'll be assigned a time to tour the building. They say that you should get your ticket by 1:30 if you want to get in same day. I went in October and it wasn't very busy, so it wasn't an issue. Before your tour, spend some time walking around, there are some interesting exhibits right near the hall, such as the President's house and the Liberty Bell. There will likely be a line for the Liberty Bell, so you might want to wait until after you get though Independence Hall before you queue up. The tour itself is 30-45 minutes; you're really just going through the two main rooms in the hall but the tour guides are clearly humbled to be giving the tours - they portray a sense of deference and decorum that's fitting for such a monumental site.

Cedar Breaks has some incredibly beautiful views but not much else. In terms of restaurants, hiking trails, etc; they are rather sparse however, the gorgeous vistas make up for it. Park Fees are $4 for 7 days or you may use your America the Beautiful Pass. It's a great place to visit from nearby tourist locations like Brian Head but, in my opinion, one day touring the vistas by car is adequate.

As a kid I saw pictures of Mount Rushmore and thought "oh so what". I have now been to Mount Rushmore three times. The first time was in the morning. It was foggy and cool. It was awesome then. The second time was passing by during bike week. You can see the monument from the highway. This last time was just before dusk. That was awesome too. Every time I have seen it I have not been disappointed. The one thing that is nice is that in the evening they have a lighting ceremony. The park ranger gives a talk about the history of the monument and pays respect to the veterans who also help in the flag ceremony. Every time I have been I have not been disappointed. It is worth paying the money to get into the park. Plus the proceeds of the entrance fee pay for keeping this park open. There is a hiking trail, restaurant, gift shop, and bathrooms. This is a site worth visiting!

Recently had a conference in Dallas, and was looking for somewhere green to go for a few days prior to the conference. Hot Springs is about a four hour drive, but well worth the time spent. What a gem of a city! As the other reviewers have stated, the National Park is in the middle of the city, and it focuses more on the history and culture surrounding the Hot Springs and the industry of the bath houses that put Hot Springs, AR on the map. Definitely take the short motor trail up the mountain to the lookout. There is a moderate fee, but it is worth it. I particularly enjoyed reading each and every one of the placards in the tower. Bathhouse Row is lined with beautiful buildings with different architectural styles. Only a few are open, but the buildings are gorgeous. I would HIGHLY recommend partaking in an old fashioned bath spa treatment. If it wasn't for the video at the Visitor's Center of the National Park that depicted the elements of a typical bath experience, I would not have thought about doing it. My friend and I enjoyed the treatment at the Arlington Hotel since the Buckstaff Bathhouse was closing the day we visited. The Arlington had longer operating hours, and we both left feeling refreshed and relaxed. It was wonderful!

Seeing the natural beauty found in Bryce was another "take your breath away" moment in our tour of southern Utah national parks. It was made all the more impressive by one of the park volunteers who led us on an hour-long nature hike, telling us of the geology, plant and wildlife found in the park. Our experience was capped off by being able to stay in a cabin in the park - which I highly recommend. By the way - you have to pay a park entrance fee at the national parks. If you are visiting several parks, it's worth getting the year-long pass. After visiting several national parks in southern Utah - I think we're getting an incredible deal in that the pass is only $85.

Besides the beaches and fresh tropical fruits, volcanoes are the main reason people visit the Hawaiian islands. This was no disappointment. As we say about Hawaii now, if it's raining, wait and it will pass. The first time we visited it was too rainy and too light out to get a great view, but we returned an hour later and the skies had cleared and there was a perfect view of the burning crater, which completed a bucket list item for me. Made for amazing photos and some deep self-reflection. We visited the vents, which can be a bit too much sulfur for some, so beware. There is a lot of sulfur in the air up here. Some people walked across the dormant crater further up the road, but we didn't have the time to hike it. It looked incredible though.

This was part of our USA tour (we are from the UK) and we found this fascinating to see. Your entrance fee allows you to return without additional charge, so we returned in the evening to see the carvings lit up. This was not as spectacular as we expected, particularly knowing how you Americans like to put on a show! We are glad we went and followed it with a visit to Crazy Horse Memorial.

I visited during the government shut down and unfortunately couldn't walk the trails or get anywhere too close, however still got some great views from the road. Its amazing to see how a piece of rock could be carved with such detail in such a hard to reach location. Walk the presidential trail if its open when you visit, just be prepared to pay for parking.
See incredible views of this deep canyon with dark walls. The view points are close to the road and, fortunately in my mind, fenced. The entry fee is $15 per car.

We went here on Saturday, Sept. 29 -- and there was no fee that day! Happy National Parks Day! Very interesting place but was it ever cold and windy! Slush and snow on the ground and part of the rim drive was closed due to weather. If you can drive up from Ashland on Dead Indian Memorial Road, do it. Takes about 3 hours but it is worth it to see the changes in the scenery along the way -- very dramatic. Make this a whole day trip or more -- so much scenery to enjoy. You have to stop at the overlooks and parking areas along the way too. Some hiking trails just beg for your attention! i will come back in the summer to check out more of this fascinating area!

A must see by all. A beautiful tribute to our country. Their is a museum which is very informative. There are beautiful flags of each state and the date of their admittance to the Union and the number of each states admissino. The people there were so nice, and so proud to tell you any and all information and answered all of our questions very eagerly. The restaurant had great food and very good prices. The admission is free, just parking is 11.00 per car. There are many exhibits relating to the making of the monument, history of the sculptor and what the monument truly means to our country. a must see if you are in the area. Makes you proud to be an American.!

I've been to Mt. Rushmore twice. The museum tells a great story of how this was built considering the technology available at the time. I always pictured it being really large and far away, but it is the opposite. It was smaller than I expected and your are right there. You still have to pay for parking even with the Nat Parks pass.

Do some minimum reading about what happened and how the history of southern Arizona was impacted by misunderstandings that started here. It can be well enjoyed without the preparation, but I'd encourage you to spend a few minutes researching "Apache Pass" and the "Bascom Affair" so that your walk into the fort can be best appreciated. This is really where the Apaches Wars began. There is a 1.5 mile hike into the fort from the parking lot where you'll find bathrooms. The fort path is an easy grade, well marked trail and you'll pass good historical signage that sketches out the significance of what you are seeing. Be sure to have some water. You'll come upon the ruins of the stage coach station where troops set up a defensive perimeter after attempting to hold the Apache leader Cochise for the kidnapping of a settler's child, an act that had actually been done by another tribe, but no matter, one Indian was as good as another. Members of Cochise's family were held as hostages when the warrior chief escaped. They were later hung in retaliation for the death of hostages held by the Apaches. Its not at all difficult to conjure up in your imagination hundreds of warriors on the ridge side and in the surrounding hillsides, looking down over the valley and its anxious soldiers. This is one of those rare battlefield sites that brings the events readily back to mind because of its uncorrupted condition. No commercial establishments or bill boards or telephone poles to be seen in any direction. My wife and I encountered a mounted ranger who commented that artifacts show up after every heavy rain. The sense of history is heavy and close. Walking to the fort you'll see the post cemetery and the location of a number of grave sites. One marks a medal of honor winner. Another marks a young child of Geronimo's who had been a favorite of the soldiers but died of sickness. The clear "Apache Spring" whose water made this site so vital for life still bubbles on. You're advised not to drink the water. The trek to the fort is uphill toward the last quarter mile. The original fort's ruins are to your right as you climb the last leg of the hill and provide a good vantage to look back over the valley trail. The more massive fort that served over decades of the latter years of the 19th century is directly in front of you, and there is a picturesque American flag flying from the flagstaff in the midst of the parade ground that you will spot from the trail. The fort is large and mostly in ruins. A small but appealing visitor center provides a shady spot to sit and drink. It also has first class bathrooms. When you leave, I'd suggest, if you're up to it, hiking back over the ridge trail that begins directly behind the visitor center. Its a steep and demanding initial push to get to the top, but from here you have one of the most impressive views of an Indian Wars landscape that will ever be your fortune to see. You are standing at the top of the Apache positions during the battle and there's a side trail to take you down to their view of the soldiers. If you turn 180 degrees and look east, you can see the flat plains across which came the stage coaches and freight carriers, headed for Apache Pass. The rest of the trail offer a series of switchbacks down to the valley floor and merges with the trail coming from the parking lot. This fort site and its southwest surroundings looks more like a movie location than an actual historic fort, but its authentic, down to the horned toad that stared me down on the trail. I kept listening for a bugle. Enjoy.

As a native New Mexican, we are very proud of our National Parks. The Chaco Canyon is no exception. What a fantastic history.I had not been here since I was six or seven and worried about the roads, after reading the posts here. The road isn't that bad. What was bad was the fact that we stayed on road 7900 for 20 miles in the wrong direction. There is not a HUGE sign marking the park. I attached photographs to show you the stop sign where road 7900 connects to 7950. This is the turn off! Do NOT cross over the cattle guard. Turn right onto 7950 and you will see a large sign for the campground. Continue on for endless miles...lol...(you will hear plenty of "are we there yet!". Finally you will see the visitors center (now closed due to the government shutdown) but it has great bathroom facilities. Visit the small musuem there. Then drive onto the sites. This is a trip well worth it. They have wonderful visitor phamplets so bring about $4 in quarters if you would like to purchase them (about .50c each or .75). If you want to, return them for no charge. Bring a picnic lunch, walking shoes, blanket to sit on and water). There are decent bathroom facilities at the sites and a picnic table. Bring your camera! Do NOT stay at the close cities unless you can make a reservation at any of the bed and breakfasts. Do stay longer than one day if possible. The campground looks bare but has minimal facilities. If you want to stay in a nice motel/hotel go to Bloomfield, Farmington, Los Alamos or Santa Fe or Jemez Mountains. Bloomfield is by the Cumbres Railyard (steam train). Worth the money and the time. Enjoy your trip!

This is a highlight. Abe Lincolns' family home and the entire neighbourhood preserved and restored to reflect the way it was - is simply impressive and a must see if visiting Springfield Illinois. The tour is free and very informative - we would have paid $25 pp - to give indication of its' real value.

Mt. Rushmore is one of those things that everyone should see. The story behind how it was carved was amazing. You can get fairly close to it if you pay to park and go into the Memorial. I was not that impressed just driving by, but was as we walked to the viewing platform. It was also very cool to drive Iron Mountain Road and view the Memorial through each of the 3 tunnels. We did not stay in Keystone overnight. We stayed in nearby Hill City, which was much more quaint town.

Took the Yankee Freedom ferry, the crew was awesome & the boat in nice shape. Google it for details and prices (which were fair). The captain allowed visits to the bridge, and answered questions about everything from the boat to the journey to Ft. Jefferson. The rest of the crew were VERY knowledgable about sea life, birds, and then the history of the Fort. The tour of it was about 45 minutes and then there was plenty of time to stroll around alone, take photos (and places to sneak a few *risque* ones if you want) and explore. There is ample time to tour, snorkel, laze in the sun, etc. The island is absolutely stunning, the views, snorkeling, beach, water.... Lunch on the boat is a nice picnic style- sammies, chips, veggies, sodas, sort of thing. The return trip was also just as good- with many more questions answered, stories told and cocktails enjoyed (extra $$, but fair). A great day long adventure, would highly recommend.

We were really surprised at how much there was to see. There were so many caves to explore. Take really good flash lights. The visitors center will let you borrow them for free which surprised me but you had to have them back by 4:30. The views from the campgrounds were so beautiful. The campground itself was OK if you like being on top of one another. The fee was only $10. per night. Luckily we were there in the fall when most people weren't camping anymore. Make sure to go to the visitors center first and do the bat screening. Once we asked what it was about we found out how important it was. They ask a few questions and then depending upon if you have been in caves back east you will need to have your camera wiped down and your shoes. Millions of bats are dying from a disease. There was so much history about the Modoc Indian wars we didn't know about.

Have been here twice as I enjoy touring Ft. Jefferson and learning a little more each time of the history behind the fort. The surrounding views are free of houses, condos, etc. Both times we have gone snorkeling and enjoyed every minute. There are several ways to get there based on price.

We started in Oklahoma City and went on a big "Out West" tour and Bryce Canyon was our FAVORITE PLACE! It is gorgeous! Wanted to spend more time here. I suggest spending 2-3 days here if you want to hike all the trails and take your time. We only had a half of a day and didn't get to hike down though the trails. So disappointed! The views from the view points are breathtaking. I can not even imagine how gorgeous they would be to actually get down into the Hoodoos and the Spires. If you only have 3-5 hours it is still worth going! If you can not hike the paved walkways to look out points are worth the stop. It is $25 a car. BUY AN AMERICAN THE BEAUTIFUL PASS before you go out west to National Parks. It 9ays for itself!

Having not ever heard of Capitol Reef NP before our recent trip, I have to agree with the many fans who have reviewed it. We had incredibly good luck in that we arrived on the first sunny, rain-free day they'd had in a long time. Besides the amazing rock formations and long, beautiful vistas, there is the opportunity to pick fruit at Fruita (apples and pears in mid--September), free to eat there or $1/lb to take with you. We also hiked along the river and then as far up the side of a cliff as we felt comfortable. The day was warm, but as we gained elevation, there was a strong, cool breeze. There were a few other people hiking, and a fair amount of traffic along the scenic route, but it never seemed crowded, and you could tell from the way the other travelers were soaking in the beauty that they were as charmed by this park as we were. We also stopped to see the petroglyphs, and drove far enough along the drive past Capitol Dome to see a tiny historic cabin. If you want a great overlook for an amazing view of this area, there are some not to be missed along Utah Highway 12. We arrived in the area via this road after dark, but backtracked to see the overlooks after exploring Capitol Reef. Definitely worth the twenty-minute back track, which was much faster when not dodging cows on the road in the dark! Reading some of the other reviews, there were enough things we missed that I would definitely return to this park again, and hope for another stroke of luck weather wise!
Disappointing to pay money for vacation and all the govt shutdowns we had to deal with. Sad story, but we found other things to visit instead.
A must see. free admission.

Haleakala is a place that you must see wether you are visiting Maui or living on Maui. It is a very long drive up, and there's a fee that you pay (which is good for two to three days) but it's worth being at the top of the island looking at Maui, and actually seeing Big Island too.

This hike was scary (at first); thrilling (hiking in the dark); informative (Ranger talks enroute); exciting (descending into the canyon); awe inspiring (upon arriving at the canyon floor, BEAUTIFUL with the full moon illuminating the hoodoos a silver-gray, clear black sky filled with stars); exhausting (ascending back up). Our hike took us to the canyon floor, a place the Ranger called the “badlands,” a 700 ft. elevation change from the rim. You have to wait in line at the Visitor’s Center the morning of the hike to get your free ticket. We got there at 5:30AM, and by the time the doors opened at 8, there easily were more than 60 people to take the 60 tickets they had to give out (two hikes went out that night). We probably could have gotten a ticket if we would have arrived at 6AM, however, during the summer months, the Ranger told us arriving very early is necessary, especially if you have a big group. You need to be wearing, or have with you, the shoes you’ll wear (lug soles required) and everybody in your party has to be there to get their ticket. We’re seniors (in our early 70s) and this hike was awesome; a definite Bucket List addition if you like the outdoors and rigorous activity! We hiked Queens Garden/half Navajo the same afternoon and that helped because we were somewhat familiar with the terrain, even though our Full Moon hike took us on different trails to the canyon floor.

About 18 miles south of St. Augustine on A1A. Free admission. This fort guarded the southern route into the city at the Matanzas inlet. You ride across the river in a very small ferry. The fort itself is not very big, but gives you an idea of the remoteness of wild Spanish Florida in the 1700's for the 17 men who were stationed there for a month at a time. The quarters are furnished, so you can see how they lived, what they ate, and what they did. The guides are extremely knowledgeable and helpful. A must see!

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: We stopped at Visitors Center and bought the CD of information that tells of each stop. It is $10 but you will get 1 admission free at the Texas White House. It is worth it. We enjoyed each stop. We toured the schoolhouse, Viewed the beautiful cemetery where he and Lady Bird and extended family are buried. You can only view cemetery from the fence. His birth home is interesting and it has restroom facilities behind it. This working ranch is beautiful. The cows roam freely. We saw deer and another exotic animal that looked like an antelope. Loved seeing the presidential jet and hangar. But the favorite it is the tour of the Texas White House! I believe it was $3 to go in. Guided tour of the downstairs. Loved seeing his office! But the whole living area is amazing, their clothes hanging in their closets etc. Don't miss seeing this historical place!

It was a beautiful morning and we got there early before it opened,it was nice because it was just us and a other couple and we got to actually stand and look at this beautiful monument without all the people and the noise. We did not pay to park because we was there before it opened. We stayed in Keystone it was 2 miles from Rushmore.

The minute you get close to this man made wonder you get goose bumps just seeing it's size. Everything is well laid out and organized right from the $11.00 yearly parking pass to the people that work there and are very helpful. there are park rangers walking everywhere to assist or tell you you can't do this or that. Parking is great and it is wheel chair friendly. Lots of washrooms and gift and food vendors. this should be on every ones bucket list and a must do when in South Dakota. The road is easily traveled to get there and if you want to do something more senic and adventurous take Old Iron Mountain Road back but beware you can not take a trailer or motorhome because the road has small tunnels and does a switch back affect to go through the vast forest. You will also see Buffalo and other wildlife. The park is not Pet friendly and they will not let them come out of your vehicle so leave them out of this trip. Mount Rushmore is definetly a must see.Very good visit.
We didn't have time to hike. Just rode through. Fortunately we were not on our motorcycle, because we got caught on the Pass in a fierce storm! Was still a beautiful ride!

There is a small fee and well worth it. There are lots of cannons to view, locations of battles are well marked; plaques to explain locations. There are 1000's of acres dedicated to this. Don't forget to drive past the main visitor building 1/4 mile down the road there is more. You can spend all day here.

A visit to Springfield to learn about Abraham Lincoln should include a visit here. The house is maintained by the National Park Service and includes a visitor center. The streets adjacent to the house are closed to traffic. Several neighboring houses have also been restored to their mid-19th century appearance and a few contain complementary exhibits related to the Lincoln Home. This is the only home that Lincoln owned and the family occupied it for almost 20 years. The house is furnished approximately as it looked in 1860 and contains some furnishings that belonged to the Lincoln family. The NPS guides are very informative although they may be rushed on a busy day. Tours are limited and require timed tickets available at the visitor center. There is a nominal fee for parking. Downtown Springfield with other Lincoln attractions is nearby.

park: Brown v. Board of Education National Historic Site
text: We stopped here on first arriving in Topeka and got a great feel for the history and background of events leading up to the landmark Supreme Court decision to end school segregation. The lessons were all the more poignant coming in the actual school building where the case was brought. I did not know that Kansas segregated on a separate but equal principle that was actually close to reality unlike many southern states but the case was settled on the notion that separate meant unequal regardless the conditions and could not be sanctioned. The politics of the court first passing on the case and a Republican President appointing Earl Warren who effectively created a unanimous court decision a year later strikes me as a great irony, given the present day antics of Ike's party. Admission is free and there is a National Park ranger on the premises to answer questions. Allow 1-2 hours. Worth a look especially if you are interested in the important historical turning points of our country.

This is a venue for any type of physical abilities. You can drive to different locations and park and hike, although there is limited parking. If you are a civil war buff have at it. OR Take the tram (bus) from the park headquarters back and forth from the park to the town proper of Harpers Ferry. At Harper's Ferry a short walk from the bus drop off, see the the town as it was way back when. . . Walk along the Potomac River for some views, or over the river bridge to head up for some serious hiking. The town has lots of eating places, a few trinket shops, a wax museum, free entry to churches, old mansions etc. The hikes across the bridge are serious. The hike to look out Rock, which gives you view over Harpers Ferry is a favorite. It is 2.8 miles and lots of ups and downs, although it is mostly flat for walking. Good for all age groups, but you should be in pretty good shape and take water. The overlook, lets you look down on the reg. railroad tracks, and the passenger train track as well as the town. Parking is a rare commodity at Harpers although you can drive through it, but there is no place to park, so it only makes sense to go to the park headquarters to take the shuttle bus. The only cost is to get into the park for a cost of $10.00 which is good for 3 days. There was wheel chair access on the bus's. That is cool for the handicapped. This area is great for biking, since bikes can park anyplace.

We visited the Adams Historical park late on a Sunday while traveling from Providence RI to Boston MA. The interstate signage to the visitor center in downtown Quincy is small, requires quick turns in heavy traffic and totally inadequate. The visitor center was closed on Sunday PM but we visited the "Old House" and found the one hour tour of the house, library building and gardens well worth the time and fee. The guide was very knowledgeable of the Adams family history and the property history but lacking in details about the furnishings. Also the guide was not afraid to express political sentiments offensive to those of us from the South. We plan to come back and see the other buildings of the site and the visitor center film in the Spring.

Unfortunately the glacier is melting..so it is not that impressive from the park hiking trail. But it's free admission, the hiking trail will get you very close to the glacier. We joined a guided tour by a very experienced and knowledgeable park ranger, learned a lot from the short trail and went on for a longer one. .

Stopped by Fort Clatsop on our way to Astoria. We only stayed for about an hour due to time constraints, but on the random day we were there, it was not crowded. We were more interested in the scenery than history, and there are some nice scenic trails. Recommend if you need something to do to pass the time!

Best way to see the forest is on the DSN&G steam train, especially if you want to get up close to the raging Animas River and the gorgeous scenery! We upgraded to first class parlor car, were able to spend most of time on back platform of rear car getting fantastic video and pictures and enjoying the fresh mountain air! The downside: the first class cabins are more expensive, you need last car on train for standing on rear platform; first class has liquor for sale, and most of the guests in our parlor car were pretty drunk on the return trip, loud, and definitely lost their initial fear of stepping onto the back platform to look over the cliff down to the Animas River. The upside: because they were so drunk, they stayed inside the parlor car the majority of time drinking and partying, so we had the back platform to ourselves for most of the way up to Silverton and back to Durango on a fabulous sunny day for riding the train in the cool mountain air and sun! Well worth the cost of the trip! The photos and memories are priceless!

We went to Bryce Canyon after two days at the Grand Canyon. I wondered how it would be different and I sure wasn't disappointed! Bryce Canyon has hoodoos - thousands of them :) We got up early and watched the sun rise over the hoodoos and into the canyon. Then we did two of the moderate hikes - you just have to go down into the canyon - don't just stay up on the rim. Getting down in there and being close to the hoodoos was so much fun! Be sure to pack plenty of water and pay attention to the 'grades' they give the hikes - easy, moderate, strenuous - they are right on the money. The second day, we drove to the far end of the canyon and then drove back, stopping at each and every lookout. Again, I couldn't believe how the views changed each time. We kept saying over and over again, "This is my favorite view!" We packed in our lunches both days, which made it easy to just stop and eat along the hikes. The Park Rangers at the Visitor's Center are very helpful in planning your trip!

While the key attraction at Capitol Reef and the reason this area was set aside as a national park is the beautiful geology, this park also offers many other reasons to visit including Fremont Indian petroglyphs, pioneer history, preserved remains of a Mormon frontier town with pick-your-own orchards, Wild-West history, such as a Butch Cassidy hideout, and backcountry adventures. Much of this is accessible along Rt 24 at no cost but even the scenic drive and access to some of the better hikes is only $5. Capitol Reef is named for geology; Capitol for the sandstone domes that look like a capitol dome and Reef for the fold in the Earth known as a monocline, named the Waterpocket Fold, which was a barrier to travel like a reef at sea. The Waterpocket Fold got its name for the pockets eroded in the monocline fold that hold water year round. Highlights of the visit for us were the scenic drive and the Notom-Bullfrog road which provided different perspectives of the Waterpocket Fold; our two favorite hikes, the Cassidy Arch trail and Capitol Gorge trail; the remains of Fruita with the flowering orchards during our spring visit and the Gifford Homestead with the wonderful homemade fruit pies; and, for the kids, the Junior Geology badge. If one has a high clearance 4x4 vehicle, one can visit the backcountry Cathedral Valley section with its famous monoliths and true solitude. This often overlooked national park is very worthwhile for visits of half a day to several days depending upon one’s time and interests.

We travel the 2 hours to Cuyahoga Valley National Park every few months. It is close to the Ohio Turnpike, Interstate 77 and Route 8.We enjoy all 4 seasons in the park ! We usually stay overnight in Independence, Ohio and enjoy the park for 2 full days. Independence is clean, safe, has a lot of good hotels and restaurants and is close to the Cuyahoga National Valley Railroad and the Towpath Trail off of Rockside Road. There is no entrance fee for the park.The park has activities for all levels. For those with limited abilities, there is the railroad ( fee ), long drives, short hikes. For those who love more active days, there are the great bicycle paths, the ski trails (fee), and the numerous hiking trails. We love biking the Towpath Trail. It is realatively flat and has interesting and beautiful stops along the way. You can rent a bicycle in Penninsula, Ohio, if you are unable to bring your own.Penninsula is also a great place to stop for a meal while biking, hiking, or taking the train ride. You can even bike 1 way and ride the train back for a fee for you and your bicycle. Our favorite hiking trail is Ledges.It reminds us of Hocking Hills. It is full of beautiful rock formations. We also enjoy Brandywine Falls. Some trails connect to other trails. Pets are welcome.The park is home to many birds and animals, the Cuyahoga River, waterfalls, small lakes, hills, old canal locks, a quarry, Hale Farm, Boston Mills Ski Resort, and and Blossom Music Center. Some areas have flush toilets, while others have pit toilets. Bring water. Make sure that you pick up a park map and individual trail maps at the trail heads.

We had three very full days at the Apostle Islands. Day 1: we took our bikes to Madeleine Island on the ferry and rode to the state park, which is a pleasant ride with a worthy payoff. The park has a scenic area on the water, next to sea caves. Day 2: We took cruises to Stockton Island and Raspberry Island, so we could see other islands. The islands have wonderful beaches with clear water. Raspberry Island has a historic lighthouse and a ranger gives a good tour. You can also take a short hike. Day 3: We had a pre-arranged kayak tour with Living Adventures, a local kayak tour company. For $99, they drive you to Myers Beach, give you a demonstration, and the group with two guides kayaks along the shore, in and out of sea caves. It was an experience I'll never forget. It happened to be foggy and eerie - all the better. At noon-ish, we stopped for lunch on the beach, and the guides set up a table with delicious wrap sandwiches, drinks, cookies - very tasty. Then we headed back to Myers Beach. It was a full and busy trip. Be prepared - weather can change instantly, although we traveled during a hot spell. If you like kayaking, hiking and biking, you can do all of these at the Apostle Islands. We have not been to Pictured Rocks in Michigan UP - that's probably next.

Malta Lava, need I say more? yes, because there's a 100 character minimum. So... spend a day or two staying around Volcanoes village uptop... Check into the NPS visitor center, find a ranger program, hike down into the crater and walk on the cooled lava lake on the Kilauea Iki Trail, find the lava tubes, then check out other entrance area stuff. Next day drive down to the coast and hike out to the lava that flowed over the road, watching for Nene's. Third day... pay to go see the flowing lava and ocean entry.... normally I wouldn't pay for a guide into a National Park, but in this case, it was a must to poke a stick into the lava. wow. This place was awesome!

The National Park Service have acquired 4 blocks in the center of Springfield, with the only home ever owned by Lincoln adjacent to the central intersection. This allows it to be car-free and a haven of tranquillity. The free tour of the home is well worth taking, even if you have to wait a while for a free time slot; our guide was knowledgeable and explained things very well. Look out for the original furniture, as well as the great attention to detail where original artefacts are lost. Make sure you take enough time to look at the adjacent properties, including the Arnold house which has an interesting exhibition on how the buildings in the vicinity have been preserved and restored. But note that not all the neighborhood homes are always open. Finally, make sure that you buy a parking ticket for long enough - I had to rush back as I had initially only purchased a one hour ticket (from the machine). There's cheaper parking nearby, but as the main visit is free, I was pleased to support the Park Service by using the official car park.

We traveled to the Redwood region of California in May of 2013. We stayed in Arcata and drove into the area the next morning. It was an easy drive from there and we were able to see everything that we wanted to see. I would say that if you have not been to the region before, make sure that you take a few minutes to look at a map before you start out. It's a little confusing because there is a National Park (but no fee) as well as State Parks and Beach areas that are all part of the same area. Once you have a plan, head on out...there are so many sights to see that you just can't go wrong. The groves of trees are just amazing and breathtaking. Even if you don't plan to spend days in the park, make sure that you take a walk around the Ladybird Johnson Grove. It's an easy walk and you get to see a great sample of the Redwoods. We hit this area early in the morning and it was so quiet and peaceful. Just us and the trees. It was a great time for some introspection. You definitely feel small!

Check out the national park website ( siign up for a password to access and use in the future) for the "reservation, timed" tickets which lets you into the roped off cluster of buildings, access to the park itself and buildings, a ranger 30 min guided tour and access to the other buildings ( Congress hall, building where a copy of the Declaration and Constitution and inkwell are kept) ..all for a $1.50 each ticket reservation fee. Entrance is free, but you need this entrance ticket to the "park" itself or you can't get anywhere near the buildings , only can view from across Chestnut street or behind the guildings from the park. Getting the reserved tickets lets you choose when you will visit, and also saves you from waiting in what can be a huge line , especially if there are large groups of schoolchildren in the visitors Center. Note: The Visitors Center is about 2short blocks north ...all on Independence Mall. The rangers who lead the 30-person tours are informative and more than willing to answer questions, but you need to have done a bit of Americqn History homework to know what to ask. The tour of the Declaration House and congress house are not to be missed as the "plans" for the very existence of America were discussed, writtn and signed in the very rooms you stand in.

We really enjoyed the visit. The tour is well organized, the guides were very knowlageable of the Adams family and history of the USA at the period. We suggest that you park near the "old house" on 135 adams st, (gps), there you can by tickets for the tour (5 $) and the shuttle thakes you to the visitors center where it starts. in the visitor center we enjoyed a short film about the Adams family four generations and their part in the history of US. It is great for those who do not have time for the tour (about 1.5 hour)

Did Zion the previous day. What a contrast of the two National Parks. Unbelievable what nature can do to the land. We stopped at all of the viewpoints along the 17 mile road in the park and each one was different and spectacular. The road in the park is a dead end so you have to come back out the same way, but you will notice other views on the return trip. Don't miss this park! Fee is $25/car if you don't have a senior or seasonal pass.

see Lincoln's home exactly as it existed in 1860. Also, the entire 2 block area has been restored to mid-1800 vintage. Just like walking back in time. Priceless. No fee for touring the house and the entire historic site, because the Lincoln family stipulated that rule when the house was turned over to the public.

Hit Mount Rushmore after meal at Alpine Inn in Hill City. came in the back way so got to see Washington's profile. Stayed for the evening lighting show. very nicely done and worth the time if you have it. parking pass is good for a year so you could go during day and come back another night. Did not get to do the trail. would like to make it back and walk that since it brings you closer to the mountain.

My husband and I, along with some friends, took our kids to visit this place. We arrived and paid for parking. $2 for 2 hours of parking. Not too bad. Then we went in to get a tour. The tours are FREE. Nice to find something for free when everything is so pricey these days. You do have to go with a group though so you need to make sure to get a time for a tour. We got our time and met at the specified spot. The park rangers took us through a narrated tour. Pictures are okay to take but we were not allowed to touch anything. After the tour we wandered around the town for a while and visited some of the other houses.

There aren't too many places where one is able to see an active volcano. There were many steam vents visible. Alas, no flowing lava during our visit. There is much to see & do if you have the time to spend: visitor's center, 30' film, hiking trails, volcano crater viewing area. The park rangers & volunteers are all knowledgeable & helpful. There is a minimal parking fee for the attraction.

They have great, short hikes were you can get a little higher for a good view of the city. And you get to see a lot of petroglyphs (big rocks with drawings on them). They look neat and are interesting. You only pay a couple bucks for parking. There are multiple sites, unfortunately when we went some were closed due to the shutdown. Would love to go again and see what we missed!

Start with the interpretative center and spend some time looking at the exhibits. This was the home of the Lewis and Clark expedition while it wintered over in 1805. If you are interested in American history, this is a "must visit" stop. Friendly staff, well versed and ablt to answer even my mundane questions. The actual fort will take about 15 minutes to visit. Plan a two hour plus stop for this one. Part of the National Park system, fee unless you have the card. I feel this is wheelchair accessible but may take some effort. The interpretative center is handicap accessible. No camping, park closes at 5:00 PM.

Great way to see and learn about ancient Hawaiian culture. Excellent exhibits and self guided tour. Also located next to a very nice snorkel area. Admission to the park is free. Recommend a morning visit as it does get quite warm and there is minimal shade. Also, bring water and snacks as closest snack place is at least 15 minute drive away. Recommend combining this with a visit to Captain Cook Monument area and then continue south to Southern Most Point of the US.

There are several tours each day at the visitor's center given by uniformed park rangers. In addition, you can get a map and do-it-yourself instructions so you can drive around the battlefield yourself. Or, ultimately, hire a private guide at the visitor's center for $75. He will drive your car and spend nearly 3 hours discussing every aspect of the battle.

park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
text: GPS brought us a very round-about way to Appomattox Court House. It enabled us to see some of the nicest views of the rolling hills of Virginia that we would have missed on the highway, but there were no services along the back-country roads. Thus our disappointment when we arrived at the park to find there are no snacks available. It was a very cold, windy day and we were unable to enjoy walking through the park, so I'm sure our discomfort is the reason I would only rate Appomattox Court House "average". The unheated buildings were very cold, and the museum was so dark we could barely see the exhibits. The films were informative, but very old. I hope the National Park Service is able to update this important part of American history. Appomattox Court House has a great story to tell. Admission is free if you have a National Park senior pass.

park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park
text: Very impressive ranch-- a working farm with all in costume describing what it was like back in 1918 (no electricity on the farm)- sure makes you think! The overall site is massive, the Texas White House complete with 7000 ffoot long airstrip, cattle everywhere. The house tour is very impressive. Free but $3 for house tour-don't miss it

We spent two months touring the West Coast of America recently and we are glad that we took the time to visit Grand Teton. It is a very attractive park with lots of wild life and a must see and well worth the drive from Salt Lake City. We had a lovely camping spot just beside Jackson Lake and it was wonderful being able to see the stars at night from the camp site. There are many pleasant walks around the park and the walk to Jenny and Taggart Lakes is very attractive. As we visited several national parks on our trip we found it useful to purchase the annual pass to get into the parks because it is more convenient and a saving in costs overall.

Wonderful visitor center and less crowded than Gettysburg can get. Should always see both if in the area for any length of time. the visitor center is a good way to start and learn about the complex battlefield. Stay in Hagerstown for a cheap hotel that is right between Gettysburg and Antietam.

When we arrived at Jewel Cave there was only the $5.00 tour available. Yes you get to go inside the cave but only to a platform to listen to the ranger's speech. Taking the longer tour would be much more informative and fun. Call ahead to make sure that there are available tours as it is quite a drive to get there.

Very interesting and beautiful view of the river. Great place for a picnic or a hike. Highly recommend if you are in the area. No fee to visit. Close to Land Between the Lakes and Paris State Park. Beautiful area.

I took my mother, who is 73, to Springfield this summer to see much of the history there. We started with The Lincoln Home Historical Site, which was a perfect way to begin. The visitor center is comfortable and filled with informative things to do. The park area around the home is lovely and quite interesting. The home itself is stunning. The park rangers who serve as tour guides are informative and relaxed and the whole visit moved at a comfortable pace. Young or old, this is a must see, and the tour and park are free to the public. All you have to pay for is parking.

If you're interersted in history or the Civil War, this is a must. The battle here was much more significant and costly than many people realize, and a visit there was a great way to learn about it. The visitor's center has a nice movie, 30 minutes long, that gives great overview of the battle. Right when that ended, we were able to catch a 30-minute ranger talk up in the observation area, which really helped orient us. After that, a walk through the museum was the final way to get acquainted with the battle before going out on the self guided auto tour. I'm thinking a guided driving tour with a ranger would have been best. We've done that in Gettysburg and it's fantastic. But this time we purchased the CD for $20. A little bit steep, but considering HOW CHEAP it is to get in the center itself it was no biggie. It was only $6 for BOTH of us for three days. Insane. I almost wish they would charge more so they could maybe make some improvements. Sadly this place has not been given the attention it deserves like Gettysburg has, but I hope it does because it should. The museum could be much larger I think... Make sure to plan about three hours for the driving tour, not the 1.5 to 2 hours they recommend. We felt rushed. Generally I would recommend doing Antietam first and then Gettysburg, if you haven't been to either yet.

While this park was not on my bucket list it certainly should have been. Admission is very cheap ($3) and admits you to a life event of walking and exploring a true desert. The dune life nature trail and the Alkali Flats trail are a most for adventurers. Be sure to bring plenty of water and sun protection with you as the hike is approximately 6 miles in total but offers spectacular views and experiences of waling in an alien world. I would not recommend this for children. The visitors center does offer snow sled rentals that you can use to go sledding on the sand dunes. Walking though the desert and finishing our trek as the sun set behind the mountains is surely a life event not to be forgotten. (The hike is perhaps not so highly recommended at the height of summer)

We were here last month on a visit with family. It took a little more than a couple hours to cover the park and drive through it with stops along the way. The Cottonwood Ranger station had some great Rangers who were very helpful and informative. If your lucky you'll see Tarantulas crossing the road. We looked but no luck. Great park. I love photography and this was a great place for pictures. We had a National Park Pass and got in free. Worth the visit!

This is a must see. There are so many walking and hiking opportunities in this unique high desert. We only did a short hike in one part of the park but it was awe inspiring. Well worth the $15.00 per car pass (good for the week). It was so peaceful and serene I thought I may have left planet earth for a short while.

This is a remarkable place - miles of sparkling white gypsum sand that looks more like snow - except for the yuccas! For a cost of $3 each, it is well worth a visit! We did the sunset walk, which was gorgeous as we were rewarded with a fabulous sunset against the sands. The ranger was also knowledgeable and explained how the sands formed and about the wildlife and plants. The next day we hied to the 'lake' (now dried) which is about a 5-mile round trip. Do this in the morning before it gets warm - we set off at around 8.00 am and it took a couple of hours (including taking plenty of photos). You may want to take water with you too - especially if it's hot. We also wore proper hiking boots/footwear, which helped us keep going. The visitor centre is also worth a look and we'd recommend the short film. Watch out for white lizards, which have adapted over time to be camouflaged against the surroundings.
