A friend and I spent one night in Oyster Point Campground. While well off the beaten path, this US Forest Service campground in Croatan Natl Forest was very convenient to our hiking trail. We met the campground hosts, Tonia, Will and Max (puppy). They were nice, helpful and apparently took great care of the area, it was very clean and seemed well maintained. There are only 10 or so sites, all primitive, fairly large, several located on the river with a path from the site to the waters edge. Wooded, dirt road, couple of large clean privies. Each site has a picnic table, fire pit, concrete pad, and hanging hook. The daily rate is $8, max stay is 14 days. We enjoyed our stay and will use the campground again when in the area.

Tumacacori is on the 'must see' list of historic sites in southern AZ. Although abandoned long ago, it is still in remarkably good shape, a testimony to the skill of the native builders centuries ago. This is an easy tour, with a well-marked and annotated guide and well worth the stop. Admission is modest (free with a Golden Eagle Pass) and there are a number of unusual places close by. This is well worth a visit.

This one was of the highlights of our 2 weeks in Hawaii. It was one of the reasons we chose to visit Maui. It was just as spectacular as we imagined it would be. We hiked into the floor of the crater on the sliding sands trail and then along a side trail around one of the cinder cones. It took us over 5 hours to hike in and then back out but it was so worth it. We got there early in the day and enjoyed such amazing vistas. The clouds were rolling in as we were hiking out but that made for some amazing photos as well. It was a tough hike out as all the reviews warned it would be. But if you take your time and lots of water it is worth every step. There are some great views from the lookout but there is nothing like walking into the crater. Would love to do it again only camp inside the crater and walk out the next day ! This is a must do if you go to Maui. The park fee was nominal and the park pass was good for 3 days so we used it the next day when we went to the Oheo gulch and Pippiwa trail.

Don't let the $5 entrance fee fool you, THIS IS NO "LESSER" PARK. I would say this one of big 4 (along with Bryce, Zion and Arches). It doesn't get promoted as much, but it is really spectacular and has some really amazing hikes. It's rainbow of colorful rocks. Visitor's center is fabulous. Some hikes were closed due to rock fall, but no problem as there are lots of options. Even just driving around is amazing.

This place is amazing, and is a real bargain too - only $3 per person. You'll find miles and miles of gigantic white sand dunes to explore. I've never seen anything like this anywhere else. The sand is soft and fun to play in. You can bring or buy sleds at the gift shop to use on the massive sand dunes, which is quite an experience. It's a little like snow after a massive blizzard without the cold and wet. There are several hiking trails available, all of which I found to be worthwhile, and you can even camp out overnight if you get a permit at the visitor's center. This place greatly exceeded my expectations. If you're in the area, don't hesitate to visit; you will not regret the experience.

Nice to wander about the area - dipping in and out of all the important museums. The area houses the liberty bell and independence hall - both free tours that cover so much important history and a must see. Constitution centre (fee) also worth seeing for its significance. Our friends missed it (as didn't want to pay the fee) which is a real shame for them.

The Visitor's Center is the place to start--go there first to get tickets to Independence Hall (free). The Liberty Bell building is free and no ticket required. Films in the Visitor's Center are good--we actually saw them at the end of our day before heading home. Everything in historic Philadelphia is within walking distance, so just park your car & put on your walking shoes. You can park in the garage underneath and walk right into the visitor's center. (Worth the cost to park there!) Park rangers give excellent tours of Independence Hall and Congress Hall. Sad to find out that the Todd House/Wright House were closed (due to the sequester cuts), but most of the sites were open and extremely interesting. Not to be missed if you have a day in Philadelphia.

Located south of Willcox, Arizona are the Chiricahua National Monument, Fort Bowie National Historic Site, and a little known Historic Site in Turkey Canyon - the grave of John Ringo. If one makes the loop from I-10 near Willcox on US-191, AZ-181, and AZ-186 he or she will pass Pearce, Arizona a Ghost Town, and Turkey Canyon. Going up 8.4 miles in Turkey Canyon to the left is a turnout and fence, and if one parks there he or she can walk the short path to the John Ringo site. Leaving Turkey Canyon, one passes the entry to Chiricahua N.M., an excellent one-day adventure and arrives at the entry road to Fort Bowie NHS.

This national monument is certainly a "don't miss!" I wish we'd had more time to spend here and enjoy more of the trails throughout the area. The sand is pure white and very fine and is spectacular against the blue sky. The gift shop at the visitor center rents or sells plastic sleds to slide down the huge dunes. We brought our own and it was all kinds of fun. Cost of admission is certainly reasonable but we were admitted free with our senior pass. There is a large area for picnicking and each table is protected from the sun by a curved roof which is artistic in and of itself.

We visited the Joshua Tree National Park on a Friday morning. It's a good 60-mile drive from Palm Desert to the south entrance. We used our senior pass for entry and started the long leisurely drive through the park. The early portions of the park are a little short on too many things of interest, but they have marked exhibit areas along the road with signs explaining the vegetation, wildlife, etc. The interest level rises with the elevation (to over 5,000 feet). We stopped for the 1/4 mile walk through the Cholla Garden and that was great. Once into the Joshua tree area it was beautiful terrain with huge boulders and hills of rocks that appeared to have been dumped there by a super being. There are plenty of places to camp and picnic (which we did) and strategically placed restrooms. The park is huge and you can easily spend the better part of a day driving and sightseeing from one end to the other. Be sure you have adequate fuel before you go. All in all Joshua Tree is a jewel in the desert and worth the time and effort to visit.
Remote - scenic - historic - environmentally significant. Those words describes the Dry Tortugas National Park. It's a fascinating place. It's costly to get there but well worth the price.

Of course you can't pass up Mount Rushmore if you're passing through, although I wouldn't have made the trip just for this. Doesn't really take long to see, however scenery is georgeous. Very interesting to see.

Visited this park this past weekend. Weather was less than perfect, but there is a wonderful visitor's center with great exhibits, and 2 wonderful films. The rangers were very helpful with maps and suggestions for trails. They still had room for the Gap Cave tour (only 15 people per tour), but we did not have the time to attend. (only $8 per person). Also, they have a tour to Hensley settlement, but it closed for the winter 10/31. There is no entrance fee, but nominal charges for the ranger led tours. The view from the pinnacle overlook is outstanding, and you can drive there. There are also several civil war cannons in this park. Would love to go back and see more of this great park.

The basic tour of Mammoth Cave was $5/person for 1 hour 15 minutes. This tour was pretty short (didn't last the whole time allotted), and they basically take you a short distance down in the cave and then right back out. The most problematic thing about the tours is the large number of people on each tour with only 1 ranger. If you don't stick close to the front, you won't hear anything. Even though there wasn't a large group with us, the tour was pretty basic and short - thought we would get a lot more out of it.

The trip up to Haleakala was WELL worth the drive and getting up at 4:30 am to drive up there for sunrise! We stayed in Lahaina and while the drive was made in the dark, what beauty awaits you when you arrive 10,023 feet above sea level! We walked down into crater and anyone who takes time to drive up, really should take time to walk down into the crater. Breathtaking views when not immersed in the clouds but be patient, as they will pass and you'll be left with some the bluest sky. Must also experience the absolute silence standing and taking in the views of the barren landscape! HIGHLY RECOMMEND this tour. Look at a half day of time to devote to this and DRESS WARMLY as it is cold up there!!

My husband and I went on the ferry boat trip to The Dry Tortugas in late September as part of a Key West long weekend. At first we hesitated because of the time (early rise - all day away) and money (couple/few hundred bucks) but then we decided to go for it. We bought our tickets from the ticket office the night before and arrived on time for check in and departure. (I have been sick while deep sea fishing so I took one Dramamine one hour before travel but I probably would have been ok without it as it was a fairly calm ride.) The boat was neat, clean, and well organized. After the passengers got situated an appetizing cold breakfast buffet was set out that included bagels, cereals, juices, fruit, and coffee. The trip to The Dry Tortugas was in full sun on deck coming (and going) so sun screen and a hat was a must. We stayed on deck the whole time but inside I think there was a snorkeling how-to video (gear was provided but we brought our own) and another on the history of the island. Eventually a speck in the distance became the island. It was breathtaking how a fortress just "appeared" out of the blue of the ocean. The boat docked and passengers disembarked. Lunch would be served in about an hour. My husband went to snorkel and I opted for the fort tour led by a Park Ranger/ferry boat guide. The tour and tour guide were both interesting and I was quite entertained by the history and lore surrounding that massive structure. It was hot, much of the tour was in direct sunlight, and some walking and stair climbing was involved. Nothing I would call strenuous but proper clothing, footwear and sunblock would aid to your enjoyment of the outing. After the tour we returned to the boat for a lunch buffet of sandwiches, sides, and sodas. It was all nicely presented and delicious. Despite those childhood warnings we went swimming immediately after we ate - snorkeling in fact! My husband thought the best snorkeling he'd found was out to a buoy and then back along the side of the fort. We headed out to the buoy, and then snorkeled two sides of the fort (one was calm and one was a little rougher - but neither was too challenging for even a novice snorkeler). All offered great views of sea life. Thankfully NO JELLY FISH at the fort although we saw lots on the boat rides. Check the most recent reviews for daily conditions. We were concerned and got lucky. Jelly fish would have been a deal breaker for us considering the cost of the trip. When time was up we boarded the boat (roll call was taken) and enjoyed background music and an open bar serving soft drinks and reasonably priced (and tasty!) tropical concoctions and beer. We relaxed on the return trip to Key West and reflected on a fabulous day of fun in the sun on The Dry Tortugas.

Went here with some visiting relatives. The house and furnishings are very interesting and informative. The ranger giving the presentation gave alot of information but was overly canned, as well as threatening everyone with arrest and handcuffing if they stepped of the carpet runner, which was annoying and unnecessarily aggressive. The ticket office reported the tour was about 20 minutes, but because of the rambling presentation, it took over 50 minutes. The ranger was very knowledgeable and was able to answer any question completely.

The Visitor Center (check out the movies) will give you a free tour ticket. It was neat to go through the house that Lincoln and his family actually lived in. We loved learning and seeing how they lived (Lincoln had his own bedroom, the tiny kitchen, etc.). There was more on the block to see ,including the train depot, but it was a rainly and cold day so we skipped it.

I was surprised that "Lincoln's Home" included "Lincoln's neighborhood" as it once was. Four blocks make up the National Historic Site with the Lincoln family house in the center. You can wander through the neighborhood on your own -- a few of the houses have exhibits inside, which are worth checking out. You need to get a ticket from the visitor center to go on a guided tour of the Lincoln's house-- be aware that there are stairs and it is not friendly to the physically challenged.

We stopped by on a whim to break up a 6hr car trip. So glad we did! 11, 9, and 7 yr old all commented that it far exceeded their expectation. We opted not for trolley ($17pp). We did the great intro movie in the visitors center then drove the 10mi loop. We used the audio prompts available by mobile phone (free). Stopped by the soldiers huts, the national arch, and Washington's headquarters. We all got a good history lesson and a great boost of patriotic pride.

This is a serene-looking national park. Dotted with Joshua trees, of course, but more amazing are the rock formations of different heights, shapes, & the "clear air" around you. This must also be a favorite of mountain climbers; there were several of them around. Also, there is an area where you can look down & see where the San Andreas fault goes through (as pointed by a huge picture posted at the look-out). We were there this past Veteran's Day weekend & the park's entry fee was waived. Thank you, JT!

There is no admission to the park or to ride the ferry to get to the actual fort. Take bug spray as we were swarmed with mosquitoes, rangers said they've never seen it so bad. Rangers were very knowledgeable and friendly. Beautiful beach spot right across A1A.

The drive is a very long and winding road, be sure that you have filled up the tank and pack some water and snacks. The drive is beautiful and there are a ton of places to stop and take pictures of the view and many waterfalls along the way. If you get car sick easily, be sure to make the necessary preparations, because you will get car sick. Once you arrive at the national park and have paid you $10 park admission, drive up to the main parking area and park. You can enter the gift shop and get maps and ask any questions you may have. There are 2 paths, the shorter path leads to the lower pools, and the longer path lead to the 200 foot waterfall and bamboo forest. I strongly suggest taking the longer path first. The lower pools are nice, but the other path is by far the best. Be sure to pack waters. This hike is long and considered difficult by some, so again if you have health issues, be careful. Honestly, as we got about 2/3rds of the way through, I was getting skeptical, even considered stopping. I am so thankful that we didn't. The bamboo forests was like something out of a fairy tale, and then as you walk out of the bamboo forest and continue about 75 yard, you get to see this amazing 200' waterfall. You can walk up to it and stand beneath and feel the exhilaration rain down on your head. It is simply one of the most memorable moments you will ever have. Don't pass up this opportunity. I'm sure that it will not be long before they regulate how close you can get to the bottom of the falls, and I am sure üit's just a matter of time. Anyhow, this was one of the best thing to see in Maui. A definite must see.

My husband and I were in Springfield and visited the Lincoln Home. The tour was wonderful. We spent the enter afternoon walking through the historic district and enjoyed the tour guides who were very knowledgeable and personable. They answered all questions. It was a great day and educational experience. There is a small fee for the tour but well worth it. You can walk around the area on your own without the tour.

This national park has a visitors' center with a multimedia presentation that overviews it's history. There are also five miles of paths that provide walking/running/biking opportunities through farmlands and wetlands and that pass refurbished historic homes. Hartwell's Tavern is a must. In the warm seasons, there are costumed rangers, musket shooting, lectures, and so forth. Major battle spots are marked with signs. The site of Paul Revere's capture is also there. Take a long stroll or go there to get your exercise, but do go.

Fascinating Pre-Civil War history and education, unanswered questions and myriad curiosities, swimming in clear, turquoise waters on white sandy beaches, amazing snorkeling, ideas for future camping under the starriest skies, and fun ferry ride make this a day trip we will never forget. It will cost a premium to go via ferry (or private seaplane, if you're inclined), but between the two meals, the trip (including choppy waters on the way back--be forewarned), and the feeling of remoteness makes this a top ten travel adventure along the Eastern seaboard. After all, you're about 70 miles from the Southernmost point in the U.S., and deep within the Gulf where they have confirmed and reconfirmed through numerous tests that BP didn't leave its imprint.

Visited the park Thanksgiving week 2013. It is amazing, much more than I expected. It is the 15th largest and least visited National Park so you will not see a crowd. Day 1 we went to the Lost Mine trail in the Chisnos Mtns and the view from the top was great that day. On the way there was actually snow in the dessert which was a rare treat from what we were told. The trail itself was easy to navigate and had a lot of switchbacks. My 9 year old daughter paced our family the entire time. The view from the top is worth the trip up. The next day we went to the Santa Elena Canyon side of the park via Jeep tour. Probably could have just as easily done this by ourselves like the other areas but wanted to try something different. If you book a jeep tour recommend you make sure that you at least get some back road travel, ours did not. Santa Elena is spectacular as well and there is a short hike back into the canyon. There were several points of interest along the way that we stopped as well. Our 3rd day we went to the Rio Grande/Boquillas area. We took the Boquillas International Ferry (heavy sarcasm but that's what they call it) to Mexico for some shopping and lunch and felt safe and enjoyed ourselves. There is plenty of evidence of illegal border crossing activity as there are many locations that have souvenirs for sale on the US side and a bucket for $ donations. We saw a couple of folks that had canoed across the Rio Grande to sing for the tourists, kind of comical and never felt threatened. There is small cave at the end of the trail that you can climb up to. Kids of all ages enjoyed.

This is an awesome place to check out. The tour guides are very informative and friendly. The cost is minimal for the tours and well worth it. Do not wear shorts or tank tops because it is cool down there. Also, wear good walking shoes and preferably closed toe.

Seeing volcanoes was the main reason I wen to Hawaii, so this was the key place to visit. The park has various options for hiking, but you do need a car to get there, and to get around to the different parts (unless you do one of the preplanned bus tours). (There is a vehicle fee, good for 7 days.) I spent 3 days at the park, and there was lots more I could have done. Note that you are not going to get close to live eruptions - if anything like that is going on they close the area because of the danger (including gasses).

The museum at the Visitor's Center is interesting and the friendly park rangers share information about recent wildlife activity. The road up to Montezuma Pass Overlook is gravel and a little steep, but the views are spectacular. A short hike up to Coronado's Peak is rewarded with more amazing views. Great way to spend an afternoon or morning.

I had no idea what to expect, but this place was amazing. We found many areas to watch the rock climbers, take photos, enjoy the weather in November. We came from Colorado so the landscape was very different and so beautiful. There are many areas for photo ops and areas to hike. You can spend hours there! The $10/car fee is well worth it for entry. Plan to stay as long as you can, take in the vast expanse as you can see for miles. Awesome sunsets!

We planned to visit Mt Rushmore and other National parks this October, when the shutdown happened al of the sudden and we had to shift the itinerary slightly. We were so lucky that by the time of our trip all parks were opened and we were so much happy to visit Mt Rushmore and the Custer State park. Very impressive! We came twice to the monument, because the parking fee was valid till the end of 2013. One day it was snowy and the weather was changing from snowfall to bright sun. Another day was just sun and blue sky. Definitely, the monument looks great against the blue sky. The Presidential Trail allows you to see the faces from different points of view and the trail is not difficult at all. We also liked the Made in USA store and had very good lunch at the Presidential Cafe. Both places highly recommended. We stayed in the Holiday Inn in Keystone.

We visited on a weekday morning, so there weren't many other visitors. The tour is free, but you need to get a ticket from the desk at the Visitor's Center. There is a parking lot next to it, and costs $2/hour. Note that it is on a one way street - we had to go around the block to get into the parking lot.

A great learning experience for the whole family for very little money. The trolley/ bus ride by itself is worth the price of admission. A year ound attraction that can be enjoed all four seasons here in greater Boston/ New England.

This is an amazing trip. We took the boat and love it. I was with an 8 yr old girl and she loved it too. She was not bored on the boat, they show videos of snorkeling, etc. and point things out along the way. We were lucky to have a gorgeous day. The weather plays a big role in this trip. If you have a bad day, it might not be as much fun. We toured the fort, snorkeled swam, walked the moat and looked at fish 0- basically just explored. It's amazing. I totally forgot to look at the birds! Even brough binoculars, but I was so blown away by the fish I forgot!!! The crew on the yankee freedome was great. Food was perfect. I was a little put off by the crew at the end of the trip standing at the exit with a tip bucket. It just rubbed me the wrong way since I just paid over $200 for the trip. I would not have minded tipping, but I didn't like the feeling of being shamed into it by them holding a bucket and staring at me. That really bothered me. I would tell anyone to do this trip, but maybe book it once you know the weather - this trip will go even if the weather is bad and sea is rough so you might want to make sure it's going to be a decent day. Don't forget a towel and water shoes - it can be rocky in the water. Most important, bring your camera!!!!

Our day began very early (5:30 AM) and the boat left the dock at 8:00. When we returned at 5:30PM I was more than ready to be back. The time at Fort Jefferson was too short to make 5 hours on a boat in fairly rough seas worth the trip and the $300 it took for me and my husband to make it. If we had it to do over again we would have paid the money to take a sea plane out to the fort, or perhaps one of the overnight fishing trips available from Key West. However, the staff of the Yankee Freedom was very, very professional and did a very good job.

Amazing place with an amazing story! We visited the Tortugas National Park by seaplane a while back. It was recommend that we fly for both time savings (long journey) and the scenery. I was hesitant due to the added expense but it was worth every penny. Not only did we see things that we otherwise would not have, but moment the clouds broke revealing the fort it was like a scene out of a movie. Breathtaking! The Gulf waters of this area are full of beautiful colors, sea life and fantastic snorkeling. If you enjoy history you should not miss this.

Took the 2.5 hr ferry ride with Yankee Freedom from Key West to Ft Jefferson (breakfast & lunch included). Make sure you use the coupon inside one of the tour books available at all the visitor centers and bring your student ID for extra discount if you have one. I ended up paying $155. Normal price is $170 for adults. Staff were friendly and attentive, constantly checking on everyone. If you drive your car, there's a covered parking lot across the street for $10/day.
This is a hidden gem, which is hardly advertised, the entry into the Park is a modest €5 and your ticket lasts the week.

Each time we have visited Key West, we have missed out on visiting Dry Tortugas National Park. When I saw the cost of the ferry trip for our recent visit, I almost didn't make a reservation, but I am so glad I did! We had a great crew on the boat ride over and back and they also assisted us on the island (I will review the boat separately). I also thought it might be boring visiting Fort Jefferson. It was anything but that and it was a very interesting tour. My husband snorkeled (equipment included in the cost) and I just relaxed on the beach after touring the fort. Breakfast and lunch were included in the price. By far this was one of the best things we have done during our 5 visits to Key West and can't wait to do it again!

During the winter months the rangers only offer two types of tours. There is a brief 20 minute tour offered at 9:05, 12:45 and 3:45. We took the hour and twenty minute scenic tour which is offered at 10 and 2 costing $8. I would call a head and confirm the tour times. The rangers were all very nice. Our guide was Kate who was very interesting and really knew all about the cave. This tour does have a lot of stairs but it's not strenuous. Since we were there in December, we were the only ones on the tour. I really like visiting National Parks during the winter months. They are less crowded and the rangers are more laid back without large crowds to deal with. Being winter, the 49 degrees in the cave was about the same temperature as outside. If you are visiting during the summer you may want to bring along a light jacket.

We decided on seeing sunset at the summit so we could enjoy the drive up and we are so glad we did, We were amazed at the change in landscapes as we got higher and the view going up was something to see and experience. Take note the ticket booth doesn't give change for your park pass so have the $10 per car. Once at the top we stopped at the crater lookout.....that is a sight in itself looking over into that vast area with all the changes in colors.. Wow. We arrived at the summit lookout about 45 min from sunset.. Took a look around at the observation area with all the great information, It was cold and windy but we were prepared and dressed for the occasion, Our biggest laugh of the day was seeing everyone wrapped in the striped hotel towels and even one lady in a bedspread. Not everyone reads trip advisor before taking this trip I guess :). As the sun went down I realized that the observatory that is at the summit (not open to public) sits directly in front of where the sunset would take place so after a few photos and some deliberation we decided our best view would be a little down the mountain at one of the lookouts so that's what we did and it was amazing, the view of sunset was stunning. We stopped at a couple different places and even made it out of the park area before dark. Maybe the sun sets a bit farther north so the observatory isn't always in the way but in December it sure was. I'm glad we chose to descend for some shots, This was worth the drive and even if you aren't keen on sunrise do this instead, Equally amazing!

Park rangers were well versed and knowledgeable. There is no entry fee to the park and the fort is only a short ferry ride away. A period role player was very entertaining with his stories of life at the fort. Definitely worth the visit. We thoroughly enjoyed the tour.

Haleakala National Park is not just a sunrise. First, it has two components 1) The summit 2) Kipahulu coast. Check out both if you parts if you can. The two areas however, are not connected so will likely require too different days to explore. The summit is great to see the variety of climates/scenery on Maui. It changes dramatically green pastures to panoramas that are more reminiscent of a martian landscape. I would recommend taking some time to explore the sliding sands trail that starts from the upper visitors center. It was amazing! On the Kipahulu coast, definitely take the Pipiwai trail up to see the Waimoku falls and the bamboo forest. This was also a must do in Maui. Once you get down from the hike, take a short hike to the O'heo gulch and cool off and go swimming in the freshwater pools fed by small series of waterfalls. The park has a lot to offer, definitely check it out! Oh, and save your entry receipt because the $10 entry gets you into both sections on different days.

I've visited here three times in the last year - once with my teenage brother-in-law, once with with a gang of 20 teenaged Boy Scouts, and once with a pair of friends when we walked in on the AT. It was enjoyable by all three groups, and is a great deal at only $10 per carload (Thanks national parks system!)

I was taken pass the Quincy area in Boston and down Adam house learning some of the history of US by friends. It was beginning to snow and was informed that the John Adams house is closed now but when opened, I can get ticket for the tour at the Quincy College nearby then tour the small house with small rooms full of many nice things with history. I will come again and see inside for myself

This year we were fortunate enough to get the last 2 places on the River Styx tour, right to river level. Well worth the tour price, with knowledgeable guides as always. Note to viewers: may be worth booking in advance if you are thinking of this tour, although the other tours are also very interesting. Also explored some of the surrounding countryside this year, including the Green River ferry. Very relaxing.

A cousin of mine recomended this trip when he heard we were going to Key West. When I saw the price I was hesitant, but after reading all the positive reviews on Trip Advisor decided to go ahead. This was probably the best excursion my wife and I have ever taken!!! In fact, after what we experienced it was CHEAP for what we got! I walked the windward side of the beach to Palm Key and took some of the prettiest pictures ever! My advice...read up on it and GO!

Hovenweep is a little out of the way and not too well known. The sites are remarkably interesting. That is why it is not touristy and crowded. The road is good to get there. There are restrooms, gift shop and a helpful Ranger to take your fee and answer questions. She gave us great advice and directions.

While the ruins are relatively new, the look like remnants of a distant era and they are. American history is so dynamic…. At some point, more than 4000 soldiers and civilians lived here, and now it is a ghost town. The location is spectacular. The view are astounding. A pleasant walk of 1.6 miles allows to "take the place in" and it is really worth it. $3/person, free to National Park pass holders. So glad to have seen it. A well kept place, and a memorable experience.

Well preserved buildings, free entry (though some buildings you can only enter with guide) and knowledgeable staff. Nearby there is the Christ Church Burial Ground where you can see Benjamin Franklin's grave. There is a fee for going into the cemetery or you can walk along the fence perimeter and you can see his tombstone through the fence.
So the ferry ticket out to the park is kinda steep, but for about $5 more you can camp overnight on this unique historic site in the middle of nowhere.

Get a good tan on the boat to Tortuga. When you are there you can snorkel and swim in the rief. You can also take a tour in the fort and learn some history, or Watch birds and beach Life. If you want you can camp on Tortuga for 3 dollar a night

We decided to make the trip from Kona to VNP and back in one day and found it very doable. The road to and from has a lot of curves, so if you don’t like to drive curvy roads in the dark (coming back) I wouldn’t do it. We had no problems and still spent 6-7 hours in the park. Make sure you fill up the car before you leave, gas is limited and costly on this road. There is a $10 per car entrance fee into VNP, but we thought it was well worth the money paid. The park is laid out very well and the visitor center is a must stop. The park rangers were very helpful and shared the important places to visit. Here are the stops we made: Visitor Center, Volcano House, Jagger Museum, Steam vents, Thurston Lava Tube, Chain of Craters Road, ending our tour at the Jagger Museum. Plenty of stops along the way to take pictures of the beautiful scenery. The two highlights for us were the walk at the end of chain of craters road (over the lava flow) and the night-time viewing of Kilauea Crater (glowing red lava). While it was a fairly long day (11 hours) from the time we left Kona until we returned it was well worth the trip. Note: we also stopped at South Point and Punaluu County Beach Park (a black sand beach) on the way to VNP, so if you didn’t do that it would only be about 9.5 hours.

We stopped here at the end of our Christmas road trip. There is a small visitors center with exhibits and a tiny gift shop. There is no cafe, and only vending machines if you are hungry. But that's not why you come here. You're here to see the cave. Discovered in the early 1900s by the Michaud brothers who tried to make this a tourist attraction, Jewel Cave was a commercial flop. It became part of the Park Service. Today only a portion of the cave has been explored. In order to see the cave you must take a tour. There are various tours of different lengths and abilities. The only one available to us when we went was the shortest tour and it was free if you had a park pass. The guide took us by elevator down about 240 feet where we entered a large cavern lit with electric lights. It had intricate formations that we could see from the large metal platform we were standing on. The guide told us about the cave and the formations and that was the tour. Then we took the elevator up again. Katherine, our guide was very knowledgeable and friendly, and answered all our questions. The only thing I would do differently is get there earlier and take a longer tour.

Any time I pass through New Mexico on I-40 I MUST veer off the interstate and take an hour on the top of the sandstone bluffs overlooking the lava flows. I discovered this spot by accident when I got curious upon seeing the sign on 40. Wanted to catch one last sight in NM. As if I already knew where to go, I pulled onto a gravel road 10 minutes south of 40 and ended up on the bluffs. When I'm here I feel completely at peace. This place feels absolutely sacred, especially since many people don't know it exists. It is very quiet and out of three visits (2 during the peak of tourist season) I have never encountered a living soul. Walked right along the edge of the towering cliffs with my dog, neither of us concerned with worldly distractions. Last time we stopped it was snowing and the desert was covering with a light dusting - just enough to add to the desert's beauty without completely masking the land. The clouds cleared quickly to expose the mountains within them, like billowing smoke below a baby blue sky. This is where I go to rediscover myself and clear my head of all stresses. It doesn't matter how much time you spend here. You will be enlightened nonetheless.

Seeing Mount Rushmore was such a moving experience! Nature's beauty and man's creative artistry all rolled into one. The hike around the monument was really enjoyable. It was sad to see that some people actually had the stones to drop litter along the way, but the site was kept up well and clean - and the ranger at the admission area was cheerful, helpful and pleasant. We had close parking (trip was end of Aug) and were able to get great views. Got to see lots of wildlife, including a mountain goat. Went back to see the patriotic night time service where veteran's were honored. So glad we went during the day and then also attended the night time service - doing both proved to be worth the time and effort. One of the nicest experiences we've ever had as a family!

The Visitor's Center is the "must start" jumping off point for your day. This is where you can get your tickets to Independence Hall and I will tell you to get there early as they are free and go fast. You MUST have a ticket for Independence Hall. They also have tons of brochures for attractions iin the area and there is also a vendor to schedule 90 minute bus tours (at a cost) as well as making other tour arrangements. Think about a walking tour of the Ghosts of Philadelphia. There is a place to get sandwiches and snacks but no formal restaurant that I could see. There is a gift shop and clean rest rooms. They have some actors in period clothes to talk with the kids and get them in the right frame of mind.

We visited that park and started off at the visitors centre where we learnt of the best sights to see. We went to the steam vents first which was spectacular!! We were here on a sunny day right after days of rain so they were really letting off steam! We went to jagger museum and saw the Kilauea crater which was fantastic, didn't see any lava but saw plenty of smoke. It would be amazing to be here at night as it has a red glow to the volcano. The road from jagger museum to the other side of the crater was closed due to volcanic activity. We then went to the thurston lava tube I was hesitant about going in these lava tubes as I thought it may be claustrophobic but it was fine! The tube could fit a large car inside them and it was well lit up and an amazing feeling. We drove past and stopped at a few pit craters and drove down to the 2003 lava that blocked the road off near the ocean lava was everywhere it was incredible too see!! We spent 4.5 hours in the park and I think that's the absolute minimum time you should spend here to really enjoy everything. It is a $10 fee to enter per car valid for 7 days that goes toward improving the park. One tip is they have a few places to get a beverage but not anywhere to eat we were starving when we left so bring some snacks at minimum!

In 1880 Robert Lincoln, son of Abraham and Mary Lincoln, sold this home to the city for $1 with the promise that it would be maintained and that visitors could always tour the home with no admission fee. Well, 134 years later, amazingly the home has been maintained correctly and there is still free admission.

For two teens and a 9 year old, most historical landmarks and such get pretty boring. We had a blast sledding on our disks down the dunes. They rent them to you for $14 but we bought ours at Big 5 Sporting Goods in Alamogordo for $10! Take a picnic lunch.

A short but steep hike from the visitor center winds up through switchbacks to a nice cliff dwelling where you can walk around most of the dwelling. Along the way you get to see the beautiful scenery of a saguaro cactus forest and vistas going off several miles down to Lake Roosevelt. Well worth an hour to spend at the monument, and the drive to the monument is beautiful enough to make the time pass quickly.

This was worth the drive from Kansas! Parking is about $11 but we went on Christmas eve (was open) and there was no parking fee :) The displays and exhibition rooms were worth it, if you are one to not just take the views but spend some time reading. Wheelchair accessible.

We took the ferry and had a wonderful time. I had concerns about it being a crowded ferry, but there was plenty of room to sit either inside or out, and to easily move around so it never felt crowded. The optional tour of the island was done in small groups. The crew was truly amazing. They were enthusiastic, helpful and kind, and really went out of their way with the guests. The breakfast and lunch were very good. The weather wasn't spectacular for us, but we had a very good time. You need to book the trip way in advance. It is expensive, but the fee includes everything for the day, and totally worthwhile to visit this amazing place.

Great hiking. Unique, fantastic views of volcanoes. Interesting presentations. $10 for whole week! See my individual reviews for Kilauea Iki Crater Trail, Thurston Lava Tube, and Jaggar Museum Lava Overlook.

We spent an afternoon and evening and the next day visiting this park and felt it was enough time. Rt. 12 goes right through the northern section of this park; there really is no “entrance.” or “exit.” Arriving at 3PM, we spent time at the Visitors’ Center (be sure to see the film “Watermark”) , headed back to Torrey for a bite of dinner, then headed back to Panorama Point (right off Rt. 12) to watch sundown. The skies were threatening, with rain afar, and we got some awesome pictures of rainbows. The next day we visited Frutia, a restored Mormon settlement, very near Rt. 12. Get there early to have a selection of the homemade pie. You can pick apples, on the honor-system for payment, in the orchards that are still maintained there. There is also a hike that starts there, following the Fremont River. Frutia gives you a feeling of peace; it’s very peaceful there. A short distance east of Frutia on Rt. 12 we visited the petroglyphs and the School House. We got lucky and joined a Ranger-led group and saw petroglyphs we otherwise may have missed. The Scenic Drive is a 16-mile round trip drive that goes south from Frutia and it is breathtakingly beautiful! The second night we returned to Panorama Point (we were the only ones left at nightfall, a bit spooky) to view the stars. Capitol Reef has some of the best naturally dark night sky viewing of the western national parks. It was a clear night and the stars and the Milky Way in the dark night sky were amazing! You could also just use some of the turnoffs off Rt. 12 for this night sky viewing.

We took our children ranging from infant to 12 yrs. to the Steam Festival. The infamous 119 steam engine was there and we were able to tour it and see it in motion. Really a beautiful machine! We also got to ride the hand-cart and ride on a little motorized cart on up and down the tracks. There is a little museum with a interesting movie about the history of the Golden Spike. We all really enjoyed ourselves, all the employees were very friendly and informative. I think it was only $5.00 for our carload, so a real inexpensive family friendly activity. They have several events throughout the year.

We went there on Dec. 27th 2013. The first tour was 9am, got there early and had a private tour. Melissa was a great tour guide and answered all of our questions and let us take as many pictures as we wanted. Many of the furnishings are the original. They even found a swatch of the wall paper from the Lincoln bedroom that they have recreated. This is run by the National Parks Service and is free of charge. The houses surrounding Lincoln's home are also part of the restoration. We also visited the Lincoln Museum and tomb. Both are a must see.

We visited the Big island last year & really enjoyed it. One of the highlights was our visit to the Volcanoes National Park. Terrific sights you won't see anywhere else. Take the Chain Road & allow time (more than they say) to get out at some of the waysides to enjoy & experience the vastness of the lava flows that created this island. Make sure you're at the Visitor Center/Observation platform at dusk/dark. The glow at night is simply awesome. It can be VERY windy & cold so make sure you bring a jacket with you. The National Park Service has a great center that will take you through the history & geologic make up of the volcanoes. There is a fee but its free if you go on a Federal holiday

The Visitor Center is very informative on the history of the mountain, the art behind the mountain, and the history since then. If you are counting on getting in with the National Park Pass, think again. The parking has been contracted out, so there is a fee. Good news is that the fee works for multiple days. If you get the chance, get a cone of Thomas Jefferson's ice cream. The BEST ever!

Spent a day in this park. $10 entry fee is good for a week. Make sure you drive the road of craters down to the lava going across the road by the ocean - really interesting. The crater rim and steam vent walks are good and suitable for most anyone as is the lava tube walk. Definitely make sure you visit the Jaggar Museum around sunset so you can see the glow of the lava. Well worth at least a day in this park.

My friend and I stopped at the gift shop to buy sleds ($10/each new; $8/each used, I think) to play in the sands. Also sat and watched a 17min video on the park at the info center. There is a $3 fee/person to enter the Dunes. Dogs on leash are also welcomed. Lots of picnic areas toward the end of the loop, so bring water and food because there's none available for sale after you enter the Dunes. We had so much fun running up and sledding down the dunes. It's worth the climb to get some of the better views, but really not a bad seat in the house. I'd recommend a handkerchief to wrap around your nose/mouth if you don't want sand in those orifices. Beware: you will get sand EVERYWHERE. :) Fun for all.

Fort Matanzas National Monument is free to visit. It is a nice way to spend an hour or two. There is a small gift shop and video room showing a 8 minute video on the forts history. Make sure to get a ferry ticket from the gift shop to go see the actual fort. The ticket is free and the ferry usually leaves every half hour. Picnic tables are available if you would like to bring a picnic lunch.

Park provides multiple options for viewing volcanoes depending on your time availability. Stop in at the visitor center at the beginning of your visit to get suggestions from the rangers. We drove the craters and road south to lava fields near the ocean (Chain of Craters Rd) as well as the Jagger Museum and lava flow nearby after dark. The latter was a bit disappointing as you're not able to get too close, but that's entirely understandable and something to see nonetheless. The park entrance fee is good for a week allowing for return visits if you're staying in the area. Multiple hiking opportunities if you're so inclined with different levels of intensity.
We arrived at sunset, surprised that there was a fee to drive in.

White Sands are not sand, it is gypsum. The same white chalk like stuff that is in wall board or sheet rock. I arrived just after a heavy rain the first time what a mess. The second time the park was open late for a full moon. They also stay open for special nights like predicted meteor showers and on a clear night it gets cold so be prepared. If you are in the area this is a great 1/2 day excursion. Yes there is a national park fee. This is one of the natural wonders that can be seen from space. Pretty neat place.

Took a seaplane here. Worth the extra $125/person because of the time it took (40 minutes vs. 2 hours and 20 minutes by ferry), because of the view, and because I get seasick! Enjoyed touring the fort, and snorkeling - the best place to see fish was near the piles and against the fort walls!

If you love history, you must see Mission San Xavier and on the same day you could also drive farther up the road past Tubac (3 miles) to Tumacacori Historical Park. It only costs 3 bucks for entry (unless you are a senior for which you can buy a 10 pass good forever at all national parks!). On the Sunday I went there was an 11 a.m. guided tour and Joan was just terrific with interesting information. Go on a beautiful day, enjoy the guided tour and also free native craft exhibits, such as tortilla making & hand-tooled leather goods. You could plan to eat lunch in Tubac on your way home.
Took the float plane ($300 vs. $150 ferry ride) Fun day! I really appreciated that our government makes this site available to all and is professionally managed. My favorite day in Key West!

Desert vegetation is nothing short of fascinating, not to mention the piles of great rocks which have a unique origin, formed under the ground and pushed up as they are. The best parts of the park are concentrated in the norther fork - though of course all the roads have interesting vistas. Watching climbers - will ropes, totally free climbing and on slack bands - oh my goodness. This park is definitely best during cooler seasons; heat and mid-day sun can be dangerous. Follow rangers' directions and caveats. Remember to use your 62+ $10 card to visit, if anyone in your party is in that age group. And the trails are friendly to seniors as well.

We were very excited to drive over from the Kona region to explore Volcanoes National Park. It's a fair drive away, but we drove along the North shore and stopped at multiple breathtaking waterfalls, and a botanical garden along the way. I recommend leaving at daybreak, as you'll need all the time you can get, and will definitely return after dark. Also, make sure you have LOTS of film/space on your memory card. There is an entrance fee to get into the park, but it is relative to the experience. There is so much to see onsite, lots of wildlife as well! The lava tunnel was very interesting, but not good if you're claustrophobic, and the steam vent was neat to experience as well. Part of the park was closed down while I was there due to toxic fumes coming up from the earth. It was very cool to see the craters, and the lava flow, where it had solidified over time. There are placards all over the place with a lot of info to keep you informed. Dining and bathroom facilities onsite, as well as gift shops, but all very overpriced. You cannot actually SEE the active lava flow in the National park, which is a bit of a disappointment if you weren't aware previously, but we spoke with our concierge before leaving Kona. He told us about a road located about a half hour up the road, backtracking toward Hilo. **You MUST do this after dark, or it is pointless, so go to this after the National Park** You drive down this road for approximately 25 mins, and it feels as though you are driving into the middle of nowhere. The road cuts off into what is basically a dirt path into the jungle, but don't panic! It's not the developing horror story that it feels like. At the end of the dirt road there is a field in which you can park and walk up to a small makeshift market. The market has coconuts for sale, as well as lava photos and other items. On the other side of the market a path leads over hardened lava flow, which is difficult to navigate, so be very cautious, even though it is well marked. You must bring your own flashlight with you, and I recommend one per person as it's pitch black. try to purchase your flashlight at a wal-mart in Hilo or Kona, as they are available onsite, but with an extreme markup. The path over the lava opens onto an open area where you can see the active lava in the distance popping and splashing up. This is the closest you can get to active lava flows without hiring a helicopter or a boat tour to take you, and there is no entrance fee. I would speak with your concierge about it so they can give you clear directions on a map. This part of my day trip was definitely an unexpected highlight, but the actual National park is worth every second of the daylight hours you have!
Our family stopped here on our way down the Oregon Coast. Assuming we were going to pay about $50 for our family to get in, we were amazed by the LOW COST of admission - less than $20??
This park is easy to pass up, but we found it very enjoyable. Hiked over an hour through the lava fields and mangrove forests. A volunteer geologist was conducting a tour while we were there

We visited in January so there were no crowds, in fact I would say it was exclusive for our visit. We talked with 2 different park rangers who were so helpful we felt like family, thank you. We were not sure what to expect but we were wowed by its awesomeness, really, what a great sight. The parking is a fantastic convenience, I didn't mind paying $11 as it was steps away from the gift shop and everything. The restaurant food was great even thou there were 4 people there at lunchtime, including us!

Nice clean historical place. Loved it , restaurants are great , lots to chose from, loved the bison burger, it's kinda of a of WOW place, go see it. History you gotta love it. There is a price to park, the outside vendors are worth a shot, they have wonderful food also

The Dry Tortugas are small islands about 70 miles west of Key West. One of them houses the deteriorated remains of a civil war fort and prison. There is only one ferry boat that goes out there. It's a nice ride and they serve breakfast and lunch as part of the price, and also provide snorkeling equipment. It sounded pretty interesting so we splurged on a day at the Tortugas. Unfortunately, you can't count on the weather. So although it warm and sunny, winds had kicked up the surf pretty hard from mid-day on. Some snorkeling areas were rough for swimming and in others the waters were obscured with all the sand kicked up by wave action. And on the two-hour trip back, the sea got quite rough with several people getting very sea-sick. The ship's crew were very helpful, but overall I'm not sure the day was worth the $320 we paid for the two of us.

We visited the Joshua Tree National Park yesterday for the first time. We found it to be quite unique - huge one-of-a-kind rock formations, that draw lots of climbers, and vegetation that is unique to the area. Since I recently had knee surgery, we didn't do any hiking, just mostly stuck to the main roads for sightseeing from the car. It is a hiker's paradise though. Got a pretty good look at the San Andreas fault from one of the high vantage points. Make sure you take food and water with you as there's no food for purchase in the park. One word of advice - if you've come in at the West gate, probably best to go back out the west gate when you want to leave. My husband decided to go all the way out to the east end, and the road is torturously winding and curvy (much worse than the Road to Hana!) Note that there is a $15 fee per car to enter the park.
This is a must see while in the area. It is worth the $7 that is for sure. Give yourself plenty of time.
This was my favorite part of our 6 day vacation in Key West. Getting there isn’t cheap but it was worth every penny. If you're going by boat and the water is choppy... take the Dramamine.

At the top of every hour they have a period actor do a short history tour of the fort. This was exceptional as it really gave you a sense of why the fort was so important when it was built and how it served the settlement. Also informative on why it is such a good defensive building. All around the fort there are interesting signs that give more history. The view of the bay is really something, great place for photos! There is a fee to get in, I don't mind paying it for the work the park service does to preserve these monuments. But I understand how if you were in a large group it could start to get pricey.

Pinnacles NP is one of the release sites for the endangered California Condor - the largest North American bird. Our original goal in visiting was to see the Condors with their 25 foot wingspans. We saw 3 on our first trip, and at least 7 on our second trip, (three of the 7 sightings were for the same bird). We went into the park through the West entrance near Soledad. The 20 mile trip is on a curvy road that is frequently one lane wide, but we had no problem at all. There were plenty of spots to pull over to allow the little bit of oncoming traffic to pass. We used the Balconies loop trail which is rated as moderate, and goes through a cave. We picked up flashlights on the way. However, once we got to the park, several other middle-age couples told us that the cave is not as easy to get through as the brochure states, and they recommended head lamps and an ability to do a little climbing in the dark. We decided to hike the trail to the cave entrance, and when we saw the size of the large boulders just inside the cave, we knew that for us, we had made the right decision. The parking lot for the trail has restrooms and a picnic area. The path is well-maintained dirt, with short wooden bridges over the stream beds that normally would have water in them. The rock formations looming overhead are beautiful, and everywhere we turned was unique and scenic. The path has some ups and downs, but they were fairy easy to negotiate and not steep. On our second visit, we chose to follow the loop up to the Balconies and head towards the other cave entrance. This path climbed up through the boulders, but was never steep. The switchbacks in the trail made for a pleasant climb both up and down, with no section that left us panting for breath. When we got to the highest point on the trail, ( about 1 mile from the parking lot) we stopped for lunch and looked over into the next canyon. Several groups passed us that completed the loop through the cave, not all of them were young and super-fit, and they said they had no problem with the cave. One group even had a little one in a backpack. I highly recommend taking time to visit Pinnacles and hike this short, fairly easy trail to experience the beauty of the canyon, the chaparral and the rock formations. The condors and many other birds living in the park are an extra bonus. We saw several types of jays, titmice, sparrows, wrens and the acorn woodpecker, as well as a road-runner crossing the road. For the more intrepid, there are numerous climbing walls maintained in the park, and several long trails - we did not use these.

Every January, my family and I go on a cruise that leaves from either Tampa or Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Due to soaring airline prices, we prefer to drive down, and this was a great stop along the way. We came because we are always exploring new national parks, and we were not disappointed! Although the weather was not warm, it was not humid either, and there were no mosquitos to ruin our day. Once we arrived, we decided to take the Boardwalk Trail, which was not too long for our 7 year old son. The mangroves were amazing, the water was beautiful, and we even saw wildlife! Much to our excitement, we saw feral hogs, which are basically wild pigs. In addition, we saw turtles, birds, squirrels, and a pileated woodpecker. We have been to hundreds of national parks around the country, and I would definitely rate this one in the top 3. If I am ever in South Carolina, I will certainly make the trip to one of my favorite locations on the Eastern Seaboard.
How many places can you go, and NOT pay, for a tour and a ride on a boat to a fort. So lucky to have these National Mounments. They help us to understand our past.

We were fortunate enough to be at the Fort when there was no charge (MLK holiday). We were early, so got to take a nature hike around the area before catching the ferry to the fort, which is a short ride. Once at the Fort, got a talk by a ranger about how and why the fort was built. Ranger gave an excellent talk about the history. Well worth the trip.

went snorkeling here with Fury company. I'd recommend the double dip excursion, this way you'll get more snorkeling! Tip book in advance or online for discount rates, or search the flyers and coupon booklets you can find at your hotel!

We boarded Yankee Freedom (made reservations online - $170 each) in Key West and made the 2 1/2 hour ride to the Dry Tortugas. The crew was great and although we had terrible weather on the way out (choppy seas), they did everything possible to make it as smooth as possible. They provide meals on board as well as snorkeling equipment. Once we arrived, we had three opportunities to tour the fort plus private time to explore and snorkel. It is pricey, but I figure it's a once in a lifetime trip. Do NOT miss the chance to see this bit of history.

We took the ferry over. The only other way is to go by seaplane. Tickets on the ferry were $170 and the trip is worth it. Takes about 2.5 hours one way. The ferry serves breakfast and then lunch later in the day. One you arrive there is Fort Jefferson to tour and then of course, the good snorkeling. We saw a couple schools of parrot fish, two barracudas, and lots of small, colorful fish.

Such a wonderful day! We took the Yankee Freedom catamaran from Key West to the Dry Tortugas' Fort Jefferson. Although the crew warned we might experience some waves, the 2.5 hour trip was smooth and uneventful. The sun and temps were perfect! The crew and staff clearly enjoy their jobs and take pride in customer satisfaction, safety and informing their passengers of the history and opportunities to enjoy oneself at Fort Jefferson. From the breakfast and lunch aboard the Yankee Freedom, to the tour guides inside the fort, to the delightful sail back to Key West, the day was perfect. The history of this fort is quite interesting and worth greater research upon returning to the mainland. . While the fish did not cooperate by joining us while we were snorkeling, the beautiful water and the opportunity to snorkel in the shadow of Fort Jefferson was outstanding. Recommend taking some drinking water with you before you leave Key West as there are no water fountains on the island. And, while there are no restroom facilities on the island, the Yankee Freedom is but a stones throw from the fort and has ample restroom facilities. Lots of walking involved, as well as stairs if one wants to get the full appreciation of Fort Jefferson. Likely not a great trip for children as well as folks who might get sea sick. Well worth the price for this amazing opportunity to visit a wonderful National Park located in the Florida keys! Go! And, be grateful we have a National Park Service!

Ok, the trip to Dry Tortugas was very expensive - $329 for two of us. But, until we got to Key West, I never even knew it existed, so I had to see it. The trip takes two and a half hours each way. The boat is very comfortable, so traveling is not a problem. If you don't love just soaking up the sun and ocean breeze, then bring a book or your iPod for diversion. A lot of people slept, which just baffles me. We skipped the guided tour and explored on our own because there are very informative videos playing during the trip and the guide provides additional information. There is also printed material available to read all about the fort's history.

This gem of the National park system is often overlooked as the crowds flock to the well known Arches, Canyonlands, Bryce canyon and Zion NP's nearby, it's Red rock heaven without the crowds ! Lots of trails and a scenic drive that starts from the main hub of the park, the Gifford Homestead, offer fantastic views. The homestead is a little oasis of green with the orchards producing fruit and the river running nearby. Barns and trees dotted around with deep red rock walls all around make this a surreal and peaceful experience. There is a small fee for the scenic drive but it's worth it for the rock formations along the Waterpocket fold. Along UT24 you will find other areas of interest like the old schoolhouse and Panoramic point with hiking trails. [Note that Capitol Reef is on UT24 not route 12 as mentioned in an earlier review] UT24 is in itself a very scenic drive and combined with UT scenic 12 through Escalante is an outstanding drive that links Bryce canyon to Arches NP with a little run on I70 and is a far better option [if a little longer] than the route mapping programs, or your Sat Nav will send you.

Read this review knowing I've been spoiled by having been to Carlsbad Caverns in New Mexico. I read several other reviews of cave attractions in the area (the zip line one), but thought it would be better to give my dollars to the National Parks. I was glad I did. You don't have to pay an entry fee to get in the park which was a pleasant surprise. You also don't have to pay to park, so you can spend the day in the park for no money at all. The only thing that I saw you have to pay to enjoy are the cave tours, a back country permit or the on site hotel. The facility here is beautiful. I heard the ranger say it was three years old. There are indoor bathrooms, a very small gift shop and plenty of hiking trails and shelters to picnic. I made my reservation for the "historic" tour online a week ahead of time. When I arrived, the helpful ranger pulled up my reservation and I had my ticket with no problems at all. In the two hours before my tour started, I was able to hike a few of the trails. It was a beautiful, unusually mild February day. I'm not an avid hiker and didn't come prepared to hike. I just had water, a jacket and tennis shoes. I did fine on the main trails around the visitor center. The trail to the river was a challenge on the way up the hill for me, but a good workout. The historic cave tour itself started with warnings about health, claustrophobia and minding your children. All three warnings were for good reason. There were about 4-5 areas of the tour where at 5' 3", I had to crouch. Tall people, be warned. There was also an area of the tour ("Fat Man's Misery") where you shimmy and squeeze between these natural rock formations about 4 feet tall. The guide said the gaps are 18" wide. This was one of the highlights for me. I felt like a giant making my way through the grand canyon! Large people, claustrophobic people, special needs people, be warned. The final highlight of the tour for me was winding up several hundred stairs to get back to ground level and seeing the beautiful waterfall that had formed due to melting snow and ice. This was a challenging stairway hike, but doable for average people. I was in the front of the group just behind the guide- which I recommend for anyone not wanting to have the experience of running to catch up, listening to everyone's chatter or children and hearing the impromptu comments from the guide. The overall experience could have been better. The tour guide was a colorful Kentucky fellow really uptight about camera flashes (which I didn't mind). The tour experience depended on listening to his rendition of the cave's highlights. There were no signs anywhere in the cave- which could have provided more information. There were areas at the beginning of the cave that were poorly lit where people banged into each other. I felt this was a bigger safety hazard than a wayward camera flash. The tour was light on interesting history and facts, but still interesting. Improved lighting, some signage and more historical or geological facts would have made this a 4 or 5 star place, Definitely a worthwhile stop. A true bargain at $12 for a 2 hour experience.

Excellent trip! The experience is worth the price. You enjoy the beautiful waters of the Florida Straits as you travel for two hours to reach the fort. We took the guided tour of the fort which is included in the price. If you want to learn the history it's a must plus you will see beautiful ocean water from different areas of the fort. The snorkeling is great, go to the area where the old pier use to be located, saw the largest mangrove snappers I have ever seen. The food provided by the fish is very good and everything is clean and well organized. Before you leave visit the store in the fort get presents for grandchildren.

I went to this park on my stay in Blanding. A charge for the park is $6 per car. Not bad for what they have in park. I only like the third natural bridge in the park. The first two, I didn’t think was worth the hike so I only viewed from the parking lot site. However, the third natural bridge was worth the hike. Thank god the hike was only .5 mile. That was plus for me. I am not a fan of hiking but .5 mile was fine by me.

This unique National Park is an easy day trip from the Palm Springs/Palm Desert area. There are 3 entrances; northwest, north, and south. We entered at the northwest entrance, picked up maps and a pass at the user friendly visitor center (The rangers there are very knowledgeable about hikes, driving times, etc.) and completed two fabulous hikes. I highly recommend the Ryan Mountain hike. It's a great workout, but not overly strenuous. The scenery is absolutely spectacular, and you will be rewarded with a 360 degree view of the park when you reach the top. You start by hiking around skyscraper sized boulders and then continue up with the view and scenery getting better and better. I was waiting for John Wayne to ride up. Be forewarned: While it may be balmy and pleasant at the foot of the mountain, the weather at the top can be cold and windy (depending on the time of year). Bring plenty of warm clothing that you can layer, and don't forget a warm hat and gloves. We followed this hike with an easy, but very scenic 1 mile hike in Hidden Valley....also highly recommended (and great for kids or non-hikers). Imagine entering a valley surrounded on all sides by huge boulders. You'll think you're in an episode of the Flintstones! Excellent signage along this trail will educate you about the geology and plants. Both of these hikes can be done in a day trip to the park.

This is the latest upgrade to a fantastic vessel and crew. The three-hour ship ride to The Dry Tortugas National Park was made even more enjoyable by the latest in the line of the Yankee Freedom. It is a two level catamaran that is supported by an outstanding and dedicated staff of employees. A nutritious breakfast is served on the main deck, food that is included in the rather expensive cost of the tour. After reaching Fort Jefferson and spending an hour or so on either a guided tour staffed by one of the knowledgeable employees, a filling nutritious lunch is served, again on the main deck. Again, there is no additional charge for either the tour or the lunch. The visitors on board then are able to get snorkeling gear, again without charge, to enjoy a delightful undersea tour with all sorts of denizens at a private beach. On the return to Key West, beer is available for a small fee, while bottled water and soft drinks are free.

If you come to the Big Island , this place is a must. Bring your hiking shoes and spend the day on the many well marked trails. Most of the people who visit will stay on the buses so it's fun to get out and walk. The trails are well marked and you have numerous examples of lave flows and collapsed roads to get a unique appreciation of volcanos at work. I also recommend the drive down Crater Parkway to observe the lave/ocean interface. The cost is minimal ($10 per car). Rent a car and explore.

only took the rim trail as the idea of going down the other trail was okay but thinking about the climb back wimped out. the information was great the views were terrific. highlight 6 deer grazing and ignoring us while we took pictures this area is wheel chair accessible. it is a national park so if you have an America the beautiful pass it is free. We happened to be there on Presidents day weekend and it was free for everyone

This was our anniversary gift. We have been wanting to do this for awhile. Last year it got cancelled for weather reasons, so we tried again this year. It was worth the wait, the money and definitely the experience. To go on the seaplane to the island was great, my husband got to sit on the cockpit going over and I sat coming back. What a rush!!!! it's the closest you will get to flying as a bird. You will see islands, sharks, stingrays, turtles, sunken ships, even boats left in the water by refugees trying to reach the US soils. The park was fun, we've seen many forts, but it was ok. The beach amazing a little cold but it's February and freezing in the east cost, the water was in the low 70"s, many people snorkeled we went up to our knees. We took the two o'clock tour and it was great because the ferry leaves when we arrive so we had the island to ourselves. The only negative is that their no water, the tour included a cooler with water each guest had their own cooler but their is no running water to clean up after your swim. You are in the middle of nowhere and it felt amazing. Great Experience, I wish more people would take this adventure.

Don't let the price of the boat ride to/from the park scare you. It is worth every penny!! Great breakfast and lunch. Great views. Great snorkeling. Great history. Our group of 10 loved it!!! A once in a lifetime thing to check off your bucketlist!!

We only toured the Melrose Estate and found it very interesting and educational. The slavery display was simple but well done. The exterior of the house was under renovation, but it didn't diminish the experience. The fee to tour was minimal at $10 per adult and $5 per child. Credit cards are not accepted so bring cash.

There’s just something about this historic place. It truly makes you feel great to be an American. I didn't at all mind the $11 "parking fee". I believe in supporting our state and national parks and monuments! Everything was very well kept and clean. I WOULD have appreciated some plaques or reading materials outside the museum to clue us in to some of the history. A five star visit as it is one that everyone should do sometime and the day was just that perfect! Love this place! Plan on coming back next Christmas!

Of all the things we did while in Hawaii for two weeks this was the most unique and amazing. We've visited volcanoes before but this was the absolute best. There are actually a number of craters in the park - each a little different. And the drive to the ocean, while a little long, is well worth the effort. We had dinner at The Volcano House restaurant arriving a little before sunset. As the sun sets the steam rising from the caldera slowly begins to glow orange and just gets better as the sky darkens. There are so many things to see and do at the park plan on spending a full day. You won't be disappointed. If you have a nation parks senior pass there is no admission fee.

Went to see the ice formations. We went on a Tuesday so it wouldn't be crowded. Arrived at 6 AM and was the 5th car there. They have a lot of porta johns set up to handle the big crowds so bathroom availability should be good even with a big crowd. It is a long walk. The path over the lake was well packed and easy to walk over but it was cold the day I was there so no slush. Did find a really soft wet spot on the ice (only in one spot) so watch where you walk. As others have said it'll be about 3-4 hours. The website said there was a $3 parking fee but there wasn't anyone there when I was there to take money. When we left cars were starting to line down the road as the parking lot was full. I stayed in Ashland.

Not much to do, and the road getting here is brutal on your vehicle. Few ruins that are in stages of dilapidation, kinda cool but there are others in the southwest that are easier to get to. Welcome center isn't much, but is the only modern thing they have in this park. Decent clean bathrooms, but that's about it for the amenities. Cost is $8 per car, bring cash!

Interesting tour of the fort and an actual demonstration. Very knowledgeable staff and very affordable. If you can get a senior pass definitely do it. You can get children and several guests in with you for free.

We were down south of Tucson to specifically check out this beautiful mission. We went on President's Day and the park service was having a free admission day, but the $3 per person would have been worth it. Lovely people working the desk, we were there in time for a brief tour that starts at 11am. The guide gave us lots of information about Father Kino and the start of the mission. After that, we went on a self guided tour, with a very informative booklet of the grounds. Interesting points were described in detail in the booklet with corresponding numbers. The church was begun in 1800 and so much went on there, many people living and working on the beautiful property. Nice, easy walk through the grounds to the kiln where they made the bricks, the cemetery, the orchard. Fresh tortillas made for you, fill it with salsa and beans, no charge. You should go.

My wife and I were visiting Southern California last week from Texas and I needed something to do while she was at Disneyland with her girlfriends so I drove out to the park for a day hike. I did a little research on the internet beforehand as I was just looking for something in the moderate range with some nice views and solitude. This hike fit perfectly for what I was looking for. About 6 miles round trip with about 1000' elevation gain. Nice views from the top of Warren Peak. I saw a couple of other hikers at the beginning of the trail but no one after about the first mile or so all the way to the top and back down. I spent about an hour at the peak just relaxing and enjoying the view and solitude. The hike is very exposed to the sun so be prepared. I took a couple of 32 oz bottles of Gatorade and drank both. It also follows a sandy wash most of the way so its slow walking. It was sunny and low 80's when I did it. I wouldn't want to do this when it was very much warmer. The trail is accessed from the Black Rock Campground in the far NW corner of the park. The trailhead is to the left of campsite #30. No day use fee in this section of the park, so hiking the trail is free.

I'm so glad I stopped here to take in the amazing views! The drive out is 8 miles but that's where the tallest dunes and thus, best sledding is. You can buy sleds for $15 and they'll refund you $5 if you return them. Be warned...climbing the dunes is quite a workout at this elevation so pace yourself and bring lots of water and sunscreen. Weather was perfect in Feb but I'd imagine summer could be quite brutal. I didn't get to do any of the hikes but they looked like fun as well. Well worth the $3 admission fee! This place is a photographer's dream.

We had a great day at Dry Tortugas National Park. Granted, the weather was absolutely perfect so we really didn't have much to complain about. It was a great trip to get us out of Key West for the day. The boat ride didn't seem that long to us. The crew was very friendly and helpful and the boat made the ride very smooth even though the water seemed choppy. Breakfast and lunch was included, which was nice not to have to pay Key West prices for the day. If you are into history, the story of the fort was interesting. The snorkeling was disappointing. Not a huge variety of fish or color, but we did see a huge hermit crab. There were cocktails for sale on the way back, which also made the boat ride go by fast.

We visited by way of a seaplane. Neither my husband or I had ever been on one, so we decided to go this way.
